DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
KMT Secretary-General John Chang said strengthening the functions of the National Assembly does not mean an expansion of the assembly's power.
The China Times:
The ruling Kuomintang plans to restructure the National Assembly into a national council.
The United Daily News:
The KMT's bottom line for the constitutional amendment is that one-third of National Assembly deputies are selected under a proportional representation system.
The Liberty Times:
The KMT proposed a constitutional amendment that will require the president to deliver a state-of-the-nation report to a joint meeting of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan.
The Commons Daily:
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party reached a consensus on the proportional representation system.
The China Post:
The WTO bid will ignite cigarette price rise in Taiwan; smokers to cough up 20 percent health tax.
The Taiwan News:
Corporate crime is targeted by the Justice Ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER LEAVES FOR SEOUL FOR APEC INVESTMENT FAIR

TEXT.P: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang left for Seoul on Tuesday to attend the first investment fair sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Wang is the first ROC ministerial-level official to visit South Korea since the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in August 1992.

Wang said prior to his departure that he is going to Seoul to attend an APEC event. "Therefore my itinerary there will mostly belong to group activities, including meeting with South Korean President Kim Dae Jung," he noted.

President Kim broached the idea of holding an investment fair under the APEC framework at the 1998 APEC informal leadership meeting. Kim said the fair would stimulate investment activities in APEC countries and thus help boost their economic development and overcome regional financial woes.
Kim's proposal won unanimous support of the top leaders of all APEC member economies and South Korea was granted the right to organize the first-ever APEC investment fair from June 1 through June 5.
Wang is accompanied by a large delegation of economics officials and senior executives of private business groups on his Korean visit.
Wang said the ROC's exhibition booth at the fair will introduce the country's ambitious plan to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific business operation hub.

Another theme is to introduce Taiwan's 10 star industries -- aerospace, biotechnology/pharmaceuticals, communications, information, consumer electronics, semiconductors, precision machinery/automated technology, high-end materials, medical equipment and environmental protection, Wang said.
By 2002, Wang said, the total production of the 10 star industries will reach US$94.2 billion.
Meanwhile, Taipei-based Core Pacific Group will introduce several large investment projects with a view to attracting European, American and Japanese investors.

All of the 21 APEC member economies, including Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, have sent delegations to attend the gala. More than 2,000 companies from the APEC countries have presented dazzling exhibits and lucrative investment proposals in the fair.

In connection with the show, South Korean organizers have planed a series of speeches and workshops on new investment trends, the role of foreign capital in economic development and many other related topics.
Wang is scheduled to return to Taipei on June 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 1, or the 18th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of the French from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some like It Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The Republic of China wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles De Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu formerly had served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that has brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investor is established in Taipei.
1973: British Honduras changes its name to Belize.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointments of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the Republic of China.
1990: US President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial." (By Ben Wu) ENDIEM ZCZC CEP005 06-01-99 AIR RAID DRILL SCHEDULED FOR WEDNESDAY
Taipei, June 1 (CNA) A pre-dawn air raid drill is scheduled to be held in seven cities and counties in northern Taiwan on Wednesday, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman said.
The spokesman said that the drill, dubbed Wan An No. 22, will cover the areas of Taipei City, Taipei County, Ilan County, Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.
The 40-minute drill is set to begin at 5 a.m., featuring contingency exercises by nuclear power plants and civil groups conducting rescue and recovery operations.
The MND reminded the public to take note that those who are at home are required to turn off all lights and electricity and then quickly proceed to a basement or other shelter.
Pedestrians should follow the instructions of military or civil defense personnel in moving to appropriate shelters.
Train travel will proceed normally, as well as vehicles on the highway. However, vehicles are barred from leaving or entering a highway during the drill. Ships docked in harbors will remain there while ships that have not yet entered a harbor will not be allowed to do so during the drill.
The Sungshan Airport in Taipei, CKS International Airport in Taoyuan, and Hsiaokang Airport in Kaohsiung will operate normally. Other flights at other airports will be subject to control, meaning flights may land but not take off. Disembarking passengers will be moved to the shelters immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MINISTER WEEPS WHILE MARKING TIANANMEN MASSACRE

TEXT.P: A Canadian minister broke down and wept as he denounced the Communist Chinese government at a weekend ceremony commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre, The Globe and Mail reported Monday.

The Canadian newspaper quoted Raymond Chan, secretary of state for Asia-Pacific, as telling a gathering in Vancouver, "Human dignity and human lives are the most valuable things a nation has. No government can justify killing its own people."
With Tiananmen Square student leaders sitting nearby on Saturday, Chan attacked Beijing's excuse that the crackdown was necessary to maintain order, according to the Mail.
Chan pointed out Deng Xiaoping had argued that it was worth killing 200,000 people over 20 years if that was necessary to maintain stability in the country, the daily reported.

"That kind of barbaric statement is nonsense, and that's why it's still important, 10 years later, to continue to have these kinds of ceremonies to remember those who died and send a message that human rights is important," Chan was quoted.
At that point, Chan was overwhelmed by emotion and returned to his seat, the Mail reported.
Earlier, he said the Chinese government is changing in some areas but "dissidents and human rights activists are still being persecuted, rounded up and silenced, and we need to speak out for them."

Chan spoke at the University of British Columbia in front of a replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue erected at Beijing's Tiananmen Square in the spring of 1989 that came to symbolize the Chinese citizens' pro-democracy movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA SAYS US SHOULD CLEAN UP TOXIC WASTE ON FORMER BASES

TEXT.P: The Estrada administration hopes to negotiate with the United States government on the issue of toxic wastes reportedly found on former US military bases in the Philippines.
President Joseph Ejercito Estrada said Monday he would also take up the matter with US President Bill Clinton should they have a chance to meet.
"Well, we will make representations," the President said when asked about the issue of toxic wastes. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT SAID RISING IN THE PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Malacanang maintained Monday that investment in the Philippines as reported by the Board of Investments for March 1999 increased by 834.8 percent (P21.3 billion) from February's level of P2.278 billion.
"This shows that we are witnessing improvements in investment as we move towards the remaining months of the year," said Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican.
Barican said despite global trends of mergers and acquisitions, the Philippines is still seeing a rise in investment amounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA DENIES PI CONSTRUCTION ON SPRATLEY ISLAND

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada on Monday dismissed as speculation reports that the Philippines is planning to build structures on the Spratley islands.
"There's no truth to that. Even if we want to, we cannot finance it. We don't have the money," he said in an interview in suburban Mandaluyong City.
The Philippines is one of the six claimants to the Spratley group of islands in the South China Sea. The others are mainland China, Taiwan, Malaysia, Brunei and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S TRADE DEFICIT HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Australia's trade deficit in April hit a record high of A$1.9 (US$1.27) billion due to less exports to Asian countries and the devaluing of the local currency as financial investors worried about the current account deficit.

Federal Treasurer Peter Costello told parliament on Monday that Australian exports are still affected by the Asian financial crisis because its major trading partners, Japan and South Korea, imported less.

Figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show Australia's exports in April fell 6 percent from its March level mainly due to the decline in its exports of commodity and transport equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG TIGHT-LIPPED OVER PRESIDENTIAL BID
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, May 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Monday declined to comment on whether he would run in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, saying only that he is mindful of his supporters' encouragement and would never let them down.

Soong flew to San Francisco on Monday at the invitation of the US-based Asian Foundation and the University of California at Berkeley. He was expected to deliver a speech on Tuesday at the university on democracy in Taiwan in the 21st century.
Dozens of Soong's supporters from the "Friends of Soong Association" in the San Francisco Bay area came to the airport to greet him and urged him to run for president.
Soong thanked them for their support but did not say whether he would run.
Soong told members of the media at the airport that he would announce his decision after fully considering the question once he returns to Taiwan.
His touring of various parts of Taiwan over the past three months, though, suggests he is genuinely considering the possibility.
Soong said that people hoping for social and political change strongly support him and have expectations of him.
He said he would work hard to meet their expectations for a stable, prosperous, democratic and progressive Taiwan.

Soong had a full schedule Tuesday. He was to meet with the Asian Foundation and the mayor of San Francisco in the morning, and then deliver a speech at the University of California at Berkeley. A banquet was to be held in his honor in the evening.
Although he is not currently a government official, Soong has attracted a great deal of US attention and is considered a political heavyweight.
According to informed sources, the American Institute in Taiwan requested that US authorities treat Soong with special courtesy during his visit.
Soong received preferential treatment while passing through customs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXPORTS TO INCREASE AFTER BEIJING JOINING WTO

TEXT.P: Australia's exports to China will surge dramatically following Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization, according to Trade Minister Tim Fischer.

Fischer, who went to Beijing on May 17, told reporters that after China's entry intio the WTO the country would help buy more Australian exports and that Australia would have greater access to the Chinese market in agricultural and industrial products, including sugar, wool, barley, cotton, rice, wheat and processed foods, as well as the banking, insurance, legal and accountancy sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: GORBACHEV SEES DANGER IN US POST-COLD WAR POLICY

TEXT.P: Former leader of the Soviet Union Mikhail Gorbachev warned that the post-Cold War US policy shows the danger of trying to build a new world order based on one power and predicted that other countries would resort to more advanced weapons after watching the NATO bombings of Yugoslavia.

In a lecture to the Center for Democratic Institutions at the Australian Parliament House in Canberra on Monday, Gorbachev said the US had not tried every possible means to resolve the Kosovo situation.

He said the U.S. sought to discredit and disparage the United Nations and had abrogated to itself the role of world judge, policeman and enforcer at a time when the world was becoming more interdependent and pluralistic.
He indicated other countries, which are watching the bombings in Yugoslavia, would resort to acquiring more advanced weapons in order to defend themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE IN 90'S RANKS NINTH IN WORLD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, May 31 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate in the first nine years of this decade ranked ninth worldwide, while mainland China ranked first in growth, according to data released Monday by the World Bank (WB).
The data showed that in the first nine years of the 1990s, Taiwan's annual economic growth rate was 6.2 percent, while that of mainland China was 11.2 percent.

Worldwide the average annual economic growth rate from 1990 to 1998 was only 2.4 percent, lower than the preceding decade's average annual growth rate of 3.2 percent. The main reason for the decrease was Asia's financial turmoil in the second half of 1997, which affected economic development worldwide, according to the bank.
Bank data revealed that in the first nine years of the 1990s, only six countries with a population of more than 3 million registered annual economic growth of more than 6 percent.
Mainland China, with an annual growth rate of 11.2 percent ranked first, followed by Vietnam at 8 percent and Chile at 7.8 percent.
Singapore was fourth at 7.5 percent, followed by Sudan at 7.4 percent, Ireland and Uganda both at 7.2 percent, and Malaysia at 6.9 percent.
South Korea ranked 10th with an annual growth rate of 5.8 percent.

The report also showed that the average annual economic growth rate of the G7 countries from 1990 to 1998 period was about 2.2 percent. During that period the United States achieved annual growth of 3.1 percent, while Japan's economy grew by only 1.2 percent annually, as the country experienced its worst recession since World War II.

WB statistics also revealed that Taiwan's average annual inflation rate in the first nine years of the 1990s stood at 3.2 percent. Among countries whose economies grew more than 5 percent annually, Singapore registered the lowest average annual inflation rate at 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST 7-ELEVEN STORE OPENS IN KINMEN AMID FANFARE

TEXT.P: Taipei-based President Chain Store Corp. opened its first 7-Eleven convenience store on the frontline island of Kinmen on Tuesday.
The opening of the 24-hour store caused a stir in the usually quiet offshore defense outpost, which lies closer to the southeastern mainland Chinese coast than to Taiwan.

A large crowd of young and adult consumers, including military servicemen stationed on the island swarmed to the store to witness its opening ceremony. A number of police officers were mobilized to help maintain law and order.
Hsu Chung-jen, the company's president, said President Chain Store has opened the store mainly to serve garrison troops and civilian residents on the remote offshore island.
Despite higher transport costs, Hsu said, the company will not raise retail prices for its products.

Much to the surprise of President executives, the demand for the company's brand-named foods, including rice balls, sandwiches and shaved ice, was so high as all of them were sold out in a few minutes.

Some teenage consumers said they were excited by the opening of the 7-Eleven store. A young conscript soldier said in the past he often asked his parents in Taiwan to send him his favorite 7-Eleven trademark foods via express mail. "From now on, I need not do so," he said with a radiant smile.
To attract customers and celebrate the grand opening, the new 7-Eleven store has planned a series of promotional programs, including a soft drinks drinking contest and offering give-away toys.
Observers said the arrival of the round-the-clock convenience store may herald a significant change in retail business on the offshore frontline island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.008 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Tuesday, closing at 32.737.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.731, and had a low of 32.763.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$272.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHENG HAI' DOCK LANDING SHIP DECOMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy's "Cheng Hai" dock landing ship was decommissioned on Tuesday in a ceremony held at a military wharf in Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

The decommissioning ceremony was presided over by Chang Yi-chien, head of the fleet to which the "Cheng Hai" belonged. More than 100 naval officers and enlisted men serving on the ship and their families attended the ceremony.
The "Cheng Hai" had served in the ROC Navy for 22 years, during which time the ship had taken part in numerous transport and military training missions.
The dock landing ship, which could transport small vessels, tanks, troops and cargoes, was originally christened "Fort Marion" when it was serving in the US navy.

Launched in 1945, the ship once took part in the Korean War in the early 1950s. It also assisted in transporting goods between Taiwan and its offshore frontline islands during the 1958 Battle of the Taiwan Strait in which the Chinese communists fired on the Taiwan-held Kinmen Islands.

In 1977, the United States sold the ship to Taiwan. The ship had since been christened "Cheng Hai." Over the past 22 years, the ship had navigated more than 21,800 hours, with a total voyage of 159,100 nautical miles. A total of 15 captains once served on the ship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO PHILIPPINES RETURNS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Representative to the Philippines Chan Hsien-ching returned to Taiwan Tuesday afternoon to report on Taiwan-Philippine relations at a Legislative Yuan foreign relations committee meeting to be held Wednesday.

The Legislative Yuan invited Chan to report on relations between the two countries in light of Philippine Foreign Minister Domingo Siazon's one-sided statement on April 18 regarding the denial of an entry visa to ROC President Lee Teng-hui. The statement was issued before Lee had decided whether to visit the country.
Foreign wire services have reported that Filipino alumni of Cornell University were planning to invite Lee to a private gathering in late April. Taipei, however, has denied these reports.
The Legislative Yuan considered the Philippine government's hasty response gave a blow to the ROC government and its people, as well as to relations between the two countries.

The Philippine Presidential Office issued a second statement on April 20 indicating that it had ruled out the possibility of granting Lee a visa because of its "one China" policy and that the trip would not be helpful to maintaining regional stability.

In regard to the ROC's strong objections to the Philippine Foreign Ministry's statement, the Philippine Presidential Office issued another official statement on May 25 that pointed out that Lee had not been denied a visa, since he had not applied for one or even decided whether to attempt a visit to the country.

The statement expressed Manila's hope that inaccurate reports would not affect the Republic of China's relationship with the Philippines. The statement also included calls for continued developments and increased economic relations between the two countries.
Chan received an instruction from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs last Thursday asking him to attend the June 2 foreign relations committee meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MACHINERY FOR PLASTIC PRODUCTS POPULAR AT PARIS EXPO
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, May 31 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: A total of 48 manufacturing companies from Taiwan participated in an annual plastics-producing machinery exposition that opened Monday in a northern suburb of Paris.
Among more than 800 manufacturing companies from over 40 countries taking part in the exhibition, Taiwan's machinery makers attracted much attention and interest from the French machinery industry.
The show, which is sponsored in turns by France, Germany and Italy, is the largest of its kind in Europe and one of the most important global exhibitions of machinery for the production of plastics.

Most machinery displayed by Taiwan companies fell into one of two categories: machines with the capacity to project plastics products, and those with the capacity to make products through the vacuum mold production method.

European plastics manufacturers expressed strong interest in the Taiwan products on display, and it is expected that after the five-day exposition, Taiwan-made machinery for the production of plastics will be renowned in Europe.

Taiwan is the world's fourth-largest producer of machinery to make plastics, following the United States, Italy and Germany. In terms of export volumes, Taiwan is the world's third-largest producer, behind only Italy and Japan, said Tuan Enlei, director of Taiwan Trade Service Inc. in Paris.

The plastics industry has been a very prosperous business in Taiwan. From the production of materials and machinery to raw-materials processing, plastic mold research and development, and commodity processing, Taiwan businesses are involved in all aspects of plastics production. Tuan said that is rare among major plastics-producing countries.

Wang Cheng-chin, deputy director of the Taiwan Association of Machinery Industry, is to attend a seminar held by the host of the show. He will be interviewed by a magazine that covers the plastics industry in France. Wang is expected to introduce Taiwan's success story in the field of plastics-producing machinery production to French readers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS URGED TO PRESENT NATIONAL SECURITY POLICIES

TEXT.P: Several scholars and experts said on Tuesday that presidential candidates should present substantial policy statements on national security.
They made the remarks when they attended a seminar sponsored by Lung-chu Chen New Century Foundation on the upcoming presidential election and national security strategies.
Professor Chang Wu-chang of Tamkang University said that a presidential candidate's national security policy should be convincing, tested, workable and as well as open to debate.

Chang also stressed that there should not be too much debate on abstract ideas in regard to national security policies. The nation should learn from the past and avoid during the presidential race issues of ethnic rivalry and debates on unification.
Professor Su Chin-chiang of Nanhua Management College described the qualities of an ideal presidential candidate in regard to national security.
Su said that the ideal candidate should have the ability to deal with emergencies, to lead the armed forces and to present a clear policy on the nation's military buildup.
He said that candidates should, without going into details, be clear in the direction of their national security policies and offer voters explanations in a plain language to win their trust.

Of the four presidential hopefuls, only former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian has presented some of his opinions, he said. The others, Vice President Lien Chan, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, have yet to express their views.

Lien has the most experience in dealing with defense matters and that gives him an edge over other candidates, he said. But it remains to be seen whether he has substantial policies to offer, he added.

Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that presidential candidates should present ideas on new national defense and security measures, conduct reforms on military institutions and establish friendly relations with mainland China so as to avoid confrontations resulting from misjudgment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN DOMINANT LANGUAGE FOR MOST CHINESE STUDENTS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Mandarin is the dominant language for most Chinese students, with over six in 10 saying they spoke mainly Mandarin in school and at home in Singapore, according to a survey commissioned by The Straits Times on students' attitudes toward the language.
In contrast, English was used by only about one-third of students when speaking to their classmates. At home, English was the main language for about a quarter of pupils.
Many of the students polled in the survey also said they watched Chinese television programs and read Chinese magazines and newspapers.

They also scored better in Chinese than in English. Fifty-five percent of primary school students polled and 64 percent of those in secondary school said they managed better grades in their mother tongue than in English.
Six in 10 secondary school students spend more time on Chinese than English. But for primary school students, just over half spend more time on English than Chinese.
The survey, conducted by telephone during the first week of May, covered 725 Chinese pupils.
Half of the students from English-speaking homes find learning Chinese "difficult or very difficult," the survey said.
In contrast, the majority of the student population find the subject "easy or very easy" to cope with in school, the survey noted.
The findings suggest that more students could have problems coping with the Chinese language as the proportion of English-speaking homes rises in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER MEETS SALVADORAN PRESIDENT-ELECT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, May 31 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Premier Vincent Siew met with Salvadoran President-elect Francisco Flores on Monday for wide-ranging talks.
Siew forwarded to Flores a personal letter from ROC President Lee Teng-hui. In his letter, Lee congratulated Flores on his election as new Salvadoran president.
Flores will be sworn in as new Salvadoran head of state on Tuesday. And Siew will attend Flores' inauguration ceremony on behalf of President Lee.
During their talks, Flores, a former speaker of the Salvadoran parliament, said he has fond memory of his meeting with Lee when Lee made a state visit to El Salvador two years ago.

Flores assured Siew that he will continue promoting cooperation with the Republic of China after assuming office. He promised to travel to Taipei in September to attend a summit meeting between the ROC and six Central American countries, including El Salvador.

Flores also expressed keen interest in signing a proposed free trade agreement between the ROC and its five Central American allies. The proposed pact is a major topic to be discussed in the September summit meeting.
Siew is accompanied by a large delegation of government officials and senior business executives on his current 10-day, three-nation Central American visit.

During talks with senior Taiwan business executives, Siew said he earnestly hopes Taiwan companies will be more active and aggressive in launching investment projects in El Salvador and other Central American countries that maintain longstanding diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Siew said he has ordered the Ministry of Economic Affairs to set up a special task force to seek investment and joint-venture opportunities in Central America to facilitate Taiwan entrepreneurs' penetration of the Central American market.

Noting that the North and South Americas will certainly become a single market in the next century, Siew said Taiwan companies should set up footholds in Central America as early as possible in order to gain access into the vast North and Latin American markets.
Siew said he has spared no effort to encourage Taiwan banks to open branches in Central America to help resolve financing problems for Taiwan investors.
According to Siew, El Salvador has granted the green light to Taiwan's First Commercial Bank to set up a branch in San Salvador. If all goes smoothly, the branch will begin operations in October.
First Commercial Bank Chairman Huang Tien-lin, who accompanies Siew on his Central American visit, said the bank is also considering opening a branch in Guatemala.

Central America is one of the ROC's diplomatic stronghold as many of its diplomatic allies are located in the region. As part of its efforts to cement ties with these countries, the ROC government has been encouraging Taiwan business people to invest more in the region.
With the assistance of the ROC government, major Taiwan business groups have pooled resources to set up a Latin America investment holding company.
After extensive market research, the joint-venture holding company will launch its first investment project in Central America on Wednesday -- a garment plant in Nicaragua.

An agreement on the new investment project will be signed in Nicaragua's capital on Wednesday, said Ho Yu, president of the joint-venture holding company. The new garment plant will have a paid-in capital of US$8.5 million.

Ho said the company's next plan is to seek the opportunity to open a food processing plant in El Salvador. Meanwhile, the company also plans to invest in tourist and recreational industries in Costa Rica.

El Salvador is the second leg of Siew's current Central American visit, which will also take him to Saint Christopher and Nevis in the Caribbean. Siew already visited Guatemala before coming to San Salvador.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGDN SEEKS COOPERATION PARTNERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The emerging field of gene engineering technology can reduce the time needed for the research and development (R&D) of new drugs and associated R&D risks, said Hsu Li-chih, a member of Academia Sinica, the nation's highest academic research institution, on Tuesday.

Hsu, one of the organizers of the Canadian Gene Disease Net (CGDN), arrived in Taipei with CGDN's executive general, Ron Woznow, on Monday to raise funds for the net in a bid to promote the diagnosis and treatment of gene diseases.
Hsu said he and Woznow plan to raise US$5 million to US$10 million in Taiwan to invest in the development of gene engineering technology. The gene disease net needs at least US$25 million, he said.
Hsu has called on some government officials and businessmen to provide monetary assistance.

Major pharmaceutical-producing plants in the United States and Canada generally need to spend eight years on R&D testing of new drugs before releasing them onto the market, he said, adding that R&D costs are often as high as US$500 million, which leads to a sharp decline in profits.

Emerging gene engineering technology can shorten R&D time and lower associated risks, he said. If R&D times could be shortened by even one day, drug manufacturers could save US$5 million to US$10 million in R&D expenditures.

Hsu said Taiwan manufacturers can develop bio-technology through investing in CGDN and joining in the development of gene engineering technology. A tremendous income can be generated by participating in this field, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF PROPOSES POSTPONEMENT OF JUNE TALKS WITH ARATS

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Tuesday confirmed reports that its mainland Chinese counterpart has invited SEF officials to visit mainland China in late June for talks to arrange a Taiwan trip by mainland China's top envoy to the Republic of China.

But SEF Secretary-General Shi Huei-yow said the date chosen by the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- June 22-24 -- is inconvenient, because the SEF is already scheduled to sponsor a large-scale Dragon Boat Festival activity in Taipei for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen at that time.
Shi said he has discussed the matter with the Mainland Affairs Council, which oversees SEF operations, and added that SEF officials are willing to travel to mainland China at any time except June 22.
Shi proposed that ARATS suggest another time to continue their talks if the organization is sincere in wishing to promote bilateral exchanges.

In response to an ice-breaking visit by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to mainland China last October, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan has promised to visit Taiwan this autumn. SEF and ARATS officials have held several rounds of preparatory talks since the beginning of this year to pave the way for Wang's Taiwan trip.
SEF and ARATS are semiofficial organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO OPTIMISTIC ABOUT MAINLAND ENVOY'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China on Tuesday expressed optimism about his mainland counterpart's planned visit to Taiwan later this year.

"I believe Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will certainly visit Taiwan this autumn," said Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Koo, a veteran business tycoon and a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, made the optimistic forecast during a meeting with a Legislative Yuan subgroup, which is mainly composed of legislators from the ruling Kuomintang.
Wang promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan this spring when he met Koo in Shanghai last October. However, Wang later changed his schedule and agreed to visit Taiwan this autumn.
Some lawmakers said they were worried that Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's mentor, may once again break his promise.
Koo said he doesn't think so. "I'm confident that Wang will come to Taiwan this fall," he added.
As to the agenda for the Taipei round of Koo-Wang talks, Koo said he hopes Wang will not confine the agenda to certain sensitive or controversial topics.

"Such a practice would only narrow the scope of our discussions and will do no good to relations across the Taiwan Strait," Koo said, adding that he is willing to frankly exchange views with Wang on any matters of mutual concern.
Koo also urged mainland China to face up to the political and historical reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now ruled by two separate governments.

"Cross-strait talks and relations can make significant progress only when Beijing treats Taipei on an equal footing," Koo said, adding that Beijing's attempts to downgrade the ROC government as a local government are the biggest obstacle to cross-strait rapprochement.

Turning to the US proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign interim agreements on certain thorny issues before they can finally resolve their disputes, Koo said he does not oppose the idea.

Koo said he thinks "interim agreements" can be signed to address practical issues related to the rights and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Nevertheless, Koo said it hinges on mainland China's attitude whether the proposed "interim agreements" can be signed or implemented.

Koo said the most important thing at the moment is that the two sides forge mutual trust. Therefore, Koo said Beijing should abide by the agreements reached in the first Koo-Wang meeting held in Singapore in April in 1993. "Otherwise, it will be to no avail to discuss any interim or permanent agreements," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMPHETAMINE MOST-ABUSED ILLEGAL DRUG

TEXT.P: The results of a recent government investigation show that there are more male than female drug addicts in Taiwan, and that amphetamine is the narcotic of choice for most of them.

Quoting reports from hospitals islandwide, the investigation carried out by the Narcotics Bureau under the cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) shows that a total of 1,471 drug users received treatment for drug abuse during the second half of 1998, 80 percent of whom were male.

Amphetamine and heroin were the most-abused narcotics, with 38.5 percent and 34.4 percent, respectively, of the drug users addicted to them. Some 11.8 percent favored sleeping pills such as hypnotics and soporifics, while 7 percent addicted to glue-sniffing.

Youths aged between 20 and 35 accounted for the largest group of abusers -- 67.8 percent -- and as many as 45.2 percent cited friends as their most frequent providers of narcotics. About 15.5 percent said they obtained drugs through "other means," ahead of 13 percent who purchased narcotics from pushers.

Injection was the most frequent method of administration used by 30.9 percent of the total drug users, with 5.6 percent of them saying they shared needles with other users. Some 28.2 percent said they sniffed the fumes given off by heating the drugs, while 18 percent said they smoked their drugs.
Meanwhile, the DOH announced that it is planning to establish a comprehensive monitoring system for drug abuse by joining forces with communities and schools islandwide.

The DOH said in an annual anti-drug report that it plans to work with regional hospitals and communities to strengthen its monitoring of drug addicts released from hospitals, and will also cooperate with the Ministry of Education to set up monitoring systems in schools islandwide to crack down on drug abuse among the nation's youth.

The DOH also plans to work with the Ministry of Justice to establish rehabilitation centers at 145 hospitals across the island, and to train more personnel to help drug addicts shake their habits, according to the report. Since 1994, 4,451 people have received such training, 1,533 of whom are practicing physicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI '99 KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's international computer exposition, Computex Taipei '99, kicked off on Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Some 18,000 buyers and business executives from around the world are expected to visit the five-day show which is Asia's largest, and one of the three leading information technology (IT) exhibitions in the world. They will be examining the latest products and technologies of 912 IT companies and manufacturers from home and abroad.

Like the annual Comdex Fall of Las Vegas, and CeBIT in Hanover, Germany, Computex Taipei is also showcasing products and technologies that are ready for mass production, said a spokesman for the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), which co-sponsors the Taipei show with the Taipei Computer Association.

The state-of-the-art products on display include four-processor servers, Internet boxes and television set-top boxes from Mitac International, 42-inch plasma-display super-thin television sets from Acer, high-performance multimedia network-ready systems from Micro-Star International, and slim panel industrial PCs and semi knock-down industrial PC kits from Synertron Technology.

To beef up the attractions of the show, the sponsors are also playing host to a workshop, dubbed "New Information World Crossing the 21st Century" slated to take place on Wednesday at the Taipei International Convention Center, said the CETRA spokesman.

The workshop will be jointly presided over by Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company; Brian Halla, CEO of National Semiconductor Inc. of the United States; and Intel Vice Chairman John Davies, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SMOKING CONFERENCE CALLS ON TEENAGERS TO `SAY NO' TO CIGARETTES

TEXT.P: Anti-smoking experts from the Asia-Pacific region agreed unanimously on Tuesday that a smoke-free environment should be created for teenagers to help them say "No" to cigarettes.

The agreement came at the close of a two-day conference of the Asia Pacific Association for the Control of Tobacco (APACT) which was held in Taipei. Attendees from countries in the region meet every three years to discuss issues related to tobacco taxation and building a smoke-free environment for the younger generation.
Surveys show that 55 percent of Taiwan's male adult population smoke, as well as over 30 percent of males over the age of 19. Most of them started smoking during their teenage years.

A Department of Health (DOH) official said the government is gradually creating a smoke-free environment through law enactment, counseling and anti-smoking education; teenagers under 18 are not allowed to smoke, nor are stores allowed to sell them cigarettes.

Professor Chen Chien-jen from National Taiwan University's school of epidemiology pointed out that teenagers become habitual smokers after smoking for just one year, making it more difficult for them to quit when they are adults.
Chen said it is the responsibility of the government and society to prevent teenagers from taking up the habit, and that prevention measures should be carried out in all aspects of teenagers' lives.

Scott Baldwin, one of the first attorneys in the United States to win lawsuits against tobacco companies, said Taiwan should seek compensation from American tobacco companies, and not let the fear of US trade retaliation sacrifice the health of its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST WORLD CONGRESS ON INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will sponsor the World Congress on Information Technology 2000 (WCIT 2000) which is slated to take place next June 11-14, Acting Secretary-General of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Thomas Tsou said on Tuesday.

Tsou made the announcement at the opening ceremony of Computex Taipei '99, where he said the World Information Technology and Services Alliance (WITSA) has authorized Taiwan's Software Association to host the congress in which industry and government leaders from around the world will discuss some of the hottest topics in the field.
Tsou said Taipei plans to hold various activities in conjunction with WCIT 2000, to showcase Taipei's cultural character as an "information capital."

In addition, Computex Taipei 2000, which will immediately precede WCIT 2000, will be expanded as part of Taiwan's sponsorship of the key IT conference in the first year of the 21st century, Tsou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER WANTS TO PRICK THE MRT BALLOON MENACE

TEXT.P: A French resident of Taiwan has suggested to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation (TRTC) that balloons be prohibited on the city's mass rapid transport system after being startled by a child bursting balloons on one of the trains.

TRTC officials pointed out that since many of the mass transit lines have their destinations at the popular scenic spots frequented by souvenir vendors, families often travel on the trains, and it is not unusual for children to bring balloons aboard.
The officials admitted that the sound of balloons popping might shock other passengers, and could even cause accidents, with stray balloons posing an added hidden danger to mass transit facilities.

However, despite the dangers involved, the TRTC said, banning the balloons might cause "a negative reaction," although it added that instructions have been issued to station managers to "persuade" passengers not to bring balloons on board.

The incident has sparked enthusiastic debate on the Internet, with some people agreeing that balloons should be banned, and others saying that such a move would restrict peoples' freedom, and that the next step would be a ban on the rubber menaces in places such as amusement parks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAS BODY OF 60-YEAR-OLD: DOCTOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old, and is in extremely good health, his chief physician at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) said on Tuesday.
Lee and his wife had just undergone a routine physical, the results of which indicate that both the Republic of China's president and his wife are very healthy, said Dr. Lien Wen-pin.

The president is actually in better shape than he was in 1997 when he received his last physical, said Lien, citing the facts that Lee's spinal bone matrix is more solid than that of a much younger man, his blood sugar level is normal, and even a stone on his left kidney has disappeared.
The Lees checked into NTUH at 8 a.m. and were discharged from the medical center at 5:50 p.m.
According to the examination results, Lee now stands 179 cm tall, one centimeter shorter than in 1997, but he has gained six kilograms over the last two years, bringing his weight to 76 kg.

He has a blood pressure reading of 136-70 -- quite healthy for a man of his age, and although he has slow degeneration of his right shoulder, Lee is still full of energy, Lien said, adding that the president apparently has no problem with his golf game, and can play 27 holes in a single outing.
As Lee's doctor, Lien suggested that the president slow his public life down a bit, take more rest, do more exercise and get more sunshine.
As for Mrs. Lee, Lien said the first lady is also in better shape than most women her age, apart from two tiny seeds in her thyroid gland, a condition which requires no treatment.
A small gallstone has dissolved, and her bone matrix is also more solid than average, Lien noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT CORP. INVESTS US$30 MILLION IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 1 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Southeast Asia Investment Corp. (SAIC) Chairman Liu Tai-ying on Tuesday signed an agreement with Thai Finance Ministry Permanent Secretary Supachai Pisitvanich to invest US$30 million in Thailand's TISCO Finance Public Company Ltd.

The investment is a part of TISCO's increasing capitalization program. The leading finance management company of Thailand plans to issue 600 million more shares to collect additional capital of 6 billion baht (US$162.12 million).

The Thai government will buy half of the new stocks, with private enterprises sharing the rest, according to TISCO, whose business covers commercial banking, securities brokerage, and leasing services.

During Tuesday's signing ceremony, Liu, who also chairs the China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB), said that with the signing of the agreement, both the SAIC and CDIB will enhance cooperation with their new Thai partner to expand their financial and business operations in the Southeast Asian country.

Asked why they have chosen to dump money in a country battered by the Asian financial storm, Liu explained that the Thai economy is recovering under the government's efficient financial reforms. Bangkok's measures to deal with the financial crisis are in the right direction, and this has helped foreign investors to regain confidence in the country, he added.

Since the outbreak of the regional financial crisis two years ago, the SAIC and CDIB have invested US$120 million in Thailand by merging with local companies, especially banks and financial businesses, Liu said, revealing that their total investment in Thailand will grow to US$200 million by the end of this year.
Liu is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Wednesday after his two-day stay in Bangkok.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT INTENDS TO PROLONG LEGISLATORS' TERM TO FOUR YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang is working on a proposal to prolong legislators' terms from the current three years to four years, sources from the ruling KMT's Constitutional Amendment Panel revealed on Tuesday.
The KMT panel decided on Tuesday that when the National Assembly convenes later this year, this proposal will be high on the agenda, the sources said.
The panel also decided that the party will propose the promulgation of an act to increase the quota of elected women members in all representative bodies, including the legislature.

The KMT will also propose that the rights of prosecutors and law enforcement agencies to detain suspects be extended to 48 hours from the current 24 hours, and that those eligible for military conscription can opt instead to serve the state in a non-military capacity, the sources noted.
Meanwhile, the sources said, the function of the National Assembly will be further boosted, and the number of its members may also be increased.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 FIGHTER JET MISSING

TEXT.P: An F-16 flight jet of the Republic of China Air Force lost contact with ground controllers during a night training mission 22 miles southwest of Green Island off the coast of southeastern Taiwan, the Air Force Headquarters said in a news release.
The single-seat fighter took off from an air base in Hualien in eastern Taiwan at around 7:40 p.m. and lost contact with controllers at 8:29 p.m., the release said.
Rescue operations were under way for the pilot, 34-year-old Squadron Leader Hsu Chung-wei, it added.

This is the third accident in Taiwan involving the highly advanced F-16 fighter. A two-seater F-16 with its crew of two disappeared in the vicinity of the offshore island of Penghu in March last year, and on Jan. 25 this year, another two-seater F-16 crashed in a mountainous area of Taitung, killing the two pilots.
As part of efforts to modernize its air force, Taiwan has ordered 150 F-16 MLU (mid-life-upgrade) fighters from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES BOTH UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.1 percent higher on Tuesday as prices for raw-materials stocks rebounded after falling for several sessions.

The Taipei Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's barometer, moved up 81.05 points to close at 7,397.62 with 1.82 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$83.41 billion compared to Monday's turnover of NT$111.46 billion.

Strong buying interest appeared in sectors such as textiles, plastics and chemical, and paper-making. This pushed up share prices in those sectors, while electronics shares attracted less attention and were the only one of the eight major stock categories to lose ground, slipping 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 350 to 108, with 45 issues unchanged.
Paper-making shares rose the most at 4.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 4.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.6 percent and cement stocks at 1.6 percent.
Construction shares and financial issues both listed gains of 1.4 percent while foodstuff issues rose 1.2 percent.
The over-the-counter market opened low but ended 2.07 points higher, closing at 171.93 on a turnover of NT$6.95 billion.
Meanwhile, trading on Taiwan's stock index futures opened high and ended high in Tuesday's session.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June ended up 87 points to 7,408 with 2,952 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July closed up 60 points to 7,400 with 162 contract transactions, while those for September moved up 54 points to 7,404 with 26 contract transactions. December futures rose 70 points to 7,420 with 7 contract transactions, and futures for next March slipped 2 points to 7,445 with 2 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,321 for June, 7,340 for July, 7,350 for September, 7,350 for December and 7,447 for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STEEL FIRM TO BUY BACK AN FENG'S SHARES IN ABORTIVE VENTURE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) (By Amanda Chang) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, June 1 (CNA): Kingstream Steel Co. of western Australia is working to buy back almost 331 million shares from its Taiwanese former partner -- An Feng Steel Co. -- following the abortive joint venture between the two sides due to financial trouble of the Kaohsiung-based firm.

Kingstream Chairman Ken Court on Monday told his shareholders at an annual general that the buyback of An Feng's shares in the abortive venture would clear a big hurdle for the Australian company and eventually pave the way for a 100 percent control of the US$1 billion Midwest Iron and Steel (MIS) project, according to a report by the Australian Associated Press (AAP).

He said Kingstream planned to cancell all the shares held by the financially stricken An Feng as it attempts to revive development of the MIS project, east of Geraldton in western Australia, according to the AAP.
However, a further 104.9 million shares would remain off limits because they are still on the hand of An Feng's creditors in Taiwan, Court told his shareholders.
But the buyback of the An Feng's shares would pave the way for future acquisition of other shares now being held by Taiwanese creditors, he said.
The buyback of An Feng's shares will be made in "a few months," he said.
"This is a very positive move, because ... now we can move ahead to finalise the funding package," Court said, adding that Kingstream was negotiating with its financiers now.
Court was not available for comment on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER ATTENDS INAUGURATION OF SALVADORAN PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, May 31 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday attended the inauguration of Salvadoran President Francisco Flores on behalf of ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
The ROC was one of 54 nations to send a delegation to celebrate Flores' inauguration as president of the Central American nation.

Foreign heads of state attending the ceremony included Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez, Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman, Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu, Honduran President Carlos Flores and Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladarez.
On Monday, Siew met with Flores for wide-ranging talks, during the course of which Siew passed on a personal letter from the ROC president to Flores.

Flores assured Siew that he will continue promoting cooperation with the ROC after assuming office. He promised to travel to Taipei in September to attend a summit meeting between the ROC, El Salvador, and several other Central American countries.

Flores also expressed keen interest in signing a proposed free trade agreement between the ROC and its five Central American allies. The proposed pact will be a major topic of the September summit meeting.
Siew is accompanied by a large delegation of government officials and senior business executives on his current 10-day, three-nation Central American visit.

During talks with senior Taiwan business executives, Siew said he earnestly hopes Taiwan companies will be more active and aggressive in launching investment projects in El Salvador and other Central American countries that maintain longstanding diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Siew said he has ordered the Ministry of Economic Affairs to set up a special task force to seek investment and joint-venture opportunities in Central America to facilitate Taiwan entrepreneurs' penetration of the Central American market.

Central America is one of the ROC's diplomatic stronghold as many of its diplomatic allies are located in the region. As part of its efforts to cement ties with these countries, the ROC government has been encouraging Taiwan business people to invest more in the region.

El Salvador is the second leg of Siew's current Central American visit, which will also take him to Saint Christopher and Nevis in the Caribbean. Siew already visited Guatemala before coming to San Salvador.
Siew later in the day also met with the heads of state from Nicaragua, Panama and Costa Rica, which are also the ROC's diplomatic allies in the Latin American region

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang's special panel passed four proposals on constitutional amendment, including extending the tenure of legislators to four years.
The China Times:
An ROC Air Force F-16 disappeared off eastern Taiwan coast.
The United Daily News:
The ROC military launched all-out search for missing F-16 and pilot.
The Liberty Times:
The KMT agreed to extension of legislator's tenure to four years.
The Commons Daily:
The KMT reached a four-point consensus on constitutional amendments.
The China Post:
The National Assembly opposes plan over detention time.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan rated regional leader in e-commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 2, or the 19th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1780: Lord George Gordon foments riots to protest against the ending of penalties against Roman Catholics in the Roman Catholic Relief Act of 1778.
1868: Britain crushes the Marathas in India and annexes their lands.
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the spoils system.
1896: Guglielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor, patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1899: Spain cedes the Carolinas, Pelews, Marianne and Ladrones to Germany.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shi-chang resigns as president of the Peking government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide by jumping into the Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Peking (Beijing). He was 50. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty, where the summer palace is located.
1942: Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and US Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1946: Italy becomes a republic after its monarchy is abolished.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the Crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The coronation is televised for the first time.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Frank E. Evans, a US destroyer, collides with the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1966: Surveyor I, a US automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The Pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Church and the countries of the communist block.
1983: The ROC's Executive Yuan approves at its regular meeting a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by British fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins the championship of an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: Sir Rex Harrison, British actor, dies at the age of 82. He was best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage, and in the film version of 1964, winning not only a Tony but also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro in Brazil.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation; in extravagance; in mere conviviality: such pleasures are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO LEAD TAIWAN ARTISTS TO VENICE ART SHOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will personally lead a group of Taiwan artists to the 48th Esposizione Internazionale d'Arte La Biennale di Venezia, a biennial art exhibition that will open in the Italian city of Venice on June 12, sources from the Taipei Fine Arts Museum said on Wednesday.
Three Taiwan artists, Buh-ching Hwang, Chieh-jen Chen and Tung-lu Hung, will jointly exhibit their contemporary art under a theme of "Toward An Openness" at the Palace of Prigioni in downtown Venice.
It will be the third time that Taiwan artists have taken part in the illustrious biennial art show since 1995.
This year's show, with a general theme of "APERTO overALL," will be a showcase of contemporary art masterpieces from around the world under the direction of world-renowned curator Harald Szeeman.

Hundreds of artists from 59 nations and areas will be taking part in the exhibition, the most expensive biennial art show ever staged. Compared with previous shows and other exhibitions, this year's one is expected to be more global, though there will be no work from African artists on display, and there will be more video pieces and fewer traditional paintings and sculptures.
According to the Taipei Fine Arts Museum, the artistic works of Hwang, mostly paintings, reflect the shift of Taiwanese society from conservative, inhibited and dull to liberal, open and vibrant.

Chen meanwhile is a determined outsider who uses computer and image-processing software to create his works, and he will show off pieces that neatly integrate traditional methods of drawing and photographic collages using computer technology.
As for Hung, the artist will put out "installations" using the "simple formula of iconographic language," according to a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT TO CONTINUE WITH `GO SOUTH' POLICY: CEPD HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, June 1 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The ROC government will continue promoting its "go south" policy, despite its call for Taiwan businesses to invest in Central America, a top ROC economic planning official said here on Tuesday.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the government policy of urging Taiwan firms to invest in Southeast Asian countries does not contradict its call for Taiwan enterprises to invest in Central America, and that there is no need to adjust the southward investment policy.
Chiang claimed that the "go south" policy will not lose its importance, although the ROC government is pushing for a greater number of Taiwan companies to set up strongholds in Central America.

Currently, Taiwan investment in Southeast Asia totals more than US$40 billion, and the "go south" policy will help further strengthen Taiwan's substantive ties with countries in that region, Chiang noted.

In addition to Southeast Asia and mainland China, the ROC government is also actively encouraging Taiwan businesses to tap the Central American market, and is providing them with handsome incentives, said the CEPD head, who is currently accompanying ROC Premier Vincent Siew on a Central American tour.

Because of the region's proximity to North and South America, Chiang said Taiwan companies should consider breaking into the Central American market, which is rife with business opportunities, as soon as possible. This would not only help create more job opportunities in the host countries, it would also help Taiwan to cement ties with those countries, he added.

Speaking of a move by the First Commercial Bank and the International Commercial Bank of China to open branches in the region, Chiang expressed the belief that Taiwan businesses with operations in Central America will be able to enjoy credit at favorable interest rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWER EXPORTS PUSH UP AUSTRALIA'S CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT

TEXT.P: Australia's current account deficit (CAD) surged to a record high of A$8.9 billion (US$5.93 billion) in the first quarter of 1999, pushing the country's net foreign debt to an all-time high of A$241.6 billion (US$161.1 billion), and some economists have predicted the figures could swell further in the coming months.

The first-quarter CAD reached about 5.9 percent of Australia's gross domestic product, the highest level since fiscal 1994-95, when it reached 6.6 percent, according to figures released Tuesday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

Australia's first-quarter net foreign debt represents a rise of A$2.6 billion (US$1.73 billion) from the fourth quarter of 1998. But the servicing ratio was steady at a 15-year low of 9.6 percent, according to the ABS.

Federal Treasurer Peter Costello attributed the surging CAD and foreign debt to lower exports due to the lingering impact of the Asian financial crisis. But he said the CAD figure was consistent with government forecasts of 5.5 percent in fiscal 1998-99, which ends June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: KKK ESTABLISHES AUSTRALIAN CHAPTERS AS ABORIGINES SEEK BAN

TEXT.P: The US-based Ku Klux Klan has made inroads into Australia, and worried local Aboriginal and Jewish leaders have called on the government to ban such groups from operating in the country.

In a front-page story, The Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday reported that Kentucky-based Imperial Klans of America has set up branches in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and has appointed a Sydney man, identified as Peter Coleman, as its Australian "exalted Cyclops."
The daily also reported that the New Order Knights, based in Montana, plans to start an Australian chapter soon.

Both US KKK organizations revealed they are recruiting their members through the Internet, as it provides them with a virtual office in Australia that is free of official scrutiny, the daily reported.
In an interview with the Herald, Coleman said, "Our aim is for a white Australia, a fair Australia."

News of the KKK gaining a foothold in Australia prompted the Anti-Defamation Commission and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to urge state and federal governments to ban the KKK groups from operating in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIANS TO REMEMBER TIANANMEN SQUARE MASSACRE

TEXT.P: Amnesty International (AI) Canada and Democracy China-Ottawa will hold a candle vigil and wreath ceremony outside the mainland Chinese Embassy in Ottawa on the evening of June 4 to mark the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Massacre.

Paula Kelsall, a spokeswoman for AI Canada, said Tuesday that 10 years after hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed by the People's Liberation Army, the mainland Chinese government still has not accounted for those killed, injured or arrested, and it still maintains that the peaceful protests were a "counter-revolutionary riot."
Amnesty International has records of 241 prisoners who are still in jail or on medical parole and serving long sentences in connection with the events, she added.

She said members of AI Canada and Democracy China-Ottawa will honor those who died with a special wreath of white chrysanthemums, the color of mourning in mainland China, and will call for the release of those still being held.

Last week Amnesty International stated that "the time is ripe for the Chinese authorities to give a final and complete account of all those killed and injured during the crackdown, to compensate the victims and their relatives, and to release those still imprisoned for their role in the 1989 pro-democracy protests."

DOC.HEADLINE: GUANGDONG POLICE ARREST NEARLY 1,900 SUSPECTED CRIMINALS

TEXT.P: Guangdong's provincial public security bureau launched a "strike hard" anti-crime operation in eight major cities, mainly targeting areas near Macau, from May 26 to 28, Lusa reported Monday.

According to the Portuguese news agency, the three-day sweep, code-named F-1, netted a total of 1,859 suspected criminals, among them seven alleged Macau triad members. Seventy-two people suspected of having connections to Macau triad activities were also arrested.
It was reported that during the operation 120,000 places in eight unidentified cities were raided by public security bureau officials, while 786 cases were solved and many weapons were seized.

The report also said that as part of the operation in the adjacent Zhuhai Special Economic Zone, a suspected Macau triad member wanted by local police for armed robbery was arrested and a racket that forged certificates and smuggled women for prostitution to Macau was busted.
Macau's chief executive-designate, Edmund Ho Hau-wah, has made the fight against crime one of his top post-handover policy priorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY REPORTS ON TIES WITH PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the Philippines Chan Hsien-ching on Wednesday urged the Philippine government to respect the Republic of China's stance while handling relations with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chan, who returned to Taipei on Tuesday for home consultations, made the call in a report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee.

Noting that the Philippine government's recent handling of a proposed visit to the Philippines by President Lee Teng-hui has hurt the ROC's national dignity, Chan said he hopes a similar situation will not occur again.

Chan said Filipino alumni of Cornell University originally planned to invite Lee to a private gathering in the Philippines in late April. Lee has a doctoral degree in agricultural economy from the prestigious American university.

Chan said the Philippine government first approved the invitation. At that point, Chan said, the ROC government was still mulling whether to accept the invitation. However, as soon as it heard about the planned invitation, Beijing began to pressure the Philippine government to deny Lee an entry visa.

On April 20, the Philippine Presidential Office issued a statement saying Lee's Philippines visit would not be helpful to maintaining regional stability. The statement apparently ruled out the possibility of Lee being issued a visa.

The following day, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu expressed his strong dissatisfaction with the Philippine government's unfriendly move, saying its premature announcement "was unnecessary and inappropriate."

Chan said he had unequivocally conveyed the ROC's stance on the issue to the Philippine government. As a result, the Philippine Presidential Office issued another statement on May 25 that pointed out that Lee had not been denied a visa, since he had not applied for one, and nor had he even decided whether to visit the Philippines.
Chan said the latest statement signified Manila's hope that the incident will not affect the bilateral relationship.

In fact, Chan said, the incident had caused concern among many Philippine congressmen, and the foreign relations committee of the Philippine House of Representatives convened a hearing to discuss the event.

Chan said a number of Philippine congressmen have criticized their government for its sloppy handling of the issue. They said the Philippines has benefited greatly from its engagements with the ROC, particularly in trade, investment, bank loans, tourism and labor policy. They also demanded that the Philippine government review its "one China" policy and adopt effective measures to reinforce substantive ties with Taiwan.
Chan said Philippine authorities appreciate the treatment Taiwan extends to the large number of Filipino workers on the island.

"The Philippine government also intends to expand mutually beneficial economic relations with Taiwan," Chan said, adding that Philippine officials hope to attract more Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in hog raising and aquaculture in northern Luzon, the largest of the Philippine Islands.
Chan further said the Philippines intends to cooperate with Taiwan in developing its northern seaports to shorten Taiwan-bound navigation time.
The Philippines diplomatically recognizes Beijing while maintaining close substantive ties with the ROC.
