DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUELING REVIVAL IN SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 1 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: After a three-year slump, the semiconductor industry is experiencing a revival, largely as a result of Taiwan companies serving as original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), according to a report Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal.

OEM production accounted for just 8 percent of total production in the industry last year, though the figure is expected to rise within one or two years to 13 percent. And this growth will ultimately reflect growth in the industry, according to the paper.
The sale of semiconductor products is expected to grow 9 percent in 1999, slightly lower than last year's 11-percent growth, the paper said.

Meanwhile, the sale of equipment used to manufacture semiconductors is experiencing single-digit growth, compared to last year's decline of 24 percent as Taiwan companies have placed significant orders for new equipment.

US-based General Instrument Co., the biggest producer of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, told the paper that Taiwan companies accounted for 20 percent of its total sales last year, and are expected to account for 25 percent this year.

Taiwan's largest two semiconductor manufacturers, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Micro Electronics, have each invested US$1.3 billion in new projects. This contrasts sharply with the picture last year, when the market was suffering from a slump in demand.

The paper attributed the two Taiwan companies' improved performance to constant technological innovation, which has enabled them to compete against Intel and to weather the recent global economic downturn.

Although dynamic random access memory (DRAM) modules used to be what fueled the industry's growth, the industry is now focusing on producing chips for Internet-related products and consumer devices, as well as for personal computers, the paper noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA WANTS APEC MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: India will continue to push for membership of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum "because APEC without India is like Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark," according to its finance minister.

Pallaniappan Chidambaram, who has been described as the best finance minister in Asia, said India is unhappy over Australia's role in seeking to limit APEC membership. He said APEC's admission of Russia was irrelevant, and that India should be given a chance to become a member.
Chidambaram, who is currently visiting Australia, is one of the architects of India's economic liberalization since 1991, and he is meeting Australian business and political leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S F-16S GROUNDED IN WAKE OF RECENT CRASHES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force on Wednesday grounded all of its newly acquired F-16 jet fighters for safety checks in the wake of another accident of the advanced warplane on Tuesday evening.

The single-seater F-16, piloted by Squadron Leader Major Hsu Chun-wei, went missing during a night training mission about 35 kilometers southwest of Green Island off the coast of southeastern Taiwan at around 8:12 p.m.
Marine police rescue units from nearby Taitung City reported by Wednesday noon that pink oil residue suspected to be from a military plane had been spotted on the ocean surface near Green Island.

Air force personnel speculated that the F-16 fighter's ECS control system malfunctioned when the cockpit's pressurization system broke down, causing the pilot to black out and lose control of the fighter. Similar accidents have been reported by the United States Air Force, according to air force sources.

This is the third accident involving the high-performance jet fighters since 150 F-16 MLU (midlife upgrade) fighters began to be delivered from the United States to Taiwan one year and three months ago.
The Ministry of National Defense announced on Tuesday that initial rescue efforts will continue for 72 hours, and that the search will go on for three months if there is no immediate success.

After two air force night surveillance rescue helicopters were deployed throughout Tuesday night without finding anything, navy frigates and other vessels also joined the rescue mission on Wednesday morning. As of press time, no sign of the fighter or the pilot has been found.

An ROC Air Force statement said the 34-year-old Hsu is a member of Squadron 41 of Chiayi Air Force Base in southern Taiwan, and was engaged on a night training mission in eastern Taiwan. The fighter took off from Hualien's Chiashan Base at about 7:44 p.m. on Tuesday.
At 8:29 p.m., the air force confirmed that the fighter was missing, and launched a rescue operation at around 8:40 p.m.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung urged the US manufacturer of the aircraft to provide Taiwan with complete literature and reports about the jet fighters to see whether the plane's functions are well-developed or not.

Ting also called for the air force to increase F-16 pilots' simulation training time and expand simulation training categories before they are actually allowed to fly the planes. "Taiwan's air force and personnel resources cannot afford any more losses like this," Ting stressed.

A two-seater F-16 with its crew of two disappeared in the vicinity of the offshore island of Penghu in March last year, and on Jan. 25 this year, another two-seater F-16 crashed in a mountainous area of Taitung, eastern Taiwan, killing the two crewmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC WILL NOT ADJUST OIL PRICES IN NEAR FUTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said on Wednesday that although its crude oil import costs in May had increased to US$14.95 per barrel from US$12.3 the previous month, the company does not intend to adjust its oil prices.

The state monopoly has raised prices for its various oil-derived products twice -- on April 7 and on May 12 -- since the beginning of this year due to an upward spiral in international crude oil prices because of the conflict in Yugoslavia.
So far this year, the CPC has raised prices by a total of 5.49 percent.
A CPC spokesman explained that the current domestic oil prices are calculated on the criteria that imported crude oil costs US$12.5 per barrel on a new Taiwan dollar exchange rate of NT$32.74.
However, the spokesman said, the CPC has decided to absorb the additional costs itself in the near future, in order to maintain a stable oil market.
He also said that crude prices are expected to fall again soon.

The current local retail price of premium gasoline is NT$16.8 (US$0.5) per liter, while the price of 95-unleaded gasoline is NT$16.6 per liter; 92-unleaded gasoline is NT$15.6 per liter; high-grade diesel is NT$12.1 per liter; and normal-grade diesel is NT$10.9 per liter.

Meanwhile, CPC statistics show that on June 1, the first day on the local market for 98-unleaded gasoline, 337 kiloliters were sold. The fuel is more efficient and cleaner than other fuels on the market, but can only be used in high-end cars.
Sales accounted for 2 percent of that day's total CPC sales, the statistics show. There are now 302 gas stations around the island selling the new fuel.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPANDING TROPICAL STORM MAY AFFECT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A depression over the seas east of the Philippines is likely to develop into a tropical storm by Wednesday evening, and might effect Taiwan later in the week, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported on Wednesday.

A forecaster for the bureau indicated the mass of low atmospheric pressure, moving in a north-northwestern direction, is deviating to the northwest. He warned that if it maintains its current course, it might hit Taiwan.
The CWB predicted that the island will first encounter the outer rim of the mass by Saturday, and that residents of eastern Taiwan can expect rains.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN POLICY ANALYST URGES CLINTON TO HEED COX REPORT SUGGESTIONS

TEXT.P: President Bill Clinton should follow the Cox report's recommendations and improve US counterintelligence and national security so as to head off potential conflict with mainland China in the future, according to a senior American policy analyst.

Richard D. Fisher Jr., director of the Asian Studies Center at the Heritage Foundation, wrote Tuesday in an analysis that the Clinton administration's failure to warn Congress and the American people of the danger that Beijing's efforts to obtain military technology to build modern nuclear missiles and other weapons could threaten US security and challenge US interests in Asia "constitutes a stunning lapse of leadership."

Critics who downplay the seriousness of mainland China's actions by saying "everyone does it" miss the point: US taxpayers will have to bear the cost of new weapons to defend the United States against new mainland Chinese missiles based on US technology already paid for by Americans, noted Fisher.

The policy analyst said the Cox report is a long-overdue wake-up call for the Clinton administration and US allies to reassess Beijing's intentions, to undertake a serious counterintelligence campaign to protect the United States from mainland Chinese espionage, and to develop effective missile defenses to blunt mainland China's emerging missile capabilities.

The most important impact of mainland China's espionage is its ability to threaten the United States both directly and indirectly, wrote Fisher. The Cox report warns that Beijing could use US thermonuclear weapons and missile guidance technology to build new modern intercontinental-range ballistic missiles with multiple warheads that could cover the United States.
Stolen US technology could also be used to endanger US satellites and ballistic missile submarines that are critical to the United States' nuclear deterrence efforts, he said.

Indirect threats will come as a result of mainland China's providing ballistic or cruise missiles or satellites based on US technology to rogue states like Iran and North Korea, which are trying to build nuclear missiles capable of reaching the United States. The Cox report, moreover, states that Beijing is stealing military technology on a vast scale to advance its goal: to retake Taiwan and to replace the United States as the primary power in Asia.

Fisher concluded that although mainland China does not pose a threat like that of the former Soviet Union, the Cox committee provides an essential warning of Beijing's potential future hostile intent toward the United States and its friends in Asia.

The Cox report recommendations include abandoning the notion that mainland China is a "strategic partner" of the United States, a crash program to improve counterintelligence, reviving multilateral high-technology export controls, and accelerating the development of missile defenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Tuesday donated 2.5 million tons of rice to recession-hit Mongolia, said Kao Koong-liang, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MATC).
The donation ceremony took place in the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar.

Mongolia's economy was hit hard by the regional financial turmoil last year, and the situation became worse when the country was ravaged by storms which caused serious damage to livestock and crops, said Kao, who added that the donation should help strengthen the relationship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFF TIANANMEN HOOK THANKS TO NATO

TEXT.P: NATO has given mainland China's leadership a helping hand, just as it was facing demands for accountability in the Tiananmen Square Massacre of 10 years ago, leading pro-democracy activists said.

Michael To, Frank Woo and Xu Shuiliang jointly issued a long statement Tuesday to commemorate the tragic and bloody events in Beijing of June 1989. To and Woo are spokesmen for the World Council of Chinese Pro-democracy Organizations, and Xu is a renowned Chinese dissident now exiled in the United States. Xu maintains close ties with the Democratic Party of Zhejiang Province.

"By using the pretext of the NATO bombs, the Chinese government has effectively removed any possibility of pro-democracy demands on the eve of the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre," they said.

Western values such as human rights and democracy -- values championed by students and civilians 10 years ago -- "have no chance at all in the current anti-West climate" in mainland China, they noted.

But they said they do not think the cultural gap between mainland China and the West is as wide as that between the Christian and Muslim worlds because the Confucian culture, deeply rooted in mainland China, is a secular and practical culture that "simply cannot remain antagonistic toward the West for long."

The mainland Chinese are more fortunate than others if they want to join the new world order, in that they have "living proof in Taiwan and Hong Kong that Chinese culture is adaptable to full democracy and the rule of law," the overseas democracy leaders said.
Mainland China must come to grips with the fact that its real challenge is internal rather than external. "NATO is simply not the issue," they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TYCOON DONATES CASH PRIZE TO ENVIRONMENTAL EFFORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 2 (CNA) (By K.M. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Hsu Wen-lung, founder and chairman of Taiwan's ABS and acrylic giant Chi Mei Corp., on Wednesday donated to Asian environmental protection efforts a prize of 3 million Japanese yen he received from a Japanese media group.
Hsu is one of the few regional leaders to be awarded with the Asian Award sponsored by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun in recognition of outstanding contributions to the people of Asia.

Hsu received the award plus a cash prize of 3 million yen on Wednesday, making him the first private entrepreneur from Asia to receive the prestigious citation since its inception five years ago. Previous recipients of the award have been statesmen or leaders in fields other than industry and commerce.
During the award presentation ceremony, Hsu was lauded by the award panel as being not only a successful entrepreneur, but also an art connoisseur and philanthropist.

In a speech delivered in the Taiwanese dialect upon receiving the award, Hsu said that what concerns him most as a businessman is when society becomes complacent over industrial or business growth, and disregards the harm done to the environment as a result of this growth.
Hsu said he would like to keep the citation, but give the cash prize to environmental protection efforts, in the hope that his "trivial contribution" will help conserve the environment across Asia.
Chi Mei Corp. is one of the top 50 enterprises in Taiwan, with corporate assets totaling NT$12 billion (US$366 million).

An avid art collector and connoisseur, Hsu established the Chi Mei Museum in southern Tainan County about a decade ago, providing free tours to the Taiwan public of his collection of art pieces gathered from around the world during his many business trips.
Hsu also made it a rule that 10 percent of the annual revenues of his Chi Mei Cultural Foundation be allocated to various charity organizations.
He was also one of the first leading entrepreneurs in Taiwan to implement the five-day work week program to allow his employees to enjoy more leisure time.
During the ceremony, Hsu also thanked the Japanese people, crediting Japan for making valuable contributions to Taiwan during the 50 years of Japanese rule of Taiwan prior to 1945.

DOC.HEADLINE: A MEGAWATI VICTORY IN INDONESIA SEEN AS A LONG TIME COMING

TEXT.P: Five hundred years ago an Indonesian prophet predicted Megawati Sukarnoputri would usher in a golden age for her country and people, according to a report in The Australian Financial Review.

Review writer Tim Dodd reported a Javanese king named Jayabaya predicted that Indonesia would be invaded by giant beings from abroad -- the Dutch. Then he said the country would be conquered for a short time by a race of yellow midgets.
Afterward, there would be four kings who would rule the country, with the first ruling from jail. Sukarno, the founder of modern Indonesia, was jailed before he became Indonesia's leader.

The next king, according to the prophecy, would be a person with extraordinary wealth and charisma that inspired obedience. This, according to the report, is a reference to Suharto, who resigned last year after more than 30 years in power.
The third king would have a short and violent reign, Jayabaya predicted, and this could be taken as a reference to current President B.J. Habibie.
Finally, the fourth king would be little-known figure who would unexpectedly unite the country and usher in a golden age.

Many of Jayabaya's adherents see the fourth king as Megawati, who while hardly being "little known" was not seen as a possible leader until Suharto made her a martyr in 1996 by expelling her from one of his two officially sanctioned opposition parties.

In other news about Indonesia, The Australian reported recently that opinion polls show that among the country's 4 million Indonesian-Chinese, 56.7 percent support Megawati as the country's next president.
One of the polls by Sinergi Magazine -- a new publication for the Chinese community -- said that what is important is the new willingness of the Chinese to get involved in politics.
"That's a very significant phenomenon; that differs with the last five or six elections," said Sinergi's commercial director, Martinin Wiranata.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted a modest gain of NT$0.002 against the greenback in Taipei on Wednesday.
The local currency opened at 32.729 and was traded between 32.721 and 32.738.
The interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$215.5 million, the lowest single-day turnover in the past two month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES MAINTAIN BULLISH TREND

TEXT.P: Strong buying of electrical and financial shares kept the Taiwan stock market bullish on Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, moving up 90.41 points to close at 7,488.03.
A total of 2.54 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$118.98 billion (US$3.63 billion).

The eight major stock categories closed mixed, with electrical stocks up 2.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks, up 1.3 percent; cement stocks, up 0.6 percent; financial issues, up 0.6 percent; and foodstuff issues, up 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares closed lower, down 0.6 percent, followed by textile shares, down 0.3 percent; and construction shares, down 0.2 percent.
The over-the-counter market opened low but soon entered an upward trend which lasted until the close of trading. The market's index closed at 173.58, up 1.65 points, on a turnover of NT$7.43 billion.
Meanwhile, trading on Taiwan's stock index futures was brisk and closed higher.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June were up 40 points to 7,448, with 2,668 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July were up 50 points to 7,450 with 172 contract transactions, while those for September moved up 42 points to 7,441, with 14 contract transactions. December futures rose 13 points to 7,450, with two contract transactions, while futures for next March slipped 51 points to 7,483, with one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,408 for June, 7,400 for July, 7,399 for September, 7,437 for December, and 7,534 for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT CALLS FOR INTERNATIONAL PRESSURE ON BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's top dissident, on Tuesday urged the international community to continue its pressure on Beijing over human rights.
Wei made his appeal at a seminar in Washington, D.C. in commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the June 4, 1989 massacre by the Beijing authorities of pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square.

Even in a democracy, Wei said, politicians will change the course of national policy only in the face of domestic or foreign pressure. The difference between a totalitarian and a democratic country is that the politicians of the former are unlikely to respond to pressure from their own people, making pressure from the international community especially important, such as is the case in mainland China, Wei added.
The noted dissident said he does not agree with the view that Beijing is willing to resolve issues concerning human rights, nuclear arms proliferation and environmental protection.

The Beijing authorities may or may not be willing to resolve these problems, Wei said, but the fact that they are a communist regime makes them unable in essence to deal with the situation in an internationally acceptable manner, he added.

In view of the wave of nationalistic fervor instigated by the Beijing authorities in the wake of NATO's accidental bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the mainland's human rights record has become even worse than it was 10 years ago, noted Wei.

He explained that this move by Beijing meant that not only are the mainland's pro-democracy dissidents facing a stronger crackdown than before, even foreign businessmen in mainland China have been experiencing hardship at the hands of the authorities.

Wei went on to say that pressure from the international community will affect mainland China's future development, and the effect of the pressure will depend on its scale, noting that Beijing's intransigence is inversely proportional to pressure from outside.
Wei pointed out that without international pressure, Beijing will commit to reforms only in the face of heavy domestic economic pressure.

The seminar titled "The 10th Anniversary of Tiananmen: The US, China, and Human Rights" was held at the Brookings Institute, one of the most highly respected independent research organizations in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 21 KILOGRAMS OF HEROIN WORTH MORE THAN NT$1 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport Police Bureau announced on Wednesday the seizure of 60 heroin bricks hidden in three machinery molds imported from Thailand.

The bureau said the high-grade heroin, weighing more than 21 kilograms and worth an estimated NT$1 billion (US$30.49 million) in market value, is the largest narcotics seizure in Taiwan's civil aviation history.
Two suspects involved in the drug trafficking, identified as Liu Li-tseng and Fang Ping-nan, were caught red-handed as Liu was handing the contraband consignment to Fang.
The duo told police that they were only responsible for transporting the shipment, and did not know the products were contraband narcotics.

Police said they have obtained information about the mastermind behind the shipment. "We will launch a large-scale manhunt to bring to justice the alleged mastermind and other accomplices who are still at large," said a senior official at the CKS Airport Police Bureau.
Acting on a tip-off, police had been closely monitoring the three molds ever since they were brought to CKS Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, on a May 27 flight from Bangkok.

Liu claimed the cargo on May 31 and immediately sent them to an address in a back ally in Jenwu in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung. Liu was about to pass the cargo on to Fang when police officers arrested them.

Initial investigations show that Liu, who has a long criminal record, once worked at a blue-chip company in Luchu, Taoyuan County. He used the company's name to import the three molds from Thailand, but senior company executives were unaware of the import of the goods until the police informed them of Liu's actions.
The police said this is the first time they have uncovered contraband narcotics hidden in machinery molds.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG OUTLINES QUALIFICATIONS FOR FUTURE ROC LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs strong leadership, but does not need a "strongman" as head of state, former Taiwan Governor James Soong said at the University of California at Berkeley on Tuesday.

Soong also outlined the qualifications for a future Taiwan leader in his speech, titled "Public Service with TLC: A Vision for Taiwan's Democracy in the 21st Century." TLC refers to tender, love and care, is now a buzzword widely used in US society.

Soong, who ended his stint as Taiwan's first and last popularly elected governor late last year, is widely believed to break ranks with Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang to run in the island's 2000 presidential election as an independent.

Tuesday's speech at Berkeley marked the first time that Soong, a Berkeley alumnus, has spelt out his political concepts to foreign nationals. The speech drew the attendance of more than 100 Berkeley faculty members and graduate students.
In his speech, Soong said a future Taiwan leader must have a loving heart, efficiency, capability, direction, eloquence, sincerity, diligence, integrity and ability to resist pressure.

Soong said the future Republic of China government must provide a stable environment for sustained economic development. To reach this goal, Soong said, the ROC govenrment must meet three requirements in policy-making process -- the govenrment must have the support of all people; the govenrment must be responsive to popular demand; all government agencies must abide by law and keep their operations transparent.
"These three indispensable factors will constitute tough challenges to Taiwan's future leader and its people," Soong said.

During the question-and-answer session that followed the speech, Soong was tight-lipped over the possibility of his running in next year's presidential election. Soong also declined to answer the question whether he has the qualities or qualifications to be Taiwan's next president.

Soong arrived in San Francisco on Monday for a brief visit. Soong said he is scheduled to visit Japan next week to exchange views with Japanese scholars and politicians on the new Japan-US defense cooperation guidelines, the current situation in Northeast Asia and other topics related to regional stability and prosperity.
Before coming to San Francisco, Soong also made a high-profile four-day visit to the Philippines in lat May, where he met with many Filipino political heavyweights.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO FORSWEAR REPRESSIVE RULE

TEXT.P: Beijing should forswear its repressive mandate in mainland China or it will face a serious challenge to its one-party rule, an ROC official in charge of mainland China affairs said on Wednesday.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the quest for freedom and democracy is already an irreversible trend among the people of mainland China, and described as "very normal" the fact that the families of the unarmed victims of the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre have asked the Beijing authorities to vindicate the pro-democracy movement for which they gave their lives.

Wu said he is not optimistic that Beijing will heed the calls, because such a move would mean that certain incumbent Beijing leaders would have to step down to take the responsibility for the killings.
Wu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters at a seminar in Taipei on cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural development.

Pointing out that mainland China's sweeping economic reforms of recent years have led to greater demands for change in the political system, Wu said he hopes that the Chinese communist regime will handle the vindication request without resorting to repressive means.

Democracy is an irresistible historical trend in the current post-Cold War era, and mainland China cannot isolate itself from this wave, he noted, adding that mainland China's democratization is also the key to improved ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR RAID DRILL HELD IN NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Air raid sirens resounded in seven cities and counties in northern Taiwan early on Wednesday, in the annual "Wan An" air raid drill.
About 67,000 people in Taipei City, including civil defense personnel, took part in the drill which began at 5 a.m and lasted for 40 minutes.
Taipei streets were cleared of people when the drill began, and pedestrians around the train station were instructed to take shelter in the underground floors of the station.
The Far East Department Store on the Jenai traffic circle was chosen as the simulated site of a bomb hit and subsequent fire, and firefighters conducted firefighting and rescue exercises.
The emergency room of Jenai Hospital was filled with "seriously injured air raid victims," giving staff the opportunity to practice their emergency measures.
Water and power plants also carried out drills to deal with bomb-damaged electricity and water supplies.
Similar exercises were held in Taipei County, Ilan County, Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.

The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said that since most air attacks in recent international conflicts have been launched in the early morning hours, the MND decided on a 5 a.m. start for the drill.
The early start was also designed to cut the inconvenience to the public to a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS FOREIGN LEADERS IN EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: Capitalizing on the rare chance to appear on an international stage, Republic of China (ROC) Premier Vincent Siew hobnobbed with foreign leaders at the inauguration of El Salvador's new president Francisco Flores on Wednesday.
Besides conducting several talks with Flores after his arrival on Sunday, Siew met with Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman and Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladarez.
Both the Nicaraguan and Panamanian heads of state reconfirmed their diplomatic support for Taipei and courted Taiwan investment in their talks with Siew.
Siew also exchanged views with envoys from states without official ties with the ROC while attending the gala inaugural ceremony.
Siew was the highest ranking Asian state envoy and the ROC delegation was the ninth to enter into the inaugural ceremony among 61 delegations from around the world

A prerecorded congratulatory message from ROC President Lee Teng-hui was broadcast on local TV channels. In his message, Lee lauded the achievement of outgoing president Armando Calderon Sol and said he looked forward to cooperating with Flores.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC TO JOIN IN BD-100 AIRCRAFT'S DESIGN AND MANUFACTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) won the right Wednesday to join Canada's Bombardier Group in developing the BD-100 passenger aircraft.
AIDC President Hu Chin said the contract is expected to earn his company about NT$8 billion (US$244.65).
AIDC Chairman Tsai Chun-huei and Pierre Lortie, the chairman of Bombardier's international operation section, presided over a press conference at AIDC's Taichung base on Wednesday.

Pierre said that AIDC will be in charge of detail design, manufacturing, and integration of the planned airplane's rear-section and tail wings. The Bombardier Group has also invited Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and other international aircraft manufacturers to participate in the project.
Pierre said the aircraft with a full capacity of eight persons can cover 5,741 kilometers without refueling. The plane can fly from one coast of the United States to the other within five hours.
With its long-distance capability, Pierre predicted that by 2012 the global market demand for the aircraft will reach 1,000 units, with the United States as the main market.

The Bombardier Group operates a variety of businesses that manufacture equipment used in air and rail transportation. The group employs some 53,000 people and its aeronautic operation section is the world's third largest civil aircraft maker.

AIDC, originated as Taiwan's military-run Aero-Industry Development Center. It designed and built the Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF) and is currently in the process of becoming a private corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST EUROPEAN TRADE FAIR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A large-scale Eastern European trade and travel fair is slated for June 15-19 at the Taipei International Convention Center to introduce to local businessmen investment opportunities in the region, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Wednesday.
The fair will introduce various investment opportunities in Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland and Lithuania. Visitors will also be exposed to the special cultures and customs of the four nations.
CETRA has invited 50,000 local dignitaries from all walks of life to attend the trade fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVIEDO UNLIKELY TO SEEK ASYLUM IN TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Former Paraguayan military strongman Lino Cesar Oviedo is unlikely to seek political asylum in Taiwan as predicted by foreign news reports, said officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Wednesday.

The officials said that Oviedo, who is currently in exile in Argentina, is waiting for the chance to launch a political comeback in his homeland. They believed that Oviedo would prefer to take refuge in a country near Paraguay rather than in distant Taiwan.
Noting that Taiwan has never granted asylum to a foreign political leader, officials predicted that Oviedo would not be so naive as to come here and risk being denied protection.

A recent report by Argentinean newspaper El Clarin said that Oviedo, who is suspected of drug trafficking by the US government while serving as chief of the Paraguayan military, could seek political asylum in Taiwan in light of his commercial ties here and the absence of an extradition treaty between Asuncion and Taipei.

In disputing the reports, MOFA officials said that Taiwan does have an extradition treaty with Paraguay, but it only applies to convicted criminals who are pursued by signatories through proper diplomatic channels. In Oviedo's case, the diplomatic proceedings have not yet began, said the officials.

While admitting that Chinese businessmen in Paraguay used associates of Oviedo as brokers in conducting business, the officials said, as far as they know, Oviedo does not have any direct business ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE CONCLUDES PROBE INTO F16 CRASH

TEXT.P: Saying that their investigation was inclusive, air force officials speculated on Wednesday that an flight-guidance instrument error might have led to the crash of an F16 jetfighter in Taitung County last January.
Two pilots, 43-year-old Chang Chia-kun and 30-year-old Dai Wei-kang, were killed when the twin-seat F-16 crashed into a mountain in Taimali on the afternoon of Jan. 25.
After the accident, the air force general headquarters formed a task force to investigate the cause of the crash. A press conference was called on Wednesday to announce the results.
The most probable cause of the crash is an error in the reading of the flight deviation indicator, said an air force officer.
He said that because most of the aircraft's equipment and instruments had been destroyed in the crash, investigators were unable to determine the exact cause of the crash.

He noted that prior to the crash, the pilots could not see the ground as the jetfighter was in clouds. The officer speculated that the pilots might have continued relying on their flight instruments, not knowing their instruments were in error.
A navigation error, the officer said, might have caused the jetfighter to deviate from its regular decent route and crash into the mountain.
In the wake of the crash, the air force has taken steps to prevent the reoccurrence of a similar accident, including a broad review of all flight training involving the reading of instruments.
The air force has also ordered flight-guidance instruments aboard all F16 jet fighters to be examined.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC'S INFORMATION INDUSTRY WILL NOT THREATEN TAIWAN FOR FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information industry will not be threatened by mainland China for at least five years, according to Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., on Wednesday.
Although mainland China has progressed rapidly in the information industry, Chang said, it still lags far behind Taiwan in its development environment.
Admitting that mainland China is certain to pose a threat to Taiwan's information industry in the future, he asserted that the threat will not happen for at least five years.
Chang made the remarks while giving a speech on the development of Taiwan's information industry at the invitation of the Science, Technology and Information Committee of the Legislative Yuan.
When asked about his company's plan to purchase shares of Texas Instruments-Acer Inc., Chang regretted the information has been leaked. But he said he is still optimistic about the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SPEAKS AT UC BERKELEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is moving toward the third wave of democratization, and everyone is entitled to a chance to fair competition, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said in a speech at the University of California at Berkeley on Tuesday.

Soong was speaking on "Public Service with TLC: A Vision for Taiwan's Democracy in the 21st Century" as a distinguished visiting scholar and alumnus of the school. TLC stands for tender, love and care, a buzzword widely in US society.

Part of Soong's 40-minute speech, in which he shared his views on Taiwan's democratic development, reviewed its present plights and looked ahead to its challenges, was made available through his office in Taipei.

Soong noted that Taiwan has undergone two waves of democratization. The first was led by late President Chiang Chin-kuo in 1980s, with a main focus of expanding the participation of multi-level governments so that the central government's policy reflects the state of Taiwan's situation.

The second wave of democratization, led by President Lee Teng-hui, featured institutionalization and identification, so that "traditional gaps among ethnic groups and religions were gradually bridged," and a consensus was formed to fight for the future of Taiwan.

He noted that as the next millennium approaches, Taiwan must upgrade and continue to improve its quality of democracy during a third wave of democratization. During this stage, no one has the right to enjoy prerogatives but all have a chance to engage in fair competition.

Soong then touched on three indispensable elements for government policies. He said policies should be supported by the public, a government should have kindred feelings towards its people, and that the process of making decisions should be apparent.

Soong also reaffirmed his idea of the three R's which he broached during his stint as the first and last popularly elected Taiwan provincial governor; a modern government should be responsible to the people, responsive to its needs and be reasonable in policy formation and resource distribution.

He then presented a fourth "R" - that a modern government should be representative, meaning that when it formulates and executes policy, it should always take into account the people's will, and that a policy should be just toward all persons.
Soong also touched on cross-strait relations, saying that since the missile crisis in 1996, Beijing and Taiwan have made little headway in establishing a constructive dialogue.

He said that Taiwan has no "expediency" in handling cross-strait relations, and that the official "go slow, be patient" policy has led to worry in the private sector that Taiwan is gradually losing its competitive edge to the mainland.

But he reaffirmed that from his grass-roots talks, he has learned that no person living in Taiwan would like to live under a communist rule, and that no one on the island wants war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He said that most people in Taiwan believe that the best defense will be to deter the war so that the way of freedom and democratic system on the island can be protected.

He also urged the world community to note that the row across the Taiwan Strait is not about "sovereignty," but about "human rights", adding that the world should respect the rights of 22 million people living in Taiwan to have a free life.

Noting that Taiwan is the 14th largest trade nation in the world, Soong noted that Taiwan's voice and participation should not be absent from international forums. He added that allowing Taiwan to rejoin the world community achieves the double goals of free trade and fair competition.

On Tuesday evening, Soong met with figures from high-tech industries in the Bay Area in a dinner Tuesday night. He met with George Shultz, former US Secretary of State, Wednesday morning at Stanford University.

Soong and Shultz were old friends, and the meeting in San Francisco was arranged about two weeks ago. The presidential hopeful is scheduled to visit Japan next week and exchange views with Japanese scholars and politicians on the new Japan-US defense cooperation guidelines, the current situation in Northeast Asia and other topics related to regional stability and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN PARLIAMENT WELCOMES TAIWAN TO JOIN AS OBSERVER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received a delegation from the Central American Parliament at his office on Wednesday.

In addition to extending a welcome to the delegation led by Fabio Gadea Mantilla from Nicaragua, Lee lauded the formation of the parliament as a boost to the development of the Central American region.
Lee reiterated Taiwan's willingness to join the organization as an observer and vowed the nation will do its best to aid Central American development.
In the meeting, Gadea read a statement formally welcoming the Republic of China to join the body as an observer.
In an unrelated development on Wednesday, Lee met with visiting US Sen. John Rockefeller (D-West Virginia).
Lee thanked Rockefeller for his firm support of Taiwan and exchanged views with him on a broad range of issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW DEPARTS FOR CARIBBEAN SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, June 2 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew and his delegation left El Salvador for Saint Christopher and Nevis on Wednesday.

During an interview prior to departure, Siew vowed to strengthen ROC-El Salvador relations and to encourage Taiwan investment in the country. Siew also expressed his government's appreciation of the support El Salvador has given Taiwan in its attempt to join international organizations.
Saint Christopher and Nevis is the last stop of Siew's 10-day, three-nation trip to Central America and the Caribbean which also took him to Guatemala.
During his two-day stay in Saint Christopher and Nevis, Siew will meet with Governor General Cuthbert Sebastian, Premier Denzil Douglas, and other political figures.
He will attend a seminar on trade and investment between the ROC and Saint Christopher and Nevis. He will then tour model farms under the guidance of the ROC's agricultural mission to the country.

Siew will also attend a summit meeting that will include the prime ministers of Saint Christopher and Nevis, Grenada, the Commonwealth of Dominica, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. During the summit Siew will present each country with US$50,000 to aid the development of their tourism industry.

When ROC Vice President Lien Chan visited Costa Rica in May of last year, he also traveled to Grenada to attend the summit meeting of the four East Caribbean nations. The meeting has become a forum for the ROC to discuss its cooperation with East Caribbean nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling and opposition parties agreed to convene the annual National Assembly session as scheduled.
The China Times:
President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui politely declined to discuss constitutional amendments with DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.
The United Daily News:
The African National Congress is expected to win the South African national elections easily.
The Liberty Times:
The KMT-proposed constitutional amendment package rules out the expansion of National Assembly powers.
The Commons Daily:
DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung suggested that all DPP deputies absent themselves from the soon-to-be-opened National Assembly session.
The China Post:
An American jetliner crash-lands in midnight storm.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan's state-run aerospace company joins partnership with Canadian firm to build jets.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAUER CRITICIZES CLINTON'S CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential nomination candidate Gary Bauer said Wednesday that President Bill Clinton's plan to formally ask for most-favored-nation (MFN, now normal trade relations) trading status for Communist China on the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre "illustrates the shallowness and utter bankruptcy of the tin-ear foreign policy this administration has towards China."

Meanwhile, Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) noted that not only is Clinton's timing bad, so too is his policy, saying the Clinton administration's China policy, like that of the Bush administration, "has not succeeded in making trade fairer, people freer, or the world safer."

The California congresswoman said that for the past ten years, the Republican leadership has opposed the efforts of a bipartisan coalition Congressmen who have opposed the Bush-Clinton China policy. This year, with a highly charged partisan atmosphere, Republicans may want to exploit politically the failures of the Clinton China policy, while appeasing the business community by voting to give Beijing MFN (or NTR).
"The human rights situation in China and Tibet challenges the conscience of our country, and we respond with business as usual," criticized Pelosi.

Bauer, a conservative Republican, said it borders on the unbelievable that "on the very day America should be condemning the Communist Chinese government for its shameful, brutal killing of hundreds of its own people -- cold-blooded murders for which that government still refuses to take responsibility, President Clinton offers not a policy of punishment but instead of a policy of reward."

June 4 is an important day in the march for freedom, stressed Bauer, adding that "we should honor those women and men who gave their lives, some of them even walking up to tanks in a historic and memorable show of courage in pursuit of freedom.....President Clinton darkens their memory by rewarding their killers on the day of the murders. The president should at least have the dignity to choose another day."

Bauer, who has called for a new China policy, opposes both MFN and Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization. He has challenged some of his republican rivals to change their positions favoring MFN and the PRC's entry into the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICA NEEDS MISSILE DEFENSE POLICY: ANALYST

TEXT.P: Mainland China's expanding nuclear capabilities and its role in proliferating military technology highlight the need for the United States to deploy a national missile defense, and Congress now must make a policy declaration that brings an effective national missile defense into reality, according to an American defense policy analyst.

James H. Anderson, of the Heritage Foundation's International Studies Center, wrote Wednesday that despite the Cox report's startling revelations of Beijing's efforts to obtain, through legal and illegal means, a wide range of US military technology secrets and clear evidence that a missile threat from the Third World is growing, President Bill Clinton refuses to make a decision on the deployment of a national missile defense until June 2000.

The People's Republic of China's relentless efforts to acquire sophisticated US nuclear weapons designs is part of a larger strategy to promote its position as Asia's hegemonic power. And a key element of this strategy is Beijing's determination to threaten other countries with ballistic missiles, as the PRC did in 1996 during Taiwan's first direct presidential elections, noted Anderson.

Since then, the analyst said, the PRC has positioned more than 100 short-range missiles within striking range of Taiwan. "Unless the United States and its Asian allies move quickly to deploy credible missile defense systems, China will continue to flex its 'missile muscle' to intimidate its neighbors," added Anderson.

He pointed out that to counter the growing Chinese missile threat, the United States should develop sea- and space-based defenses that can identify, track and shoot down hostile missiles shortly after liftoff and before they can release multiple warheads or decoys.

This "boost-phase" intercept capability will offset the PRC's ability to threaten the United States and its allies with ballistic missiles, and also will make Third World tyrants think twice before attempting to attack the United States, said Anderson.

However, Anderson added, it is not enough for Congress to profess its commitment to deploy a national missile defense. It must provide requisite funding, oversight and programmatic direction to make this a reality. And it must not allow the defunct 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty to crimp the testing and development of technologies that hold near- and long-term promise for defending the United States against missile attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT MAINLAND ENVOY'S VISIT TO COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday it is concerned about a recent visit to Costa Rica by mainland Chinese Ambassador to the United Nations Qin Huasun.
Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of the MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, said the ministry was informed of Qin's travel plan before his departure from New York to Costa Rica.

"ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Mao Kao-wen had expressed our stance on the issue to Costa Rican authorities," Chen said, adding that Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez, in response to Taiwan's concern, had ordered all ministerial-level officials not to meet Qin during his visit.

According to press reports, Qin arrived in Costa Rica, which maintains formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, on May 30 and ended his visit on June 2. During his stay, Qin reportedly had met with Costa Rican Foreign Minister Roberto Rojas Lopez and a senior adviser to the Costa Rican president.

This was Qin's second visit to Costa Rica. He first visit the Central American country in March 1997 in an attempt to lure Cost Rica to switch its diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing. His bid, however, failed.
Against this backdrop, Qin's latest trip to Costa Rica had attracted wide attention.

Noting that Qin's latest trip was organized by a Costa Rican think tank -- the International Law Research Institute, Chen said President Rodriguez had told ROC Ambassador Mao that Qin applied for an entry visa in the name of trade promotion. "Therefore, Qin's visit was private in nature," Rodriguez was quoted as having stressed.
In addition to banning senior Costa Rican officials from meeting Qin, Rodriguez also assured Mao that the longstanding ROC-Costa Rican relationship will not be affected by Qin's visit.

Over the past few years, mainland China has made strenuous efforts to lobby Cost Rica for switching its diplomatic recognition. Mainland China has even purchased a large quantity of bananas from Cost Rica as a bait.
Chen said the MOFA will continue keeping close watch on developments after Qin's just-concluded visit to Costa Rica.

In fact, Chen said, mainland China has spared no efforts to squeeze the ROC's diplomatic frontiers. "We must work even harder to counter Beijing's attempt to isolate our country from the international community," he added.
