DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MAY DENY VISAS TO AMERICAN KKK MEMBERS

TEXT.P: White supremacists wanting to visit Australia, including members of the Ku Klux Klan, will be denied visas, the Federal Government warned.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday quoted a spokesman for Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock as saying that visa applications from KKK members and other white supremacist groups, would be examined to determine "whether or not their character is appropriate for them to enter the country."
"It could well be" that the views espoused by such groups were not compatible with the Immigration Department's character requirements for visa applications, he said.

The spokesman's warning came after Herald's reports on Wednesday that a KKK Imperial Wizard, Barry Black, would visit Australia soon to talk to the new Klan branches in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S SAVINGS RATE PLUNGES TO RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: Australia's national savings rate has plunged to a record low of only 0.4 percent during the first quarter, down sharply from 12.5 percent in 1985, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
But Federal Treasurer Peter Costello downplayed the need to implement initiatives to encourage households to spend less and save more for their future.

Costello told reporters that he was concerned about the low savings rate. "It is true to some degree that if people running low on savings they might be spending a little too much, but there is another way of looking at a rundown in savings. It is also a measure of confidence, and I think there is a lot more confidence out there now."
Savings is needed to fund local investment. Otherwise, Australian investors will have to look overseas for access money, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEX IN SPACE OK: CANADIAN ASTRONAUT

TEXT.P: Weightlessness in outer space should poise no obstacle to sex, according to a Canadian woman astronaut on Tuesday.
Julie Payette posed the theory while answering a reporter's question while orbiting the earth on board the Discovery space station.

"Right now, we are in the space station and there aren't any functions that we cannot perform because of weightlessness," Payette, speaking in French, told the reporter at the Canadian Space Agency in St. Hubert, Quebec.
"So I don't see any reason why we would have any problems with any other biological functions," she said.
Earlier Tuesday, Canadian school children joined with Prime Minister Jean Chretien in speaking with the Canadian astronaut on board the US space shuttle.
The children and Chretien used a special satellite linkup at the National Museum of Science and Technology in Ottawa.
Payette and the rest of the shuttle crew are scheduled to return to Earth Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 3, or the 20th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Jefferson Davis, the American soldier and president of the Confederate states, is born. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years, and although he was indicted for treason in 1866, he was never prosecuted.
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1864: More than 6,000 Unionists in the American Civil War are killed or wounded in less than an hour at Cold Harbor, near Richmond, Virginia.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King," and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium at Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories and novels, including "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot, "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus," and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American bride, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The US Navy launches offensive against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships, as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, a puppet regime established in China by breakaway former government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, which was reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940, is executed for being a traitor to China.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1984: The British government admits there is a higher than average level of leukemia cases around the Sellafield nuclear power station.
1989: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of state of Iran, dies at the age of 86. Arrested and exiled for his opposition to Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi's regime, he returned to Iran on the shah's downfall in 1979 and established a new constitution giving himself supreme power.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being froward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MINISTER URGES US TO HEAL RIFT WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Australian Defence Minister John Moore said Wednesday that he would urge the United States to promptly respond to mainland Chinese demands for an apology and compensation for the NATO bombing of its embassy in Belgrade.
In an interview with The Australian on Wednesday, Moore said he would soon call his US counterpart -- Defence Secretary William Cohen -- to pass on his concerns and urge the U.S. to respond quickly.
"I think it's not at all unreasonable for them to ask for a proper response to the bombing and I'd urge America to respond," Moore told the Australian daily.
Moore, who returned to Canberra from a trip to China, Japan and South Korea last week, said anti-American feeling is pretty strong in mainland China.
The US has apologised for the bombing of the embassy, which it insists was accidental.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.1 percent higher on Thursday to reclaim the psychological 7,500-point level on strong buying in the financial sector.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index surged 84.88 points to close at 7,572.91 points, posting a gain for the third consecutive day.
A total of 3.23 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$155.58 billion (US$4.75 billion), up from the previous session's NT$118.98 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, financial shares posted the largest gains of the day, rising 2.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks, which climbed 1.9 percent.
Construction shares went up 1.6 percent, textiles shares advanced 1.2 percent and foodstuff issues gained 0.8 percent.
Cement stocks and paper and pulp issues both posted 0.5-percent growth, while the electronics sector went up 0.3 percent.
Advancers led decliners 276 to 146, with 85 issues unchanged.
The over-the-counter market climbed 0.69 points to close at 174.27 points, with a turnover of NT$9.01 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June rose 58 points to close at 7,510, with 3,292 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July gained 65 points to close at 7,514 points, while those for September climbed 47 points to close at 7,500 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 375 and 39, respectively.

December futures went up 59 points, closing at 7,540 points, with 2 contract transactions. Futures for next March posted the only loss of the day, dropping 28 points to close at 7,550, with 1 contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,452 points for June, 7,449 points for July, 7,453 points for September, 7,481 points for December and 7,578 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA ENCOURAGES TAIWAN TO TAP CENTRAL AND EAST EUROPE MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen could use distribution centers and warehouses located in west Europe as based to open central and east European markets, said Kao Yi-hsin, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) on Wednesday.

Kao recently led a delegation of some 60 Taiwanese companies to Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and Macedonia to express Taiwan's interest in expanding economic coorperation with those countries and to promote Taiwan-made products.
After the visit, Kao said the countries were receptive to the idea of business cooperation.
According to Kao, Taiwanese businessmen can make use of the distribution system used in the Netherlands to approach the targeted European markets.

Because Macedonia's economic activities have become almost paralyzed due to the bombing in Yugoslavia, Kao suggested Taiwan provide Macedonia with management skill to improve business operations so that the country can struggle through its present difficulties.

Taiwan could help Macedonia to revive its industries of scale by attracting foreign capital and offering job opportunities. In the meantime, Taiwan can tap into Macedonian textile, foodstuff and plastic product industries with local raw materials, Kao added.
In order to facilitate the new trade and investment opportunities in central and east Europe, Kao will urge Taiwan banks to provide local businessmen with sufficient capital.

In line with the Ministry of Economic Affairs' plan of promoting external trade, CETRA will sponsor a trade fair in Taiwan for countries in central and east Europe in the near future. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS IN MAINLAND CHINA SAID LITTLE CHANGED

TEXT.P: On the eve of the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre, the president of Amnesty International in Queensland said little progress has been made in mainland China in regard to human rights, as trade, financial and commercial interests have taken precedence.

In a speech at Queensland University of Technology in Brisbane on Wednesday, Ross Daniels said that in the current "economics first" climate, it is not fashionable to remind governments of the horrors of Tiananmen.

"Despite this, human rights activists will continue their demands on behalf of those who were killed, injured and imprisoned," he said in an article published in The Australian Financial Review on Thursday.

"Governments, including the present Australian government, should understand that justice for the victims of Tiananmen will remain illusory while good governance principles of transparency and accountability are sacrificed on the altar of short-term economic expediency," he said.

Despite its signing of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights in 1997 and of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1998, mainland China has continued to violate the rights of free association, free speech and freedom of assembly, Daniels said.

Meanwhile, a report Thursday in The Australian indicates mainland China has moved to close Internet chat rooms, prohibit access to Cable News Network satellite broadcasts and ban transmissions of sensitive television footage in the run-up to Friday, the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR TO VISIT JAPAN FROM SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 2 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Wednesday revealed that he will fly to Japan from San Francisco, as he prepares for his third visit to a foreign country in a month.
Besides his current US visit, Soong visited the Philippines late last month.

Soong called on former US Secretary of State George Shultz at Stanford University's Hoover Institute Wednesday. During his visit to the institute, the Taiwan political celebrity disclosed his plans to visit Japan.
Soong will discuss with Japanese politicians regional security issues and the Japan-US security treaty, which affects Taiwan's security and cross-strait relations, Soong said.

In his meeting with Shultz, Soong was praised as a good man who is endowed with a great deal of wisdom. Shultz, however, refused to comment on Taiwan's 2000 presidential election or whether Soong is qualified to run for the position.

Shultz was in charge of US foreign policy during the Bush administration, and he encouraged Taiwan and mainland China to promote exchanges, and to deal with disputes through communication. He has a reputation as an expert in the Asian-Pacific region and cross-strait affairs.
After the one-hour meeting, Shultz said he understands Soong's opinions on Taiwan's political and economic development, as well as on the island's relations with foreign countries.

Soong, who ended his stint as Taiwan's first and last popularly elected governor late last year, is the front-runner in next year's presidential election, even though he has not yet announced his candidacy.
Soong arrived in San Francisco on Monday, where he gave a speech on Taiwan's democracy a day later. He is scheduled to head for Japan on Saturday.
During Soong's May 21-24 Philippine visit, he met with incumbent Philippine President Joseph Estrada and former Presidents Corazon Aquino and Fidel Ramos.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BRITISH BUSINESS COUNCIL LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-British Business Council was formally launched on Thursday, signaling a breakthrough in bilateral trade relations between the two countries.
Leslie Koo, president of Taiwan Cement, and Colin Green, director of operations at Rolls-Royce Plc, will act as co-chairmen of the business council.

The Department of Trade and Industry of Britain first broached the idea of setting up such a business council during ROC-UK trade consultations in 1997. After the idea was actively promoted by Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade, it was formally launched.
The council comprises top businessmen from both nations. It currently has 19 members from Taiwan and 16 members from the United Kingdom.
Green will come to Taipei to attend the first joint meeting of the business council on June 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,400 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS LURKING IN TAIWAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: An estimated 1,400 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants are hiding themselves in Taiwan, posing a threat to Taiwan's public order and national security, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said on Thursday.
The minister made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's interior affairs committee.
Huang said the undiscovered illegal mainland immigrants include Chinese Communist Party and youth corps members as well as criminal ring members.
"The presence of these people is a threat to our national security and public order," Huang noted.

Quoting official tallies, Huang said 26 percent of uncovered mainland stowaways were seized at airports, sea ports, coastal areas or fishing boats off the Taiwan coasts. And the remaining 74 percent were discovered at various places on the island.
Huang said some of the uncovered mainland stowaways were Chinese communists or youth corps members, while a few others were underworld figures.

"Some of those seized mainland gangsters had colluded with their local counterparts in embarking on drug trafficking, firearm smuggling, gambling, robbery, extortion and murder," Huang said, adding that all those mainland suspects have been transferred to law enforcement authorities for prosecution.
Huang said the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior was authorized to investigate illegal mainland immigrants and other related affairs in July 1991.

In 1992, 3,709 mainland stowaways were seized and the number reached a peak in 1993 when 5,643 mainland stowaways were uncovered. By 1998, the number had declined to 1,126. In all, Huang said, 35,491 illegal mainland immigrants were seized or intercepted between 1992 and 1998.

Speaking on the same occasion, independent legislator Huang Yi-chiao said he believes that the decline in the number of seized mainland stowaways could be attributed to mainland China's fast economic growth in recent years which he said has encouraged mainland people to work in their own hometowns.
Against this background, Huang said he thinks economic factors are no longer a core reason behind the influx of illegal mainland immigrants into Taiwan.
"I'm convinced that nowadays the main purposes for mainland people to smuggle themselves into Taiwan are intelligence gathering or engaging in criminal activities," the lawmaker said.
In reply, Minister Huang said the ministry has intensified investigations of illegal mainland immigrants and has carefully analyzed backgrounds of all seized mainland immigrants to facilitate probes.
Meanwhile, the minister said he will study the feasibility of imposing harsher punishment on local employers who hire illegal mainland immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SAYS MFN RENEWAL FOR MAINLAND CHINA WILL BENEFIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's decision to renew most favored nation (MFN) trading status for mainland China will benefit Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and Taiwan's re-exports to mainland China through Hong Kong, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
Some congressmen have reportedly objected to the decision, but it is expected that Congress will not be able to muster enough "no" votes to override Clinton's decision.

MOEA officials said NATO's accidental bombing of mainland China's embassy in Belgrade and a recent US report on mainland Chinese espionage in the United States have strained US-mainland Chinese relations. This has resulted in a moratorium on bilateral talks on mainland China's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO). Faced with these problems, Clinton should take a low-key approach to promoting MFN renewal for mainland China, they said.

The officials said Clinton's decision to extend mainland China's MFN status will help mainland China's exports to grow, and that will be good news for Taiwan businessmen on the mainland. Clinton's decision will also benefit Taiwan goods re-exported to mainland China through Hong Kong, they said.
It has been estimated that 70 percent of Taiwan goods exported to Hong Kong are re-exported to mainland China through Hong Kong.
The US Congress must decide whether to approve Clinton's decision within 30 days of its submission to Congress.
According to US law, a two-thirds majority is needed to override President Clinton's decision.
Mainland China has enjoyed MFN status since 1980, the year after it established diplomatic ties with the United States.
Over the past 19 years, MFN status for mainland China has always been renewed, even after the Tiananmen incident in 1989.
Mainland China's status, however, is still subject to annual review, though once the mainland enters the WTO, both countries will automatically extend permanent MFN status to the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHER NAMED 'HONORARY MEMBER' OF US ACADEMY

TEXT.P: Typhoon Lee, a researcher with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic body, has been named a "foreign honorary member" of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Lee, a researcher jointly employed by Academia Sinica's Institute of Earth Sciences and the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, is the first local researcher to receive the honor.

The 219-year-old American Academy said it has selected Lee as its "foreign honorary member" because he is one of the discoverers who proved that aluminum-26 was alive in the solar system 4.56 billion years ago.

The academy, founded by the second US president, John Adams, in 1780, also cited Lee's other research achievements, including helping to create a theory for the formation of chondritic meteorites; investigating the relationship of their oxygen, magnesium, calcium, and lanthanum isotopic anomalties to Galactic nucleosynthetic events; and using isotopic methods to deduce the hisotry of Asian land masses and the past climate.

Lee said titles or awards are not the ultimate goal of a researcher. "The msot important thing for me is to explore the secrets of the universe and natural phenomena," Lee said, adding that the honor from the American Academy marks a recognition of Taiwan's efforts in scientific research.

Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said the American Academy's recognition of Typhoon Lee's achievement also marks Taiwan's progress in some scientific research fields.

The Nobel laureate said some Academia Sinica academicians have been named members of several prestigious foreign research institutions. But all of them reside abroad. "Typhoon Lee is the first Academia Sinica resident research fellow to be named a foreign honorary member of the American Academy," he added.
The American Academy currently has 3,500 academicians and 600 foreign honorary members, including 170 Nobel Prize winners and 60 Pulitzer Prize laureates.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC HOPING FOR GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The head of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) stressed on Thursday that every aspect of the construction of a domestic high-speed railway should proceed according to the railway's construction contract.

MOTC Minister Lin Fong-cheng made the remark in response to reports that the head of the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) wants the government to act as an investor to aid in the railway's construction.

The railway system's construction is being carried out under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula -- a private consortium builds and operates the system for a specified period of time, and after that period control of the system is transferred to the government.
THSRC Chair Nita Ing paid a visit to Premier Vincent Siew earlier this year, and during that meeting she expressed her hope that the government would invest in, as well as supervise, the THSRC.
To date, however, the government has not directly replied to Ing's request.

Government investment is totally different from government financing, according to the THSRC. And according to the Industrial Upgrading Promotion Statute, government investments can amount to up to 20 percent of the cost of a project, said the THSRC officials, adding that they hope the government will become a partner of the THSRC.

Lin said he was not aware of the meeting between Ing and Siew. He noted that the BOT formula has been adopted in the construction of the high-speed railway. The contract signed last July between the MOTC and the THSRC has complied with all the rules of the BOT agreement. The contract indicates that the government does not need to finance its construction, Lin said.
As to the 28 project-related tasks that have to be completed by the government by June 30, Lin promised to have them all completed before the deadline.

The government has completed 22 tasks, though the six most difficult remain unfulfilled, according to Ing. The six unfulfilled items include land acquisition and the tearing down of factories. The railway project will be at a standstill until all tasks are completed, said Ing earlier this week.
Ing said she doubted that the government could complete the six remaining tasks in one month.

The high-speed railway project is valued at NT$400 billion. Ing acknowledged that the THSRC has had fund-raising difficulties. Under its current financing plan, the THSRC will reportedly ask for an NT$280 billion loan from the government, and NT$120 billion in syndicated loans from banks.
Lin stressed that the MOTC will do its best to assist the THRSC in getting the bank loans.
The high-speed railway project is the first of its kind in Taiwan. Ground was broken in late March, and it is scheduled to be completed in 2003.

Chung Hwa High-Speed Rail Consortium (CHHSRC) was edged out by the THSRC in bidding for the contract last year. The most important factor behind THSRC's winning the contract was that the THSRC did not request government funding while the CHHSRC insisted on government financing of up to NT$100 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CALLS FOR INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION IN FIGHTING NARCOTICS

TEXT.P: A senior official with the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) on Thursday called for closer international cooperation in fighting contraband drugs.

Chang Hsiang-shan, a division chief with the MJIB's anti-narcotics center, made the appeal at a national anti-drug meeting held in connection with the June 3 Opium Suppression Movement Day, which has been observed since 1930 the Republic of China in commemoration of the burning of imported opium in 1839 during the Opium War against the British.
Chang said the ROC has devoted much effort to curb drug trafficking and abuse. However, the United States has continued listing Taiwan as one of the world's 28 main drug transshipment centers.

Chang said the greatest obstacle to drug investigations is changes in smuggling channels and modes. "With changes in social environment and communications tools, drug dealers now have often traveled abroad to negotiate trade deals, making it more difficult to eradicate such illegal trade."
Chang said cross-border drug trafficking has made it more important to strengthen international cooperation in fighting such operations.
Chang said container shipment remains the most common way for drug trafficking, and amphetamine and heroin form the bulk of seized contraband drugs.

According to MJIB tallies, mainland China is the top source of amphetamine seized in Taiwan, with fishing boats as the main smuggling tool. Meanwhile, Chiang Kai-shek International Port, Taiwan's main gateway, accounts for the largest share of heroin seized in Taiwan.
Chang said all relevant government agencies should cooperate even more closely to fight drug trafficking and abuse in order to protect public health and national image.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR PREPARING FOR FOREIGN COMPETITION IN HOG RAISING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest hog raiser, the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation (Taisugar), is branching out overseas in order to protect itself from the impact of Taiwan's market-opening to foreign products.
Because of this market opening, Taisugar has had to cut its domestic hog-raising operation by one-third according to company officials.
The officials said on Thursday that the company plans to invest NT$800 million (US$24.46 million) to establish a series of hog farms in Canada, each of which will have a 130,000-head capacity.

The three-stage investment is planned for a 2000 launch, which will allow market sales by 2002, the officials said, pointing out that the produce can be shipped to a number of markets including the United States and Japan, or even back to Taiwan.

Taisugar pork is popular in Japan because of a "special sweetness" the product is said to have. Although Japanese orders have declined over the past few years due to a two-year export ban following an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease in Taiwan, Taisugar executives said the company believes it can regain its market share with its Canadian pork.
In addition, Taisugar is also negotiating to invest in two hog farms in Australia with a total capacity of 450,000 head.

Last year, Taiwan opened its market to US-produced chicken, pork and offal, as part of its bid for membership of the World Trade Organization (WTO). However, the opening triggered a wave of demands from other WTO members for equivalent treatment.

During WTO multilateral working meetings which took place in Geneva earlier this year, Taipei representatives promised a global quota for imports of agricultural products, and that the quotas can be raised gradually from as early as July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar slipped on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market on Thursday, losing NT$0.002 to end the day at NT$32.733.
A total of US$352 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.765, and fluctuated between NT$32.733 and NT$32.767 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINOR TYPHOON MAGGIE MIGHT AFFECT TAIWAN ON SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Winds whipped up by minor typhoon Maggie are expected to affect Taiwan on Saturday, although the storm at present is still some way from the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said on Thursday.

The CWB said Maggie, whose power is still strengthening, is now situated over the seas east of the Philippines, and moving in a north north-westerly direction. Its speed has also accelerated from 11 kilometers per hour to 13 kilometers per hour, and its storm radius has increased to 200 kilometers, the CWB said, while cautioning the public to pay close attention to news about the typhoon's progress.

The weather bureau forecast that winds generated by the typhoon will affect Taiwan with sporadic showers first hitting eastern and southeastern Taiwan. It will rain islandwide on Sunday and Monday, according to the bureau.

The CWB said that because there is another area of low pressure over the seas west of the Philippines, it will not be clear until Friday whether or not Maggie will directly affect the island on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEA POPULAR IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan tea, especially the Paochong and Oolong varieties, have become popular in mainland China because of their "special fragrance," the Taiwan Tea Manufacturers' Association (TTMA) said on Thursday.

TTMA Chairman Hsu Fa-cheng noted that although mainland China is one of the world's major tea producers, while Taiwan produces less than one percent of the world's tea, Taiwan tea has nevertheless made inroads into the mainland market.

Hsu made the remarks while announcing that a delegation comprising around 70 Taiwan tea producers and representatives of Taiwan's farmers associations will attend an international tea exhibition which opens on June 18 in Beijing.

He said that despite the fact that mainland China's Puer and Dragon Well teas are world famous, and very popular in Taiwan, it is the special fragrances of Taiwan's Oolong and Paochong teas which have won the hearts of the mainland Chinese.

Prize-winning tea from Taiwan has become a hot gift item among Taiwan businessmen hoping to impress their mainland counterparts, so much so that some reports claim that most of this championship tea is purchased by Taiwan businessmen to be used as business deal sweeteners.

Hsu said that with mainland China's economic growth, consumer spending power has substantially increased, and many tea shops in the mainland are eager to stock Taiwan tea. At the same time, Taiwan businessmen who open tea houses in the mainland also prefer to feature tea from the island.
The Taiwan government bans the import of tea from the mainland, but it is still easily obtained due to the frequency with which it is smuggled into the country.
Hsu said that the government should accept this fact, and open Taiwan's markets to legally imported mainland tea, as he said this would deter smuggling and provide revenue from import tariffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADULTS SHOULD BE RESPONSIBLE FOR SCHOOLYARD INCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Adults should be held responsible for a recent series of schoolyard "forbidden game" incidents in Taiwan, according to women's rights groups.

That agreement came Thursday at the "Innocent Young Couple vs. Forbidden Games--The Adults' Role in Schoolyard Incidents" press conference held by several local women's rights associations, including the Awakening Foundation and the Humanistic Education Foundation, and women's rights activists.
Yang Fang-wan, chairman of the Awakening Foundation, said that it is inappropriate to rashly charge children in primary school under current sexual assault laws.

Yang said it is necessary to offer juveniles proper counseling, especially in view of Taiwan's long-standing lack of appropriate and diversified sexual education, adding that it is unfair to punish children.

Wu Li-fen, executive director of the Humanistic Education Foundation, pointed out that previous sexual education offered only an adult's point of view toward the world of children, which meant teenagers were in the dark as to how their sexual development ought to occur.
She said these incidents should teach adults a lesson, namely that adults need further sexual education as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR HIGHLIGHTS PLIGHT OF TAIWAN'S GROWING NUMBER OF SINGLE MOMS

TEXT.P: The number of single mothers is on the rise in Taiwan, and the government should pay more attention to this issue, said a sociology professor at National Taiwan University Thursday.

Professor Wang Li-jung, who is also a member of the Women's Rights Promotion Committee (WRPC) under the Executive Yuan, spoke at the "Women's Policy Blueprint Over the Millennium" seminar joinly sponsored by the WRPC and the Women's Rights Promotion Foundation.

Wang pointed out that the number of instances of divorce, separation, abandonment, spousal loss and illegitimate children have risen due to social changes. The number of single mothers has risen particularly sharply.
In 1996 single mothers accounted for some 60 percent of Taiwan's 390,300 one-parent families, about 6.7 percent of the total number of families in Taiwan, according to official statistics.

Wang said women have traditionally received less respect in Taiwan society, which adds to their burdens as single mothers. Their main problems are economic, and these problems have a negative influence on the upbringing of children.
Single mothers face more psychological pressure as well, having to cope with family pressures, social stigmas and gossip, all of which add to their emotional burden, Wang said.
In addition, Wang said, present custody laws and visitation rights tend to favor fathers.

Wang suggested the government provide more help to single parents through social welfare systems, the aim of which would be to establish the well-rounded social welfare facilities needed by single mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM, TAIPOWER MOST PROFITABLE COMPANIES IN 1998

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan Power Co. and Central Investment Holding were the three most profitable corporations in 1998 in Taiwan, the latest issue of Business Weekly said on Thursday.
After a compilation of data from numerous companies, Business Weekly released on Thursday its 1998 rankings for 500 Taiwan service corporations.
The 10 most profitable companies were President Enterprises Corp., Evergreen, Hotai Group, China Airlines, KG Group, Far Eastern Group, Yulon Group, Shinkong Group, Pacific Group and Chin Fong Group.
This is the first time President has overtaken Evergreen, which held the top spot for the past three years, as Taiwan's top business group.

The 10 largest corporations were Chunghwa Telecom, Taipower, Hotai Motors Co., China Airlines, EVA Airways Co., President Chainstore Co., Nissan Taiwan Ltd., Fortune Motors Co., Yangming Marine Transport Corp. and Sino Diamond Motors Co. Of those companies only President Chainstore is a retail service provider.

According to Business Weekly, the average increase in turnover for the 500 companies in 1998 was only 4.18 percent, compared with 17.37 percent in 1997. In addition, 33 percent of the companies either earned no profit or were in the red last year as a result of the region's financial turmoil.
The average operational profits of the 500 reached 5.95 percent, down from the 11.27 percent in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE DISSIDENTS DETAINED BEFORE TIANANMEN ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 mainland Chinese dissidents have been detained by police in recent weeks because they wanted to observe on Friday the 10th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that on Thursday alone six dissidents were detained in Beijing and Hangzhou, the capital city of eastern Zhejiang province.

Mainland Chinese public security authorities are trying to avoid public commemorations of the 1989 Tiananmen incident, in which hundreds of demonstrators were killed, by detaining and keeping surveillance of dissidents in the country. Of the nearly 100 dissidents detained recently, at least 34 are still in police custody, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN ENVOYS PROMOTING COFFEE IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The envoys to the Republic of China from El Salvador, Guatemala and Nicaragua on Thursday announced that an exhibition of Central American coffee will be held on Sunday in this southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

El Salvadoran Ambassador David Ernesto Panama, Guatemalan Ambassador Luis Noriega, and Nicaraguan Councilor Eugenio Cano made the announcement to recommend their countries' specialty coffees, in the hope of gaining a foothold in the large Taiwan coffee-drinking market.

The exhibition, the vanguard of a move toward "coffee diplomacy," is aimed at introducing the coffee culture of various Central American countries and the development of the international coffee market to the people of Taiwan, and to show the "proper" way to drink coffee.
Although the number of coffee-drinkers in Taiwan has skyrocketed in recent years, Central America, the world's fourth-largest coffee producing region, does not have a large hold on the Taiwan market.
Local coffee drinkers are familiar with Brazilian, Blue Mountain, Mocha, Java and Colombian coffees, but few of them know much about Central America's specialty coffees.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRYING TO POSTPONE TOP ENVOY'S TAIWAN TRIP: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Beijing is seeking to postpone a planned trip to Taiwan by its top envoy with the island as a way of pushing Taiwan to the negotiation table for political talks, experts attending a seminar said on Thursday.

Beijing will use the "technical" approach to postpone the visit by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), from the slated autumn date to a date at the end of the year, according to the academics and professors.

Speaking at the symposium sponsored by the Foundation for National Development Research to mark the 10th anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen Square massacre, Pan Hsi-tang, a mainland China affairs professor at Tamkang University, said Beijing will undoubtedly allow Wang to visit Taiwan this year, as it is one of the major events in the mainland's dealings with Taiwan on its 1999-2000 agenda.

Referring to comments by mainland China-based think tanks, Pan said Beijing will use "technical" means to delay Wang's trip to Taiwan to November or December in a bid to force Taiwan to accept its terms that Wang will only discuss political issues with Koo Chen-fu, his Taiwan counterpart and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), during his Taiwan trip.

As an example of these "technical" moves, Pan cited Beijing's postponement of trips to the mainland by SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow and his deputy Jan Jih-horng until late June. Jan was originally supposed to head for the mainland earlier than Shi for talks to pave the way for Wang's Taiwan visit.

While repeatedly declaring that Wang's visit to Taiwan will be more than just a sightseeing tour, and that he cannot return to the mainland empty-handed, Beijing has been airing its view to the international community that cross-Taiwan Strait political talks will focus on three issues -- the end of hostilities under the framework of "one China," the establishment of direct trade, postal, and shipping links, and Taiwan's international presence, according to Pan.
Aware of Beijing's tactics, Taipei has insisted that the topics of the upcoming Koo-Wang talks will not be limited to just political issues, Pan added.

As to the question of whether cross-strait relations have been affected by the deteriorating Washington-Beijing ties following NATO's bombing of Beijing's embassy in Belgrade, the mainland affairs expert said that the setback in US-mainland links is temporary, and that the two sides will continue with their engagement after resolving their current disputes.

Y.K. Ko, a professor from National Taiwan University, said Taiwan should continue its dealings with mainland China in order to help the mainland undergo peaceful transformation into a democracy, while seeking to join the Theater Missile Defense (TMD) shield proposed by the US for its allies in East Asia.

However, Ko warned that while joining the TMD would certainly provide Taiwan with greater security, it would also block the development of cross-strait ties, and he suggested that the government should play the TMD proposal close to its chest.

He predicted that there will be no substantial breakthrough in Taipei-Beijing links before the island's presidential elections slated for March 2000, but echoed Pan's view that Wang will definitely visit Taiwan as it is already set in Beijing's agenda.
The future of cross-strait relations will mainly depend on the policy of Taiwan's next president, Ko added.

Y.S. Liao, a member of the National Security Council, called on the government to be on high alert in its dealings with mainland China at present, because of what he called the many "unseen obstacles" in Beijing-Washington ties.

Meanwhile, Lin Cho-shui, a lawmaker of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said that cross-strait relations will not undergo any major changes, as basic differences between the two sides have yet to be resolved. Future bilateral exchanges will be more ceremonial rather than substantive, he added.

After years of carrot-or-stick dealings with Taiwan, the Beijing regime has now realized that it must adopt a firm but non-violent approach to its dealings with Taiwan, since it is impossible for Beijing to achieve its goals regarding Taiwan overnight, he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA MAY GIVE FPG 60 MORE DAYS TO DISPOSE OF TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is considering granting a 60-day extension for Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to handle a shipment of toxic waste temporarily stored in an offshore warehouse at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

EPA received a letter from FPG last week in which it asked that it be given a 90-day grace period to help facilitate the handling of the mercury-laced waste. It also expressed the hope that the waste could be allowed into Taiwan for handling, but this request was rejected.

FPG officials said that they have applied for permission to ship the waste to the United States, but information from the Environmental Protection Agency there shows that three environmental groups have expressed concern about the possibility of the waste being allowed into the United States.

The officials noted that it usually takes a month for a US agency to process an application for entry in cases such as this, and added that while the application process has yet to come to a conclusion, if it is approved, the waste will be allowed into the country in stages.

Taiwan's EPA allowed the waste to be stored at Kaohsiung Harbor for 45 days after it was shipped back from its original disposal site in Cambodia in early April. The temporary storage period will expire on June 6, and if the FPG has not made arrangements by then, it will be punished according to the law.

But the EPA officials said that in view of FPG's efforts to comply with the transshipment, the EPA is considering granting a 60-day grace period, but will also ask the group to complete plans to transship the waste to an alternative location within the 60 days in case the United States does not approve the application. If FPG fails to do so, it will face daily fines for each day the waste remains at Kaohsiung Harbor.

The controversial waste was first shipped from an FPG plant in southern Taiwan late last year to the southern coastal town of Sihanoukville in Cambodia, where it was improperly stored, causing panic and chaos among the town's residents.
FPG apologized to Cambodia for causing unrest among its residents, and shipped the waste in 30 containers back to Taiwan in early April.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER TO VISIT MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: San Christopher and Nevis, June 2 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew is expected to visit Macedonia later this year, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.
Hu, who is accompanying Siew on a 10-day visit to Central America and the Caribbean, made the remarks as the premier arrived in San Christopher and Nevis on the last stop of his three-nation visit.
Macedonian Premier Ljubco Georgievski is scheduled to visit Taiwan on June 6.

Macedonia will hold a presidential election in October, the result of which will be crucial to further cooperation between the ROC and the Balkan nation, Hu said, adding that after Georgievski's visit to Taiwan June 6, Siew will pay a reciprocal call, probably no later than October.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HOLD INVESTMENT SEMINAR ON MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: In line with the upcoming visit by Macedonian officials to Taiwan, the Republic of China government is to sponsor a seminar to introduce the country's investment climate to the local business community.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will jointly sponsor the three-day investment seminar which will open on June 8.
Macedonian Premier Ljubo Georgievski, leading a 50-member delegation, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on June 6 for a weeklong visit.

A CETRA official who recently returned from an inspection tour to Macedonia said that both the Macedonian government and its people have high expectations that Taiwan businesses will invest in their country.

Although its economy has been adversely affected by the war in Yugoslavia and the resultant influx of ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring Kosovo Province, the CETRA official said Macedonia is a promising market untapped by Taiwan businesses.
Two-way Taiwan-Macedonia trade remained limited as of the end of last year, with the figure totaling just over US$100,000, government statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, June 3 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: South Korean President Kim Dae Jung on Thursday expressed the hope that Asia can recreate its economic miracle through regional economic cooperation.

Kim made the remarks at a reception for ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, mainland China's Assistant Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Ma Xiuhong and eight other officials attending an investment fair which took place in Seoul from June 1-5 under the sponsorship of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
During the 40-minute meeting, they discussed regional economic cooperation under the APEC framework.
Wang, the first ROC ministerial-level official to visit South Korea since the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in August 1992, said he received a warm welcome from Kim.

The South Korean president also said that as his country is struggling to overcome its financial crisis, he has come to realize the importance of free trade and foreign investment, but added that South Korea has a traditional aversion toward the introduction of foreign capital.

However, Kim said he never misses an opportunity to advocate the benefits of the introduction of foreign capital, including transparency in business management, promotion of overseas markets, and the subsequent increased job opportunities for local people.

He stressed that one lesson South Korea has drawn from the financial crisis which has swept through the region since mid-1997 is that one country cannot insulate itself from crises in other countries, and he urged Wang and his other guests to dedicate themselves to regional economic cooperation in order to create a new economic miracle for the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BANKER REITERATES WILLINGNESS TO HELP BUILD HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY

TEXT.P: Although it failed in its bid to build the island's first high-speed railway, the Chung Hwa High-Speed Rail Consortium (CHHSRC) is willing to help its business rival to complete the project, CHHSRC head Liu Tai-ying said on Thursday.

In a five-point statement, the head of the Kuomintang-owned China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB) which is the backbone of the CHHSRC, said that contrary to reports that he had been told to block the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) from carrying out the project, he was instructed by KMT leaders to help THSRC finish the construction.

However, Liu said he believed all along that the THSRC was too optimistic in its estimation of the project's cost, which led it to win the contract by offering to construct the railway at an unrealistically low price.
He said his bank would be more than willing to help THSRC out of its fund-raising difficulties if the THSRC would allow CDIB staff to examine the basis of its calculation of the cost.
The CDIB has so far balked at investing money in the island's largest-ever infrastructure project because of the THSRC's reluctance to reveal its cost estimate, said Liu.

Nevertheless, he offered to lend THSRC the NT$280 billion (US$8.75 billion) it needs to finish the project, providing the loan is guaranteed by the government, and providing the CDIB is given the exclusive right to raise any further funds for the project.
He also suggested that the government extend by three years the THSRC's franchise to operate the railway after construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER VISITS SAINT CHRISTOPHER AND NEVIS
DOC.DATELINE: Saint Christopher and Nevis, June 3 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew arrived in Saint Christopher and Nevis on Wednesday afternoon on the last leg of a three-nation visit to Central America and the Caribbean.
Siew and his 60-member entourage were greeted at the airport by Saint Christopher and Nevis Premier Denzil Douglas with full military honors.

On the way from the airport to Basseterre, the capital of the Caribbean country, Siew's motorcade was greeted by more than a hundred elementary school students who were granted scholarships by the ROC.

Siew met with Saint Christopher and Nevis Governor Cuthbert Montraville Sebastian on Wednesday evening, at a dinner which was also attended by the heads of government from the Caribbean states of Grenada, the Commonwealth of Dominica, and Saint Vincent and Grenadines.

On Thursday, Siew and his entourage of ROC officials and business leaders, attended a seminar on trade and investment between the ROC and Saint Christopher and Nevis. Siew promised at the seminar that ROC will help the state's development by beefing up trade ties.
A summit between Siew and his counterparts from the four eastern Caribbean states was slated for later in the day.
Siew, who left Taipei on May 27, has already visited Guatemala and El Salvador. He is expected to leave the island on Friday and return to Taipei via the United States on June 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT TO DEAL WITH COMMUNISTS AT REGIONAL LEVEL

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Thursday authorized his government to deal with communist groups at the regional level following the termination of peace talks with the National Democratic Front.

Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense has given his assurance that the armed forces will be ready to deal with any "military contingencies" as a result of the termination of peace talks with the communist rebels, according to Vice President Gloria Arroyo. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang-proposed constitutional amendment package includes a provision for popular exercise of initiative and referendum powers on critical national affairs.
The China Times:

The United Daily News:

The China Post:
Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic accepts Kosovo peace plan.
The Taiwan News:
Serbs accept Western peace plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SCHOLAR DOES NOT RECOMMEND QUICK REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Before mainland China really begins the process of democratization, the reunification of Taiwan and the mainland is not recommended, said Yen Jiaqi, a dissident Chinese scholar and a visiting professor at Columbia University.
Yen said a federation formula is more viable for Taiwan and mainland China when they talk of possible unification.

Yen and several other renowned mainland Chinese scholars are here to take part in a June 4 roundtable meeting on mainland China's democracy and on the country's reforms. The meeting will be held Friday evening at the Grand Hotel.
The meeting is being sponsored by the Central Broadcasting System of the Republic of China in commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square incident in 1989.

Three other Chinese scholars are Yang Jianli, founder of the San Francisco-based 21st Century China Foundation; Ruan Ming, a former senior Chinese Communist Party public official; and Kuan Weiyen, former director of the Institute of Physics under the prestigious Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Yen, who has shunned media contact in recent years, came to Taipei at the invitation of Central Broadcasting "because he accidentally heard of radio broadcasting from the Taipei-based company right after he was wanted by the Chinese authorities in the wake of the 1989 massacre." He then became an avid and regular listener to its broadcasts.

Formerly president of China's Political Restructuring Research Society, Yen said he chose to come to Taipei to take part in activities commemorating the June 4 incident because he considers Taipei the greatest place where Chinese people are living. Taiwan's democratization will have a profound influence on mainland China's social and political evolution, he said.

Yen, who in 1989 fled to France, where he lived for several years before going to the United States, said that even New York and London's Chinatowns cannot compete with Taipei's Chunghsiao East Road in terms of economic development.
Citing Taiwan and Hong Kong as the only hope of bringing about mainland China's democratization, Yen said Taiwan today is mainland China tomorrow.

Citing President Lee Teng-hui's recent proposal of dividing China into seven regions, Yen said the idea is impressive. Actually, China can be divided into eight or nine regions to more rationally make the nation a federation of separate states, he said.

Meanwhile, Yang, who obtained Ph.D. from both Harvard University and the University of California, Berkeley, said the "seven-region" proposal provides a window for all Chinese people to think about China's future. He recommended the federation concept, saying that a Chinese federation looks like a group of separated states, but actually they are united as one country.
Yang also said he does not think the time is ripe for Taiwan and mainland China to reunify, since it will take a very long time for mainland China to evolve into a democracy with the rule of order.

Kuan, who renounced his Chinese Communist Party membership during the democracy movement in 1989 and is now a visiting professor at National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu, said rehabilitating disgraced or imprisoned student activists and other democracy campaigners in the 1989 democracy movement is the most important thing that the mainland Chinese authorities should do now.

A renowned superconductivity expert, Kuan was the first mainland Chinese scholar to be invited by an educational institute in Taiwan to teach here after 1989. He was president of Hefei University of Science and Technology in Anhui before leaving the mainland.

Meanwhile, Central Broadcasting is also conducting call-out and call-in programs to allow a number of the Tiananmen Square student leaders who are now residing overseas to take part in the roundtable meeting through long-distance calls, further increasing the discussion's significance.
The former student leaders who will be joining the discussion Friday will include Feng Cungdeh from France, and Li Lu, Wang Dan, and Sheng Tung from the United States.

The roundtable meeting will be simultaneously broadcast at home and abroad, covering areas throughout mainland China and North America. The program will also be transmitted through the Internet radio, allowing on-line viewers to see the discussion, according to Central Broadcasting officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS URGED TO SUPPORT NTR STATUS FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton urged Congress Thursday to support his decision to renew Normal Trade Relations (NTR) status for mainland China, claiming that maintaining NTR with Beijing will promote America's economic and security interests.

Clinton said in a statement that NTR with mainland China is good for Americans, because US exports to mainland China have quadrupled over the past decade and support some 400,000 American jobs. Revoking NTR would derail ongoing negotiations to increase US access to the mainland Chinese market and to promote economic reforms there, he added.
The president noted that trade also remains a force for social change in mainland China, "spreading the tools, contacts and ideas that promote freedom."

"We continue to speak and work strongly for human rights in China. A continued policy of principled, purposeful engagement reinforces these efforts to move China toward greater openness and broader freedom. This is the path to lasting stability and prosperity for China, to a future that will benefit the Chinese people -- and the American people," explained Clinton.

"We pursue engagement with our eyes wide open, without illusions. We continue to speak frankly about our differences and to firmly protect our national interests. A policy of disengagement and confrontation would only strengthen those in China who oppose greater openness and freedom," he said.

Therefore, Clinton said, he is committed to bringing mainland China into global structures and to promote Beijing's adherence to global norms on human rights; weapons of mass destruction; crime and drugs; immigration; the environment; and trade. And he is determined to pursue an agreement for mainland China to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) on viable commercial terms.

"This is not a favor to China but a means of opening and reforming China's markets and holding China to the rules of the global trading system -- developments that will benefit America. Accordingly, I am prepared to work closely with Congress to secure permanent NTR status for China in the context of a commercially strong WTO agreement," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC MARKS JUNE 4 TRAGEDY, URGES BEIJING TO BOOST DEMOCRATIC REFORMS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, on Friday urged the Beijing leadership to accelerate democratic reforms for the well-being of all mainland people.
The council made the appeal in connection with the commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the bloody end of the 1989 student-led pro-democracy demonstrations on the Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
"We mourn all those who died 10 years ago for pursuing freedom and democracy on the mainland," said MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng at a news conference.
Hundreds or possibly thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators were killed when mainland Chinese troops and tanks shot their way into the Tiananmen Square on June3-4, 1989.

Sheu criticized Beijing authorities for brutally crushing the student-led pro-democracy movement, saying the military crackdown contradicted the implication of communist China's national title "the People's Republic of China (PRC)."

Noting that democracy was the goal of the Chinese communists when they established the PRC 50 years ago, Sheu said it is regretful that the Beijing leadership now thinks democracy would disrupt mainland China's stability.

Sheu said the Republic of China on Taiwan has consistently believed that only when mainland China launches sweeping reforms and establishes a democratic political system can it enjoy long-term social and political stability.

Sheu pointed out that democracy is a universal value and common goal of all mankind. Although mainland China has continually promoted economic reforms over the past decade, it has been reluctant to carry out necessary political reforms and has even harshly suppressed calls for democracy.

"As a result, improvement in material life in mainland China in recent years has not offered increased political participation for mainland people," Sheu said, adding that such unbalanced development has made mainland China's future prospects full of uncertainties.

Sheu reiterated that mainland China's democratization is crucial to the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. "We believe that only when democracy prevails in mainland China, the Beijing government will not become a negative factor affecting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and prosperity in the entire Asia-Pacific region," Sheu explained, adding that cross-strait relations cannot see a major breakthrough until that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DAILY ON MAINLAND CHINA'S 'MEMORY HOLE'

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese attempts to use George Orwell's "Newspeak" technique in rewriting Tiananmen history may not succeed, thanks to another modern technology called the Internet, a Canadian newspaper commented Thursday.
The Ottawa Citizen warned Beijing that in the age of the Internet, things thrown down the "memory hole," to use Orwell's phrase, have a disconcerting habit of bouncing back.

The influential newspaper carried an editorial, plus long feature stories, columns and letters to the editor, to mark the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre, memories of which mainland China's aging oligarchs have spent the past decade trying to suppress.

Many mainland Chinese seem prepared to accept the government's view that it was fighting a "counter-revolutionary rebellion," the editorial said. Many others, it added, seem prepared to forget it entirely, which is the government's long-term goal.

But "reality control," to use another Orwellian term, is a difficult business, and it is doubtful mainland China's rulers will be able to make their version of reality stick permanently, the Citizen pointed out.
It said the lengths to which Beijing has gone to suppress the truth is "not only a tacit admission of culpability but also a betrayal of their uneasiness about the future."
"The Communist regime knows it is reaching the end of its tether," it noted. /

For now, the mainland Chinese government's legitimacy is bound up with continued prosperity, which requires changes in the political and legal system that would weaken the regime's control, the daily observed.

The quandary in which mainland China's leadership finds itself is that without contact with the West, prosperity -- and therefore political survival -- will be threatened. But with contact with the West comes freer information, including e-mail and the Internet, the daily said.
