DOC.HEADLINE: COLUMNIST DECRIES TIANANMEN AND THE WEST'S RESPONSE

TEXT.P: The 1989 Tiananmen Square carnage was an atrocity, an obscenity, by any standard, and the fact the regime that ordered the massacre is "still in power, still enjoys our diplomatic respect and the investments of almost all our leading companies" is itself, proportionately, atrocious and obscene, said a Canadian columnist.
David Warren made the remarks in "Ten years after Tiananmen Square," which appeared Thursday in The Ottawa Citizen.

He stressed that the mainland Chinese politburo under Deng Xiaoping "were not psychopaths" who may not be held fully responsible for their behavior. They made a cool calculation of the likely consequences before ordering the butchery, he wrote.

"They would have to accept the temporary outrage of the rest of the world -- that was not a problem. They would have to endure certain short-term trade sanctions. ... But so what? Compared to the risk of losing power?" he wrote.

Their calculation worked, Warren said. The pro-democracy protests were snuffed in a single day; the subsequent arrests and clampdown only increased the regime's commodity in trade with the West. "Whenever a trade or other concession is wanted from the West, they just dig out" one of the leading dissidents and put him on a plane for the United States, he noted.
No one pays attention to them once they are out of mainland China. As Wang Dan, once mainland China's "most wanted man," said last week in Toronto, "No one wants to listen to me here," Warren wrote.

Like the Soviets before them, mainland China's leadership has found the West to be consistently "open for business," he observed. So they have bought their way back to political equality with the West, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA THREATENS TO RETALIATE FOR AUSTRALIAN SALMON BAN

TEXT.P: Canada has threatened to retaliate if Australia fails to lift a ban on Canadian salmon, by imposing 100 percent tariffs on Australian exports, including lamb, seafood, cheese and horticultural products.

The Australian Financial Review reported the threat made by Canadian International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi, who released a list of nearly 25 product lines -- worth more than US$40 million in Australian exports to Canada -- which may be included in a World Trade Organization-authorized retaliation package if Australia fails to lift the ban by July 6.

"To date, Australia has shown no sign of lifting the (salmon import) ban. That is why we are preparing to defend Canadian interests and why we are consulting with the public on building a list of imported products that could be taxed," the daily quoted Marchi as warning.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MEDIA REFLECT ON TIANANMEN ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre was the subject of considerable coverage in The Australian Friday.

In an editorial titled "Freedoms in China muted but not gone," The Australian said: "Images of one man standing before a tank; of bicycles crushed in the square; and of students carrying their wounded friends, still form the overriding image of China for many outsiders."

"Yet within China, there is little official memory of June 4 and apparently no public memory apart from a relative few who were directly touched by the killings. There are, of course, many private memories," the editorial said.
The editorial noted the mainland Chinese government has tried to avoid a repetition of the Tiananmen massacre in past years, though it has made little political progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RELAXES BAN ON FOREIGN AIRLINE OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia has announced plans to relax airline operations and investment rules for international carriers, giving foreign operators more space to offer services between their countries and Australia.

The Australian government on Thursday said the relaxation would prove a boon for international airlines and two Australian major operators -- Qantas and Ansett -- to expand in their routes between Australia and other countries.

Unveiling the new aviation "open skies" policy, Transport Minister John Anderson also announced plans to allow international airlines to use Australia as a stopover, en route to other destinations, for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-POLAND ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFAB TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference is scheduled to be held in Taipei on June 14 with government officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.

The conference will be jointly presided over by Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), and Adrz Arendarski, president of the Polish Chamber of Commerce (PCC), said officials from the Euro-Asia Trade Organization (EATO), which is sponsoring the event.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Adam Pawlowicz, director of the Foreign Investment Bureau of Poland, will also attend the conference.

EATO and the PCC decided to hold this year's meeting on June 14 to coincide with Eurogate '99, an Eastern and Central European trade exposition in Taipei jointly sponsored by CETRA and the ROC ministries of foreign affairs and economic affairs, slated to kick off on June 15, said EATO officials.

Delegates from Hungary and the Czech Republic who will be in Taipei to attend Eurogate '99 will also be invited to the Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference, so as to allow Taiwan businesses greater opportunity to gain an understanding of trade prospects and the economic climate in Eastern and Central Europe, the officials added.
Top of the conference agenda will be discussions on a Taiwan industrial processing zone to be developed in Poland by the Taipei-based Acelon Chemicals and Fiber Corp.
Acelon will finance the development of the zone, which is a 133-hectare tract located in a now defunct state-run textile plant compound some 100 kilometers from the Polish capital of Warsaw.

EATO and PCC began to take turns hosting the Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference in 1994 after the Polish market became increasingly opened by the wave of democracy which swept Eastern Europe in 1989.

In addition to organizing large-scale Taiwan trade missions to Poland over the last three years, CETRA, Taiwan's top foreign trade arm, also chose Warsaw last year as the location of Taiwan's first trade center in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LOOKS FOR CAPTIVES' RELEASE

TEXT.P: Australia on Friday said it had renewed hope for the release of two aid workers now being detained in Belgrade following convictions of espionage last week.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told reporters that he believed the two workers -- Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace -- of CARE Australia, the largest relief agency in this country, "will be released soon rather than late."

CARE spokesman Anthony Funnell told a press conference in Melbourne on Friday that agreement to a NATO peace accord by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic would bring about the release of the two aid workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR ENVISIONS PRATAS AS `MALDIVES OF THE EAST'

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh said on Thursday that he plans to develop the Tungsha, or Pratas Island group lying 444 kilometers southwest of Taiwan's southern port of Kaohsiung, into "the Maldives of the East."

Hsieh made the remarks during an appearance before a committee of the Legislative Yuan. The committee had invited officials of the Ministry of the Interior to report on issues concerning the development of the Pratas Islands, and Hsieh was also invited to give his views.
Vice Interior Minister Yang Pao-fa pointed out that the government pays close attention to the Pratas, and noted that military personnel are stationed there.

Yang also said the ministry has agreed to let Kaohsiung city government name the streets on the island, register the people who relocate there, and study the possibility of developing the islands into a tourist destination.

Responding to legislators' questions on recent remarks by Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT Business Management Committee, on the development of the Pratas, Yang denied that the ministry has discussed the development with Liu, and stressed that if Liu is indeed interested, he must proceed through the proper channels.

Hsieh said that the city will basically adopt the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model to develop the Pratas, meaning that Kaohsiung will invite private businesses to develop the island group under its guidance, and that those businesses will then operate the project for a certain period before transferring the operation to the city government.

In the meantime, Kaohsiung city government will help the private sector to acquire land and meet the requirements of environmental assessments, as well as coordinate with the navy on the security aspects of the project.
He also said that he is planning transportation links between the Pratas and two famous scenic spots -- Little Ryukyus and Kenting -- to form a "beautiful blue highway in the sea."

Kaohsiung will work with international development firms to develop the Pratas into what Hsieh described as "the Maldives of the East." The city government will also follow the example set by Australia with the Great Barrier Reef, and turn the Pratas into a wildlife preservation area as well as a resort for local and international tourists, Hsieh said.
Hsieh said that to preserve the natural resources of the Pratas, he will adopt a "low development" principle, keeping man-made facilities to a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES LILLEY TALKS ABOUT BEIJING'S POSITION ON KOSOVO

TEXT.P: James Lilley, former US envoy to Beijing and famous expert in international relations, has explained in his article the reason why Beijing is so contrary to NATO countries in so far as the Kosovo issue is concerned.

In an article published in The Australian Financial Review on Friday, Lilley said that in mainland China's eyes, NATO is establishing a precedent that powerful countries have the right to intervene militarily in a sovereign country in favor of an ethnic minority seeking to attain independence through self-determination.
"This is an anathema to China when it looks at Taiwan and Tibet. So China has come down on the opposite site of the US in Kosovo," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PRESENTS AWARDS TO ELITE RESEARCHERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui offered some words of encouragement to the nation's academic researchers on Friday, as he presented awards to five of Taiwan's foremost in a ceremony at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level research institute.

Yu Ching of Academia Sinica's Institute of Mathematics, Tsong Tien-tzou, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics, Professor of Chemistry Lu Tien-yao of National Taiwan University, Professor of History Hsiao Chih-ching of National Tsing Hua University, and Professor Chen Pei-che of National Taiwan University's clinical medical institute, each received an award plus NT$200,000 from the president.
Lee noted that academic research is a long and winding road, and he encouraged persistent efforts by those involved to achieve new breakthroughs.

The candidates for the award are chosen from among researchers who complete their studies in Taiwan and whose research has been innovative, and from among those that enjoy leading positions in the international academic field.

Following the award presentations, each of the recipients delivered a speech on their respective fields, and President Lee later also listened to a briefing from Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, before touring the Institute of Biomedical Sciences and the Institute of Information Science.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS UP 0.2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.2 percent higher on Friday, posting a gain for the fourth consecutive day thanks to strong buying in the electronics sector.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 17.53 points higher, ending the day at 7,590.44 points.
A total of 2.68 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$132.88 billion (US$4.06 billion), down from the previous session's NT$155.58 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, the electronic sector posted the largest gains of the day, rising 1.6 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which climbed 1.4 percent, and cement shares, which rose 1 percent.
Financial stocks suffered the greatest losses of the day, dropping 1.7 percent. Plastic and chemical shares declined 1.1 percent, while the textile sector went down 0.9 percent.
Construction stocks decreased 0.6 percent, closely followed by paper and pulp issues, which registered a 0.5 percent drop.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market gained 1.83 points to close at 176.1 points, with a turnover of NT$7.40 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June gained 25 points to close at 7,535 points, with 1,614 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July rose 17 points to close at 7,530, while those for September went up 30 points, closing at 7,530 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 169 and 16, respectively.
December futures dropped 29 points to close at 7,510, with two contract transactions. Futures for next March suffered a 113 point loss, closing at 7,523, with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,510 points for June, 7,514 points for July, 7,500 points for September, 7,539 points for December, and 7,636 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE COMPONENTS, PARTS PRODUCERS TO INVEST IN VENEZUELA
DOC.DATELINE: Basseterre, Saint Christopher and Nevis, June 2 (CNA) (By Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese car components and parts producers are considering investments in Venezuela that could total US$16 million to US$20 million within five years, sources said on Wednesday.

They said executives of Yi-Tong Co. and Gi-Yi Co. in Taiwan are members of a Taiwan delegation, which is led by Premier Vincent Siew and currently visiting Central America to seek out investment opportunities there.
The delegation arrived in Basseterre on Wednesday.

The two companies plan to ship components and parts from Taiwan to Venezuela, where assembly lines will be built. Some of the products assembled there would remain in the country, while others would be shipped to markets in North America.
They would then try to encourage the companies that produce the components they use to shift their production base to labor-intensive Venezuela.
Ultimately they intend to mull over the feasibility of inviting technology-intensive companies to set up factories there.
Officials of the two companies said they would phase in their plan, which aims to help Taiwanese companies open up new markets, as well as strengthen their competitiveness through joint efforts.

Under the North American Free Trade Agreement, all goods circulated in the Americas and the Caribbean will be free of tariffs and quotas by the year 2005. This is seen as a further incentive for the establishment of the assembly lines in Venezuela.
This is also said to be why Premier Siew and P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, have been actively promoting investment opportunities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MAGGIE GAINING STRENGTH

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Friday afternoon issued a sea warning as tropical storm Maggie gained strength to become a medium typhoon and continued to head toward Taiwan.
At 2 p.m., Maggie, the first typhoon to pose a threat to Taiwan this year, was centered 790 kilometers southeast of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan.
Packing center winds of 38 meters per second, the storm was reported by weathermen to be moving in a west-northwesterly direction at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour.
They added that if it maintains its present course, Maggie is expected to affect southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan on Saturday, bringing strong winds and heavy rain.
Shipping in the Bashi Channel and the waters to the east of the Philippines were cautioned to remain alert.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 4, or the 21st day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1831: Prince Leopold, of the House of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, becomes the first king of Belgium, although King William II of the Netherlands refuses to acknowledge Belgian independence.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in the northeast (Manchuria), is killed on a train by a bomb explosion at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with the US General Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1954: President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The Republic of China joins the provisional Committee on the Communications Satellite.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of Academia Sinica.
1973: A Tupolev 144, a Russian supersonic airliner built on the lines of the Concorde, crashes at the Paris Air Show, killing six crew and 27 onlookers.
1982: US Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Cheyne J.Y. Chiu (Chiu Chin-yi) as the new ambassador to Swaziland.
1987: The Executive Yuan passes a revision of the Law of Negotiable Instruments. The revision is submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
1989: A massive gas explosion wrecks two crowded passengers trains about 740 miles (1,190 km) east of Moscow, killing over 460 people.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1991: The communist government in Albania under Fatos Nano resigns after a 20-day general strike.
1994: Five Iraqis and a Kuwaiti are sentenced to death in Kuwait for plotting to kill former US President George Bush with a car bomb while Bush was visiting Kuwait in April 1993.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST LEADERSHIP SEEN AS CHINA'S WORST ENEMY

TEXT.P: The Tiananmen uprising will continue to haunt the Chinese Communist Party leaders as long as there is no genuine desire to learn its lessons, and in the end, the communist leadership will become Beijing's own worst enemy, a Thai English daily predicted on Friday.
On the 10th anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing, The Nation carried an editorial titled "China Cannot Erase 1989 Beijing Spring."

"China's status in the world, not the chauvinistic version of the Middle Kingdom, will not be judged by the height of its skyscrapers and the number of department stores it has, but rather by how its citizens are being treated and respected," the editorial said.
Indicating that economic reform in mainland China has moved forward rapidly, The Nation reminded its readers that political reforms remain at a snail's pace.
The paper urged Beijing to allow the parents and relatives of those killed in the June 4 massacre to go into the streets to express their tragic losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT BUMPED OFF EVA FLIGHT TO MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 4 (CNA) (By Belle Chou and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's leading dissident Wang Dan was refused a seat on a Taiwan-based airline's flight to Macau, preventing him from attending a memorial activity on the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, sources said on Friday.
Wang had already been refused a visa by the Hong Kong authorities to enter for a similar activity in the former British colony.
The only excuse EVA Air's Macau branch could offer was that they canceled Wang's booking "because he did not reconfirm his reservation 14 days ahead of his trip."

However, Wang Ming, chief editor of the magazine "China Spring," and the sponsor of Macau's Tiananmen Square memorial, said he was booked on the same flight, and had no problem with his seat, leading him to the conclusion that EVA had succumbed to pressure from the Beijing leaders regarding Wang Dan.
Since Wang was unable to enter Hong Kong, he had no choice but to fly with EVA, which offers the only direct flight from the United States to Macau without transiting through Hong Kong.
EVA Airways belongs to Taiwan's Evergreen Group, and the group has lucrative transportation businesses in mainland China's port cities of Shanghai, Ningpo and Qingdao.

DOC.HEADLINE: `PACKET MODE' INTERNET USERS TO REACH 3 MILLION BY END OF 2000: NII

TEXT.P: The National Information Infrastructure (NII) special committee under the Executive Yuan announced on Friday a goal of having a "packet mode" on-line population of 3 million by the end of 2000.

The "packet mode" of Internet access allows users to log on directly after turning on the computer, bypassing the traditional dial-up method, thus drastically reducing Internet fees and improving overall Internet quality.

The convener of the 28th special committee, Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, said at a press conference after the meeting that the NII originally planned to reach its goal by the end of September.
Yang said Taiwan's on-line population using traditional dial-up mode will have exceeded 5 million by the end of next year.

The NII decided to promote the new "packet mode" in the hope that it will reach 3 million by the end of 2000, representing 60 percent of Taiwan's Internet users with access to on-line quality surpassing most of the rest of the world.

Telecommunication construction will be carried out by Chunghwa Telecom, and upon completion will guarantee each PC's on-line speed to reach 64K or 128K, instead of the present dial-up speed of 56K, Yang said.
However, he went on, the biggest advantage of "packet mode" is that it can drastically reduce Internet users' fees.
According to Yang, dial-up users incur average monthly fees of NT$3,000, but logging on through "packet mode" can reduce monthly fees to NT$1,000 or lower.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOLD OUTPUT EXPECTED TO FALL

TEXT.P: Australia's gold production is expected to plunge about 20 percent by 2010 as a result of an expected protracted fall in global bullion prices, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics (ABARE).
ABARE officials predicted that the falling bullion prices will force mining companies in Australia to reduce their gold production from 311 tons in 1998 to 277 tons in 2005, and 246 tons in 2010.
Australia is the world's third-largest gold producer and exporter.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC MUST CONDUCT RISK ASSESSMENT BEFORE LOANS FORTHCOMING: MOF

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Paul Chiu said on Friday that his ministry is willing to assist the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) to obtain syndicated loans to build the island's first high-speed rail system.
However, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) must first get access to the THSRC's financial records and its risk assessment report, he added.

Chiu made the remarks in response to reports that the THSRC has encountered snags in getting syndicated loans from banks to fund the railway's construction, Taiwan's biggest-ever infrastructure project.

Chiu also declined to comment on a proposal by Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB), that the government can invest NT$100 billion in the THSRC in the form of ordinary stocks and special shares, saying only that the proposal should be weighed by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Premier Vincent Siew said last year that as part of plans to stimulate domestic demand, the MOF would assist the THSRC with syndicated loans if it became necessary.
As it now indeed appears necessary, much public attention is being paid as to whether the MOF will live up to Siew's promise.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing noted that her biggest worry is that the THSRC will not get the syndicated loans in time, and that the project will fail.

Liu's written statement released on Thursday said that if the THSRC's financing projections are correct, the CDIB will be more than willing to invest in the project, and will lead other banks in providing loans.

Ing noted that as Liu's statement is a suggestion to the government, she is in no position to respond, but she remarked that the THSRC totally accepts the rules of the government. She also pointed out that while the THSRC project is already on track, Liu's proposal represents another track altogether.

Construction of the railway system is being carried out under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula, whereby a private consortium builds and operates the system for a specified period of time, after which control is transferred to the government.
The majority of previous BOT projects worldwide have failed, but Ing said she intends to make the Taiwan high-speed railway project a success.
However, as it the first of its kind in Taiwan, the THSRC's BOT project has no precedent to follow in terms of how to best carry out the task.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar ended at 32.737 against the New Taiwan dollar Friday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, up NT$0.004 from Thursday's finish
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.735 and had a high of 32.75.
Interbank transactions totaled US$220.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR DENIES IT BUMPED MAINLAND CHINA DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's EVA Airways denied on Friday that they prevented mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan from taking an EVA flight from San Francisco to Macau, saying that in fact he never showed up at the airport.

Wang's reservation on the flight to Macau, where he was to attend a memorial on the 10th anniversary of the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, had earlier been reportedly canceled by EVA Airways without explanation.
However, Evergreen Group, which owns the airline, said on Friday afternoon that the reports were erroneous.

A statement from the group said that Wang booked a seat in San Francisco on May 15, and that the airline issued his ticket on May 25. As long as Wang's travel documents were complete, there would have been no reason for EVA to prevent Wang from boarding the plane.

According to Wang's reservation data, he was supposed to take EVA's 1:30 a.m. (0830 GMT) flight on June 4 from San Francisco to Taipei, which is scheduled to arrive at Chang Kai-shek International Airport at 5:30 a.m. on June 5, and transfer to a 10:10 a.m. flight to Macau.
However, according to the statement, Wang failed to show up for his flight from San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR WANTS RID OF FPG TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) has been urged to ship a consignment of mercury-laced industrial waste out of Kaohsiung Harbor, as the deadline of a two-month temporary storage period approaches.

The Kaohsiung Harbor authority said on Friday it has sent formal notification to FPG demanding that it transport the more than 4,000 metric tons of toxic waste out of the harbor before the June 8 deadline.

Commenting on recent foreign wire service reports that a request by FPG to ship the waste to the port of Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province has been turned down, the Kaohsiung Harbor authority said it knew nothing about any such request, and had not received any application from FPG to ship the waste out of its jurisdiction.
The harbor authority stressed that it has demanded that FPG ship the more-than 300 containers of waste out of the port as required by the regulations.

The Taipei-based petrochemical giant was given permission on April 9 to temporarily store the industrial waste in Kaohsiung Harbor for two months on condition it is transshipped elsewhere at the end of the period.

FPG originally tried to dispose of the shipment in a southern coastal town in Cambodia, but were forced to remove it again after local residents discovered the toxic nature of the waste. Since then, the company has been desperately trying to find a suitable dumping ground, to little avail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
New law lengthens compulsory schooling to 12 years.
The China Times:
The Legislative Yuan passed the Education Basic Law on Friday, paving the way for implementation of a number of major changes to the island's education system.
The United Daily News:
The legislature passed a new bill to pave the way for abolishment of the decades-old wine and tobacco monopoly system and liberalization of wine production and dealing.
The Liberty Times:
The Education Basic Law stipulates that the central government must delegate more authority to local administrations in handling education, thus allowing for a more diversified and localized curriculum for students.
The Commons Daily:
DPP National Assembly deputies plan to absent themselves from the forthcoming plenary session for three days to protest the ruling Kuomintang's constitutional amendment proposals.
The China Post:
70,000 people in Hong Kong mark the Tiananmen tragedy.
The Taiwan News:
Compulsory education to be extended.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOSEL VITELIC MULLING WAFER FOUNDRY IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Taiwan semiconductor giant Mosel Vitelic Inc. will send executives to Canada at the end of this month to finalize the location of a wafer foundry plant it plans to construct there, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Saturday.
CETRA's Vancouver office said that Mosel Vitelic is planning to invest US$2 billion in Canada to set up the plant, either in Vancouver, Ottawa, or Montreal.
Canada is the only G-7 industrial nation without a large silicon chip manufacturing plant, and the Canadian government is keen to attract investors in this field.
The proposed plant is expected to create 1,000 jobs, and Vancouver, Ottawa and Montreal have offered generous investment incentives to Mosel Vitelic.
However, the company has not ruled out the possibility of setting up its plant in the United States instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 5, or the 22nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1783: A hot-air balloon, made by the brothers Joseph-Michel and Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier, slowly rises 6,000 (2,000 m) into the air in Annonay, France.
1806: Louis Bonaparte, Napoleon's brother who fought with Napoleon in Italy (1796-1797) and Egypt (1798-1899), is declared king of the Netherlands.
1819: John Couch Adams, British mathematician and astronomer, is born. He predicted in 1845 to within 2 degree the position of the planet Neptune, which was certified in 1846.
1883: John Maynard Keynes, British economist, is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1916: Horatio Herbert Kitchener, British soldier and war leader, drowns off the Orkneys Islands, northeast of the Scottish mainland, when the SS Hampshire, carrying him on a mission to Russia, hits a German mine and sinks. Earlier in his life, he brought the Boer War to a conclusion and served as secretary for war during World War I.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces.
1940: German forces begin their attack on France. They occupied Paris on June 14.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that takes control of Germany and divides it into four occupation zones.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignias, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: US Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1955: The Taiwan Provincial Teachers College is reorganized into National Taiwan Normal University.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1963: British Secretary of State for War John Profumo resigns from his parliamentary seat and from his Cabinet position after admitting that he lied to the House of Commons about his association with the model Christine Keeler.
1967: The Six-Day War which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes breaks out between Israel and its neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1988: A train packed with explosives blows up as it enters the station at Arzamas, an industrial city east of Moscow, killing more than 50 people and injuring several hundred of others.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail around the world solo and nonstop.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: US President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China in protest of the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. A cabinet reshuffle is passed three days later.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAND WARNING ISSUED AGAINST TYPHOON MAGGIE

TEXT.P: A land warning against Typhoon Maggie was issued on Saturday by the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), although the storm's center, on its current course, is unlikely to hit the island.
The CWB warned people living in southern and eastern parts of the island of heavy rain and the possibility of mudslides.

The typhoon was centered at 18.9 degrees north latitude and 124.5 degrees east longitude, 480 km to the south of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at 11 a.m. on Saturday. It was moving on a northwest-westerly course at a speed of 17 km per hour.

Packing maximum winds of 30 meters per second, with gusting to 48 meters per second, Maggie's center was forecast to be locate at 20.5 degrees north and 121 degrees east, or 170 km southeast-south of Hengchun, by 8 a.m. on Sunday, said the bureau.
The Taiwan Railway Administration announced on Saturday the suspension of services on its south-link line between the cities of Kaohsiung and Taitung for Sunday.

Although northern Taipei City is furthest from the storm's forecast path, the city government on Saturday established an anti-typhoon center as a precaution, and city officials visited people living in shanties on hillsides at the city's edge to warn them to evacuate.
At the opening of the Taipei City typhoon center, Mayor Ma Ying-jeou dictated two hypothetical scenarios to test the center's ability to cope with typhoon damage.
Meanwhile, another anti-typhoon center of the central government was established by the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER GOVERNOR DESCRIBES HIS VISION OF TAIWAN'S LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 4 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said on Friday that the new leaders of Taiwan should have the vision to look after the interests of the people and to view Taiwan's value from the regional and global perspectives.

Soong, who arrived in San Francisco on Monday at the invitation of the Asian Foundation and the University of California at Berkeley, made the remarks as he spoke about his recent trips to the Philippines and the United States.

On Taiwan's political development, Soong reiterated his supra-party and supra-ethnic stance, and said he believes that Taiwan's political figures should have regional and global vision, should promote the interests of Taiwan and speak out on the country's behalf.

They should also make the international community realize that Taiwan is an important member of that community, that it has valuable contributions to make, and that it is well able to shoulder its international responsibilities.

The presidential hopeful said that in addition to its own interests, Taiwan should stress its positive significance to Asia and the Pacific and the world community. If Taiwan can play a constructive role, it will be a great help to the situation in East Asia, he said.

Soong said that political leaders in Taiwan should help the international community to learn the value of Taiwan's democracy, and should for their parts learn about the world's views about Taiwan so that a positive interchange can be established.
Soong, who has just completed a grueling round of engagements, is expected to leave here for Taiwan on Saturday, where he rest for a few days before traveling to Japan.

Soong would not divulge his schedule in Japan, and declined to respond to reports that he might meet incumbent ministers, former prime ministers, and the executives of major political parties in Japan.

In the past month alone, he has visited the Philippines and the United States, and although he has yet to formally announce his bid to run in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, he is obviously trying to raise his international stature.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE URGED TO STREAMLINE MANAGEMENT OF OVERSEAS SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang legislator on Saturday urged the Ministry of Education (MOE) to streamline the management and supervision of Republic of China-funded schools abroad.

Legislator Lee Ching-an made the call at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, after alleging that Chao Yen-wei, president of the Taipei School in Ho Chi Minh City, southern Vietnam, had an affair with Shao Mei-ling, a former teacher at the school.
Shao's former husband Chen Wen-su, who was also present at the news conference, accused Shao of having Chao's baby while they were still married.
Lee said the adultery charge signifies management problems in overseas schools. The journalist-turned-lawmaker demanded that the MOE launch an immediate probe into the allegation.
The lawmaker said she basically supports the opening of Chinese-language schools in foreign cities which have populations of ROC expatriates.

Such schools can not only facilitate the younger generation's study of Chinese language, but can also help narrow the academic gap between overseas schoolchildren and their local counterparts, Lee noted.
Nevertheless, Lee said the MOE and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission should tighten the supervision and evaluation of the schools to prevent scandals and other irregularities.

"The MOE should send officials to all ROC-funded overseas schools to evaluate their teaching qualities and interview their students," Lee said, adding that in recruiting teachers, the MOE should place more emphasis on integrity, character and moral stature.

In response to Lee's demand, Kao Chung-yun, a senior MOE official, said the ministry had already asked Chou Yen, chairman of the Ho Chi Minh City Taipei School, to investigate the allegation after it received Chen's petition earlier this year.
Kao said that if Chao is found guilty of misconduct, the MOE will ask the school's board of directors to punish him.
The ROC has set up Chinese-language schools in Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. The MOE sets aside a budget of NT$60 million (US$1.83 million) annually to help finance the schools.
