DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF TAIWAN-MACAU PROMOTION BODY DELAYED
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, June 5 (CNA) (By C.L. Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The opening of a privately funded organization to boost Taiwan-Macau trade and tourism relations has had to be delayed as a result of interference by Beijing, organization officials said on Saturday.

The officials of the Taiwan-Macau Tourism, Trade and Cultural Promotion Association said they decided to postpone the opening ceremony and that they will choose an "appropriate time" to announce the new date, after failing to resolve a dispute between attending dignitaries from Taiwan and mainland China.

The opening ceremony was originally slated for Saturday morning, and representatives of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait had been invited to take part. However, the event was blocked by Xinhua News Agency's Macau bureau chief, who protested that W. L. Lee, representative of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau, was to have attended the ceremony under his official title.
Xinhua New Agency, Beijing's official mouthpiece, is the de facto representative office of mainland China in the Portuguese enclave on mainland China's southern coast.

The association is said to have its principal backing from an influential "casino king" in Macau who is seeking to play a greater role in bilateral Taiwan-Macau relations after the Portuguese enclave returns to Beijing rule on Dec. 24 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S R&D SPENDING DOWN

TEXT.P: Australia's spending on research and development plunged 4 percent to A$4.04 (US$2.89) billion in fiscal 1997-98, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

As a proportion of gross domestic product, Australia's R&D fell from a high of 0.86 percent in 1995-96 to just 0.72 percent of GDP in 1997-98, well below spending levels in other major developed countries, according to the ABS.
The opposition Labor Party labeled the downturn a "national emergency."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NEGOTIATING WITH MAINLAND CHINA OVER ABORTION

TEXT.P: Australia has been forced into awkward negotiations with mainland China over a Chinese woman at the center of an abortion row who has sought asylum at the Australian consulate in Guangzhou, The Australian newspaper reported on Saturday.

The woman, identified as Zhu Qingping, who was deported from Australia when she was pregnant in 1997 and then later was forced to have an abortion in mainland China, re-emerged last Thursday at the Australian consulate in the company of a crew from Australia's "60 Minutes" TV show, the daily reported.

Program executive John Westacott told the daily that his crew took Zhu to the consulate at her request to seek asylum in Australia after they had interviewed her for a story. Zhu is now staying at a hotel near the Australian consulate.
The incident prompted Foreign Minister Alexander Downer to summon mainland China's ambassador to Australia this week to inform him of the situation and ask for a guarantees of Zhu's safety.

The daily reported that Australia is attempting to persuade the mainland Chinese authorities to give both Zhu and her daughter identification papers which they were deprived of on their return to China in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXILED TIANANMEN LEADERS SAY THEIR CAUSE STILL SUCCESSFUL

TEXT.P: Former leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement gathered Friday at Harvard University in the United States and declared that their cause in 1989 did not fail, according to an article published in Australia's Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.
The leaders included Li Lu, Wang Dan, Chai Ling, Wu'er Kaixi, Wang Juntao and Wei Jingsheng, according to the article.
On of them was quoted as saying that "Tiananmen did not fail," and that "The communists killed the messenger but had to take part of the message."

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBANIAN REFUGEES SKEPTICAL ABOUT NATO PEACE PLAN

TEXT.P: Ethnic Albanian refugees in Australia are skeptical about Yugoslavian President Slobodan Milosevic's promise to honor the peace plan drawn up by NATO.

For a majority of ethnic Albanians, the peace plan is not a cause to celebrate, and many say they will return only when United Nations peacekeeping forces are stationed in Kosovo, according to Australian TV and newspaper reports.
Australian Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said Friday his government will not send the refugees back until conditions in Kosovo improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE READY FOR NEW ATTACKS BY INDONESIANS

TEXT.P: Ethnic Chinese across Indonesia have been preparing for new attacks before the general election next Monday, according to a report in Australia's Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.
A dispatch from Jakarta reported that some ethnic Chinese have bought guns, while others are paying military units to guard commercial areas. Many others have left Indonesia.

Since former President Suharto stepped down last year, a better-educated, better-integrated younger generation of ethnic Chinese have begun to seek a more active place in Indonesian society, the report said.
Ethnic Chinese account for only about three percent of Indonesia's total population of 220 million, but they control most of the country's wealth. They were hit by rioters last May in social unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S QUALITY OF LIFE SATISFACTION RATING DROPS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 90 percent of Taiwan's residents are satisfied with their relations with their spouses, parents and children, according to the results of a survey released on Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

The survey, conducted by Fu Jen Catholic University, also found that 79 percent of the respondents said the government should maintain social order, while 44 percent suggested that it curb corruption.

MOI officials said 92.4 percent of the respondents are satisfied with their spouses, and 91.3 percent are satisfied with their parent-children relations. They are most concerned about the safety and health of their family members.
Most of the respondents said they hope to live at ease during their old age, and that they support the government's measures to step up social and medical welfare, especially for the elderly.

Some 71.8 percent said they are satisfied with their home environment, while 27.4 percent said they are dissatisfied. Among the reasons for dissatisfaction, 34.7 percent complained of noise, 22.4 percent complained of improper disposal of garbage, and 17.3 percent were unhappy with air pollution levels.
Some 58 percent of those polled said that they regularly investment and save money, mostly in order to provide for their old age, and for their children's' education or weddings.

The survey also found that not many of the respondents participate in social charity work, with only 26 percent saying they had taken part in charity work in the past year, mostly in the form of donating money.
The overall rating for life satisfaction was 76.1 percent, or 1.9 percent lower than the 78 percent recorded in a similar survey conducted three years ago.
The telephone survey polled 3,720 people over the age of 20 about their views on life, and had a margin of error of 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP URGES MORE EMPHASIS ON ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

TEXT.P: With its fast economic development, Taiwan's living conditions are on a par with those of industrialized nations, but damage to the environment has reached an unprecedented level, an environmental group said on Saturday.

Hsieh Chih-cheng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, unveiled statistics showing how Taiwan's environment has been affected between 1985 and 1997 by economic development. He urged the public not to ignore the problem.

One of the most significant features of Taiwan is its high population density, Hsieh said. Although population growth dropped from 12.91 percent in 1985 to 8.65 percent in 1998, the island's population density is still too high, he said.

He noted that the population density was 602 people per square kilometer in 1997. In urban areas, the figure was much higher, as the cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung had about 9,000 people per square kilometer.

There are also far more motor vehicles in Taiwan now than before. Between 1985 and 1997, the number of motor vehicles grew by 93 percent, and as of 1997 there were 15.31 million, most of which were motorcycles.
But the number of roads in Taiwan increased by only 70 percent during that same period, and now each 100 square meters of road must support 4.56 vehicles.

Another area of concern is garbage and industrial waste. Although the government has built more incinerators to handle regular garbage, the production of industrial wastes has increased each year. Proper handling of industrial waste is not occurring often enough, he said, adding that the likelihood of toxic waste being dumped is especially worrisome.
The union said that the soil, air and water in Taiwan have been affected by unprecedented pollution.

The union said that the energy and industrial structure of Taiwan is also cause for concern, noting that some industries waste too much energy and produce too much pollution, namely the petrochemical, steel refinement and cement industries. Taiwan does not need these types of energy-consuming industries, they said.

As for the island's water quality, Hsieh said that the pollution of rivers and drinking water has cast into doubt the government's handling capacity. A particularly serious problem is the eutrophication of Taiwan's reservoirs, the main source of Taiwan's drinking water. The problem has reached a serious level, the union said.
Hsieh expressed his hope that the government and private sector will pay attention to the environment so that there will be better living conditions for the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PM TO ARRIVE SUNDAY FOR 1ST OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day official visit.
This will be Georgievski's first visit to the Republic of China since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.

Georgievski originally planned to visit Taiwan in February or March. But his travel plan was postponed several times because of the Kosovo crisis, which triggered the influx into Macedonia of a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

With the outlook in the Balkans brightening following Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's consent to accept an international peace plan for Kosovo, Georgievski has finally managed to realize his long-planned Taiwan visit.

During his stay, Georgievski will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials to discuss concrete measures to boost bilateral relations and cooperation.
Georgievski will chair a seminar to introduce Macedonia's general investment climate, related regulations and development potential to attract Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in his nation.

To facilitate bilateral trade, investment and economic cooperation, Georgievski will sign an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord and a free trade agreement with ROC Premier Vincent Siew.
On June 9, Georgievski will preside over the inauguration of the Macedonian Embassy in Taipei.
The 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister is still on a visit to the United States. He will travel directly from there to Taipei.
Georgievski told a news conference in Washington, D.C. on Friday that Macedonia's upcoming presidential election will affect his country's relations with the ROC.
Even though the incumbent Macedonian president once opposed the establishment of diplomatic ties with the ROC, Georgievski said that problem has been resolved.
By now, Georgievski said he does not see any problems in bilateral relations between Macedonia and the ROC.
He went on to say he believes that ROC-Macedonian economic cooperation will be further strengthened following his visit to Taiwan.

Georgievski complained that major countries around the world have been reluctant to honor their promises of giving financial aid to Macedonia whose economy has been seriously affected by the Kosovo crisis. "The large number of Kosovar refugees is a heavy financial burden for us," he complained.

The ROC has donated US$2 million in cash to Macedonia to help the former Yugoslav state cope with the refugee problems. In addition, the ROC donated many relief goods, including pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, and daily necessities, to Kosovar refugees in Macedonia. It also sent a medical team to Macedonia to offer free medical services to Kosovar refugees.
The ROC attaches great importance to its relations with Macedonia because the Balkan state is one of its only two diplomatic allies in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUNMAN SPRAYS DEPARTMENT STORE WITH BULLETS IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A man sprayed a department store in downtown Taichung City with gunfire Saturday, injuring a pregnant woman, police said.
The hit-and-run attack took place at noon at the Kung-San Sogo Department Store.

The unidentified woman, who was 20 weeks' pregnant, was shot in the neck. She was rushed to a nearby hospital, where doctors characterized her condition as serious and said they are concerned she may lose her baby.

The gunman and an accomplice arrived at the department store in a car at noon, according to a witness. A man wearing a ski mask got out of the car and fired randomly at the store's front windows with a Uzi-style machine gun.
After about 40 rounds were fired, the pair drove off. The car they arrived in was found later on a nearby street, and the car's owner said it had been hijacked by two gunmen earlier in the day.
This is the second such attack on a department store in Taichung, and the first to take place in the daytime.
Taichung police have launched a large-scale search for the men, but no arrests have been made so far.
Police said the attack may have been intended as a warning, but store officials said the store was not involved in any dispute that could have resulted in the attack.

The store attracted nationwide attention earlier this year after its owners became embroiled in a high-profile financial scandal. A trial resulting from the scandal is still pending in Taichung District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose by NT$0.005 on the Taipei foreign exchange market to NT$32.742 on Saturday.
A total of US41 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's low of NT$32.736 and rose to NT$32.751 before easing to its closing level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHAY MOVES TO EASE PILOT SICK-OUT

TEXT.P: Cathay Pacific Airways announced on Saturday the resumption of ticket reservation services on five routes as a pilot sick-out entered its ninth day.

The Hong Kong-based aviation company announced that it will resume ticket reservation services for its Hong Kong-Taipei, Hong Kong-Bangkok, Hong Kong-Manila, Hong Kong-Kuala Lumpur and Hong Kong-Singapore routes as part of its efforts to minimize the effects of the sick-out.
Cathay canceled 63 flights on Saturday.

Meanwhile, Cathay management said they will seek to resolve the current pay dispute with pilots by holding a negotiation meeting with the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers' Association and government labor affairs authorities on Saturday afternoon.

A spokesman for the association said they are optimistic about the likely results of the talks, adding that the union will convey the pilots' stance to Cathay's top management in the meeting in a bid to help forge a consensus between the two sides.

The dispute erupted last week when Cathay informed pilots of pay cuts of 7 percent to 22 percent in return for stock options. Otherwise, they would have to retire. The airline posted a loss last year for the first time since 1963.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDIB CHAIRMAN SUGGESTS GOVERNMENT RESOLVE RAIL PROJECT PREDICAMENT

TEXT.P: The chairman of the China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB) suggested on Saturday that the government provide NT$100 billion in financing for the construction of Taiwan's multi-billion dollar high-speed railway.

CDIB Chairman Liu Tai-ying said that the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), the project's main contractor, has relied on a too-optimistic and unsound financial assessment, which has inevitably resulted in fund-raising problems.
Liu proposed government investments totaling NT$100 billion in the form of ordinary stocks and special shares, which the THSRC can purchase back whenever it has enough funds.

Liu, dubbed by outsiders as a "wicked mother-in-law" in the project -- even though he is a man -- praised the head of the THSRC, Nita Ing, as a "good daughter-in-law." He said Ing's father was one of his intimate friends, and Ing is a dedicated worker, clever and competent. But he said there is too much pressure in trying to complete the island's most ambitious infrastructure project.

The CDIB chairman stressed that he has never criticized the financing plan of the THSRC as unfeasible. He said he just meant that the group might encounter snags in getting syndicated loans from banks to fund the railway's construction. The difficulties could come from the fact that the THSRC has assets worth only NT$60 billion, but its bid for the high-speed railway project is valued at NT$400 billion.
Ing acknowledged that the THSRC has been plagued by fund-raising difficulties since winning the bid for the contract last July.
Under the current financing plan, the THSRC will reportedly ask for an NT$280 billion loan from the government and NT$120 billion in syndicated loans from banks.

Construction of the railway system is being carried out under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula, whereby a private consortium builds and operates the system for a specified period of time, after which control is transferred to the government. It is the first of its kind in Taiwan.
Liu re-emphasized that the CDIB is sincerely willing to assist the THSRC, adding that the CDIB would be willing to invest substantially in the project if the THSRC developed a sound financing plan.

In regard to the system's design, Liu suggested that the THSRC adopt a Japanese design instead of a European one. If the THSRC cannot complete the project, Chung Hua High-Speed Railway Corp., which bid against TSHRC for the construction contract, might be given a chance to take over the project.

Although the group, which was chaired by Liu, disbanded after it lost the contract to TSHRC, the consortium might be regrouped and step in to complete the railway, provided it were able to construct a Japanese-style system, Liu said. Otherwise, he added, it would be impossible for the task to be continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY UNITY IS THE PRIORITY: KMT VICE PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: Unity within the ruling Kuomintang is the party's main priority, said Wu Poh-hsing, the only known vice presidential hopeful within the Kuomintang, on Saturday.

Answering questions from reporters at the end of a seminar on religion and national development, the current senior adviser to the president said division within the KMT before the 2000 presidential election could end the party's rule of the island.

Although he has made no secret of his vice presidential aspirations, Wu said party unity takes precedence over his personal desires, and that he would put the party's solidarity before his personal interests.
Wu's statement was interpreted as a suggestion that he might abandon his attempts to become the party's vice presidential candidate if it were to boost the KMT's chances of winning the election.

Although the KMT is almost certain of selecting current Vice President Lien Chan as its candidate for president, there has been talk of nominating party heavyweight and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong as the party's vice presidential candidate.
Soong is believed to be thinking of a presidential run, even if it means running as an independent.
Although popular among the party's grassroots supporters, Soong had a falling out with the party's leadership because of his opposition to the KMT's plan to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government.
Political analysts have suggested that the party recruit Soong as Lien's running mate to avoid party division and to ensure a KMT victory in next year's presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE WOMAN PAYS TRIBUTE TO HER FATHER'S TAIWAN SAVIORS

TEXT.P: A Japanese woman on Saturday finally relaized her wish of paying tribute to a Taiwan family which rescued her father from rough seas off northeastern Taiwan coast 54 years ago.
Kuniko Inatomi, 54, was moved into tears when she met Chang A-shuang, the only surviving member of the family, in Wuchieh, a coastal town in the northeastern county of Ilan.
An emotional Inatomi grabbed Chang's hands tightly to express her gratitude for the family's resuce of her father and four of his colleagues aboard a Japanese military supply ship.

Chang A-shuang is the wife of Chang Tsao-yang who, together with his father Chang Wu and elder brother Chang Tsao-chih, rescued Inatomi's father and four other Japanese men near the Wuchieh beach in September 1945.
The Changs carried home the five Japanese men on their back after spotting them on the beach. The family provided the Japanese men with foods and clothing, in addition to curing their wounds.

After five to six days of attentive care from the Chang family, the five Japanese men regained strength. The Chang family reported the case to local authorities which then sent the Japanese back to their country.

Inatomi said her father was the captain of the Japanese military supply ship which capsized in a storm on its way from Taiwan's Keelung port to Japan's Ishigaki. All the 16 crew members aboard the ill-fated ship fell into rough seas. Only five of the crew, including Captain Inatomi, were rescued by the Chang family, while the 11 others all disappeared.

Inatomi said she was only nine months old when the incident took place. "I heard of the episode from my parents when I was young," Inatomi said, adding that her parents had asked her to convey their thanks to the Taiwan family on their behalf.
Inatomi's father already died and her 92-year-old mother has repeatedly reminded Inatomi to travel to Taiwan to find her father's rescuers.
With the assistance of the Suao Junior Chamber of Commerce and several Japanese and Taiwan politicians, Inatomia finally managed to locate the Chang family.
Inatomi gave a gift to Chang A-shuang to express her gratitude. She said from now on she will travel to Taiwan every year to meet the Chang family and see for herself Taiwan's progress.
On Saturday, Inatomi also held a memorial service at the Wuchieh beach in memory of the 11 Japanese sailors who died in the incident.
According to Inatomi, only one of the five rescued Japanese crew members is still alive. "Because of his poor health, he could not travel with me to Taiwan," Inatomi said. (By Sofia Wu) ENDITEM

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 6, or the 23rd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1660: The Peace of Copenhagen is signed, ending a generation of war between Denmark and Sweden. The treaty delineates their borders, with Denmark regaining Fyn and Bornholm from Sweden.
1683: The Ashmolean, the first public museum, is opened at Oxford, England.
1801: The Treaty of Badajoz is signed, ending the War of the Oranges between Spain and Portugal.
1884: Vietnamese emperor recognizes French protectorate under the Treaty of Hue.
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58 and the republic form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913, and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1933: The first drive-in movie opens in Camden, New Jersey.
1934: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of US Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark toward the coast of Normandy, France, to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second ceasefire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1961: Carl Gustav Jung, Swiss psychiatrist and the founder of analytical psychology, dies in Switzerland at the age of 85. His works include "The Psychology of the Unconscious."
1967: Egypt closes Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1972: An underground coal mine explosion at the Wankie colliery in Rhodesia kills 422 miners.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the world's biggest bubble blower. He blows a bubble measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: Earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit of a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in 23 years after the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan on full alert against Typhoon Maggie.
The China Times:
Listed companies will have to cut capitalization in order to regain the firms' own stock shares, says the Ministry of Finance.
The United Daily News:
IBM, Acer tie-up represents a venture of US$25 billion.
The Liberty Times:
Pregnant woman shot in Taichung SOGO hit-and-run assault.
The Commons Daily:
Five southern cities and counties to join Kaohsiung city government in lottery sales, beginning on July 1.
The China Post:
Typhoon Maggie to pass through southern Taiwan; Travel delays expected in south; 2 killed in the Philippines.
The Taiwan News:
Typhoon skirts parts of island; travel hindered.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SHUN BELGIAN MEAT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will shut the door to meat, poultry, and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination scandal in that European country.
The Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is expected to make a formal announcement on the ban on Monday, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Sunday.
The ban will be imposed on frozen animal meat and poultry, eggs, milk and dairy products imported from Belgium, COA officials said.
Processed meat products from Belgium may also be included in the ban, and if necessary, related products which are already on supermarket shelves may be retrieved, COA officials noted.

Meanwhile, officials from the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine are looking into facts and reports to see whether meats from European countries other than Belgium have also been contaminated.
Taiwan has never imported poultry, pork and beef products and eggs from Belgium, although the island has purchased a considerable quantity of milk and dairy products from Europe's "dairy kingdom."

Taiwan imported 89,452 kilograms of cream butter, 370,000 kilograms of yogurt drinks, 107,400 kilograms of cheese, 133,600 kilograms of dried dairy fat, and an unknown amount of yolk from Belgium in the first four months of this year, according to tallies from the Board of Foreign Trade.

Although the Belgian dioxin contamination scandal has so far mainly affected poultry, pork and beef, COA officials noted that yolk and cheese from Belgium have also reportedly been tainted with the cancer-causing dioxin chemical.

Taiwan is paying close attention to the dioxin contamination scandal as it occurs at a time when Taipei is poised to increase the importation of foreign agricultural products in its bid to join the World Trade Organization, before the end of this year.
The contamination, Europe's worst food scandal since Britain's "mad cow" crisis, has led to stricter European Union restrictions on Belgian poultry, pork, beef, and related products.

The scare came to light last Friday after it was acknowledged that some 1,000 Belgian farms have used feed from a contaminated storage tank. How the chemical got into the tank remains unclear, and the scale of the contamination is still being investigated.
The United States, Singapore and Hong Kong have also banned the importation of Belgian meat products.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE WOMAN PAYS RESPECTS TO TAIWAN SAVIORS
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, June 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Japanese woman is here fulfilling her parents' wishes to pay respect to an Ilan family for saving her father's life some 54 years ago.
Kuniko Inafuku, a 55-year-old duty-free shop owner in Ishigaki Port near Okinawa, flew to the eastern coastal city of Ilan Saturday to meet with Chang Ah-shuang, 73.
Chang is the only "savior" still alive from a family who cared for Inafuku's father and several other Japanese after they nearly drowned in an ocean mishap in 1945.

Inafuku's father, the captain of the "Masafuku-Maru", was on board the Japanese transport ship on Sept. 1, 1945 with 15 military and civilian passengers en route from the northern Taiwanese port of Keelung to Ishigaki Port when a typhoon ravaged the ocean and overturned the vessel.

While most of the passengers were swallowed by the sea, Captain Inafuku and four passengers of the "Masafuku-Maru" were swept by strong winds and currents to near Ilan's Wuchieh Hsiang beach. The five Japanese washed ashore on a salt land forest near Wuchieh's Litze Village.
The five were discovered lying on the beach by Chang Wu, a Litze-based fisherman, and his two adult sons. The Changs then carried the Japanese back to their home.
Chang Ah-shuang, at the time was the 18 year-old daughter-in-law of Chang Wu. She remembered that the Japanese were carried home one at a time and that all of them were barely alive.
Under her father-in-law's instructions, the Chang's made a hot bath for the Japanese and prepared meals, although food was scarce.

The five Japanese men rehabilitated in the Chang's narrow and ragged home, sleeping on the living room floor for about one week. Chang Wu then reported the incident to the relevant agencies and the Japanese were returned to Japan.

Kuniko Inafuku said her father died in Ishigaki two years later, but it has been the long-cherished desire of her mother, now 92 years old, to find the Taiwanese saviors and thank them for their kindness. Kuniko said her mother always told her that it was father's wish that a member of the Inafuku family visit Taiwan and express respect to the Chang family.
One of the rescued is still alive, said Kuniko. The 83-year-old former soldier, however, could not make the trip due to poor health, she added.
Chang Ah-shuang is also the only surviving member of the Chang family.
On Saturday, Kuniko Inafuku, on behalf of her elder mother, visited Chang Ah-shuang and visited the home where Captain Inafuku and his four passengers rehabilitated 54 years ago.
The "Masafuku-Maru" was one of the last Japanese ships to return to Japan from Taiwan after Japan formally surrendered after World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES URGED NOT TO DISRUPT DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Sunday that it is undesirable for the country's diplomacy to be affected by prospective presidential candidates.
Hu made the remarks upon his return from a visit to Guatemala, El Salvador and Saint Christopher and Nevis with Premier Vincent Siew.
Hu came back to Taipei one day ahead of Siew to greet Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski who arrived in Taiwan on Sunday for a six-day visit at the invitation of the ROC government.
The foreign minister's remarks were apparently referring to former Taiwan Governor James Soong's recent trips to the Philippines and the United States.
During his trip to Manila, Soong held talks with the incumbent and former Philippine presidents through private arrangements -- talks which caused some controversy in Taipei.
Hu told the media that he would not like to see domestic "internal strife" stretch to the diplomatic front.
He denied reports that the Foreign Ministry gave discriminative treatment to Soong and another presidential candidate, former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian.

Hu said that Chen had asked the Foreign Ministry to provide assistance before his recent trips to the US and Japan. Through arrangements of the ROC representative offices, Chen had dined with the ROC Representative to Washington Stephen Chen, and was able to meet with Japanese political leaders.
He went on to say that Soong did not inform the Foreign Ministry prior to going to the Philippines and the United States.

Meanwhile, in responding to Hu's remarks that political leaders should not harm the country's interests by making statements when abroad, Soong told the media in San Francisco on Saturday that he hopes Hu "will remember what he has said."
Soong said that he believed his recent meetings with the Philippine presidents were in the interest of the country.
Soong added that in consideration of the country's interest, he has turned down several foreign invitations.

For instance, he said, Georgetown University, his alma mater, had invited him to give a public speech, but he did not accept because the university is located in the politically-sensitive Washington area.
He said that he had also turned down an invitation from former US President Gerald Ford to take part in an international forum in the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MAGGIE AFFECTING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Maggie, a medium-strength typhoon, is blowing across the southern part of Taiwan with heavy rain soaking the mountainous areas in the south and east.
According to a report released by Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau Sunday morning, the cyclone was located near Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, and moving in west-northwest direction at 26 kms per hour.

Maggie is passing through the southern Taiwan Strait, with rains and strong wind jolting the seas. It has a storm radius of 250 kms, and is packing center winds of 38 meters per second, a force similar to that of a hurricane, the report said.
The weather bureau predicted Maggie will move out to sea by 7:00 a.m. Monday.
CWB weathermen estimated that the typhoon would next land on mainland China's Guangdong province. The CWB will not call off land warnings until Sunday night, at the earliest, they said.
The southern and eastern parts of Taiwan are being soaked by Maggie's relentless rain. As of Sunday morning the two areas had received 200 millimeters of rain.
Forecasters warned people living in mountainous regions to take precautions against flooding. They also warned that high seas may inundate the southern coasts.

Rainfall and winds grounded most domestic flights Sunday morning , including all flights between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Lanyu, Green Island and Penghu. The Fengnien airport of Taitung, as well as the airports in Kaohsiung and Tainan, were also closed.
It is expected that airports will remain closed until after Maggie has moved away, according to officials at a typhoon monitoring center in Taipei.

Officials said that roads in Taitung and Hualien have been severely damaged and there have been mudslides. The South Link Railway has been closed since Saturday and is not expected to be reopened until Monday morning, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW TO RETURN FROM C. AMERICAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Premier Vincent Siew will arrive in Taipei Monday morning after a one-day transit stop in New York City at the end of his three-nation visit to Central America and the Caribbean.
Siew and his 60-member entourage arrived in New York on Friday, and spent the weekend relaxing in the Big Apple with no official visits. Siew visited the Metropolitan Museum Friday afternoon.
Under a tacit agreement between Taipei and Washington, Siew received high-level transit treatment, with an emphasis on safety and comfort.
Siew, who left Taipei on May 27, visited Guatemala, El Salvador and Saint Christopher and Nevis.

His entourage included Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Government Information Office Director General Chen Chien-jen, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yu-fu, Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lee Jen-chyuan and private business sector representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR SOON RETURNS FROM US TRIP

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, a prospective presidential candidate, returned to Taipei on Sunday after a several speeches in the United States.

Meeting the media at C.K.S. international airport, Soong said that the Republic of China should fully assume its international duties, and should not let the Taiwan problem become a source of apprehension for the international community.
He pointed out that Taiwan's task is to maintain continued development in the midst of a peaceful, rational and stable environment.
During his stay in the US, Soong delivered a speech at the University of California. He also met with several important political and business figures.
After visits to the Philippines and the United States, Soon plans next to visit Japan as a warm-up for his formal announcement to run for president.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PM ON OFFICIAL VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: C.K.S. Airport, northern Taiwan, June 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski leading a 59-member delegation, arrived in Taipei Sunday for a six-day official visit.
Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu met Georgievski and his entourage at the airport, where the Macedonian dignitaries were welcomed by honor guards from the Republic of China Armed Forces.
It is Georgievski's first visit to the Republic of China since the two countries established formal diplomatic relations in January this year.

The Macedonian head of government and his entourage left the C.K.S. International Airport for the central Taiwan city of Taichung where they will stay for one day. During their stay there, they will meet with Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shou-poh, and visit two computer manufacturing companies.
Premier Vincent Siew, who is on his way home after a 10-day three-nation tour of Central America, is scheduled to host a dinner Monday evening in Taipei in honor of Georgievski and his entourage.

The 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister originally planned to visit Taiwan in February or March. But his travel plans have been postponed several times because of the Kosovo crisis, which resulted in an influx of Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo into Macedonia.

During his stay, Georgievski will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and other senior ROC officials to discuss concrete measures to bolster bilateral relations and cooperation.
Georgievski will personally outline Macedonia's general investment climate, related regulations and development potential in an investment seminar.

Georgievski will also sign an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord and a free trade agreement with Premier Vincent Siew to facilitate bilateral trade, investment and economic cooperation.
He is scheduled to preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Macedonian embassy in the Republic of China on Wednesday.

During their six-day stay, the Macedonian dignitaries will also visit the Executive Yuan -- the ROC parliament -- the National Palace Museum, the Lung Shan Temple, the Tzuchi Buddhist Compassion Foundation and the Taiwan Handicraft Center.

Taiwan donated US$2 million in cash to Macedonia to help the former Yugoslav state cope with the refugee crisis. In addition, the ROC government donated a considerable amount of relief goods, including pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, and daily necessities, to Kosovo refugees in Macedonia. Taiwan also sent a medical team to Macedonia to offer free medical services to the refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOND MARKET TURNOVER EXPECTED TO EXCEED NT$60 TRILLION

TEXT.P: Turnover on Taiwan's bond market is expected to hit a new high this year, topping the NT$54.95 trillion (US$1.68 trillion) registered last year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said Sunday.
The island's bond market turnover in the first four months of this year totaled NT$17.13 trillion, an increase of NT$2.50 trillion over the same period last year, according to CBC statistics.
Bond market turnover stood only at NT$21.25 billion in 1984. It surpassed NT$100 billion to reach NT$141.62 billion in 1986, and exceeded NT$1 trillion on its way to NT$1.59 trillion in 1990.
The figure reached NT$10.73 trillion in 1992 and climbed to NT$20.80 trillion in 1995.

Encouraged by government efforts to expand the bond market, turnover of the island's bond market reached NT$40.39 trillion in 1997. The figure jumped to NT$54.95 trillion in 1998, an historic new high.
Due to the government's systematic pushing of the development of the bond market, turnover this year is expected to exceed NT$60 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO-DAY WEEKENDS WILL LOWER ECONOMIC GROWTH BY 2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will fall 2.07 percent if two-day weekends are implemented across the country next year, according to the newest evaluation by the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The Legislative Yuan has decided that starting next year, the two-day weekends, now occurring every other week, will be extended to every week. The lost eight hours from the two Saturday workdays will be replaced by additional half-hour work periods from Monday to Thursday.
The Legislative Yuan asked the CEPD to submit an evaluation report on the socio-economical effects of two-day weekends in the year 2000.
According to the evaluation, each additional day off will lower the gross domestic product (GDP) by 0.084 percent, and add 0.36 percent to labor costs.

If two-day weekends are implemented nation-wide next year, workers will receive 24.7 more holidays compared to 1998, the GDP will be lowered by 2.07 percent and labor costs will increase 8.89 percent, which are detrimental to Taiwan's economic growth and national competitiveness.

The report pointed out that the government's weekend system will influence the private business sector. If the private sector does not follow the government's lead, two-day weekends will have a smaller impact on overall economic growth.

However, the report noted, a discrepancy between government and private workers' working days will increase tension and disputes between employers and employees. The tensions will negatively impact Taiwan's national competitiveness, employment opportunities and economic growth.

The report concluded that since national holiday adjustments have not been clarified, rash decisions to implement five-day workweek could leave Taiwan with more holidays than any other country in the world.
At the same time, while public servants' working days have decreased, total working hours have not changed, which is detrimental to government efficiency and public service.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$100,000 TO ALBANIA FOR REFUGEE RELIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 6 (CNA) (By H.T. Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) government on Sunday donated US$100,000 in cash to Albania to help the Balkan state cope with its refugee problems.

The cash donation was presented by officials of the ROC embassy to the Holy City, and was received by the Albanian Archbishop Rrok Mirdita from the Durres-Tirana region in Albania on behalf of Catholic and charitable organizations in his country.
In a formal statement, the ROC embassy at the Vatican said the ROC government made the donation based on humanitarian considerations.
Serbian ethnic cleansing has triggered an influx of large numbers of refugees from Kosovo province into Albania.

Taiwan has donated US$2 million in cash to Macedonia to help that country cope with similar refugee problems. In addition, Taiwan also donated other relief goods and sent a medical team to Macedonia to help Kosovar refugees there.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGGIE CAUSES US$31,000 WORTH OF AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Typhoon Maggie's strong winds and torrential rains caused about NT$10.17 million (US$31,000) worth of agricultural damage to Taiwan as of Sunday morning, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported.
The island received some NT$3.37 million worth of crop losses and NT$6.8 million of damage to agricultural fields, the report said.

Most of the losses occurred in Taitung and Hualien counties, where the middle-sized typhoon struck the hardest, an agricultural official said, noting that seven hectares of agricultural fields in Hulien county have been flooded.

However, the official said that Maggie had caused minor damage to Taiwan compared with other typhoons. He said it was fortunate that rice farmers around the island had already harvested their crops prior to Maggie's approach.

Meanwhile, islandwide anti-typhoon centers reported no casualties as of Sunday noon. However, 100,000 households in Pingtung's Hengchun area, and 3,700 in Taitung suffered electric power blackouts, the reports said.
Maggie's strong winds damaged two major electric lines of the Third Nuclear Power Plant in Hengchun, triggering the shutdown of two generators, according to the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).
Taipower said the generators cannot be reset quickly, though, their failure will not affect daily power supply. The damaged power lines will be repaired as soon as the wind weakens, Taipower said.
Maggie was the first typhoon affecting Taiwan this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING, MOSCOW TO ENHANCE MILITARY COOPERATION: REPORT

TEXT.P: Russia and mainland China plan to step up their cooperation in the military and other fields, the national radio station of Russia said in a recent Mandarin broadcast.

In a commentary on Russian Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov's visit to Beijing on June 1-3, the broadcast said that the United States and NATO have taken actions of military aggression against Iraq and Yugoslavia, and that they may also make countries in the Asian Pacific region victims of their aggression in the future.
Ivanov's visit to Beijing attested that Russia and mainland China need to enhance their cooperation in the military and other fields, it added.

The broadcast also said that Russian President Boris Yeltsin will visit Beijing in late October or early November, and that he and his mainland Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin "will sign important documents, including a joint statement on the world situation" during the visit.

It added that the two countries are "quite uneasy about the general strategy of NATO and the United States," and that the joint statement will enable the two countries to cooperate more closely than before "in preventing this trend of threat from developing."

The broadcast said however that Russia and mainland China do not want to enter into a military alliance, because this will usher the world into a new cold war. "But, to oppose hegemony is another matter," it said, adding that the drive to oppose hegemony will be more effective, if India and other Asian Pacific countries join in the efforts.
