DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB UP-LINKS WITH 48 NATIONS IN ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING EFFORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) is now up-linked to an international anti-money laundering network that covers the monetary trading activities of 48 countries.

The Internet uplink gives a shot to the arm to the MJIB's efforts to crack down on Taiwan-based companies that engage in insider trading or illegal transactions of assets through their overseas holding affiliates, MJIB officials said on Monday.

The MJIB formally joined the Egmont Group, also known as the International Money Laundering Prevention Center (IMLPC), last year to strengthen Taiwan's efforts to prevent cross-border money laundering.

Through the assistance of the Egmont Group, the MJIB has recently joined up with Egmont's anti-money laundering network, gaining access to financial activities and related information from 48 IMLPC member nations from Europe, North America, Latin America and the Caribbean.

MJIB officials took part in an annual Egmont conference in Slovak from May 26 to 28, during which member countries agreed to form a network to allow quicker and more efficient crackdowns on money laundering.

It was also agreed in the conference that member countries will exchange bank account records and related information to allow law enforcement agencies to trace bank deposits suspected of being illegal.

A number of Taiwan firms have been found to have conducted insider trading or illegal transactions of their assets through overseas affiliate companies registered in Bermuda, the Virgin Islands, Panama and other nations in the Caribbean or Latin America.

Most of those countries are members of the Egmont Group, and since the MJIB is included in the anti-money laundering network, it will be easier for the bureau to look into instances of suspected fraud or illegal financial transactions involving Taiwan companies, MJIB officials said.

The Egmont Group was formally established in Egmont-Arenberg Palace in Brussels, Belgium, in 1995 with 28 founding members. Ten economies, including Taiwan, formally joined the group in its 1998 conference.
Taiwan is now the only Asian member of the group. Japan took part in the 1999 conference in its capacity as an observer and is expected to become a full member next year.
Taiwan's Money Laundering Prevention Center formally began operations under the MJIB in April 1997, one year after the Legislative Yuan passed a law to outlaw money laundering.
The law obliges banks to report to law enforcement authorities any transaction involving a sum of more than NT$1.5 million (US$30,580).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREX RESERVES AT NEARLY FOUR-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves continued to surge in May to US$95.7 billion, a nearly four-year high, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Monday.
The May forex reserves were the highest since August 1995 when the reserves amounted to US$98.96 billion.

Taiwan's forex reserves passed the US$100 billion mark for the first time in May 1995, when they reached US$100.32 billion. They continued to swell to US$100.41 billion in the next month, which was their highest level in the country's exchange reserve history, officials from the CBC's Economic Research Department said.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves have increased every month since last June, and the total at the end of May was US$11.26 billion higher than the year-earlier level.

CBC officials attributed the remarkable growth mainly to the appreciation of the Taiwan currency against the US dollar since late 1998. Greenbacks account for more than 50 percent of Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves.
Other factors contributing to the increased foreign exchange reserves include a better export performance and greater inflows of foreign capital, CBC officials said.

The pace of the reserves' growth, however, slowed in May over April, though officials attributed the decline to the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, which was NT$0.04 lower in May than in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 7, or the 24th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1329: Robert I, king of Scotland known as "Robert the Bruce," dies at the age of 55. He defeated Edward I of England, crowned himself king and went on to win Scottish independence from England in the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314.
1494: The ongoing dispute between Spain and Portugal over territorial rights is finally resolved as ambassadors from both countries sign a treaty at Tordesillas in northern Spain.
1712: Philadelphia bans the import of slaves.
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he was thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1916: Li Yuan-hung becomes president of the Peking (Beijing) government, after Yuan Shih-kai death from illness the previous day.
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1937: Hollywood star Jean Harlow, the original platinum blonde, dies of cerebral edema at 26.
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into the US to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1977: Street Parties are held all over Britain to celebrate Queen Elizabeth's silver jubilee.
1981: Israeli jets carry out a bombing raid on a nuclear reactor near Baghdad. The raid succeeds in destroying the plant.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law in the third reading, putting the manufacture, possession, or use of firearms and other weapons under stricter control. Violators will be sentenced from 7 years to life.
1988: Bangladesh makes Islam its state religion.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1990: President de Klerk lifts the state of emergency in South Africa.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Burma's military rulers pass a stiff new law effectively muzzling Aung San Suu Kyi's opposition party.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-straits talks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MAGGIE CAUSES US$18.17 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Typhoon Maggie caused NT$596 million (US$18.17 million) in losses to agricultural production in one city and five counties in Taiwan, according to the Department of Agriculture and Forestry under the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Department officials said agricultural losses were reported in the city of Tainan and in Ilan, Pingtung, Taitung, Kaohsiung and Hualien counties. Losses were heaviest in Pingtung County, which lost NT$422.96 million (US$12.89 million).
Officials said losses in Pingtung County were heavy enough that it is eligible for relief loans and cash assistance.

Crop losses are expected to exceed NT$554 million, while damage to agricultural fields has been estimated at NT$6.8 million and damage to fisheries and fishing equipment has been estimated at NT$30 million and NT$4.8 million, respectively.
In all, 3,606 hectares of agricultural fields, including 1,800 hectares of submerged rice paddies, were affected by Maggie.
Typhoon Maggie also caused substantial damage to mango, banana, lichee and water melon farms, mainly in Pingtung County.

Although land and sea warnings for Maggie are no longer in effect, the Central Weather Bureau said more rainfall is expected islandwide Monday. Residents in eastern, southern and southeastern Taiwan are being warned about possible heavy rains and flooding.

Bureau officials also said that Maggie has brought ample rainfall to the island in the past few days. Tienhsiang in Hualien County received the most at 425 millimeters, while Taitung County's Chihpen received 375 millimeters, Kaohsiung received 283 millimeters and Pingtung received 269 millimeters.

State-owned Taiwan Power Co. said on Monday that Maggie has caused power disruptions in 250,000 households in southeastern Taiwan. As of Monday morning, only about 300 households in the mountainous areas of Fengkang and Manchou in Pingtung County were still without electricity after emergency repair work was done.
Taipower said they expected power to be restored islandwide by the end of the day.
Two units of the third nuclear power plant in Hengchun, at the southernmost tip of Taiwan, tripped after Maggie hit, though it has not affected the power supply, the officials said.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) said that major vegetable and fruit production areas escaped the typhoon unscathed.
COA officials said that the supply of vegetable and fruits remains ample and that the public should not expect prices to rise, as has happened after past typhoons.

The officials said that the major agricultural areas in central Taiwan, namely Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi, have not been ravaged by Maggie. Even if there are heavy rains in the next few days, supplies will remain stable.

They said that compared with past years, the prices of vegetables and fruit are comparatively low, noting that the average wholesale price of vegetables was NT$25 (US$0.76) per kilogram last year, but only NT$17 (US$0.52) per kilogram this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO HELP THSRC BUILD HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday the government will assist Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC) in completing the island's first high-speed rail system as scheduled.

Siew made the pledge at a news conference held shortly after his return from a 10-day, three-nation Central American visit, which took him to Guatemala, El Salvador and the Saint Christopher and Nevis.
The premier lauded the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) for its efforts to promote the high-speed railway project in a responsible manner.

Siew said the government, the private contractor and the bank consortium should forge a partnership and cooperate closely to overcome difficulties and ensure smooth proceeding of the multibillion-dollar project.

Asked whether the government is likely to lend the THSRC NT$100 billion (US$3.05 billion) to enable the company to carry out the project in full swing as early as possible, Siew said the government must make a thorough evaluation before a decision can be made.
Noting that the high-speed railway is Taiwan's first BOT (build-operate-transfer) project, Siew said the government must consider whether its funding would affect the BOT spirit.
"If the THSRC files a formal request, the government will carefully screen the application and make a final decision," Siew said.

The THSRC, a private business and industry consortium, won the contract to build the US$13 billion-worth high-speed railway under a BOT formula last year. The company's difficulties in raising enough funds, including a delay in reaching a loan agreement with a bank consortium, have recently sparked speculation and doubt about the firm's ability to complete the project as scheduled in June 2003.
Siew said if necessary, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development will pool wisdom and resources of all relevant government agencies to help the THSRC fulfill the project.
Meanwhile, Siew described his just-concluded Central American visit as very fruitful and inspiring.

The main purpose of Siew's visit was to attend the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Francisco Flores. During his stay in El Salvador, Siew said he managed to meet with top leaders from many countries, including those with which the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties.

"Many foreign politicians have expressed admiration for our progress in economic and political reforms," Siew said, adding that many foreign officials have also shown keen interest in developing closer ties with the ROC.

Siew said he has come to understand through the visit that despite Beijing's constant attempts to isolate Taiwan from the international community, the ROC will still be able to forge close ties with other countries through its own efforts.

"Diplomacy is critical to our country's future development. All relevant government agencies must redouble efforts to help expand our diplomatic frontiers," Siew said, adding that Taiwan can use its economic clout to help foster friendship and substantive relations with other countries.

Commenting on a plan by five southern Taiwan cities and counties controlled by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to jointly issue welfare lottery, Siew said he hopes the issue will not be politicized.

"The issue should be considered from technical and functional perspectives. The central government has handled the issue in accordance with the law. Earnings from the lottery will all be used for social welfare projects," Siew said.
Turning to relations with Macedonia, Siew said he will take advantage of Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski's current visit to discuss concrete measures to boost bilateral ties.

Siew said the ROC will assist Macedonia in economic rehabilitation and in resolving its unemployment problems. Georgievski, heading a 59-member delegation, arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day official visit. If necessary, Siew said, he will make a reciprocal visit to the Balkan state later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA URGED TO WITHDRAW THREAT OF TRADE SANCTIONS

TEXT.P: Australia has told Canada to back away from its threats of trade sanctions over imports of salmon, saying Canberra is determined to ban infectious Canadian salmon.
Federal Agriculture Minister Mark Vaille on Sunday said Ottawa's threat to impose 100-percent import tariffs on a range of Australian agricultural products was "provocative."

"The Canadians are very aggressive and very assertive and their recent announcement on possible retaliation is quite provocative, as far as this stage of the process is concerned," he said on an Australian television program.

Canada has set July 6 as a deadline for Australia to lift its salmon ban. The salmon was declared infectious by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and the service said the salmon could affect the health of the Australian salmon population in Tasmania.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS ASIAN FIRMS SEE HOPE IN THEIR REGION

TEXT.P: Two-thirds of Asian companies now view their region as an opportunity rather than a crisis because of higher economic growth, according to a new survey by Andersen Consulting in Australia.

The survey shows three-quarters of multinational firms now view the region as an opportunity and not a crisis, with their focus on five strategies to support their upbeat view, according to The Australian Financial Review on Monday.
The five strategies are expansion into new markets, cost cutting, expanding production capacity, investing in information technology and re-engineering processes, according to the same survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM ASKS CLINTON TO SECURE RELEASE OF AID WORKERS

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has asked US President Bill Clinton to include the release of two Australian aid workers as part of an agreement between NATO allies and Yugoslavia.

Howard told reporters on Sunday that he had asked Clinton to help secure the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace of CARE Australia. The two were convicted by Belgrade of espionage and have been imprisoned.
He said the NATO agreement with Yugoslavia should include conditions for the release of the two aid workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CRACKS DOWN ON SMUGGLING OF MAINLAND CHINESE

TEXT.P: Australia captured 112 illegal mainland Chinese migrants through a joint operation in New South Wales involving the country's navy, coast guard, customs and police.

The Department of Immigration said preliminary questioning on Sunday has revealed that the 112 illegal migrants came from southern mainland China. They are the third batch from the region to have been captured by Australian authorities since February.
The other two groups contained fewer than 80 people.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said he would introduce harsher penalties against illegal boat people in an attempt to stem the influx of people from mainland China and elsewhere into Australia.

Justice Minister Amanda Vanstone said she was glad to see the efficient crackdown on the smuggling of human beings to Australia. She said it is clear that smuggling syndicates have been targeting Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONTEMPLATING US ENVOY VISIT

TEXT.P: Beijing is likely to agree to a visit by a special American envoy within the next week or two to present Washington's explanation of NATO's May 7 bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy, The Hong Kong Standard reported Monday.
Whether this would be an initial step toward repairing Sino-US ties would depend on Washington's explanation, the report quoted diplomatic sources as saying.
A mid-June visit by a special envoy was suggested by the Americans during recent diplomatic consultations between the countries, the report said.
But "the United States envoy would have to offer an explanation beyond the use of outdated maps," the sources were quoted as saying.

Beijing, which had earlier been opposed to the United States' sending an envoy, is said to have softened its position for several reasons: the June 4 anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown passed without incident, US President Bill Clinton has announced his decision to renew Normal Trade Relations status for mainland China, and the alliance's strikes against Yugoslavia appear to be near an end.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXPANDS FOOD ALERT ON BELGIAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Canadian government on Sunday expanded its list of Belgian food imports that should not be used.
Also, retailers have been asked to remove Belgian products, including beef and dairy products, from their shelves.
Earlier, Ottawa warned against consuming pork, poultry, eggs or products that contain eggs, as well as cheese, chocolate and ice cream, from Belgium.

The Canadian alert came on the heels of a food scandal in Belgium, where some livestock and poultry operations were found to have given their animals feed contaminated with oil containing dioxin, a cancer-causing agent.
The prime minister of Belgium is calling for an inquiry into the widening scandal. The Belgian government has not been able to identify which farms had been using animal feed laced with dioxin.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES CHANCE FOR BETTER TIES WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to forge better relations with Indonesia following its first free elections in several decades on Monday.

Political analysts predict that the first democratic elections in 44 years in Indonesia will change the political landscape of that country after 32 years of authoritarian rule under former President Suharto.
They have said a coalition government will emerge following the elections because none of the 48 competing parties will win enough votes to form a government by itself.
Analysts said Australia has a greater stake in Monday's elections than in any other foreign elections in several decades.
Other analysts predict Australia's long-term fear of uncomfortable relations with Indonesia would be eased after the elections.

To ensure successful elections, the Australian government has provided US$10 million in assistance. In addition, Australia has also sent election experts to Indonesia to offer advice to Indonesian election officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STRUGGLING TO STOP ILLEGAL MIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is in the spotlight again, as Australia is waging an uphill battle to stem a rising tide of illegal immigrants, while its detention centers are already fully packed.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Monday told the House of Representatives that in the first five months of this year, up to 13,000 illegal migrants arrived in Australia by sea and by air, up sharply from the same period last year. In all 33 boats were seized during the period.
In the past few years, about 12,000 illegals were detected in Australia each year. "It is a significant increase in the number of illegal immigrants to Australia this year," he said.
The new arrivals came from mainland China, Vietnam, Thailand, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Afghanistan, Iraq and areas in Eastern Europe.

He said international smuggling syndicates, including those from southern mainland China, are continuing to target Australia. The groups are spreading rumors that the migrants will be allowed to stay in Australia because Canberra will offer them amnesty after the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.
Ruddock and Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer said rumors are being spread throughout mainland China that people can stay in Australia after successfully landing here illegally.

Ruddock said he had discussed the problems with mainland China's vice foreign minister and senior officials in Fujian province and have asked them to help prevent mainland Chinese people from being sent to Australia.
He said he had asked the mainland Chinese officials to note every boat that leaves mainland Chinese ports as one way of preventing human smuggling.
"We intend to protect our territory not only in sea, but also by air," he told Australia's Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.113 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at the day's high of 32.629.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.74.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$102.05 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LA COUNTY SHERIFF VISITING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, June 7 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Los Angles county sheriff Leroy Baca arrived in Taipei Monday with his Taiwan bride for a weeklong visit.

During his stay in Taiwan, Baca will call on the Ministry of Interior and the National Police Administration to establish operative relations between the two sides for jointly cracking down on organized crimes in both Taiwan and Los Angeles.

Doyle Campbell, spokesman for Los Angles County policy bureau, noted that close coordination between police authorities in Taiwan and Los Angles had solved the kidnapping of Chen Kuan-nan, a Taiwanese residing in Los Angles in mid-December. Chen's case involved gangsters in Taiwan, Los Angles and mainland China.

Campbell noted that in order to deter the criminal activities in in Los Angeles, where there is a great numer of Chinese population, it is necessary to establish communication between Taiwan and Los Angeles law enforcement authorities.

Baca has been invited to review training exercises by Taiwan's SWAT team and will share his three decades of experience in solving criminal cases with members of Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau.
Sheriff Baca will also visit the family of his bride and honeymoon at scenic spots in Hualien and Kaohsiung.
Baca will leave Taiwan on Sunday for Hong Kong before returning to Los Angles on June 16

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG WILL VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong will visit Japan on Tuesday, Chin Chin-sheng, former Taiwan provincial government spokesman, said on Monday.
Soong, a prospective presidential candidate, just returned to Taiwan from a visit to the United States Sunday.
Chin revealed that Soong is slated to fly to Japan on Tuesday afternoon and return to Taipei Saturday, but Chin would not reveal the names of the political leaders Soong is expected to meet in Japan.
Soong had a full schedule of public and private meetings on Monday despite leaving for Japan the next day.
During his stay in the United States, Soong delivered a speech at the University of California at Berkeley and met with political and business figures.

After visits to the Philippines and the United States, Japan is expected to be the last foreign country that Soong will visit before formally announcing his bid to run in Taiwan's presidential election early next year. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices jumped 2.1 percent on Monday to reach a record high for this year thanks to strong buying in the electronics sector.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 163.39 points higher, ending the day at 7,802.69. Turnover also soared to its highest level for 1999, NT$175.24 billion (US$5.35 billion).
Investors bought on expectations of more gains before listed companies announcing their dividend earnings. Positive sentiment could lead the market upward toward the 8,000-point level, dealers said.
Gainers led losers 216 t0 215, with 78 issues unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the electronics sector enjoyed the largest gains of the day, jumping 6.1 percent, followed by the financial sector, which climbed 3.59 percent.
The over-the-counter market lost 0.02 points to close at 177.63 on a turnover of NT$9.28 billion.

TAIEX Index Futures for June jumped 211 points to close at 7,795, with 4,588 contract transactions. Those for July rose 205 points to close at 7,790 points; those for September moved up 222 points, closing at 7,792 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 826 and 50, respectively.
December futures climbed 226 points to finish at 7,768, with 15 contract transactions. Futures for next March soared 211 points to close at 7,801, with 4 contract transactions. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO DONATE US$300 MILLION TO HELP KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui announced on Monday that the Republic of China will donate US$300 million to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.

Lee made the announcement at a news conference held after chairing a meeting on the Kosovo problems. The meeting was attended by Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, and Ying Chung-wen, secretary-general of the National Security Council.

Lee said the ROC, as a member of the international community, has consistently been concerned about world affairs and problems. "We want to play an active role in the world arena and work together with other members of the world society in maintaining world peace," Lee said, adding that the aid to displaced Kosovar refugees is purely based on humanitarianism.
Asked about his view on possible backlash from mainland China, Lee said humanitarian aid to Kosovar refugees is a common goal of all civilized countries.
"Since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-exist in the international community, we should make joint efforts to promote international peace and stability," Lee said.

The president urged mainland China to throw support behind the ROC's aid drive, adding that he hopes mainland China will also take concrete steps to assist hundreds of thousands of displaced Kosovar refugees.
Lee's announcement came a day after Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day official visit.
This is the 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister's first trip to the ROC since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.
Macedonia has been burdened by a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS DEPENDS ON MAINLAND'S DEMOCRATIZATION: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The schedule for an improvement of cross-strait relations and eventual reunification during the next century depends on whether mainland China decides to walk down the path of democracy, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi Monday.
Su made the remarks in a speech entitled "Cross-Strait Relations During the Next Century" on a local television program Monday morning.

Su said there are three obstacles to reunification: an imbalance in mainland China's internal structure; the backward access to information on the mainland; and less importance the mainland has attached to cross-strait relations.
Su said mainland China is riding a bicycle supported only by the two wheels of economic growth and nationalism; once economic growth slows down, social unrest will follow.
Su said if mainland authorities rely on economic development, cross-strait relations will benefit, if they lean on nationalism Taipei-Beijing relations will suffer.

Secondly, Su said, because of its backward access to information and ideology, mainland China frequently points a finger at others but seldom reviews its own policies, this is especially true in terms of China's policy toward Taiwan. It puts most of the blame on Taiwan, and often misinterprets Taiwan's good intentions, he said.

The third aspect impacting cross-strait relations is that mainland places less emphasis on the issue, Su said, adding that while cross-strait relationship is of national interest in Taiwan, it is not a priority in mainland China.

Su emphasized that in the long run, reunification depends on mainland China's democratization while improvement of relations in the near future will depend on the mainland's willingness to walk down the path of democracy, he added.

Su concluded that it is the government's hope that Taiwan and the mainland can achieve mutual economic benefits, increase cultural exchanges and strengthen political communication to achieve a "win-win" situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUCLEAR WASTE'S FINAL DUMPING SITE NOT DECIDED YET: TAIPOWER

TEXT.P: The final dumping site for Taiwan's nuclear waste has yet to be determined, noted the head of the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) on Monday.

Board Chairman of Taipower S.C. Hsi made the remark while answering interpolations at the Legislature. Lawmakers were concerned whether a decision had already been reached to dump nuclear waste on the offshore islets of Wu Chiu or Hsiao Chiu near Matsu.

Hsi, in denying a final site had been selected, said potential dumping sites include North Korea and Russia. He admitted that Taipower has also contacted the Chinese mainland about the possibility of storing the waste.

Government enterprises under the Ministry of Economic Affairs made administrative reports Monday at the Economic and Energy Resources Committee of the Legislative Yuan. The two main issues of concern to the legislatures were the privatization of government enterprises and if a storage site for nuclear waste had been selected.

The Taipower head said that intervention from outsiders had made the storage problem much more complicated. He added that news that the waste might be stored at foreign sites has resulted in pressure from the international community.
Taipower will do its best to provide local residents at the potential dump sites with services according to the law as a way to win their support, stressed Hsi.

A foundation established to pay for the handling of nuclear waste has accumulated NT$90 billion to date, and should increase by NT$10 billion every year, disclosed Hsi. The use of the fund will be operated according to law, Hsi added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PRAISES TAIWAN CEMENT AS MODEL FOR LOCAL FIRMS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday praised Taiwan Cement Corporation as the leading company in Taiwan's manufacturing sector and a model for all Taiwan businesses.

Speaking at a ceremony to mark Taiwan Cement's 45th anniversary, Siew said the company has not only succeeded in its core business, it has also successfully diversified into other areas such as telecommunications, the information industry, and petrochemicals.

Although he hailed Taiwan Cement as a "model company" for all Taiwan enterprises, Siew nevertheless urged the company to pay greater heed to environmental protection, in light of the fact that it is pushing for several investment projects in eastern Taiwan, including the building of a cement plant, a power plant and a port.

The premier, who had just returned from a tour of Central America and the Caribbean, reminded Taiwan Cement of the importance of paying attention to environmental protection while making greater contributions to Taiwan's sustained economic development.

For his part, Taiwan Cement Chairman Koo Chen-fu, also a senior advisor to President Lee Teng-hui, attributed his company's success to a series of land and economic reforms carried out by the government beginning in 1953.
Over the past 45 years, Taiwan Cement has played a leadership role in transforming Taiwan from an agrarian society to an advanced economy, he noted.

Also present on the occasion were senior presidential advisors Sun Yun-hsuan, Chiu Chuang-huan, Yu Kuo-hwa and Ma Shu-li, as well as former Central Bank of China Governor Samuel C. Shieh and Bank of Taiwan Chairman James C.T. Lo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INDONESIAN MISSION REMAINS OPEN DESPITE GENERAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ROC representative office in Jakarta remained open on Monday as Indonesia's first national elections for 44 years kicked off.
Lin Shui-jih, representative of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta, said the office was remaining operational to look after the needs of resident ROC nationals during the voting.
Monday was a national holiday in Indonesia, and all shops and offices nationwide were closed.

Lin said Indonesian military and police chiefs had assured him of the personal and property safety of Taiwan businessmen and their families living in the country, and that his office had also contacted Taiwan businessmen in the provinces of Bandung and Surabaya for discussions on security measures in case of social unrest against ethnic Chinese.
As of press time, the situation in Jakarta had remained peaceful, and the elections were expected to conclude smoothly, Lin told CNA.
The Indonesian government estimated that it will complete the vote counting by the end of this month and that the official list of all elected candidates will be announced on July 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO IMPORT TOBACCO, WINE FROM MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 7 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chao made the announcement while meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who arrived in Taiwan on Sunday for a six-day official visit.

Despite an overproduction of tobacco leaves in Taiwan, Chao said he will still order the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board to purchase US$800,000 worth of tobacco leaves and US$200,000 worth of wine from Macedonia.
"We hope the deal will help boost ROC-Macedonian exchanges and friendship," Chao told Georgievski.
For his part, Georgievski said Macedonia looks forward to forging closer economic ties with the ROC and welcomes Taiwan investment in his country.
Earlier in the day, Georgievski toured a government-run central Taiwan vocational training center. Georgievski said he was impressed by the institution's facilities and its functions.

Ting Wen-sheng, director of the vocational training center, said Macedonia intends to commission the ROC to help train 2,000 Macedonians in machinery and woodworking skills. "Details concerning the cooperative program will be worked out later," Ting said.

In the company of ROC Ambassador-at-large Loh I-cheng and ROC envoy to Macedonia Cheng Po-jeou, Georgievski and his entourage also toured the Taichung Export Processing Zone and visited several blue-chip companies, including Leadwell Computer Co. and Hiwin Technology Corp.

Ten-plus Macedonian business executives in Georgievski's delegation visited major auto parts, machine tool and footwear manufacturing companies in central Taiwan, which is the island's machinery industry stronghold.

This is Georgievski's first visit to the ROC since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year, and Taichung was the first stop of his current visit. He and his entourage flew to Taipei in the evening.

In Taipei, the 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister first met with ROC Premier Vincent Siew for wide-ranging talks. The exchanged views on feasible measures to promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation. Siew later hosted a dinner in honor of Georgievski and his entourage.
During his stay, Georgievski will also meet with President Lee Teng-hui and other senior ROC officials on matters of mutual concern.

Meanwhile, Georgievski will sign an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord and a free trade agreement with Premier Siew to facilitate bilateral trade, investment and economic cooperation.
On Wednesday, Georgievski will preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Macedonian Embassy in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 7 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The 10th paragraph of CEP ITEM 0016 dispatched on June 5 Saturday should read: "Georgievski told a news conference ... that Macedonia's upcoming presidential election will not affect his country's ties with the ROC." (Adding 'not' into the sentence.)
A corrected repetition follows. MACEDONIAN PM TO ARRIVE SUNDAY FOR 1ST OFFICIAL VISIT
Taipei, June 5 (CNA) Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day official visit.
This will be Georgievski's first visit to the Republic of China since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.

Georgievski originally planned to visit Taiwan in February or March. But his travel plan was postponed several times because of the Kosovo crisis, which triggered the influx into Macedonia of a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

With the outlook in the Balkans brightening following Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's consent to accept an international peace plan for Kosovo, Georgievski has finally managed to realize his long-planned Taiwan visit.

During his stay, Georgievski will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials to discuss concrete measures to boost bilateral relations and cooperation.
Georgievski will chair a seminar to introduce Macedonia's general investment climate, related regulations and development potential to attract Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in his nation.

To facilitate bilateral trade, investment and economic cooperation, Georgievski will sign an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord and a free trade agreement with ROC Premier Vincent Siew.
On June 9, Georgievski will preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Macedonian Embassy in Taipei.
The 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister is still on a visit to the United States. He will travel directly from there to Taipei.
Georgievski told a news conference in Washington, D.C. on Friday that Macedonia's upcoming presidential election will not affect his country's relations with the ROC.
Even though the incumbent Macedonian president once opposed the establishment of diplomatic ties with the ROC, Georgievski said that problem has been resolved.
By now, Georgievski said he does not see any problems in bilateral relations between Macedonia and the ROC.
He went on to say he believes that ROC-Macedonian economic cooperation will be further strengthened following his visit to Taiwan.

Georgievski complained that major countries around the world have been reluctant to honor their promises of giving financial aid to Macedonia whose economy has been seriously affected by the Kosovo crisis. "The large number of Kosovar refugees is a heavy financial burden for us," he complained.

The ROC has donated US$2 million in cash to Macedonia to help the former Yugoslav state cope with the refugee problems. In addition, the ROC donated many relief goods, including pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, and daily necessities, to Kosovar refugees in Macedonia. It also sent a medical team to Macedonia to offer free medical services to Kosovar refugees.
The ROC attaches great importance to its relations with Macedonia because the Balkan state is one of its only two diplomatic allies in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO STEP UP INSPECTION OF IMPORTED ANIMAL FEED

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) and private groups on Monday sought to allay public fears about dioxin-contaminated animal feed making its way to Taiwan from Belgium, saying that most of the island's feed comes from the United States.
However, the COA has decided for safety reasons to carry out increased inspections of imported feed so as to ensure the safety of the island's poultry.

COA officials noted that because of the scare in Belgium over livestock contaminated by cancer-causing dioxin, which has caused European nations, the United States, and South Korea to ban livestock products from Belgium, public concern about animal feed has also risen.

The officials said that Taiwan imports about 5 million tons of corn and 3 million tons of soybeans from the United States every year for animal feed, and added that most of the produce comes from the central plains of the United States, far away from industrial areas.
The US also has strict requirements regarding environmental protection, and animal feed imported from there can be expected to be safe, the officials said.

The Poultry Association of the Republic of China said that the feed imported by Taiwan's poultry industry has to be tested and notarized on its levels of pesticide residue and humidity, and should be considered safe.

Meanwhile, the ROC Swine Industry Development Association said that 95 percent of the feed for Taiwan's swine also comes from the United States, while the remaining 5 percent comes from South Africa and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN PRAISES ROC PRESIDENT'S KOSOVO AID PLAN

TEXT.P: Former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Hsu Hsin-liang on Monday had high praise for President Lee Teng-hui's announcement of an aid plan for Kosovo, saying the move will win him international respect.
Hsu made the remarks at a press conference following Lee's announcement that the Republic of China will donate US$300 million to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
Hsu said Lee's aid plan is the best diplomatic move the government has made in recent years, and added that it was a skilled move on Lee's part to announce the plan through a press conference.

Hsu said the ROC government has in the past placed too much emphasis on how many allies it has, which not only incurs the wrath of mainland China but also leads to smearing of Taiwan's international image with allegations of "money diplomacy."
Only the universal value of respect for human rights will win global respect, Hsu said, adding that this is precisely the stand of his own "new politics."

Hsu also announced that he plans to visit Macedonia and Kosovo in July to gain a first-hand understanding of the refugee problem there. He said his "journey of history" will take him to the refugee camps via Greece, together with a group of history scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BANS IMPORTS OF BELGIAN DAIRY, LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan announced on Monday a temporary ban on the import of dairy and livestock products from Belgium amid fears that a toxic chemical had contaminated animal feed.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said the ban, effective from Tuesday, covers milk, eggs, dairy and egg-based products, animal feed, animal fat, poultry and livestock products originating from Belgium.
BOFT Director-General Chen Ryey-long said the government initially will only ban imports of Belgian dairy and livestock products.
"We'll decide whether to ban similar products from Belgium's neighboring countries and other European countries based on future developments," Chen said.

The Taiwan ban came after a decision by European leaders to destroy chicken- and egg-based foodstuffs from Belgium. The crackdown was spurred by the discovery that 400 poultry farms in Belgium may have used animal feed contaminated with cancer-causing dioxin. In addition, the Belgian government said the feed may have gone to 500 pig breeders. And Belgian cattle are also being tested for the highly toxic chemical. It is Europe's worst food safety scare since the mad cow disease outbreak in Britain.
The United States, Canada and many other countries have announced import bans on Belgian livestock products.
As Belgium is a foot-and-mouth disease- and New Castle disease-infected area, Taiwan has long banned imports of poultry, pork and beef from Belgium.

Nevertheless, Taiwan has imported dairy products from Belgium. According to BOFT tallies, Taiwan imported 89,452 kilograms of cream butter, 370,165 kilograms of yoghurt, 107,475 kilograms of cheese and 133,668 kilograms of dehydrated dairy fat from Belgium in the first four months of this year.

BOFT officials said local importers should divert Belgian dairy products to other areas if those products are en route to Taiwan. If the products have been loaded at Taiwan ports, they will be allowed to enter the island only after they have been confirmed to be free of contamination.

As there are reports that fairy and livestock products in France may have been contaminated with dioxin, the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine (BCIQ) said on Monday that dairy products from France will also be subject to strict examination.
BCIQ Director-General Chen Tso-chen said bureau staff already started inspection of suspicious dairy products from Belgium and France over the weekend.

"We have collected samples from products on supermarket shelves and sent them to the medical college of National Cheng Kung University and the graduate institute of chemical engineering of National Tsinghua University for examination," Chen said, adding that final examination reports will be available in a week.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, KOREA TO HOLD MINISTERIAL MEETING ON FRUIT IMPORTS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Monday that he was received with courtesy on a recent trip to South Korea, and that both sides have agreed to hold a ministerial-level trade conference on fruit imports.

Wang, who visited South Korea to attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's first investment exhibition, also met with President Kim Dae Jung to ask for South Korea's support for Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization (WTO) entry.
In return, Taiwan would resume imports of South Korean fruit, according to unnamed sources.
There have been no formal ministerial-level channels of communication between the two countries since the severing of diplomatic ties in 1992.

Regarding the resumption of bilateral ministerial-level meetings, Wang said South Korea agreed to meetings on specific economic and trade issues "when necessary," but sees no need for regular conferences at present.
Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kui confirmed that South Korea has formally demanded a resumption of fruit imports by Taiwan.

In response to the South Korean demand of resumed fruit imports in return for support for Taiwan's WTO entry, Peng said the imports should be discussed on a "barter trade" basis, and not through WTO multilateral trade talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLAN TO AID KOSOVAR REFUGEES TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN 2-5 YEARS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday that Taiwan's US$300 million aid plan for Kosovar refugees will be implemented in two to five years.
He said that the decision to provide the assistance was made by President Lee Teng-hui personally, and that it indicates Taiwan's ability and willingness to contribute to the international community.
Hu made the remarks following a press conference called by Lee earlier on Monday in which he announced his humanitarian aid plan.

The plan is focused on providing emergency refugee aid in the form of clothing, food, commodities, housing and medical treatment, as well as inviting refugees to receive professional training in Taiwan, and supporting international rehabilitation projects in Kosovo.
Hu said that the ROC government has not yet worked out details of the plan, but stressed that the Foreign Ministry will discuss concrete contents with related government units "soon."
He said that there will be no problem raising the money, but added that it may take as long as two to five years to implement the plan.

With regard to the professional training plan, Hu said that Taiwan has often considered offering such training courses, and envisions groups of several hundred refugees coming to Taiwan for six-month training programs focusing on television, computer and automobile repair.

Lee announced the aid plan to coincide with the visit to Taiwan by Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, but Hu declined to say whether the recipients of the aid will be Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
"We have no political motivation. We hope to carry out the aid plan through charity organizations, and we hope they will not reject our offer," Hu said.
So far, Taiwan has provided US$7 million for Kosovar refugees in Macedonia, including US$2 million in cash and US$5 million in medical treatment, food and clothing.
Hu said that the aid plan was announced before the Yugoslav peace resolution is concluded because Lee hopes to indicate Taiwan's willingness to help as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PAYS MALAYSIA IN ADVANCE FOR GAS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, July 7 (CNA) (By Chen Yok-pin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan paid a cash advance to Malaysia for a purchase of liquefied natural gas (LNG) out of what Taiwan's representative to Kuala Lumpur described on Sunday as "a spirit of good-neighborliness."

Speaking at a gathering of ethnic Chinese in Malaysia, Paul J.K. Tso said that Taiwan has entered into a deal with Malaysia to purchase LNG, and has made a down payment of US$250 million to cash-strapped Kuala Lumpur in order to help the Southeast Asian country ravaged by the Asian financial crisis.
As the third-largest foreign investors in Malaysia, Tso said Taiwan has funneled an accumulated US$8.6 billion into the country, and has not been scared away by the financial crisis.

As proof of its commitment to helping its Southeast Asian neighbors out of their financial difficulties, Taipei has set up the Southeast Asian Investment Co., with capital of US$300 million, to boost its business investment in the region, said Tso.

Lin Yien-wen, secretary-general of Taiwan's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), said at the meeting that OCAC's budget has increased by 23 percent last year in defiance of Taiwan's own economic crisis, a movement which vindicates the importance Taipei attaches to its fellow Chinese overseas.
Lin said OCAC is also expanding programs to recruit overseas Chinese students to study in Taiwan and to offer vocational training to overseas Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION STRONGLY OPPOSED TO CENTRAL GOVERNMENT CONTROL OF LOTTERY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Parry (DPP) has vowed to boycott the sending on Tuesday of a draft amendment to the act governing the issuance of the national lottery to the legislature's finance committee for screening.
The DPP move is in protest against the ruling Kuomintang's insistence that the central government should be in control of issuing the lottery.

The draft amendment is scheduled to be the subject of a floor discussion, and it is expected that the KMT will mobilize its legislative members to vote to send the draft to the Legislative Yuan's finance committee for screening, much to the anger of the DPP legislators.
Chang Chun-hsiung, the DPP's general convenor at the Legislative Yuan, described the KMT move as "illicitly helping its policy to pass through the legislature."

He also urged legislators elected from counties and cities in southern Taiwan to take concerted action to oppose the draft amendment, which would take the right of issuance away from local governments.

The Legislative Yuan passed the act governing the issuance of a national lottery in 1995, stipulating that the issuance right belongs to Taiwan Province and the two cities under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan -- Taipei and Kaohsiung.

Chang pointed out that since the promulgation of the act, Taiwan Province and Taipei and Kaohsiung cities have not yet formally issued lottery tickets, and he questioned how the central government can now withdraw the issuance right.

He said the central government's claim that the revenue from the national lottery under its control will be used to pay for a national pension scheme is only an excuse, and added that the real reason for the central government wanting to gain the issuance right is to "steal money."

In response, KMT said the draft amendment has been scheduled for a floor discussion at the Legislative Yuan in accordance with a resolution passed by the legislature's procedure committee last week, and that the dispute between the two parties should be resolved at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST STEAM TRAIN GETS FACE-LIFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first steam train, which has just received an elaborate face-lift, will go on public display once again on Wednesday, the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) announced on Monday.
The announcement came at a ceremony marking the completion of the refurbishment of the 112-year-old train, known as "Teng Yun (Flying Cloud)."
TRA officials said the refurbished antique train will make its debut on Wednesday as part of celebrations of the anniversary of the TRA's founding.
The German-made train was built during the imperial Ching dynasty. It was decommissioned in 1923 and has since been kept in a courtyard adjacent to the Taiwan Museum in downtown Taipei.

As the train was badly corroded through years of exposure to the elements, the TRA decided to renovate it, and moved the train to the TRA's Taipei workshop in March so that work could begin by a team which included retired TRA engineers and craftsmen. After three months of painstaking effort, the Teng Yun has now regained its past glory.

TRA officials said Germany and Holland also each have a steam train of the same type, and added that the TRA plans to build five or six replica steam trains patterned on the Teng Yun which will run on various branch lines in order to attract more customers.
The new steam trains will burn either natural gas or diesel, and if the government approves the plan, the new trains can be completed and start commercial operation by as early as next year.

Meanwhile, the TRA will be selling 1,000 miniature versions of the Teng Yun, which it commissioned from noted Japanese train model manufacturing company KTM, at the Taipei Railway Station on Wednesday. The trains will cost NT$35,000 each, and all proceeds will be donated to welfare institutions around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER AND IBM FORGE STRATEGIC ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Acer Group on Monday forged an US$8 billion cooperation relationship with US-based computer giant IBM, the most significant strategic alliance to date in Taiwan's information sector.
Acer Chairman Stan Shih and IBM Vice Chairman David Ernsberger jointly announced the agreement at a Taipei news conference.

The sum involved is expected to surge to more than US$20 billion when Acer signs to become IBM's Asia-Pacific manufacturing center as part of IBM's attempts to expand its personal computer (PC) division.

Under the terms of the seven-year contract, Taiwan's leading computer maker will buy IBM hard disks and semiconductor chips, as well as IBM products and technology relating to network and video. Acer will sell computer parts and components, including monitors and TFT-LCD panels, to its new partner.

In addition, the two sides plan to jointly develop the so-called "system on a chip" based on the IBM "Power PC" computer architecture, in an effort to integrate computer peripheral devices like VGA and sound cards, modems, and network cards, on a single chip, a product that can also facilitate the computerization of household electrical applicants.

Shih described the new tie-up as Acer spending "a great deal of money on the purchase of a small amount of IBM gold. Naturally, the gold itself is valuable; but Acer is also keen to learn IBM's gold refining know-how," Shih said, noting that Acer can sell IBM "gold" as soon as it has the technology.

The computer tycoon said that he believes IBM still owns "diamonds," referring to the potential of the Acer-IBM cooperation agreement. Shih added that Acer's goal is to equip every computer with Acer parts and components made using key IBM techniques.
However, he declined to comment on how much profit the Acer Group will get from the deal. Acer is Taiwan's leading computer maker, with 1998 net profits of NT$2.49 billion (US$76.15 million).

Meanwhile, it was announced that Taiwan's leading semiconductor maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), will on Tuesday sign to buy a 30-percent share of Acer affiliate Acer-Texas Instruments to manufacture silicon wafers.

Local market observers described the upcoming deal as a three-way profit arrangement, as Acer will see more on its net profit, TSMC will obtain relief from its increasing demand, while Acer-Texas Instrument will get rid of its huge deficit by turning itself from an independent semiconductor maker into an order-processor for TSMC.

It is estimated that with Acer-Texas Instrument's current capacity of 300,000 eight-inch silicon chips per year, the company can earn net profits of over NT$3 billion if it uses its production lines to service process orders, a far better situation than its NT$5 billion deficit of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATORS SUPPORT AID PLAN FOR KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Legislators from the ruling Kuomintang on Monday expressed their full support for President Lee Teng-hui's plan to provide US$300 million as aid for Kosovar refugees, but New Party legislators voiced their opposition to the idea.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT Department of Party-government Coordination of the Legislative Yuan, said that the aid plan is "in line with international justice and the spirit of universal brotherhood."
Chen Hung-chi (KMT, Taipei City) said the plan will improve Taiwan's international image, and will help Taiwan's diplomatic ally, Macedonia, to solve its pressing economic problems.

But Feng Ting-kuo (New Party, Taichung County) said that such a decision should have been announced by the premier rather than by the president. He added that the government's financial situation is tight at the moment, and that Lee should retract his announcement.

Two other New Party legislators, Lai Shih-pao (Taipei City) and Feng Hu-hsiang (Taipei City), pointed out that matters relating to foreign aid are normally handled by the Foreign Ministry or the Legislative Yuan, and they also criticized Lee for disregarding the due process of government.
The aid plan was initiated and announced by Lee at a hastily convened press conference, but not before he called a high-level meeting to discuss the plan.

The officials present at the meeting included Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, National Security Council Secretary-General Yin Tseng-wen and KMT Secretary-General John Chang.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu said that he was told of the aid plan by Lee when he returned to Taipei from an official visit to three Latin American countries on Sunday night.

He said that he gave a briefing on the aid plan to members of the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan shortly before Lee's announcement of the aid plan, and added that most members of the committee supported the aid plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE IN GOOD HEALTH: TAIWAN UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is in good health, according to the National Taiwan University Hospital which conducted a routine physical examination of Lee on June 1.
In a bulletin issued on Monday, the hospital said that 76-year-old Lee has good cardiopulmonary function and normal blood pressure.
Although Lee's blood sugar level is slightly higher than normal, the condition does not require treatment, and he is otherwise in good physical condition, according to the bulletin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT OFFICIAL CONVICTED IN RETRIAL OF SPYING FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: One of two former Kuomintang officials charged but acquitted of spying for Beijing was sentenced to one year and two months imprisonment in a retrial on Monday, while the other was acquitted again.
In the first retrial of the case, We Taoming was found guilty by the Taiwan High Court of leaking classified information concerning affairs other than national defense.
His alleged accomplice, Chang Lu-chung, who was also retried, was again acquitted for lack of evidence, as he was by the same court in October 1997.

In throwing out the earlier acquittal for We, the court said that during the investigation, he had admitted spying for Beijing, and that his subsequent withdrawal of his confession on the grounds of alleged coercion used by his interrogators was not convincing.

We and Chang, who were released on bail after the first trial, were not in court to hear the sentences. We's wife, however, who was at court along with his lawyer, said her husband will certainly appeal against the sentence.
We, who also went by the name of Ng Wah, was chairman of the Macau Association of Dr. Sun Yat Sen, the KMT's front-office in Macau, while Chang was a KMT commissioner posted in Macau.

They were accused of having been recruited by Beijing as spies and of handing classified information over to their Beijing contact, identified as Chang Yi, who is still at large. The information included the list of delegates to the 14th KMT National Congress.
In the first trial, the court refused to accept that the list of KMT delegates was classified information, and threw out the case.
The prosecutor appealed against the sentence to the Supreme Court, which threw out the sentence and sent it back to the Taiwan High Court for a retrial.
At the retrial, the court decided that while the list did not concern national defense, it was nevertheless secret infomation which should not have been divulged to the Beijing regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER MEETS WITH VISITING MACEDONIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Monday held 30-minute talks with visiting Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski before hosting a dinner party for his guest.

According to ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu who was present at the meeting, Siew and his Macedonian counterpart spoke of issues related to the promotion of economic bilateral cooperation between the ROC and Macedonia, and Georgievski reiterated the solid relations between the two countries.
Hu said Siew also explained to Georgievski the ROC's humanitarian aid program for Kosovar refugees which President Lee Teng-hui announced at a news conference earlier on Monday.

The foreign minister said Georgievski "very much supports" Lee's US$300 million emergency aid proposal, and that he suggested that the ROC government should think of Macedonia as a "bridge" or an "intermediary body," in which to purchase relief supplies.

Lee's plan is focused on providing refugee aid in the form of clothing, food, commodities, housing and medical treatment, as well as inviting refugees to receive professional training in Taiwan, and supporting international rehabilitation projects in Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHECKING REPORTS OF US$10 BILLION AID PLAN TO CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday it has no knowledge of foreign wire service reports that the Republic of China will funnel US$10 billion to Central America over the next seven years under a cooperation and investment plan.
MOFA officials said the ministry is checking all related reports.

An AFP report said on Monday that Timothy Tseng, an economic advisor to the ROC Embassy in Costa Rica has told La Republica, a Costa Rican daily, that Central America will receive a total of US$10 billion in investment capital or development funds for various ROC diplomatic allies in line with the particular needs of each one.
Central America is the ROC's diplomatic stronghold where many of its allies are located.

The AFP report said Costa Rican business leaders believe that the planned aid from Taiwan and the US$9 billion promised by donor nations at a Stockholm conference in May will help reinvigorate regional economies devastated by hurricane Mitch last year.

The ROC has donated funds to help its Mitch-stricken Central American allies, including Costa Rica, rebuild their battered economy. Meanwhile, private Taiwan business groups have also pooled their resources to set up a joint-venture holding company to facilitate investments in the region. All such moves are part of the ROC's efforts to shore up its diplomatic relations with Central American and Caribbean nations.
