DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 8, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
632: Mohammed, Arab prophet and founder of Islam, dies in Mecca at the age of 62. At the age of 40, he began to preach as God's prophet of Islam as the true religion. Mohammed established a theocratic state at Medina after 622 and began to convert Arabia to Islam.
1809: British-born American writer and Revolutionary leader Thomas Paine dies in New York at the age of 72. He wrote the pamphlet "Common Sense" in 1776 arguing for American independence from Britain. In England, he published "The Rights of Man" (1791-1792), a defense of the French Revolution.
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased the presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1921: Suharto, former president of Indonesia, is born.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye as his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II while he is serving in the British army. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1942: Japanese submarines and aircraft attack Australia, striking at Sydney and Newcastle.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: US President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 US troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: C.S. Wu and S.S. Chern, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the US National Medal of Science.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first ethnic Chinese American astronaut.
1986: Kurt Waldheim becomes president of Austria despite growing evidence that he collaborated with the Nazis in World War II.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan-Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: Governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China Chang Chi-cheng announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Communist China carries out a nuclear test explosion at the Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province, with a blast that rocks the remote region.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard.
"But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: the expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS MIXED OVER US$300 MILLION AID PLAN TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Legislators were mixed Tuesday in their reaction to an announcement that the government will provide a huge aid package to Kosovar refugees.

Reacting to the announcement by President Lee Teng-hui on Monday that the Republic of China will offer US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees for humanitarian reasons, most of the legislators from the ruling Kuomintang threw their support behind the plan.

KMT Legislator Yang Chi-hsiung said that if the government can assist Kosovar refugees, the move would win the respect of and applause from the international community, especially at a time when mainland China is squeezing Taiwan diplomatically by every means.

But KMT Legislator Hung Hsing-jung said that the ethnic Albanian refugees from the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo are not citizens of an ROC ally. It is unacceptable to provide aid to them, when government debt is near its legal ceiling, Hung said.

Legislators from the opposition camp were unanimous in their opposition to President Lee's plan, saying that the use of taxpayers' money for such an aid plan ignores the dire financial situation at home.

Peng Shao-chin of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the aid is not pragmatic, saying Taiwan should offer to help only within its capacity. He said that he is adamant in his opposition, especially because the government is trying to funnel the aid from its reserve fund to try to circumvent the legislature.

DPP legislator Tsong Chai questioned Lee's motive in providing the aid, saying that the move has triggered speculation that Lee is trying to boost his personal reputation in the international community in hopes of winning a Nobel Peace prize.
Chai urged the government to report clearly to the legislature on how it reached the decision to provide the aid, as well as on the government's motives and the purpose of the aid.
Another DPP Legislator, Parris Chang, also said that if the government wants to aid Kosovar refugees, the KMT should donate the money, which he said would boost the KMT's image.

Feng Hu-hsiang of the opposition New Party said that Lee's plan to aid Kosovar refugees was a decision made by Lee alone, and his generosity toward other countries ignores the suffering of his people at home. Huang Yi-chao, an independent, echoed Feng's words.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET RISE TO YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 1.1 percent to reach their highest level this year on strong buying in the electronics sector due to good news from computer companies on Tuesday.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index soared 89.44 points, ending the day at 7,892.13 points, a record high for the year.
Trading in electronics stocks accounted for over 70 percent of Tuesday's turnover of NT$176.02 billion (US$5.4 billion), up from the previous session's NT$175.24 billion.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Taiwan's largest chip maker, announced a 30-percent acquisition of computer giant Acer Group's semiconductor unit on Tuesday.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics and steel stocks registered the largest gains of the day. Decliners led advancers 234 to 203, with 72 issues unchanged.
The over-the-counter market gained 4.69 points to close at 182.32, with a turnover of NT$10.56 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June rose 99 points to close at 7,894, with 2,870 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July surged 104 points, closing at 7,894 points, while those for September gained 85 points to close at 7,877 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 674 and 37, respectively.
December futures jumped 132 points to close at 7,900 points, with 8 contract transactions. Futures for next March soared 178 points to close at 7,979 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN SNAKE VENOM SAID TO BE GOOD FOR TREATING HEART ATTACK

TEXT.P: The venom of the Indian viper has provided the basis for a drug capable of reducing the chances of people with angina from suffering a heart attack, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday.

The daily reported the drug -- tirofiban -- will be available to Australian doctors starting Monday. It works by stopping blood platelets from joining together to form clots. It is used to treat patients who come to the emergency room with unstable angina, characterized by severe and long-lasting chest pain.

Until Monday, all heart patients in Australia had been treated with aspirin, a known blood thinner, and heparin, a coagulant, which stops one part of the clotting process. But there had not been a drug that could quickly stop the platelets from clumping together, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION INFILTRATED BY KKK MEMBERS

TEXT.P: One Nation, founded by Pauline Hanson in 1997, has been infiltrated by members of the US-based Ku Klux Klan (KKK), and as a result the party was forced to expel two members within one week.

Hanson told reporters on Monday that there was no evidence that the KKK was in Australia and that publicity about the KKK was a "smear campaign" to denigrate her party. But her party's national director, David Ettridge, expelled two party members -- identified as Peter Coleman and Robert Leys -- within one week.

The expulsions were made after Coleman and Leys told The Sydney Morning Herald that they had been recruited by KKK organizations in the United States to set up branches in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

David Palmer, a former electrician from Sydney who describes himself as the imperial wizard of the Australian KKK, said he is an admirer of Adolf Hitler and now heads a Nazi group called the National Socialist Defense of Aryan People Movement. He told the Herald that his group had infiltrated the One Nation Party and that Klansmen were occupying official positions in the party's branches in New South Wales.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.05 against the greenback on the Taipei market Tuesday, closing at 32.579.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.614, and had a high of 32.525.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$885 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MULLING SETTING UP OFFICE IN MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: When exchanges between Taiwan and Mongolia reach a certain level, the Republic of China government will consider setting up an office there, a ranking ROC government official said on Tuesday.
Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the cabinet-level Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission, said that the proposed office will help boost bilateral trade and cultural exchanges.

Kao said that the proposed office will provide service as well as information, adding that such an office will benefit Taiwan businessmen as well as people from other countries who want to contact the ROC.

Kao noted that exchanges between Taiwan and Mongolia are not bound by the Statute Governing Relations Between People on Taiwan and the Mainland as Mongolia is not under the jurisdiction of the mainland, and that the country has never harbored hostilities toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SENDS MORE POLICE TO DARWIN TO CRACK DOWN ON HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Alarmed by a growing influx of boat people, Australia has sent more police to Darwin in the country's Northern Territory to vigorously crack down on human smugglers and to intercept them before they enter Australian waters, according to Australian Federal Police (AFP).

The Australian on Tuesday reported the AFP has advertised for someone with "experience in investigating illegal boat people" to go to the Northern Territory, the place where most illegal immigrants have landed in the past few years.

An AFP source told the daily that the newly recruited expert will be responsible for gathering intelligence on the movements of illegal boat people offshore to help police identify and track them before they try to land or head to the eastern coast, where several boatloads have been intercepted in recent months.
Police were encouraged to focus on intelligence gathering after they succeeded in seizing a Taiwan-registered trawler carrying 108 illegal mainland Chinese from Fujian province last Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SUPPORTS EX-FOREIGN MINISTER TO HEAD UNESCO

TEXT.P: The government of Australian Prime Minister John Howard has expressed its support for former Foreign Minister Gareth Evans of the Labor Party to take over the top job at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).
Foreign Minister Alexander Downer of the Liberal Party on Monday announced the decision to back Evans, describing him as "eminently qualified" for the post.
"Mr. Evans has the political and intellectual stature, and international standing, to take the organization in that direction (of reform)," he told reporters.
Evans, a long-serving foreign minister in Australia, is now a back-bencher in the House of Representatives.

Evans, who is one of eight candidates for the position of director-general at the UNESCO, told reporters on Monday that he would not take leave to fight for the UN post, which is set to be decided in October. He said he would quit politics if he won the UN job.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO TELL IF MEGAWATI'S PDI-P WILL HAVE LANDSLIDE WIN

TEXT.P: Monday's early voting tallies in Indonesia, which show Megawati Sukarnoputri's party firmly in front, should not be mistaken for an overall trend and could change dramatically when results from non-urban centers filter in on Tuesday, The Business Times reported.
It is too soon to tell if Megawati's Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P) is headed for a landslide victory. Official tallies will not be known for another two weeks, the sources said.
The observers noted that the tallies released so far come from only 42 percent in four provinces, namely East Java, Central Java, Bali and South Sulawesi.
These are areas where Golkar was not expected to do well, the observers said, and where the PDI-P was known to have good support.
There are more than 320,000 voting centers in 27 provinces. Some 112 million people, or 91 percent of the electorate, registered to vote for the 462 seats at stake in a new Parliament.
Commenting on the early tallies, observers said the results are believed to have come from urban areas where the anti-Golkar mood is strong.

The PDI-P is also strong in Java and Bali. At several voting centers in Jakarta, voters booed down Golkar each time the party's name was mentioned while loud cheers and applause were reserved for the PDI-P and other reformist parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PM WELCOMES ROC'S AID PLAN FOR KOSOVARS

TEXT.P: Macedonia welcomes the Republic of China's plan to offer up to US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees, Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski said here on Tuesday.

"The ROC's aid initiative is more than acceptable," said Georgievski, who arrived in Taipei on Sunday for his first official visit to Taiwan since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.
ROC Minister-Counselor to Macedonia Cheng Po-jeou said it is understandable that the Balkan state welocmes the ROC's aid plan because it will help relieve Macedonia's current plight.

Noting that Macedonia has a population of only about 2.2 million, Cheng said the influx into its territory of more than 280,000 Kosovar refugees in the past few months has had a serious adverse impact on the Macedonian economy.
In related news, the visiting Macedonian prime minister personally chaired an investment seminar Tuesday morning to attract Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in his country.

Georgievski told a packed audience at the Taipei International Convention Center that now is the right time to invest in Macedonia as the Kosovo crisis will soon be over with the imminent signing of a peace agreement for the region.

The 33-year-old prime minister said there are currently 16,000-plus NATO troops in Macedonia and that the number will increase to 30,000 in the near future. In addition, more than 50,000 NATO servicemen are stationed in the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

"The presence of NATO armed forces will help maintain political and economic stability in Macedonia and its neighboring countries," Georgievski said, adding that Macedonia can serve as a gateway for Taiwan businessmen to tap the vast European market.

Georgievski cited advantages of the Macedonian investment climate, including that Macedonia implements a highly liberal economic system, enjoys a most-favored-nations status in the United States, and maintains close ties with the 15-member European Union.

"The Macedonia government is scheduled to negotiate with the EU Executive Commission concerning its application for EU membership," Georgievski said, adding that Macedonia will also join the EU single currency system. "In the not too distant future, Macedonian products will be able to enter the EU market without any tariff barriers," he said.

In addition, Georgievski said Macedonia also maintains good relations with non-EU European countries. "We have signed free trade pacts with Yugoslavia, Croatia and Slovenia, and will soon sign similar agreements with Turkey, Russia and Bulgaria," he added.
Premier Vincent Siew, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and more than 100 senior executives from local conglomerates also attended the seminar.
Premier Siew said the ROC government has consistently encouraged local companies to invest in Macedonia to help boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
Noting that the EU is the world's second largest consumer market, Siew said he believes that Taiwan firms will benefit from setting up trading footfolds or production facilities in Macedonia.
Taiwan's exports to Europe posted a 6.7 percent gain in 1998 and the amount accounted for 17.8 percent of the island's total outbound shipments, making the continent Taiwan's No. 2 export market.
In 1998, Taiwan exported US$1.86 million worth of goods to Macedonia while imports from that country totaled only US$593,000.

The ROC and Macedonia will co-sponsor another investment seminar on Thursday, which will provide a forum for prospective Taiwan investors to discuss possible joint-venture deals with Macedonian business executives who are accompanying Georgievski on his six-day visit here.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LARGEST SEMICONDUCTOR MAKER BUYS STAKES IN ACER GROUP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), on Tuesday signed a letter of intent with the Acer Group to buy 30 percent of the shares of Acer's semiconductor unit, the Acer Semiconductor Manufacturing Inc (ASMI) at the cost of NT$ 5.47 billion (US$ 167.6 million).
The deal between TSMC, Taiwan's largest semiconductor and Acer, the world's thrid largest PC maker, will be the largest-ever in Taiwan's information technology industry.
After taking the shares, TSMC will become ASMI's largest share holder and thus be entitled to take over ASMI's operations.

The two groups will also forge a technology alliance, based on TSMC's technology and expertise in marketing and management, that aims to transform ASMI from a DRAM maker into a dedicated foundry company.
The partnership allows TSMC to further secure its leading position in the global foundry business by utilizing ASMI's excess capacity.
TSMC chairman Morris Chang said in a statement that the deal allows Acer to increase its global presence and position itself for long-tern success.

Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih said negotiations began one and a half years ago. Acer decided to form a strategic alliance with TSMC with the expectation that TSMC would lead ASMI toward its target of becoming a professional wafer maker.

"After TSMC takes over ASMI's management, Acer can concentrate on developing its PC, peripheral and key component business as well as explore opportunities in intellectual property and digital services", said Shih.
This cooperation shows that the IC and IT industries complement each other and guarantees a promising future for both parties, Chang noted.

The Acer Group's alliance with International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) and TSMC facilitates all three in any future collaboration, Chang said. He also revealed that TSMC is currently negotiating a strategic partnership with IBM.
Tseng Fan-cheng, TSMC's general manager, will be formally appointed as ASMI's president while other board members will be elected in July, Chang noted.
There will be only minor adjustments in ASMI's personnel with most employees retaining their current positions, Tzeng said.
Currently ASMI has a monthly capacity of 30,000 eight-inch wafers with hopes to expand to 38,000 by the end of 2000. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: US WELCOMES ROC AID INITIATIVE TO KOSOVARS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of State said on Monday it welcomes Taiwan's plan to offer US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees and for reconstruction of their homeland -- the Yugoslav province of Kosovo neighboring Macedonia.
In response to a press inquiry, a State Department official said: "We welcome assistance from the international community, including Taiwan, to assist Kosovar refugees and Macedonia."
As for details of Taiwan's aid initiative, the US official said: "We refer you to the Taiwan authorities and the government of Macedonia for details of Taiwan's reported offer of assistance."

The official would neither confirm nor deny whether the Clinton administration had asked Taiwan about its willingness to help finance resettlement of Kosovar refugees or reconstruction of their battered homeland. He just said the United States has traditionally not made any comments on such kind of discussion.

Statistics show that more than 782,000 ethnic Albanians have been forced to leave Kosovo since Yugoslav troops began ethnic cleansing in the region. Among them, 443,000 refugees fled to Albania and some 247,000 swarmed to Macedonia.
In addition to its previous aid, the US Congress recently approved an additional US$37 million aid package to help Macedonia cope with the Kosovar refugee problems.

Taiwan unveiled a US$300 million aid package on Monday, which will include emergency supplies for Kosovar refugees and contributions to long-term reconstruction efforts by the international community in Kosovo once a peace plan is accepted. Moreover, it also offers to arrange for Kosovar refugees to receive short-term technical training in Taiwan.
ROC President Lee Teng-hui personally announced the aid package to show Taiwan's sincerity to join the international drive to help Kosovar refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SHOULD NOTE KOSOVO AID EFFECTS: BUSINESS COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private business sector Tuesday declared support for President Lee Teng-hui's US$300 million aid plan to Kosovar refugees, saying that the public should pay close attention to the aid's effect.

Taicom Systems President Liu Kuo-chao, Taiwan Matsushita Electric Co. President Hung Min-hung along with Paul Hsu, senior partner of Lee and Li Attorneys-at-Law expressed their unanimous support at a luncheon banquet given by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce in honor of Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski.

Hsu said domestic public and media should understand the practical effect the Republic of China's (ROC) aid has on the Kosovar refugee situation. For example, he said, after World War II the Marshal Plan aided war-torn European nations.

The countries that benefited from the Marshall Plan have rebuilt their economies and now maintain good diplomatic relations with the countries that provided the capital for the Marshall Plan, Hsu said.

The public should not focus on the amount of aid Taiwan offers, but rather on the aid's practical effect, Hsu pointed out, adding that people should consider aid to other countries as another form of investment.

Liu also said the public should not calculate how much aid is given, since the aid is based on humanitarian principles. He added that the ROC government should continue to lend a helping hand to nations in need.
At the same time, he said, the government's plan to aid Kosovo will help pave the way for future investments in Europe and help establish long-term business relationships.
Hung said if Taiwan aid to Kosovo causes European countries to be more aware of the ROC, then Taiwan investors will be able to use Kosovo as a base for expansion into the European market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT DONATES US$100,000 TO ALBANIAN CATHOLIC CHURCH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Tuesday that the Republic of China (ROC) government has donated US$100,000 to the Albanian diocese of Durres-Tirana to aid Kosovar refugees.

MOFA received news from the ROC Embassy in Vatican City, the Holy See that the embassy donated the money on Tuesday to the Albanian Catholic church and charity groups that are caring for Kosovar refugees.

An official at the ROC embassy called the large influx of Kosovar refugees into neighboring countries a serious international issue. In response, the ROC, as a constructive member of the international community, donated US$100,000 in humanitarian aid to ease conditions for Kosovar refugees in Albania, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY WILL REMAIN STABLE: PECC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will continue to grow in 1999 and 2000, with real growth reaching 5.0 percent and 5.5 percent respectively, according to the latest Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) forecast.

Most economies of PECC member countries have shown evident recovery since early this year, and the 19 countries in the group are expected to post an average growth of 2.6 percent this year, the 1999-2000 PECC Pacific Economic Outlook indicated.
The outlook indicated that while most member economies have recovered from last year's doldrums, South Korea will be the only country in the region to post a phenomenal "V" shaped bottoming out.

Indonesia and Hong Kong, however, are forecast to continue experiencing sluggishness this year, with their economies posting negative growth of 2.5 percent and 0.5 percent respectively. Japan's economy also is not promising, with zero growth, according to the outlook.

Meanwhile, the PECC report estimated that Taiwan's consumer product index will rise 2.0 percent in 1999 and 2.5 percent in 2000, while its export trade, which declined 9.4 percent in 1998, will soar 3.5 percent and 3.7 percent during the respective next two years.
Taiwan's import trade, which posted negative growth of 8.5 percent in 1998, is forecast to expand by 2.7 percent in 1999 and 4.5 percent in 2000.
The PECC also forecasts that Taiwan's monetary policy will remain easy.
Founded in 1980, PECC is an informal international organization grouping 19 members. Each member country has a PECC committee composed of government officials, academics and industrialists.

Taiwan joined PECC in 1986 under the name of "Chinese Taipei." Other members of the group include Australia, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Columbia, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO OFFER US$10 MILLION IN AID TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Tuesday that the Republic of China will offer US$10 million in aid to Macedonia in the next two to three months.
Lee said the fund is part of a US$300 million aid package for Kosovar refugees announced by ROC President Lee Teng-hui on Monday.
The vice minister said the aid package is not targeted at any single country nor is it drafted at the request of any country.
Nevertheless, Lee said the government will certainly give top priority to assisting Macedonia, one of the ROC's two diplomatic allies in Europe.
Lee went on to say that US$300 million is the ceiling of the newly unveiled aid package and that it has yet to be decided how long the package will be implemented.
Lee said the proposed US$10 million aid to Macedonia has been included in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' budget plan for the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30.

"Therefore, the aid can be provided before the end of June. Nevertheless, we must still discuss with Macedonian authorities details of the aid program, including how Macedonia will use the fund," Lee said, adding that the issue will be discussed during Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski's current visit here.
Lee further said Foreign Minister Jason Hu had fully taken part in the planning of the US$300 million aid package.

Commenting on questions from some legislators about the source of the needed fund, Lee said the government will raise funds strictly according to existing budget law and the process will certainly be subject to parliamentary supervision.

Meanwhile, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said part of the aid will be used in purchasing Taiwan-produced products and equipment. "As a result, domestic industries will also benefit from the aid package," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT AMENDMENT TO LOTTERY ISSUANCE ACT TO BE SCREENED BY LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The legislature on Tuesday adopted to send a draft amendment to the act governing the issuance of the national lottery to a joint meeting of the finance, health and environmental protection, social welfare, and judicial committees for screening.
After voting three times, the legislature passed the draft amendment. It is expected that the draft amendment will be the subject of much discussion by relevant lawmakers next week.
The major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) strongly opposed the sending of the draft amendment to be screened by the legislature's committees.

The Legislative Yuan passed the act governing the issuance of the national lottery in 1995, stipulating that the issuance right belongs to Taiwan Province and the two cities under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan -- Taipei and Kaohsiung.
The draft amendment to the act, sent to the Legislative Yuan by the Executive Yuan, would take the right of issuance away from local governments and transfer it to the central government.

Chang Chun-hsiung, the DPP's general convenor at the Legislative Yuan, pointed out that since the promulgation of the act, Taiwan Province and Taipei and Kaohsiung cities have not yet formally issued lottery tickets. He questioned how the central government can withdraw the issuance right.

Feng Ting-kuo, an opposition legislator from the New Party, said since the central government wants to gain the issuance right, the revenue from the national lottery should be used to pay for social welfare and charitable activities instead of paying for a national pension scheme.

Yeh Hsien-hsiu, an independent legislator, said that the Kaohsiung City Government's intention to issue the national lottery by itself is not against law. Therefore, he urged the Ministry of Finance to keep communicating with Kaohsiung City Government to solve the dispute.

Lin Cheng-tse, the KMT legislator, thought the central government should be in control of issuing the lottery, saying that only in this way can the central government afford to pay for a national pension scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DRAFTING PLAN FOR NATIONAL STABILIZATION FUND

TEXT.P: In response to a call by President Lee Teng-hui, Finance Minister Paul Chiu confirmed on Tuesday that his ministry has started working on a draft plan to establish a "national stabilization" fund.

Stressing that the major purpose of the fund is to help stabilize the local financial market, Chiu said the government will consider using its revenues from stock transaction taxes, postal savings, land sales, release of shares by state-run enterprises, and other various government funds, as a way of raising money for the proposed fund.

Chiu did not reveal the scale of the planned fund, saying only that it will be large enough to help stabilize the local stock market. The fund is expected to be officially established by the end of next year at the earliest, pending approval from the Legislative Yuan, he added.

President Lee proposed the fund on Monday during a meeting with a group of local small business leaders, saying it would help tackle the impact of free international capital movement on the domestic financial market after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.

Although admission to the world trade regulatory body will help Taiwan achieve greater economic liberalization and globalization, Lee warned that local small businesses will face greater foreign competition as a result.
In light of the increased short-term foreign capital movement in and out of Taiwan, Lee said it is necessary for the government to do something to minimize the expected impact.

Meanwhile, speaking at an ROC-Philippines economic forum, Y.P. Chu, a researcher at Academia Sinica, contended that Lee's proposal is a feasible way of balancing the advantages and disadvantages brought about by foreign capital movement.

Analyzing in terms of supply and demand, Chu said Taiwan is a capital export country, and that the setting up of such a stabilization fund will help build public confidence in case of large amounts of foreign capital withdrawal.

Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a major domestic think tank, also praised Lee's suggestion as a good idea which he said can help the country establish a mechanism to cope with economic downward spirals.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DENIES FLOP IN ELECTRONIC WARFARE SYSTEM RESEARCH PROGRAM

TEXT.P: ROC naval authorities denied on Tuesday that the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology's (CIST's) research program on electronic warfare system to be installed on Lafayette-class frigates has turned out to be a flop.

Lai Kuang-shu, a department chief at the Navy General Headquarters, told a news conference at the Ministry of National Defense that the CIST has delayed in completing testing of the new electronic warfare system, but the whole project has been proceeding smoothly.
"We are confident that the institute will be able to finalize the whole project within the specified period of time," Lai said.

Noting that the Navy has commissioned the CIST to develop electronic warfare system for its six French-made Lafayette-class frigates in line with the government's defense self-reliance principle, Lai said the CIST has rich experience in developing command-control-communications systems for various types of naval ships.

"All CIST-development electronic warfare systems have managed to meet the requirements of different types of our warships," Lai said, adding that few countries in the world are willing to export their sophisticated electronics warfare systems.

Lai, who once served as commander of Navy's Lafayette fleet, said the French-made frigates have superb air-defense and anti-submarine capabilities. "Their performance will be further enhanced after installation of the CIST-development electronic warfare system," he added.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chen Chung-yi, a CIST division chief, said the CIST has managed to overcome many unexpected difficulties and problems in developing electronic warfare system for Lafayette-class frigates, also known as Kangting-class frigates.

Chen said the electronic warfare system must undergo testing at depot, in coastal areas and on seas. "The system has already passed depot tests and will soon undergo coastal testing," Chen said, adding that he is confident that all the remaining test work can be fulfill as scheduled by the end of June.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense said it has set up a special task force to handle all unexploded bombs in various military branches or units.
"The measure is mainly aimed at reducing danger and risks in handling unexploded military bombs," said a ministry spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SEEKING TO DIRECTLY ISSUE VISAS FOR MACAU RESIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, June 8 (CNA) (By C. L. Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei is seeking the right to issue visas directly in Macau for residents of the Portuguese enclave wishing to go to Taiwan, an ROC official in charge of Macau affairs said on Tuesday.

William Li, head of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau, said his office is seeking to obtain permission from the Macau authorities for that purpose, because "such a development in bilateral Taiwan-Macau ties would benefit the interests of Macau's residents."
Li said he remains optimistic that his office will receive approval from the Macau government. He said he will find an "appropriate time" to discuss the issue with relevant Macau officials.

Commenting on the question of whether his office -- the Republic of China's de-facto embassy in Macau -- will change its name after the Portuguese colony returns to Beijing rule in December 1999, Li said discussing the issue at this time would be premature.

Meanwhile, Tseng Wen-chang, chief of the Bureau of Immigration under the ROC Ministry of the Interior, revealed that a total of 35,864 Macau residents, Portuguese passport holders excluded, applied for visas to visit Taiwan last year.

The large number of Macau people who visit Taiwan is an advantage for the ROC government in its dealings with the Macau authorities, according to Tseng, who made the remarks after a meeting with his Macau counterpart.
Tseng arrived in Macau from Hong Kong on Monday to discuss with Macau officials the issues related to post-1999 visa issuance between the two sides.

In addition to expressing appreciation for Macau's assistance in immigration matters in the past, Tseng also voiced the hope that two-way cooperation in cracking down on crime can be further strengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS IN MAY EXCEEDED US$10 BILLION--HIGHEST IN 18 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in May totaled US$10.64 billion, the highest since Dec. 1997, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Tuesday.
In comparison with the same month last year, exports in May registered a growth of 13.7 percent to create a trade surplus of US$1,830 million, the highest figure since Dec. 1996.

If viewed from the value of average daily customs clearance in exports, the daily average export value in May was US$443 million, an increase of 6.3 percent from that of May 1998, an indication that Taiwan's export prospects are brightening.

The May performance was a result of an export increase of 13.6 percent to the US and an increase of at least 29 percent to Japan and to the Association of South East Asian Nations region, pointed out Hsu Kuo-chung, director of MOF's Department of Statistics, at a press conference.
Taiwan's exports to Asian nations in May accounted for 50.32 percent of the island's total exports, the largest since Sept. 1997, proving the economies in the Asian region have recovered, Hsu noted.
The total exports to the Asian region in May valued US$5.35 billion, the highest since Dec. 1997. Exports have now scored positive growth for three consecutive months, Hsu added.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's imports from the US rose 2.5 percent in May, the first positive growth in 14 months, according to the MOF figures.

In view of the fact that the shadow of the Asian financial turmoil has gradually faded away, the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association has predicted that global trade will grow by 3.2 percent in 1999, and that the Asian region, after having bottomed out, will recover this year.
If stable economic growth is maintained in Europe and in the US, Taiwan's exports will benefit, Hsu noted.

In addition, said Hsu, the construction of Taiwan's multi-billion dollar high-speed railway, the largest-ever infrastructure project on the island, will enter into its primary construction stage next year, which will be an incentive for private investment.
Against this backdrop, Taiwan's economic prospects are robust, stressed Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PHILIPPINES FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taiwan-Philippines Forum opened in Taipei on Tuesday to discuss the prospects of economic development and cooperation between the two countries.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taiwan-based Chinatrust Commercial Bank, opened the one-day forum which was jointly sponsored by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and the Philippines' Center for Research and Communication.

In an address at the opening ceremony, Liu Yi-shan, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, noted that the Philippines is Taiwan's 12th-largest export market, while Taiwan is the Philippines' fifth-largest source of foreign investment.
Despite the financial crisis which swept through Asia from mid-1997, bilateral trade has shown steady growth, Liu said.

But he said that Taiwan businessmen in the Philippines have reported that in Subic Bay, the main investment center for Taiwan businessmen in the Philippines, water prices are set to increase from six pesos to 32 pesos per unit from July, a development which is causing concern among the Taiwan businessmen there.

Liu also urged the Philippines to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan as soon as possible, adding that according to studies by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, this will help upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness and speed up the economic development of the Philippines.

Koo said that although Taiwan businessmen traditionally invest in mainland China because of similarities in language and customs, Southeast Asian countries are some of the world's major export markets, and he predicted that Southeast Asia will increasingly become the focus of Taiwan investors.
Koo noted that the Philippines has ample resources and labor and is Taiwan's 5th-largest source of foreign laborers and 15th-largest trading partner.

However, he added, both sides still have room for growth, and Taiwan is hoping to combine the resources and advantages of both nations to provide more commodities and services to the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIA TO FORGE INVESTMENT AND ECONOMIC COOPERATION PACTS

TEXT.P: Macedonia and the Republic of China are scheduled to sign a number of agreements on efforts to further bolster economic, trade and diplomatic ties, sources from the Executive Yuan said on Tuesday.

Visiting Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and ROC Premier Vincent Siew will jointly preside over a ceremony on Wednesday at the Executive Yuan during which they will witness the signing of four pacts by officials from the two countries.

ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang will join his Macedonian counterpart Nikola Gruevski to forge an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord, and an economic cooperation agreement, while the foreign affairs ministers of the two countries will sign a diplomatic protocol agreement, Executive Yuan officials said.

In addition to these four agreements, Macedonia and the ROC are also considering forging other pacts, including an agreement on cooperation in customs affairs, a free trade zone accord, and a loan agreement, to further accelerate business and trade exchanges between the two countries, the officials said.
Georgievski, who is leading a 59-member Macedonian delegation on a six-day visit to Taiwan, personally chaired an investment seminar on Tuesday aimed at attracting Taiwan investment to his country.

The Macedonian head of government cited advantages to investment in Macedonia, including the very liberal economic system, its most-favored nation status in the United States, and its geographical and commercial proximity to the 15-member European Union.

He noted that Macedonian officials will meet with EU authorities on June 21 for talks on Macedonia's EU accession. Once Macedonia becomes an EU member using Europe's unified currency, commodities originating in Macedonia will enjoy duty-free customs clearance in all EU member countries, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR VISITS JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 8 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong arrived in Japan on Tuesday for a five-day private visit aimed at meeting with friends from Japan's political, trade and industrial sectors.
Soong was invited by the Japanese alumni association of the University of California at Berkeley to deliver a series of speeches.
Upon his arrival, Soong said that he intends to obtain Japan's opinions on the Republic of China, to reveal Taiwan's current state, and to highlight the ROC's attitude toward East Asian affairs.
He said he hopes Japan can understand that Taiwan pays great attention to the US-Japan security agreement, from the point of view of its own security and of the entire Asia-Pacific region.
He also said he would like to exchange views with Japanese politicians on Taipei-Tokyo relations in the 21st century.

Soong will deliver his first speech at the Josui Kaikan building Wednesday, and will deliver another the following day at a conference hall of the Upper House members building on ROC-Japan relations in the new century, according to Soong's entourage.

Before his departure for Japan, Soong was asked to comment on President Lee Teng-hui's US$300 million Kosovar refugee aid program, and responded that while it is "nice" that the Republic of China is playing a contributory role as a member of the international community, it should "assess its strength before acting."

This is the former governor's third foreign visit in a month following trips to the Philippines and the United States. The trips are considered as part of Soong's attempts to boost his presidential bid, despite the fact that he has yet to announce whether or not he will run in the 2000 election as an independent.

Soong ended his public service career as Taiwan's first and last popularly elected governor late last year. Prior to that post, he served as director-general of the Government Information Office, and as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang.

A loyal KMT member, Soong's relations with the largest political party in Taiwan, however, have soured after the KMT-controlled central government downsized the Taiwan Provincial Government as part of its efforts to upgrade administrative efficiency.
Other reports have said that Soong's supporters are arranging for him to visit Hong Kong in July, with the aim of further expanding his overseas profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY TO EXPLORE EUROPEAN MARKET

TEXT.P: A seminar designed to promote strategic alliances between Taiwan's semiconductor industrialists and their European counterparts will be held in Paris in November, economics officials said on Tuesday.

In a move to help Taiwan's semiconductor industry gain a foothold in Europe, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the China External Trade Development Council are encouraging European semiconductor and electronic companies to take part in the Paris seminar, the officials said.
A dozen local firms, running the whole gamut of IC design, manufacture, packaging and testing, will be selected to take part in the seminar slated for Nov. 15-16, said the officials.

The European Union, with a population of 370 million and a gross net production of US$8.4 trillion in 1998, is the world's biggest single market in general terms. Its semiconductor industry posted a growth of 1.4 percent for a total value of US$28.4 billion in 1998 in defiance of the worldwide recession in the industry.

The EU semiconductor market is the second-biggest in the world after the United States, said the officials, and is forecast to grow by 7.8 percent in 1999 to US$30.7 billion, more than half of which will depend on imports. This provides a potential opportunity for Taiwan companies wishing to exploit the market, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT CHIEF TO ATTEND SEMICONDUCTOR CONFERENCE IN BRUSSELS

TEXT.P: Director-General Chen Ruey-long of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will attend a conference of the Government Council Mechanism (GCM) salted for Thursday in Brussels, BOFT sources said on Tuesday.

The GCM is an official global organization composed of representatives of the world's largest semiconductor-manufacturing countries, including the United States, European Union, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.

During the conference, participants are expected to discuss replacing the Global Government Forum (GGF), an official global semiconductor organization, and the civilian "World Semiconductor Committee" with the new GCM, to create a new communications channel for both the industry and governments.
The two organizations will be disbanded once they are replaced by the GCM.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELGIAN FOOD PRODUCTS TAKEN OFF TAIWAN STORE SHELVES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei and Kaohsiung, June 8 (CNA) (By Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: Belgian dairy and livestock products contaminated by the cancer-causing dioxin have sparked panic in Taiwan, and many stores have taken Belgian food products off their shelves to ease consumer worries.

The Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine (BCIQ) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Tuesday announced that all dairy and livestock imports from Belgium, France and the Netherlands must pass inspection before going on the shelves, effective immediately.
While it is not compulsory for stores to take Belgian food products off their shelves, the BCIQ has asked supermarkets and chain stores to cooperate, and urged the public not to buy such products.
To protect their reputations and set their customers' minds at rest, many stores have already removed the offending products from their shelves.

The 7-11 chain of convenience stores said that while most of their products come from reputable domestic distributors, they have still asked suppliers to provide documents showing that Belgian food products are contamination-free.
Meanwhile, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the Health Department conducted an overall inspection of 52 of the city's biggest supermarkets on Tuesday.

No Belgian egg or poultry products were discovered during the inspection, but inspectors found a "high calcium, iron and fiber" non-fat powdered milk manufactured by Belgium's Orimex S.A. in one supermarket, which was immediately taken off the shelves until the manufacturer can prove it is safe.
The Board of Foreign Trade on Tuesday also announced a temporary ban on milk, eggs, dairy and egg-based products, animal feed, animal fat, poultry and livestock products from Belgium.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVES TO CZECH REPUBLIC, VENEZUELA SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new representatives to the Czech Republic and Venezuela, Roy Wu and Ko Chi-sheng, were sworn in on Tuesday at a ceremony presided over by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee.

Wu, 56, has previously served as director of the North American Affairs Department and director of the ROC's semi-official offices in Honolulu and Chicago. He was director of the Foreign Ministry's Information and Cultural Affairs Department before assuming his new post.
Ko, 55, has previously served as secretary of the Sun Yat-sen Center in the Spanish capital of Madrid, and as counselor at the ROC Embassy in Guatemala.

Speaking at the swearing-in ceremony, Lee lauded Wu and Ko as capable and experienced diplomats, and expressed his hope that Taiwan's substantive relations with the two countries will be further strengthened as a result of their appointments.
The ceremony was presided over by Lee because Foreign Minister Jason Hu was suffering from a cold following his return from a trip to three Latin American and Caribbean countries last Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIRANTO SEEN HOLDING TRUMP CARD IN INDONESIAN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Gen. Wiranto is seen as holding the trump card in Indonesia's presidential election later this year, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Jakarta, correspondent Raphael Pura reported that in the contest to select Indonesia's next president, Wiranto holds a possible trump card, because the military remains a potentially decisive force in Indonesia following elections on June 7, when 462 members of Parliament were chosen.

The daily quoted Indria Samego, a military analyst and adviser to President B.J. Habibie, as saying, "The armed forces will become a beauty queen. Everybody will want to have a special relationship with her."

Wiranto, who was instrumental last year in replacing former President Suharto with Habibie, could determine whether the incumbent president keeps his job. It is also possible that he will side with Megawati Sukarnoputri, the leader of the Indonesian Democratic Party for Struggle and the presidential front runner.
Wiranto is already being mentioned as a vice presidential candidate for either Habibie or Megawati Sukarnoputri, the daily reported.
The daily quoted a high-ranking military official, Maj. Gen. Agus, as saying that the military will take its cues from Wiranto.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESCUERS SCRAMBLE TO SAVE BEACHED BABY DOLPHIN
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, June 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A baby Risso's dolphin which was found beached on Chishingtan Beach in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County on Tuesday morning was shipped to the southern city of Pingtung later in the day for medical treatment.

The dolphin, believed to be two or three months old, was first spotted by a local man who was taking a walk on the beach. He pushed the dolphin back into the sea hoping it would swim away, but the young animal soon washed ashore and grounded on the beach a second time.
The man then called the police and the Hualien county government for help, in the meantime using an umbrella to provide shade for the dolphin and pouring water on it to keep it moist.

Police arrived, as well as experts from the county government's Wildlife Conservation Committee, only to find that they lacked the expertise and equipment to save the animal, which by this time was close to death.
Staff from the Hualien Fishermen's Association also joined the rescue effort, and offered to carry the dolphin to their headquarters, where there were better facilities to help the stricken animal.

Meanwhile, the Taipei-based Taiwan Cetacean Society was called for help. Society representatives led by veterinarian William Chi immediately rushed to the fishermen's association to help with the rescue.

Chi found that the dolphin needed professional care, and suggested that the mammal be transported south to Pingtung where the Ocean Museum there was believed to be capable of taking care of the animal.

Since the trip from Hulien to Pingtung takes several hours by road, Hualien Magistrate Wang Ching-feng telephoned the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to ask for a transport plane to take the dolphin by air. However, the MND turned town the plea, saying that the job was beyond the scope of the air force's capabilities.
The baby dolphin was at last loaded aboard a specially adapted truck for the trip to Pingtung. As of press time, the animal was on the road, heading for an uncertain fate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANS 77 BELGIAN DAIRY AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Tuesday ordered an immediate ban on imports of 77 egg-based, dairy, poultry and livestock products from Belgium, in the wake of panic over contamination by cancer-causing dioxin.

The ban also covers products already en route to Taiwan, the order said, while products which have already arrived at harbors around the island must pass inspection before being allowed to clear customs.

Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture (COA) prohibited from Wednesday the use of Belgian milk powder used for feeding calves, and launched an investigation of livestock farms around the island as part of efforts to prevent contamination.

A COA official explained that if the milk powder has been contaminated by dioxin, it will endanger the health of the calves, but the toxic substance will not remain in their systems, so that dairy and beef cattle would be free from contamination after the age of two years.
Belgium is Taiwan's fifth-largest source of animal feed-quality milk powder.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DOCTORS PROBED FOR UNDECLARED VISITS TO MAINLAND CHINA: MND

TEXT.P: Two military doctors are under investigation for making secret and illegal visits to mainland China, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday.

A statement issued by the MND confirmed media reports that Maj. Ting Pin-huang, a doctor serving at a military hospital in Taitung County, and Maj. Cheng Yung-hsiang, a doctor serving at the Taoyuan Military Hospital, visited mainland China without the knowledge of the military authorities.

The statement said that preliminary investigations have found that Ting has applied to travel overseas four times since Aug. 1997, while Cheng has applied to go abroad three times since Aug. 1997. None of the applications declared mainland China as the destination.
The two will be punished if the investigation finds that any regulations have been broken, the MND statement said.
Although visits across the Taiwan Strait are common for private individuals from Taiwan, mainland China is still off-limits to ROC military personnel and senior officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES DELEGATION FROM BURKINA FASO

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday received a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
Lee welcomed his African visitors, and pointed out that Taiwan and Burkina Faso have maintained close relations since the two countries restored their diplomatic ties in 1994.
He expressed the hope that these bilateral relations will be further strengthened in the future.

Lee said that Taiwan's development in the past half-century has been a success, and that as a member of the international community, Taiwan is willing to use its experience to help its diplomatic allies.
Melegue said that he is deeply impressed by Taiwan's development, especially the fact that Taiwan has been able to make political reforms even during the process of economic development.
He expressed his appreciation for Taiwan's assistance to Burkina Faso, saying that the two countries' relations are certain to be further strengthened.
Other Taipei officials present at the reception included Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, Senior Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih and Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Lin Bih-jaw.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN POLITICAL GROUP WELCOMES TAIWAN'S DONATION TO KOSOVO
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 8 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A human rights advocacy party in the European Parliament on Tuesday welcomed Taiwan's US$300 million donation to help with the rebuilding of Kosovo.

The Group of European Radical Party Alliance, a movement espousing human rights and world peace, said in a statement that Taiwan has once again demonstrated its ability to play a sensible role on the international stage.

Contrary to the Beijing regime, the statement went on, Taiwan has distinguished the aggressors from the victims in the Kosovo conflict, for which the group said it will express its admiration to Taiwan.
Taiwan announced on Monday that it will provide US$300 million in aid to the Kosovo refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRODUCT EXPOSITION OPENS IN COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, June 8 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China product exposition opened Tuesday in the Costa Rican capital of San Jose.
The opening ceremony of the six-day exposition, which is being held June 8-13, was presided over by Mao Kao-wen, ambassador of the Republic of China to the Republic of Costa Rica.

Costa Rican central bank President Eduardo Lizano, Vice Foreign Minister Walter Niehaus, Vice Economics Minister Eduardo araya Vega and Olando Morales, a representative of Costa Rica's president, cut ribbons at the ceremony. The ceremony was attended by more than a hundred guests from Taiwan and by local dignitaries.
A total of 18 manufacturing companies from Taiwan are participating in the exhibition, including Taiwan Sugar Corp., Chung Hua Engineering Corp. and Acer Computer Service Corp.

Ambassador Mao said in his speech that this is the first time the Republic of China has put its products on display in Costa Rica and that the show will be held biannually from now on to promote bilateral trade between the two countries.

With more than 40 years' experience in manufacturing and sales, Taiwan has already seen its products break into global markets, said Mao. Telecommunications products and high-tech goods make up the bulk of Taiwan's exports, and the country was the third-largest exporter in the world last year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW CABINET PARTIALLY RESHUFFLED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Cabinet is undergoing a minor reshuffling, after Education Minister Lin Ching-chiang resigned over an illness, sources from the Executive Yuan reported on Wednesday.

Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday appointed former Vice Education Minister Yang Chao-hsiang, currently chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin as education minister.
Yang's vacancy, meanwhile, will be filled by Wei Chi-lin, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration.
Wei will be succeeded by Chang Che-shen, deputy secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, according to the sources.
The partial reshuffle was endorsed by the ruling Kuomintang Wednesday during a meeting of the Central Standing Committee.
President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as chairman of the Kuomintang, lauded Lin for making commendable contributions to Taiwan's educational reforms.
The new nominations are expected to be formally approved by the Executive Yuan in a meeting Thursday.
Premier Siew accepted Education Minister Lin's resignation on Tuesday when Siew visited Lin at his hospital room.

The 59-year-old Lin tendered his resignation in late May for health reasons. In a formal statement on May 31, Lin said that leaving the ministerial post would allow him to concentrate on undergoing treatment for a brain tumor. The resignation was necessary to prevent his health from affecting his duties as education minister, he said.
According to doctors at Veterans General Hospital, where Lin is being treated, Lin was found to have a malignant brain tumor late last year, and has since received chemotherapy.

The minister has begun to experience convulsions on the right side of his body, and doctors said Lin feels that the convulsions and the difficulty he has walking, for which he is now using a cane, could adversely affect his public image. That is why he has decided to resign, they said.
Doctors said that Lin's illness would not affect his ability to work, adding that his current condition is good. His right leg, however, is still weak and will take time to recover.
As education minister, Lin championed many educational reforms and was praised for his advocacy of lifelong learning.
Lin assumed his post in February 1998.
President Lee, meanwhile, confirmed Yang, Wei and Chang's nominations.

Yang Chao-hsiang, the newly appointed education minister, is 52 years old, and has a Ph.D. in industrial education from the University of Pennsylvania. He has been professor at National Taiwan Normal University and vice education minister.

Wei Chi-lin, 52, who has a Ph.D. in humanity sciences from the University of Paris, France, has been professor at National Taiwan University's College of Business, and a researcher at the Executive Yuan's Economic Reform Committee.

Chang Che-shen, 54, who has a master's degree in accounting from Central Michigan University in the United States, has been deputy director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DECLINES COMMENT ON ISRAELI CORRUPTION CHARGE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) Wednesday declined comments on reports that the Republic of China was involved in a corruption charge in Israel.
The ministry also stressed that the ROC's overseas arms purchases have been conducted through normal channels and legal processes.
Foreign wire service reports said on Tuesday that Taiwan might have been involved in corruption charges against Shimon Sheves, a top aide of the late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
The reports said Sheves, director-general of the Prime Minister's Office under Rabin, was charged with several counts of fraud, abuse of confidence and bribe taking.
Israeli prosecutors charged that Sheves received a bribe of US$80,000 to help secure an arms contract between an Israeli firm and a foreign country, and sought a further bribe of US$5 million.
According to foreign wire service reports, the indictment did not name the country in question but Israeli media reports said it was Taiwan.

MND officials said the ministry is not in a position to make any comments on foreign judicial cases. Moreover, they said Israeli judicial authorities did not confirm that the Sheves case is related to any foreign country.

MND officials further said it is the ministry's established policy of refraining from commenting on any reports concerning its weaponry deals. "We must respect positions of other countries involved in those deals," said an MND spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 9, or the 26th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
68: Nero, emperor of Rome, stabs himself in the throat with a dagger and dies at the age of 31. His early reign was dominated by his mother, Agrippina the Younger. He had his mother and wife murdered, and he may have set the Great Fire of Rome in 64. His cruelty and irresponsibility provoked widespread revolts which led to his suicide.
1672: Peter I, Russian emperor known as "Peter the Great," is born. He extended Russian territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores, reformed the administration of the state, and founded St. Petersburg as a new capital.
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1908: King Edward VII of England visits Tsar Nicholas II on board the royal yacht in the Baltic Sea, the first meeting between a British monarch and a Russian tsar.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1940: The king and prime minister of Norway order their troops to stop fighting at midnight, surrendering to the Nazis.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned to hang for "crimes against humanity. In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the Chinese communist regime.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: The ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1995: The Parliament of Japan passes a controversial resolution designed to atone for the country's role in World War II.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Communist China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison following the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN EMBASSY IN TAIPEI INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China was formally inaugurated in Taipei on Wednesday to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

It is Macedonia's 29th embassy around the world. Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski said at the inaugural ceremony that the embassy opening marks a new beginning for ROC-Macedonian relations.

"I believe that cooperation between our two countries will become ever more cordial and closer following the inauguration of our embassy here," said Georgievski, who arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day official visit.
Verka Modanu, Macedonia's first resident minister-counselor to Taipei, said the embassy will soon start visa services for prospective Taiwan visitors to Macedonia.
Modanu said many Taiwan business executives have expressed interest in traveling to Macedonia for market surveys and exploring possible investment or joint-venture opportunities.
Modanu, who speaks fluent mandarin Chinese, said the embassy will add a commercial affairs division in the near future to promote bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
Speaking on the same occasion, Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov said the ROC and Macedonia have forged formal diplomatic ties for only 133 days.

During this short period, Dimitrov said, Macedonia's parliamentary speaker, information minister and prime minister have led large delegations to visit Taipei, and ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu also has made an official visit to Macedonia.
"All these visits indicate that both sides are active in spinning a comprehensive framework to facilitate bilateral cooperation in trade, economic and political fields," Dimitrov said.

When Macedonia announced its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the ROC in January this year, Dimitrov said some skeptics questioned Macedonia's wisdom. "At that time, we said we want to learn from Taiwan's developmental experience. Our prime minister's current visit signifies our determination to fulfill our goal," Dimitrov said, adding he believes that Georgievski's visit will lay a solid foundation for future development of ROC-Macedonian relations.

ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, who attended the inaugural ceremony on behalf of Foreign Minister Jason Hu, said the inauguration of the Macedonian Embassy has opened yet another "door" for bilateral exchanges. Minister Hu was on a sick leave.

Lee said he is convinced that the "Taiwan experience" will flourish in Macedonia through concerted efforts of the embassies of the two countries. The ROC Embassy in Macedonia began operations in April.
To boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation, the ROC and Macedonia signed an investment guarantee agreement, a tax exemption accord and an economic cooperation accord.
The agreements were signed by ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Macedonian Trade Minister Nikola Gruevski on behalf of their respective governments.

In addition, the two countries are discussing several other agreements, including an accord on cooperation in customs services, a free trade zone pact and a loan agreement, to speed up bilateral engagements.

Georgievski is heading a 59-member delegation, composed of senior Macedonian officials and business executives, on his first visit to Taiwan with a view to cementing bilateral ties and attracting Taiwan investment. Macedonian business leaders will meet with their Taiwan counterparts in a seminar on Thursday to discuss possible trade deals or joint-venture projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLLAND TRADE OFFICE ASSURES SAFETY OF DUTCH DAIRY PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taipei on Wednesday explained to the Department of Health (DOH) that all dairy products from the Netherlands are safe and clean from dioxin contamination.

The Taipei-based Dutch trade officials said veterinarians from the Netherlands could issue certificates to any concerned individuals or organizations throughout the world that prove the safety of Dutch dairy products.

The Dutch statement came at a time when Taiwan, as well as other countries, are on alert against farm products, particularly meat, eggs and dairy products, from Belgium, which shares a common border with Europe's "dairy kingdom."
The Belgian dioxin contamination, Europe's worst food scandal since Britain's "mad cow" crisis in 1996, has led to worldwide boycotts of Belgian poultry, pork, beef and related products.
The scare came to light last Friday after it was acknowledged that some 1,000 Belgian farms have used feed from a contaminated storage tank.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) narrowed its focus on Taiwan's imports to Belgian animal feed-quality milk power, which is considered the product with the greatest likelihood of being contaminated by the dioxin.
It was found that there is only one company in Taiwan that imports Belgian milk powder used for feeding calves.

The COA on Wednesday demanded the Taichung-based importer, which imported 800,000 metric tons of feed-quality powdered milk from Belgium last year, to ask for certificates from the Belgian supplier to prove that the products that have already arrived in Taiwan are safe and clean from dioxin contamination.
The importer has sent samples of the Belgian imports to relevant quarantine agencies for analysis and, in the meantime, has suspended distribution of the product islandwide.
Taiwan on Tuesday announced a ban on imports of 77 egg-based, dairy, poultry and livestock meat products from Belgium, in the wake of a panic over the dioxin scare.
The ban also covers products already en route to Taiwan, while those products that have already arrived at harbors around the island must pass inspection before being allowed to clear customs.
Belgium is Taiwan's fifth-largest source of animal feed-quality milk powder.

The United States, Singapore, Malaysia and Egypt have enacted across-the-board bans on meat, egg and dairy products from Belgium, while Hong Kong and South Korea announced bans on similar products from Belgium, France and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL CRITICIZES MOVES TO EASE EXPORT CONTROLS

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer on Tuesday called on President Bill Clinton and members of Congress not to ease export controls on supercomputers to mainland China in the wake of the Cox report findings.

That committee released on May 25 a declassified version of its investigation report, and one of its major findings was that Beijing has used supercomputers it purchased from the United States through steadily relaxed export controls for nuclear weapons research, design and testing.
Bauer was responding to recent reports that the Clinton administration is preparing to further loosen controls on the sale of supercomputers to mainland China and more than 100 other countries.

"After the revelations of the Cox report, the American people want new policies that will ensure their safety, not further erode it," said the conservative Republican leader. "The move toward easing export restrictions on supercomputers is exactly the kind of measure that has helped create the problems the Cox report outlines, and which endangers America's national security."

"The Clinton-Gore administration must rethink this unwise and imprudent proposal, and reverse its present course toward making access to American technology easier for our adversaries. After what we have learned about the role of China's acquisition of supercomputers in enhancing its nuclear arsenal, easing export restrictions is the last thing our political leadership in the White House and on Capitol Hill should be doing," he said.
On May 5, 79 members of the House of Representatives wrote President Clinton, requesting that he ease export controls on supercomputers to mainland China and other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF ROC LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO VISIT MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng is scheduled to visit Macedonia on July 3 to further cement ties between the Republic of China and its new diplomatic ally in the Balkans, sources from the Legislative Yuan said on Wednesday.

Wang, traveling at the head of a supra-party legislator's delegation, is scheduled to leave for Europe on June 26 as part of Taiwan's efforts to further promote diplomatic efforts through parliamentary channels. Before visiting Macedonia, Wang and his group will tour Italy, Austria and Hungary.
This will be Wang's first overseas visit in his capacity as president of the ROC Legislative Yuan.
His entourage will include legislators from various political parties, including Chang Chun-hsiung, party whip of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's caucus at the Legislative Yuan.

In related news, Wang is also scheduled to host a luncheon on Thursday in honor of Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who is currently leading a 59-member delegation on a six-day official visit to Taiwan.
The ROC and Macedonia established formal diplomatic relations on Jan 27 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRESSURES MAINLAND CHINA TO CRACK DOWN ON HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Hard pressed by Australia, mainland China has started launching a crackdown on illegal migration, targeting the "snake-head" operators in coastal provinces known for smuggling human beings, according to a report in The Australian.

In a dispatch from Beijing, correspondent Lynne O'Donnell reported mainland Chinese police have been ordered to tighten border controls after an alarming increase in the number of boat people caught in Australia trying to leave the mainland illegally since last October, the daily cited a report from mainland China's official mouthpiece -- The China Daily -- as indicating.
The Australian reported that the crackdown followed top-level discussions between Canberra and Beijing.
So far this year more than 600 mainland Chinese boat people, mainly from Fujian, have been arrested after landing illegally in Australia.
The Australian reported that the crackdowns include Zhejiang, Guanxi, Guangdong and northern Lioaning, in addition to Fujian.
