The China Daily reported that mainland Chinese police cracked 437 illegal emigration cases involving 3,545 people in the first four months of this year, up 34 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CONFERS TOP HONOR TO MANDELA FOR HIS CONTRIBUTION TO PEACE

TEXT.P: The Australian government on Thursday conferred its top award -- The Order of Australia -- to South African President Nelson Mandela for his contribution to peace and reconciliation, and the improvement of ties between Pretoria and Canberra.
Australian Governor-General William Deane conferred the highest honor to Mandela. In his citation, Mandela is appointed an honorary Companion of the Order of Australia.
Other recipients of top honors included Shoichiro Toyoda, chairman of Toyota Motors in Japan, for his contribution to the development of the Australian automotive industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR `YET TO DECIDE' WHETHER TO ENTER PRESIDENTIAL RACE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Wednesday said he has yet to decide whether or not to enter the 2000 race for the Republic of China's presidency, but expressed concern over the direction the election runup is taking.
Soong made the remarks to reporters covering his visit to Japan.

A loyal member of the ruling Kuomintang for more than 20 years, Soong's links with Taiwan's largest political party have soured in the wake of the KMT-controlled central government's moves to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Soong is widely believed to be preparing for a presidential bid, and polls show the ex-governor to be a front-runner among the various presidential aspirants, including Vice President Lien Chan for the KMT and former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian for the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In an earlier interview with Japan's Sankai Shimbun newspaper, Soong spoke of his opinions of ROC-Japan relations, and stressed that Taiwan will never give up its democratic system or its determination to pursue freedom and play a contributory role as a member of the international community.
He said ROC President Lee Teng-hui's long-term efforts to defend Taiwan's dignity and the Taiwan people's interests can only be secure when there is no military threat to the island.

Soong is scheduled to deliver a speech on ROC-Japan cooperation in the maintenance of the regional security on Wednesday evening, and will deliver another the following day to members of Japan's Upper House on relations between the two countries in the 21st century.
Soong arrived in Japan on Tuesday for a five-day private trip to visit friends, including President Seiichiro Vjiie of the Nippon Television Network Corporation (NTV).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX PASSES 7,900 POINTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 0.8 percent on Wednesday to this year's highest record on continued buying in the electronics sector, registering a rise for the eighth consecutive trading session.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index surged 65.58 points to close at 7,957.71 points, the highest level this year.
A total of 321.78 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$186.30 billion (US$5.72 billion), another record high and up from the previous session's NT$176.02 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics shares and financial stocks registered the only gains of the day, rising 2.2 percent and 0.1 percent, respectively.
The paper and pulp sector posted the heaviest loss of the day, dropping 2.1 percent, followed by construction issues, which fell 1.2 percent.
Textile shares lost 0.9 percent, closely followed by cement issues, which dropped 0.8 percent. Foodstuff issues declined 0.6 percent and plastic and chemical shares went down 0.2 percent.
The over-the-counter market suffered a 1.48-point drop, ending the day at 180.84 points, with a turnover of NT$9.73 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June climbed 31 points to close at 7,925 points, with 2,287 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July rose 45 points to close at 7,939, while those for September gained 43 points, closing at 7,920. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 740 and 62, respectively.
December futures increased 20 points to close at 7,920, with six contract transactions. Futures for next March fell 29 points, closing at 7,950 points, with two contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,894 points for June and July, 7,877 points for September, 7,900 points for December, and 7,979 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.051 against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 32.528.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.553, and had a high of 32.466.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US961 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA SECURITIES FORUM TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fifth Asian Securities Forum is scheduled to open at Taipei's Grand Hotel on Thursday, with nearly 70 delegates from home and other Asian countries expected to attend.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will deliver a speech to kick off the annual meeting, which this year carries a theme of "Collaboration toward Asia's New Century."

Finance Minister Paul Chiu is scheduled to address the forum's closing ceremony on Friday afternoon, according to officials from the Taipei-based Chinese Securities Association, which is sponsoring the event.

Participants at the forum will include financial officials and executives of stocks, securities, funds and futures businesses from Taiwan, Japan, Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines, said association officials.

Several major subjects, including cross-border securities trading and settlements, resolution measures against the millennium bug problem, and prospects of Internet trading, will be mooted in the forum, the officials said.
The Asia Securities Forum has been meeting annually in different Asian cities since 1995 for discussions on problems and prospects of stock and securities markets throughout Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESSIONAL RESOLUTION OPPOSING TRADE STATUS RENEWAL INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: US Sen. Robert C. Smith (R-N.H.) has introduced a joint resolution opposing the extension of normal trade relations with mainland China, as recommended by President Bill Clinton on June 3.
The joint resolution was read twice Monday and referred to the Senate Committee on Finance.

Smith also introduced a resolution on May 26 asking the Senate to form a select committee to investigate mainland China's spying activities in the United States. The resolution was introduced one day after a House committee released a report on Beijing's theft of US nuclear weapons secrets.

In addition, Rep. Duncan L. Hunter (R-Calif.) introduced a House resolution on May 26 to prohibit the export of high-performance computers to mainland China and several other countries until certain applicable provisions of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1998 are fulfilled.

Hunter noted that since the secretary of commerce has reported that mainland China has not allowed post-shipment verifications to be conducted as required by the National Defense Authorization Act, the US government does not know if the computers in question are being used by mainland China for purposes that benefit the military or attempted weapons proliferation.

The resolution also requests that the secretary of defense submit to both House and Senate committees on the armed forces a report on the impact on US national security of the export of high-performance computers to countries that have been identified as countries of concern for national security or proliferation reasons, such as mainland China, Russia, India, Pakistan and Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREVENTING SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH

TEXT.P: A researcher at Washington University's School of Medicine in St. Louis has invented the first non-invasive test that identifies people at risk of sudden death caused by irregular heartbeat.
The test is called the alternans test because it measures a tiny fluctuation in heartbeat called the T-wave alternans.

Doctor Joseph M. Smith, associate professor of medicine and biomedical engineering, invented the test while he was at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and he hopes it will be used widely to identify those at risk of sudden death. Cambridge Heart Inc. developed the test for commercial use, and the Food and Drug Administration approved it in April 1999.

Smith and colleagues described their latest study at a meeting of the North American Society of Pacing and Electrophysiology in Toronto, Canada, in May. They determined how the heartbeat fluctuation changes as a person's heart rate changes, which will allow for improvements in the test's accuracy.

"Because the consequence of a positive alternans test may be implantation of a defibrillator in some patients, we want to make the test as accurate as possible," Smith said in an article distributed by the Washington University Feature Service.

Most cardiac patients undergo a stress test to evaluate problems associated with insufficient blood supply to the heart -- a plumbing problem. Such tests are of little value in detecting the electrical problems responsible for sudden death, however. Studying the electrical system of the heart typically requires an invasive test in which electrode catheters are placed inside the heart.

While the majority of sudden deaths occur in patients with plumbing problems, only a small minority of patients with plumbing problems who also are suspected of having electrical problems go on to receive the invasive electrical test, according to the article.

This is due in part to the test's invasive nature, its cost and the associated risks. "As a result, some people go about their daily lives without knowing they might suddenly die. In fact, one in three people who develop fatal arrhythmias have had no previous arrhythmia symptoms or known heart problems."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S PRODUCTIVITY UP, UNEMPLOYMENT ON DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Australia's productivity growth nearly doubled between 1994-95 and 1997-98 from previous years, while its unemployment rate is expected to fall to 7 percent from the current 7.5 percent by the end of this year.

The Productivity Commission reported on Tuesday that annual productivity growth of 2.4 percent had been sustained in the past four years to 1997-98, compared with the long-term average of 1.4 percent in previous years.
"The acceleration in productivity growth in the 1990s is outstripping any earlier results," the commission said in a report released to the media.

It said recovery from the recession of the early 1990s, structural reforms, underlying technology advancements and organizational and management improvements have driven the improved productivity performance. The acceleration in general has not come from a reduction in the size of the labor force in this country, it added.

The unemployment outlook is expected to improve as companies are employing more people as a result of strong economic performance, according to a survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Westpac Banking Corp.

The survey predicts that the jobless rate in Australia will fall to 7 percent by the end of this year from the current 7.5 percent, which is a more optimistic forecast than the official target of 7.5 percent unemployment at the end of the year.

"For the first time since 1994, we have a majority respondents expecting to increase their workforce," said Westpac's general manager of economics, Bill Evans. "A lift in employment growth will be important for sustaining the economy's current momentum for much longer than generally expected by most commentators," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON COMMENDED FOR NOMINATING CHINESE-AMERICAN TO FEDERAL BENCH

TEXT.P: US Rep. David Wu (D-Ore.) Tuesday commended President Bill Clinton for nominating Dolly M. Gee to the 9th District Court.
If confirmed, Gee would be the first Chinese-American woman to serve on the federal bench on the US mainland.

Wu, the first ever Chinese-American member of the House of Representatives and who wrote in January a letter in support of Gee's nomination, said, "Ms. Gee will be a great addition to our judicial system. Her years of experience as a public interest attorney make her well-qualified for this post."
Furthermore, Wu added, "as the first Chinese-American woman appointed to the federal bench, Ms. Gee offers a unique perspective."
Gee's mother, a Chinese immigrant who toiled as a seamstress in the garment industry, played a major role in her daughter's choice to represent workers, according to Wu's office.

After earning a law degree from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1984, Gee clerked for US District Judge Milton Schwartz in Sacramento. She is currently an attorney at the Los Angeles law firm of Schwartz, Steinsapir, Dohrmann & Sommers, and a member of the California Bar Association Commission, which evaluates prospective nominees for state courts.
Gee co-founded the Asian Pacific American Bar Association of Los Angeles, as well as the Multicultural Bar Alliance. She is also a

DOC.HEADLINE: SOMALIS SUE CANADA OVER KILLING OF YOUTH

TEXT.P: The parents of Shidane Arone are suing Canada for C$5 million (US3.4 million) in compensation for the death of their son, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported late Tuesday.
Their suit comes as a result of the torture and death of a 16-year-old Somali boy by Canadian peace-keeping troops six years ago, the CBC noted.
Arone's brutal death in 1993 touched off a chain of events that rocked Canada's military to its core.
The conduct of Canadian military personnel was investigated by the Somalia Commission of Inquiry. But the inquiry was shut down before it could hear testimony about Arone's death.
The CBC quoted Arone's father as saying, "I would like justice, humanity, so that my son can rest in peace." The family wants an apology as well as C$5 million in compensation for their son's death.
Rohan Bansie, the family's lawyer, said the family is still very upset. "Their son was horrifically tortured, beaten, murdered essentially. And they want some justice."
Canadian peace keepers said Arone was captured because he broke into their camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIGRANT CRIME STIRS STRONG DEBATE AND CRITICISM IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Immigrants from Vietnam, Cambodia, Romania, Yugoslavia, Lebanon, Fiji, Turkey and New Zealand are more likely to commit crimes than Australian-born people, according to research by the Australian Institute of Criminology.
The research immediately triggered strong debate and criticism from ethnic groups from Vietnam and other countries named in the report.

The author of the research report, Satyanshu Mukherjee, said the lesson from the study was not that certain nationalities were more criminally inclined than others. He said the problem lay not in their ethnic background, but in their social disadvantages, including language problems, lack of formal education, poor housing and unemployment.
Seizing on the report, Pauline Hanson, the leader of Australia's One Nation Party, said social disadvantages were no excuse for turning to crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAYS INDONESIAN ARMY BACKING PRO-INTEGRATION MILITIA

TEXT.P: Australia has acknowledged publicly for the first time that Indonesian armed forces were actively supporting and encouraging pro-integration militia in East Timor, The Australian reported on Wednesday.

The daily reported that Hugh White, deputy secretary for strategy and intelligence at the Defense Department, on Tuesday told a Senate estimates committee of hearing about the active support of the Indonesian armed forces in East Timor, brushing aside repeated denials by the Indonesian government. The admission contrasts sharply with more cautious previous statements by the Australian government.

"We believe the Indonesian armed forces have been actively engaged in support and encouraging the pro-integration movements, and that has contributed significantly to the security problems in East Timor," White told the Senate.
The Australian government has been very cautious and unwilling to confirm directly the numerous reports of Indonesian military support for the pro-integration forces in East Timor.
The daily quoted government sources as saying that White's comments reflected "more up-to-date information."

Meanwhile, Monday's general elections in Indonesia were calm and orderly, and that helped boost the country's stock market, which surged 12 percent on Monday. It also strengthened the Indonesian rupiah, which gained 6 percent, to close at 7,665 to the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MOVES FOR US-STYLE SECURITY BODY

TEXT.P: Stung by past "mistakes" in handling major world events, Beijing is moving to revamp its top foreign-affairs structure to more closely parallel that of the United States, The Hong Kong Standard reported Wednesday.
The move will affect both the top decision-making body headed by President Jiang Zemin and a task force working under it that handles day-to-day affairs, the report said.
It quoted diplomatic sources as saying that the changes will create a decision-making structure along the lines of the United States' National Security Council.
The decision was reportedly made by Jiang after a review of the government's response to the Kosovo crisis and the NATO bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
"We are strategically right in the whole process but have made some technical mistakes on many occasions," a well-informed source quoted Jiang as saying at a recent top-level meeting.

"Jiang has apparently been unhappy with some propagandists and some academics affiliated to the military who deliberately whipped up anti-US sentiments to attract attention," one source was quoted as saying.

According to the report, key to the changes is a shake-up of the central leading group on foreign affairs, which is chaired by Jiang, while Premier Zhu Rongji and Vice-Premier Qian Qichen serve as his deputies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF SWITCHES POSITION ON TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR OFFSHORE RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang on Wednesday dismissed a previous decision by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) that residents living on offshore islands would receive a five-year tax exemption, saying the decision was unfair.

Yen made the statement in response to a report that the MOF, under the request of several legislators elected from offshore islands, had agreed to stop levying personal income taxes, business taxes and business income taxes on offshore island residents.

In an attempt to speed up construction on the offshore islands, the MOF on Tuesday had accepted the legislators' proposal that the ministry not impose the three types of taxes on offshore island residents for five years.

The offshore island areas are the Penghu Islands, Kinmen, Matsu, Green Island and Orchid Island. If the exemptions had gone forward, it would have been the first time offshore island residents would have received preferential treatment.
In announcing its about-face on the exemptions, the MOF said it would never have consented to the proposal in the first place, had it not been pressured by the legislators.

Legislator Chu Li-lun from the ruling Kuomingtang said the MOF should have the guts to reject such unreasonable requests. If the offshore islands were tax free, they would become tax havens, legislators added.
Yen welcomed Chu's "voice of justice" and said he was happy to prevent the mistaken policy decision from being adopted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT DEFENDS MASSIVE AID PLEDGE TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday defended his pledge to donate US$300 million to the refugees from Kosovo against fierce criticism at home, saying the move will benefit Taiwan.

Taiwan has gained a better position on the international stage because of its remarkable performance in political reform and economic development, Lee said, adding that to secure this position, Taiwan should make more effort to safeguard its dignity, and should provide more humanitarian aid from an international viewpoint.
Lee, who is also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, made the statement at a regular weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee.

Wang Yu-tzeng, a member of KMT Central Standing Committee, as well as chairman of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce, backed Lee's pledge, even though it has invited criticism at a time when the government's financial situation is worsening. He also urged KMT legislators to support the humanitarian aid program.

Although the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said it has no idea where the funds for the massive amount of aid will come from, Lee told reporters after the meeting that he is confident there will be "no problem" financing the fund.
President Lee told a news conference on Monday that Taiwan will give US$300 million for the relief and rehabilitation of displaced Kosovo refugees.

The proposal came under fierce fire as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party accused Lee of seeking to further his own political agenda and his Nobel prize ambitions without considering Taiwan's financial difficulties.
The two parties suggested that Lee take NT$10 billion out of the KMT's own coffers, rather than from the pockets of the nation's taxpayers, if he wants to boost his party's image.
However, other legislators offered Lee their support, saying that Taiwan has an obligation to aid the starving and the underprivileged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT PROPOSAL SEES LONGER LEGISLATIVE TERMS

TEXT.P: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang on Wednesday passed a proposal for a series of constitutional reforms, with the most notable of which being an increase from three to four years of legislative terms.
Also under the draft package, the numbers of the National Assembly and legislative seats will be set at 300 and 225, respectively.
To encourage more women to take part in politics, the quota for female members of the National Assembly and the legislature will also be increased.

Under the terms of the proposed amendments, the functions of the National Assembly will also be expanded. When the National Assembly convenes, it will be able to invite the heads of the Legislative Yuan, the Examination Yuan, and the Control Yuan to report on their work, whereupon the National Assembly members will be able to offer suggestions on improvements.
The general public will also have the right to exercise their initiative and their power of referendum on critical national affairs, according to the draft amendment.
Another proposed major change is a 48-hour limit for police detention without charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: BCIQ HEAD LEADS INSPECTION OF BELGIAN DAIRY IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine (BCIQ) Director-General Chen Tso-chen on Wednesday oversaw a spot check of powdered milk imported from Belgium, and urged the public not to buy such products.
As the scare over Belgian dioxin-contaminated dairy and livestock products continues to spread, BCIQ's Keelung bureau has stepped up inspections of European imports.
Chen said the BCIQ will tighten inspection of all European dairy and livestock imports, and return all goods that do not pass inspection.

The Keelung bureau on Monday sent a shipment of Belgian powdered goat milk to the National Tsinghua University for laboratory tests, and on Tuesday conducted spot checks on 18 containers of European dairy imports. Most of the shipments were from France, but there was also a batch of 1,400 boxes of Belgian Ugan-1 baby formula.
Chen said it takes six to eight days to get results from the dioxin test.

Chen said the BCIQ has suggested a complete ban on European dairy imports, and said without elaborating that the continent is a "code red" zone for dioxin contamination. However, the Ministry of Economic Affairs issued only a temporary ban on Belgian imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA CHIEF RETURNS FROM EUROPEAN TOUR

TEXT.P: A trade delegation headed by China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Secretary-General Kao Yi-hsin returned to Taipei on Wednesday from a trade promotion tour of various European countries.

Upon arrival, Kao said the delegation, comprising more than 70 representatives from over 60 Taiwan companies achieved fruitful results from the tour of Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Romania, Macedonia, France, and Russia.

However, he noted that if Taiwan is to open up the eastern European market, it will have to strengthen the ability of Taiwan's trade center in Poland to distribute goods, and added that in order to do so, Taiwan must utilize the Dutch and Hungarian markets.

Kao pointed out that the present priority is to strengthen the image of Taiwan products, and to break away from competing with mainland China in the market for low-end goods. Taiwan must move towards the mid-to-high-end market if it wants to thrive in the international market, he said.

During his visit to Macedonia, Kao said he learned that the country currently imports many products through intermediary channels, which raises the prices of goods, and added that CETRA has arranged for a conference of Taiwan suppliers and Macedonian traders to discuss in detail Macedonia's import of Taiwan products.

Kao also said that in order to help the Macedonian business sector improve its trading skills, CETRA has arranged to send specialists to the Republic of China's eastern European ally to conduct short-term training programs in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FUGITIVE NABBED AT HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: An American fugitive identified as George McConnell was repatriated to the United States on Wednesday afternoon after being arrested that morning at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said McConnell, 41, has been wanted by a New York district court since 1995 on charges of having infringed upon his divorced wife's custodial rights and "abducting" their daughter abroad.
CIB officials said McConnell brought his 1-year-old daughter Miranda to Taiwan in November 1995 after the New York Northern District Court granted custody of the child to his estranged wife.

McConnell's ex-wife, Chen Ming-ju, originally only applied for a separation, but when her husband went into hiding, the court granted her a divorce. Chen, an ethnic Chinese, accused McConnell of having often beaten her during their marriage.
Prior to his arrest, McConnell had been working at a computer company in the Hsinchu industrial park.
Following the arrest, Chen managed to claim their daughter, now almost five years old, from a kindergarten in the industrial park.
Chen came to Taipei earlier this week in the company of two US police officers after the CIB informed the US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) that McConnell was living in Taiwan.

The CIB received a request from the FBI two or three months ago for assistance in locating McConnell, who was believed to have fled to Taiwan. After extensive investigations, CIB investigators found that McConnell had taken up residence here, and was working in the Hsinchu industrial park.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES PARAGUAYAN CONGRESSMEN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told a visiting delegation of Paraguayan congressmen on Wednesday that the South American state should make good use of its abundant hydro-electric resources in order to decrease its dependency on imported crude oil.

In a courtesy meeting with the congressmen led by Rep. Mario Eusebio Alegre Ortega, vice chairman of the Congress Foreign Committee, Lee also suggested that Paraguay should process its soy bean and cotton crops before exporting them, thereby adding to their value.
He offered to share Taiwan's development experience with the South American diplomatic ally, and said he looks forward to closer ties between Taipei and Asuncion.

Alegre expressed thanks to Lee for the warm welcome they received in Taiwan, and admiration for Taiwan's prosperity and rapid development. He also called for more aid from Taiwan to help his country's economic development.
Accompanying him at the meeting were his colleagues Juan Carlos Caballero, Eduabdo Gonzalez, Blas Osvaldo Brizuela Azuaga, Oscar Gonzalez Daher, and Constancio Juan Carlos Araujo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODELS OF RESTORED LOCOMOTIVE SELL LIKE HOT CAKES

TEXT.P: Every one of 1,000 miniature-scale models of the first locomotive to see service in Taiwan was sold on Wednesday, National Railway Day and the 112th anniversary of the inauguration of the island's first railway line.

Yang Peng-fei, a 74-year-old retired Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) employee who once served as captain of the 112-year-old locomotive, managed to purchase the hand-made model bearing the serial number 0001, after waiting at the Taipei Railway Station for two days and nights.
The model sale coincided with the opening of an exhibition featuring the recently restored locomotive at the Taipei Railway Station.

The steam engine, named Teng-yun or Cloud Rider, was made in Germany in 1887, purchased by then-Taiwan Governor Liu Ming-chuan, and began service on the island's first railway line running between the northern cities of Taipei and Keelung in 1891.
After 32 years of service, the Teng-yun was decommissioned in 1923 and put on display in the Taipei New Park, which was recently renamed the 2-28 Peace Park.

The Teng-yun suffered serious rust damage through years of exposure to the elements, so in order to preserve this historic treasure, the TRA in March this year invited retired craftsmen to help restore the engine to its former glory. The refurbished locomotive will be exhibited at the Taipei Railway Station for the next few weeks.

Yang said the locomotive is of great personal significance to him. "It is a symbol of my prime years and a witness to the island's progress over the past decades," he noted, adding that he is very happy to have been able to purchase the first model of the antique locomotive.

The 1,000 models were custom made by KTM, Japan's largest model train manufacturing company. Each model was sold for NT$35,000 (about US$1,067). Despite the high price, they were sold out before sunset. TRA officials said the profits from the sale will be donated to local charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HOPES TO INCREASE EXCHANGES WITH CZECH REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan told visiting Czech Republic Cultural Minister Pavel Dostal on Wednesday that both countries should increase exchanges in the arts and culture, as both peoples have long and rich cultural histories.
Lien expressed the hope that these exchanges can strengthen bilateral understanding and make for closer relations.
Lien visited the Czech Republic in June 1995, when he met with President Vaclav Havel and received an honorary doctorate from Charles University, one of the oldest seats of learning in Europe.

Lien said that his visit enabled him to gain a better understanding of the history and culture of the Czech people, and added that he has since encouraged more cooperation and exchanges between the government and private sectors of the two countries.
Dostal is the first ministerial-level Czech official to visit the Republic of China since the formation of a cabinet by its ruling Social Democratic Party a year ago.
He said he attaches great importance to his trip to Taiwan, and that he also hopes to boost cultural and artistic exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FOOD SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The ninth annual Taipei International Food Show opened Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 478 local and foreign businesses from more than 30 countries participating.

Despite the current panic caused by the dioxin contamination of Belgian livestock and dairy products, this year's show is the largest ever with over 1,300 booths and eight divisions featuring foodstuff, beverage equipment, seasoning, add-on substance and barbecue-related materials.

There are also national and foreign product sections that display foods as well as cultural aspects of such countries as Australia, France, Spain, Germany, Canada, South Korea, New Zealand and Austria.
Taiwan is well-represented by a theme section that promotes high-grade agricultural and fishery products from more than 70 island-wide farmers' associations and fishing groups.

Chairman Lin Chen-kuo of the sponsoring China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), and Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), warmly welcomed the attendees to the opening of the four-day food fair.

Many first-day visitors were attracted to the exhibition of "coffee dancing" hosted by Taiwan's five Latin American allies -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua -- to promote their coffee-related products.

However, Taiwan's recent ban on the importation of 77 livestock- and dairy-related products from Belgium and the policy to inspect all Belgian imports already circulating on the island hampered the festive atmosphere.

Business representatives from European countries such as Austria, France, Spain and Germany expressed their opinion that the threat of contamination from Belgian products is being exaggerated, adding that most health authorities, including those in Taiwan, are over-reacting.

The Europeans stressed the purity of their food exports, with Gerard Chesnel of the France Institute releasing a statement by the French government certifying that French dairy exports are not contaminated by dioxin. The statement said all French products must pass a strict examination before being exported.
The Europeans urged relevant authorities here to be more cautious in dealing with reports of dioxin contamination.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REQUIRED TO PRESENT REPORT ON TRA IMPLEMENTATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Senate on Tuesday passed an amendment to the 2000 Defense Appropriation Bill, which requires the Department of Defense and the US Pacific Command jointly prepare a report on the implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
The amendment, initiated by Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.), was passed with a unanimous vote.

The amendment demands that the Office of Net Assessment in the Office of the Secretary of Defense, jointly with the US Pacific Command, submit a report to Congress on the TRA implementation no later than 180 days after the enactment of the Defense Appropriation Bill.
The report should address the following issues:

-- A review and evaluation of the operational planning and other preparations of the US Defense Department, including the US Pacific Command, to implement the relevant sections of the TRA since its enactment in 1979; (The TRA is the US law governing relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.)

-- A set of recommendations, based on these reviews and evaluations, concerning further research and analysis that the Office of Net Assessment and the Pacific Command believe to be necessary and desirable to be performed by the National Defense University and other defense research centers.
The Senate version of the 2000 Defense Appropriation Bill was also passed on Tuesday with a vote of 93-4.

On May 27, the Senate also passed a Lott-initiated amendment to the 2000 Defense Authorization Bill, which requires the Pentagon to submit to Congress before Feb. 1 annually a report on military balance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and threats to Taiwan's security.
The Senate versions of the Defense Appropriation Bill and the Defense Authorization Bill still need integration with House versions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUANGDONG PROVINCE MURDER CASE HAS NO TAIWAN VICTIMS: SEF

TEXT.P: Despite reports from Hong Kong, no Taiwan residents were victims of the murder that occurred Monday in mainland China's Guangdong Province, Deputy Secretary General Wu Hsin-hsing of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Wednesday.
A Hong Kong-based newspaper, the Oriental Daily News, reported on Wednesday that the seven people were killed including Taiwanese, a Chinese-American and Hong Kong residents.
The murders occurred Monday on the first and second floors of a residential building located in Fanyu City, southeast of Guangdong Province's capital city of Guangzhou.

The five men and two women were reportedly shot separately. Because the killer(s) only used one bullet to end each victim's life, mainland Chinese police suspected a professional carried out the crime.
The news has caused much concern for the SEF. After asking the association of Taiwan businessmen in Fanyu City to check, it was ascertained that no one from Taiwan was among the dead, Wu said.
Except for one Chinese-American, all the other victims were from Hong Kong, Australia or mainland China, Wu quoted personnel of the association as saying.

It was learned that because the place where the murder occurred is used as a residence hall by many Taiwanese, Japanese, Hong Kong Chinese and overseas Chinese, and the place is under special protection from the police. Despite the protection, criminal elements have in the past used the building as an underground casino.
Mainland police speculated that the cause of the murder was related to a financial dispute or was a pure robbery.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM REPORTS TO LEGISLATORS ON KOSOVAR AID PLAN

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu Wednesday met with legislators who expressed dissatisfaction with the government's decision-making process in pledging US$300 million to aid Kosovar refugees and have demanded his resignation.

Hu, who had taken two days off from work due to a cold, still managed to call on each of the seven Legislative Yuan Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee (FOCAC) members who were present on Monday when the Kosovar aid was reported.

Hu invited the seven legislators as well as three other FOCAC members to the Foreign Ministry Wednesday afternoon for a closed-door conference to explain the course the government has taken in deciding the Kosovar aid.
President Lee Teng-hui announced at a news conference on Monday that Taiwan will give US$300 million to relieve the suffering and help rehabilitate Kosovar refugees.

Before Lee's announcement, Hu had reported the aid pledge to Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, FOCAC conveners Wang Hsueh-fung and Lee Hsian-jen, committee members Hung Chao-nan, Ying Chi-hung, Chen Hsueh-sheng and Yang Tso-chou, asking for their opinions.

However, during Premier Siew's welcoming banquet for Macedonia Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski Monday evening, Wang, who is a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said Hu told them the aid package would not exceed US$10 million.
The amount of US$300 million was never mentioned in the meeting, Wang said, adding that even the US$10 million was to be paid from the budget of the International Cooperation and Development Fund.

Wang said most of the FOCAC members agreed to aid Kosovar refugees, believing that it was "in the right direction." As for what the US$10 million can achieve and the reaction of the public, Wang said these issues remain to be evaluated.
The amount of aid has to be what Taiwan can afford, she said. If it turns out to be US$300 million, she would be personally opposed, and has demanded that Hu submit an explanation report.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA HIGHWAYS BUILT FOR MILITARY USE

TEXT.P: Beijing has ordered local governments in coastal provinces to ensure that new highways can double as emergency runways for military aircraft, according to a report in the June 17 issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review.

An advance copy of the report says that the Military Communications and Transportation Department of the General Logistics Department told a recent closed-door meeting that highways in the region could be pressed into service in the event of conflicts over Taiwan, the Spratly Islands or the Diaoyutai Islands.
"Especially with respect to Taiwan, the moment there is any development in the situation, these highways will have great military significance," the report quoted an official as saying.
Foreign investment -- as well as World Bank funding -- is common in highway projects in Fujian, the province facing Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait, the report says. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DARES BEIJING TO JOIN IN AIDING KOSOVO

TEXT.P: Sheu Ke-sheng, vice president of the Mainland Affairs Council dared Beijing on Wednesday to join the country in assisting the Kosovo refugees instead of accusing Taipei of fostering ulterior political motives.

Sheu denied Beijing's criticism that the Republic of China's (ROC) US$300 million donation to Kosovo is part of a ploy to mislead the international community into believing that there are either "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan".

Contrasting Beijing's bitter criticism to the warm reaction from European states and the United States, Sheu said Beijing's bitterness toward Taiwan has driven it to fit all of the ROC's international activities into its anti-Taiwan concept.
The ROC offers its aid to Kosovo out of humanitarian reasons, and will be more than pleased to see Beijing following suit, said Sheu.
He urged Beijing to stop raising political speculation on every humanitarian act by Taipei.
President Lee Teng-hui offered on Monday to donate US$300 million over three years to help the Kosovo refugees. The generous humanitarian grant has drawn applause from the West and flak from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIA SIGN SIX AGREEMENTS TO BOOST BILATERAL RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Macedonia signed six agreemetns on Wednesday to strengthen relations between the two countries.

ROC Premier Vincent Siew and Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski signed the agreements on behalf of their respective governments. Witnessing the signing ceremony were Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, National Defense Minister Tang Fei, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, as well as other ranking officials from the two countries.

The six agreements covered economic development and cooperation, the protocol on cooperation between the two foreign ministries, a US$12 million loan provided by ROC's International Cooperation Development Fund for Macedonia's private sector, the avoidance of double taxation, customs cooperation and investment guarantees.

Siew said the agreement on economic development and cooperation is only the beginning of ROC-Macedonian cooperation, adding that the ROC is helping to stabilize the Macedonian economy with the hope its economy is invigorated soon.
Siew said that he learned that the Macedonian people are friendly, diligent and well-educated, which he considered to be one of the biggest assets of the Balkan country.
The geographic location of Macedonia also provides a suitable base for Taiwan businessmen wanting to making inroads into Europe, Siew said.
The premier said that the ROC is capable and willing to reciprocate the international community by shouldering its responsibility as a member of the global village.
"The ROC is happy to have the respect and friendship of Macedonia, and is willing to contribute to the rebuilding of Macedonia and peace in the Balkans," Siew said.

Georgievski said that he has felt "pleasant" every day since his arrival on Sunday. He appreciated the ROC for pledging to help rebuild his country, adding that ROC President Lee Teng-hui's announcement of an aid package of US$300 million to Kosovar refugees was a "very humanistic deed."

He said that since the two countries established diplomatic relations in Jan. 27, they have had a "fruitful and positive" engagement, and he expressed his belief that both sides would fulfill their part of the agreements to lay a solid foundation of friendship.

Siew and Georgievski held a working lunch Wednesday, during which both sides promised to push for a rapid implementation of the agreements and that in the future, both sides will sign a US$2 million stock option investment agreement that covers investment in Macedonian enterprises.

In addition to the signing of the six agreements, ROC National Defense Minister Tang Fei also donated an UH--IH helicopter and the necessary accessory equipment to help the Macedonia officers patrol its border.

Computer producer Umax Data Systems donated 500 computers and 200 scanners worth US$5 million to Macedonian primary and middle schools to be used in computer courses. Domestic enterprises also donated 100 wheelchairs to the Balkan country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FGP SOLICITING MAINLAND HELP TO DISPOSE OF TOXIC WASTES

TEXT.P: The head of a Taipei-based petrochemical giant said on Wednesday that he is soliciting assistance from the mainland to help permanently dispose of the toxic waste currently being stored at Kaohsiung Harbor, southern Taiwan.

Y. C. Wang, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), said the mercury-laced waste had passed the review by the appropriate authorities in the United States, but due to non-professional factors, the industrial waste was not allowed to leave Taiwan for transshipment to the US as was originally planned.
Under the circumstance, Wang said that FPG has had to solicit assistance from the mainland through other channels.

But Wang said that a recent report that FPG would soon ship the waste to Xiamen, Fujian province on the coast of the mainland was erroneous. Wang said the deal with Xiamen has not been finalized and that Xiamen is only one of several destinations solicited by FPG.
Wang also expressed his disappointment over the government's failure to lending a helping hand to FPG over the waste disposal issue.

The controversial waste was first shipped from a FPG plant in Kaohsiung late last year to the southern coastal town of Sihanoukville in Cambodia, where it was improperly stored, causing panic and chaos among the town's residents.
In early April, FPG apologized to Cambodia for the unrest among its residents, and shipped the waste in 30 containers back to Taiwan for temporary storage.
Kaohsiung Harbor authorities allowed the storage of the waste on the condition that FPG transship it to another country before June 7. The date has since been extended 60 days.

Wang also divulged that Xiamen is actively developing nickel hydrogen and nickel zinc as well as lithium batteries. Therefore, FPG is considering introducing related technology so that the Nan Ya Plastic under FPG will be able to produce the products in Taiwan for the needs of FPG's electric cars, mobile phones, and notebook computers.

Wang also revealed that the FPG's affiliated enterprise Chang Gung Memorial Hospital is interested in cooperating with mainland hospitals to transfer technology related to Chinese medicine to aid research and development of similar products in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW TO RECIPROCATE VISIT TO MACEDONIA IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Premier Vincent Siew told a group of reporters on Wednesday that he has accepted an invitation to visit Macedonia sometime in late summer.
In a ceremony marking the signing of six pacts with visiting Macedonian Premier Ljubco Georgievske earlier in the day, Georgievske personally extended the invitation to him, said Siew.

Jason Hu, minister of foreign affairs, said it would be an appropriate time fo Siew to visit Macedonia between Aug. 5 and Aug. 15 before the ruling Kuomintang, of which Siew is a leader, holds its national congress late August.
Details of Siew's possible journey still has to be worked out, said Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BANKS IN TAIWAN WILL BE GIVEN NATIONAL TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Wednesday that foreign banks in Taiwan will be able to enjoy national treatment as required by the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the future.
He made the remarks while speaking at a ceremony marking the opening of the Chichien branch of the London-based Standard Chartered Bank.

Chiu said that since the 1994 revision of Taiwan's banking regulations, Taiwan has been marching toward financial liberation and globalization, providing a good chance for foreign banks to enter the Taiwan market.
In the future, the minister said, Taiwan will offer national treatment for foreign banks in Taiwan to comply with WTO rules.
The Standard Chartered Bank is among the top five foreign banks in Taiwan. Its branches in Taipei and Kaohsiung were set up in 1985 and 1990 respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN PRAISES MACEDONIA'S CONTRIBUTION TO BALKAN PEACE

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Vice President Lien Chan on Wednesday praised Macedonia's contribution to peace efforts in the Balkans by taking in refugees from Kosovo.
Speaking at a dinner party he hosted in honor of visiting Macedonia Premier Ljubco Georgievski, Lien lauded the significant role Macedonia has played during the Kosovo crisis.
Lien said Macedonia's peace efforts have earned worldwide respect.

In acknowledging the ongoing international efforts to settle the Kosovo crisis, Lien said the most effective way to snuff out disputes and conflicts "is to help the concerned states develop their economies."
That is the reasoning behind the Republic of China's offer of US$300 to aid Kosovar refugees, said Lien.

Lien and Georgievski talked about 20 minutes before the dinner party. Georgievski expressed his thanks to the ROC for the generous donation to Kosovo and called for Taiwan investment in Macedonia, according to Lien's aides.
Earlier the day, Georgievski visited the Council of Agriculture, courting Taiwan investment in his country's chicken and pig farming sector.
Georgievski arrived in Taipei on June 6 for a six day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR SOONG GIVES SPEECH IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong said in Tokyo on Wednesday that Taiwan's continued prosperity will benefit other Asia-Pacific countries, especially Japan and the United States.
Soong made the remarks while giving a speech on "Sharing a common future -- Taiwan-Japan relations in the 21st century" at Tokyo's Josui Kaikan Building.
Soong arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday at the invitation of the Japan alumni association of the University of California-Berkeley. Soong is also an alumnus of the university.
In the speech given in English, Soong said that Taiwan and Japan share many common aspects, and, therefore, the two countries should cooperate to create mutual benefits, especially economic benefits.

The former Taiwan governor, who intends to run in next spring's presidential election, said that during his recent tour around the nation he discovered that nobody in Taiwan wants to live under communist rule, and that nobody wants to wage a war against mainland China.
He said that he believes Taiwan will maintain the existing status quo, and is ready to engage in constructive dialogue with Beijing through a gradual formula.
Taiwan will also fulfill its international and regional responsibilities commensurate with its economic power and strategic importance, he added.

On Thursday, Soong will confer with Lower House member Ichiro Ozawa, head of the Japan Liberal Party, and attend a welcoming dinner. On Friday, he will address a symposium on economic and security affairs.
A Taipei news report said that the ruling Kuomintang is considering Soong as the running mate of Vice President Lien Chan, the front-running KMT presidential candidate.
When asked to comment on the report, Soong said that he was not in a position to comment, being abroad and not having a clear understanding of the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui called for forward-looking view of Taiwan's international role.
The China Times:
The ruling Kuomintang unveiled its package for constitutional amendments.
The United Daily News:
Housing rentals and child-rearing spending can be deducted from income tax returns.
The Liberty Times:
Whether drug abusers can be exempted from criminal sentences caused hot debate.
The Commons Daily:
The US Senate on Tuesday passed an amendment to the 2000 Defense Appropriation Bill requiring the Pentagon to submit a report on the implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act.
The China Post:
Asia jittery over dioxin food scare.
The Taiwan News:
Belgrade says police withdrawn while generals discuss peace deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 10, or the 27th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1190: Frederick I, known as "Frederick Barbarossa," Holy Roman emperor and king of Germany and Italy who spearheaded the Third Crusade, is drowned in the Saleph River in Cilicia (now in Turkey) on his way to the Holy Land.
1793: The Jardin des Plantes, the first public zoological garden, opens in Paris.
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy, and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1905: China's Ching court starts minting silver coins prior to adopting a silver dollar system.
1922: Judy Garland, the American singer and actress, is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," and "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1924: Antonio Gaudi y Cornet, the Italian socialist leader, is assassinated by Benito Mussolini's Fascists.
1926: Korean communists agitate people in Seoul to hold anti-Japanese demonstrations.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: US Marines invade the Ryukyus, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors, and makes a 200 percent expansion of its territory.
1970: The ROC and the Republic of the Philippines sign a cultural agreement in Manila.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern China, defects at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1990: Czechoslovakian democrats win in the country's first genuine elections for 40 years, with Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum and its Slovak allies winning more than 170 of the 300 seats.
1990: Alberto Fujimori, of Japanese ancestry, beats Mario Vargas Llosa to win Peru's presidential election.
1990: John Pointdexter, former US National Security Adviser, is sentenced to six months in prison for his role in the Iran-Contra affair.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for infringement of copyright.
1993: The United States announces it will send 300 troops to Macedonia to help the 700 Scandinavian UN troops already there to stabilize the region.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SEND MARKETING EXPERTS TO MACEDONIA TO CONDUCT RESEARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is to dispatch specialists to Macedonia to engage in short-term market research aimed at exploring bilateral trade and investment opportunities between the two allies.

CETRA Secretary-General Kao Yi-hsin revealed the plan at a trade workshop in Taipei, in which 19 Macedonian businesses were introduced to representatives of more than 100 local companies. The workshop was intended to inspire mutual trade and cooperation.

Kao, who returned from a European tour Monday, said that during his visit to Macedonia, he had not sensed a war-like atmosphere, although battles were rampant in neighboring Kosovo. Taiwan businesses may enter the Macedonian market as soon as a cease fire is signed, Kao said.

Kao indicated that the eastern European country is suffering from high prices due to the conflict in Kosovo, but he said Taiwan investors can benefit by building commodity stores or small supermarkets there.

Kao said that in addition to the short-term market research program, CETRA is also planning to send a senior executive to Macedonia as a consultant to aid in efforts to promote Taipei-Skopje trade and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES CHALLENGE 8,000-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.5 percent higher Thursday on heavy buying in the financial sector, but failed to reach the psychological 8,000-point level because of a slowdown in the trading of electronics shares at the end of the session.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 39.05 points, ending the day at 7,996.76 points.

A total of 370.5 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$198.10 billion (US$6.09 billion), up from the previous session's NT$186.30 billion. Tuesday's turnover was the highest seen this year.
Among the eight major stock categories, financial stocks posted the largest gains of the day, rising 2.9 percent. Textile issues also went up 0.4 percent.

As the majority of funds surged into the financial sector, the six other categories registered losses, with foodstuff shares posting the largest loss, falling 1.2 percent. They were followed by paper and pulp stocks, which fell 1.1 percent.
Cement shares and plastics and chemical stocks both dropped 0.5 percent, construction issues lost 0.4 percent and the electronics sector went down 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.48 points, closing the day at 181.32 points, with a NT$10.44 billion turnover.
Meanwhile, TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June rose 35 points to close at 7,960 points, with 2,548 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July gained 33 points to close at 7,972 points, while those for September advanced 50 points to 7,970. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 1,247 and 46, respectively.
December futures soared 94 points to close at 8,025 points, with 14 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,925 points for June, 7,939 points for July, 7,920 points for September, 7,931 points for December and 7,950 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MAJOR INDONESIAN PARTIES QUESTION ELECTION RESULTS

TEXT.P: Three of Indonesia's top political parties are questioning the early results of June 7's elections after polling less than they had expected, with one even threatening to set up an alternative government, according to the Australian Financial Review on Thursday.
The Review's Asia-Pacific editor Peter Hartcher reported the ruling Golkar, the PKB or National Awakening Party and PAN or National Mandate Party, have questioned the early results of the election.

Golkar chairman Akbar Tandjung said the PDI-P's lead seemed excessive and he would ask the Electoral Commission for clarification. "Our own vote-counting, too, shows PDI-P has obtained more than Golkar ... but the gap is simply too far," he said. Golkar has so far won almost 16 percent of the vote.
PAN chairman Amien Rais has suggested that his party could be the victim of a conspiracy as the early results showed the Islamic party got only 6.1 percent of the vote among the major parties.

PKB leader Abdurranhman Wahid said he was concerned at reports of vote-rigging and would consider setting up an alternative emergency government if the suspicions were confirmed. PKB polled more than 22 percent of the vote.
Only PDI-P's leader Megawati Sukarnoputri has so far not questioned the results, as the main opposition party received about 40 percent of all votes in the early tally.
But only three percent of the vote was counted by Wednesday, raising serious questions about the success of Indonesia's first free election and democratic experiment, the daily reported.

International election observers from the US, Europe and Australia have also voiced their concerns at the slow pace of the counting in Indonesia's national elections, saying prolonged delays could arouse suspicions of irregularities in vote tallying across the country, according to a report by the Australian on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN EXPERTS TO GATHER WAR CRIME EVIDENCE IN KOSOVO

TEXT.P: With a Kosovo peace deal in sight, Canada said Wednesday it will send a team of forensic experts to the area to gather war crime evidence.
The team will be made up of eight Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) investigators, all experts in crime scene examination.
RCMP Chief Superintendent Peter Miller said the team will spend up to four months looking for evidence of alleged atrocities.
Miller noted the RCMP has experience working on these types of investigations in places such as Bosnia and Rwanda.

He admitted one of the problems investigators might encounter is an attempt by Yugoslav forces to destroy evidence. "This is something that has happened in the past in other similar areas. It's something that we'll have to deal with. It's important that our people get in there once the area has been secured."
The RCMP team will give its evidence to the international tribunal investigating war crimes in Yugoslavia. The tribunal will try to prosecute the people responsible for any atrocities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOLD INDUSTRY FACING HARD TIME AS BULLION PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Australia's gold exports, the third largest in the world, are shrinking as a result of the continuing fall of global bullion prices, mainly due to sales by central banks, according to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural Resources and Economics (ABARE).
The ABARE reported gold export revenue in the first quarter of this year plunged 36 percent to only A$1.2 billion (US$800 million) from the same period last year.

ABARE officials attributed the plunge in exports to a dive in global gold prices ahead of the planned July 6 sale of the first 25-tonne tranche by the British Treasury of its gold reserves. Altogether Britain is set to sell more than half of its 715 tons of stockpiled gold.
Gold price closed at US$262.50 per ounce on Wednesday and are expected to further drop to between US$240 and US$250 in the months ahead, market analysts predicted.
Australia, the world's third largest gold producer, last year produced about 310 tons. The figure will drop below 300 tons this year, analysts estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILK CAN REPAIR EARLY TOOTH DECAY: AUST. SCIENTIST

TEXT.P: An Australian scientist has discovered that milk can repair early tooth decay, the Australian reported on Thursday.

The daily reported Professor Eric Reynolds of the School of Dental Science at Melbourne University has discovered that a peptide in milk that coats calcium and phosphate on teeth has led to world's first food additive that can repair early tooth decay.
The substance -- patented worldwide under the name "Recaldent" after 15 years of research -- will be added to everything from mouthwash to chewing gum.
The daily quoted Reynolds as saying, "We were very pleasantly surprised -- we actually got better results from the chewing gum in clinical trials than we got from mouthwash."
He said scientists have known for decades that milk carries calcium and phosphate, but they did not apply it to the prevention of tooth decay.

"It has been anecdotal and an old wives' tale, but there's really been no science to substantiate it up until now," he said. "(Recaldent) is certainly the first product which (by itself) can be applied to repair teeth," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUXEMBOURG LEADS WORLD IN STANDARD OF LIVING

TEXT.P: Luxembourg led other countries in terms of living standards and purchasing power, with the United States in second, Japan fifth, Australia and Germany tied at 11th, according to the Australian on Thursday.

The daily quoting a study of 52 countries by the Organization for Economic Cooperation of Development (OECD) ranked Luxembourg first in living standards -- per capita incomes adjusted to take account of local prices from a wide range of goods and services -- 14 percent above the United States, which ranked second.

Ranking third was Norway, followed by Switzerland, Japan, Iceland, Denmark, Canada, Belgium and Austria. Australia and Germany were tied at 11th; followed by the Netherlands, France, Italy, Sweden, the UK, Finland, Ireland and New Zealand, among OECD member countries.
The study focused mainly on Europe and North America and did not include other newly industrialized countries such as Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and Malaysia, according to the OECD.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S WINE EXPORTS SEEN HITTING ALL-TIME HIGH IN 1999

TEXT.P: Australia's wine exports, buoyed by rising demand in Britain, the US and Germany, are expected to hit a record high of A$1 billion (US$667 million) in the early second half of this year resulting in much higher annual sales than previously expected, the Australian reported on Thursday.
The daily reported wine exports, especially red wine, already totaled A$961 (US$641) million by May 31 of this year, up 22 percent from the same period last year.
The volume of wine exports also reached a record 210 million liters, up 11 percent during the same period, the daily reported.
The five biggest importers of Australian wine are Britain, the US, New Zealand, Canada and Germany, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS MACEDONIAN PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday reaffirmed the Republic of China's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperative programs with Macedonia.
Lee made the reaffirmation while meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who is currently on a six-day official visit here.
Noting that Macedonia has good development potential, Lee said the ROC is more than willing to share its developmental experience with Macedonia to help the Balkan state revitalize its economy.
Lee said the ROC has drafted concrete measures to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation with Macedonia since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.

"We have been waiting for your arrival to discuss some details concerning those programs," Lee told the Macedonian prime minister, adding he believes that many exchange and cooperative programs can into practice after Georgievski's visit.
Lee went on to say that many Macedonian agricultural products, including red wine, cotton and tobacco leaves, have great market potential in Taiwan.
On the other hand, Lee said, Taiwan has rich experience in vocational training. "We have many vocational training centers which can help train skilled workers for Macedonia," he said.
Moreover, Lee said the ROC is willing to assist Macedonia in setting up export processing zone and encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in Macedonia.
Lee further said the ROC, as a member of the international community, will provide US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees and will help them rebuild their war-torn homeland.

"We believe that our aid program to Kosovo will also benefit Macedonia because of their geographical proximity," Lee explained. Macedonia has been troubled by the influx of more than 200,000 ethnic Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

For his part, Georgievski said he originally planned to visit Taiwan shortly after the two countries established diplomatic relations. "However, the outbreak of the Kosovo crisis forced me to postpone my Taiwan visit."
Georgievski told President Lee that Yugoslavia already signed a peace agreement with NATO. "I believe that the Balkan region will soon regain peace and stability."

The Macedonian prime minister expressed his gratitude for Lee's concern about the development of cooperative ties between the ROC and his country. "I earnestly hope that bilateral exchanges and cooperation in various fields will soon get started."

Georgievski further said the ROC's US$300 million humanitarian aid to Kosovars has won worldwide recognition. "We believe that the ROC's aid package will contribute much to the Balkan's peace and stability," he added.
Georgievski told President Lee that the Macedonian Embassy in Taipei already became operational on Wednesday to facilitate bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
The 33-year-old Macedonian prime minister, heading a 59-member delegation of senior officials and business executives, arrived in Taipei on Sunday for his first visit to Taiwan.
Georgievski signed six agreements with ROC Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday to reinforce bilateral trade, investment and cooperation in various fields.

Georgievski personally chaired a seminar on Tuesday to attract Taiwan investors. And another trade seminar was held on Thursday, with the participation of Macedonian entrepreneurs and their Taiwan counterparts.

Senior executives from more than 100 Taiwan companies in banking services, computer, textile, food processing, insurance and shoemaking industries took part in Thursday's forum to explore possible trade deals or joint-venture projects.
As Macedonia can serve as a springboard to tap the vast European market, many Taiwan entrepreneurs have shown keen interest in setting up footholds or launching investment projects there.
