DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SURVEY ON TAINAN VOTERS SHOWS CHEN SHUI-BIAN IN LEAD

TEXT.P: A public poll of Tainan County voters in southern Taiwan shows former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian leading among presidential hopefuls.

The survey, conducted by the Focus Survey Research Co. and commissioned by Global Braodcasting Co., shows Chen leading in Tainan, his hometown. He rated higher than other presidential hopefuls in terms of his resolve to carry out reforms and his ability.

But his lead over another presidential hopeful, James Soong, was not very large, while Vice President Lien Chan received positive marks for his perceived ability to maintain national security and stability.

In a two-way election between the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the DPP's Chen would receive 53.6 percent of the vote, while the KMT's Lien would receive 23.4 percent.

But if former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong breaks ranks with the KMT and runs independently, Chen would capture only 34.7 percent of the vote, while Soong would receive 30.2 percent and Lien, 12.2 percent.
If former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang throws down the gauntlet and enters the race, the numbers would change considerably.
Support for Soong would drop to 24.1 percent, while Chen's support would increase to 39.5 percent, and Lien's would rise to 14.2 percent, suggesting Tainan voters would close ranks behind Chen.
Some 83.1 percent of the polled said that they would not be influenced by President Lee Teng-hui's campaigning for Lien. Two percent said they would be influenced and 6.7 percent said they might be.

As for the personal traits of the four presidential hopefuls, Chen led Soong 29.2 percent to 28.9 percent in terms of worthiness of the public trust. On that point, 12.7 percent of respondents supported Lien and 1 percent supported Hsu.

On the question of who would be most resolute in carrying out reforms and who is most capable of doing the job, Chen received support from 48.8 percent of respondents, while support for Soong, Lien and Hsu was at 12.4 percent, 7.1 percent and 1.2 percent, respectively.

On the issue of national stability and security, Tainan voters are more in favor of Lien, who received support from 24.5 percent of respondents, while Chen received support from 17 percent; Soong, 16 percent; and Hsu, 0.3 percent.
Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, in assessing the survey, said that it is not surprising that Chen received a high percentage of support in his hometown.
Professor Lin Chia-lung of National Chung Cheng University said that Tainan County is the fifth city or county that has conducted such a survey.
Lin said that in addition to being the hometown candidate, Chen's strong showing stems from the fact that Tainan county has traditionally identified with the DPP.
The survey was conducted June 3-4, with 1,031 effective samples, and it had a margin of error of 3.05 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD TO VISIT GREECE, MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang will visit Greece and Macedonia in July, his aides said Thursday.
Hsu, who has advocated an end to discussions on both Taiwan's independence and unification with mainland China, said he is planning to leave for Athens, Greece, on July 7.
Hsu has invited writers, photographers, historians and political scholars to go with him.
Hsu is expected to write about his weeklong trip, which will include a tour of Macedonia.
Though President Lee Teng-hui's announcement of US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees has received a mixed reaction at home, Hsu has been a staunch supporter of the plan.

Hsu said that he will visit Kosovar refugee camps near Skopje, the capital of Macedonia, to learn more about the relief operations and about the international community's means of dealing with the refugee problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR ROSE TO FOUR-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.038 against the greenback on the Taipei market Thursday as active inflow of foreign capital continues.
The local currency opened at 32.488 and fluctuated between 32.50 and 32.459 before closing at 32.49 against the US dollar, the highest level over the past four months.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$702.5 million. Trade volume totaled US$3.58 billion over the past four trading sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER DIOXIN SCARE

TEXT.P: Concerned about the dioxin-contaminated Belgian dairy products, Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday instructed authorities to map out efficient measure to protect local consumers.
Siew issued the order after hearing briefings from Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Deputy Director-General Chang Hung-jen of the Department of Health.

Chang's report indicated that the department has confirmed that Belgian meat, egg-based products and dairy products are suspected of being contaminated. Of those products, however, Taiwan imports only dairy items from Belgium, Chang said.

Stores and supermarkets around the island have been instructed to remove from their shelves products suspected of being contaminated, and certification experts at National Tsinghua University have been mobilized to analyze the products.

Wang reported that his ministry is convening a supra-governmental meeting Thursday afternoon, in which farm, trade, health and quarantine officials will discuss whether to expand bans on Belgian imports.

Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu told reporters that the ban may be expanded to include Belgian chocolates, cakes, cookies, powdered infant milk formula and other food items, in addition to the 77 food types -- ranging from egg-based and dairy goods to animal fat and feed -- already on the list.
More than 20 types of food from Belgium could be added to the list, Lin said.
Asked whether the ban would be expanded to include products from other European countries, Lin answered that restrictions would be based only on scientific evidence of signs of toxic contamination.

The Taiwan ban came soon after a decision by European leaders to destroy chicken- and egg-based foodstuffs originating from Belgium. The crackdown was spurred by the discovery that 400 poultry farms around Belgium may have used dioxin-contaminated feed.
Belgium has said that the contaminated feed may have gone to 500 pig breeders, while Belgian cattle are now being tested as well.

So far, the United States has restricted all imports of poultry products and pork from European countries, while members of the European Union have banned imports of Belgian chickens, eggs, pork and beef. Singapore has banned imports of all kinds of poultry and livestock products from European countries, according to an official report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANS IMPORT OF 41 MORE BELGIAN FOOD ITEMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Thursday expanded its ban on Belgian imports to include 41 additional food items, bringing to 101 the total number of products to be banned in the wake of a dioxin contamination scare.

The items added to the list include cookies, cakes, candies, chocolates and powdered infant milk formula produced in Belgium, where animal feed that went to livestock breeders was found to be contaminated with dioxin.

The decision was announced in a supra-governmental meeting at the Ministry of Economics Affairs building Thursday afternoon, in which government officials representing various areas, including the economy, agriculture, health, trade and quarantine centers, discussed whether to expand the ban on Belgian imports.

It was also decided at the meeting that all similar products originating from Belgium's neighbors, namely Holland and France, can be imported to Taiwan only when accompanied by governmental certification that they are not contaminated.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR MEETS FORMER JAPANESE PRIME MINISTERS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two former Japanese prime ministers Tsutomu Hata and Toshiki Kaifu paid visits to former Taiwan Governor James Soong at his hotel on Thursday for wide-ranging talks.
As Soong has consistently topped other presidential hopefuls in Taiwan's public opinion polls, his current visit has drawn much attention in the Japanese political and journalistic communities.

The unprecedented moves by two Japanese former prime ministers to meet Soong at his hotel indicate that the Japanese political community is very concerned or curious who will be Taiwan's next president.
Soong said after his one-hour talks with Hata that they have exchanged views on a number of issues concerning relations between Taiwan and Japan.
Soong said he has briefed Hata on Taiwan's determination to continue promoting economic reform and political democratization as well as further reinforcing exchanges with Japan.
"For his part, Hata expressed his views on the current situation and future development directions in Japan and the entire East Asia," Soong said.
Soong said he has told Hata that Taiwan and Japan should work closely to push mainland China to move toward democracy and peaceful evolution in order to maintain regional stability and prosperity.
This was the first meeting between Soong and Hata, who is now secretary-general of Japan's largest opposition Democratic Party.
Around noon, former Japanese Prime Minister Kaifu arrived at the Prince Hotel in downtown Tokyo where Soong is staying.

Kaifu, who is now the top adviser to the Liberal Party, told a group of Taiwan journalists that he has not had any contact with Taiwan's political figures since he became Japanese prime minister in the late 1980s.
"This is my first encounter with Soong," Kaifu said, adding that he would exchange views with Soong on matters of mutual concern.
Soong, Kaifu and several of their friends lunched together at the hotel.
In the afternoon, Soong also met with Ichiro Ozawa, chairman of the Liberal Party, which forms a ruling coalition with the largest Liberal Democratic Party.
Soong attended a welcoming party in the evening, which brought together with some 60 influential figures in four major Japanese parties and elite members in the business and academic communities.
Meanwhile, the Sankei Shimbun published an interview with Soong on Thursday, in which Soong showed an active attitude toward joining Taiwan's next presidential election, scheduled for March 2000.

Soong said in the interview, conducted in Tokyo on Wednesday, that he will make a final decision at an appropriate on whether he will run in next year's presidential election. "Public expectations will be my top concern in mulling the issue," he added.

Asked if he is likely to serve as Vice President Lien Chan's running mate, Soong said public opinion polls show that it is already too late to consider the possibility of a Lien-Soong presidential ticket.
At the moment, Soong said he has no intention to break ranks with the ruling Kuomintang to run in the presidential election as an independent.
Nevertheless, Soong said he earnestly hopes that the KMT will nominate the person most favored by the general public as its standard bearer.

Soong told the major Japanese economic daily that the core purposes of his current Japan visit are to exchange views with Japanese politicians on the promotion of cooperation between the two countries and to listen to their opinions about Taiwan-Japan relations.

Asked what will be his top priority if he is elected president, Soong said improving relations with mainland China, revitalizing the economy, reinforcing the democratic system and reducing the crime rate will be his priority agenda.

Touching on speculation about his rift with ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, Soong said Lee has made outstanding contributions to the Republic of China on Taiwan, particularly in democratic reforms. Soong further said he shares same views with Lee on many issues related to Taiwan-mainland China relations.
Soong arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday for a five-day visit, following his trips to the Philippines and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MULLS INTRODUCING CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICAN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Chairman Kao Chin-yen of the Chinese National Federation of Industries said on Wednesday that the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) are pondering the feasibility of introducing labor from Taiwan's Central and South American allies.

Kao Chin-yen, who is also the CEO of the President Group, said during a conference attended by CLA chairman Chan Hou-sheng and the heads of various industry groups, that the policy would be implemented for diplomatic reasons.

Chan confirmed that allied countries' labor might be introduced, but stressed that the overall number of foreign laborers in Taiwan, including current workers from Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Vietnam would out surpass 270,000.

During the conference, the issue of insufficient domestic labor was raised again. Industrial leaders requested that workers from the Central and South America be excluded from the limit of 270,000 in order to meet current industrial demand.

Meanwhile, Chan, in facing strong complaints from industrialists over insufficient workers, said the CLA will not reduce the foreign labor quota assigned to the "3K industry", if the CLA finds a labor problem exists.
Chan's remarks overturned his previous stance calling for a reduction of the construction and manufacturing industries quota by 10 percent annually.
The "3K industry" refers to jobs that are exhausted, out of hardship or danger, with the working environment unpleasant and dirty.

Wen the labor shortage problem continues, the unemployment declines, the CLA, with the support of the general public, will distribute foreign labor quota to industries that in the past were not allowed to hire foreign laborers, Chan added.
Chan also backed the federation's viewpoint that foreign laborers should not become the scapegoats of unemployed aboriginal people.
Foreign labor policy is often a target of politicians who use it as an excuse to oppose introducing foreign workers, Chan added. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MARCH IN PROTEST OVER KOSOVAR AID PLEDGE

TEXT.P: Hundreds of wrought-up opposition New Party (NP) members and supporters Thursday marched to the Presidential Office in protest over President Lee Teng-hui's aid pledge to Kosovo, with the march ending in a slight skirmish with police.

In protest over President Lee's announcement on Monday of a US$300 million (approximately NT$100 billion) aid package to Kosovar refugees, around 400 NP supporters, led by more than 20 NP legislators, National Assembly (NA) deputies and Taipei City councilors, marched toward the Presidential Office Thursday morning.

NP Legislative Yuan Caucus Convener Lee Ching-hua; Legislators Cheng Lung-shui, Ying Chi-hung and Lai Shi-pao; NA Convener Chin Chi-hua; and Taipei City Council Vice Convener Wei Yi-lung said they were not opposed to aiding Kosovar refugees.
But they object to the amount of the proposed aid package and the means by which the decision to offer the aid was made, they said.

They said that with the worsening of Taiwan's economy, numerous underprivileged people are in dire need of government help, but Lee has ignored the legal system and announced the massive aid package to aid Kosovo, which is not an ally of the Republic of China.
The NP urged Lee not to conduct "checkbook diplomacy" and asked Lee to spread his charity among his own people before helping others.

The military police had set up blockades in front of the Presidential Office before the protesters arrived. It was decided that the NP could send one legislator, eight NA deputies and one Taipei City councilor into the building to hand in their protest letter.
But a slight skirmish erupted after military police refused to remove the blockades and let the representatives enter through the front entrance.

In the end, Director-General Fann-Jiang Chun-sheng of the Department of Public Affairs came out to receive the 10 NP members, as their demand to see the presidential secretary-general or deputy secretary-general went unanswered.

Since the protest group was unable to meet with Lee, the representatives read aloud their protest letter in the Presidential Office, asking Lee to understand "what the people wants" and not to "do whatever he wants."
The NP also demanded that the amount of the Kosovar aid be reduced to NT$300 million and that the procedure used to determine whether the aid should be offered be explained to the public.

NP National Assembly Vice Convener Huang Hung-chun said that, as the 10 representatives were all the people's representatives, it was unacceptable that the military police should prevent the "guests" from seeing the president.
The NP has decided that Lee will be given the same treatment when he attends the National Assembly for his national conditions report, Huang said.

In addition to the morning's protest, the NP has made a motion requesting Premier Vincent Siew report at the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday. The party has also made a motion to counterbalance the president's power through constitutional amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7.7 PERCENT PASS ENGLISH TEACHER PROFICIENCY TEST

TEXT.P: Of the 45,539 people who took in March a qualifying exam to teach English in elementary schools, a total of 3,536 people, or 7.7 percent of all test takers, passed the exam, sources from the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.
Two-thirds of those who passed the exam have lived in English-speaking countries, and one-fourth have degrees from foreign universities, sources said.
Test results will be sent out Thursday, and the results can be viewed online at http://www.lttc.ntu.edu.tw.
Those who passed the exam will receive, starting later this month, a 360-hour training program, and those who are not accredited teachers are required to take classes to receive accreditation.
Partial exemption from the training program will be given to the test takers with the highest scores, MOE officials said.
Of the 3,536 who passed the qualifying exam, 60 percent hold bachelor's degrees, 32 percent hold master's degrees and 17 have Ph.D.s.
More than 60 percent have lived or studied abroad, while a significant number were either born abroad or went abroad to study as children.

Many of the 45,539 people who took the March 21 qualifying exam were attracted to the profession because of the benefits teachers receive, such as job security, long summer and winter vacations, and income tax exemptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MILITARY OVERFLIGHTS POSE NO THREAT TO TAIWAN: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Thursday that frequent US military overflights pose no threat to Taiwan's national security.
The ministry was responding to criticism by Legislator Chen Hsueh-sheng (KMT-Taipei) that US military aircraft fly through the Republic of China's airspace too often.
Chen said at a news conference that US military aircraft flew through Taiwan's airspace a total of 112 times between 1998 and April 1999.
"This is a record rarely seen elsewhere in the world," Chen claimed, adding he does not think that the frequent US military overflights are all really "innocent passages."
Chen demanded that the MND give an immediate explanation of the issue.

In response, the MND said US military authorities usually apply beforehand when their aircraft want to fly through Taiwan's flight information zone, applying through the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, a semi-official body founded by the ROC to handle exchanges with the United States in the absence of official ties.

After receiving the application, the MND inspects the flight route and time. "MND inspections show that US military aircraft have consistently flown through our airspace via international flight routes," said a ministry official.
According to international regulations, the official said, the ROC is obligated to provide necessary flight services and controls.

Moreover, the official said, US military overflights are mainly for personnel transport. "Their missions pose no threat to our national security," the official stressed, adding that in view of longstanding cordial relations between Taiwan and the United States, the MND has no reason to reject US overflight applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN COMMENDS TAIWAN'S OFFER TO AID KOSOVAR REFUGEES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 10 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Tom Buley, chairman of the Committee on Commerce of the US House of Representatives, on Wednesday praised Taiwan's decision to provide US$300 million to help Kosovar refugees return to their homes.

In his remarks, which have been entered into the congressional records, Buley said that "President Lee and the people of the Republic of China should be commended for their commitment to international peace and stability."
He pointed out that "The Republic of China, as a member of the international community, has always been very active in world affairs."
"This is yet another example of the Republic of China being an active and positive international partner with the United States in international affairs," Buley added.
The ROC's offer was announced by President Lee Teng-hui on June 7, and Buley said that the aid will consist of:
-- Emergency support with food, shelter, medical care and education for the Kosovar refugees who are currently living in exile countries neighboring Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province.
-- Short-term accommodation for some of the refugees in Taiwan, with opportunities for job training in order to better equip them for the restoration of their homeland upon their return.
-- Support for the rehabilitation of Kosovo in coordination with international recovery programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES DRAFT PACT ON VIETNAMESE LABORERS

TEXT.P: A draft agreement for the importation of Vietnam laborers between the Tapei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Vietnam and the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office (VECO) in Taipei was approved in a Cabinet meeting on Thursday.
Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Chan Hou-sheng said the agreement was signed by TECO representative in Vietnam Hu Chia-chi, and VECO's Taipei representative Dang Dinh Luu in Hanoi on May 6.

Under the terms of the labor accord, Taipei will decide the number of Vietnam laborers allowed into Taiwan and the type of work they will do, while the Vietnamese side will offer concrete measures guaranteeing the laborers' compliance with Republic of China laws and their employment contracts.

Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen echoed Chan's words at a press conference following the meeting, saying that the agreement will strengthen Vietnam's responsibilities in addition to safeguarding against the problem of absconding laborers.

Chen said the Vietnamese government will dispatch a representative to Taiwan to tie up the loose ends concerning the deal, and that Taiwan will formally introduce Vietnamese laborers from September, under a three-year agreement period.
The agreement stipulates that Vietnam laborers working legally in Taiwan will be under the protection of its legal system.
Vietnam will guarantee to send the laborers to Taiwan within a month of the signing of the contract between the Taiwan employer and Vietnamese labor broker.
In addition, if the laborer is ineligible for National Health Insurance, his medical fees will have to covered by the Vietnamese agency's funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE ROC FIRM, NOT GOVERNMENT, TO INVEST IN CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: A private Taiwan firm established to boost local investment in Central America will funnel US$10 billion into the region over the next seven years, and not the Republic of China government, an ROC diplomat said on Thursday.

In a report to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), Timothy Tsen, the economic adviser to the ROC embassy in Costa Rica, said that Taiwan's media had got their facts wrong when they reported on his remarks published on June 4 by Costa Rica's La Republica daily.

Tsen said he told the Costa Rica media at a press briefing at an ROC trade show in Costa Rica's capital of San Jose that the Taipei-based Central American Investment Holding Company (CAIHC) had come up with a plan, dubbed "El Tucan" (toucan), to funnel US$10 billion over the next seven years into the states of the region, according to their various needs.
Tsen said his statement was based on a brief given by CAIHC's general manager Ho Yu to the Costa Rican government the previous day.

Ho, who went to San Jose to inspect the trade show on June 3, met Samuel Guzowski, the minister of foreign trade who doubles as minister of industry and commerce, and Rafael Sequeira, adviser to the president, and briefed them on CAIHC's background and aims, including the "El Tucan" program. Tsen was present at the briefing.

Unfortunately, he said, the story was misquoted by some Taiwan reporters, who described the plan as an aid program being offered by the Taipei authorities to its Central American allies, taking MOFA by surprise.
Tsen gave his explanation after being contacted by MOFA and asked to explain himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOT-AND-MOUTH DISEASE BREAKS OUT AMONG KINMEN CATTLE

TEXT.P: The island of Kinmen was declared a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD)-infected area after two cattle there were diagnosed with the disease, the Republic of China Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Thursday.
Kinmen, a fortress island 2.3 km from mainland China's Fujian Province, is weighing the option of slaughtering all of its 3,000 head of cattle, COA officials said.
The two cases of FMD are the first in five decades on the island, which has not imported any cattle from abroad since 1945.
Four veterinarians from the COA immediately set off for the frontline island carrying 6,000 vials of vaccine, the officials said.
A ban on exports of the island's livestock produce was imposed on Thursday evening as soon as the FMD diagnosis was confirmed.

FMD is an acute contagious disease of cloven-hoofed animals which is caused by various rhinoviruses. It ravaged Taiwan's swine population in 1997, crippled the island's booming pig farming industry and totally wiping out its port exports.
The disease flared up again among pigs on the offshore island of Penghu and in southern Taiwan earlier this year, but no cattle were reported to have been affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REPUBLICAN PARTY WHIP TOUTS TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Tom DeLay, the Republican Party's whip in the US House of Representatives, has sent letters to his colleagues, seeking their support for the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act.
The act was jointly introduced by DeLay, House International Relations Committee Chairman Ben Gilman, and other House members, in May this year.
The bill has three main thrusts:

-- Ensuring that Taiwan has the necessary equipment to maintain its self-defense capabilities, as promised under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), by authorizing the sale to Taiwan of a broad array of equipment and defensive weapons;

-- Bolstering the process for such defense sales to Taiwan by prohibiting politically motivated reductions in US arms sales, requiring an increase in staffing at the American Institute in Taiwan, and requiring an annual presidential report to Congress on Taiwan's defense needs; and

-- Redressing deficiencies in Taiwan's combat readiness by supporting increased Taiwan enrollment at US military colleges, expanded military exchanges and joint training, and establishing direct communications between the two countries' militaries.

DeLay said in his letter, dated June 7, that "the threat to the Taiwanese people from the People's Republic of China is on the rise," adding that one lever Beijing uses in pursuit of its goal to reunify Taiwan is "intimidation."
He quoted a Pentagon report as saying that the PRC is engaged in a major buildup of ballistic missiles on its coast directly across the Taiwan Strait.
Other military buildups were also described in the report, coupled with increased efforts to improve mainland China's logistical capabilities for a Taiwan invasion scenario, he said.

In order to maintain a balance of power in the region, DeLay noted, the US should ignore Beijing's pressure on the US to limit or cease its arms sales to Taiwan, and should remain steadfast by continuing to provide Taiwan with the means to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.

According to reliable sources, as of June 8, 17 congressmen have co-sponsored the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act. A similar bill introduced in the Senate in March has received support from seven senators.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY HIGH ON BEIJING'S LIST

TEXT.P: Beijing has adopted a two-pronged policy to ensure that national security is in line with its perception of an enhanced anti-China containment policy by the West, The South China Morning Post reported Thursday.
Mainland authorities are also committed to maintaining the "multi-polar" nature of the world order -- in other words, putting limits on the powers of the United States, said the report.
After the bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, President Jiang Zemin has held marathon sessions with advisers from areas including diplomacy, defense and foreign trade.
According to the report, one recommendation is that mainland China seek to ensure peace and good neighborliness along its borders.

The past few weeks have seen dozens of meetings between mainland Chinese officials and their counterparts from neighboring states. The latter range from regional powers such as Russia and Pakistan to small countries including North Korea, Nepal, Laos, Burma, as well as former Soviet countries bordering Xinjiang.

Several visiting delegations, including those from Russia, Pakistan and Laos, were led by military officers. People's Liberation Army generals have been active on foreign trips or meeting civilian foreign dignitaries in Beijing, the report noted.
The report quoted diplomatic analysts as saying that the military component of the talks suggested Beijing particularly wanted to avoid conflicts close to home.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO VISIT THREE US SISTER CITIES

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will lead a 35-member delegation on a visit to three of the southern Taiwan port city's US sister cities -- Honolulu, Seattle and Portland, Oregon -- in late July.

Hsieh will depart for Honolulu on July 28, where he plans to meet with Hawaiian Governor Cayet Benjamin and Honolulu Mayor Harris Jeremy, and deliver a speech at a meeting of worldwide Taiwanese organizations.
The delegation's second stop will be Seattle, where they will attend activities of the International Ocean Festival at the invitation of Seattle Mayor Paul Schell.
From Seattle, the delegation will proceed to Portland, and is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Aug. 6.
The Kaohsiung Children's String Musical Troupe, the Children's Choir, and the city orchestra will also give performances in Honolulu and Portland to coincide with Hsieh's visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
NATO suspends war as Serbs withdraw.
The China Times:
NATO stops air strikes as Yugoslav troops begin pulling out of Kosovo.
The United Daily News:
Foot-and-mouth disease infects Kinmen cows for first time.
The Liberty Times:
Generals sign agreement for peace in Kosovo; Serbs and ethnic Albanians celebrate deal.
The Commons Daily:
Victim of court misjudgment during the martial law era will get national compensation.
The China Post:
Number of banned Belgian products expanded to 118.
The Taiwan News:
NATO suspends its air attacks against Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN BEEF, CATTLE BARRED FROM ENTERING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two oxen on a Kinmen range were identified Friday as being infected with foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), the first report of the deadly disease on the offshore island in 70 years.
The identification prompted quarantine officials from Taiwan to slaughter all 45 head of cattle on the Hsin Yao Chi Range to eliminate the highly contagious disease.

Four officials representing the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), the Pig Research Institute in Taipei and the Taiwan Research Institute for Animal Health, flew to Kinmen Friday morning to investigate the epidemic on the island, which is located close to mainland China's coastal Fujian province.
After analyzing virus samples obtained from the two affected oxen, the officials were certain that the disease was not identical to the one found in FMD-stricken hogs in Taiwan.
The finding led the officials to believe that the FMD strain affecting Kinmen cattle originated in mainland China.
According to Yang Shui-sen, director of the Kinmen Livestock Research Institute, the cattle will be anesthetized, then electrocuted, and their bodies will be buried in Kinmen.
The FMD report has also led the COA to announce that live cattle and all fresh, unprocessed meat of cloven-hoofed animals from Kinmen will be barred from entering Taiwan starting Friday.
Kinmen air and sea passengers, as well as cargoes bound for Taiwan, were also strictly scrutinized before boarding transport carriers.

Officials from the Kinmen County Government blamed the possible outbreak on a reduction in the number of armed forces personnel posted on the former front-line anti-communist bastion. Fewer personnel has resulted in lagging security around Kinmen and increased smuggling from mainland China, they noted.

Meanwhile, all 3,000 head of cattle and 2,000 head of goats around Kinmen that are not affected by the disease will receive FMD vaccine injections in the coming days to stem the spread of the deadly disease.

COA officials said they are not particularly worried about the possibility that some of the 700,000 head of cattle in Taiwan may become infected by the Kinmen FMD strain. Some 295 head of Kinmen cattle were shipped to Taiwan between January and May this year, and all were delivered to slaughterhouses in Tainan County and Panchiao, Taipei County.
Officials said they are concerned, however, that cattle from mainland China may have been smuggled into Taiwan through Kinmen, creating a "black hole" that cannot be monitored.

In the months before May this year, FMD epidemics were widely reported in mainland China. The disease has reportedly affected not only pigs but other cloven-hoofed animals, including cattle, sheep, goats and even camels, said COA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S ECONOMY POSTS SOLID GROWTH IN 1ST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Canada's economy grew by a solid one percent (1.0%) in the first quarter of this year as consumer spending boosted the domestic economy and a booming U.S. economy led to a surge in exports, Statistics Canada (StatsCan) said Thursday.
At an annualized rate, real gross domestic product (GDP) grew by a robust 4.2 percent (4.2%) in the first three months of 1999, down from the fourth quarter's very strong 4.8 percent GDP growth.
StatsCan said consumer spending, showing renewed strength after two flat quarters, rose 1.3 percent in the quarter, with gains throughout a number of categories.

"Stable interest rates and recent employment gains boosted consumer confidence in the quarter. Growth picked up speed in virtually all categories of personal expenditure, with durable goods, notably new motor vehicles, leading the increase," said the federal agency in a press release.

The continuing strength of the U.S. economy continued to benefit Canada as exports increased by 2.1 percent in the quarter. Advances in exports of autos, machinery and equipment offset declines in agricultural and energy exports.
The housing market also heated up, particularly in Ontario and the Atlantic region. British Columbia also showed improvement after a series of quarterly declines.
Business investment in residential construction, machinery and equipment was also up, the government tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SETS UP POWERFUL HIGH-TECH WEAPONS RESEARCH GROUP

TEXT.P: Beijing is revitalizing its drive for high-tech military research and weapons development by setting up a powerful task force to coordinate the efforts, the Hong Kong Standard reported Friday.

The military high-tech research group, under the Central Military Commission, is a revival of the mainland's endeavor from the late 1950s to 1970s, when Marshal Ni Rong-zhen was assigned by chairman Mao Ze-dong to head an army of leading scientists, engineers, technicians and intelligence officers to develop mainland China's first nuclear bomb, the report said.
It is also Beijing's latest response to the Kosovo crisis and the Cox Report.

According to the report, the task force, headed by General Xiong Guang-kai, deputy chief of the general staff in charge of the PLA's intelligence and military research units, will be comprised of officials from several central military and civilian agencies.

Besides various military research units, several ministry-level agencies will join the team. They include the Commission for Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense, the Ministry of Science and Technology, as well as the Ministry of Information Industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES GAMBIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday that the Republic of China has in the past received foreign assistance, and now is the time to reciprocate.
The president made the remarks when he received Mustapha Wadda, speaker of the Gambian National Assembly, at the Presidential Office.

President Lee welcomed the visit by Wadda and his delegation, saying that his visit will help promote bilateral friendship. Lee expressed his hope that Wadda would also learn more about the development of the ROC during his stay in Taiwan.
The president also asked Wadda to convey his greetings to Gambian President Yahya Jammeh.

Lee stressed that the ROC has received foreign assistance in the past, and now is the time to reciprocate. This is the ROC's national policy, he said. As an ally of Gambia, the ROC is willing to help Gambia develop its economy to improve the living of the Gambian people, Lee said.

Wadda expressed his appreciation for the ROC for the past assistance it has extended to Gambia, adding that his country is now dedicated to the improvement of the lives of the people, and it welcomes Taiwan investment.
Wadda and his delegation, which arrived here Monday, later called on the Legislative Yuan and National Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPECTS CONTINUED SUBSTANTIAL, FRIENDLY RELATIONS WITH S. AFRICA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is expected to continue to have substantial, friendly relations with South Africa after Thabo Mbeki succeeds Nelson Mandela as the leader of South Africa, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.
MOFA officials noted that South Africa completed its presidential election earlier this month, and Mbeki, leader of the African National Congress (ANC), is expected to become president.

They noted that South Africa is the largest trade partner of the Republic of China in Africa and that they expected the ROC to continue to have substantial, friendly relations with South Africa under Mbeki.
The officials said that the ruling ANC garnered 66.35 percent of the vote to win 266 seats in the Parliament, one seat shy of an absolute majority.
Wire reports said that the Minority Front, which won one seat in Parliament and is popular among the descendants of Indian immigrants, has allied itself with the ANC.

They noted that the support rate for the ANC this year is higher than the 62.5 percent support rate seen in the last election in 1994. The ANC will direct its efforts toward constitutional reforms, more jobs, lowering the crime rate and upgrading South Africa's educational system over the next five years under Mbeki.
The election is also significant in the sense that it marks the arrival of the era of Mbeki, who will face daunting challenges in fighting crime and poverty, as he vowed to do while campaigning.
The officials said that another difficult task that will face Mbeki is finding a way to close the gap between whites and blacks in South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JOINT STATEMENT ON SEMICONDUCTORS SIGNED

TEXT.P: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and the European Union signed on Thursday a new, multilateral Joint Statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
The Joint Statement follows the 1996 bilateral US-Japan Joint Statement on Semiconductors which expires July 31, 1999. The new accord includes the essential elements of the 1996 accord.
The five largest semiconductor-producing countries have basically agreed to several competitive provisions, including a commitment to create barrier-free trade in semiconductors in worldwide markets.

In the Joint Statement, the parties also recognized that the GATT Agreement of 1994 condemns injurious dumping, and reaffirmed the need to avoid the problem of dumping by taking fair and effective anti-dumping measures consistent with GATT and WTO agreements .

"Under the new Joint Statement, industry CEOs will continue to meet at the World Semiconductor Council (WSC) to discuss and engage in environmental concerns, worker health and safety, intellectual property rights, trade and investment liberalization, and worldwide market development," said US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky in a press release.

The WSC in their previous meeting last April agreed to recharter the group effective Aug. 1, 1999. They also agreed to bring mainland China in as a member as soon as semiconductor tariffs are phased out.

Chip industry sales have declined for the past three years, however, a recent forecast by the US Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) projected a rebound of 12.1 percent this year, marking the first double-digit growth since 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ASKS U.S. NOT TO RESTRICT LAMB TRADE

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has urged US President Bill Clinton not to impose new restrictions on lamb imports from Australia, which amounts to US$73 million a year.
Clinton is expected to announce soon his long-awaited decision on a request from the struggling US sheep meat industry for restrictions on lamb imports from Australia and New Zealand.
In a long-distance call this week, Howard said new barriers to the lamb trade would be regarded a threat to the trade relations between the two countries, according to Australian news reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S JOBLESS RATE REMAINS AT 7.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 7.5 percent in May from the April's level despite a buoyant economy, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The ABS figures show only 530 new jobs have been created monthly since February of this year. In May, the number of jobs in the economy grew by 1,100 with a small fall in full-time employment offset by a slight rise in part-time jobs. The participation rate fell to 62.9 percent from 63, its lowest level in almost five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PHANTOM MENACE' BECOMES A BOX-OFFICE MONSTER IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: George Lucas's "The Phantom Menace" continues to score box-office records and has earned almost US$8 million in its opening week across Australia.

The movie, mainly made in Australia, broke the previous opening week record of US$6.7 million for Hollywood's "Independence Day," according to the chief executive of Twentieth Century Fox Film Distributors, Robert Slaviero.
Slaviero told the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday that the movie's record breaking performance in Australia was at least on par with its North American opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S TOURISM INDUSTRY RECOVERING

TEXT.P: Australia's tourism industry, hit by the Asian financial crisis in 1997, is recovering slowly as evidenced by a 1.3 percent growth in foreign tourist arrivals, which totaled almost 4.27 million between April 1998 and March 1999, according to the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC).

Between April 1998 and March 1999, the ATC figures show India led other Asian countries with a rise of 14.3 percent in its tourists going to Australia; followed by China, up 13.2 percent; Hong Kong, 6.2 percent and Singapore, 3.1 percent.

But tourist arrivals in Australia from South Korea plunged 54.7 percent; followed by Indonesia; a drop of 25.6 percent; Thailand, down 15.6 percent; Malaysia, down 8.8 percent and the Philippines, down 5.7 percent.
Tourist arrivals from Japan -- Australia's biggest market -- plunged 7.1 percent between April 1998 and March 1999, according to the ATC figures.
The same figures show tourist arrivals from Taiwan only registered a drop of 0.5 percent during the period.
The ATC said preliminary figures in April show a slight decline of 1.3 percent from foreign tourist arrivals. But tourists from Taiwan rose 10 percent in April 1999 from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 11, or the 28th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1488: James III of Scotland is murdered after his defeat at the Battle of Sauchieburn, Stirling. He is succeeded by his son, James IV.
1727: George II of England accedes to the throne following the death of his father, George I, the first Hanoverian king of England.
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was voted a US representative and was the only legislator to oppose US involvement in both World Wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1946: Italy is proclaimed a republic.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with Progressive Conservative John G. Diefenbaker's victory.
1955: Horrified spectators see the Le Mans racetrack in France become a scene of carnage when one of the cars competing in the 24-hour Grand Prix runs out of control and plunges into the grandstand, killing 85 people and injuring 200 others.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation performed on May 27 was successful.
1970: Aleksandr Feodorovich Kerenski, prime minister of Russia in 1917 until the Bolshevik Revolution, dies in exile in New York.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Statecoach," "Red River," and "True Grit," the later won him an Academy Award.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1988: A crowd of 80,000 packs London's Wembly Stadium to celebrate in absentia the 70 birthday of South African leader Nelson Mandela, who has been in prison since 1964, serving a life sentence from a conviction of attempting to overthrow the state.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden, and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS FAIL TO RECLAIM 8,000-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.2 percent lower Friday as a sour performance in the electronics sector dragged down stocks, breaking a nine-day rising streak.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 17.36 points to finish at 7,979.40.
A total of 3.05 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$162.41 billion (US$5 billion).
Buying sentiments prevailed as investors switched their interest to paper, textiles and financial issues, dealer said.
Advancers led decliners 254 to 190, with 62 unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the textiles sector posted the largest gains of the day, rising 3.2 percent, while electronics stocks suffered the only drop, falling 2.6 percent.

Paper-making shares rose 2.9 percent, followed by financial issues, which rose 2.1 percent; foodstuff issues, 1.5 percent; plastics and chemical issues, 1.4 percent; cement shares, 1.3 percent; and construction shares, 0.8 percent.
The over-the-counter market dropped 1.17 points to 180.15 on a turnover of NT$8.07 billion.
Meanwhile, TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June remained unchanged, closing at 7,960 with 1,857 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July moved down 13 points to 7,959 with 1,208 contract transactions, while those for September declined 20 points to 7,950 with 33 contract transactions and those for December went down 63 points to 7,947 with 4 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March also remained unchanged at 7,987 with 2 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,960 for June, 7,972 for July, 7,970 for September, 8,010 for December and 7,987 for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PLANS TO SUE JAPAN OVER TUNA FISHING

TEXT.P: Australia plans to sue Japan for over- harvesting the dwindling bluefin tuna stocks.

Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Minister Mark Vaile told reporters that the Japanese government had "disregarded" Australia's earlier protest against its decision, saying several Japanese long-liners were already in the Southern Ocean, not far from Australia's fishing zone.
"The government has decided to act decisively. We are now examining our legal options to ensure that we pursue the most effective course," he told reporters.
The southern bluefin tuna is one of the world's most valuable fish species, capable of yielding up to US$60,000 each at Tokyo's fish market.

Under an agreement signed in 1989, the annual cap on bluefin tuna is limited to 11,750 tons a year. Japanese fishing fleets are permitted to catch 52 percent of the total figure with Australian fleets accounting for 45 percent and New Zealand vessels making up the rest.
But Japan flouted the cap last year, harvesting 1,400 tons of tuna above its quota and this week confirmed it planned to do the same again this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR MEETS LDP HEAVYWEIGHT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong met with Koichi Kato, head of the second largest faction in Japan's long dominating Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), on Friday for wide-ranging talks.

The closed-door meeting was held at Kato's office, but neither of them would divulge the content of their hour-long talks. Kato once served as the LDP secretary-general and director of the Self-Defense Agency. He plans to run for the LDP leadership in September.

Soong lunched together with several Japanese members of the House of Representatives from the Liberal Party. And then he delivered a speech at a House of Councilors conference hall at the invitation of the Economic Security Research Association.
Soong said in his speech, titled the Asia-Pacific Security Strategy and Taiwan's Responsibility, that Taiwan is located at a critical point on Japan's lifeline.
Therefore, Soong said, Taiwan's stability, prosperity, freedom and democracy are crucial to peace in the Asia-Pacific region and deserve Japan's concern and respect.
Soong said Taiwan is pleased to see the signing of the new Japan-US Defense Cooperation Guidelines which he said provides a new mechanism to maintain regional security in the post-Cold War era.

He pointed out that there are four "leading players" in the Asia-Pacific -- the United States, Japan, Taiwan and mainland China. "Each of them is obligated to help maintain peace and stability in the region," Soong said, adding that Taiwan should act like a buffer to reduce the risk of conflicts in the region.
Soong said Taiwan should avoid taking any irrational actions to provoke mainland China and thus force the United States and Japan to make difficult, painful choices.
In the meantime, Soong called on mainland China not to underestimate Taiwan people's determination to safeguard their highly cherished democratic system and liberal lifestyle.
"Mainland China should also never overlook the general Taiwan public's strong will-power to resist pressure," Soong said.

Quoting President Lee Teng-hui's views unveiled in his new book "With the People Always in My Heart," Soong said the well-being of all Chinese people must be the priority concern in mulling China's reunification.
Moreover, Soong said China can be reunified only under the principles of freedom, democracy and equitable distribution of wealth.
Touching on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Soong said Taiwan and mainland China should establish a comprehensive framework for regular dialogue to maintain cross-strait peace.

Noting that cross-strait political talks are the inevitable, Soong said Taiwan and mainland China should establish a three-stage consultation formula which calls for fostering consensus, seeking agreement and approval of the general Taiwan public.
About 90 Japanese politicians, media and business executives, and academics, as well as overseas Chinese community leaders, including five Japanese councilors, attended Soong's speech.

Soong arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday for a five-day visit aimed at upgrading his international profile as he is likely to run in Taiwan's next presidential election scheduled for 2000. He already visited the Philippines and the United States before coming to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GRANTED MEMBERSHIP IN WORLD SEMICONDUCTOR COUNCIL
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 11 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of the semiconductor industry and of the governments of the United States, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the European Union (EU) announced on Thursday the establishment of a new semiconductor organization, the World Semiconductor Council.
The council, sponsored by the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, accepted Taiwan's semiconductor industry association as a new member.

After the conference, a joint statement was issued, saying the council was designed to ensure fair and open global trade in semiconductors. It will seek zero tariffs for the industry and will urge governments to make policies based on World Trade Organization standards.

This mechanism, meant to replace the 1996 US-Japan Joint Statement on Semiconductors, due to expire July 31, 1999, led to an unprecedented level of cooperation among all the members involved, said a US government representative.

Under the new pact, the council will be subject to review on August 1, 2004, and industry leaders will continue to meet annually and cooperate on global issues such as standardization, the environment, intellectual property rights, investment liberalization and global market development.
According to data released from the European Commission, the combined output from the five member states totals US$141.5 billion and accounts for 90 percent of the world's semiconductor production.
