DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRAVELERS FINED HEAVILY FOR NOT POSSESSING 'TAIPAOZHENG'S'

TEXT.P: Another batch of Taiwan business people were reportedly fined heavily by mainland Chinese authorities for traveling in mainland China without having "taipaozheng's" -- the official travel document for people from Taiwan visiting mainland China, travel industry sources said on Friday.

The Taiwan business people were recently found to be visiting the southern mainland Chinese city of Xiamen. Instead of carrying taipaozheng's, they had travel documents that were issued by mainland Chinese authorities for overseas Chinese visiting mainland China.

Taiwan businessmen and travelers previously found to be traveling in mainland China with travel documents inappropriate for people from Taiwan were fined 5,000 renminbi each and had their travel documents confiscated, said officials from the Taipei Association of Travel Agents (TATA).

It was learned that the Taiwan residents obtained their travel documents from a few overseas Chinese who moonlighted as travel agency brokers between Taiwan and mainland China and who provided the documents at a cost of NT$10,000 each. Reports said the travel documents were sought after by the Taiwanese because it saves them the trouble of trying to obtain multiple-entry visas for visits to the mainland for a variety of purposes.
Mainland Chinese immigration authorities reportedly acknowledged that the practice of providing inappropriate entry documents has been occurring and launched a crackdown.

Although TATA officials said the taipaozheng requirement is discriminatory against people from Taiwan, they urged all Taiwan people about to visit mainland China to be realistic and to apply for a taipaozheng before heading to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LAWMAKERS COMMEND TAIWAN ON AID TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 10 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Four US legislators on Thursday lauded Taiwan's decision to financially aid Kosovar refugees, saying that the move underlines Taiwan's commitment to playing a "helper's role" in the international community.

Senator Max Cleland (D-Ga.) and Representatives Solomon Ortiz (D-Texas), Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) and Gary Ackerman (R-N.Y.) on Thursday spoke individually on the Senate and House floors to praise the goodwill shown by the Republic of China in offering the US$300 million aid package.

The package, unveiled Monday, includes emergency supplies for Kosovar refugees and contributions to long-term reconstruction efforts by the international community in Kosovo once a peace plan is accepted. Moreover, it also offers to provide Kosovar refugees with short-term technical training in Taiwan.
The US lawmakers praised President Lee Teng-hui for the compassion he has shown to the people in Kosovo.
On Wednesday Tom Buley, chairman of the House Committee on Commerce, praised Taiwan's decision to offer to help Kosovar refugees return to their homes.
In his remarks, Buley said, "President Lee and the people of Republic of China should be commended for their commitment to international peace and stability."

All the lawmakers' statements commending Taiwan's aid program for Kosovar refugees have been entered into the US Congressional Record, said officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.
Meanwhile, the Group of European Radical Party Alliance, a European parliamentary body espousing human rights and world peace, on Tuesday welcomed Taiwan's US$300 million aid package.
The group said in a statement that Taiwan has once again demonstrated its ability to play a sensible role on the international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ADVISED TO FORSWEAR USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A former foreign policy speech writer for US President Bill Clinton said mainland China should take note of the United States' war record and forswear the use of force against Taiwan, if it wants to reunite the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In an article published in The Australian Financial Review on Friday, Joshua Muravchik said it is "vital for Chinese leaders to absorb one of the key lessons of the war in Kosovo. Alas, it is a lesson which their conspiracy-minded way of interpreting events will make it difficult for them to grasp."
He referred to the recent reaction of mainland Chinese leaders following the accidental bombing of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

"While Beijing cannot bring itself to believe that the targeting of its embassy was unintentional, the truth is that the entire war was unintended. Strange though it may seem, that is the way America usually gets into its wars," he said.

"This point takes on ominous implications when it is applied to Taiwan, which is the most likely flash point for a violent conflict between America and China. Because Beijing regards Taiwan as falling within its sovereignty, it steadfastly refuses to renounce the use of force to regain control over the island," he noted.
He urged mainland China to consider the United States' war record before deciding future moves against Taiwan.

He said at the outbreak of the World War I in 1914, US President Woodrow Wilson declared neutrality, but two years later, he discovered that America needed to enter the fray in order to "make the world safe for democracy." The United States has also been drawn into other conflicts that it originally intended to avoid. "Americans never want to fight, but once mayhem begins, they have a hard time remaining aloof from it."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE WOMAN'S PLIGHT BRINGS CHALLENGES TO AUSSIE POLICY

TEXT.P: Australian immigration policy is under serious challenge after a 28-year-old mainland Chinese woman at the center of a high-profile abortion row has applied to become a permanent resident of Australia.

In a dispatch from mainland China, The Australian reported that the woman, identified as Zhu Qingping, and her supporters on Thursday lodged applications in Canberra and Quangzhou, in southern mainland China, where she is now staying.
The daily reported that the case presents a challenge to Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock, who told Channel Nine TV Network this week that Australia was "not at all" responsible for Zhu.

Zhu was deported in 1997 when she was eight-and-a-half-months pregnant, despite repeated requests to Australian immigration authorities to allow her to remain in Australia until she gave birth. She was forced to have an abortion by mainland Chinese authorities after she returned to her hometown.

After getting her identification papers from a relative, Zhu provided her documents to Immigration Department secretary Bill Farmer in Canberra and the Australian consulate in Guangzhou, applying for permanent resident status in Australia.
The daily quoted Independent Senator Brian Harradine as saying that Australia has a responsibility for the well-being of the woman.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN HALF OF WEIGHT-LOSS, BEAUTY CENTERS VIOLATE REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has found that 53 percent of weight-loss centers and beauty spas in the cities and counties of Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung and Kaohsiung violate DOH regulations, sources from the DOH said Friday.
The finding was released after the DOH conducted inspections of 104 weight-loss centers and beauty spas. Fifty-five centers were found to have committed a total of 134 violations.
Regulations governing operations of weight-loss and beauty centers, including standards for advertisement, which were announced by the DOH and the Fair Trade Commission, went into effect June 1.
Violations discovered during Friday's inspection included selling illegal food and cosmetics, hiring unlicensed dietary consultants and not having a business license.
Meanwhile, 35 violations involved commercials that presented false information or centers that issued unfair contracts.

Many famous companies were among the violators, including Best Leading Lady branches in Taipei's Chungshan area, Taichung City and Kaohsiung County; Famous International Beauty Center branches in Taichung and Hsinchu; and Taipei's Angel Face.

According to the DOH, local health and business management authorities will take action against the violators, while some violations involving false information in commercials will be referred to the Fair Trade Commission.
The DOH urged potential customers to protect themselves by making sure the centers are following regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT TO INTERFERE WITH ROC'S NEXT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China is not expected to interfere with the Republic of China's next presidential election nor will it repeat its past mistake of resorting to saber-rattling, a senior mainland affairs official said on Friday.
Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks during a seminar on political and economic situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

When the ROC held its first-ever direct presidential election in March 1996, mainland China conducted live-fire military exercises and lobbed missiles into waters near Taiwan in addition to publishing a series of articles criticizing President Lee Teng-hui in an apparent attempt to prevent Lee from winning the historical election.
Su said he does not think that mainland China will again use such a failed strategy when the ROC holds its second direct presidential election next year.

"I also don't think that Beijing authorities will interfere with our coming presidential election," Su said. "Nevertheless, we'll stay alert on Beijing's possible attempts to influence the result of our election, including providing campaign funds for presidential hopefuls," he stressed.
Su said if the ROC finds that mainland China tries to interfere with its presidential election, relations across the Taiwan Strait will certainly be adversely affected.

Meanwhile, the ROC's top mainland policy planner said he hopes details concerning a planned visit to Taiwan this autumn by Wang Daohan, head of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), can be set in the near future.

Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) proposed on Thursday that its deputy secretary-general, Jan Jyh-horng, lead a delegation to visit Beijing from June 27 through June 29 to discuss with ARATS officials an itinerary for Wang's Taiwan visit.
"The MAC, which oversees SEF operations, hopes Jan's Beijing visit can produce definite results, including setting dates and itinerary for Wang's visit," Su said.

Meanwhile, Su said he hopes the two sides will also discuss some non-political practical issues closely related to people's rights and interests during Jan's Beijing visit. Such issues include cross-strait fishing disputes and repatriation of mainland Chinese hijackers and illegal immigrants.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official contacts.

It remains uncertain whether ARATS will agree to Jan's planned June 27-29 visit to Beijing as the intermediary body originally invited Jan to visit the mainland from June 22 through June 24. Jan cannot accept ARATS invitation because during that period SEF will sponsor a golf tournament in Taipei for Taiwan investors in mainland China.

Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan when he met with his Taiwan counterpart SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu in Shanghai last October.
According to a preliminary agreement reached earlier this year between SEF and ARATS, Wang will visit the island this fall. However, no definite dates have been set yet.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100 LEGISLATORS ENDORSE UNICAMERAL PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Over 100 legislators have given their endorsement to a unicameral proposal initiated by Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chen Hung-chi.
Shen brought up the proposal during a Friday meeting of the legislature's Procedure Committee, in hopes of getting the proposal added to the Legislative Yuan's agenda for next week.
Shen, Chen and KMT Legislator Eugene Jao displayed the single-chamber parliament proposal, endorsed by over 100 legislators, during a Friday morning press conference.
The question of whether to retain or abolish the National Assembly (NA) has become a popular subject recently, as has the question of whether Taiwan needs a two-chamber parliament system, Shen said.
All jurisdictional conflicts between the NA and the Legislative Yuan stem from the presence of two separate representative organs, Shen said.
The proposal for a single parliamentary office needs more support from "people of noble aspirations," he said.
The proposal contains four main points:

-- The Legislative Yuan believes the presence of two central civil representative organs, the NA and the Legislative Yuan, causes conflicts of jurisdiction, which require immediate reformation to resolve;

-- The Legislative Yuan advocates the deletion of chapters three and six of the constitution concerning the NA and the Legislative Yuan, and the addition of a new chapter on a single parliament as the Republic of China's sole parliamentary organ. Moreover, the total number of parliamentary members must not exceed 225; and
-- The Legislative Yuan proposes, under the premise of accomplishing the previous resolution, to lengthen the term of current assembly members to the end of the fourth legislature's term.
Over a hundred deputies have given their endorsement to the proposal, including 18 KMT legislators, all 72 DPP legislators, 10 independents and one from another sub-group of the legislature.
But NA deputies were mixed in their reactions to this proposal on Friday.
DPP NA Convener Chen Ching-te pointed out that according to constitutional amendment procedures, legislators as well as NA deputies, have the right to propose amendments to the constitution.

But the proposed amendments must receive legislative approval, and the NA must receive six months' notice before the amendments are handed over to the assembly, he said. As the NA is already in session, it seems too late for the legislators to make the motion, he said.
This proposal should have been made a long time ago, Chen said, adding that the bill is "in the right direction but lacks sincerity."
Chen said he doubted whether the bill would pass the legislature, since this type of proposal appears in every session of the NA.

KMT NA Working Committee Director Chen Ching-jen said the bill was proposed by legislators, and is not on the NA's agenda for the current session, which deals mainly with discussing proposed constitutional amendments.

The legitimacy of a single-chamber parliament commands careful consideration, since the ROC government has been a two-chamber parliament system from the beginning, Chen said, adding that the Council of Grand Justices has already explained that parliamentary reform requires national consensus.

Chen said he does not oppose the unicameral proposal, but he asked for caution, saying that the legislators were too hasty in their action and that the NA and the legislature cannot be abolished rashly.

New Party NA Vice Convener Wu Cheng-chun pointed out that the focus of the NA's current session should be reformation of parliamentary functions and that the NP has already started considering parliamentary reformation.
The NP is still in discussions over whether the parliament should move toward an unicameral system, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIOXIN-CONTAMINATED EXPORTS FROM FRANCE TO TAIWAN: FIT

TEXT.P: The French Institute in Taipei (FIT) reassured the Taiwan public on Friday that French-made dairy products are not dioxin-contaminated.
The FIT quoted a written statement issued by the French Agriculture and Fisheries Ministry which confirmed that no French dairy products have been contaminated by the cancer-causing dioxin.

A dioxin contamination incident in Belgium involving dairy goods and animal feed has provoked a wave of public panic here about imported European food, forcing local shop owners to clear a broad range of European food products from their shelves.
The FIT faxed the statement to the Department of Health, the National Bureau of Standards, and the Board of Foreign Trade, in a bid to ease public fears arising from the incident.

According to the statement, the French ministry said it was informed by Belgian authorities that only a limited number of allegedly contaminated Belgian meat products have been exported to France, and added that none of the suspect items have been transported to a third country.

After imposing a series of stringent monitoring measures, the French government is sure that no dioxin-contaminated Belgian pork, chicken, beef or dairy products are being sold inside France, and that no such Belgian imports have been re-exported to other countries, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN MERCHANDISE AND TOURISM FAIR OPENS NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A "Neo European Merchandise and Tourism Fair," the first large-scale exhibition in Taiwan with the aim of introducing central and eastern European countries, will be held in Taipei June 15-19.

The exhibition, a joint venture of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and Economic Affairs (MOEA), will display representative products and merchandise from the Czech Republic, Hungary, Lithuania and Poland at the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC) from June 15-19.

MOFA European Affairs Director Liu Hsiang-pu said in a press conference Friday that more than 10 high-level government and economic affairs officials from the four European countries will be present for the opening ceremony next Tuesday.

Liu said the purpose of this exhibition is to introduce Czech, Hungarian, Lithuanian and Polish products, as well as information about travel to those countries and their investment environments. The show will also help promote the Republic of China's trade relations with central and eastern Europe, he added.

A total of 116 companies from the four countries will participate in the fair, exhibiting all kinds of raw materials, agricultural and mineral products, industrial and chemical products, hand-made goods and daily necessities, as well as travel information, Liu said.

In addition to actively seeking trade partners in Taiwan, Liu said, participants will also introduce neo-European cultural traditions to promote further an understanding of the "new Europe" among local businessmen.

A neo-European investment and trade seminar will be held on June 16 at the TICC as well. Economic affairs officials from participating countries will introduce their respective investment environments, as well as highlight the trade opportunities that exist in their countries, to local businessmen.
June 16 and 17 have been named "Polish Day" and "Hungarian Day," respectively. Aside from cultural artistic performances, travel fairs will be held as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PRIME MINISTER WINDS UP VISIT TO ROC

TEXT.P: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski said here on Friday he hopes a large portion of the Republic of China's promised US$300 million aid to Kosovars can be used for reconstruction projects in Macedonia.
Georgievski made the appeal during a tea party with a group of local diplomatic journalists at the end of his six-day official visit to Taiwan.
Georgievski said the Macedonian government and people are grateful for ROC President Lee Teng-hui's generous offer to aid Kosovar refugees.
"We also look forward to seeing a part of the fund can be used to help finance our reconstruction projects," the 33-year-old prime minister said.

Georgievski said the Macedonian economy has lost about US$1.5 billion because of the Kosovo crisis. "We need an estimated US$440 million before the end of this year to revitalize our battered economy," he noted.

Macedonia has a population of only about 2.2 million. Since Yugoslavia began its ethnic cleansing in Kosovo early this year, more than 240,000 ethnic Albanians in the Yugoslav province have fled to neighboring Macedonia, inflicting a heavy economic burden on Macedonia.
Georgievski said the United States, the European Union and several other major countries have agreed to financially support Macedonia's economic recovery projects.
"We hope East Asian countries, including the ROC, will also take part in our reconstruction projects," Georgievski said.

Commenting on some Taiwan opposition politicians' criticism of President Lee's generous aid offer, Georgievski said he hopes major political parties here and members of the general public can reach a consensus on the aid program.

Georgievski, heading a 59-member delegation of senior officials and business executives, arrived in Taipei last Sunday for his first official visit to Taiwan since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.

During his stay, Georgievski met with President Lee, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials to discuss concrete measures to boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
He also signed six agreements with Premier Siew to facilitate trade, investment and economic cooperation between the two countries.
Georgievski also chaired the inauguration ceremony for the Macedonian Embassy in Taipei and an investment seminar to court Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in his country for mutual benefits.
On Friday, Georgievski toured the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei to view a large collection of Chinese art treasures.
Georgievski and his entourage left Taipei for home Friday evening. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS TO FOUR-MONTH LOW ON TAIWAN FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped on the Taiwan foreign exchange market on Friday, dropping NT$0.031 to a four-month low of NT$32.459.
A total of U$497.5 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.461, and was traded between NT$32.452 and NT$$32.482 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN APPOINTS NEW DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Y.S. Liu, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), was appointed as new deputy secretary-general of the Executive Yuan on Friday.

Liu, 55, acquired a doctorate in civil engineering from National Chengkung University, and obtained two masters degrees from National Chunghsing University and the Bangkok-based Asian Institute of Technology.
He will fill the post vacated by Chang Che-chen, who has been appointed director-general of the Central Personnel Administration.

Meeting the media following his appointment, Liu said that he has worked with the CEPD for 29 years and has never thought of changing jobs, but he added that he will do his utmost to assist Premier Vincent Siew, former CEPD chairman and Liu's former boss.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DEMONSTRATIONS AGAINST CORRUPTION STAGED IN XIAN, CHINA

TEXT.P: Two groups of mainland Chinese people staged demonstrations separately Thursday at the government building of Xian, the capital city of Shaanxi province, in protest against heavy tax and corruption.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Friday that some 400 merchants from a textile marketplace in the city protested against their heavy tax burden.

The information center quoted a spokesman for the demonstrators as saying that 17 official organizations are collecting taxes from them, that they have to pay five times the taxes they paid six years ago, and that they have temporarily closed down their stores since June 6 and staged a demonstration at the city government building Thursday.
Another group of some 100 workers from a state-run boiler manufacturing factory in the city staged a separate demonstration Thursday against embezzlement and corruption , it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAEKWONDO TEAM RETURNS WITH TWO GOLD, FOUR BRONZE MEDALS

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returned to Taipei on Friday from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada, bearing two gold and four bronze medals.
At the airport upon arrival, however, team leader Hsu An-chin described the result as "barely satisfactory."
The two gold medalists are Miss Kao Ching-yi (heavyweight) and Miss Chi Shu-ju (flyweight). The four bronze medalists are Hsu Chi-hung, Chen Wei-chun, Miss Meng Mei-chun and Miss Chang Wan-chen.
Shortly after their return to Taipei, the team paid a call on Nancy Chao, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level National Sports Council, and Chang Wan-li, president of the Chinese-Taipei Sports Federation.
Chao praised the team's performance, and expressed her hope that Taiwan will be able to win a gold in taekwondo at the next Olympic Games. She then presented gifts to the six medal winners.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVAL FLEET VISITING PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 11 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A "fleet of friendship" of the Republic of China Navy arrived in the Philippines on Friday for a three-day visit.

Amid a warm welcome from hundreds of flag-waving ROC nationals and locals, including ROC Representative to the Philippines Chan Hsien-ching and Filipino dignitaries, three ROC naval vessels -- the Wuyi, the Chengho, and the Panchao -- sailed into No. 15 port in Manila Bay.

In addition to being a training exercise for ROC Naval Academy cadets, Fleet Commander General Chen Yeng-kang said the major purpose of the fleet's visit to the Philippines is to strengthen the friendly ties between the ROC and the Philippines, and to meet with ROC nationals residing here.
The three ROC-built vessels were later opened to the public, where Chen gave a briefing to the visitors.
The Philippines is the fourth leg of the fleet's voyage over the past 31 days, following visits to Nauru, Solomon Islands, and Singapore.
The fleet is slated to set sail for Taiwan on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DOWNPLAYS KOSOVO AID PLEDGE

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials on Friday were stumbling desperately around questions on President Lee Teng-hui's hotly debated US$300 million Kosovar aid pledge, saying the amount "will not exceed the amount stipulated by Foreign Minister Jason Hu."

The previous evening, Hu had apologized for making "mistaken" pronouncements regarding the amount of aid pledged for the Kosovar refugees, but the public was still mystified over several issues, including whether or not the aid pledge includes a US$7 million sum already given to Macedonia. MOFA officials remained silent.

While Hu now acknowledges the Kosovar aid package is indeed US$300 million, the public is still demanding an explanation for Hu's "slip of tongue" over the massive difference in the amount compared with the aid figure of US$10 million he mentioned in a report to the legislature.

According to a MOFA press release, Hu said the US$10 million in his legislative report was "part of the US$300 million aid package," but this failed to explain how the foreign minister was not privy to the aid amount Lee later announced.

MOFA European Affairs Director Liu Hsiang-pu said during a Friday press conference only that the Kosovar aid plan is "connected with" the Macedonian aid package, since many of the Kosovo refugees are currently in Macedonia.
He said: "Helping Kosovo includes helping Macedonia, and it is a very important part of the aid package."

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR SPEAKS IN TOKYO ON CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong gave a speech on "Asia-Pacific security and strategy and Taiwan's responsibilities" at a symposium in Tokyo on Friday.

The symposium was chaired by Upper House member Hideaki Tamura of the Japan Liberal Party, and was attended by about 90 people from Japanese political and economic circles and the local Chinese community.

Soong, who might be a candidate in next spring's presidential election, said that Taiwan has failed to receive equal treatment from the international community, is unable to enjoy the privileges it deserves, and is therefore unable to do its duty as a member of the international community.

He called on the international community to allow Taiwan become a member of various international organizations, and asked Japan to throw its "just support" behind Taiwan when the island seeks to take part in international organizations.
In answer to a question from one of the participants, Soong said that the cross-Taiwan Strait issue is not solely a sovereign problem, but also very important in terms of human rights.
He noted that the inhabitants of Taiwan share a two-point consensus on this issue -- they will not accept communist rule, and they will not engage in war with mainland China.

On the solution of the Taiwan issue, Soong said the welfare and opinions of the 21 million Taiwan people must be respected, but added that Beijing's views on the Taiwan issue should also not be ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY TIGHTENED IN LEAD-UP TO PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: In preparation for the 2000 presidential election, Taiwan has tightened its security, especially with regard to mainland Chinese applying to enter Taiwan, a security official said on Friday.
Wang Chao-hua, an official from the National Security Bureau (NSB), told a public hearing convened by Legislator Shen Chih-hui that the move is to prevent "foreign intervention" in the election.

At the hearing, Chang Min-teh, an official from the National Police Administration, said Taiwan people's connivance at their mainland Chinese counterparts staying and working in Taiwan illegally poses a threa to national security.

Citing a number of recent espionage cases involving mainland Chinese spies as proof of his charges, Chang said many mainland Chinese who visit Taiwan under the bilateral exchange program disappear after arriving in Taiwan.

Beijing's insatiable interest in Taiwan's semiconductor industry also has local security officials worried, Chang said, pointing out that 17 of the 20 overseas groups which have visited the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the heartland of Taiwan's semi-conductor industry, last year were from mainland China.

A total of 380,000 mainland Chinese have visited Taiwan since 1987 when the ban on cross-strait family reunions was lifted, said Chang. The figure does not include the 36,000 mainland Chinese who were caught as illegal immigrants during the same period.

A total of 250 mainland Chinese have been caught trying to enter the island with false documents, along with 120 phony mainland brides who entered Taiwan via fake marriages with Taiwan residents with the intention of working as prostitutes. Many of these phony brides disappear after arriving in Taiwan, and even their Taiwan spouses do not know their whereabouts, said Chang.

Meanwhile, Liu Yun-sen, an official from the Investigation Bureau, urged the Legislative Yuan to pass a Law on Protection of National Classified Information which would provide a sound legal framework to prevent the leakage of national secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR HOLDS PRIVATE TALKS WITH JAPAN'S FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who is a prospective candidate in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, held informal talks with Japanese Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura in Tokyo on Friday.
It was the first time Soong had met with an incumbent Japanese cabinet minister since his arrival in Japan on June 8.
Komura had just returned from a meeting in Germany of foreign ministers from eight countries.

Over the past three days, Soong has conferred with several Japanese political heavyweights, including former prime ministers Tsutomu Hata and Toshiki Kaifu, Japan Liberal Party chief Ichiro Ozawa, and former Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Koichi Kato.

Earlier in the day, Soong delivered a speech on "Asia-Pacific security and strategy and Taiwan's responsibilities" at a symposium chaired by Upper House member Hideaki Tamura of the Japan Liberal Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES PITCH FOR ASIAN PACIFIC SECURITY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday pitched his "Asian Pacific Collective Security System" to a group of scholars attending a seminar in Taipei.

During a reception at the Presidential Office prior to the seminar titled "The Asian Security Guarantee and the Taipei-Beijing Relationship," Lee said the collective security system which he has devised will not only help maintain regional stability, it will also contribute to world peace.
Noting that the Taiwan Strait has long been one of Asia's potential flash points, Lee said the Republic of China has come a long way in its efforts to reach out to Beijing.
He recalled the various steps taken by Taipei to eliminate the hostility between Taipei and Beijing, and said he regrets that Taiwan's goodwill has not been fully matched by Beijing.

Lee reiterated Taipei's pursuit of national unification, saying that he looks forward to the visit to Taiwan later this year of Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait and Beijing's point man in dealing with Taiwan. The visit will help maintain the momentum of the constructive dialogue between Taipei and Beijing, the president said.

He also defended his decision to donate US$300 million in aid to the Kosovo refugees, saying that it is time for Taiwan, which benefited greatly from US aid in the 1950s, to return the favor to international community in kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said humanitarianism is the only reason for the US$300 million aid offer for Kosovars.
The China Times:
President Lee said constructive dialogue across the Taiwan Strait can help reduce tension.
The United Daily News:
FMD (foot-and-mouth disease) virus found on Kinmen unknown in Taiwan.
The Liberty Times:
President Lee said the cross-strait status quo should be maintained if mainland China fails to implement democratization.
The Commons Daily:
More than 100 legislators jointly initiated a bill calling for a unicameral parliamentary system.
The China Post:
Peacekeepers race to Kosovo.
The Taiwan News:
NATO force moves toward Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 12, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1667: Jean-Baptiste Denys, personal physician to King Louis XIV of France, successfully transfuses the blood of a sheep into a 15-year-old boy.
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1839: Abner Doubleday invents baseball in Cooperstown, NY. The new kind of ball game with a four-base infield bears a striking resemblance to the American children's game "old cat" and the English "rounders."
1917: King Constantine of Greece abdicates in favor of his son, Prince Alexander.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as US ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before going to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1931: As part of their crackdown on bootleggers, Chicago police arrest Al "Scarface" Capone, the Italian-born American gangster who ruled the Chicago underworld with an iron fist, charging him with 5,000 offenses under America's Prohibition laws.
1938 China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese Communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1975: A judge rules that Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's landslide victory in 1971 was invalid becuase civil servants illegally aided her campaign.
1978: Strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win an US$185,000 prize.
1987: Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served as prime minister for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other person in the 1900s.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The Republic of China's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anticommunist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members of both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN TAIWAN INFORMATION-RELATED FIRMS RANKED AMONG WORLD'S TOP 100
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Seven Taiwan companies were named by US-based Business Week magazine as being among the world's 100 best information-related companies in terms of their performance last year.

The seven companies, with their rankings in parentheses, are Quanta Computer (14), Asustek (29), Hon Hai Precision (33), Arima (36), Gigabyte (41), Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (93) and Compal Electronics (99).

This is the second year that Business Week has compiled a list of the top 100 information companies. In addition to companies that make computers and related components, producers of software and networking equipment are included on the list as well.

They are chosen from a pool of computer and component makers with annual revenues of more than US$300 million, while software and networking equipment producers are expected to have annual revenues of more than US$5 million.
Their performance was measured according to four criteria: stockholder profits, earning per share, the growth rate of a company's revenue and its total revenue.

Taiwan's highest-ranked firm, Quanta Computer, was named 14th with an annual revenue of US$1.58 billion, which represents a growth rate of 48.6 percent, or a yield of 74 percent to its security par value, and a growth rate of 44.1 percent in stockowners' dividen.

The Business Week issue with the list, due out next week, will introduce the 100 firms, and the issue will include a story about Taiwan semiconductor giant Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., which, the weekly said, has reshaped the world's wafer foundry industry by expanding its business from the manufacture of wafers to their design.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LAWMAKERS PRAISE TAIWAN FOR AID OFFER TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Eight members of the US Congress have applauded the Republic of China on Taiwan for its decision to donate US$300 million to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes, saying Taiwan should be recognized by the United States and the entire world for this selfless, charitable action.

Rep. John Sweeney (R-N.Y.) told the House of Representatives Thursday that he would like to applaud the ROC for playing an active role in the "world arena" and working together to maintain world peace.

Saying humanitarian aid to Kosovar refugees is a common goal for all countries, Sweeney also submitted President Lee Teng-hui's statement regarding assistance to Kosovar refugees in recognition of the ROC's honorable deed.
Both his remarks and President Lee's statement were later printed in the Congressional Record.

Rep. Philip English (R-Pa.) said President Lee should be highly commended for his leadership in announcing the aid package for the refugees in Kosovo, and his generosity should inspire other wealthy nations of the world to open their hearts and pockets to help the war-torn region.

"Taiwan is a geographically small nation, yet its government and people have large, unselfish hearts. They recognize the need for generosity toward the Kosovars, and they are always more than willing to help the less fortunate throughout the world," noted English.

The congressman added that "President Lee's offer of financial assistance to Kosovo is very generous, and Taiwan should be recognized by the United States and the entire world for this selfless, charitable action."

Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) then noted that despite mainland China's diplomatic embargo, Taiwan unveiled on June 7 a US$300 million aid package to assist the ethnic Albanians who have been forced to leave their homes as a result of Slobodan Milosevic's genocidal campaign.

The congressman said he rose on the House floor to recognize Taiwan's continuing commitment to peace and stability in the Balkan region. He then urged his colleagues to recognize Taiwan's sincerity and commitment to join the international drive to help the Kosovar refugees.
Rep. Tom Bliley (R-Va.), chairman of the House Committee on Commerce, was the first member of the US Congress to mention Lee's aid package, commending on Wednesday the ROC president for his actions.
Sen. Max Cleland (D-Ga.), as well as congressmen Solomon Ortiz (D-Texas), Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) and Gary Ackerman (D-N.Y.), also commended the ROC on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS TYCOON INTERVIEWED IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan business tycoon Hsu Wen-lung said in an interview Saturday that Taiwan has emerged largely unscathed from the region's financial storm, and he attributed this to the small- and medium-sized enterprises that form the backbone of Taiwan's economy.

In an interview with The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a major business newspaper in Japan, Hsu said that Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises do not benefit from tax incentives. In addition, they do not have strong financial support and could not possibly engage in the type of over-investment seen among big enterprises in South Korea.
Hsu, founder and chairman of Taiwan's ABS and acrylic giant Chi Mei Group, predicted that Taiwan's economic growth this year will be between 4 percent and 5 percent.

Hsu said that the Asian financial crisis is almost over, and the big problems now are the political situation in Indonesia and questions about how much longer mainland China can continue to uphold its promise not to devalue its currency.

He urged Japanese enterprises to join hands with their Taiwan counterparts to make inroads into the mainland Chinese market, adding that although Taiwan investment in the mainland has declined, investments are nevertheless continuing, since there is still money to be made there.

But he said that as the mainland has encouraged anti-Japanese sentiments among its people, it is only natural that Japanese enterprises will not fare well in the mainland. He said that it is best to cooperate with Taiwan to make inroads into the mainland market.

On the possible impact of Taiwan's presidential election next March and of the return of Macau to mainland China on Taiwan's economy, Hsu said that Taiwan's democratization, as championed by President Lee Teng-hui, has made it impossible for Taiwan to go back to its old ways, adding that the presidential election will have no effect on the island's economy.

Hsu said that as long as the United States and Japan are united on the Taiwan issue, then the mainland will be unable to invade Taiwan. Calling Japan's attitude crucial, he said Taiwan has high regard for Japan and, in particular, for Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi for refusing to kowtow to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin when the latter visited Japan last year.

Hsu was the winner of the Asian Award sponsored by the newspaper. He was presented with the award and a cash award of 3 million yen in Tokyo June 2, though he donated all the money to an Asian environmental protection group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PLAYS A KEY ROLE IN CHINESE CULTURE: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's existence plays a significant role in Chinese culture, and that is the happiness of being the Taiwan people, said President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday.

Speaking at a graduation ceremony at the Minghsin Institute of Technology in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, President Lee stressed that Taiwan's culture -- its way of life and thinking -- will play a key role in Chinese culture, and that the happiness of being the Taiwan people is that the island's existence will allow mainland China's 1.2 billion people to enjoy the same lifestyle in the future.

"This happiness does not belong to me alone, but it belongs to everyone living on this island," he noted, adding that this is effectively the focal point of what he calls "Taiwan people's happiness" in his new book -- "With The People Always in My Heart."

Meanwhile, Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei said at an international seminar on Asian security and cross-strait ties that President Lee still welcomes mainland China's top envoy Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan as scheduled, and that Lee remains firm in his plans to accompany Wang on a tour of Taiwan.

Huang said President Lee has not made any change in his plan to accompany Wang on a tour of Taiwan when he pays a visit here, and that officials of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- are still seeking to set a date for ARATS Chairman Wang to travel to Taiwan this autumn.

Turning to recent rumors that Wang has fallen sick and is currently in critical condition, Huang said the Mainland Affairs Council, the highest government agency in charge of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has confirmed that the rumors are groundless after multilateral verification.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO DECLINES OFFER TO ENTER SISTER-CITY RELATIONSHIP WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara has politely turned down a proposal to establish a sister-city relationship with Taipei, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou indicating Saturday that he understood the decision.
Ishihara told a news conference on Friday that he had received a letter from Ma, suggesting that Tokyo and Taipei sign a sisterhood agreement. "I did not make an affirmative reply," he said.
Tokyo and Beijing are sister cities, and this year marks the 20th anniversary of their relationship.
Ma told the media on Saturday that he understood Ishihara's position, and that Taipei City would continue to strengthen relations with Tokyo through various channels.

The mayor said he had asked former Control Yuan member Wang Ching-feng to take a letter to Ishihara, extending his congratulations on Ishihara's election as Tokyo governor and expressing his hopes of entering a sister-city relationship with Tokyo.

According to Ma, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government's reaction to his proposal was mild, while the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly objected more strongly, apparently out of concern over possible protests from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCA COMMENDS US CONGRESSMEN ACKERMAN AND WELDON

TEXT.P: The Organization of Chinese Americans (OCA) in Washington has commended Congressmen Gary Ackerman (D-N.Y.) and Curt Weldon (R-Pa.) for speaking in defense of Asian-Pacific Americans (APA) who are not involved in mainland Chinese espionage in the United States.

On May 26, at a hearing before the Asia and Pacific Subcommittee of the House International Relations Committee, Ackerman questioned some of the wording found in the Cox report. "There is a chill that's going up and down the spine of every Asian American in the country right now. This kind of language does a tremendous disservice to that community," he said.

At a May 25 press conference regarding the release of the Cox report, Weldon said, "There are those who will use this report to cast a negative light on honorable Chinese and Asian Americans, who are the leaders in many cases of our scientific community.

"Let no one make any mistake that this report is in any way attempting to reflect negatively on the contribution by hundreds of thousands and millions of Asian and Chinese-Americans who form the backbone of many of our most complex technical areas of research. ... That is not the case of our report."

"We want to extend our appreciation to Congressmen Ackerman and Weldon for their leadership and sensitivity to the Chinese and APA community," OCA President George M. Ong said in a press release dated June 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERIAN DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A conference between the Republic of China and Liberia is slated to be convened from June 15 to June 17 in Taipei, with Liberia's foreign minister, Monie R. Captan, arriving here next Monday with a delegation, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Saturday.

The delegation will also include the economics minister, John Weseh McClain, and the country's finance minister, John G. Bestman. The delegation is expected to meet with President Lee Teng-hui, as well as visit various sites in Taiwan.
A regular annual conference between the two countries on issues of mutual concern was suggested by both countries' leaders in 1997, with each country holding the conference every other year.
The first conference was held in April 1998 in Liberia's capital, Monrovia. ROC Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan attended the conference on behalf of the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: EYE DOCTORS TO HAVE LASER VISION CORRECTION

TEXT.P: June 16 will be "Eye Doctors Only Day" in New Jersey when a dozen eye doctors will have laser vision correction. These doctors have so much confidence in this state-of-the-art procedure, which can correct nearsightedness, hyperopia and astigmatism, that they are undergoing the procedure themselves.

These doctors will all undergo LASIK -- a highly advanced type of refractive surgery in which the surgeon creates a hinged corneal flap before using a precise, computer-controlled excimer laser to gently reshape the patient's cornea with a cool beam of ultraviolet light. The flap is then put back in place, and the cornea assumes its new shape.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORM SAID BEHAVING LIKE HUMANS

TEXT.P: US and Australian scientists have discovered that human beings have much in common with the nematode, C.elegans, or the worm, as it is known to aficionados, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.

The daily reported that the worm has provided a vital clue as to how to grow human organs for transplant in the laboratory. US researchers this week announced they had discovered the gene that controls the shape of the worm's intricate sex organs.

The shape of human sex organs may turn out to be controlled by a completely different mechanism than in the worm, Warwick Grant, head of the only lab at Flinders University in Adelaide dedicated to studying C.elegans, told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN HOG EXPORTS TO SINGAPORE INCREASING

TEXT.P: Australian farmers are riding on booming hog exports as demand from Singapore surged between February and May this year because pigs in Malaysia have been hit by the Nipah virus.
Australia's monthly hog exports to Singapore surged to 1,000 tons in May from 18 tons in February.
The outbreak of the Nipah virus in Malaysia has killed 100 people, and millions of pigs there have been destroyed, according to a report by The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TOUTS ROC'S STRATEGIC ROLE IN ASIA-PACIFIC SECURITY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Saturday that the Republic of China on Taiwan has played a critical role in the Asia-Pacific security mechanism.

"Peace in the Taiwan Strait is also vital to the safety of international shipping lanes in the West Pacific and to the prospects of Asia-Pacific economic development," Lee said in his congratulatory message to the opening of a seminar on Asian security and cross-strait relation.
In his message, Lee for the first time lauded the new Japan-US Defense Cooperation Guidelines as "having positive contributions to Asia-Pacific stability."
Lee pointed out that the Asia-Pacific security framework faces new challenges following the end of the Cold War and the restructuring of international order.

"Mainland China's provocative firing of missiles at Taiwan's doorsteps, Beijing-Manila disputes over the Spratlys and North Korea's nuclear and missile development plans have added up to the uncertainty in the Asia-Pacific region," Lee noted.

These factors have not only threatened the Asia-Pacific security but have also affected regional economic development, Lee said, adding that overcoming these uncertainties and creating a favorable environment for regional economic development have become an urgent task for both Asia-Pacific countries and the entire international community.

Noting that the future development of US-Japanese relations is a cornerstone for Asian security, Lee said the newly revised Japan-US Defense Cooperation Guidelines and the Japanese parliament's recent passage of three bills to bolster the guidelines are of great significance to Asia-Pacific security.

Lee further said the strengthening of Japan-US defense cooperation not only signifies the necessity of US military deployment in the Asia Pacific but also reminds Japan that it should play an even more active role in the regional security system.

Another crucial factor to Asia-Pacific security is the future direction of the Chinese community regime, Lee said, adding that whether mainland China can move toward freedom and democracy, forsake its pursuit of hegemony, and abide by current international political and economic regulations will affect Asia-Pacific stability and development over the next few decades.
Lee said the US "engagement" policy toward mainland China is aimed at inspiring it to move toward democracy and accept general international regulations.

However, Lee said, recent developments in Beijing-Washington relations, including human rights issues, negotiations for mainland China's seat in the World Trade Organization, humanitarian aid for Kosovars and mainland China's technology theft, all signify structural conflicts in their relations and the limitation of the US "engagement" policy.

Because of mainland China's instinctive resistance to foreign force or influence, Lee said, mainland China is unlikely to engage with the United States without imposing any restrictions or self-protection measures.
Stressing that Taiwan is located on a strategic point, Lee said Taiwan has played a pivotal role in the US-Japanese security cooperation system and the US engagements with mainland China.
Moreover, Lee said, Taiwan's experience in liberalization and democratization can serve as a driving force behind mainland China's peaceful evolution and abandonment of its pursuit of hegemony.

Therefore, Lee said, the US, Japanese and international recognition of Taiwan's role in the Taiwan Strait stability and Asia-Pacific security will help boost constructive cross-strait interaction and the formation of a new regional security system.

The two-day seminar is co-sponsored by the Taipei-based Liberty Times and the ROC's representative office in Japan. Scores of Asia and international affairs experts from the United States, Japan, Taiwan and other Asian-Pacific countries are attending the seminar, which will close on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIGAR SMOKERS LIKELY TO SUFFER HEART ATTACK

TEXT.P: Cigar smokers are a third more likely than non-smokers to develop heart disease, according to US medical research.
The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that the association between cigarette smoking and heart disease is well established, but cigars have been touted as a healthier alternative.

The daily reported that the survey, conducted by doctors from the most aggressively anti-smoking US state -- California -- also confirms earlier findings that regular cigar puffers are 50 percent more likely than non-smokers to develop lung disease and twice as likely to suffer cancers of the mouth, throat and lung.

DOC.HEADLINE: BENIGN SUN-SPOTS CAN TURN INTO SKIN CANCER: REPORT

TEXT.P: Benign sun-spots can turn into full-blown skin cancer in a matter of four weeks, and standard treatments may not be enough to fully eliminate them, warned an Australian scientist at Sydney University.

Professor Ross Barnetson told The Sydney Morning Herald on Friday that in a survey of 50 patients, he found 10 out of 20 whose sun-spots had recently turned painful had squamous cell carcinoma -- a form of skin cancer that affects 20,000 Australians a year and can be fatal if it spreads to other parts of the body.
He said about 370 Australians die annually from the cancer, the incidence of which has doubled in the past decade.

He said his findings suggested that a common treatment for troublesome sun-spots or solar keratoses -- burning them off with liquid nitrogen -- may be inadequate and that surgery should be used more widely.

He suggested that people with sun-spots seek medical attention much earlier in the development of a skin lesion. But people tend to neglect the danger of sun-spots until they feel pain, and that is a dangerous sign, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INSURANCE FIRM TAKES OVER MANAGEMENT OF PHILIPPINE FIRM
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 12 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Chung Kuo Insurance Co. has taken over the management of Philippine firm Cathay Insurance Corp. after the purchase of 51 percent of its shares.
The deal was made in line with the Republic of China government's policy of expanding business relations with Southeast Asian countries.
The value of the deal was not disclosed. But it is understood that the Taiwan firm made a careful appraisal before concluding the deal and obtained approval from the ROC Finance Ministry.
Liu Cheng-yi, the new chairman of Cathay Insurance, said that the company would step up services to overseas Chinese residents and Taiwanese businessmen in the Philippines.
He added that the company will also support Manila's policy of extending aid to the poor, and help with the development of the Philippine economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SPEAKS AT FU JEN COMMENCEMENT CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Saturday that in view of today's changing pattern of warfare and current policies to streamline the army, as well as to maintain a credible armed force, the government will have to review its compulsory conscription system.

Lien said that he believed that it is necessary to push for alternative forms of service and that a person's period of service in the army should be shortened, though these things can be completed only after constitutional amendment.
Lien made the remarks when he spoke at a commencement ceremony at Fu Jen Catholic University on Saturday morning.
Lien said that if there were fewer military conscripts, valuable manpower could be devoted to national construction projects.
He said that one of the top priorities of the government will be to create a just environment for the youth to develop their talents and creativity.

He also encouraged young people to take part in the community service through volunteer activities, adding that their participation would give them a chance to contribute to society what they have learned in school and to nurture a sense of teamwork.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND STAGES CALL-UP DRILL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) ordered that an unspecified number of reservists be called up in a call-up exercise on Saturday.
The launch of the exercise, code-named "Tung Hsing 11 Activation Operation," was announced through television stations, radio stations and newspapers, according to a spokesman of the MND.
Reservists who had been notified in advance but had not been told where to report should appear for duty at the times and places specified in their call, said the spokesman.

The exercise also involved orders to make ready property and materials that would have been used by the armed forces in the event of a real activation of reservists, as well as orders to mobilize civil defense members in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, and in Kinmen County, located on the front-line island, said the spokesman.
Taiwan's reserves number about 4 million, and it has 400,000 troops in active service. The MND regularly stages call-up exercises to ensure that the reservists can be activated immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOSOVO CRISIS INSPIRING TO TAIWAN: FORMER JAPANESE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan should learn from the recent Kosovo crisis, a former Japanese defense official said here on Saturday.

Tokuichiro Tamazawa, a former director-general of Japan's Defense Agency, made the remarks at a seminar on Asian security and relations across the Taiwan Strait, co-sponsored by the Taipei-based daily Liberty Times and the ROC's representative office in Japan.

Tamazawa said in his speech, titled "the new Japan-US Defense Cooperation Guidelines and relations across the Taiwan Strait," that military confrontation is the worst scenario in cross-strait relations.
"The United States and Japan will do their utmost to prevent such a scenario from happening," Tamazawa said.
The former Japanese defense official went on to say he thinks that the Kosovo incident has a positive meaning to Taiwan. "I hope Taiwan will learn a lesson from the incident."

Tamazawa said the United Nations Security Council recently endorsed NATO attacks on Yugoslavia with a vote of 14-0 on grounds that Yugoslav ethnic cleansing in Kosovo had violated the UN human rights declaration.
Against this backdrop, Tamazawa said, mainland China will not have any legitimate reasons to attack Taiwan so long as Taiwan does not formally declare independence.
In that case, Tamazawa said, the United Nations will certainly support Taiwan. "This will also justify the UN and US intervention in cross-strait disputes," he noted.

Meanwhile, Tamazawa said he believes that so long as Taiwan does not pursue de jure independence, the United States will take necessary actions in accordance with its Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) when Taiwan's security is threatened.
"I'm convinced that Taiwan's security will be better protected if it does not seek outright independence," Tamazawa said.
The TRA is the US law regulating relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BANK SINOPAC SETS UP OFFICE IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Bank SinoPac opened a representative office in Hong Kong on Saturday to help tap business in the Asian-Pacific region.
Cheng An-Kuo, Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong, joined banking and finance officials and industry leaders from Hong Kong at the office's inauguration party.

SinoPac officials said that in the beginning, the representative office will not be fully operational. Instead it will focus on collecting information in hopes that it will be upgraded to branch status sometime soon.

Taiwan banks have come to Hong Kong to set up footholds in recent years despite the fact that several Japanese banks have withdrawn from the former British colony after the financial crisis that swept over the Asian region in mid-1997.

Six Taiwan banks have set up branches in Hong Kong. They are Bank of Taiwan, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Chinatrust Commercial Bank and International Bank of Taipei.

Seven Taiwan banks have set up representative offices in Hong Kong. They are SinoPac, E. Sun Bank, United World Chinese Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, The Medium Business Bank of Taiwan, Taipei Bank and Taishin International Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG HINTS AT PRESIDENTIAL RUN IN INTERVIEW WITH JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong expressed interest in running in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election during an exclusive interview with Asahi Shimbun, sources said on Saturday.

Soong said people have strong expectations of him at a time when Taiwan people are eager for change. Therefore, he said, he will not allow himself to let the people down. As he has done in the past, though, Soong refrained from saying explicitly whether he would run.

Speaking on how should Taiwan's next president should serve the country, Soong said people look forward to having a strong guide, but not a dictator. He said they want a practical, righteous and decent man who always pursues the public's happiness before his own.
Soong said he believes he has led in several polls because he is perceived by the people as being such a person.
Regarding the relationship between Taiwan and Japan, Soong urged Japan to engage itself more with Taiwan, as the two countries share the same national defense lines and interests.
Soong met with the former secretary-general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Koichi Kato, and Ichiro Ozawa, chief of the Liberal Party, during his Japan visit.

During the meeting, they agreed to take as a lesson the collapse of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to prevent mainland China from falling into chaos, and to regard Taiwan as an example of a country stepping toward a democratic society.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN KILLS CATTLE TO ELIMINATE FMD

TEXT.P: Although only two bulls were diagnosed with foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), an entire herd, totaling 65 head of cattle, at a ranch in Kinmen County was slaughtered early Saturday as part of government efforts to ensure Taiwan does not experience another FMD epidemic.
Veterinarians sealed off the "New Yao-chih" cattle farm, and took saliva and blood samples from the cattle before injecting them with barbiturates.
The carcasses were buried in a huge pit on the ranch. Health officials painstakingly lined the pit with a waterproof fabric before the carcasses were dumped into it.
They marked the burial site with lines and affixed a sign saying the pit should not be opened for any reason within three years.

They also sterilized the ranch where the disease originated and limited access to it for at least six months. During the six-month period, veterinarians will conduct regular checks to ensure that the virus does not resurface, said health officials.

A chief veterinarian from the Kinmen County Government said that since no other cattle on the island were found to have FMD, an earlier plan to vaccinate all cloven-hoofed livestock in Kinmen has been deemed unnecessary.
The country government, however, will intensively monitor the health of the 3,106 head of cattle on the island by recording their health examination results.
A ban on the slaughter of other cattle took effect on Saturday, to prevent the disease from spreading from cattle to the island's pigs, which share Kinmen's only abattoir with the cattle.
As a result, beef almost disappeared from the market on Saturday.

Kinmen cattle were found to have FMD on Thursday. Taiwan authorities have since imposed a ban on the import of Kinmen livestock, although health officials refused to declare Kinmen, an island 150 nautical miles to the west of Kaohsiung, as a FMD-affected area, because only a few cattle were found to have the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAICANG PROJECT NOT STOPPED: XIAMEN MAYOR

TEXT.P: The Haicang project initiated by the Taiwan-based Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in mainland China's Fujian province has not been stopped, but instead will focus on hi-tech sectors, Xiamen Mayor Hong Yongshi said on Saturday here.
Hong, who is currently visiting Taiwan at the invitation of FPG Chairman Y.C. Wang, said the FPG's Haicang project has never been stopped, despite the fact that it has been temporarily shelved.

FPG, Taiwan's petrochemical giant, launched a plan to build a thermo power plant in Haicang in mainland China's southern Fujian province, but was unable to carry out the plan because the Republic of China government still bans Taiwan businesses from investing in mainland Chinese infrastructure projects.
Against this background, Hong said the Haicang plan will no longer center on the petrochemical industry. Its focus has been shifted to hi-tech and sophisticated sectors, he said.
The FPG's Haicang project was submitted to Hong shortly after he assumed the Xiamen mayorship in 1992.
The Xiamen mayor made the remarks during a visit to the Mailiao Port in central Yunlin County, where FPG is building a sixth naphtha cracker plant.
Impressed by the plant's large scale, Hong said he believes that such an investment will undoubtedly benefit all of Taiwan society.

As to the question of whether he has reached any concrete agreement with FPG in regard to bilateral cooperation, Hong was reluctant to elaborate, saying only that the economies of Taiwan and mainland China are complementary in nature, and that he would welcome any cooperative venture between the two sides.
Hong, the leader of an eight-member delegation composed of Xiamen City government officials, arrived in Taiwan on Wednesday, and is slated to depart here on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW'S CABINET GETS LOW CREDIT AMONG COLLEGE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew's Cabinet has a low credit among local college students, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Saturday.

The telephone survey of 1,127 students randomly selected from local colleges and universities showed that the overall performance of Siew's Cabinet received a score of only 49.77 points on a zero-100 measurement scale.
Premier Siew's performance score was also low at 52.59 points, according to the poll.
The survey was conducted by the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology at the request of opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao.
Poll results showed that none of the ministries, councils and departments under the Executive Yuan managed to receive a "passing" score of 60 points.
The Council of Agriculture received the highest score of 57.67 points, while the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) got the lowest rating of 46.93 points.

A cross-analysis based on gender found that male students were most dissatisfied with the MOTC, the Environmental Protection Administration (51.13 points) and the Ministry of the Interior (51.29 points) in that order.
Meanwhile, female students were most dissatisfied with the MOTC, the Ministry of Education (50.97 points) and the Ministry of Finance (52.3 points).

Lai said the poll results indicate that college students are very concerned about issues related people's living or livelihood as they are generally most dissatisfied with the performance of agencies responsible for traffic, education, environmental protection, public order and crime.

Lai said college students will be a major source of votes in next year's presidential election. "I suggest that all presidential hopefuls pay more attention to these young opinion leaders," he said, adding that he believes Taiwan's future top leader should be concerned about domestic and livelihood issues as well as have vision, strength of character and capability to lead Taiwan to a new stage of national development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS URGE PEOPLE NOT TO PANIC AMID DIOXIN SCARE

TEXT.P: Food experts called on the public Saturday to avoid overreacting amid concern that dioxin-contaminated meat and dairy products from Belgium may have been imported, saying that people would have to consume a large amount of contaminated products for a long time to suffer any adverse effects.

In a seminar held by New Party Legislator Hau Long-ping to discuss how people should respond to potentially toxic dairy products, Professor Lin Yung-chien from the department of chemistry at National Tsinghua University said only sustained and massive consumption of toxic dairy products would result in a person being infected.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE SENATORS CALL FOR SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Jesse Helms, chairman of the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and two other senators on Friday sent letters to their colleagues, calling for their support for the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act introduced last March.
The letters, signed by Helms, Frank Murkowski and Robert Torricelli, stated that the threat to Taiwan from mainland China is on the rise.

Therefore, they said the United States should remain steadfast by continuing to meet its obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), by providing Taiwan with the means to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.
As of June 11, the bill has been co-sponsored by seven senators from the Democratic and the Republican Parties.
The Taiwan Security Enhancement Act contains three major thrusts:

-- Ensuring that Taiwan has the necessary equipment to maintain its self-defense capabilities as promised under the TRA, by authorizing the sale to Taiwan of a broad array of equipment and defensive weapons;

-- Bolstering the process for such sales to Taiwan by prohibiting politically motivated reductions in US arms sales, requiring an increase in staffing at the American Institute in Taiwan, and requiring an annual presidential report to Congress on Taiwan's defense needs; and

-- Redressing deficiencies in Taiwan's readiness by supporting increased Taiwanese participation at US military colleges, expanded military exchanges and joint training, and establishing direct communications between the two countries' militaries.
A similar bill introduced in the House of Representatives last May has received support from 18 congressmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN ENVOYS PROMOTE SPECIALTY CATAMONA COFFEE
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, June 12 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Envoys from the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America jointly sponsored a coffee trade fair in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung on Saturday.

Senior officials from the embassies or trade offices of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua introduced specialty Central American coffees at the trade fair held at Lee's Hotel in downtown Kaohsiung.
Among the specialties on display was Catamona coffee which was grown in volcanic regions and has an extremely pleasing flavor.
In addition to introducing Central American coffee specialties and the region's unique coffee culture, traditional Central American dances were also presented in the exhibition.
The show also featured exhibition of interior designs of stylish modern coffee shops and demonstrations of coffee-related customs.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh attended the presentation to throw his support behind the drive to promote sales of specialty Central American coffees.
The event was aimed at helping high-quality Central American coffees gain a foothold in Taiwan's ever-growing coffee-drinking market.
Although the number of coffee fans has increased rapidly in Taiwan in recent years, Central America, the world's fourth-largest coffee producing areas, has not had a large hold on the Taiwan market.
Local drinkers are familiar with Brazilian, Blue Mountain, Mocha, Java and Colombian coffees, but few of them know much about Central America's coffee specialties.
Mayor Hsieh said he hopes the show will help attract more Kaohsiung coffee drinkers to try tasty Central American coffees.

DOC.HEADLINE: WU CALLS FOR MORE BALANCED DISTRIBUTION OF POLITICAL RESOURCES

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang vice presidential hopeful on Saturday called for more balanced distribution of political resources among different ethnic groups.
Wu Poh-hsiung, a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, made the appeal at a seminar on balanced development of ethnic groups in the 21st century.

Wu, a popular Hakka politician who once served as Taipei mayor, interior minister and KMT secretary-general, said if political resources are not distributed in proportion to demographic structure, minority ethnic groups will become increasingly disgruntled in the long run.
In the past, Wu said the government was anxious to promote mandarin Chinese among local people. As a result, mother tongues of minority ethnic groups here had been suppressed.
"Thanks to Taiwan's democratization, the situation has improved," Wu said, adding that nowadays, Taiwanese dialect and grassroots folk culture have received much attention and promotion.
However, Wu said, mother tongues and folk cultures of Hakka and aboriginal tribal groups have received far less attention.
"Today, we see a large number of Taiwanese-language programs on television, while TV programs featuring Hakka and aboriginal languages remain few," Wu noted.
Wu said he is worried that long-term disregard of Hakka and aboriginal languages and cultures may restrict these groups' access to political and economic resources.
"I hope to see more balanced cultural preservation and allocation of political and economic resources among various ethnic groups on this island," Wu said.
Nevertheless, Wu, a devout Buddhist follower, said he would not like to see conflicts or rifts among different ethnic groups simply because of political competition.
Wu has made no secret his intention to seek the KMT's nomination as its vice presidential candidate in next year's presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
ROC partaking Balkans reconstructions through international bodies.
The China Times:
Indonesia's ruling party admits defeat in elections.
