DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 13, or the 30th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
323 BC: Alexander the Great, king of Macedonia who came to the throne at the age of only 20 and conquered Persia, Egypt, Babylon, Central Asia and part of India, dies in Babylon at the age of 33 upon his return from India.
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1842: Queen Victoria becomes the first British monarch to travel by train when she takes a trip from Slough to Paddington.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1893: The first women's golf championship is held at Royal Lytham in Britain and is won by Lady Margaret Scott.
1900: A group of volunteer soldiers known as the Boxers go on the rampage through Beijing in protest against the "foreign devils" who have such a hold on their country. Popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by the unequal treaties combined to spark what becomes known as the Boxer Uprising.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under shock attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1957: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1988: The Soviet Union holds its first beauty contest.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of leaders of the demonstration in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1990: East Germany begins the final demolition of the Berlin Wall, which was built in 1961.
1994: The foreign ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit UN nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years from unauthorized copper trade.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-POLAND ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFAB TO OPEN IN TAIPEI MONDAY

TEXT.P: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference is scheduled to open Monday in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.

The conference will be jointly presided over by Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), and Miroslaw Kuklinski, a Polish parliamentarian who is familiar with foreign trade and relations, said officials from the Euro-Asia Trade Organization (EATO), which is sponsoring the event.

During the one-day conference, Kuklinski, who is also an influential member of the Poland-Taiwan Friendship Committee under the Parliament of Poland, will deliver a keynote speech on how to accelerate bilateral trade ties between Poland and the Republic of China (ROC).
Adam Pawlowicz, director of the Foreign Investment Bureau of Poland, will also deliver a speech on bilateral business and trade exchanges between the two countries.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Cho Shih-chao, deputy director-general of the ROC Industrial Development and Investment Center, will also make speeches on behalf of the government of the Republic of China, which maintains no formal diplomatic relations with Poland.

EATO and the Polish Chamber of Commerce, the co-sponsor of the conference, decided to hold this year's meeting on June 14 to coincide with Eurogate '99, an Eastern and Central European trade exposition in Taipei that is jointly sponsored by CETRA and the ROC ministries of foreign affairs and economic affairs, said EATO officials.

Delegates from Hungary and the Czech Republic who are now in Taipei taking part in Eurogate '99 will also be invited to the Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference so as to allow Taiwan businessmen greater opportunities to gain better understanding of trade prospects and economic climate in Eastern and Central Europe, the officials said.
At the top of the conference agenda is discussions concerning a proposed Taiwan industrial processing zone to be developed in Poland by the Taipei-based Acelon Chemicals and Fiber Corp.
Acelon will finance the development of the zone, which is a 133-hectare tract located in a now defunct state-run textile plant compound, some 100 kilometers from the Polish capital of Warsaw.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Poland amounted to US$321.90 million in 1998, with Taiwan enjoying a surplus of US$152.90 million.
Poland is currently the second largest trading partner of Taiwan in Eastern and Central Europe behind Hungary.

In addition to organizing large-scale Taiwan trade missions to Poland over the last three years, CETRA, Taiwan's top foreign trade arm, also chose Warsaw last year as the location of Taiwan's first trade center in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS WU POH-HSIUNG AS FAVORED VEEP HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: Senior Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung is the most popular choice as a running mate of two presidential hopefuls in the 2000 election, a recent poll of public opinion showed.

The survey, conducted by Taiwan Politics Poll Center, found that former Taiwan Governor James Soong remains the most popular presidential candidate, followed by Vice President Lien Chan, and former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, in that order.
If both Soong and Lien take part in the presidential election, the best running mate for either of them would be Wu Poh-hsiung, the poll found.

The poll of 3,000 owners and/or executives of private social groups around Taiwan found that 38 percent would throw their support behind Soong to be president of the Republic of China. Thirty-three percent would support Lien, 27 percent would vote for Chen, while only 2 percent would choose Hsu Hsin-liang, former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman.

A high of 70 percent said Wu Poh-hsiung, who has also served as Taipei mayor and as minister of the interior, would be the best running mate for either Soong or Lien, if both participate in next spring's race.

If it is impossible for Wu to run on a ticket with Soong, the survey found the next best options for Soong include former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, and lawyer Wang Ching-feng.

If it is impossible for Wu to be part of a Lien ticket, Lien should consider Examination President Hsu Shui-teh, Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, and former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, in that order.
The poll showed that Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu is the most suitable running mate for DPP presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian.

Wu Poh-hsiung, a popular Hakka politician, has made public his intention to seek the KMT's nomination as its vice presidential candidate in next year's election. The ruling KMT has apparently decided to field Vice President Lien Chan as the sole presidential candidate.

Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, also a senior KMT member, may jump into the race as an independent candidate. "The decision (to run) was made, and there is no turning back," said Soong Saturday upon returning to Taiwan after a visit to Japan.
The survey, conducted by telephone between June 4 and 11, totaled 15,37 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD ALLOW PARTIAL DEMOCRATIZATION: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China should "allow democratization for a segment of its people", particularly those who live in urban areas, before expanding democratization to rural regions, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi Sunday.
Su made the remarks during a cable television interview Sunday morning.

The mainland government's so-called "basic-level elections" are restricted to rural areas only, the people do not possess freedom of speech or the right to organize political parties. There is still a long way from true democracy, Su said.

On the other hand, the economies of coastal cities have developed rapidly, because the people enjoy more knowledge and wealth, he said, adding that mainland authorities should allow urban citizens to democratize before further expanding it to rural parts.
Once mainland China has achieved overall democratization, Su said, its politics, economy and society will possess long-term stability, and only then will cross-strait relations receive new progress.

In response to questions on cross-strait dialogue, Su said an end to mutual hostility, Taiwan's role in the international community and the three links are the mainland's priority concerns at present, as well as highly sensitive political issues.

If the mainland wants to address these issues, Su said, the Republic of China (ROC) would comply. However, Taiwan's most pressing concerns are investment protection and cooperative measures against crime, smuggling, fishing disputes and illegal immigrants, said Su.
The ROC wishes to resolve these problems first since they are directly pertinent to Taiwan citizens' interests, Su said.

In addition, Su said "ending the state of hostility" should not be the title of cross-strait negotiations, but rather a result . It must be achieved through concrete step-by-step measures to strengthen mutual trust in order to reach a real conclusion to hostility.

Su also pointed out three ways to increase mutual trust across the strait. The first is to increase communication, especially between top-level officials of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Second, Taiwan and the mainland should hold official talks on specific issues, and sign as many agreements as both sides can achieve, to gradually build trust.
Finally, both sides must make sure agreements signed in the past are put into actual practice.

Su said mainland China has not been scrupulous in fulfilling past agreements. For example, he said, according to the Kinmen Agreement signed in 1990, the mainland government is supposed to extradite mainland stowaways arrested by Taiwan authorities within 20 days.
But according to Taiwan statistics, mainland China allows an average of 130 days before extraditing their stowaways, adding a large burden, financially and otherwise, to the ROC, Su said.
Mainland China might have difficulties practicing these agreements, Su said, but its failure to keep its side of the agreement lowers mutual trust over the long run.
"It is our belief that anyone who obstructs the practice of bilateral agreements is the true destroyer of cross-strait relations," Su said.
In reply to relations between the SEF and ARATS, Su said the two organizations used to be on rather amiable terms, but verbal and actual threats from mainland China have affected the relationship.
Lately the SEF and ARATS have rebuilt their relationship, this year's relationship exceeds last year's, and next year will exceed this year's; making the future outlook "positive," said Su.

In response to mainland China's possible interference in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, Su replied firmly that due to Taiwan voter's high education level, autonomy, participatory will and voting rate, if the mainland were to repeat past intervention, it would "pay a price."
Su said he believed mainland China would not make the same mistake again.
Su emphasized that peaceful and stable cross-strait relations cannot be attained through direct political negotiations or by ending mutual hostility, but rather through a gradual process.

He also pointed out that even though there are no war-preventive measures between the two sides, the ROC has already abolished the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion, restructured its military force and reduced its national defense budget.

President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew have brought forth measures to create cross-strait military trust. Those, including Lee's "Journey of Peace" proposal, are all in the hope of cultivating mutual trust.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS RATTLE NORTHERN AND EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau on Sunday released a torrential rain warning to the northern and eastern areas of Taiwan after detecting a moisture front passing over the island.

Weathermen said the typical rainy-season front, will soak the entire northern region, adding that as of Sunday morning, Yangminshan had received more than 50 millimeters of precipitation while Taipei absorbed over 30 mm of downpour.
The rain will continue until Monday. The forecasters predicted that beginning Tuesday, Taiwan will be again be covered by the heat and dryness of tropical summer weather.

The Sunday rainfall lowered northern Taiwan's day temperature to 28 Celsius degrees from 35 degrees on Saturday. Southern parts of Taiwan had readings of 31 Celsius degrees on Sunday, according to the nation's weather bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HIGH-RANKING FINANCIAL OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR ECONOMIC TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Tim Geithner, US undersecretary for international affairs at the Department of Treasury, is scheduled to visit Taiwan in late July for the forth Taipei-Washington sub-Cabinet economic dialogue.
The US delegation will be headed by Chairman Richard Bush of the American Institute in Taipei, according to officials in Washington.

According to a preliminary plan, the dialogue will start on July 21 in Taipei under the joint presidency of Geithner and his Taiwan counterpart. However, the officials added that Washington has yet to confirm the date.
Scheduled members of the American mission will include officials involved in finance, commerce and trade, as well as officials from the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
It is still uncertain whether or not working-level officials from the Department of State will join in the Taipei dialogue.

The 37-year-old Geithner, who holds a master's degree in international economy and East Asian research from the Johns Hopkins University, is known as a workaholic in the Treasury Department. He was promoted to his current position last December after serving in the department for 11 years.
Regular economic dialogue between the Republic of China on Taiwan and the United States was established after President Bill Clinton's Taiwan policy review in 1994.
When the two sides opened the first talks in Washington in June, 1995, they agreed to put the economic meetings on a trial basis for three years.
In 1997 the second meeting was suspended. The third dialogue opened last May in Washington, during which the two sides agreed to continue the talks.

In the 1998 meeting the two sides discussed macro-economic issues, the state of Asian financial systems, financial management and liberalization, trade and investment, as well as economic crime prevention measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION OF TAIWAN PROMOTES 'FAST TO HELP'
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A "fast to help" drive will be staged in Taichung next week to raise funds for famine-stricken people around the world.

World Vision of Taiwan (WVT) is scheduled to sponsor the fast in downtown Taichung on June 18, Dragon Boat Festival Day, to allow Taiwan people to understand the feeling of hunger, and at the same time to contribute the money saved from the fast to hungry people, WVT staff said on Sunday.

WVT wants materially affluent Taiwan residents to experience a different Dragon Boat Festival Day -- a traditional Chinese festival observed by holding dragon boat races, eating rice dumplings or tsungtse, and playing Chinese riddles -- by being hungry for one day.
WVT, one of Taiwan's major charity organizations, has in previous years sponsored 30-hour fasts islandwide to raise funds to help famine-stricken or materially deprived people in the Third World.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMPLE ROOM FOR TAIPEI AND TOKYO TO COOPERATE, SAYS MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: While citing factors hindering sisterhood ties, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Sunday there is still ample room for Taipei and Tokyo to cooperate in a wide variety of fields.

Ma cited the two factors hampering the two capital cities from establishing closer ties as the different political climates existing currently in the Republic of China and Japan and the lack of formal diplomatic relations between the countries.
This factors, however, should not be barriers to Taipei and Tokyo for further bolstering economic and cultural exchanges.

Ma made the statement when responding to remarks made by newly-elected Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who reportedly said on Saturday that Tokyo has no intention of establishing sisterhood ties with Taipei.
Ma said promoting city diplomacy is the established policy of the Taipei City Government, and the policy has not been altered under his administration.

He said he fully understands that there is no guarantee such efforts will work out smoothly in every case, particularly between Taipei and Tokyo. The Japanese capital is especially conservative in affairs involving Taiwan, Japan and mainland China.

Ma acknowledged that he has invited Ishihara to visit Taipei and expressed the Taipei city government's intention to forge sisterhood ties with Tokyo when Ishihara was elected governor of Tokyo in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLUENCING MAINLAND CHINA IS PRESENT PRIORITY: PRES. LEE

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) President Lee Teng-hui said on Sunday that influencing mainland China is Taiwan's present priority as he called upon Taiwan citizens to stand together in creating a brighter future for the 1.2 billion mainland Chinese.
Lee was invited to speak at the National Taipei University of Technology graduation ceremony Sunday morning.
During his speech, he digressed from his prepared notes to defend his massive aid pledge to Macedonia.

Lee said he used to harbor a deep sense of "sorrow for being a Taiwanese," but "the tragic history of the past has transformed into a multi-fold of bliss." He urged everyone to understand Taiwan's history and treasure today's accomplishments.
Using a love for Taiwan as a starting point, Lee encouraged everyone to strive to create a "beautiful future" for the country and it people.
In the past, education was aimed at teaching students how to "do things," but now education should be focused on teaching them how to think, especially about challenging issues, he said.

In addition, the president said that people should throw away traditional thinking and behavior. Lee cited large business corporations that have gone out of business due to their inability to change, and small companies have been able to change the world because they know how to think.

He used America's Microsoft software company to illustrate his point, saying that while the company is thriving now, it has to constantly retain a sense of crisis. Without knowing how to handle challenges, Microsoft would be overtaken by small companies that know how to deal with emergencies.
He encouraged the graduating class to realize their responsibilities and to acknowledge they have a duty to create a brighter future for themselves and for their country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AERONAUTIC COMPANIES SHINE IN PARIS AIR SHOW

TEXT.P: Four Taiwan aeronautic companies are currently displaying Taiwan's progress in aerospace development at the 43rd Paris Air Show.
The Paris Air Show opened Saturday with French President Jacques Chirac's welcoming speech. There are 1,884 companies from 40 countries participating in the nine-day exhibition.

Fan Che-ning, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) official in charge of local exhibitions, said this year's participating companies represent only a small fraction of the Republic of China's (ROC) aerospace industry.
These companies are here not only to exhibit Taiwan's strength in aerospace development, Fan said, but also to seek technological cooperation with foreign companies.

Another member of the Taiwan delegation, the Aerospace Industry Promotion Committee (AIPC), which is organizing an international aerospace industry conference in Taipei in August, is developing contacts with major international aerospace companies to beef up the Taipei conference.

After years of government support and research by the private sector, Fan said, the ROC's aerospace industry has achieved swift progress, gaining a stronghold in the international airplane parts market. Its future looks positive, said added.

The biennial Paris Air Show has 200 of the newest airplane prototypes from major companies on display and daily performances by 70 airplanes. More than 500,000 viewers are expected over the nine days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG RESUMES GRASS-ROOT ACTIVITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, central Taiwan, June 13 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, an announced candidate in next spring's presidential election, on Sunday resumed his grass-root activities immediately after returning from a trip to Japan.
Soong returned to Taipei on Saturday and came to Chiayi Sunday morning to attend the funeral of Lee Chun-sheng, father of Chiayi Magistrate Lee Ya-ching.

Lee Ya-ching is an influential figure in local political arena, and, therefore, his father's funeral drew many political heavyweights, including Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng and Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General John Chang.
Soong, who is still a KMT standing committee member, avoided openly announcing his candidacy by saying he would continue to see old friends.

Several recent public opinion surveys indicate Soong has taken the lead in the presidential race over three other prospective contenders -- Lien Chan (KMT), former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.
As part of his warm-up activities, Soong visited the Philippines, the United States and Japan in the past few weeks, to state his political ideas and to meet with local political leaders.

During his five-day visit to Japan on June 8-12 at the invitation of the Japan Alumni Association of the University of California, Berkeley, he gave two lectures and was interviewed by the mass-circulation Asahi Shimbun.

Soong also held talks with several influential Japanese political leaders, including former Prime Ministers Tsutomu Hata and Toshiki Kaifu, Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura, Liberty Party chief Ichiro Ozawa and former Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Koichi Kato.
Upon his return to Taipei on Saturday, Soong said that he would not travel to foreign countries in the immediate future, and would instead turn his energy to grass-root activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON ROC FIRST LADY'S PLAN TO VISIT PRAGUE: WU

TEXT.P: Roy Wu, the Republic of China's (ROC) new representative to the Czech Republic, on Sunday declined to comment on a local newspaper report that President Lee Teng-hui's wife Tseng Wen-fui will visit Prague in the near future.
The newspaper said that Tseng will visit the Czech Republic and other European countries, and that Wu will assume his new duty ahead of schedule in order to arrange Tseng's visit.
When asked about the matter, Wu said that as his appointment was announced on April 8, his plans to leave for Prague on June 20 is normal procedure.
On the reported plan for the first lady to visit Prague, Wu said, "I have no comment."
Prague has no diplomatic relations with the ROC, but takes a friendly posture toward Taipei.

Czech President Vaclav Havel has openly voiced his support for the ROC to participate in United Nations activities. Mrs. Havel has visited Taipei, and ROC Vice President Lien Chan has made a "private" trip to Prague.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORT COMPETITIVENESS WEAKENING: TIER REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export competitiveness has been continually weakening since the outbreak of the Asian financial crisis in mid-1997, a report of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) indicated on Sunday.

The weakness is particularly obvious in Taiwan's market share and business competitiveness in Japan and the United States, according to the report. Local exporters are advised to improve product quality and lower costs, as well as to work harder to increase market share and collect trade information.
The TIER report analyzed the exports of 10 eastern Asian countries to the world's four major import markets -- the United States, Japan, mainland China, and the European Union as a whole.

TIER statistics show that in 1998 the total market share of Asian countries in mainland China reached 56.27 percent. They enjoyed a 36.47 percent market stake in the US market, 34.89 percent in Japan, and 5.35 percent in the EU market.
Eastern Asian economies' market share in both the US and Japan registered drops after the Asian financial meltdown, the TIER said.

According to the report, Taiwan's exports to Japan sustained the largest drop. The drop was mainly a result of Japan's economic slowdown and the suffering caused by the Asian financial storm, both of which shrunk Japan's external demands, the report analyzed.

Taiwan's exports to the American and mainland markets have been reduced since the start of the regional financial crisis, due to the fact that Taiwan has faced stronger challenges than other competitors, the report said.
The report suggested local export companies move into the EU market, which represents a new market to be explored and developed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT WANG ZECHEN DETAINED

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Wang Zechen, organizer of the Liaoning provincial branch of the outlawed "China Democracy Party," has been "formally" detained on charges of "endangering state security," a dissident group in Hong Kong said Sunday.

The Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China quoted a member of Wang's family as saying that he was picked up by police on May 20, when he and a number of other dissidents were planning to observe the 10th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen military crackdown on June 4.
The information center said that his family received on Saturday a notice of his "formal detention," indicating that he might be convicted.

Liao Shihua, a worker of an automobile electrical parts manufacturing company in Changsha, capital of Hunan province, was also "formally" detained Saturday, because he organized workers laid off by state-run enterprises and other kinds of people for petitioning to the Hunan Provincial Government, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA WILL INSPECT ALL CLOVEN-FOOTED ANIMALS THIS WEEK FOR FMD

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will convene an islandwide meeting on Monday to discuss the inspection of Taiwan's cattle, sheep and goats in a bid to discover if domestic animals are infected with the deadly food-and-mouth disease (FMD).
FMD epidemics occurred throughout mainland China in May. The disease there reportedly affected not only pigs but other cloven-hoofed animals, including cattle, sheep, goats and even camels.
The new strain of FMD is very troubling for COA officials as it, unlike the strain two years ago that didn't infect cattle, sheep and goats, can be spread to all cloven-hoofed animals.

COA officials said that they are not worried that cattle in Taiwan have become infected by the Kinmen FMD strain. Instead, they fear that cattle from mainland China may have been smuggled into Taiwan through Kinmen.
Some 295 head of Kinmen cattle were shipped to Taiwan between January and May of this year. All were delivered to slaughterhouses in Tainan County and Panchiao, Taipei County.

On May 25 the COA began an all-out inspection of cattle, sheep and goats on the offshore Kinmen, Penghu and Matsu islands in an attempt to prevent the spread of FMD. During that inspection two oxen on Kinmen's Hsin Yao Chi Range were found to be infected with the disease.

The identification of the FMD virus in the two Kinmen oxen prompted quarantine officials from Taiwan to slaughter and bury on June 11 all 45 head of cattle on the Hsin Yao Chi Range in an attempt to eradicate the highly contagious disease.

COA officials said that prior to this week's inspection of domestic cattle, sheep and goats, COA officials would not give vaccine injections in order to prevent the animals from producing antibodies, causing the inspection results to be inaccurate.
The COA has adopted a policy of deterrence, that is to say, once a new case of FMD is found, the infected animal will soon be isolated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 14, or the first day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1645: Parliamentary troops under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell inflict a heavy defeat on Prince Rupert's Royalist forces at Nasby in the English Midlands, scoring a decisive Parliamentary victory in the Civil War.
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1789: After drifting an incredible 3,500 miles in an open boat, English Admiral Captain Bligh and 18 royal crew members, cast adrift from HMS Bounty, eventually reaching the island of Timor in the East Indies.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Columbian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris and the swastika flag is hoisted on the Eiffel tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: A Japan Airlines DC-8 crashes at Delhi airport, killing 87 people.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
1997: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan announces that the government will establish a Ministry of Culture.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES POST SLIGHT DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices dropped 0.1 percent Monday as stocks failed to surpass the 8,000-point level after investors gathered in profits from the previous trading session.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 5.82 points to close at 7,973.58 points.
A total of 2.12 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$114.78 billion (US$3.54 billion), down from the previous session's NT$162.41 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, the financial sector suffered the largest setback of the day, falling 1.6 percent, while construction shares, with a 1.9 percent rise, enjoyed the session's largest gain.
Cement issues rose 0.7 percent, electronics shares advanced 1 percent, while paper and pulp stocks remained static.
Foodstuff shares fell 0.2 percent, plastic and chemical stocks declined 1.1 percent, and the textile sector went down 1.4 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market suffered a 1.91-point drop, ending the day at 178.24 points, with a turnover of NT$5.68 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June gained 15 points to close at 7,975 points, with 1,284 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July climbed 26 points to close at 7,985 points, while those for September increased 20 points, closing at 7,977. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 1,248 and 17, respectively.
December futures fell 20 points, ending the day at 8,000 points with 13 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March's futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,960 points for June, 7,958 points for July, 7,957 points for September, 8,020 points for December, and 8,030 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAO, DENG LISTED AMONG CENTURY'S GREAT POLITICAL LEADERS

TEXT.P: Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping have been listed by a leading Australian newspaper as being among the greatest political leaders this century.

The Weekend Australian published a list of the 10 greatest political leaders this century in terms of their effect on the largest number of people over the longest period of time. List members are Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Ronald Reagan and Teddy Roosevelt of the United States; Vladimir Lenin, Joseph Stalin and Mikhail Gorbachev of Russia; Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping of mainland China; Adolf Hitler and Winston Churchill of Europe; and Mahatma Gandhi of India.

The list, compiled by respected columnist and foreign editor of the Australian Greg Sheridan, contains 12 names instead of 10 because he said it is impossible to omit any of the 12 and understand the shape of our century.

He ranked Roosevelt as the greatest leader of the century because he restored confidence to the United States with his strong determination and elan after being confronted with the Depression. He also overcame US distaste for European wars to commit the United States to World War II and ensured the defeat of Nazism.

Mao, meanwhile, gave birth to Asian communism and effective Chinese independence. But Deng is perhaps a more important figure because he, much more than Mao, began the vast task of modernizing mainland China, a process of incalculable consequence, Sheridan said.
Truman was named to the list because of his decision to use the atom bomb against Japan and for efforts to reconstruct Europe after World War II.

Reagan was credited with ending the Cold War and recasting US domestic politics, Sheridan said. As for Teddy Roosevelt, he created the modern United States and was the first president to conceive of the United States as a great global power.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MINISTER TARGETS LAWYERS HELPING BOAT PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Australia, alarmed by a growing influx of boat people, is now attacking Australian lawyers who perform legal services for them.

Australian police and Coastwatch on Sunday intercepted two Indonesian fishing boats carrying 86 suspected illegal immigrants at a reef off the northwest coast of Australia in the Timor Sea. So far this year a total of 35 boats carrying more than 1,500 illegal migrants have been seized and detained.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said it is the capacity of Australian law firms to delay the repatriation of refugees that helps make Australia an attractive destination for illegal immigrants, according to Glenn Milne, political writer for The Australian.
The daily reported that Ruddock has now gone on the offensive by referring the ethics and practices of one legal firm to both the Law Society and Migration Agents Registration Authority.
He said many of the illegal mainland Chinese landing on Australian shores may simply be common criminals. In other words, they are not duped innocents, the daily reported.
This makes the behavior of the Australian law firms who then set about representing these refugees even more suspect because their arrival means more business for the lawyers, the daily reported.
The daily reported such law firms seek clients through the ethnic Australian press -- particularly within communities where it is known there are a high proportion of illegals.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MISSILES CAN HIT US HEARTLAND, SAYS REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese missiles can now reach the heart of the United States after breakthrough technological developments, the Hong Kong Standard reported Monday.
Before the new developments, mainland missiles could reach only the US West Coast.
The report quoted mainland sources as saying that the development has reduced the technology gap with the United States from between 15-20 years to 5-10 years.
And it is now possible to target hundreds of missiles at once at the middle portion of the United States, the sources revealed.

The sources reportedly said the People's Liberation Army (PLA) had developed technology to use solidified fuel in missiles, enabling troops to point several hundred missiles at targets in the middle of the United States with high accuracy.
According to the report, in the past, mainland China had only 18 to 24 warheads ready for action, despite having the capacity for more, because of technological and financial constraints.
In addition, the PLA has evolved the technology to launch missiles from a moving launching base with high accuracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM SEES RELEASE OF TWO AID WORKERS DETAINED IN YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer predicted the release of two aid workers in Yugoslavia was imminent following the march of UN peacekeeping forces into Kosovo.

Downer told reporters on Sunday that Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace of CARE Australia -- the largest relief agency in Australia -- would be released in "the not too distant future" following promising developments in the case of the two men, jailed for spying against Yugoslavia.

Downer said Greek Foreign Minister Georgios Papandreou had met officials in Belgrade over the weekend to push Australia's case after Pratt's pregnant wife -- Samira -- was permitted for the first time last Friday to visit her husband in his Belgrade cell.
Downer said he was prepared to visit Belgrade to help free the two workers if it would make "a quantum difference."

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE COMMUNIST LEADERS AGAIN UNDER THREAT OF ARREST

TEXT.P: The Philippine government is now preparing warrants for the arrest of communist leaders, who have lost their immunity from arrest and prosecution due to the termination of peace talks between the government and the National Democratic Front (NDF).
Secretary Serafin Cuevas of the Department of Justice said his office is now working with the Philippine National Police (PNP) and National Bureau of Investigation to prepare the arrest warrants.
"This service of warrants of arrest will only be covering those involved in the peace treaty negotiations. They do not involve other members of other insurgent groups," Cuevas said.

He explained the Joint Agreement on Safety and Immunity Guarantees (JASIG), which had bestowed on these communist leaders immunity from arrest and prosecution, became void after the end of peace talks.

Because of the talks, Cuevas said, NDF leaders with standing arrest warrants had been extended immunity guarantees during the peace negotiations. But they will now find themselves again subject to arrest.

"Those who have been granted exemptions and have been enjoying the same, and by virtue of the slashing or cutting of their privileges, they will be the ones subjected to arrest. Only those who have standing warrants previously or earlier issued against them," would be under threat of arrest, he said.

The government and the NDF, an umbrella organization of all left-leaning groups in the country, held talks last month. The NDF terminated the negotiations in the wake of ratification by the Senate of the Philippine-US Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA).
But while it terminated the JASIG along with the peace negotiations, the government has given NDF leaders a month's grace period before it serves the warrants of arrest.
The government is now considering holding peace talks with other communist leaders at the regional level.

Also, the government is mulling an order to the PNP to help the armed forces of the Philippines carry out counter-insurgency operations. Last weekend, President Joseph Ejercito Estrada reiterated that the government would go after NDF members who have insisted on violating the constitution.
Estrada added the government is now asserting its authority over the NDF, making it clear that there is only one government and one constitution in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE TO SLOW COMMISSIONING OF F-16 WINGS

TEXT.P: The ROC Air Force has decided to slow the commissioning of its F-16 jet fighter wings and will prolong F-16 pilot training to enhance their capability to operate the highly advanced warplanes, a senior official said on Monday.
The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) made the decision after three of its F-16 fighters crashed during routine training flights over the past year.

The AFGH official said Defense Minister Tang Fei, who once served as air force commander-in-chief, has ordered the air force to conduct a thorough review of the replacement of its fleet with F-16 fighters and related manpower training programs. In response to Tang's directives, the official said, air force authorities have decided to extend the F-16 pilots' mandatory training period from the current six months to eight months. "The extended training is aimed at helping the trainees get more familiarized with the US-made fighter and upgrading their ability to operate the high-performance warplane," noted the official, who preferred anonymity.

The ROC Air Force struck a deal with the United States in 1992 for purchasing 150 F-16s as part of its military modernization plan. the Air Force plans to form two F-16 wings, one stationed in the Chiayi air base in southern Taiwan and the other in the Hualien air base in eastern Taiwan.
The Chiayi wing comprises four squadrons and three of them have so far been commissioned, while the Hualien wing will have three squadrons and only one has entered services for combat preparedness.

Noting that F-16 is a multifunctional, all-weather, high-performance warplane, the AFGH official said it can not only intercept enemy plane at high altitude but also can conduct air-to-surface attacks. Its myriad functions, however, have increased risks in operating the plane, the official said.

The official conceded that the Air Force has adopted intensive training courses in cultivating F-16 pilots as it hopes to replace its aging fleet with the new second-generation warplanes as soon as possible.

"However, we have come to understand that it needs accumulation of practical experiences to operate high-performance warplanes like F-16s," the official said, adding that the Air Force is determined to intensify manpower training, including both combat skill and strategic training.
In addition, the official said, the Air Force will conduct an extensive check and review of the F-16 mechanical system and various components.

"We hope our twofold efforts will help enhance flight safety and beef up our air defense capabilities," the official said, adding that the delay in completing the commissioning of F-16 wings is not expected to affect the country's combat readiness because the replacement of two other types of second-generation warplanes -- the locally developed Ching-kuo Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs) and the French-made Mirage 2000-5s -- has proceeded smoothly.
"At present, we still can maintain our air supremacy in the Taiwan Strait," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CONFIRMS 2ND RANCH INFECTED WITH FMD IN KINMAN

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) convened an emergency meeting on Monday to deal with the FMD situation on the offshore island of Kinmen as a second ranch there was reported to have been infected with the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

COA officials after confirming that the Shao Ser Fu ranch has been infected with FMD, demanded that all 45 cattle on the ranch be slaughtered following the example after the outbreak on the Hsin Yao Chih ranch last week.
The COA has also decided to conduct FMD tests on all 3,000 head of cattle on Kinmen, the officials said.

Lee Chin-lung, deputy director of COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that the COA conducted random FMD checks on four Kinman ranches, including Shao Ser Fu and Hsin Yao Chih in late May. It is rumored that the four ranches have frequently smuggled cattle in from mainland China.

Lee said that according to regulations governing the prevention of communicable disease among animals, the entire cattle population of affected ranches will be exterminated and that cattle on nearby ranches will be closely monitored for movement in order to deter the spread of FMD.
He also announced a series of emergency measures to stop FMD from spreading to Taiwan.

The measures include continued random checking on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu islands, the testing of animals along the route from Kinmen into Taiwan, the testing of cattle and goats on ranches near slaughter houses and examinations of animals on ranches located near the coast that may have been have smuggled in from the mainland.
The COA has asked that virus samples taken from infected cattle on Kinmen be brought to a FMD laboratory in Britain for analysis so as to find a suitable vaccine.
Professor Lai Hsiu-huei of National Taiwan University said that the FMD strain in Kinmen is different from the FMD strain found in hog population two years ago.
The new strain of FMD is a big worry to COA officials as it, unlike the strain two years ago that didn't infect cattle, sheep and goats, can be spread to all cloven-hoofed animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS JAPANESE LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that the Japanese parliament's approval of the new Japan-US Defense Cooperation Guidelines will benefit Japan and contribute to security and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

Lee made the remarks while meeting with Tokuichiro Tamazawa, a senior member of Japan's House of Representatives who arrived in Taipei last Friday to attend a seminar on Asian security and relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Noting that Taiwan sits on an important strategic point, Lee said the Republic of China has played a pivotal role in Asian security.
"The ROC government and people have offered indispensable strength in safeguarding peace, democracy and prosperity in the region, particularly peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait," Lee said.
In response, Tamazawa, who once served as director-general of the Japanese Defense Agency, lauded Lee for his vision and concern about the Asia-Pacific situation and development.
Tamazawa also praised Taiwan's decision to offer US$300 million in aid to Kosovars, describing the generous aid package as a wise and forward-looking move.

The former Japanese defense official said problems related to the recent Kosovo crisis are common concerns of the international community. "The ROC's aid offer has caught world attention and won much respect," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC DENIES TAIWAN TO SELL GOLD RESERVES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) is neither under necessity, nor will it sell its gold reserves, said an official of the Issue Dept. of the CBC of the Republic of China on Monday.
The official refuted reports that the CBC intends to sell its gold stock in response to world gold prices dropping 10 percent since early May.

The recent plunge of the price of gold was triggered by concern the International Monetary Fund (IMF) intends to sell as much as 10 million ounces of its gold stock to finance debt relief for some of the world's poorest countries.
The IMF reportedly holds about 103 million ounces of gold, the second-largest stockpile in the world, following the US.

A ranking official at the CBC's Issue Dept. pointed out that in the wake of the UK's decision to sell 415 tons of its gold stock over the next several years, the central banks of several other countries have followed suit. The mass sell-off has resulted in a current price of less than US$260 per ounce.

Since Taiwan is not an IMF member, remarked a CBC official, its gold should be held in reserve in case there are future financial crises. Thus the CBC has no necessity to sell its gold reserves, the official added.
At the end of May, the CBC held about 13.57 million ounces of gold reserves, according to latest statistics of CBC's Issue Dept.
Although gold prices have fluctuated heavily in recent years, the CBC did not purchase or sell any gold reserves during that period, stressed the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP TO FOUR-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: A dramatic fluctuation was seen on currency trading in Taipei Monday, with the New Taiwan dollar posting a modest gain of NT$0.032 against the greenback, closing at a four-month high of 32.427.
The local unit opened at 32.457 and was traded between 32.483 and 32.400. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$555 million.
The NT dollar has experienced gains against the US dollar for six consecutive sessions, with appreciation totaling NT$0.315. Over the six sessions, US dollar turnover totaled US$4.635 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE BLASTED FOR SLOPPY HANDLING OF OVERSEAS SCHOOL SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A group of legislators on Monday blasted the Ministry of Education (MOE) for alleged sloppy handling of the resignation of the president of the Taipei School in Ho Chi Minh City, southern Vietnam.

Legislator Lee Ching-an (KMT-Taipei City) said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission that the ministry should not have allowed Chao Yen-wei, president of the Taipei School in Ho Chi Minh City, to resign before his adultery-related scandal is clarified.

Chao was accused of having an affair with Shao Mei-ling, a former teacher at the school. In the company of Legislator Lee, Shao's former husband called a news conference early this month, during which time he accused Shao of having Chao's baby while they were still married.

In response to Lee's criticism, Education Vice Minister Wu Ching-chi said upon learning of the adultery charge, the MOE had asked Chao to return to Taipei within a week to report on the case. Chao, however, offered to resign on health reasons. The board of trustees of the school already accepted Chao's resignation.
Moreover, Kao Chung-yu, chairman of the MOE's Overseas Chinese Education Committee also resigned from the school's board of trustees following the report of the scandal.
Lee said all these incidents indicate that the MOE has not properly supervised the management of the ROC government-funded schools abroad.
Lee went on to say that complaints about sexual harassment and other scandalous allegations have been rife in the Taipei School in Ho Chi Minh City.

In addition to Kao, four officials at the ROC's representative office in Ho Chi Minh City are also trustees of the Taipei School there. "I simply couldn't understand why the MOE had failed to investigate all those scandalous allegations earlier," Lee said.

Mu Ming-chu, also a KMT legislator, echoed Lee's view, saying that the MOE should have carefully checked Chao's integrity and character before appointing him as the Taipei School president. Chao was a retired MOE employee.
"The case has highlighted problems in MOE supervision of overseas Taipei-funded schools," Mu said.

Both Lee and Mu demanded that the MOE ask Chou Yen, director of the Taipei representative office in Ho Chi Minh City, to return within a week to deliver a special report to the legislature on the scandalous case.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOODWILL FLOTILLA LEAVES PHILIPPINES FOR HOME

TEXT.P: After a three-day port call in the Philippines, the Republic of China (ROC) Navy's goodwill flotilla left Manila Bay for home on Monday.
The goodwill flotilla, sailed into Manila Bay on June 11.

Amid strained Beijing-Manila relations resulted from a dispute over an islet in the Spratly Island chain, the visit of ROC Navy attracted extensive attention from the international community in Manila and drew angry protests from Beijing.
Beijing questioned the Philippine government whether it has changed its "one China" policy and now allows ROC Navy ships to visit the Philippines.

Before leaving Manila Bay, a national flag hoisting ceremony was held aboard the deck of the flotilla's flagship "Wu Yi." The ceremony was jointly presided over by Rear Adm. Chen Yung-kang, commander of the flotilla, and Chan Hsien-ching, ROC's representative in the Philippines.

While in Manila, Rear Adm. Chen called on high ranking Philippine officers. The flotilla's officers and men also played two basketball games against the Philippine Navy, conducted medical diagnoses and treatments for Filipino citizens, and staged two military band performance for overseas Chinese in the Philippines.
The ROC Navy organizes a goodwill flotilla each year as a training mission for seniors at the nation's Naval Academy prior to their graduation.

DOC.HEADLINE: IN DEFIANCE OF CENTRAL GOV'T, KAOHSIUNG TO BEGIN LOTTERY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government decided to begin an experimental form of its proposed lottery Monday evening, in defiance of the ban by the central government.
Premier Vincent Siew in the morning warned the southern port city not to rush through the lottery issuance, saying it is a legal issue, and the city government should not politicize the event.
The holding of lotteries is currently under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Finance (MOF), Siew said, and the MOF would deal with the situation according to law, Siew said.

Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh has decided to inaugurate the lottery by offering to donate revenues from the first batch of 30,000 lottery tickets to charity. The tickets were available at a dinner party Monday evening.
Tuesday morning 240,000 lottery tickets will be on sale for NT$100 (US$3.08) each.

Despite beginning the sale of tickets, Hsieh has visibly softened his original plan to formally begin the lottery on July 1. Hsieh said the implementation of the formal lottery will depend on public reception during the trial period.
While Hsieh pointed out the central government should respect local government rights, he also revealed that the July 1 issuance appears uncertain.

Kaohsiung citizens, while interested in the lottery trial sale, are criticizing the issuing process for being too "rash and careless." The city government is accused of not announcing where tickets can be bought or how to collect prizes.

The 240,000 trial lottery tickets can be purchased from any of the city's 28 organizations that benefit under-privileged citizens. The largest cash prize is NT$500,000 (US$15,423), and the smallest NT$200. Approximately one out of every six tickets is a winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS URGED TO TAP EU MARKET FROM POLISH BASE

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses should seek to tap the European Union (EU) market due to its increasing importance in international trade, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang said on Monday.

Speaking at a one-day ROC-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference which took place in Taipei, Chiang said that with the partial launch of the new single European currency -- the Euro -- at the beginning of this year, the EU is set to play an increasingly important role in world trade.

In terms of long-term economic trends, the EU is a potential market rife with business and investment opportunities, and Taiwan businesses should seriously consider investing in the region, Chiang said.

Pointing to the Evergreen Group as an example, Chiang said that with its setting up of a branch in Poland, the Taiwan-based world leading container fleet operator has moved a big step forward in realizing its ambition of breaking into Europe, providing a major fillip for many other Taiwan businesses, mainly in the electronics sector, to follow in its steps.
Conference Chair Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), also said that Poland is an ideal springboard for Taiwan companies wishing to edge into the EU market.
Two-way Taiwan-Poland trade totaled more than US$300 million in 1998, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$153 million, Lin added.
Currently, Poland is Taiwan's second-largest trading partner in central and eastern Europe behind only Hungary, while Taiwan is Poland's fourth-largest export market in Asia.

H.E. Miroslaw Kuklinski, a Polish member of parliament who co-chaired the conference with Lin, stressed that Taiwan and Poland should try to strengthen their bilateral trade ties under the framework of the World Trade Organization in light of Taiwan's imminent membership of the world trade regulatory body.

Taiwan businesses can take advantage of Poland's farm and agricultural resources, while the high quality of Taiwan's hi-tech products, such as computers and telecommunications equipment, can provide great benefits to companies and offices all over Poland, Kuklinski pointed out.
Poland's cheap labor, good location, and free-trade economic policy are other advantages which should lure Taiwan investors, he claimed.

In addition to more than 40 representatives of Polish firms, scores of representatives from Hungary and the Czech Republic who are in Taipei to take part in the 1999 Eurogate trade bazaar were also present at the conference, according to the Euro-Asia Trade Organization, organizer of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESLITE TO CONTINUE 24-HOUR OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Eslite, which three months ago became the first bookstore in Taiwan to run a pilot scheme for 24-hour operations, has decided to continue its round-the-clock business, an Eslite official said over the weekend.
Lo Mei-ling, manager of the Eslite chain's flagship bookstore on upscale Tunhwa South Road, noted that the pilot scheme which began on March 12 has received an enthusiastic response.

Lo estimated that nighttime (10 p.m. to 10 a.m.) revenue of the bookstore in the three-month test period accounted for about 25 percent of the total revenue, which she said is much better than the average ratio of 20 percent in some 24-hour convenience stores.

Lo divided the nighttime patrons into several broad categories -- elderly patrons, graduate students seeking reference books, young people who enjoy being out and about at night, those who regard the bookstore as their personal library, and tourists from overseas whose hectic daytime schedule does not permit them to visit the store.
T.T. Tsui, founder of the Tsui Museum of Art in Hong Kong and a noted antiques collector, said that he often takes the time to visit the bookstore when he visits Taiwan.
Tsui said he enjoyed the peace and serenity of the store at night, adding that when typhoon Maggie hit Taiwan recently, he visited the store and bought books worth NT$10,000 (US$308).
Asked when most nighttime patrons tend to visit the store, Eslite officials noted that peak time is between 10 p.m. and 1 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

The Ministry of Finance sued the Kaohsiung City Government over the issue of controversial lottery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES AND FUTURES BOTH OPEN HIGH BUT END LOWER

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices dropped 0.2 percent on Tuesday as share prices failed to rally in late trading.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 13.58 points to close at 7,960 with 2.52 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$139.47 billion (US$4.3 billion).
The market opened 118 points higher on the news of a merger between United Microelectronics Corp. and its four affiliates and an overnight rally on Wall Street.
But share prices declined as late profit taking eroded early gains, failing attempts once gain to breach the psychological 8,000-point level, dealers said.

Trading in the electronic sector reached nearly 73 percent of Tuesday's turnover of NT$139.47 billion. The electronic sector, in posting gains of 1.6 percent, was the only sector among the eight major stock categories to end higher.

The textile sector registered the largest loss of 2.1 percent, followed by construction shares, at 1.8 percent; both financial and plastic and chemical issues declined 1.7 percent; cement shares lost 1.2 percent; paper-making issues were down 1 percent and foodstuff shares fell 0.5 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market suffered a 2.94 drop, ending the day at 175.3 points on a turnover of NT$6.28 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June moved down 32 points to close at 7,943 with 1,714 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July went down 45 points to finish at 7,940 with 2,798 contract transactions, those for September declined 21 points to 7,951 with 44 contract transactions and those for December fell 2 points to end at 7,998 with 4 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March reported no transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,975 for June, 7,985 for July, 7,972 for September, 8,000 for December and 8,025 for next March. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 15, or the second day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer, and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1846: The 49th parallel is proclaimed as the border between the United States and Canada.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1904: The paddle steamer "General Slocum" catches fire in New York Harbor, killing 693 people.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name into International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) and becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down on the green turf at Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1929: The Kuomintang announces that the government planned to end by 1935 the Period of Political Tutelage, a pre-constitutional form of government which started in 1928.
1933: China and Tibet end a two-year war with a treaty that mutually respects the pre-war border.
1944: US forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the US envoy to China notifies the Chinese government on the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the US, UK and the USSR, agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The Peoples Daily, A Chinese Communist Party newspaper, puts out its first issue.
1949: Taiwan adopts a new currency.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastic raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1960: The Seoul government promulgates a new constitution introducing a parliamentary system of government in South Korea.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1969: Georges Pompidou is elected president of France.
1977: The first democratic election in 41 years is held in Spain and won by Adolfo Suarez and his Democratic Centre coalition.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1992: The Japanese Diet approves an act authorizing the Japanese troops to join United Nations peace-keeping missions.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1994: Israel and the Vatican establish diplomatic relations, sealing a historic accord on mutual recognition and reconciliation after centuries of bitterness.
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries: Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES RIVAL KOREAS TO EXERCISE SELF-RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: The ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday urged North and South Korea to exercise self-restraint and resolve their disputes by peaceful means.
The ministry made the appeal as gunboats from the two rival Koreas traded fire on Tuesday in their first naval clash in the Yellow Sea since the 1950-1953 Korean War.

MOFA acting spokesman Chen Ming-cheng said the ministry has ordered the Republic of China's representative office in Seoul to keep a close watch on the developments in the Korean peninsula and informed it of the latest situation there.
Chen further said the ROC looks forward to seeing the conflicts between the two Koreas resolved soon in a peaceful manner.
Chen also urged local fishermen not to operate in waters near the Korean peninsula during this period of turbulence in the region.
In the past, many Taiwan fishermen operate in the Yellow Sea. But the number has declined steadily in recent years because of a drain on fishery resources in the region.
Chen said the MOFA has contacted the Fishery Administration of the Council of Agriculture for more information about local fishermen's current operations in the Yellow Sea.
According to foreign wire service reports, four North Korean patrol boats and three torpedo ships intruded into South Korean waters early on Tuesday.
The three torpedo boats fired at a South Korean patrol boat in South Korean waters and the South retaliated by firing 100 rounds, the reports said.

One North Korean patrol boat was sunk and a torpedo boat was wallowing in South Korean waters, the reports said, adding that three other North Korean ships were heavily damaged and retreated to Northern waters.
Meanwhile, seven South Korean soldiers were slightly injured in the clash and two South Korean boats were reportedly damaged.

A spokesman for the South Korean government said it has put its military on "Defcon three," which the military defined as "a serious situation ... that could lead to deployment of North Korean military forces."

It was the worst incident between the Koreas since the South Korean navy and air force sank a North Korean spy vessel off the southern tip of the Korean peninsula last December, killing the Northern boat's crew.
But it was the first clash in the Yellow Sea since the 1950-53 Korean War and the first incident involving regular navy vessels from both sides in recent memory.
"It's an obvious challenge to our consistent tolerance and efforts towards North Korea's intrusion which started from June 7," South Korean Defense Ministry spokesman Cha Young-koo said.
