DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CASINOS TARGET ASIAN BIG SPENDERS

TEXT.P: Big spenders from Guangzhou are increasingly being targeted by Australian casinos in addition to those from Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia and other Asian countries.

Crown Casino in Melbourne, the biggest gambling den in the Oceania and its rival Star City in Sydney, are competing fiercely between themselves and US casinos in Las Vegas, to lure big gamblers from southern China, Hong Kong and other Asian countries as the region recovers from the 1997 financial crisis, according to a survey by the Australian.
The daily reported Australian casinos are cashing in on the fact that escalating wars between Triad gangs on Macau have convinced more and more Chinese to take their money to Australia.
The daily reported the Australian government has relaxed visa applications for high-roller betters from southern China, who spend a minimum of US$50,000 per visit.
The daily reported wealthy lawyers, entrepreneurs and the children of People's Liberation Army top brass and Communist Party officials are among the high rollers.

Before the Australian casino on Christmas Island closed last year, among the clients were Thailand's Madam Thong Thip and wealthy businessmen from Indonesia. That casino was officially owned by a wealthy Indonesian businessman, while unofficially the owner was, Tommy Suharto, the son of former president Suharto. (Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN GROUP DRAWS ATTENTION TO UNPAID WORK

TEXT.P: A Canadian social group said Monday elderly women should not face poverty because they cared for sick relatives or their children instead of joining the paid workforce.
Mothers Are Women, a national women's group, released a hefty manual on the scope of unpaid work and the problems faced by caregivers in Canada.
The organization has been trying to keep unpaid work on the political front burner to force the government to do more policy research on the issue.
A 1992 Statistics Canada survey calculated the value of unpaid work each year in the country to be between C$284 and C$318 million.

Spokeswoman Evelyn Drescher said her group was not suggesting that stay-at-home mothers or caregivers be paid for their work, but that politicians take a closer look at the inequalities that exist for such women in the tax and social system.
"The issue is not compensation, it's understanding how the economy functions and then how best social policy and economic policy can be directed," Drescher added.
The manual suggests that 53 percent of single female seniors live below the poverty line because their unpaid work was not recognized.
Beverley Smith of Calgary, Alberta brought a complaint to the United Nations in New York about discrimination against unpaid workers, specifically homemakers.
The U.N. did not respond specifically to her case, but in a report made mention of discrimination against women in national legal systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.043 against the greenback on the Taipei market Tuesday, closing at 32.384.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.42 and had a high of 32.343.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$712.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF DELEGATION TO VISIT BEIJING JUNE 27-29

TEXT.P: Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will head a delegation to visit Beijing from June 27 through June 29 to set the stage for mainland China's top envoy to visit this island later this year.

SEF made the announcement on Tuesday shortly after it received a message from its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- concerning Jan's travel plan.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of official contacts.
ARATS said in its message that it welcomes Jan to visit Beijing June 27-29 as proposed by SEF earlier this month.
Nevertheless, the Beijing-based association didn't respond to the SEF proposal that the two sides conduct double-track dialogue during Jan's upcoming Beijing visit.

According to SEF's proposal, the agenda for Jan's talks with his ARATS counterpart would include not only ARATS President Wang Daohan's planned Taiwan visit this fall but also practical issues, such as repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal immigrants, and fishing disputes.
It seems that ARATS' main interest lies in discussing details concerning Wang's Taiwan visit and political issues, such as unification of the two sides.
ARATS also politely rejected a SEF invitation to send its staff members to take part in a SEF-sponsored golf tournament for Taiwan investors in mainland China, to be held in Taipei on June 22.

Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan when he met his Taiwan counterpart, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, in Shanghai last October.

According to a preliminary agreement reached between Jan and ARATS Deputy Secretary-General Li Yafei in Taipei in March this year, Wang will visit Taiwan this autumn. However, no definite date has been set.

On May 26, ARATS invited SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow and Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng to visit Beijing from June 22 through June 24 to discuss an itinerary and agenda for Wang's Taiwan visit.

In a June 10 message to ARATS, SEF told ARATS that both Shi and Jan cannot travel to the mainland during that period because of their busy schedule in Taipei. It instead proposed that Jan visit the mainland from June 27 through June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO ADOPT NEW POLICY TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The United States (US) should adopt a new China policy of limited engagement that firmly clarifies the US commitment to the defense of Taiwan and the critical US interest in a peaceful resolution of differences across the Taiwan Straits, according to an American foreign policy expert.

Bates Gill, director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies, wrote in the latest issue of "Foreign Affairs" bimonthly magazine that Taiwan is the most important security issue dividing Washington and Beijing. Despite President Bill Clinton's public statement a year ago of Washington's long-standing "Three Noes" policy toward Taiwan, the People's Republic of China perceives a gradual strengthening of US-Taiwan ties.

Indeed, the senior fellow in foreign policy studies at Washington's Brookings Institute noted, Taiwan's status as one of the world's largest free-market economies and as an emerging democracy sharply contrasts with the PRC, encouraging US support for a fortified relationship with Taiwan.

Beijing thinks that such developments violate US pledges and obstruct eventual reunification by encouraging Taiwanese recalcitrance. But the status quo on which US-PRC understandings were based 25 years ago is eroding, and "Washington and Beijing need to think in an innovative manner how to reach a more appropriate modus vivendi," said Gill.

He stressed that for the United States "this means firmly clarifying the US commitment to provide for the defense of Taiwan and the critical US interest in a peaceful resolution of differences across the Taiwan Straits." This dispute holds the greatest potential for war between the United States and the PRC, so the two sides must work patiently to avoid this outcome, added Gill.

The senior analyst continued that US leaders must speak realistically and candidly about America's interests and the strengths and the weaknesses of the US-PRC relationship. At a minimum, he wrote, " a new China policy should contain more realism about the future relationship with Beijing: neither a full-fledged containment strategy nor a whole-hearted embrace, but a clear-headed mix of engagement and hedging -- a limited engagement."

President Clinton's recent remarks about mainland China -- that America has to work for a better future even as it remains prepared for any outcome -- suggests a step in the right direction, said Gill.

When US interests are strongly and consistently conveyed and US policy openly acknowledges not just America's shared concerns with the PRC but also its strategic differences, confidence in engagement will increase and more domestic constituencies will get behind it, he added.

Moreover, Gill wrote, mainland Chinese leaders will better understand the US perspective on both the opportunities and limits of engagement, making the chances of bitter disillusionment less likely. But this approach should not over-exaggerate the PRC's power -- an all-too-often tendency that is not only divisive at home but grants Beijing psychological leverage it can exploit in diplomatic discourse, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SEND OFFICIALS TO CHECK STOWAWAYS IN DETENTION CENTER

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) officials arrived at a detention center for mainalnd Chinese stowaways on Tuesday to try to determine the cause of a mysterious disease .

The DOH said that during the past month three people at the Ching Lu detention center in Ilan have died and six more have been hospitalized. On Tuesday another three were rushed to hospital intensive care units.
DOH and local health officials checked blood and urine samples of more than 300 stowaways. After the tests, the officials announced that preliminary results show the disease is not contagious.

Officials from DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Center said that the victims of the mysterious disease have complained of weakness in their lower limbs. Testing found acidosis and an elevation of muscle enzymes, leading the experts to believe the cause was rhabdomyolysis, a disease often caused by drugs, trauma, heat stroke or over exertion.

The officials said that judging from the symptoms, the disease is not contagious, and they are tying to learn why the stowaways became infected en masse. A conclusive result of the blood and urine tests should be known in one week, they said.
Meanwhile, the outbreak of the disease has caused some to call for an investigation into its cause.
One local newspaper reported that most of the mainalnd illegal immigrants came from coastal provinces, areas that have poor hygiene habits and people drinking well water.

A China Times' report said that when illegal stowaways are discovered they are sent by police straight to the detention center. There the stowaways provide detention officials with only a very brief personal history. The China Times report concluded that the center has no way of knowing if newly-arrived detainees are disease carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SET TO TRIM CIVIL SERVANTS BY 65,000

TEXT.P: The newly appointed chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, Wei Chi-lin, said Tuesday that the government plans to reduce its number of civil servants from 240,000 to 175,000 within five years as part of government efforts to streamline its workforce.

Wei made the statement in a seminar, sponsored by the Central Personnel Administration and the Institute for National Policy Research, on reducing the number of public servants to a suitable level. The seminar comes amid strong public protests over Taiwan's large number of civil servants.

Wei said the central government intends to reduce the number of civil servants it employs to 120,000 while the provincial government and local governments will reduce their numbers to 35,000 and 20,000, respectively.

In addition, the number of people employed by state-run businesses is set to be reduced from 140,000 to 70,000 in five years, while the police and armed forces will undergo streamlining as well, Wei said.

In response to public complaints that there are over 600,000 public servants in the administrative sector, resulting in low efficiency, Wei explained that the legislative, judicial and other non-administrative sectors, which together employ 360,000 civil servants, account for more than 60 percent of the total and are mainly responsible for the large number.

Wei said that the size of the reduction in Taiwan's civil service should be based on a variety of considerations rather than a specific figure. He said the consequences of any reduction need to be taken into account.

Wei said factors that should be taken into account include administrative productivity, the current national development strategy, the government's financial burden and the country's employment outlook.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN CATTLE BARRED FROM OUTBOUND SHIPMENT FOR 1 YEAR

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Tuesday that all cattle raised in the offshore frontline island of Kinmen will be barred from outbound shipment for one year.
Moreover, the council said, all Kinmen cattle will be subject to a three-year intensive monitoring over the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) infection.
The Cabinet-level council made the announcement after cattle raised in two Kinmen ranches were found to have been infected with the FMD virus.
Noting that the FMD virus is viable for up to three years in cattle, COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei said cloven-hoofed livestock ranches in Kinmen must stay high alert over the next three years.
"Even livestock farms in Taiwan must also be wary of the FMD infection over the next three years," Peng said.
To curb the spread of the disease, Peng said Kinmen cattle should not be sent out of the island for a year.

Meanwhile, the Kinmen County Government on Tuesday slaughtered all the 67 cattle raised at the Shao Ser Fu and Chen Cheng Tsai ranches as some Shao Ser Fu cattle had been infected with the deadly FMD virus.

The nine cattle from the Chen Cheng Tasi ranch were also slaughtered mainly because the farm is located between the Shao Ser Fu ranch and the Hsin Yao Chi ranch whose cattle were all killed last week when the farm was hit by an FMD outbreak.

A 30-member team composed of COA animal quarantine officials and staff members from the Kinmen Livestock Research Center began cattle slaughtering and ranch sterilization early in the morning and the work didn't end until Tuesday evening.
Some residents in Kucheng and Hsienantsun villages near the FMD-infected ranches staged a demonstration in front of the Shao Ser Fu farm, protesting their hometowns from becoming animal graves.
The protest ended only after COA and Kinmen County Government officials assured them of taking proper measures to prevent environmental pollution.
The COA has also decided to conduct FMD tests on all 3,000 head of cattle raised in Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT-ELECT TO VISIT TAIWAN IN EARLY JULY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 15 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President-elect Mireya Moscoso is scheduled to visit the Republic of China on Taiwan in early July, La Estralla de Panama (The Star) reported on Monday.
Moscoso, a coffee company owner who was elected Panama's next president in early May, will also visit Japan and Hong Kong during her Asian tour in July, the daily newspaper said.
Moscoso, 52, the widow of three-time populist President Arnulfo Arias, is very friendly toward the Republic of China.

The chairman of Panama's opposition Arnulfista Party since 1991, Moscoso defeated Martin Torrijos, son of the late dictator Gen. Omar Torrijos, in the presidential election by winning 45 percent of the vote.
She is slated to be inaugurated on Sept. 1, making her Panama's first female president.

ROC President Lee Teng-hui may attend Moscoso's inauguration personally. If he makes the trip, it would be Lee's second visit to Panama in two years after attending the World Congress on the Panama Canal held in Panama City Sept. 7-11, 1997.
Moscoso visited Taiwan in 1993. During that visit, she observed activities of the ruling Kuomintang's 14th National Party Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE RUSHING TO BUY COMMEMORATIVE NT$50 BILLS

TEXT.P: People are rushing to purchase newly issued plastic bills in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the issuance of the New Taiwan dollar.

The Bank of Taiwan (BOT) was entrusted by the Central Bank of China (CBC) for the sale of the plastic legal tender. Crowds gathered and people stood in line in the summer sun at every BOT branch in hopes of purchasing the plastic bills.

The New Taiwan currency was first issued 50 years ago on June 15, 1949. In order to honor its indispensable role in and contribution to Taiwan's economic development, the CBC entrusted the BOT to sell 30 million NT$50 bills to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the NT dollar's issuance.
The BOT will also sell 100,000 packages of commemorative coins, which have a combined face value of NT$750.

Officials of the CBC's Issue Department noted that the CBC wishes to share Taiwan's economic achievement with all the people in Taiwan through the issuance of the commemorative plastic bills, and hopes that through the efforts of all the people, another economic miracle will occur in Taiwan.
Tang Shao-wu, manager of the CBC's Issue Department, said that those who are interested in acquiring the bills need not hurry, as there will be enough to meet demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET'S POTENTIAL ATTRACTS FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Following a search for opportunities in Taiwan's stock market by US Pensions 2000 and the Hong Kong branch Morgan Stanley in April, US investment consultant Merrill Lynch plans to hold a conference to assess the investment potential in Taiwan's stock market, sources said on Monday.
This shows the profitability of the local bourse has been widely identified by global investment institutions.

The second Asia-Pacific technology conference to be sponsored by Merrill Lynch Taiwan Limited will be the first of its kind in Taiwan. The three-day conference is scheduled to begin June 22, and taking part will be the company's leading hi-tech analyst, Steve Milunovich, and other analysts together with 100 heavyweight investors from around the world.

Peter Kerz, the general manager of Merrill Lynch Taiwan Limited, said the company has planned the conference for months with the hope of giving their customers a better understanding of hi-tech industries in the Asia-Pacific region.

Over 100 global fund managers and representatives of the high tech industries of Taiwan, the United States, Japan and Hong Kong, including semiconductors, software, hardware and Internet service providers, are also expected to attend the conference, Kerz added.

Foreign investors highly value the future development of Taiwan's stock market, and have a special interest in the electronics and financial sectors, Kerz noted, adding that Merrill Lynch's move is expected to bring a deeper understanding of the development of the local bourse to global investors.
An official of a Hong Kong-based securities company said many forums on how foreign capital should operate in Taiwan's stock market have been held either in Taiwan or abroad in 1999.

Most of the foreign fund managers invited to Taiwan to attend the conference are experienced in investing in Taiwan's market and have traveled to Taiwan more than once to obtain a better understanding of the market.

Up to last week, a total of NT$128.9 billion (US$ 3.96 billion) in foreign capital had flowed into Taiwan's stock market, and further inflows are expected, particularly in the electronics sector, as a result of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEFENSE ORGANIZATION TO BE RESTRUCTURED: MND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's national defense organization will be restructured in line with changes in styles of warfare, weaponry systems, and management style and tools, Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Tuesday.
"Following our troop reduction plan, we must now launch a sweeping organizational restructuring drive," Tang told a routine news conference held at the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

In the past, Tang said, the military was responsible for training manpower in various professional fields for its own use. "With the expansion of education, our civilian education system now can train various professional personnel to meet the demand of the MND, except for some combat-related fields."

Against this background, Tang said, all national defense-related organizations should be restructured. For instance, many departments at military academies can be phased out or scaled down. With the implementation of the National Health Insurance Program, the number of military hospitals can be reduced, and production of weaponry and military equipment can be commissioned to private contractors or state-owned enterprises.

In response to a promise offered by Vice President Lien Chan to shorten the period of compulsory military service, Tang said the MND will conduct an overall review of the manpower supply and demand before shortening the service period.

Noting that weaponry renovation has helped cut the military's manpower demand, Tang said the number of conscripts has often exceeded demand in recent years, and wasted time spent waiting for the MND's draft notice is a common complaint among Taiwan men of service age.

To address the issue, Tang said, the MND and the Ministry of the Interior are working on a system which will allow some conscripts to engage in specialized social services instead of compulsory military service.
He explained that the current two-year mandatory military service period may be shortened by two to three months, depending on the number of excess conscripts.
If all goes smoothly, Tang said, the shortened service period will be implemented as early as next year, allowing about 20,000 conscripts now on active duty to leave early.

Meanwhile, Tang, a former air force commander in chief, said he has ordered the Air Force General Headquarters to conduct a thorough investigation of the three F-16 crashes to determine whether there were common factors behind the incidents.
"We must find out all possible problems with F-16 fighter jets and check whether there is a gap in our combat readiness following the three F-16 crashes," he said.

The four-star general further said the air force has decided to slow commissioning of the US-made F-16 fighters and extend the mandatory training period for F-16 pilots from the current six months to eight months.

Taiwan struck a deal with the United States in 1992 to purchase 150 high-performance F-16 jet fighters. The air force has so far formed four F-16 squadrons which are stationed at Chiayi and Hualien air bases, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROGATE '99 OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Eurogate '99, a trade bazaar featuring products, information on investment environments and tourism in four central and eastern European countries, kicked off in Taipei on Tuesday at the Taipei International Convention Center.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang, Polish Vice Economics Minister Tadeusz Donocik, Hungarian Vice Economics Minister Gabor Gulacsi, Lithuanian parliamentary member Laima Andrikiene, and Czech Investment Bureau Chief Judita Stouracova all attended the opening ceremony.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Hu extended a warm welcome to the foreign dignitaries and described the five-day show as a beginning of bilateral cooperation between the Republic of China and the four European countries.

He also expressed the hope that Eurogate '99 will provide the people of Taiwan with the means to gain a better understanding of the countries represented at the show, all of which are abundant in cultural heritage, natural resources and tourism spots.
A total of 116 firms from the four countries are displaying their products at the show, ranging from agricultural items to petrochemical products.

Speaking on the same occasion, Wang said the timber, textile, chemical, and electronics sectors of these countries are particularly worthy of investment by Taiwan businesses due to their good location, cheap labor and rich natural resources.

Meanwhile, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council, organizer of the bazaar, said trade officials of the attending countries will hold an investment seminar on Wednesday to introduce their countries' investment climates and the handsome incentives they are offering to the local Taiwan business community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S THIRD ENGLISH-LANGUAGE DAILY LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Taipei Times, a newly published newspaper owned by the Chinese-language daily "Liberty Times," and touted as the first English-language daily launched by "native Taiwanese," hit newsstands Tuesday.
A party was held at the Taipei Grand Hyatt Hotel Tuesday afternoon in celebration of the Taipei Times' inaugural issue.

Guests of honor included Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, President of the Examination Yuan Hsu Shui-teh, Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang and Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.

Liberty Times founder Lin Rong-san said in his opening speech that the Taipei Times is a Taiwan-oriented newspaper devoted to providing accurate information to the local and foreign communities in Taiwan.

The Liberty Times has been the most widely read newspaper on the island for three consecutive years, Lin said, adding that it is his wish that the Taipei Times will also become the most authoritative and trusted English-language newspaper in the Asia-Pacific region.

The newborn English-language daily is also aimed at enhancing the island's profile among international readers, Lin said, adding that the motto of the Taipei Times is "bringing Taiwan to the world, and the world to Taiwan."

The newspaper not only has the most comprehensive local reporting on the island, but also the most extensive and informative international coverage, thanks to a team of fine editors, reporters and production people, he said.

President Lee lauded the launch of the Taipei Times, saying it marked a milestone in the development of an international press in Taiwan. He noted the importance of press freedom, saying that without it, there would be no true democracy.
The Taipei Times will help present the Republic of China's achievements to the international community, and make Taiwan's voice heard across the world, Lee said.

Lien pointed out that many international press publications, such as The Asian Wall Street Journal, The International Herald Tribune and 10 Japanese newspapers, have established operations in Taiwan recently, which shows the ROC's growing importance in the world community.

Taiwan's production, transportation and financial sectors are already fully developed and can function as parts of an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center, Lien said, adding that with the publication of the Taipei Times, the ROC has taken another step toward becoming a regional media center as well.

The Taipei Times serves an important role in the transmission of up-to-date information, as well as cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the world, Lien said, adding that the daily's stance of "Taiwan first" will make the island's voice heard throughout the global community.

The premier also lauded the Taipei Times for seeking to help the world understand Taiwan. He said it is natural for people to read The New York Times in New York City, and now Taiwan finally has an international-caliber daily to compete with the international press.
Other attendees of the newspaper's inauguration party included representatives of all political parties, members of the local and foreign press, and noted figures in the entertainment business.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE, EUROPEAN GROUPS VIE FOR HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY ELECTRIC SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Two foreign consortia, one from Japan and the other from Europe, will formally vie for the US$2.44 billion contract to provide the electric engineering system for Taiwan's high-speed railway.
Both the European consortium Eurotrain and the Japanese consortium presented their bids for the contract to Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC) on Tuesday.

Eurotrain is composed of Germany's Siemens Group and France's Alston Group, while the Japanese consortium comprises Mitsui Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industry Co., Toshiba and Kawasaki Heavy Industry Co.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said the top principles for selecting the new railway's electric engineering system are "meeting Taiwan's demand and the ROC government's requirements."
THSRC, which is formed by a group of local business and industrial companies, won the contract in 1998 to build the island's first high-speed railway under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula.

The company originally planned to use a French-German (or TGV-ICE) mixed electric engineering system. As the two European companies have no intention to invest in construction of Taiwan's high-speed rail system, THSRC has decided to hold an open tender to select the most suitable supplier of the electric engineering system.
Ing said changes in the electric engineering system is not expected to have a great impact on the railway's civil construction.

The Japanese consortium once joined with a group of local companies to vie for the contract to build the NT$400 billion high-speed railway. The Taiwan-Japanese consortium was disbanded after losing the bid to THSRC.

The newly formed Japanese consortium reportedly has cut the price by 20 to 30 percent from its previous offer and the Japanese government has also promised to offer a huge loan for the electric engineering equipment. All these terms have helped sharpened the Japanese consortium's competitive edge to win the contract.
Moreover, the Japanese consortium said its Shinkansen system, which has been used in Japan for many decades and has never had any accidents, is the safest high-speed rail system in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL GOVERNMENT SUES KAOHSIUNG AUTHORITIES

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Tuesday that his ministry has filed a lawsuit with prosecution authorities against the Kaohsiung City Government for illegally issuing public lottery tickets.
Speaking at a Kuomintang legislative caucus meeting, Chiu also said that some Finance Ministry officials have left for the southern port city to gather evidence of how the lottery is being run.

Stressing that the central government will take necessary measures to stop illegal issuance and marketing of public lotteries by local government authorities in compliance with the Criminal Code, Chiu said that the Finance Ministry has already notified the Kaohsiung City Government and its contractor who printed the tickets that they face prosecution.

Ignoring a central government ban, the Kaohsiung City Government kicked off its test run of a public lottery on Monday, issuing 240,000 scratch-and-win tickets to raise funds for social welfare programs for underprivileged citizens.
The move has stirred up opposition from the central government, which insists that lottery issuance by local authorities must first obtain central government approval.

Regarding the allocation of the proceeds of the lotteries, Vice Finance Minister Wang Rong-jou said that at least 50 percent of the revenue should be used to carry out social welfare programs for minorities, but a detailed allocation must be worked out among the central and local governments, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIECHTENSTEIN BANK TO SET UP OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Tuesday approved an application from LGT Bank in Liechtenstein Aktiengesellschaft (LBLA) to set up a representative office in Taiwan.

An MOF Bureau of Monetary Affairs (BMA) spokesman said that with the establishment of the bank's Taipei bureau, there will be 27 foreign banks which have set up representative offices in Taiwan, and 16 which have set up branch offices or bureaus.

The LBLA, the largest bank in the Principality of Liechtenstein, was established in 1920. According to the 1998 July issue of Bankers' magazine, the bank's total assets amounted to US$7.17 billion, and the total amount of its capital was US$670 million, making it the 408th-largest bank in the world.

The bank is a subsidiary of the Liechtenstein Global Trust Aktiengesellshaft, which specializes in assets management, investment consultation and portfolio management. It currently owns over US$1 billion of capital in Asia.

According to the BMA, several foreign financial institutions have adjusted or withdrawn their operations from Taiwan due to their global management policies. However, that does not mean that foreign banks are pessimistic over the island's financial market, it stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA PAINTING ITSELF INTO DIPLOMATIC CORNER: AUSSIE PAPER

TEXT.P: Recent diplomatic events have served to isolate mainland China and bring Taiwan to the fore, particularly in Europe, according to a leading Australian newspaper.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, Australian Financial Review correspondent Rowan Callick reported that mainland China was the only country to abstain from a vote on a resolution that effectively ended the war in Kosovo following the accord reached between NATO members and Russia.

Callick said a group of officials from Macedonia -- Taiwan's newest diplomatic ally in Europe and one of only two in the region -- were in Taipei last week. That same week Taiwan pledged US$300 million in aid to Kosovar refugees.

Callick noted mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization remains stalled after President Jiang Zemin told US President Bill Clinton: "It is not the time yet for talks (on WTO), the atmosphere is not good."
As mainland China continues to claim that the NATO bombing of its embassy in Belgrade was deliberate, it is perceived as backing the almost universally reviled Slodoban Milosevic, Callick reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: OMBUDSMAN BODIES OF ROC AND ARGENTINA FORGE TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and visiting head of Argentina's national ombudsman body Jorge Luis Maiorano, on Tuesday jointly signed an agreement to promote bilateral cooperation between the watchdog bodies of the two countries.
The agreement signed in a ceremony at the Control Yuan building is aimed at defending human rights and the interests of every individual, according to Control Yuan officials.

The terms of the agreement specify several cooperation projects which include expertise, information, and personnel exchanges, training programs, sponsorship of seminars and conferences, and plans for the expansion of the ombudsman system.
Maiorano is also president of the Board of the non-political and unofficial International Ombudsman Institute (IOI), which has 100 member states.

In an address during the occasion, Maiorano expressed his pleasure in serving the international organization, and said he is devoting himself to helping countries build their ombudsman systems. He also said he will invite more countries around the world to join the IOI.
Maiorano, who arrived in Taiwan on Monday for a five-day visit was elected to lead the IOI Board last October for a two-year tenure.
The Argentinian official has long been friendly toward Taiwan, the officials said, noting that Maiorano's visit to the island is expected to help Taiwan's bid for its IOI membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HEADS OF MOE, CPA SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Cabinet-level Central Personnel Administration (CPA) welcomed their respective new heads on Tuesday.

Kirby Chaur-shin Yang assumed the post of Minister of Education and Chang Che-chen took the post of Director-General of the CPA at two separate ceremonies supervised respectively by Ministers Without Portfolios Huang Ta-chou and Chen Chien-min.
Yang replaced Lin Ching-jiang, who resigned recently due to a brain tumor.
At a speech at the swearing-in ceremony, Yang proposed a policy that "each citizen can study anywhere, and each citizen can have an equal opportunity to receive advanced education."

He said he will continue to push for the education reforms that have been underway since his predecessor's ministership, pay more attention to the health of the nation's schoolchildren, and raise and efficiently use the education budget.
Yang served as chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission before assuming his new post.
Meanwhile, the new director-general of the CPA unveiled six major goals for his organization:
-- The re-engineering of the government;
-- The further streamlining of the organization and function of the Taiwan Provincial Government;
-- The establishment of a well-organized and flexible government framework;
-- The efficient management of manpower resources;
-- The promotion of governmental administrative efficiency; and
-- The promotion of the morale of military personnel, government employees and teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOODLE MERGER FALLS THROUGH IN FAVOR OF JAPANESE COMPANY

TEXT.P: A high-profile merger of Taiwan's food giant President Enterprises with the Hong Kong-listed Tingyi Holding Corp. was aborted on Tuesday when Tingyi, producer of the biggest-selling instant noodles in mainland China, forged a cooperation accord with a Japanese manufacturer.

Tingyi, a subsidiary of the Taiwan-based Ting Hsin Co., and producer of Master Kang instant noodles, better known in the mainland as Kangshihfu convenient noodles, signed an agreement with Sanyo Foods, allowing the Japanese company to own 33.14 percent of Tingyi's shares at a cost of US$143 million.

Sanyo Foods is a veteran noodle manufacturer whose annual turnover reached 80 billion Japanese yen in 1998. Sanyo is currently the second-largest instant noodle maker in Japan, and its noodles, mainly marketed under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban," dominate the Japanese market.
In addition to making instant noodles, Sanyo also has golf courses and hotels in Japan.

Sanyo's buying into Tingyi is viewed as a "win win" development, giving a shot in the arm for Sanyo in its bid to explore mainland China's huge instant noodle market with Tingyi's 1,450 distribution centers across the mainland, while instantly relieving Tingyi of its financial strain.

Tingyi currently operates 12 production hubs in mainland China. Ting Hsin entered the mainland market in 1989 with start-up capital of just a few million new Taiwan dollars, but has seen its capital grow to more than NT$32 billion (nearly US$1 billion) over the past 10 years.

Although its annual sales have reached over NT$20 billion (US$612 million) in previous years, Ting Hsin's turnover has been declining in recent years due to growing competition and too-rapid diversification of its business operations.

After nearly one year of talks, President Enterprises and Ting Hsin had still failed to seal a merger accord, mainly because the two companies could not reach a consensus on the price of the 33 percent stake of shares that Tingyi was to have sold to President.

President Enterprises Chairman Kao Chin-yen said he felt sorry about the failure of the merger, but added that the setback will not adversely affect President Enterprises' determination to further crack open the food market of mainland China. Currently, President instant noodles are the second-biggest sellers in the mainland.

President, which first cut into the mainland Chinese market in 1992, has increased its investment capital there to US$270 million, with the number of production plants around the country surging to 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH MONTHLY LAUDS ROC AID TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 15 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A French monthly magazine in its latest issue praised Taiwan for extending cash and humanitarian aid to help Macedonia in its efforts to resettle refugees from Kosovo.

The Economic, Labor and Social Chronicle said both sides of the Taiwan Strait have played a role in the Kosovo conflict -- mainland China explicitly showed support for Yugoslavian President Slobodan Milosevic, while Taiwan silently dispatched cash aid, relief goods and medical teams to help the Kosovar refugees.
However, it said, Taiwan's aid to the Kosovar refugees is not well known to the rest of the world.

The monthly noted that Beijing supported Milosevic's ethnic cleansing movement which has driven ethnic Albanians into refugee camps in neighboring countries, which it said is understandable because the Chinese rulers did the same to the Tibetan people.

But the people and government of the Republic of China, a peace-loving full-fledged democracy, offered to provide humanitarian aid to Macedonia, first by speeding US$2 million-worth of cash, food, medicine and other relief goods to the Kosovar refugees, and following this with another commitment of US$300 million in aid to refugee settlement efforts and reconstruction programs.

In Taiwan, donation drives were launched for the cause of helping the Kosovar refugees, the monthly continued, while a 30-member medical team from Taiwan was sent to the Kosovo-Macedonia border where they built a field hospital to accommodate the refugees, it added.

The magazine said Macedonia's decision to establish formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China was right, and urged the Macedonian government and people to treasure the invaluable friendship that Taiwan has shown to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TIGHTENS VISA REQUIREMENTS FOR 43 HIGH RISK COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Australia is tightening visa applications for citizens from mainland China and 42 other countries because they are highly likely to overstay their visas after entering the country, the Department of Immigration said on Tuesday.
A list compiled by the department designates all mainland Chinese women older than 20 and all men between 20 and 39 or over 60 as likely to overstay their visas, the Australian daily reported.

The department has devised a system involving locally accredited travel agents to get around this problem and mainland Chinese travel agents allowed to organize tours to Australia will lose their accreditation if their clients overstay their visas, the daily reported.

To discourage visitors from high-risk countries, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock has added 10 more countries as potential sources of illegal immigrants to Australia in a bid to tighten entry rules, bringing the total number of high-risk countries to 43.
The newly listed countries are Albania, Bosnia, Bulgaria, Ecuador, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Laos, Lithuania, the Russian Federation and Nepal, the daily reported.
But at the same time, Ruddock also dropped Cyprus, Vanuatu, Slovakia, Portugal, Nauru and Mauritius from the list because of an improvement in visa compliance.
In addition to tightening visa applications, the government is also increasing visa fees for visitors from the high-risk countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-LIBERIAN MIXED COMMISSION CONVENES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The second meeting of the Republic of China-Liberian Mixed Commission opened at the ROC Foreign Ministry on Tuesday to discuss cooperation projects between the two countries.

Following the opening ceremony, presided over by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Liberian counterpart Monie Captan, the two sides started working-level discussions chaired by ROC Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Liberian Vice Economic Planning Minister Norwood Langley.
The minutes of the meeting and an agreement on investment protection will be signed by the two countries' foreign ministers at the close of the meeting on Thursday.
In the first day's meeting, the ROC agreed to provide two sets of power generators for reconstruction of power facilities in the capital, Monrovia, which were damaged in Liberia's civil war.
Taiwan also decided to extend aid for a second phase reconstruction project at Liberia's airport. The first phase project, which was completed in May this year, also received assistance from Taiwan.
Other promised assistance from Taiwan include facilities at Monrovia Port, medical equipment, agricultural machinery and fertilizer.

The ROC and Liberia decided to hold the annual mixed commission meeting alternately in Monrovia and Taipei, when Liberian President Charles Taylor visited Taipei in November 1997. The first meeting was held in the Liberian capital in April last year.

Meanwhile, Taipei City has donated 19 used buses and three garbage-collection trucks to Monrovia, its sister city. The vehicles have already been shipped to Monrovia, and the handover ceremony will be held at the Taipei City Government on June 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR UNCERTAIN OVER FORMAL LOTTERY ISSUANCE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh announced on Tuesday that he has signed a contract with a lottery agent on the terms of formally issuing lottery tickets, but said he has yet to decide whether to begin sales on July 1.
Hsieh made the announcement at a news conference at Kaohsiung City Hall, where he also said he is happy with the big sale of 240,000 trial-version lottery tickets which began on Monday evening.
However, he went on, the popularity of the trial does not mean the formal version can begin as scheduled, because the central government might ban lottery games.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF), the supervisor of lottery affairs, filed a complaint with the prosecution authorities after Kaohsiung City issued the trial lottery tickets, and asked for fines for the local government and confiscation of the profits.

Responding to the complaint, Hsieh said he will not defend his actions, but will wait instead for a judicial decision. He said that if he and his city government is to be punished for trying to help the government free itself from its financial straits, he will appeal.

Hsieh reiterated that he respects the laws regarding the issuance of the charity lottery, and added that he is looking forward to a legal resolution to the dispute between local and central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONIC INDUSTRY STUNNED BY ESPIONAGE ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Security Bureau (NSB) infuriated local electronic manufacturers on Tuesday by alleging that Beijing has gained control of a well-known Taiwan computer company through a Taiwan electronics firm which also operates in mainland China.

The NSB said, without mentioning names, that Beijing has pumped more than NT$1 billion (US$30.76 million) into the Taiwan bourse through the firm to take a controlling stake in the listed Taiwan computer company.

The ploy behind Beijing's venture is to create a collapse of stock prices before the island's 2000 presidential election, and to trigger another round of financial crisis on the island, according to the NSB allegation.
The NSB instructed the Investigative Bureau to probe the case after receiving information from the Military Intelligence Bureau which is charged with collecting information on mainland China.

The Taiwan company in mainland China, with a capitalization of NT$100 million, raised the Military Intelligence Bureau's suspicions when it came up with NT$1 billion to take over a company much bigger than itself, said the NSB.
An investigation by the Investigative Bureau revealed that Beijing is the creditor who financed the deal, said the NSB.
Taiwan's law enforcement authorities routinely warn of disruptive ploys by Beijing before elections, but rarely have they gone so far as to take any espionage case before the court.
Later in the day, a stunned local electronic industry urged the (NSB) to take action against the company in question rather than make unsubstantiated accusations.
Empty rhetoric without action will only panic the market and lead to a disaster without Beijing actually having to lift a finger, said industry representatives.
Many local electronic firms have shifted their plants to mainland China, and have been justifiably infuriated by the NSB's unsubstantiated accusation which casts suspicion on all of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN AUTHORITIES SAID TO BE USING FOOD AID TO BUY VOTES

TEXT.P: Indonesian authorities are using aid money worth nearly US$4.7 million earmarked for poor people to fund pro-autonomy propaganda and militia groups in East Timor, while Nobel laureate Jose Ramos Horta is being banned from returning to the territory, according to documents exclusively obtained by the Sydney Morning Herald.

The daily on Tuesday reported the documents, signed this month by East Timor Governor Abilio Soares, authorize the district head in Ambeno, for example, to spend much of his 3 billion rupiah allocation from President B.J. Habibie's Social Safety Net program in support of the autonomy cause.

Horta, who has been in exile abroad, including Australia for 23 years, has complained to the United Nations about Indonesia's refusal to allow him and the pro-independence leader Xanana Gusmao to campaign in East Timor in July, ahead of the August autonomy ballot.

The daily quoted diplomats and political analysts as saying that the documents, if authenticated, indicate a misuse of international aid from countries such as Australia, which have given substantial amounts to help ease Indonesia's financial crisis. Australia has given Indonesia over US$30 million.
Horta said the UN should immediately send a peacekeeping force to East Timor so that the Timorese can vote without fear or intimidation. (Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DONATES USED POLICE MOTORBIKES TO 5 SISTER CITIES

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government on Tuesday donated 46 used Harley-Davidson police motorcycles to five of Taipei's sister cities in Latin America.

The American-made motorbikes were imported in 1990 for use by the Taipei motorcycle police units. Managua, San Salvador, Santo Domingo and Guatemala City will each get 10, while six will be given to the Honduran Public Security Ministry.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said at the donation ceremony that the move was designed to show Taipei City's goodwill toward its sister cities, and was also based on the concept of the "global village."

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER 67 HEAD OF CATTLE SLAUGHTERED ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: Another 67 head of cattle suspected of being affected with foot and mouth disease (FMD), were destroyed on the island of Kinmen on Tuesday, bringing the number of cattle slaughtered on the island to 132 since Saturday.

About 30 veterinarians and health officials arrived at the Shao She-fu Ranch early on Tuesday, where some of the 58 bulls tested positive for FMD virus, although none of them were displaying symptoms.
The veterinarians took blood and saliva samples before injecting the animals with lethal doses of barbiturate.

The carcasses were buried in a waterproof fabric-lined pit on the ranch, although the process was disrupted briefly by a group of local residents who protested over the mass grave which they said would contaminate the environment and pose a health risk.
They dispersed after being assured by officials that the dead animals will not contaminate the environment.
After burying the cattle, the health officials erected a notice at the site forbidding any opening up of the ground for any reason within three years.
They then cordoned off the ranch and sanitized it before leaving to repeat the process at the Chen Cheng-tsai Ranch, where nine bulls were put to death.
The two ranches were a stone's throw from the Hsin Yao-chih Ranch where 65 head of cattle were slaughtered on Saturday after they were found to be infected with FMD.
Health officials will continue testing at other cattle ranches in the vicinity of the three affected ones, in an attempt to eliminate the disease.

Kinmen, a Taiwan-controlled front line island about 150 nautical miles to the west of southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, has not been declared an FMD-affected area thus far because of the limited number of cases found, according to officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN IOC MEMBER FORCED TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Australia's senior member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has resigned from the board of the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) after being reprimanded by the IOC for "serious negligence" involving a series of bribery scandals.

Phil Coles, 67, tendered his resignation from the SOCOG board on Monday immediately after the IOC reprimanded him for failing to ensure that revealing dossiers written by himself and his partner -- Patricia Rosenrock -- about IOC members did not go outside the Sydney bid committee.

IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch had rejected Coles' last-minute appeal to remain on the SOCOG job. Samaranch claimed the charges that Coles accepted travel and jewelry from the Salt Lake City and Athens Olympic Committees had seriously damaged the IOC's image worldwide.

Coles will be allowed to keep his IOC job, but he will lose a second salary of nearly US$100,000 a year from the Australian Olympic Committee, plus a director's fee of US$33,000 a year from the SOCOG. In addition, he will be suspended from IOC membership for two years. (Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Violence erupts at the legislature as the controversial lottery bill passes the third reading.

The United Daily News:

The China Post:

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND STOWAWAYS TAKE ILAN POLICE OFFICERS HOSTAGE

TEXT.P: Illegal mainland Chinese immigrants detained in the eastern city of Ilan were still holding two detention police officers hostage as of noon Wednesday, demanding early repatriation and a televised live dialogue with Taiwan officials.

The mainland stowaways took officers Lu Chuan-fang and Lin Hu-shih hostage around 10 p.m. Tuesday. The act capped a day of prisoner unrest amid an outbreak of a mysterious disease that claimed three lives there and caused nine others to be hospitalized.

Ilan Magistrate Liu Sho-cheng met with the detainees in the small hours of Wednesday, though he failed to persuade the 373 mainland stowaways at the Ilan Detention Center to release the police officers.

More than 100 members of a crack police force entered the detention center around 8:30 Wednesday morning and managed to disperse more than 100 detainees who were occupying first-floor rooms at the center.
As of 1 p.m. Wednesday, 173 detainees were continuing a standoff with police on the second floor of the center, with the two police officers still in the detainees' hands.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the top Taiwan government agency in charge of mainland Chinese affairs, sped to the eastern coastal city early Wednesday to calm the uproar and get a better understanding of the situation.

Wu was told by the detainees that six to 10 detainee representatives would be selected later in the day to meet with officials from the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in front of television cameras for talks on their early repatriation and on their health problems.
SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow was also heading from Taipei to Ilan Wednesday to help settle the conflict. He was expected to arrive at the center around 2 p.m.

Shi, one of the most seasoned Taiwan negotiators with mainland authorities, urged Beijing to establish a detention center in Xiamen, Fujian province, to accommodate the stowaways so as to help accelerate the repatriation of the illegal mainland immigrants.

He asked the mainland authorities to share the costs of the repatriation and detention of the illegal immigrants, saying the Republic of China government has spent NT$600 million (US$18.4 million) at the Ilan Detention Center alone on accommodations, repatriation and relevant affairs.

In the absence of cooperation from the mainland authorities, illegal immigrants stay in Taiwan detention centers for an average of five months before being repatriated, and each year about 5,000 illegal mainland immigrants are caught by Taiwan police, according to SEF tallies.

In addition, Shi said it is SEF's hope that affairs surrounding the repatriation of mainland hijackers, illegal immigrants and other mainland convicts will be included in talks with the mainland when SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng visits Beijing on June 27 to discuss the forthcoming visit to Taiwan by the mainland's top negotiator, Wang Daohan, later this year.

Meanwhile, MAC Chairman Su Chi bemoaned Beijing's reluctance to cooperate with Taipei on the stowaway repatriation issue, saying that Taiwan is highly sympathetic toward the illegal immigrants, but it needs cooperation from the Beijing authorities to accelerate repatriation efforts.
Besides the Ilan Detention Center, there are two other similar centers located in Hsinchu in northern Taiwan and on the offshore island of Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 16, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1654: Queen Christina of Sweden abdicates in favor of her cousin, Charles Gustavus.
1858: Gustavus V, Swedish monarch who reigned for 43 years, is born. He kept Sweden neutral through both world wars.
1869: Charles Sturt, English explorer who discovered much of Australia, dies at the age of 74.
1890: Stan Laurel, American comedian, is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of talking films. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Dr. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at the Whampoa Military Academy and is presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1928: Sinkiang pledges allegiance to the Nationalist government after Chiang Kai-shek resumed the Northern Expedition on April 7.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling the severe economic problems of the American nation.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1948: The first air hijacking occurs when Chinese bandits attempt to take over a Cathay Airways Catalina aircraft. The crew fight back and the aircraft crashes, killing all but the leader of the hijackers.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1958: Yellow lines marking no-parking zones appear on British roads.
1958: Imre Nagy, former prime minister of Hungary, is hanged for the role he played in an unsuccessful 1956 revolution that was crushed by Soviet tanks.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the US Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1983: The European rocket Ariane 1 blasts off from the French National Space Center at Kouron, French Guinea.
1983: Yuri Andropov is elected chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, a position equivalent to president.
1987: The Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls at the proper time. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: US President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MORE THAN WILLING TO CONTRIBUTE TO WORLD PEACE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is more than willing to contribute to world peace and development and the well-being of all mankind, ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said on Tuesday.
The de facto ROC ambassador made the statement at a seminar on the reconstruction of the war-torn Balkan peninsula.
In his speech, Chen explained in detail a US$300 million aid package proposed by the ROC government last week for Kosovars.

Noting that the ROC shares the same political, economic and humanitarian ideals with all other countries around the world, Chen said Taiwan looks forward to joining various international relief programs and providing financial aid and technological assistance to needed people and developing countries.

Chen said Taiwan has long forsaken a "zero-sum" stance in handling disputes with mainland China. "We hope all countries around the world will follow the example of the United States and maintain parallel engagements with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

The career diplomat called on major countries around the world not to reject resources and manpower provided by Taiwan for international relief programs nor ignore its willingness to cooperate with other countries in promoting global stability, prosperity and democratic reforms.

Chen said the ROC has offered humanitarian aid to Kosovar refugees in Macedonia, including offering various relief goods and free medical services. In the past four decades, he said, the ROC has assisted many developing countries in economic development through agricultural and fishery technological cooperation.

The one-day seminar was sponsored by the Center for Reconstruction and Development. Ambassadors to the United States from many Balkan countries, including Macedonia, Albanian, Bosnia, Bulgaria and Greece, the representative of the provisional Kosovo government, and officials from the European Union, the World Bank and other international relief organizations also attended the seminar.

Dino Asanaj, the Kosovo interim government stationed in the United States, said about 1,000 villages in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo are no longer suitable for living because of destruction by Serbs.

Asanaj said the Kosovo interim government appreciates the ROC's aid offer. "We hope to forge contacts with Taiwan authorities to discuss concrete relief measures," he said, adding that his office in New York has not had any contact with the ROC's representative office in the United States.
The ROC's aid offer was announced by President Lee Teng-hui on June 7, and highlights of the package include:
-- Emergency support with food, shelter, medical care and education for the Kosovar refugees who are currently living in exile countries neighboring Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province.
-- Short-term accommodation for some of the refugees in Taiwan, with opportunities for job training in order to better equip them for the restoration of their homeland upon their return.
-- Support for the rehabilitation of Kosovo in coordination with international recovery programs.
