DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES REACH 8,000-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices rose 1.2 percent on Wednesday to breach the psychologically important 8,000-point level, buoyed by strong buying in the financial and electronics sectors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index soared 99.02 points, ending the day at 8,059.02 points.
A total of 2.61 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$156.56 billion (US$4.83 billion), up from the previous session's NT$139.47 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics and financial stocks posted the only gains of the day, rising 2.8 percent and 0.9 percent, respectively.
As the majority of funds were concentrated in financial and electronics shares, the other six categories all registered losses for the day, with foodstuff issues dropping the most at 2.4 percent.
Textile shares fell 1.1 percent, closely followed by plastic and chemical shares, which declined 1 percent.
Cement stocks went down 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues 0.6 percent, and the construction sector registered a 0.3-percent loss.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market suffered a slight drop of 0.23 points, closing at 175.07 points, with a turnover of NT$6.14 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June surged 147 points to close at 8,090 points, with 2,128 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July jumped 173 points to close at 8,113 points, while those for September increased by 131 points, closing at 8,082 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3,526 and 113, respectively.
December futures gained 51 points to close at 8,021 points, with four contract transactions. No transactions were registered for next March.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,943 points for June, 7,940 points for July, 7,951 points for September, 7,970 points for December, and 7,993 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PLAYS DOWN 'SECURITY DIALOGUE' WITH INDIA

TEXT.P: Beijing has played down the decision to establish a security dialogue mechanism between mainland China and India during the ongoing visit of Union External Affairs Minister Jaswant Singh of India to Beijing, a New Delhi-based English daily reported from Beijing Tuesday afternoon.

In response to Singh's statement on Monday that India and mainland China have agreed to establish a security dialogue mechanism between the two Asian states, Zhang Qiyue, Beijing's foreign ministry spokeswoman, said she could not comment on the issue, according to The Hindustan Times.
Zhang later said she had no information on the proposed security dialogue between mainland China and India, the newspaper added.

Singh who arrived in Beijing Monday for a three-day visit, told Indian reporters Monday in Beijing that the security dialogue would be held at "an appropriate level" and that the details would be chalked out by the foreign ministers of the two sides.
Singh said the proposed security dialogue with Beijing still had to be fleshed out, however, Indian officials believed that its focus is likely to be largely bilateral.

According to the English daily, while proposing a security dialogue with India, the mainland Chinese foreign minister apparently told his Indian counterpart that the two neighbors needed to discuss security concerns in both a regional and a global context.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPRANATIONAL FORUMS GIVE QUEBEC POWERFUL ARGUMENT FOR INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: A ranking Quebec official said independence will continue to be a priority for Quebecers over the next 25 years, as Quebec's economic destiny is intimately linked to its political destiny.

Bernard Landry, deputy premier and minister of finance of Quebec, said, "If we as a province are absent from all the forums where the key decisions are made, we will continue paying a very heavy price."

In an interview appearing in the current issue of Forces -- a Quebec economic, social and cultural quarterly -- Landry pointed out that globalization calls for supranational interventions, but "only nations are called to supranational forums."
Luxembourg will be there; so will Chile and the Central African Republic, he said. "But if Quebec is not there, people from Ottawa claiming to represent us will be," he added.

He acknowledged that federal officials "will be right" sometimes, but at others times, "they will simply be advocating for the heart of Canada," he said, referring to Ontario, Canada's largest province in terms of population.
As long as Quebec is merely a province, it will not be at those forums, he said. "If this continues over the next 25 years, it will be a tragedy for Quebec."
This is the most powerful economic argument that exists in favor of Quebec's sovereignty, Landry emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBANIAN REFUGEES REFUSE TO STAY IN AUSSIE ARMY BARRACKS

TEXT.P: About 80 ethnic Albanian refugees taking temporary shelter in Australia have refused to stay at former army barracks and instead bedded down in buses for the second consecutive night on Tuesday, because of poor accommodations at Singleton, northwest of Sydney.
They said the Australian army barracks were no better than the camps they had previously stayed at in Macedonia, falling short of their expectations for better shelter in Australia.

The Albanian refugees said the facilities are lacking heat, and toilets are hundreds of meters away from where they are staying within the Singleton barracks. In addition, they also complained about the presence of wild animals, including snakes and kangaroos.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said he had ruled out sending the refugees back to Sydney's East Hills army barracks. In response to some refugees floating the idea of going home, Ruddock indicated the refugees would be free to go, provided they paid their own airfare, which would be impossible for the refugees, because they have little money.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADING PARTNERS' INACTION IN SOLVING Y2K WILL LIKELY BUG AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Inaction among Australia's trading partners in fixing the millennium bug could trigger major problems for Australian industries, with financial service firms expected to suffer the most, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture Resources and Economics (ABARE).

The ABARE on Tuesday released a report in which it said that two-thirds of companies in mainland China, Indonesia and the Philippines will suffer from critical systems failures. Those countries are all Australia's trading partners.

The report indicated the United States and Australia are rated as the best in their preparations for Y2K. Japan -- Australia's No. 1 trading partner -- is tied with Taiwan, South Korea, New Zealand, Singapore and Thailand as second best in their readiness to solve the Y2K problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAYS DELAY MAY BE NECESSARY IN EAST TIMOR BALLOT

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has flagged a possible delay of the scheduled Aug. 8 ballot in East Timor and pledged additional logistical support for the UN mission because of continuing intimidation by pro-Indonesian militia in the territory.

Meanwhile, the Indonesian army is expected to be the big winner from the country's first democratic election in 44 years because it appears set to hold the balance of power in a hung parliament, according to Australian media reports.

Downer told Australian journalists in New York that he discussed the matter with UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, and he said Australia wanted the ballot to go ahead on Aug. 8, though it was even more important that people be able to vote without being harassed.
"We very much hope it will occur, but it has to be a free and fair ballot ... otherwise, (it) would not take forward the task of achieving a solution for East Timor," he said.
Downer is floating a delay of "a couple of weeks" for the ballot if militia harassment continues.
Major Australian newspapers reported on Wednesday that although Megawati Sukarnoputri's PDI-P is still leading in the vote count, it will likely win fewer than 160 seats in the 500-seat parliament.

If she wants to win the presidential election in November, she has to win the support of army, which holds an appointed 38 seats in addition to cooperating with the moderate Muslim PKB Party, which is expected to win 51 seats, according to a calculation by The Australian Financial Review.
If she could win support from Amien Rais' party, PAN, then she would gain 33 additional seats, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC HELPS SYDNEY CUT COSTS AS OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS SEEK NEW SPONSORS

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC), eager to restore its credibility after a series of corruption scandals, has helped the organizers of the 2000 Olympic Games cut costs, while the resignation of a senior Australian IOC member is paving the way for efforts to seek new sponsors to make up for financial shortfalls.

IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranch worked out plans to help Sydney save money at a meeting in Seoul on Tuesday. The plans call for lobsters to be removed from the menu for Olympic officials, and planned bouquets at the hotels where the officials will be staying have been canceled as well.
Expensive sightseeing and guided shopping tours for IOC spouses are also out under an agreement reached between the IOC and the Sydney for Organizing Committee for Olympic Games on Tuesday in Seoul.
Officials estimate the savings will be more than US$1.7 million.
They said the resignation of Australian IOC member Phil Coles on Monday is expected to result in new sponsors for the 2000 Olympic Games in the coming months.
The resignation has now put an end to corruption scandals involving IOC members, they said, adding that Sydney organizers are still short almost US$70 million in sponsorship.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.01 against the greenback in Taipei on Wednesday, closing at 32.374.
The local currency opened at 32.372 and was traded between 32.348 and 32.4.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$324 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE ACADEMIC SEMINAR TO OPEN IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 110 scholars and experts from Taiwan, along with 165 academic elite of Chinese descent living in North America, are to gather in Washington in early July for a three-day academic seminar.

The 6th North American Chinese Academic Seminar is slated to open on July 2, with participants divided into 11 groups to release 181 theses, 69 of which will be from Taiwan, according to Dr. Lee Wu-lang, chief convenor of the preparatory committee for the seminar.

Lee predicted that the upcoming seminar will be three times larger in scale than similar government-sponsored national development seminars held in Taiwan, and added that the Washington seminar will be the largest and highest-caliber Chinese academic conference in the United States.

Lee, who works at the US Department of Treasury, said the seminar is aimed at helping the Taiwan authorities in a variety of fields. Gathering the collective wisdom of the attending academicians, Lee said, can contribute to Taiwan's national development.

Other sources in the preparatory committee said several ministerial-level Taiwan officials, including Finance Minister Paul Chiu and Chairman Su Chi of the Mainland Affairs Council, will attend the seminar, some of whom will be invited to speak.
The seminar will center on challenges and tasks facing the Republic of China in the approach of the 21st century.

The theses presented will cover a range of topics including Taiwan's foreign and cross-Taiwan Strait relations; the judicial system; reforms of the educational systems; economic development; finance and monetary affairs; strategies for science and technology development; construction and management of transportation systems; health care; environmental protection; labor-related policy and reform; and agricultural development.
The papers will be discussed, and there will also be conferences on high-tech investment and overseas Chinese affairs.
The Chinese academic seminar in North America, which takes place every three years, was first held in 1984 in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO OVERSEE HI-SPEED RAILWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will take part in all aspects of Taiwan's first high-speed railway project, including discussions on a loan agreement, CEPD Chairman P.K. Chiang said on Wednesday.

Chiang met at a breakfast meeting with Nita Ing, chairman of the Taiwan High-Speed railway Corp. (THSRC), a private business and industry consortium which won the contract last year to build the high-speed railway system, to clear up recent reports that cast doubt on THSRC's ability to complete the project by June 2003 as scheduled.
According to the reports, Ing had said that the THSRC would consider giving up the contract if the loan agreement could not reached in the near future.

Chiang said he will personally preside over meetings of a CEPD-sponsored supra-ministerial task force on the high-speed railway development project, adding that if the THSRC has any doubts or difficulties regarding loan acquisition and other related issues, the company should approach him for a possible solution, rather than making "improper complaints."

In the future, he said, relevant CEPD officials will take part in all discussions regarding loan agreements, and the meetings will also be attended by officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications, the THSRC, and the bank consortium.

In addition, the CEPD high-speed railway task force will be involved in all discussions on other development and relevant issues concerning the project, Taiwan's first BOT (build-operate-transfer) endeavor, to ensure the smooth running of the multi-billion dollar project, Chiang noted.

He stressed the importance of exercising the "spirit of partnership" by all parties involved in the project, adding that the CEPD and other relevant government agencies are actually partners in the project rather than supervisors.

The US$13 billion railway is expected to shuttle passengers from Taipei in the north of the island to the southern port city of Kaohsiung in just 90 minutes, at a maximum speed of 300 kilometers per hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DISTRICT COURT TO FORGE ALLIANCE WITH ROMAN COUNTERPART
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 15 (CNA) (By P.C. Fang and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: The President of the Taipei District Court (TDC) on Tuesday proposed an alliance with the Rome District Court, and suggested that it could be signed into effect in November in Taipei to coincide with an international judges' conference slated to be held there.

TDC President Chen I-hsiung, the leader of a visiting delegation of 14 magistrates from the district courts of Taipei, Panchiao and Taoyuan, noted that if the plan goes through, the Rome District Court will become TDC's third sister court along with the Hamburg and Vienna district courts.
The delegation members attended a seminar with their Roman counterparts on various legal procedures, and the ROC delegation was invited to attend hearings at the Roman first- and second-trial courts.
The delegation arrived in Europe on June 6, and visited the Hamburg and Vienna courts before traveling to Rome. It will later proceed to Paris before returning to Taipei on June 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL INTERNET STOCK TRADING BOOMS

TEXT.P: Stock trading on the Internet has become the most popular type of e-mail commerce in Taiwan, with transaction amounts and the number of traders increasing at an astounding rate.

Currently, more than 40 local stocks and securities companies have started providing Internet stock trading services to over 130,000 account holders, a huge jump from the few thousand people who started using the system in July 1997, when the Tah Hsin Securities Co. took the lead in introducing the new trading method.

Over 8,000 Tah Hsin customers now conduct stock trading via the Internet, with monthly transactions topping NT$3 billion, a 30-fold increase from two years ago. The level of business is approaching that of a conventional trading branch, a sign that Internet stock trading has great growth potential in Taiwan.

At the same time, the overall monthly amount of stock transactions through the Internet across Taiwan jumped from the NT$1 billion level in January to more than NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) in April, for a daily average of around NT$2 billion per day. At this pace, the daily transaction figure is expected to top the NT$10 billion mark by the end of this year.

As purchases through the Internet can help save a great deal on personnel spending, many local large stocks and securities firms, including China Securities Co., Ltd., Jih Sun Securities Co., Ltd., Polaris Securities Co., Ltd., Kong Cheng Securities Investment Consulting Co., and Core Pacific Securities Investment Consulting Co., Ltd., are preparing to promote Internet trading coupled with extra incentives such as lowering commission charges and providing financial management information.

Although the amount of Taiwan's Internet stock trading remains limited compared to the level in the United States, the trading method is destined to become a local trend as Taiwan's "Internet community" continues to rise.
So far, several groups are planning to merge their stocks and securities firms, fueled by the boom in Internet trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST-TIME DRUNK DRIVING VIOLATORS TO DO FORCED LABOR

TEXT.P: First-time violators of Taiwan's drunken driving laws will be punished with forced labor in the form of community service in an effort to curb rampant drunken driving, sources from the Legislative Yuan said on Wednesday.

The Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee on Wednesday passed an amendment to the Traffic Control and Punishment Statute, deciding that first-time drunken drivers be penalized by up to 50 hours of community service.

Vice Transportation and Telecommunications Minister Chen Shih-chi, who was present at the Legislative Yuan committee meeting, said his ministry supports the amendment, adding that if the punishment proves effective, similar penalties will be applied to other traffic violations such as speeding.

The amendment, originally authored by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Hsueh-feng, stipulates that repeated drunken drivers who fail a blood alcohol content test should be fined between NT$6,000 and NT$12,000 and have their driver's license suspended for six months, while first offenders should be made to perform up to 50 hours of community service.

It also stipulates that drunken drivers, whether first-time or repeat offenders, who are involved in accidents resulting in minor injuries should have their driver's licenses suspended for two years, while those involved in accidents resulting in heavy injuries or fatalities should have their driver's licenses revoked permanently.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS PROPOSE RECALL OF LEGISLATIVE VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) threatened on Wednesday to propose the recall of Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi, accusing him of "partiality."
The DPP legislative caucus also accused Yao of failing to take action when lawmakers from the ruling Kuomintang "physically attacked" DPP legislators.
The DPP legislative caucus said at a press conference that the KMT must take complete responsibility for Tuesday's violence in the legislature.
Chang then accused the KMT of ramming through bills governing local farmer's and fishermen's associations in order to win votes in the 2000 presidential election.
The passage of the regulations will allow people with criminal appeals pending to run for office in the grassroots associations, which will lead to a breakdown in social order, noted Chang.
Another bill rammed through which will allow betting on car and horse racing will generate negative impact on society, and the DPP also protested its passage, Chang said.
Meanwhile, DPP chairman Lin Yi-hsiung urged the KMT to harshly punish those who led the attack in the legislature, and to force Rau to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL FOR LOWER IMPORT TARIFFS ON 750 ITEMS PASSED BY LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday examined and passed a draft amendment to the customs' import tariff statute, covering up to 750 products.

The move, part of Taiwan's efforts to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), will see the average tariff rate after revision decreased to 8.14 percent from the previous 8.22 percent. As a result, the government's total tax revenue is expected to drop by NT$3.92 billion annually.

To implement Taiwan's promises to the US and Canada regarding Taiwan's access to the world trade regulatory body, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) listed 750 products whose import tariffs have to be amended. Among the listed commodities, agricultural products account for 125 items, while industrial products account for 625 items.

MOF Vice Minister Yen Ching-chang noted that in addition to the reduction of tariffs on imported agricultural and industrial raw materials, products whose import tariffs are unreasonably structured will also be examined and revised. The measures should ensure an improved investment environment, he said.
In the agricultural products sector, a total of 1,300 items are listed under the current customs statute as subject to import tax at an average tariff of 20.02 percent, Yen indicated.

However, he added that since just 125 of these products have been listed in the amendment, most of which are in any case not produced domestically, the forthcoming tariff decrease is not expected to harm Taiwan's agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 163 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Wednesday repatriated 163 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants from its front-line defense outpost of Matsu, two days before the Dragon Boat Festival, a major holiday in the Chinese calendar.
Hsu Cheng-chieh, director of the Matsu detention center for illegal immigrants, said that all those repatriated -- 145 men and 18 women -- were in good health.

Hsu said the center originally planned to repatriate only 140 people, but in view of the Dragon Boat Festival, he said he suggested to mainland Chinese Red Cross Society officials that the number be increased.
After bilateral consultations, the mainland finally agreed to take back the additional 18 illegal immigrants.

The released immigrants began boarding the ferry boat Haixia for their home-bound voyage at around 10 a.m. All of them looked happy to be going home after having been detained at the Matsu center for periods of between several months to more than a year.

According to the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross societies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1991, mainland China must take back seized illegal mainland immigrants within 20 days of their capture, but it has never abided by that regulation, and last year took back just four batches of detained illegal immigrants, totaling slightly more than 400 people.
More than 1,000 are still awaiting repatriation in the Matsu center and two similar detention facilities in Taiwan.

According to statistics compiled by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, Taiwan seizes an average of 5,000 illegal mainland immigrants annually, each of which has to stay in Taiwan for an average of 130 days before mainland authorities decide to take them back.

MAC Chairman Su Chi said on Wednesday that illegal mainland immigrants have become a heavy financial burden, adding that Taiwan has spent over NT$600 million providing food, clothing and shelter for them.
Official tallies show that some 36,700 illegal mainland immigrants have been repatriated since 1987 when Taiwan opened its doors to cross-strait civilian exchanges.

Wednesday's repatriation followed reports that three detainees in the Ilan detention center in northeastern Taiwan had died from an unknown disease since the beginning of this year, and that nine others have been hospitalized. The outbreak has caused unrest among the detainees and prompted them to take two police officers hostage on Tuesday night. The hostage drama was still unfolding as of press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 TAIWAN RANCHES BARRED FROM TRADING OR MOVING CATTLE
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 16 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two cattle ranches in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan have been barred from selling or moving their livestock off their farms, local animal disease control officials said on Wednesday.

The Animal Disease Control Department under the Tainan County Government issued the moving and trading ban after eight head of cattle raised in the two ranches in Shanhua township tested positive for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

The discovery has raised concern around the island, especially as more than 100 head of cattle raised in two ranches on the offshore front-line island of Kinmen were slaughtered over the past week due to FMD infection.
According to county government officials, 29 Kinmen cattle were shipped to Taiwan in early June, 20 of which were sent to Shanhua township.

After Kinmen cattle were confirmed to have been infected with "type O Kinmen" FMD virus, the Tainan animal disease control department last week sent officials to cattle ranches located within three kilometers of the ranch where the Kinmen cattle were housed to collect blood and saliva samples of the animals for FMD tests.
Initial examination reports show that eight head of cattle from two ranches in the township carried high levels of FMD antibodies.

The Taiwan Animal Health Research Institute under the provincial government said it will conduct further examinations to determine whether the cattle have really been infected with FMD virus. "The final examination result will be available in five days' time," said an institute official.
If the cattle are confirmed to have been infected with the virus, county government officials said all cattle raised in the two ranches will be slaughtered to prevent further spread of the disease.
Taiwan cattle were last hit by the FMD virus in 1929.

FMD is an acute, contagious disease that can be spread via air and infects mainly cloven-hoofed livestock and wild animals. Its mortality rate is 5 percent, but can rise to 50 percent in young animals.
Taiwan's hog farms were hit by an FMD outbreak in 1997, resulting in the death of 3.85 million pigs and an estimated financial loss of NT$160 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY GOVERNMENT FINED NT$1.5 M. FOR LOTTERY ISSUANCE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has decided to fine the Kaohsiung City government and Trio Technology NT$1.5 million each for having issued and distributed charity lottery tickets without receiving the ministry's permission.
The ministry said that under exisitng regulations governing the issuance of charity lotteries, local governments can issue tickets only with the prior approval of the Finance Ministry.

However, the Kaohsiung City government's applications were rejected by the Finance Ministry in March, April and May, respectively. The ministry also instructed the city government to immediately stop all preparatory work in regard to lottery issuance, but the Kaohsiung City government, in defiance of the directives, on June 14 launched its charity lottery.

In addition to the NT$1.5 million fines on the Kaohsiung City government and Trio Technology, which was contracted to print and distribute the lottery, the ministry will also file suit against them for violating gambling laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO POLICE OFFICERS TAKEN HOSTAGE BY MAINLAND DETAINEES RELEASED

TEXT.P: Two police officers held hostage by illegal mainland immigrants at an Ilan detention center for 20 hours were released unharmed early Wednesday evening.
After their release the two officers appeared at a press conference shortly after 6:00 p.m. at the Chinglu detention center, where 383 illegal mainland immigrants are being held pending repatriation.

In answering questions from the press, the officers avoided using the word of hostage, rather they said they were prevented from leaving the cell after entering to evaluate an detainee complaining of illness Tuesday night.
They said they were not ill-treated and their lives were never in danger during the 20-hour standoff.
The detainees rioted Tuesday night after three died and nine more fell ill from an unknown disease. Most of the detainees are anxious to return home before the Dragon Boat Festival on Friday.
They demanded earlier repatriation and staged a hunger strike.

Two representatives of the detainees appeared at Wednesday's press conference. They claimed mainland immigrants coming to Taiwan to seek better lives have never disrupted social order and should not be treated as criminals.
The detainees agreed to release the two hostages after Shi Hwei-yow, secretary general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, promised during face-to-face negotiations to deport them before June 27.
Shi also promised at the press conference not to punish those responsible for the riot and to seek better treatment for the detainees.
According to government's statistics, since Taiwan first opened a detention center for illegal mainland immigrants in 1987, more than 37,000 mainland citizens have been held.

Although Beijing has promised to process Taiwan inquiries about the immigrants' identities within 20 days, on average a detainee stays in the center for 169 days at a cost of NT$17,000 (US$523). Since 1987 Taiwan taxpayers have spent a total of NT$700 million (21.67 million) on detaining illegal mainland immigrants.
About 36,000 detainees have already been deported with approximately 1,000 more waiting repatriation in three different detention centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SME EXPERIENCE WILL BENEFIT EASTERN EUROPE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Premier Vincent Siew Wednesday said that Taiwan's alliance with Macedonia has introduced the country to the Eastern Europe market.
Siew made the remarks while receiving government and economics officials from the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Lithuania.

Siew said out that small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have played an important role in Eastern Europe's transition to market-oriented economy, and that that Taiwan's SME development experience will benefit the region.
Though Taiwan's SME investments in Eastern Europe are not large, they are long-term, and will influence the development of the region's market economy, Siew said.

Siew pointed out that the ROC is preparing to send a large SME delegation to Macedonia in August to explore the Eastern European market and investment opportunities, which hopefully will expand Taiwan's contact with the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND STOWAWAYS' ILLNESS STEMS FROM MALNUTRITION

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) health authorities announced on Wednesday that the illegal mainland Chinese immigrants at the Chinglu detention center in Ilan county suffering from the rare rhabdomolysis disease were probably caused by lack of vitamin B1 and long-term malnutrition.
Department of Health officials also pointed out rhabdomolysis is not contagious and poses no threat to Taiwan residents.
After three stowaways died and nine others hospitalized, detainees held two detention police officers hostage for 20 hours while demanding early repatriation.

The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Tuesday informed its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Strait (ARATS) that two detainees, Chen Guosheng and Hsieh Zhungfeng died of rhabdomyolysis on June 7 and 13, respectively.

DOH Bureau of Communicable Disease Control (BCDC) Director Tu Hsing-che pointed out in an interview Wednesday that the DOH has sent a team of epidemiologists to Ilan to perform health chedkup on the detainees. The DOH has consulted with medical experts from the National Taiwan University and the Veteran's Hospital as well, Tu said.
According to the medical group, rhabdomyolysis is caused by a lack of vitamin B1 intake and long-term malnutrition, he pointed out.
While the possibility of the disease causing an epidemic has been lowered, Tu said, the root cause of the disease remains to be discovered by medical experts.
As for the condition of the 11 hospitalized stowaways, Tu said they have improved considerably after medical treatment.

Tu also pointed out after a medical survey was conducted among the 171 mainlanders at the Ilan detention center, it was discovered that 20 reported numbness in their lower limbs, a symptom of long-term malnutrition.
Tu said the DOH has demanded local health authorities step up isolation measures on hospitalized patients, in addition to sterilizing the detention center.
The DOH also suggested that the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) continue inspecting illegal mainland immigrants to prevent epidemics from entering Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN WON'T IMPLEMENT 'GAMBLING CLAUSE'

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan (Cabinet) Secretary-General Hsieh Shen-shan said on Wednesday that the government firmly opposes the "gambling clause" passed by the Legislative Yuan Tuesday night.

The "gambling clause" allows, with the approval of supervising institutions, the issuance of lottery tickets for internationally-recognized car racing, horse racing, boat racing events as well as special public lottery tickets.
But Hsieh stated that the Cabinet's position of opposing the issuance of international lotteries is firm, as it is impossible to issue such lotteries in Taiwan under the present circumstances.
The "gambling clause" was written into an amendment to the public lottery statute and railroaded through the legislature with the support of Kuomintang legislators.
The session was boycotted by legislators from the Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party, the two major opposition parties.

Hsieh said that the Cabinet will not try to reverse the "gambling clause" in the Legislative Yuan, but will also not formulate relevant regulations for its implementation, letting it become a "dead clause."
It is understood that during lottery issue debate, the Cabinet indicated its stiff opposition to including a "gambling clause" into the amendment.

Following the passage of the clause, Premier Vincent Siew reiterated the Cabinet's stance when he met with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Vice President Yao Eng-chi after a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTC RULES 1ST CASE OF RICE WINE HOARDING

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) on Wednesday decided to fine a dealer of Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) NT$1.2 million for hoarding a large quantity of rice wine.
The FTC ruled that Yi Shun Hang in May had illegally hoarded rice wine, a traditional necessity goods in Taiwan, used in cooking.
It was the first fine imposed by the FTC on a TTWB dealer since the hoarding of rice wine began a few months ago.
According to data recently sent to the FTC by the TTWB, Yi Shun Hang hoarded 26,180 bottles of rice wine in May, far exceeding the minimum stock of 5,000 bottles.

Liu Tzong-rong, vice chairman of the FTC, said because rice wine is a necessity good, hoarding adversely effects the market mechanism. Hoarding also causes an imbalance of supply and demand and violates the law governing equal trade.

The FTC indicated that the price of rice wine had bulged to NT$65 per bottle in May, from its original price of NT$25. The NT$40 surcharge on the 21,000 bottles would bring Yi Shun Hang an illegal profit of at least NT$800,000, the FTC said.
Rice wine is an important ingredient in preparing Chinese food, and is an important ingredient in "ma yu" chicken, a stew used to nourish women back to health after childbirth.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS NOTE :

DOC.HEADLINE: Editor's Note:
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 16 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S COMMODITY EXPORTS SEEN AS FALLING DUE TO CURRENCY RISE

TEXT.P: Australia's commodity exports are expected to drop by over 6 percent in two years as a result of falling mineral prices, lower sales of farm products and, above all, the appreciation of the local dollar, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics (ABARE).
ABARE estimates the total value of commodity exports at A$63.1 billion (US$42.1 billion) in 1998-99, a fall of A$3.9 billion (US$2.6 billion) from 1997-98.

ABARE in a report said lower coal and iron-ore prices will more than offset higher commodity volumes. Higher gold prices will fail to boost the total value of exports of the precious metal, with significant falls in volume predicted.

The outlook for farm exports is mixed, but a stronger Australian dollar against the US currency will wipe out some of the gains from higher prices in the farm sector. The Australian dollar has increased from 56 US cents in August 1998 to 66 US cents now.
ABARE said the long-term outlook is more optimistic, however, with a commodity price recovery forecast alongside stronger world economic growth in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGARY HOPES TAIWAN WILL EXPAND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Visiting Hungarian Vice Economics Minister Gabor Gulacsi on Wednesday called on Taiwan to expand its investment in Hungary amid the increasing amount of two-way trade between the two countries.

Gulacsi made the call while presiding over the opening ceremony for "Hungary Day" at the on-going Eurogate '99 trade fair in Taipei. Over 30 Hungarian businesses are attending the fair, displaying products which strongly feature national and cultural characteristics.

In his address, Gulacsi described Taiwan as Hungary's major trade partner in Asia, noting that Taiwan-Hungary trade has grown by 20 percent annually over the last three decades. Most of this trade has been in high-tech and telecommunication products, he said.

Gulacsi said that Hungary is expected to join the European Union by 2002, and that continuing economic reforms are helping his country in the promotion of stable political and economic development. These factors will be of benefit to Taiwan if it keeps investing in Hungary, he pointed out.

At present, there are 24 Taiwan companies with investments in the eastern European country, three of which are involved in computer-related business, while the rest are mostly traders in goods such as household electric appliances, sports equipment, shoes, garments, furniture, and bicycles.

Eurogate '99 has attracted businesses from Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland, and Lithuania, all of whom are hoping to gain a toehold in the Taiwan market and to lure Taiwan investment to their countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAUNCH OF CENTRAL GOVERNMENT'S LOTTERY TO BE MOVED UP

TEXT.P: In response to the Kaohsiung City Government's issuance of its lottery on Tuesday the Ministry of Finance announced on Wednesday that it will consult with the Bank of Taiwan about the possibility of launching a national charity lottery sometime before the end of the year.

One day after the revised charity lottery statute passed through the Legislative Yuan, Minister of Finance Paul Chiu told a press conference that a resolution by the Finance Committee at the Legislative Yuan demanded his ministry launch the lottery by the end of this year.

Government rules require any acquirement contracts with a value more than a certain level be put to public bid, thus taking more time to implement. The Finance Committee gave Chiu's ministry six months to make the necessary arrangements.
The MOF will consult the Bank of Taiwan which is to be charged with issuing the lottery tickets in an attempt to speed up the lottery's inauguration, said Chiu.

Half of the profits from the lottery will go to charity or causes that benefit the public, the other half will fund the proposed national pension. Government bodies are still discussing the specifics of the pension plan.

The lottery statute was added by legislators over the MOF's opposition a clause aimed to bring into Taiwan "internationally approved sport gambling", such as car racing and horse racing. Chiu spoke out against the clause by saying the Executive Yuan has firmly asserted its opposition to any form of gambling and that his ministry will not permit the activity.

Chiu remarks about advancing the inauguration of the central government's lottery came one day after the Kaohsiung City Government issued its own lottery on Tuesday in defiance of the MOF's prohibition.
Insisting that the issuance of lottery is the exclusive authority of the central government, the MOF has threatened a heavy fine on the Kaohsiung City Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES WANTS KOREAS TO EXERCISE RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: Expressing concern over the latest naval clash in The Korean Peninsula, Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada on Wednesday urged South and North Korea to continue exercising maximum restraint to defuse tension in the area. The President said the clash, which came only a few days following his successful state visit to South Korea, should not be allowed to escalate to ensure peace and stability in East and Southeast Asia. "I'm calling on both sides to continue exercising maximum restraint to allow the situation in the peninsula to normalize," Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican quoted President Estrada as saying. The statement was issued following reports that the South and North Korean navies traded fire Tuesday in their first clash in the Yellow Sea since the Korean War erupted in 1950.

Barican said the Philippine government is urging both sides to proceed with their high-level talks scheduled next Monday in Beijing, even as he noted that the 'unfortunate incident should not affect Kim Dae-Jung's efforts to improve economic and diplomatic contacts with the North. He added that the Philippines is concerned about the situation in the Korean Peninsula not only because of Manila's diplomatic ties with Seoul, but also because of the presence of some 15,000 Filipinos in South Korea. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERTS COMING TO HELP PROBE INTO F-16 CRASHES

TEXT.P: Three groups of American aviation experts will arrive in Taipei in the next few days to help investigate three crashes involving F-16 fighters that Taiwan purchased from the United States (US), the ROC Air Force headquarters said on Tuesday.

One group of experts will exclusively take part in the probe into the cause of the latest mishap -- a F-16 single-seater that disappeared off the coast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan during a routine training mission on June 1.
A second team will try to help retrieve the wreckage of the fighter that is believed to have crashed into the sea.
The last group will try to determine whether there are any common factors in the three crashes.

A F-16 with its crew of two disappeared in the vicinity of the offshore island of Penghu in March of last year. That mishap was followed in late January this year by another F-16 two-seater crashing into a mountainous area near Taitung, claiming the lives of its two pilots.
As part of efforts to modernize its air force, Taiwan has ordered 150 F-16 MLU (mid-life-upgraded) fighters from the US. Delivery of the fighters has yet to be completed.

The crashes have forced the Air Force to slow the commissioning of its F-16 jet fighter wings and prolong F-16 pilot training in order to enhance their capability to operate the highly advanced warplanes.

In order to increase the flight safety of the US-made fighters, the Air Force recently sent a group of officials to Singapore in an effort to understand how the Singapore Air Force operates its F-16 fleet, a ranking Air Force official said.

Taiwan lent a helping hand when Singapore established its air force after the city state's independence in 1965. The Singapore Air Force has established a five-year no-accident record for its F-16 fighters, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK HIT BY POWER BLACKOUT

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park suffered its worst power blackout on Wednesday morning, with all factories in the park affected.
Power to most factories returned to normal by Wednesday evening. But the losses incurred by the blackout were estimated at more than NT$1 billion (US$30.3 million).
According to initial reports, the power-generating facilities of Winbond Electronics Corp. went out of order twice in the morning.

Responsibility for the power stoppage remains unclear as Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) said that the industrial park's power blackout was caused by the incident at Winbond. Winbond, however, said that its incident was caused by Taipower's short-time power stoppage.

The affected firms included Winbond, Taiwan Semiconductor, United Semiconductor, ProMOS Technologies, Worldwide Semiconductor, Vanguard International Semiconductor, Taisil Electronic Materials and Macronix International.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EASE RESTRICTION ON ETHNIC-CHINESE SPOUSES FROM SE ASIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior on Wednesday said it will consider easing the restriction on the entry and residence in the island of Taiwan citizens' ethnic-Chinese spouses from Indonesia, Vietnam and Myanmar.

After a meeting on national population policy, the ministry said there was no reason to maintain the discriminatory limit on ethnic Chinese from the three countries given the fact that Taiwan has virtually scrapped all quotas governing foreign spouses' residence here.
The quota for children under the age of 20 will also be canceled, said the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Two police officers were released by illegal mainland Chinese immigrants at the Ilan detention center.
The China Times:
The hostage drama at the Ilan detention house ended as illegal mainland immigrants released two police officers.
The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 17, or the fourth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1900: A joint force from eight nations attack and occupy the fort of Taku port in China, while the Ching government troops and Boxers besiege foreign settlements in Tientsin.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1944: Iceland becomes an independent republic after a referendum on disengaging from Denmark's sovereignty.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells on the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China explodes its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1979: Charles Cross, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War it could never win.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea for asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the Republic of China.
1991: South Africa's parliament abolishes race classification, the legal foundation of apartheid since 1950.
1991: Eight thousand scientists and researchers gather at Fortezza da Basso, Florence, for an international conference on AIDS.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEASIDE SCHOOL TO GIVE DIPLOMAS IN UNDERWATER COMMENCEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kungliao, Taipei County, June 17 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A commencement ceremony next to the seaside is beautiful, but a group of 12-year olds from Taipei County will graduate in a ceremony they will remember for the rest of their lives.
Graduates from the Homei Primary School in Kungliao Hsiang will receive their diplomas from Principal Lai Lien-kung 6 meters under the Pacific Ocean next Thursday.

Lai and the graduates, numbering less than 20, have been receiving scuba diving training for several weeks to enable them to swim like a fish and to be able to give and receive the certificates underwater without a hitch, according to Huang Ching-piao, chairman of the Parent Teacher Association (PTA) of the Homei Primary School.
Traditional graduation ceremonies where children stand in line on a stage to receive their diplomas one by one while parents watch is dull and lacks of creativity, Huang said.
The idea of holding a sub-aqua commencement was overwhelmingly supported by students, their parents, as well as school authorities, said Huang.

The proposed commencement actually has been well-received by the entire Homei community, a fishing village embraced by deep blue water in which coral reef fish and plants are both abundant and magnificent, he added.
All the 110-odd children of the Homei school, including the 1999 graduates, come from homes supported by the fishing industry, thus none are strangers to the sea, Huang said.

When the commencement kicks off on next Thursday morning, Principal Lai will first use a raft to paddle out to an area of the sea not far from the school. He will dive some 6 meters to the ceremonial spot to give the graduates their laminated graduation certificates.

The graduates will first dive into the sea and swim to an abalone shelve on the ocean's bottom. Each student will take a baby abalone up to a boat waiting on the surface to pay homage to village's tradition. The students will then dive back into the ocean and swim to where Principal Lai is waiting with his/her diploma. Baby abalone is a prime ocean crop of the Homei area.

Huang, the head of the local PTA, said if the diving commencement proves successful, the school may continue using different activities to replace the traditional commencement ceremony, including a rock-climbing commencement exercise. The school faces a beautiful portion of the Pacific Ocean while to its left is a giant cliff.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMERGENCY FMD CONTROL CENTER SET UP IN TAINAN COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 17 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An emergency control center for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) was set up Thursday by the Animal Disease Control Department under the Tainan County Government as county officials scrambled to prevent a possible FMD from spreading to the entire cattle population of Taiwan.
The move came after eight head of cattle on two Tainan County ranches tested positive for FMD Wednesday.

The discovery came a week after 100 head of cattle on the offshore front-line island of Kinmen were slaughtered due to FMD infection. No cases of FMD have been reported among Taiwan's cattle population since 1929.

The Animal Disease Control Department of the Tainan County Government on Wednesday issued an order banning the sell and transport of livestock off the two Tainan ranches where the eight FMD-positive head of cattle were discovered.
Samples of the suspected FMD virus were sent to an animal quarantine center in Tanshui, Taipei County, for examination, with those results not expected until Saturday.

Department officials said, prior to Saturday all livestock from the two Tainan ranches are barred from being transported off the ranches. The two ranches' personnel and workers have also been temporarily ordered not to travel.
If the Tainan cattle are confirmed to be infected with the FMD virus, Department officials said all cattle raised on the two ranches will be slaughtered to prevent further spread of the disease.
Tainan County is the largest cattle-raising region of Taiwan, with the cattle population totaling 28,000, about one-fifth of the total cattle on Taiwan.

FMD is an acute, contagious disease that can be spread via air. It infects mainly cloven-hoofed livestock and wild animals. Its mortality rate is 5 percent among mature livestock and up to 50 percent among young animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE US CONGRESSMEN APPLAUD ROC AID TO KOSOVO

TEXT.P: Another two members of the US Congress have commended Taiwan for the generous US$300 million humanitarian aid package to the Kosovo refugees.

Rep. Albert Russell Wynn (D-MD) said Tuesday on the House floor that "President Lee Teng-hui's considerate offer is representative of Taiwan's commitment to protecting and promoting human rights and fulfilling its responsibilities as a member of the international community."

"The Republic of China on Taiwan is faced with Chinese Communist aggression on a daily basis and experiences first hand the threat of aggression. Through their aid contribution to the Kosovo refugees, the Republic of China on Taiwan serves as an example to the international community that with generosity and kindness toward their fellow human beings, peace can be achieved worldwide," noted the Maryland Democrat.

Rep. Wynn added that the aid package certainly comes at an opportune time. As the Serb troops begin their pullout, many stranded refugees in the Kosovo mountains are in dire need of food, clothing and shelter. This assistance will contribute directly to their needs and will be critical in the uphill battle of rebuilding their homes.

Meanwhile, Sen. Tim Johnson (D-SD) also spoke in the Senate Tuesday in recognition of the important contribution Taiwan has made to the international effort to provide humanitarian assistance to the refugees of Kosovo.

The senator said the rebuilding and recovery efforts that are now beginning in Kosovo will take many years and many resources, and Taiwan has contributed significant financial and technical resources to this effort.

However, the South Dakota Democrat stressed, "more importantly, Taiwan's generous actions should give comfort to the people of Kosovo that the world's leaders will help them through this difficult time."
Last week eight members of the US Congress applauded Taiwan for offering generous humanitarian aid to the Kosovo refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100-M WORLD RECORD SHATTERED

TEXT.P: Canadian sprinter Donovan Bailey's reign as the world's fastest man is over after American Maurice Greene shattered the 100-metre world record in Athens Wednesday.
Greene ran a blistering 9.79 seconds. Bailey's mark was 9.84.

Ironically, 9.79 is the same time another Canadian, Ben Johnson, ran in winning the gold medal in 1988 Seoul Olympics. Johnson was stripped of his medal and his world record erased after he tested positive for steroids.
Bailey, who's making a comeback from an Achilles tendon injury, failed to reach the final after running 10.51 in a preliminary heat.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DONATES C$1 M. TO HELP BALKAN WOMEN, CHILDREN
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, June 16 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By S. C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Ottawa, June 16 (CNW) Canada said Wednesday it will support UNICEF efforts to aid women and children victims of the Balkans crisis.

Diane Marleau, minister for international cooperation, announced that Canada is donating C$1 million (US$685,000) in support of UNICEF initiatives including psychological and social assistance services, educational activities such as teacher training, and the implementation of landmine awareness programs.
UNICEF will offer medical and psychological assistance for women and girls who have been the victims of sexual assault.
The announcement was made during a visit in Ottawa by UNICEF Executive Director Carol Bellamy.
The C$1 million support is part of the C$45 million allocated by Canada to provide humanitarian and economic assistance to the countries affected by the crisis in the Balkans.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY LIFT CONTROL OF PUBLICATION: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing is set to loosen its grip on the publication industry by allowing private publishers to operate legally, the Hong Kong Standard reported today.
The report, quoting sources close to the State Council, revealed that the State Press and Publication Administration was discussing whether to give the green light to private publishers.

Debate is focusing on whether to reduce the monopoly of government agencies on printed media. Some reformist officials believe the media should play a more constructive role in anti-graft campaigns, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABDUCTORS OF TWO BELGIANS START TALK WITH MANILA OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: An emissary from the Department of Agrarian Reform (DAR) on Wednesday made initial contacts with the abductors of the two Belgian nationals now being held captive somewhere in Basilan, Malacanang.
In a press statement Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican said the emissary started preliminary talks with the abductors Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU CASINO KING TRYING AGAIN TO BUY AUST.GAMBLING DENS

TEXT.P: Despite previous failed attempts to make an inroad into the booming Australian gambling market, Macau's casino king Stanley Ho is trying again to buy Australian casinos ahead of the handover of the Portuguese enclave to mainland China.

The Australian on Thursday reported Ho's representatives have approached the management group at the Reef Casino in Cairns, Queensland. Ho is also interested in buying a stake at the Burswood Casino in Perth, western Australia.
The daily quoted Casinos Austria's Chairman Thomas Jancik as confirming that Ho's representatives had discussed with the management group of Reef Casino.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TECHNOLOGY REDUCES TRAVELER CHEQUE COUNTERFEITING

TEXT.P: American Express has sharply reduced losses from counterfeited US-dollar traveler cheques by using an Australian designed security device, the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.

The daily reported the device, developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) in Canberra, enables the cheques to incorporate a foil with a picture of the Amex centurion that switches to the Amex logo as the cheque is viewed from different angles.

The daily quoted CSIRO's chief executive Malcolm McIntosh as saying that as an extra security measure, the foil contains microscopic tracks of the Amex trademark, visible only when magnified 1000 times.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWER INFLATION AND UNEMPLOYMENT IN AUSTRALIA PREDICTED

TEXT.P: Australia will not increase official interest rates because inflation will remain at 2 percent and the unemployment rate could drop to 7 percent by the end of this year, according to the governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia on Thursday.

In a statement to the House of Representatives in Melbourne, Ian Macfarlane said the gross domestic product (GDP) would grow between 3 and 4 percent in calendar 1999, down from the 4.8 percent in 1998.
"Inflation in Australia, meanwhile, has risen, but very slightly and considerably more slowly than our central forecast of six months ago had suggested," he said.
The only problem for Australia is that its current account deficit is expected to reach about 6 percent of its GDP causing the national savings rate to remain low, Macfarlane said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT: CHINA, RUSSIA FEAR EXPANSION OF US AND NATO

TEXT.P: Leaders in mainland China and Russia fear the expansionist policy of the US and its NATO allies following their bombings in Yugoslavia because they could use similar military force under the pretext of human rights abuses in Tibet, Sinkiang or Chechnay, a leading Australian political expert said on Thursday.

In an article published in the Australian Financial Review, Professor Paul Dibb, head of the Strategic and Defense Studies Center at the Australian National University in Canberra, said the U.S. and its NATO allies "are in confrontation with China and Russia -- who will violently resist what they see as an expansionist military policy."

He said the use of military force against Yugoslavia should be treated as a "special case." "It is difficult to come up with examples in other countries where NATO would be so ready to use its military might," he said.
"Nevertheless, NATO's offensive doctrine and its display of overwhelming air power have generated deep distrust in China and Russia," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER EXPOUNDS ROC'S FOREIGN AID POLICY

TEXT.P: The ROC government will appropriate US$100 million annually over the next three fiscal years for carrying out an aid program for Kosovars, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday.
Hu made the statement at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.

Hu told lawmakers that the annual expenditure for the US$300 million aid package for Kosovars will account for a mere 0.22 percent of the government's total budget for fiscal 2000, which will start on July 1, 1999.

"This means that only NT$0.22 out of every NT$100 spent by the government during the year will be used for the Kosovo aid package," Hu explained, adding that as enforcement of the program may last more than three years, its ratio to the government's annual budget may be even lower.
Hu said the government does not face any pressure to donate a specified amount of money in a specified period of time for Kosovar reconstruction.

"We'll conduct regular evaluation of progress, effectiveness as well as domestic and overseas reactions while carrying out the aid program," Hu noted, adding that the program is not expected to affect implementation of major domestic development projects nor to require the infusion of the government's second reserve fund.

The minister pointed out that President Lee Teng-hui's announcement on June 7 of the generous aid program for Kosovars has attracted much attention and inspire fervent discussion in the international community.

"Our offer to provide short-term accommodation for some Kosovar refugees in Taiwan for job training in order to better equip them for the restoration of their homeland upon their return has especially drawn interest in the world society," Hu said.

He further revealed that a foreign political heavyweight has expressed keen interest in the job training program and plans to travel to Taiwan to see for himself the implementation of the program when it gets started.

As some lawmakers doubted the government's wisdom in making such a huge aid offer, Hu distributed position papers to legislators present at the meeting, explaining major considerations in drafting the program.

Quoting an estimate by major international relief organizations, reconstruction of the war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo requires at least US$30 billion. "Our committed aid only accounts for 1 percent of the needed fund."

Hu went on to say that Taiwan's aid package must be comparable to international mainstream relief programs if it wants to produce desired results. "We should coordinate with advanced Western countries or major international relief organizations in assisting Kosovar refugees."

The minister also explained the government's foreign aid policy, stressing that the government has consistently given top priority to assisting countries with which the Republic of China maintains formal diplomatic relations.

"Other principles in formulating foreign aid programs include humanitarianism, economic development, popular participation, expansion of domestic demand, balanced use of bilateral and multilateral relief channels," Hu said.

The ROC has formed the International Cooperation and Development Fund to take charge of foreign aid work, Hu said, adding that the government will follow the examples of some advanced countries by enacting a foreign aid bill to institutionalize such work.

Major advanced countries usually set aside budgets for foreign aid. The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) stipulates that the annual budget for foreign aid offered by its major members should reach an average of 0.39 percent of their annual gross national product (GNP).

In fiscal 1997, Taiwan offered NT$6.5 billion (US$200 million) in foreign aid, accounting for 0.07 percent of its GNP. "The ratio still falls below the OECD standard and the 0.7 percent level required by the United Nations," Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO REMOVE IMPORT TARIFFS ON GOODS TO OFFSHORE ISLANDS

TEXT.P: In a bid to boost the development of Taiwan's offshore islands, the executive and legislative sectors have basically agreed to remove tariffs from selected imports, said Kuomintang legislative caucus Secretary-General Lee Hsien-jung on Wednesday.

Lee said the decision supersedes earlier moves to exempt offshore island residents from personal income, business income and business taxes. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) deemed the proposed exemptions unfair, he said.
Lee made the remarks after he exchanged views with Premier Vincent Siew and officials from the MOF during the regular weekly meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee.
As for the establishment of resort casinos on the Penghu Islands, an idea openly advocated by some legislators, the executive and legislative sectors have rejected the proposal, Lee noted.

The MOF said earlier plans to exempt offshore island residents from business and personal taxes would have made a significant dent in government revenue. Business income tax exemptions alone would have resulted in tax revenue losses of up to NT$45 million.
Moreover, it is likely Taiwan companies would have tried to register their companies on offshore islands to avoid having to pay business taxes. This is another reason the MOF is against the measure.
The executive sector has been looking at ways to promote the development of Taiwan's offshore islands, and the preferential tax scheme and resort casino proposals were two ideas under consideration.

In light of the MOF's opposition to the preferential tax scheme, however, the Executive Yuan withdrew its support for the proposal and instead opted for the less sweeping option of removing import tariffs.
Some KMT legislators said they hope the government will come up with measures that will make the offshore islands completely tax free.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SET UP A SHELTER FOR REPATRIATED MAINLAND STOWAWAYS

TEXT.P: Mainland China should set up a shelter in the coastal city of Xiamen for illegal immigrants repatriated to the mainland, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Thursday.

MAC Spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng made the remarks after the release Wednesday evening of two police officials who had been taken hostage by illegal mainland immigrants at a detention center in Ilan county. The officers were released after a 20-hour standoff.

Sheu said in a press conference that although Taiwan treats illegal mainland Chinese in its three detention centers well -- caring for them and satisfying their humanitarian needs -- their emotional well-being can be affected by extended stays at the centers.

Sheu said that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could set up a mainland center for repatriated illegal immigrants, it would result in improved emotional health among the detainees, and many problems could be avoided.

The suggestion to establish such a center was first broached by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, who said that after Taiwan repatriates illegal immigrants to the mainland, they could be sent to the proposed center. While there, their identities would be established by mainland authorities, and they could then be returned to where they came from.

Shi noted that when Jan Jyh-horng, SEF's deputy secretary-general, visits the mainland later this month to discuss matters concerning a visit later this year by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, he will suggest that the mainland set up such a center.

Meanwhile, the standoff between detainees at the Ilan detention and police was the focus of discussion in the legislature when legislators asked Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen about ways of preventing similar incidents in the future.

Huang said the incident took place mainly because the mainland has been dragging its feet in picking up illegal immigrants. Another factor is the approach of the traditional Chinese Dragon Boat Festival, which often causes detainees to think of going home and being reunited with their families.

Huang said that Taiwan has always treated the mainland stowaways humanely and that the incident in Ilan was the result of the detainees' long stay at the center and of a recent outbreak of a disease which was probably caused by lack of vitamin B1. The disease has killed three people and resulted in nine others being hospitalized. All the victims of the disease have complained of weakness in their lower limbs.

Legislator Cheng Chao-ming said that the government has spent a lot of money to take care of the illegal immigrants. If the mainland will not pick them up, he suggested that Taiwan notify the mainland that the illegal immigrants will be sent to uninhabited islands, such as the Pratas island group.

Legislator Huang Yi-chiao suggested that the government take the initiative, saying that if the mainland uses a lack of funds as an excuse, the government could pay for immigrants' repatriation first and later seek reimbursement from the mainland.

According to government statistics, since Taiwan first opened a detention center for illegal mainland immigrants in 1987, more than 37,000 mainland Chinese citizens have been held in Taiwan's centers.

Although Beijing has promised to process Taiwan inquiries about the immigrants' identities within 20 days, a detainee stays at the center for an average of 169 days, and at a cost of NT$17,000 (US$523). Since 1987 Taiwan taxpayers have spent a total of NT$700 million (US$21.67 million) on detained illegal mainland immigrants.
About 36,000 detainees have already been deported, and approximately 1,000 more are awaiting repatriation in Taiwan's three detention centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH LIBERIAN FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday expressed his gratitude to Liberia for the strong support the African country has shown for the Republic of China in the international community.

Lee met with Liberian Foreign Minister Monie R. Captan at the Presidential Office, where Lee spoke of the friendship that exists between the Republic of China and Liberia, and extended a formal invitation to Liberian President Charles Taylor to visit Taiwan.

Captan told Lee that President Taylor plans to visit Taiwan in October, and prior to that, the Liberian president will visit New York to take part in the United Nations' annual general meeting. During the meeting, Taylor will try to rally support for the Republic of China's entry into the United Nations and UN-affiliated organizations, Captan added.

A congenial Lee said to Captan that he and his Liberian delegates are welcomed to join people around Taiwan in observing the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the most colorful national holidays of the Republic of China. To celebrate the holiday, which falls this year on June 18, people will hold dragon boat races, eat rice dumplings, or tsungtse, and compose poems.

Captan and an official delegation from Liberia, including Planning and Economics Minister John McClain and Finance Minister John Bestman Sr., have been in Taipei since Monday to attend the second meeting of the Republic of China-Liberian Mixed Commission, which opened Tuesday.
Captan and his ROC counterpart, Jason Hu, jointly signed the minutes of the meeting and an investment guarantee agreement Thursday at the close of the three-day meeting.
During the meeting, the ROC agreed to provide two electrical generators to replace facilities in the country's capital, Monrovia, that were damaged during Liberia's civil wars.

Taiwan also decided to extend aid for the second phase of the reconstruction of Liberia's international airport. Taiwan contributed to the first phase of the reconstruction project, which was completed in May this year.
Other aid that Taiwan has committed to Liberia included seaport facilities, medical equipment, agricultural machinery and fertilizer.

The ROC and Liberia decided to hold the annual mixed commission meeting alternately in Monrovia and Taipei when Taylor visited Taipei in November 1997. The first meeting was held in Monrovia in April last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG IS OF NO HINDRANCE TO TAIWAN'S ACCESSION TO WTO: BOFT

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has promised not to impede the Working Group of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in accepting Taiwan's entrance working report, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Thursday.

Canada has also agreed to sign a bilateral agreement with Taiwan by the end of June, a BOFT official indicated. Taiwan is scheduled to hold another Working Group meeting at the end of July to finish Taiwan's entrance working report, the official added.

To date, Taiwan has completed bilateral agreements with 24 of the 26 WTO contracting parties that have requested talks with Taiwan on tariff concessions and market-opening measures. Only Canada and Hong Kong have yet to sign accords.

Wei Ko-ming, deputy director-general of the BOFT, noted that Taiwan planned to hold its 11th WTO entrance working meeting at the end of July. Given that the WTO Working Group is to accept Taiwan's entrance working report on that occasion, Taiwan will "technically" complete all the bilateral and multilateral consulting work concerning its bid for membership in the world trade regulatory body, Wei remarked.
The final touch in regard to Taiwan's entry will be left to the approval of the WTO's General Board of Directors, Wei added.
A BOFT-sponsored seminar on the impact of Taiwan's WTO membership on its domestic industries was held in Taipei on Thursday. Wei made his remarks during the gathering.
This year is crucial to Taiwan in its bid for WTO accession, said the ranking BOFT official.

Since a bilateral accord was signed between Taiwan and South Africa in 1995, Taiwan has completed bilateral agreements with the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Turkey, El Salvador, Colombia, Uruguay, Chile, South Korea, Australia, Iceland, Norway, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, New Zealand, Singapore, the United States, Switzerland, Mexico, Hungary, Argentina, the European Union and Thailand.
In light of the fact that Taiwan has held a total of 10 WTO entrance Working Group meetings, the examination of its entrance working reports is largely finished, Wei stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS TO FOUR-MONTH LOW IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped to a fourth-month low in the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday by ending at 32.352 against the New Taiwan dollar, down NT$0.022 from Wednesday's finish.
The greenback was traded between a high of 32.379 and a low of 32.351 after opening at 32.369.
Interbank transactions totaled US$405 million.

It was the US dollar's ninth consecutive fall against the local currency since June 7, and the greenback has depreciated NT$0.39 since then. A total of US$6.72 billion changed hands over the past few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADING VOLUME ON TAIWAN BOURSE HITS THE HIGHEST LEVEL IN 16 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The trade volume on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) hit its highest level in 16 months on Thursday, with the market's benchmark weighted price index surging 215.34 points to close at 8,274.36.
A total of 3.96 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$226.74 billion (US$7.0 billion), up significantly from the previous session's NT$156.56 billion.

Thursday's bullish trend was encouraged by a strong overnight rally on the New York Stock Exchange, by the strong buying of technology and financial stocks by foreign funds and by the legislative passage of reductions in business taxes for financial and insurance service companies.

Among the eight major stock categories, only electronics shares, financial issues, and plastics and chemical stocks posted gains on the day, rising 4.2 percent, 3.2 percent and 1 percent, respectively.

Paper and pulp issues registered the largest loss at 2.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, down 1.7 percent; construction shares, down 1.4 percent; textile shares, down 0.8 percent; and cement shares, down 0.7 percent.
The over-the-counter market performed well, with its index closing at 177.83, up 2.76 points from the previous session's closing level. Turnover for the day totaled NT$9.59 billion.
Meanwhile, trading of TAIEX weighted price index futures was brisk on Thursday.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for June were settled on Thursday, and the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange began trading August futures.

TAIEX Index Futures for July surged 236 points to close at 8,349, with 4,654 contract transactions. TAIEX Index Futures for August garnered 235 points to close at 8,350, with 83 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for September gained 274 points to close at 8,356, with 124 contract transactions, while those for December moved up 163 points to close at 8,280, with 19 contract transactions. TAIEX Index Futures for next March increased by 50 points to 8,280, with 9 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 8,113 points for July, 8,115 points for August, 8,082 points for September, 8,117 points for December and 8,230 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND LIBERIA INK INVESTMENT PROTECTION PACT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Liberia inked an investment promotion and protection pact in Taipei at the end of the second ROC-Liberian Mixed Commission meeting.
In a ceremony marking the end of the three-day meeting, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and visiting Liberian Foreign Minister Monie Captan signed the pact on behalf of their governments.
Captan reaffirmed his government's support for the ROC's bid for a bigger international role, and said he looks forward to closer cooperation with the Republic of China.
