The ROC-Liberian Mixed Commission is the brainchild of a 1997 meeting between Liberian President Charles Taylor and ROC President Lee Teng-hui in Taipei. It was set up with the aim of promoting mutual cooperation.

The commission held its first session in the Liberian capital of Monrovia in 1998, and will meet there again next year. Also present at this year's meeting were Liberian Economics Minister John Weseh McClain and Finance Minister John G. Bestman.
They were slated to visit central Taiwan Friday and to return to Taipei the next day before leaving on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN INTERVIEWED BY JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 17 (CNA) (By K.M. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of Taiwan's largest opposition party said that if he is elected president, he will conduct across-the-board dialogues, including political dialogues, with mainland authorities.
Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the remark while being interviewed by a major Japanese daily in Taipei Wednesday.
Chen said in the interview, printed in The Yomiuri Shimbun, that although President Lee Teng-hui has established the framework for democracy in Taiwan, a true democracy has yet to be realized.

Chen noted that there are three main problems in Taiwan, namely social order, economic injustice and a political system that is influenced by money and criminal elements. He said the ruling Kuomintang cannot solve the problem and that the next stage in Taiwan's democratic reform must be conducted by the DPP.

As for cross-strait relations, Chen said that if the nation follows the course set by President Lee, then no headway will be made in regard to cross-strait ties, especially since the KMT has been dodging political dialogues with the mainland.
Chen predicted that Taiwan will develop a special relationship with the mainland, and that the relationship will include much room for discussion.

As to the mainland's strong opposition to Taiwan independence, a defining belief of the DPP, Chen said that his goal of establishing a Taiwan Republic has not changed, but he stressed that the fate of Taiwan will be decided by the Taiwan people. He said he would respect the fact that most Taiwan people want the status quo maintained, adding that he would face the issue in a pragmatic manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO SET UP DIOXIN-TESTING LAB

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) will set up a special laboratory to monitor the dioxin content in various foodstuffs sold in the Taiwan market, a senior official said on Thursday.

Chen Shu-kong, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the DOH finds an urgent need to set up such a laboratory after the recent discovery of dioxin contamination among livestock and dairy products in Belgium.
Chen conceded that the DOH has not yet worked out any reference figures for determining whether a foodstuff has been contaminated by dioxin, a known carcinogen.

Noting that dioxin is fat-soluble, Chen said dioxin, like radioactivity, exists in the natural environment. US food sanitation authorities stipulate that the average dioxin content in all kinds of foodstuffs should not exceed 59.42 pg (pico grams). One pg equals one ppt (part per trillion).

Chen said the 15-member European Union has not set any standards for dioxin content in general foodstuffs. Nevertheless, the World Health Organization (WHO) suggests that per capita daily intake of dioxin should not exceed 4 pg for each kilogram of body weight.
For local people, the DOH has suggested that the maximum daily dioxin intake be set at 118.84 pg, double the US level but only about half the WHO standard.
Based on all these standards, Chen said the recent dioxin contamination in Belgium cannot be considered extremely detrimental.

Chen said the DOH has started preparations for setting up a dioxin laboratory, adding that a German dioxin examination expert is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan next week to providing counseling services and technological advice.
Meanwhile, the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine (BCIQ) unveiled the results of an examination of dioxin content in four batches of Friesland-brand yogurt on Thursday.
BCIQ Director-General Chen Tso-chen said the dioxin content in Friesland's original, low-fat, strawberry and composite fruit yogurt is only 0.1 ppt.
"The figure is far lower than America's 1 ppt, France's 4 ppt, the Netherlands' 6 ppt and Germany's 5 ppt," Chen said, adding that local consumers can safely continue consuming this brand of yogurt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES BEIJING TO RESUME TALKS ON PRACTICAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Thursday urged Beijing to resume talks with Taipei about issues concerning the rights and interests of the peoples on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, including the repatriation of stowaways and hijackers.
MAC spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng said that recent rioting by mainland Chinese inmates at an Ilan detention center for illegal immigrants resulted from Beijing's reluctance to take back the immigrants.
Most of the mainland immigrants at the center have been there a long time, Sheu said, noting that inmates often become homesick during their stay there.
There are now more than 1,000 mainland illegal immigrants at Taiwan's three detention centers awaiting repatriation.

Although Red Cross societies in Taiwan and mainland China signed in 1991 the "Kinmen Agreement," which obligates the mainland to take back illegal mainland immigrants within 20 days of their capture, Beijing has never respected the agreement. Last year, it took back only four groups of detained stowaways, totaling about 400 people, according to the MAC.

Taiwan has seized annually an average of 5,000 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants over the past 10 years, and detainees stay in Taiwan an average of 130 days before being taken back by mainland authorities, the MAC said.
Because of Beijing's reluctance, some mainland detainees wait years to return home.

Asked about reports that mainland detainees were forced to live in overcrowded cells and treated badly, Sheu said Taiwan has done its best to take care of the detainees. For instance, the centers allow detainees to make free long-distance telephone calls to their families during major Chinese holidays, such as the Lunar New Year, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival.

For every 169 days that a detainee stays at a Taiwan detention center, the government pays some NT$17,000 (US$523) in food, clothing and housing costs. Since 1987 Taiwan taxpayers have spent a total of NT$700 million (US$21.67 million) on housing illegal mainland immigrants, according to official statistics.

The detention of illegal immigrants has become a heavy financial burden to Taiwan, MAC Chairman Su Chi said Wednesday in a briefing to the Legislative Yuan. He condemned the mainland's deliberate procrastination in taking back the illegal immigrants, saying that "the mainland authorities do not care about their own people at all."

The mainland side makes the problem, but leaves the cleanup to Taiwan, Su said, noting that in the current situation, Taiwan can do nothing but urge the mainland to respect the Kinmen Agreement and call for the resumption of cross-strait talks aimed at resolving problems like the repatriation of illegal immigrants.

The cross-strait dialogues were unilaterally suspended by Beijing to protest President Lee Teng-hui's American visit in June 1995. The move also cut off efforts to resolve problems directly affecting people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RESIDENT KILLED BY LIGHTNING

TEXT.P: A 50-year-old hiker was struck by lightning and killed after being caught in a sudden thunderstorm which hit Taipei on Thursday afternoon.
The hiker and two companions were walking in the mountainous Taipei suburb of Yangmingshan when the lightning struck. The two companions were also struck, but suffered only minor burns.
They were rushed to a local hospital, where a hospital spokesman said the two, one aged 60 and the other 70, were not in danger but had been admitted to the hospital for observation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL FAVORS CONDITIONAL `THREE DIRECT LINKS'

TEXT.P: Taiwan should allow direct trade, transportation and postal services with mainland China on a mutual beneficial and reciprocal basis, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) stalwart said on Thursday.

Chen Shui-bian, former Taipei mayor and the DPP's presidential candidate for the next presidential race slated for March 2000, said that in the current international circumstances, Taiwan and mainland China should normalize the so-called "three direct links" to benefit both sides.

Trade relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not be bound by the "no haste, be patient" investment policy advocated by President Lee Teng-hui and the broadly defined "go west" idea espoused by others, Chen said in a speech on cross-strait ties delivered at a seminar with small business leaders from central Taichung County.

In view of the prospective membership of the World Trade Organization for both Taiwan and mainland China by the end of this year, Chen pointed out that the two sides will have to face the three links issue sooner or later.
Against this backdrop, the DPP presidential contender said that the two sides could first consider setting up sea cargo traffic and later expand into passenger flight services.

Turning to direct cross-strait trade, he proposed that the government set a ceiling from 20 percent to 50 percent for mainland Chinese capital entering Taiwan -- the same ceiling currently imposed on capital inflow from other foreign countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 PERCENT OF COEDS HAVE BEEN SEXUALLY HARASSED: POLL

TEXT.P: About 10 percent of the female students at nine local universities have been sexually harassed on campus, according to the results of a survey released on Thursday.
The survey of 482 coeds at the nine northern Taiwan universities found that 49 of the respondents said they have sustained sexual harassment on campus.

Among them, only 12, or about 25 percent, had filed complaints with school authorities, and 10 of those said they were dissatisfied with their schools' passivity or lax attitude in handling their cases.

The harassment came from classmates, teachers or unidentified persons from outside the campus, according to the survey, jointly conducted by the Awakening Foundation and the National Coeds Action Alliance.
The survey results show that 24 of the victims, or 51.1 percent, were harassed by their classmates; 10, or 21 percent, were harassed by teachers; and 13, or 27.7 percent, were harassed by outsiders.
The two women's rights promotion organizations said the survey results show that local university authorities do not handle campus sexual harassment cases in a positive manner.
"We hope the survey will help push local universities and the Ministry of Education to pay due attention to the issue," said a spokeswoman for the Awakening Foundation.

According to the survey, two of the schools studied -- Chang Gung University and National Chungshing University (Taipei campus) -- have not set up any special units to handle sexual harassment complaints.

Although National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) has set up a special task force to handle such complaints, it has never unveiled a set of clear, definitive procedures for handling this type of case.

The Awakening Foundation said suspicious sexual harassment incidents were first reported at the NTNU five years ago. "It's unthinkable that the school has so far not laid out clear procedures for handling such cases," said the spokeswoman.
Even more ironic is that eight of the schools studied have never formally handled any sexual harassment cases.
The poll results also show that 81.1 percent of the respondents are not even aware that their schools have special agencies to handle sexual harassment complaints.

Meanwhile, 82.3 percent said that even if they had been sexually harassed, they would not file complaints with school administrative authorities, while 57.4 percent said they might seek the assistance of their classmates.
However, 68.4 percent said that if their schools have formal counseling offices to handle sexual harassment or gender equality issues, they would contact those offices for advice or assistance.
The six other schools studied were National Taiwan University, Soochow University, National Chengchi University, Fu Jen Catholic University, National Chung Cheng University and Tamkang University.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT VISITS ISLAND STRONGHOLD

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan visited the front-line island stronghold of Kinmen on Wednesday to convey President Lee Teng-hui's Dragon Boat Festival greetings to the armed forces based there and to local residents.
He told a local gathering that because no breakthrough has been made in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, security remains very important for Kinmen.
Lien expressed the hope that the people living on the island will remember this importance, and stand firm to strive for survival first before pursuing development.
The vice president met with local military and government leaders, as well as elected representatives and chiefs of various organizations at the Taiwushan Chientan Mountain Village.
Lien said that Kinmen has played an important role over the last few decades in safeguarding the security of Taiwan and Penghu.
He also noted that the central government appropriated NT$5.1 billion to finance five development projects in Kinmen when he was premier in 1992.
Following President Lee's visit to Kinmen last January, he added, the government has decided to use another NT$19.5 billion for 10 major projects in Kinmen over the coming five years.
To cheer up the troops on Kinmen, Lien presented them with "red envelopes" or cash gifts, which were accepted by Lt. Gen. Chu Kai-sheng, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command.

Lien made the one-day trip to Kinmen, accompanied by Defense Minister Tang Fei and ranking officials from the Education Ministry, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Council of Agriculture and the Council for Cultural Affairs.
He also attended the commencement of the Kinmen School of the National Institute of Technology at Kaohsiung, and toured several economic and cultural establishments before returning to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRIAN-TAIWANESE PIANIST COUPLE TO PERFORM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Austrian pianist Albert Muhlbock and his Taiwanese wife Chou Yu-king will give two piano recitals at the National Concert Hall in Taipei on Friday.

The couple, who have previously given three performances in Austria and three in Taiwan, also played in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan on June 3, and following their Taipei performances, will perform in Taichung City in central Taiwan on June 30.
Muhlbock is currently teaching at the Tainan Institute of the Arts, while Chou is teaching at the Women's Institute of Technology, also in Tainan.
Both Muhlbock and Chou have won many awards in international piano contests. The couple met when Chou was studying in Vienna, and they were married one-and-a-half years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD URGES RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TECHNICAL TALKS

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu on Thursday expressed the hope that a forthcoming visit by an SEF official to mainland China will also help rekindle regular cross-Taiwan Strait talks on technical issues.

The major purpose of SEF Vice Secretary-General Jan Jih-horng's trip to mainland China is to arrange a visit to Taiwan later this year by Koo's mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

However, Koo said bilateral technical talks should be resumed as soon as possible, because issues such as the repatriation of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants and fishery disputes are of major concern to the people on both sides of the strait.

He illustrated the importance of such talks by noting the recent incident which occurred in a detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in eastern Ilan County, where inmates staged a protest over poor conditions and long waits for repatriation.

Two police officers at the detention center were taken hostage on Wednesday by mainland Chinese detainees, who only released the two officers on Thursday after Taiwan authorities promised to meet their demands for speedy repatriation.

Expressing delight that the incident had been resolved smoothly, Koo called on mainland Chinese authorities to quickly restart systematic cross-strait technical issues based on the Kinmen Accord signed during his first meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993.

According to Koo, more than 1,000 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, detained at centers in northern Hsinchu, Ilan and the outlying Matsu Island, are currently awaiting repatriation. Some of them have being waiting for over six years because of mainland China's unwillingness to take them back, he added.

Taiwan and the mainland should be able to make substantive progress in two-way talks regarding such issues if institutionalized SEF-ARATS talks can reopen during Jan's visit to mainland China from June 27-29, Koo claimed.
He made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Taipei-based SEF headquarters.

SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively, which were set up to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts. But regular SEF-ARATS negotiations were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui offended Beijing by paying an unofficial visit to the United States in the summer of that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS ALLOWED TO INVEST IN AUSSIE AIRLINES

TEXT.P: In a sweeping effort to open its skies, the Australian government is allowing foreign investors to buy up to 49 percent in Ansett Airlines and other Australian airlines.
Canberra will, however, still impose a 35-percent restriction of share in its flag carrier -- Qantas.
British Airways, which owns a 25 percent stake in Qantas, has strongly criticized the Howard government for limiting foreign investment in Qantas as it attempts to buy more stakes.
The Australian Financial Review on Thursday quoted BA Chairman Lord Marshall as saying that there should be a "level playing field" on foreign ownership of Australian airlines.

The Federal Cabinet recently announced its decision to allow foreigners, including foreign airlines, to own up to 49 percent of an Australian international airline and 100 percent of an Australian domestic airline. But the government said it would retain existing limits on foreign ownership of Qantas.
Canberra regards Qantas image as an "Australian icon" reflecting political sensitivities over the possible sale of its flag carrier.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD WOMEN'S YOUTH SOFTBALL CHAMPIONSHIP OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The sixth World Women's Youth Softball Championship opened at the Hsinchuang Stadium near Taipei on Thursday, but several games on the first day were rained off.
In the opening games, Chinese-Taipei had a 10-0 shutout of Italy, while Australia defeated the Netherlands and South Korea 11-0 and 10-0, respectively.
In other games, Japan beat Brazil 8-0, and the United States defeated New Zealand 6-1.
The afternoon games were affected by heavy rain, with the game between Canada and Venezuela suspended in the sixth inning, with Canada leading 3-2.
The rain forced the cancellation of three games -- Chinese-Taipei versus Argentina, Italy versus the Czech Republic, and the Netherlands versus Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNKEN DRIVERS SUBJECT TO CRIMINAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: New regulations governing drunken driving will go into effect on Thursday night, and drivers in Taipei City who fail a blood alcohol test will face stiffer punishment, the communications battalion of the Taipei City Police Bureau said on Thursday.

The communications battalion will carry out roadside checks in 70 places in Taipei City from 11 p.m. on Thursday through 5 a.m. on Friday, with 300 policemen deployed on the mission which will be personally supervised by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Drivers who fail a blood alcohol test by having a blood alcohol level exceeding 0.55 mg per liter will be sent directly to court.
Those with a reading between 0.25 mg and 0.54 mg per liter will be fined, have their driver's license suspended and their cars impounded, and will be obliged to attend classes on traffic safety.
However, if those drivers are involved in accidents, they will also be taken to court.

The Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee on Wednesday passed an amendment to the Traffic Control and Punishment Statute, placing more criminal responsibility on drunken drivers in an effort to curb rampant drunken driving.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Independent National Assembly (NA) deputies to propose amendment to expand NA's constitutional rights, while Kuomintang deputies seeking parliamentarian reforms.
The China Times:
Convicted legislator, former Pingtung magistrate, shut out of judicial reform conference.
The United Daily News:
Beijing renews condemnation on embassy bombing, threatening to continue boycotting WTO talks before getting satisfactory US explanation.
The Liberty Times:
Cutting-edge health insurance IC cards scheduled to be introduced nationwide by the end of this year.
The Commons Daily:
National judicial reform conference shut door to former Pingtung County chief Wu Tze-yuan, now a convicted legislator.
The China Post:
Violent storm kills 1, disrupts transport.
The Taiwan News:
Convicted legislator shut out of forum; Preparatory panel excludes Wu Tze-yuan from judicial reform.
The Taipei Times:
Conference door closed on convict; Former Pingtung County chief, previously sentenced to 15 years in jail, has been found unsuitable to represent the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 18, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1583: The first life insurance policy is issued in London.
1812: The US Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1867: Despite universal appeals for mercy, Emperor Ferdinand Maximilian Joseph is executed by firing squad in Mexico.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way, in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners killed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, who headed a separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French in England, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally carries out its Manhattan Project and begins manufacturing an atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan Province, is executed for sedition.
1953: South Korea releases 26,000 North Korean prisoners of war.
1953: Egypt is proclaimed a republic with General Neguib as its first president.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200 others.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to spur war against the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1975: Prince Faisal Musaid is beheaded in Riyadh for the assassination of Saudi King Faisal on March 25.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS PHONE HOME

TEXT.P: Some 370 illegal immigrants from mainland China at a detention center in northern Taiwan were allowed to speak with their families in the mainland on Thursday, the eve of the traditional Chinese Dragon Boat Festival.
Detainees at the Ilan County detention center were each given a three-minute free telephone call to talk with their families in the mainland.
Many of them cried during their conversations. Some raised their voices to emphasize their homesickness to their relatives.
When the three-minute time ended, the center's staff had to urge the detainees to say goodbye.
The three-minute courtesy calls to family members were scheduled prior to the hostage incident involving two Taiwan policemen Tuesday evening.

Detainees in the center on Tuesday took the two officers hostage to protest what they called poor conditions and a long stay in the center. The two hostages were released unharmed Wednesday evening after 20-hour standoff.

Officials at the Ilan detention center said there are currently 383 mainland illegal immigrants in the center. Except for 13 illegal immigrants, who are hospitalized with an illness caused by malnutrition, all the residents were allowed to place the courtesy calls.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT CALLS FOR NEW CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The challenge now before US policymakers is to build a China policy that safeguards American security and fosters developments within mainland China that allow freedom, opportunity and civil society to flourish, said an American expert Thursday.

Stephen J. Yates, a senior policy analyst in the Asian Studies Center at Washington-based Heritage Foundation, wrote in an analysis that the Cox report demonstrates the strategic cost of weak safeguards on sensitive military technology. "Unrealistic optimism about establishing a strategic partnership with China seemed to blind the Clinton administration to the danger posed by relaxed controls on strategic goods," he added.

The US Congress must act to protect Americans from the abnormal trade in US nuclear and missile technologies, but at the same time promote a vigorous normal trade relationship with the People's Republic of China to foster continued economic reforms and to empower the mainland Chinese people to take greater control over their own lives, noted Yates.

The policy analyst said that to restore a proper sense of priority and balance between security and commercial interests in mainland China, the United States should extend the PRC's normal trade relations status and conclude the World Trade Organization agreement with the PRC.

But Yates stressed that the PRC's missile modernization, advanced by technology transfers catalogued in the Cox report, requires that the Clinton administration commit to an earliest deployment of effective national and theater missile defense systems.

Meanwhile, he continued, the United States should increase scrutiny of and controls on high-tech exports, because controls on the export of dual-use technology have been weakened since the end of the Cold War, but especially during the Clinton administration.

The US should restore stiff penalties for firms whose negligence compromises US security, and work to rebuild a multilateral regime to coordinate controls on the spread of the most dangerous dual-use technologies. By calling for the reauthorization of an updated 1979 Export Administration Act, the Senate could ensure that national security is not compromised in the course of continued normal trade, said Yates.

DOC.HEADLINE: FABRICATION OF STATISTICAL FIGURES IN CHINA REMAINS RAMPANT

TEXT.P: Fabricating production figures has become an industry in mainland China, according to the Australian Financial Review on Friday.

The daily reported provincial officials in China, faced with punishment if they did not meet the goals of the Great Leap Forward initiated by Mao Zedong, sent highly inflated production statistics to Beijing to please the late chairman.

With Mao now gone and China undergoing economic reforms and privatization, Chinese officials in various provincial levels have not discarded the habit and continue inflating production figures to please their new leaders in Beijing, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CRITICIZED FOR INADEQUATE HELP TO EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Nobel laureate Jose Ramos Horta scolded Australia on Thursday for failing to help East Timor while spending much more money and sending troops to conflicts in Europe and the Middle East, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.
At the same time, he also blasted Australia for appeasing Indonesian leaders, including President B.J. Habibie and Defense Minister General Wironto.

Speaking in Sydney at the launch of the East Timor Mercy Ship Program, Ramos Horta said it was "shocking" that Australia had sent only "one or two" doctors, a few nurses and insufficient medical supplies to East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: HABIBIE ASKED TO PROBE SUHARTO CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Golkar party leader has called on President B.J. Habibie to take a tougher stand on corruption by setting up an independent task force to investigate how the Suharto family accumulated its huge wealth.

In an interview with the Australian's correspondent Don Greenlees in Jakarta on Thursday, Akbar Tandjung said major Indonesian parties were hammering out a deal to speed up the appointment of a president, following the June 7 parliamentary elections.

Tandjung, whose party has nominated Habibie as its presidential candidate, said time was "very short" for the president to take action on corruption and overcome an image that he is the "protege of Suharto."
"Investigation of former president Soeharto is very important," Tandjung said, adding "If he makes a good decision about that it will help his image." (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: YUGOSLAV MAGICIAN MARRIES TAIWAN WOMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Yugoslavian magician Vukouil Miroslab is so absorbed in his career, he even performed conjuring tricks at the courthouse prior to marrying to his Taiwan girlfriend.

Thursday in a ceremony presided over by a Taichung judge, Miroslab, better known by his professional pseudonym "Rossy", married Chen Hsu-wan, whom he met last year at the Woozland recreation park in Tainan County, southern Taiwan. At the time, Rossy had been working as a magician at the park for nearly four months.

The two 35 year olds met when Chen, a former a representative of a foreign trade company, went with friends to Woozland. She found herself particularly intrigued by the magic show staged by the handsome European.
Chen approached Rossy after his show was over and asked about his tricks, beginning a friendship that led to an international marriage a year later.
After becoming Rossy's girlfriend, Chen quit her trading company job and began to work as Rossy's assistant. Chen had been fascinated with magic since she was a little girl.

Last year, Rossy planned to return home to Belgrade to accept a magic job with Chen as his assistant. However, they discovered the difficulty of obtaining a visa into Yugoslavia for a citizen from a country which doesn't have diplomatic relations with the Balkan nation.

Rossy asked for help in getting Chen a visa from the mayor of Belgrade. The inquiry resulted in another friendship, this time between the magician, his Taiwan girlfriend and the mayor. Rossy and Chen arranged for the mayor to visit Taiwan recently and acted as guides for him.

The magician was asked by well-wishers during the wedding why he married Chen. Rossy said "no reason is the best reason," but cited that Chen's tenderness and thoughtfulness made him feel he wanted start a family with her.
Besides, he said, an international marriage allows him a better opportunity to understand different people and cultures.

Rossy has a strong political family background. One of his brother-in-laws is a heavyweight in a Yugoslavian opposition party who once was defeated in a presidential election. Another brother-in-law is an incumbent minister in Italy.

Rossy, a born conjurer, said he began his career in magic at the age of 12. As a professional magician, he has performed his conjuring tricks in many countries, including the US gambling mecca Los Vegas.
Rossy said his greatest wish is for he and his new bride to make a round-the-world performance tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY HOPING FOR BEIJING-TAIPEI RECONCILIATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer said here on Friday that he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can reconcile, and the sooner the better.
Downer, who is on an official visit to Washington, said the Australians don't particularly enjoy from time to time finding themselves "squashed like some sort of meat in a Beijing-Taipei sandwich."

As far as relationships between mainland China and Taiwan are concerned, Downer said at a press conference that from the point of view of Australia, which has a very important political, economic and strategic relationship with the PRC and important economic links with Taiwan, "the sooner there is an appropriate degree of reconciliation between Beijing and Taipei, the better."

Downer said Australia engages with the PRC on a wide range of issues, which includes disarmament issues. "I think the PRC knows only too well what Australia's approach to missile proliferation is. We obviously want to see restraint exercised throughout the region," he said.
He pointed out, however, that Beijing has not discussed with Sydney matters related to mainland China's increased missile deployment in areas close to Taiwan.

Downer met with mainland Chinese Ambassador Hua Junduo soon after he assumed his foreign minister's post in March 1996 to express Australia's concern about communist Chinese missile firing and live-ammunition war games on Taiwan's doorstep.

In addition, he also expressed welcome at the United States' decision to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to the Taiwan Strait in 1996 at the height of the cross-strait tension to deter Beijing from attacking Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S NEW BOOK BEST SELLER IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 18 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Japanese version of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's new book "With the Peoples Always in My Heart" has become a best seller in Japan since it was published June 3.

The publisher of Lee's book in Japan, the Peace and Happiness Through Prosperity (PHP) institute, said in an interview with CNA that the book has sold over 50,000 copies in a two-week period to become a best seller among books concerning the economic and politic fields.
PHP said that the initial printing of 27,000 sold out while the 50,000 replacement copies sent to bookstores hardly met demand. PHP said 20,000 additional copies will be printed June 22.

PHP officials said that in the past, books dealing with politics and economics were considered best sellers in Japan if they sold 50,000 copies. In recent years, due to a sluggish economy, a book of any topic was considered a best seller if it sold between 20,000 and 30,000 copies.
They noted that Lee's books entered the best seller list in just two weeks, and that sales are increasing daily.
The 232-page book in Japanese, documents Lee's life and political philosophy. It sells for 1,600 yen (US$13) a copy.
PHP is planning to run excerpts of the book in the next issue of Voice, a political and economic monthly in Japan with a circulation of 200,000 copies.

Lee's book consists of eight chapters -- "The journey of my thought," "My political philosophy," "The power behind Taiwan's prosperity and peace," "The present expectation of the PRC," "The present expectation of the US," "the present expectation of Japan," and "The contribution that can be made by Taiwan, the US and Japan."
In the book, Lee said that Tokyo is "excessively humble' toward Beijing and dares not say words other than "yes" when negotiating with Beijing.
Lee advises Japan to "discern the real situation on mainland China and negotiate with Beijing fearlessly."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT BURKINA FASO, SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee will visit Burkina Faso and Sao Tome and Principe later this month, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday.

MOFA officials said Lee will lead a delegation to attend a meeting of the mixed commission of cooperation between the Republic of China and Burkina Faso on June 23-24 in the Burkina Faso capital of Ouagadougou.
The delegation will be comprised of officials from MOFA, the China External Trade Development Council, and the International Cooperation Development Fund.

During his stay in Burkina Faso, Lee will meet with President Blaise Compaore, Prime Minister Kadre Ouedraogo, Foreign Minister Ablosse Ouedraogo, and other ranking officials of the West African country.
He will also meet with ROC agricultural and medical missions stationed there.

Lee will then leave for Sao Tome and Principe on June 25 to meet with Presdient Miguel Trovoada and other ranking officials to exchange views on bilateral cooperation. He will also meet with ROC agricultural and medical missions stationed there.
The ROC-Burkina Faso mixed commission of cooperation is held every two years alternately in the two countries, with the first meeting held in Ouagadougou in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT PRAISES ROC SMES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 17 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez on Thursday praised the development of the Republic of China's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
He also thanked the ROC for its help in developing his Central American nation's SMEs, saying that the ROC's actions should act as a model for developing nations.
He made the remarks at a ceremony to celebrate the second anniversary of the forming of the Dominican Republic's SMEs.
Kuo Kang, ROC ambassador to the Dominican Republic, and two other embassy officials, were also present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARRESTS MADE IN TAIPEI DRUNKEN DRIVING CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou personally led a 300-strong police action on Thursday, launching a citywide crackdown on violations of new drunken driving laws.
The large-scale crackdown campaign began at 9 p.m. and continued until 6 a.m. Friday, with policemen stationed on many major intersections around the city.

A total of 276 drivers were found to have been drinking and driving, 56 of whom were arrested after being breathalyzed and found to be far over the limit of 0.55 milligrams of alcohol per liter in the bloodstream.
The other 220 violators were fined NT$6,000 (US$185.76) for having blood-alcohol levels of 0.25 milligrams or more. Most of their vehicles were also impounded, according to police.

Drunken driving is the third-biggest cause of death and injury in traffic accidents in Taipei, said Ma, who has pledged to curb rampant drunken driving by strengthening moves to crack down on violators.
The Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee on Wednesday passed an amendment to the Traffic Control and Punishment Statute, placing more criminal responsibility on drunken drivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LOWERS PUNITIVE ANTI-DUMPING DUTIES ON TAIWAN DRAM MAKERS

TEXT.P: The US Department of Commerce (DOC) on Thursday lowered the average anti-dumping duties on Taiwan's DRAM makers from 16.65 percent to 16.41 percent.
The DOC came to the decision after finding obvious administrative negligence in its previous assessment of the punitive duties on Taiwan's Vanguard International Semiconductor Corp. (VISC) on May 21.
The VISC appealed to the DOC on June 1 for a reassessment of the company's imported prices after the DOC made its preliminary ruling May 21.

As a result, VISC's punitive anti-dumping duties were reduced from 10.36 percent to 9.56 percent while the average weighted duties for Mosel VItelic Inc., Nan Ya Technology and Etron Technology Inc. were downward adjusted to 16.41 percent.
The modification will consequently result in a lower guaranteed deposit that all Taiwan companies involved have to pay.
The DOC is scheduled to hold a public hearing on the case July 27 and to reach a final ruling on the dumping duties prior to October 11.

If the ruling finds dumping did occur, the independent US International Trade Committee (ITC) will make a final ruling within 45 days on whether the US domestic industry has been harmed by the imports.

The US Customs Authority will not issue an anti-dumping order against Taiwan imports until a final decision is reached by both the ITC and the DOC on the harm to the US industry. (by Herman Pan and Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE SUGAR INDUSTRY MINISTER VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Belize Minister of Sugar Industry and Local Government and Latin American Affairs Florencio Marin arrived in Taiwan on Friday for a week-long visit.
During his stay, Marin will call on Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development P.K. Chiang, and other government officials.
He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments before departing Taiwan on June 26.

Belize, which is situated on the Caribbean coast of South America, is one of the Republic of China's allies in the Caribbean area, and imported more than US$15 million-worth of products from Taiwan in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SCHOLAR VISITS TAIWAN FOR CHINESE UNITY SEMINAR

TEXT.P: A Republic of China association for national unity is to hold a seminar on Chinese unity on Sunday, and has invited mainland Chinese scholars to attend and discuss how to unite the Chinese people in the next century.
Twenty-two scholars from mainland China, Taiwan, and elsewhere are scheduled to participate in the seminar.

The mainland participants include former Institute of Taiwan Studies Director Chiang Tien-ming under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, who will present his thesis on Taiwan society's "tragedy complex," and Huang Chung-ping, deputy secretary-general of the Shanghai Institute of Taiwan Studies, who will discuss the miltilateral development of global events and its importance to cross-strait relations.

ROC Examination Yuan Vice President John Kuan, China Youth Corps President Dr. Jeanne Lee, Fu Jen Catholic University President Peter Yang, National Open University President Chen Yih-young and other Taiwan scholars will head the panel discussions at the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL UPHOLD `TAIWAN FIRST' PRINCIPLE: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, June 18 (CNA) (By Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will uphold the principle of "Taiwan First" in stepping up contact and dialogue with mainland China if the party gets the reins of power, DPP presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian said on Friday.

Former Taipei Mayor Chen made the remark during a visit to eastern Taiwan's Ilan County to attend a dragon boat race as part of the celebration of the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the major events in the Chinese calendar.

In addition to explaining the DPP's stance in dealing with mainland China in the event that the DPP wins the 2000 presidential election, Chen also criticized the ruling Kuomintang's shortcomings in handling cross-strait relations over the past decade.
He pointed out that under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, relations between Taipei and Beijing have regressed over the past 10 years.

Chen pledged that if the DPP acquires administrative power, it will proceed with protocol as well as political dialogues with mainland China, leading the cross-strait relationship into a comprehensive stage of negotiations.

Chen was accompanied at the races by DPP Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP legislator Chen Ding-nan, and Ilan County Magistrate Liu Hsou-cheng, and was warmly welcomed by the local people attending the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 TAIPEI DRAGON BOAT TOURNAMENT KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taipei International Dragon Boat Tournament kicked off on Friday on the Keelung River, with 81 teams from home and abroad participating.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou spoke in both English and Mandarin at the opening ceremony of the annual tournament, which is part of the activities to mark the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the most colorful national holidays in the Chinese calendar.
On Dragon Boat Festival Day, which falls on June 18 this year, dragon boat races are held, glutinous rice dumplings, or "tsungtze" are consumed, and poems are composed to celebrate the event.

In his speech, Ma said he hoped that friendship will be further nurtured between the people of Taiwan and their guests from overseas during the boat races. He also did not forget to promote the city's commerce by urging the foreign visitors to "do more shopping" during their stay.

The Taipei dragon boat race will run for three days until Sunday. The US men's and women's teams from Los Angeles, which were the title winners of the 1998 Taipei International Dragon Boat Tournament, are tipped for first place again this year.

Two racing teams from mainland China's Guangdong and Fujian provinces, respectively, met with two rival teams from Taiwan in a friendly race to kick off the competition, which began on Friday morning amid slight chaos due to heavy rain.

Similar dragon boat races were also scheduled Friday in Keelung City, Taipei County and in Kaohsiung City. Premier Vincent Siew addressed the opening of the race at Taipei County's Bitan, or Green Lake, where 50 men's and three women's teams competed for a top prize of NT$500,000 (US$21,368).
The Dragon Boat Festival, which is celebrated on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month, was originally devised to commemorate the ancient Chinese patriot and poet Chu Yuan (343-290 B.C.).

Chu Yuan was said to have jumped to his death into the Milo River, located in mainland China's modern day Hunan Province, to express his rancor and disappointment with the corrupt imperial government.

Admirers of Chu Yuan's integrity, patriotism and literary talent cast rice dumplings into the river to feed the fish that might otherwise have dined on Chu Yuan's body. This led to the custom of eating tsungtze on the day of Chu Yuan's death, a practice observed by Chinese communities worldwide ever since.
In addition to boat racing, eating tsungtze and composing poems, people in Taiwan also hang special herb bouquets on their front doors to keep evil away from their homes.

At noon, the main feast of the festival is served, with the adults drinking Hsiunghuang wine, a wine mixed with a traditional Chinese medicine which is believed to have the power to kill diseases and chase away poisonous insects.

While the adults drink the orange-colored wine, the children play with eggs, since according to custom, eggs can be stood on end at noon of the fifth day of the fifth lunar month. True or false? Check it out for yourself, but you will have to wait until next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINES DEMAND SIMULTANEOUS DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan aborigines' social awareness has increased, and instead of asking the government to improve their plight, they now demand simultaneous development with the rest of society, the Council of Aboriginal Affairs (CAA) chief said on Friday.

CAA Chairman Hua Chiah-chih made the remarks in an opening speech at a three-day international seminar on aboriginal rights, jointly held by government agencies and National Taiwan University's College of Law.

Hua stressed that the government's duties should not be restricted to merely offering subsidies to aborigines, but should be expanded to raising aboriginal people's dignity and competitiveness, in addition to working toward an ideal society where different cultures respect each other.

The government's original subsidy policy has hurt the aborigines' pride, Hua said, and the correct government aboriginal policy should cover both respect for cultural differences and promotion of aboriginal development.
In addition, Hua added, the Republic of China's legal system should also acknowledge and take into consideration the aborigines' traditional way of life and cultural standards.

Hua pointed out that the 1993 International Human Rights Conference held in Vienna named that year "world aboriginal year," and announced to the international community its dedication to ensure basic human rights and freedom for the world's aboriginal people.

National consciousness of aboriginal issues and rights have risen under the joint efforts of the government, the aboriginal elite, and academia, Hua said, adding that the aborigines' awareness of their own rights have also awakened.

On the other hand, Hua pointed out, the government has faced several bottlenecks in its promotion of aboriginal policies. For example, he said, when the CAA was drafting an aborigine development act, it had trouble defining "aboriginal collective intellectual property rights" and how to protect them.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLY SEE WELCOMES ROC MEASURES TO HELP KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: The Vatican has welcomed the Republic of China's measures to help Kosovar refugees, and is glad that the refugees are getting assistance, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release on Friday.

Vatican Secretary for Relations with the States Jean Louis Tauran on June 11 sent a letter to Raymond Tai, the ROC ambassador to the Vatican, to praise the ROC's generosity, according to the press release.

ROC President Lee Teng-hui's announcement on June 7 that the ROC will provide US$300 million to help the ethnic Albanian Kosovar refugees and help reconstruct the war-ravaged region was widely reported in the international media, while the ROC embassy to the Vatican has donated an additional US$100,000 to Albania's Catholic Church.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN LACK AIDS AWARENESS, SAY HEALTH OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Women account for less than 10 percent of Taiwan's AIDS patients, but health officials and care-givers for AIDS patients concerned nevertheless that Taiwan women still lack awareness of the threat of AIDS.

Statistics released by the Department of Health (DOH) show that as of the end of March this year, a total of 2,022 local residents of the island had been diagnosed as suffering from AIDS, 145 of whom were women.

DOH officials say that Taiwan women are reluctant to take steps to protect themselves from the disease, pointing out that of 60 couples with AIDS, most wives contracted the virus after finding out that their husbands had been infected.
Lee Ta-peng, executive director of the Yi Kuang Association for AIDS Prevention, said that most of the women he encounters show little interest in the subject.
He said he finds that women with higher education attach more importance to their health, and are more eager to know about AIDS than women with lower education.

A sister working for a Catholic consultation service center for AIDS patients said that unlike young men, who are required to undergo AIDS screening before entering military service, Taiwan women have no such compulsory AIDS examinations.
She urged the women of Taiwan to be screened before getting married, and again six months before attempting to get pregnant.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MALAWI DELEGATION MAKES JOHANNESBURG STOPOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, June 18 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An ROC delegation en route to a presidential inauguration in Malawi made a stopover on Friday in the South African city of Johannesburg.
The seven-member delegation, led by Control Yuan President Frederick Chien, was greeted by ROC Representative to South Africa Du Ling upon arrival at the airport.
The mission is slated to leave for Malawi on Saturday, where the delegates will attend the inauguration of the country's president on Monday in Blantyre, a major commercial city in southern Malawi.

Although vote counting for the June 15 election in the southern African country has not yet been completed, preliminary estimates show that incumbent President Bakili Muluzi is almost certain to score a sound victory in Malawi's second multi-party presidential election in 35 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH OFFICIALS ON ALERT AFTER 1ST INDIGENOUS CHOLERA CASE REPORTED

TEXT.P: Health officials have advised local hospitals and medical centers in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, to be on guard after an old woman in a Hsinchu hospital was diagnosed with cholera.
The 80-year-old woman was admitted to hospital in shock, suffering serious diarrhea and dehydration.

After she was diagnosed with cholera, she was immediately isolated from other patients. Her condition stabilized after treatment, but health authorities warned that mortality from cholera can be as high as between 40 and 60 percent if left untreated.
The case, the first indigenous cholera case in three decades in Taiwan, has triggered panic among the residents of Hukuo township, where the woman's family sells iced products in the local market.
Hsinchu health officials went to the woman's house and the surrounding area to disinfect and take samples for analysis, but no other cases have surfaced so far.
To curb the possible spread of the disease, health officials are continuing to monitor the situation closely, and have instructed hospitals to report suspected cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCIENTIST PROPOSES SOLUTION TO SYDNEY'S WATER PROBLEM

TEXT.P: A scientist from Taiwan is at the forefront of moves to find a solution to a drinking water crisis in Sydney, which is affecting about 4 million people in Australia's largest city.

In an interview with the CNA on Friday, James Yu, president of the Australian Chinese Engineers Association (ACEA), said the crisis, which derived from contamination by parasites nearly a year ago, "is far from over."
However, he said that with the help of other Chinese scientists, the ACEA has come up with a proposal following research and a series of discussions over the past few months.
The report will be made public at a presentation at Sydney University on July 7 so that Australian experts can scrutinize it and make some essential modifications, Yu said.

Last year, an inquiry into the drinking water problem came up with the suggestion that activated carbon and ozone technology could be installed to purify the water. But the proposal was dropped because at A$300 million (US$200 million), the cost was considered too high.
Yu's proposed solution, on the other hand, will cost only about A$57 million.
Yu, 57, worked for the Industrial Technology Research Institute in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park before he emigrated to Australia in 1982.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MEN WANT SUBSIDIZED VIAGRA

TEXT.P: Australian men want the government to include the impotence drug Viagra in its medical subsidy scheme.
But the government has decided to exclude Viagra from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, drawing strong criticism from doctors, who say the decision is demeaning to sufferers of impotence.
Unofficial figures shows that about 25 percent of Australian men are impotent, and opponents of the government decision say the cost of US$12 per tablet is too high.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC SUPPORTS AIRPORT DRUG TESTS FOR SYDNEY OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has given its support to a proposal by the organizers of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games that competing athletes should be subjected to drug tests as soon as they arrive at the airport in Australia.

In a dispatch from Seoul, Australia's Sydney Morning Herald on Friday reported that the IOC is now urging all 28 international sports federations worldwide to impose immediate sanctions on any positive drug results recorded by the Australian Sports Drug Agency before they compete in the Olympic Games, scheduled for mid-September next year.

Organizers from the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) and the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympics will jointly formulate a plan for the drug testing on the more than 10,000 athletes from about 200 countries who are expected to attend.

AOC president John Coates told the daily that drug testing before the Olympic Games would be a significant deterrent to the use of steroids, especially the quick-acting type, because athletes would not risk taking them in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO HIJACKERS CONVICTED BY MAINLAND CHINESE COURTS

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese hijackers have been sentenced to jail terms of 15 and seven years, respectively, by two mainland Chinese local courts.

Zou Weiqiang, who hijacked a domestic passenger aircraft from the mainland city of Fuzhou to Guangzhou, forcing the pilot to divert to Taiwan on June 6, 1994, was sentenced to a 15-year jail term and a three-year suspension of his civil rights by the Fuzhou City Intermediate People's Court. It was the first time the court had heard a hijacking case.

Meanwhile, the Jinan City Intermediate People's Court in the eastern province of Shandong confirmed that Han Fengying, who hijacked a passenger airplane to Taiwan on Sept. 30 in 1993 jointly with her husband, had been sentenced to seven years in jail on Thursday.

Both Zou and Han were repatriated to the mainland in February this year after serving jail terms imposed by Taiwan courts. Han's husband remains detained in Taiwan for using violence against Taiwan security officers during the repatriation process.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TALKS NEEDED TO DECIDE DATE FOR ARATS CHAIRMAN'S TAIWAN VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 18 (CNA) (By Chang Lung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese government sources said on Friday that further discussions are needed to decide the exact date of the planned visit to Taiwan of Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), is scheduled to visit Taipei in October, but his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, said on Thursday that any time from the middle of September to mid-October would be suitable.
The sources said ARATS is planning to discuss the issue with SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng during his upcoming visit to the mainland.

Jan is scheduled to fly to Beijing on June 27 for talks on several issues which might include the repatriation of mainland Chinese illegal immigrants. The issue was highlighted following the outbreak of a mystery disease among some mainland inmates of a Taiwan illegal immigrant detention center which resulted in panic among the inmates, prompting them to take two police officers hostage at the center. The officers were later released unharmed.

Wang's trip is intended as a reciprocal visit for Koo's Shanghai trip last October, which was regarded as an ice-melting visit after cross-Taiwan Strait talks were suspended unilaterally by Beijing to protest President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in 1995.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MP SERGEANT ACCIDENTALLY SHOT TO DEATH BY FELLOW SOLDIER

TEXT.P: A military police sergeant accidentally shot by a fellow soldier Thursday night died Friday morning, the Military Police Command said Friday.
Sgt. Yen Chung-chieh was shot in the head by Cpl. Lin Hao-chieh, who was attempting to remove bullets from his rifle after completing a patrol.
It was reported that the accident occurred at 9:06 p.m. Thursday, just after Lin finished a 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. patrol. The gun went off after Lin accidentally pulled the trigger.
Yen was rushed to Tri-Service General Hospital by his company commander, Capt. Lin Ching-shan. He was pronounced dead Friday morning.
The Military Police Command is investigating the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 US LAWMAKERS PRAISE TAIWAN FOR KOSOVAR AID PLEDGE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: Twelve US lawmakers have publicly lauded the Republic of China's US$300 million Kosovar aid pledge in the last 10 days, according to Taiwan's representative office in the United States.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in the United States issued a press release Thursday stating that since ROC President Lee Teng-hui announced the aid pledge on June 7, four senators and eight representatives have supported the move.

Sens. Max Cleland (D-Ga.), Timothy Johnson (D-S.D.), James Inhofe (R-Okla.) and John D. Rockefeller (D. W.Va.) praised the pledge, as did Reps. Tom Bliley (R-Va.), Solomon Ortiz (D-Texas), Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), John Sweeney (R-N.Y.), Gary Ackerman (D-N.Y.), Peter King (R-N.Y.), Philip English (R-Pa.) and Albert Wynn (D-Md.).

The press release stated that these legislators unanimously commended Lee for his leadership in extending the offer, and recognized the ROC government and the Taiwan people for their love of peace and respect for human rights.
Now that the Kosovo peace pact has been signed, the statement said, all the refugees are eager to return home, and the ROC's aid package is like a "gift from heaven."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS HEAD WELCOME TO VISIT ANY TIME THIS FALL: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan is welcome to visit Taiwan any time between September to November this year, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said Friday.
Su also urged mainland China to continue practical dialogues on issues concerning the rights of people on both sides of the strait.

Since mainland China cut off its dialogue with the Republic of China on June 16, 1995, Su said, mainland authorities have refused to "open the door to negotiation," despite last October's meeting in Shanghai between Wang and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu.

In addition, Su said, the mainland has constantly demanded that the two sides of the strait conduct political negotiations. He urged mainland China not to continue its search for an "intangible moon," but to instead opt for a dialogue on practical issues, such as the repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal immigrants.

Su said SEF Vice Chairman Jan Jyh-horng will leave for Beijing on June 27 to make preparations for Wang's fall visit to Taiwan. Taiwan wishes to reach a decision with ARATS on the date of Wang's visit, in addition to promoting "double-track" talks to settle cross-strait issues and to secure the signing of agreements, he said.
Su said he supported a suggestion by SEF officials that a detention center for illegal mainland immigrants who have come to Taiwan be established in the mainland's Xiamen.
He said he could understand the homesickness the illegal immigrants must feel, adding that if mainland China cannot face this problem with pragmatism, the problem will not be solved.

Su also urged mainland China to take back illegal immigrants within one month. According to statistics, there are currently over 1,000 illegal immigrants awaiting repatriation in Taiwan detention centers, and some have been waiting for over six years to return home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES MAY PROTEST MALAYSIA'S MOVES ON SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government may file a diplomatic protest with Malaysia if reports that it has occupied two reefs in the Spratly islands are verified.

Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said Friday the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) is waiting for a report from the armed forces, which has been instructed to look into the alleged Malaysian occupation.
Earlier reports said Malaysia has occupied two small shoals in the Spratlys since two weeks ago.
DFA Secretary Domingo Siazon confirmed having heard such rumors, but said the reports must be verified before any action would be taken.

"A move similar to the filing of a diplomatic protest by Beijing would be premature unless Manila verifies the nature of the reported occupation -- whether this was within the Kalayaan (Freedom) island group and whether the Malaysian placed markers, built structures or stationed troops in the reefs," Barican noted.

The Philippines had filed at least two diplomatic protests with mainland China for its military buildup in Mischief Reef in the Spratlys, which is well within the Philippines' 200-mile exclusive economic zone.
The Philippines and Malaysia along with mainland China, the Republic of China, Vietnam and Brunei all claim the Spratlys in part or in whole.
Barican said the DFA stressed the need for a code of conduct and multilateral negotiations among claimant countries in view of the reported incursion.
The government is pressing for actions to ease tensions among claimant countries and to determine how differences may be resolved peacefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT TO DEAL WITH PRO-TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE FORCES

TEXT.P: Mainland China will not engage in any type of dealings with any pro-Taiwan independence political party, a noted mainland Chinese academic said on Friday.

Xu Shichuan, director of the Institute of Taiwan under the Chinese Academy of Social Science, told CNA that Beijing will not engage in dealings with Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) until the pro-Taiwan independence party changes its position in regard to Taiwan's independence.

Xu, who recently visited Taiwan, said a resolution issued recently by the DPP made it very clear that the party has not shifted away from its pro-Taiwan independence viewpoint, although it has made modifications in its policy.

Xu's remarks came on the heels of comments by Chen Shui-bian, a DPP stalwart and the party's candidate in Taiwan's next presidential election, slated for March 2000, during a Wednesday interview with Japan's mass-circulation The Yomiuri Shimbun.
Chen said he would promote a comprehensive dialogue, including political negotiation, with mainland China if he was elected as Taiwan's next president.

Should Chen want to engage in a dialogue with mainland China to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he must accept the "one China" principle, Xu said, adding that it is very difficult to hold bilateral talks if the two parties involved lack a common ground.

Mainland China is willing to talk about any issue with Chen, if he accepts the "one China" framework, he said, adding that there will be no possibility of two-way dialogue if Chen adopts a "one China, one Taiwan," or "two Chinas" position.

Responding to Chen's comments, ranking officials with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, mainland China's intermediary body in handling bilateral exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal contacts, said Chen's remarks reflect his political view of Taiwan as an independent political entity.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR: WITHOUT POLITICAL REFORM, MAINLAND COULD FACE INSTABILITY

TEXT.P: Mainland China will face rising instability if it fails to undertake significant political reform in the next decade, said a scholar in an article for the Philadelphia-based Foreign Policy Research Institute's "Wire" for July 1999.

Minxin Pei, a senior associate with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, noted in an article titled "Is China Unstable?" that mainland China is likely to maintain short-term political stability despite many signs of potential turmoil.
But he warned that if no significant institutional change is undertaken, the mainland "will experience rising tensions that its current political system will be incapable of handling."

Pei said that Beijing is now facing two perilous economic challenges: an insolvent banking system, with the total number of bad loans at between 25 percent and 30 percent of its gross domestic product, and rising unemployment.

In addition to its economic woes, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) also faces some structural and institutional weaknesses, such as a narrower base of support, organizational defects, weak institutional channels for resolving state-society conflicts and the absence of effective institutions to resolve conflicts within the state.

But the mainland-born scholar said that there are some strengths that help offset these weaknesses, such as weak opposition to the CCP, relative elite cohesion, the CCP's formidable powers of control and a start by Beijing's leaders to tackle long-term problems.
Pei said that although localized incidents of social unrest are likely to increase, the CCP should be able to avert significant political turmoil in the near future.

Its long-term future, however, is less certain. "Even if the Chinese government gets through 1999 without a repeat of 1989, it must soon confront the issue of political reform more seriously, because the challenges it poses will only increase as time passes," he said.
The scholar said that failure to implement political institutional reform may lead to rising instability through three mechanisms, simultaneously or sequentially:

-- The development of an environment that allows corruption to worsen, inequality to rise, and poor governance to persist, all of which could eventually cause a massive social explosion such as that occurred in Indonesia in May 1998; and
-- Increased division within "the current moderate-conservative ruling coalition," as more liberal elements become disenchanted and frustrated with the slow pace of reform.
"Although China is unlikely to become another Indonesia today, it is very likely to become one in 10 years' time if its leaders are lulled into complacency," concluded the scholar.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRIAN-TAIWANESE COUPLE GIVE PIANO RECITALS

TEXT.P: Austrian pianist Albert Muhlbock and his Taiwanese wife Chou Yu-king gave two successful piano recitals at Taipei's National Concert Hall on Friday.
Wu Chi-man, a professor in the music department of National Normal University, praised the couple for their flawless performances.
In addition to traditional piano melodies, two Taiwan folk songs, Wang Chun Feng (Wishing for Spring Wind) and Tien Hei Hei (The Sky Is Dark), were performed.
This was their sixth performance together, of which three have been in Austria and three in Taiwan.
Their next performance will be at the Taichung Chungshan Hall in central Taiwan on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA BECOMING A BITTER PILL FOR MANY IMPOTENT AUSTRALIAN MEN

TEXT.P: Viagra is turning into a bitter pill for many impotent Australian men because the wonder drug has become a financial burden for them, and they want the government to provide subsidies.

But the government has decided to exclude Viagra from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and will not provide any subsidies. This immediately drew strong criticism from doctors, who said the decision was demeaning to sufferers of sexual impotence. They said impotence is a disease not only physically, but also mentally, for many Australian men.
An unofficial figure shows about 25 percent of Australian men are impotent and have to spend US$12 for one Viagra tablet.
Australian men are the world's third most sexually active, behind American and French men.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said presidential hopefuls must show conformity in words and deeds.
The China Times:
Employers will be required to set aside 6 percent of employees' salaries as the Workers Retirement Fund.
The United Daily News:
Companies defaulting on checks worth more than NT$30 million within a week will be subject to close monitoring by the Investigation Bureau.
The Liberty Times:
Two cattle ranches in Tainan County are very likely to have been infected with foot-and-mouth disease virus.
The Commons Daily:
Opposition National Assembly deputies vow to kill any bills intending to extend tenures of the president, legislators and NA deputies.
The China Post:
Taipei gets serious in bid to sober up drunk motorists.
The Taiwan News:
Torture tools found in Pristina.
The Taipei Times:
Fresh appeal planned for "Hsichih trio."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 19, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1790: The French Assembly abolishes hereditary nobility.
1829: British Home Secretary Sir Robert Peel founds the London Metropolitan Police.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1905: Pope Pius X, originally Giuseppe Melchiorre Sarto, who was strongly opposed to religious modernism, allows Italian Catholics to join in common public affairs.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien Province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, who were accused by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He was made president of a company that became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and US President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, the Chinese communists hit Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight communist coastal guns, seven communist fortifications, and four communist ammunition depots.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau compatriots in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty by a court in mainland China's Hangchow and sentenced to death for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang Province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION EXPECTED TO TOP 22 MILLION THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population is expected to top 22 million by the end of this month, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said on Saturday.

MOI officials noted that in latest census, the population stood at 21,993,797 as of the end of May. Of the island's two municipalities, Taipei City has a population of 2,640,014, while southern Kaohsiung City has 1,467,773.

Six counties in Taiwan proper have a population of over 1 million, topped by Taipei County, with 3,481,734. This is followed by Taoyuan County with 1,667,071, Taichung County with 1,474,236, Changhua County with 1,302,741, Kaohsiung County with 1,227,971, and Tainan County with 1,101,890.

The population as of the end of May had increased by 0.81 percent compared with the same time last year. By gender, the male population was 11,270,533 and the female population was 10,723,264, with a male:female ratio of 100:105.
The increased rate of population growth was highest in Taoyuan County, at 2.375 percent; followed by Taichung City, at 2.018 percent; and Hsinchu City, at 1.421 percent.

MOI officials also reported that as of the end of last year, Taiwan's foreign population had exceeded 321,000. Among them, foreign laborers accounted for 84 percent. Meanwhile, an average of 25,000 Taiwan residents emigrate overseas every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED FMD CASES FOUND AMONG CATTLE IN TWO TAIWAN RANCHES

TEXT.P: The foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) which flared up in cattle ranches in the off-shore island county of Kinmen is suspected of having traveled to Taiwan, with cattle in two ranches in Shanhua, Tainan County, almost certainly infected, local newspapers reported on Saturday.
