Both the United Daily News and the China Times carried front-page reports that 23 head on two ranches tested positive for FMD antibodies, a sign indicating the existence of the FMD virus in their systems.

As none of the cattle in question had been vaccinated for FMD, health officials believe the only explanation of the antibodies is that they are infected with FMD, although this cannot be absolutely confirmed until a culture of the virus has been grown on samples taken from the cattle, the reports said.
Once FMD is confirmed, health officials will vaccinate the cattle on ranches within a six-kilometer radius of the two affected ranches, in addition to destroying the infected livestock.

Putting on a brave face at the prospect of a possible FMD epidemic among the island's cattle, health officials assured the public on Saturday that it too early to confirm that an epidemic has broken out on the island.
Soong Hua-chun, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said on TV that even if an epidemic is confirmed, beef and milk can still be consumed safely.
Noting that the FMD virus is killed by the heat generated in the cooking process, and will not spread to humans, Soong urged the public not to worry about consuming local livestock products.
Meanwhile, the health officials decided on Saturday to destroy another 35 head of cattle on a third Kinmen ranch hit by FMD.

The animals at the Wu Wen-teh ranch will be destroyed on Sunday and buried at a farm far from the ranch for fear of polluting the water of the nearby Tienpu Reservoir, which is the island's main source of drinking water.
Earlier attempts to incinerate the cattle were abandoned as too expensive and time-consuming. Kinmen has already slaughtered 132 head because of the FMD scare.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VICE PREMIER TO BE HONORED BY UNI. OF TORONTO

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shuan of the Republic of China has been chosen by the University of Toronto to be this year's recipient of the Rose Wolfe Distinguished Alumni Award, but he has been denied a visa to Canada.

A university spokesman said on Friday that the recipient is selected for demonstrating his leadership, dedication to community service and appreciation of the role of higher learning. But the Canadian government has declined to issue him a visa as it fears the response such a move would provoke from Beijing.
"It's a great pity" that a distinguished alumnus is barred from joining his old schoolmates in Canada, said Han-Ru Cho, professor of physics at the university, who nominated Liu for the honor.

To make up for Liu's lost opportunity to receive the honor at his alma mater, University of Toronto President J.R.S. Prichard plans to fly to Taiwan in December and present the award in person to Liu.

In 1995, then Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh made a low-profile visit to British Columbia to receive an honorary degree from the University of Victoria. That brief visit drew a protest from Communist China. It is believed that this is the reason why Liu has been denied a visa to Canada this time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO FACE SEVERE SHORTAGE OF NURSES

TEXT.P: The incoming president of the Canadian Nurses' Association predicted on Friday that the country could face a shortfall of more than 100,000 nurses by 2011.
Lemiere Rodger said an increase in the aged population, combined with a jump in the average age of nurses, now standing at 47, will mean an increased demand for new nurses.

Rodger and other nurses' representatives met recently with federal Health Minister Allan Rock, who promised to provide them with research funds to study how many nurses Canada's health care system will need in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN ISLAMIC LEADERS SAY WOMAN PRESIDENT `UNSUITABLE'

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Islamic leaders have started questioning the eligibility of Megawati Sukarnoputri to become the president of the world's most populous Muslim state as the PDI-P leader continues her lead in the June 7 elections.
In a dispatch from Jakarta, the Sydney Morning Herald reported that Megawati is being attacked as anti-Muslim by Muslim leaders and groups, who said only men are eligible to become president.

Despite the attacks, Megawati has remained largely silent and aloof, the daily reported. But she still needs partners if she wants to be able to govern the country, and most of the main parties are ridden with factional fighting and are capable of changing allegiances or splitting, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOLD MINING FIRMS FIGHTING FOR SURVIVAL

TEXT.P: Gold mining firms in Australia, the world's third-largest producer and exporter, are fighting for their survival as bullion prices have hit a 20-year low of US$260 per ounce, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

The report quoted analysts as saying that low prices have resulted in the closure of three nickel mines in Kalgoorlie, and warned that small gold mines will face similar closures if gold prices continue falling in the months ahead.

They attributed the plunge in gold prices to a series of sales of reserve gold by central banks, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, which has added fuel to the fire following the Asian financial crisis.
But other experts dismissed the warning, saying that the prospects for gold are not too pessimistic because of the economic recovery in Asia, which is known for its passion for the yellow metal.
"Gold no longer glitters for westerners, but it remains glowing for many Asians and Middle Eastern people," one analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FM TO SECURE RELEASE OF AID WORKERS IN BELGRADE

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Friday night flew to Belgrade from Washington in an attempt to secure the release of two aid workers detained in the Yugoslavian capital after being convicted of espionage on May 31.

A spokesman for Downer in Canberra told reporters on Friday that the foreign minister decided to fly to Belgrade to press for the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace of CARE Australia -- the country's largest relief agency.

CARE Chairman Malcolm Fraser, who is a former Australian prime minister, told reporters in Melbourne that Downer's trip comes at a crucial time in the negotiations to have the two aid workers and their Yugoslavian colleague set free.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GIVES SPEECH IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: Facing the challenges of a changing world in the post-Cold War era, the Republic of China government is poised to build a democratic, efficient and advanced society for the people of Taiwan, ROC President Lee Teng-hui said on Saturday in this southern Taiwan city.

Addressing a commencement ceremony at the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, Lee said the government will launch across-the-board political, economic, and social reforms to carry out restructuring in the fields of the judiciary, education and social welfare systems.

Looking at Taiwan's history, Lee lamented that for a long time, the people of Taiwan were unable to govern their homeland. Today, however, Taiwan people should be happy because they now enjoy levels of freedom, democracy and prosperity that they never had in the past, he added.

The president pointed out that every individual's future is closely linked to his country's development, and that only in an open society can a private citizen freely develop his potential. In this way, building an advanced nation ensures a bright future for each individual, and vice-versa, Lee noted.

"Our achievements today are a result of the hard work and efforts of our ancestors, and we should treasure the fruits of their labor," he went on to say, encouraging all graduates to gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan's history and make greater contributions to the country to help it reach out into the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN OFFICIAL RAPS INDONESIAN ARMY FOR VIOLATION IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: The head of the United Nations Assistance Mission to East Timor has condemned the Indonesian military for organizing and participating in terrorism and human rights violations in the territory.
The condemnation comes on the eve of the arrival of the first contingent of Australian police charged with overseeing an August ballot in East Timor.

In a dispatch from the East Timor capital of Dili, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday that Indonesian soldiers have been witnessed directing pro-Jakarta militiamen as they burned houses and beat up an old man.

Meanwhile, the Australian Associated Press reported that the first contingent of 38 Australian federal police will leave Darwin for Dili on Sunday for a three-month tour of duty to oversee the first ballot for Timorese since the territory was annexed by Indonesia from Portugal 24 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS FROM MAINLAND, TAIWAN DISCUSS UNITY IN 21ST CENTURY

TEXT.P: Scholars from mainland China and Taiwan got together at Taipei's Grand Hotel on Saturday to exchange views on how the Chinese should strive for unity and self-reliance in the 21st century.
The symposium was organized by the Taipei-based Republic of China Association for Unity and Self-Reliance.

Pai Wan-hsiang, president of the sponsoring association, said at the opening of the symposium that the 21st century will be a century of freedom and democracy, with advanced scientific and economic developments.
He stated that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will affect security and peace not only in the Taiwan Strait but across the Asia-Pacific region, and perhaps throughout the world.
Pai said he hopes relations between Taiwan and mainland China will develop in a way that brings about unity, mutual benefit and cooperation in the next century.

Jiang Denming, head of the mainland Chinese delegation to the symposium, presented a report in which he called on the Taiwanese people "to walk away from sorrowful feelings and create the future together."
In regard to cross-strait relations, Jiang suggested that both the mainland and Taiwan handle incidents with responsibility and a rational attitude, without resorting to political sentiment.
He proposed that top leaders of the mainland and Taiwan visit the other side at an appropriate occasion and in an appropriate capacity.
Participants to the symposium presented reports on how the Chinese should strive for unity and self-reliance under the themes of humanitarianism, social development and economic development.

The scholars from the Taiwan side included Examination Yuan Vice President John Kuan, China Youth Corps President Jeanne Li, Catholic Fu Jen University President Yang Tung-ho and National Open University President Chen Yih-young.

Mainland scholars attending the seminar came from the Taiwan Research Institute of China, Nankai University, the Tienjin Academy of Social Sciences, Chengzhou University, the Taiwan Research Institute of Shanghai, the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing University and Fuzhou University.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENTERS 1999 MUCH STRONGER: BRITISH STRATEGIST
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 19 (CNA) (By Mark Chun-lin Ou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan entered 1999 stronger, given the fact that Beijing has painted itself into a corner with its diplomatic flops, a British strategist said on Wednesday.

Dr. Chris Hughes, a strategist from the University of Birmingham, told a conference on East Asian security that Beijing's diplomacy has been following a bumpy road ever since US President Bill Clinton announced his so called "three noes" policy -- no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "one China" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international groups -- in June, 1998.

Branding mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan in November, 1998 "a disaster," Hughes said that Jiang has failed to dissuade Tokyo, which was alarmed by North Korea's missile test over its airspace in August of that year, from joining a US-led anti-missile system and expanding its defense cooperation pact with the US to cover the area around Taiwan.

Beijing's ties with Washington also took a nose-dive in 1999 over its alleged theft of US nuclear secrets, its alleged attempt to influence US politics through illegal campaign contributions, and its shrill protests over NATO's accidental bombing of its embassy in Belgrade.

Beijing's opposition to NATO's air strikes against Yugoslavia also soured its ties with the Western powers and handed Taiwan, which usually rallies behind the West on international issues, a favorable environment to develop ties with the West, said Hughes.
The British strategist also pointed out that Beijing's missile testing in waters near Taiwan between 1995 and 1996 has alienated Taiwan's younger generation.
They are now more pro-independence than their elders, and this attitude will probably affect Taiwan's next presidential election in 2000, said Hughes.

Hughes's point of view was supported by various opinion polls conducted in Taiwan over the past few years, said Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, the Cabinet-level body which formulates Taiwan's mainland China policy.

Lin, who was invited to deliver a speech at a conference organized by the Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies, said that the surveys found that Taiwan residents' propensity for independence peaked during Beijing's missile tests, with a higher percentage of the people surveyed saying they consider themselves Taiwanese rather than Chinese.

In his speech, Lin called the world's attention to Beijing's efforts to develop information warfare, or what he called "acupuncture warfare," which he said could paralyze an enemy's command and communications system with strong electronic pulses.
Professor Peter Ferdinand from Warwick University aired opinions similar to those of Hughes at the conference.
He also said that India's ever deepening mistrust of Beijing, and North Korea's missile tests, posed serious challenges to Beijing.

While Beijing has gone to great lengths to persuade Tokyo not to cooperate too closely with Washington on defense, North Korea's missile tests have undone this work and have in fact pushed Tokyo in the opposite direction, said Ferdinand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG BLOCKS PASSAGE OF POWER TRANSMISSION LINE

TEXT.P: Plans for Taiwan's third south-north power line were blocked by the Taichung County Government, which demanded from state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), more than NT$200 million in compensation for the use of county land, a local TV station reported Saturday.

The Taiwan TV station quoted Taipower officials as saying that the 321-kilometer high-voltage transmission line, which will run from Tainan County to Taipei County, is to be routed through central Taiwan's Taichung County.

Construction of the line, which will require the use of 76 pylons, was to begin in July, though a postponement is expected after the Taichung County Government refused to rezone the land on which a pylon would sit.
Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai demanded NT$210 million (US$6.46 million) for allowing the line to pass through Taichung, according to the station.

A down payment of NT$60 million (US$1.84 million) must be paid immediately, while the other NT$150 million (US$4.61 million) can be paid over the two and a half years that remain in Liao's term, according to the report.

In an interview with the TV station, Liao defended his demand, arguing that Taipower's Taichung Thermoelectric Power Plant, which burns fossil fuel, accounts for 90 percent of the country's air pollutants. He said this justifies their demand for compensation.
Taipower is reluctant to grant Liao's demand for fear that it will lead to similar demands being made by officials from other local governments, across whose territory the line will pass.
They said that Taipower's compensation rules cover only residents living in the vicinity of the power plants and the local governments of areas in which the plants are located.
If residents who live directly under the high-tension cable line are allowed to press for compensation, it would substantially increase the costs of power transmission, company officials said.

The 345,000-volt line, which is intended to carry power from the south to power-starved northern Taiwan, would supplement two existing power transmission lines, which are being used at up to 90 percent of their capacity.
If the third cable line is not completed before May next year, Taipower officials warned, northern Taiwan could face a serious power outage if the two existing lines were to break.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS VISIT TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Two presidential hopefuls on Saturday visited Taipei County, which with a population of 3.5 million is a powerful magnet for candidates on the campaign trail, to drum up support for their election bids.

Vice President Lien Chan visited two historic temples in Tamsui and burned incense to pray for peace and happiness. Lien was greeted by enthusiastic supporters at the temples, who said they hoped he would win the election.
Lien also walked some of the city's older streets and sampled a local delicacy, fishball soup.
Another presidential candidate, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member Chen Shui-bian, attended the inauguration of three groups who support Chen's presidential bid.

Chen urged the people to support the DPP's presidential candidate, as he presided over the inauguration of one of the groups at a big stadium in Yungho, Taipei County. His old friend, Taipei County Magistrate Su Cheng-chang, attended the inauguration as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID CRACKING DOWN ON MORE DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese government has begun a new round of crackdowns on political dissidents, the New York-based "Overseas Information Center of the China Democracy Party" said Friday.

The information center said that more than 80 organizers and members of the outlawed would-be opposition party's provincial and municipal branches have been arrested in recent weeks, and that many more have been interrogated or placed under house arrest.

Many of those arrested are still being held in detention, the information said, adding that some of them have just been sentenced to long prison terms on charges of attempting to overthrow the government .
The information center urged people in the free world to show their concern over the hard crackdowns on political dissidents and the worsening condition of human rights in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA UNIT ISSUES REPORT ON MALAYSIAN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: A report by the Committee of Economic Research and Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) indicated that Malaysia's economy is improving, though its manufacturing and construction sectors remain sluggish.
Because Taiwan is the second-largest foreign investor in Malaysia, next only to Japan, the MOEA report on Malaysia's economic situation is an important reference material for Taiwan investors.

In the wake of the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Taiwan's investment in Indonesia dropped by as much as 90 percent, while its investments in Malaysia and Vietnam rose 40 percent and 60 percent, respectively.

The latest report on the Malaysian economic situation said that Malaysia's exports have registered continued growth for six consecutive months, with its foreign exchange reserves soaring to US$27.2 billion by January this year from US$21.7 billion at the end of 1997.
But the report noted that as the manufacturing and construction sectors show no signs of improvement, it is too early to paint an optimistic picture of Malaysia's economic prospects.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU SAYS IT IS TIME TO MOVE ON KOSOVAR AID PACKAGE

TEXT.P: It is time to begin implementing the Republic of China's US$300 million humanitarian aid package for Kosovo, despite the controversy that surrounds the plan, said Foreign Minister Jason Hu.

The aid package, designed to provide emergency and rehabilitation assistance to the nearly 1 million refugees displaced by the conflict in Kosovo, was unveiled by President Lee Teng-hui on June 7. Since his announcement, the plan has been the target of criticism from people in almost all walks of life in Taiwan.

The main point in question is whether President Lee made the decision all by himself without first consulting the Legislative Yuan, the Executive Yuan, the Foreign Ministry and the Comptroller, said opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian.

In addition, Chu Li-lung, a lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang, pointed out that people are still in doubt as to why an amount of US$300 million was selected. He also questioned how the aid package would be implemented and what its consequences would be.
If the controversy drags on indefinitely, it will undermine the prestige of the foreign minister, the ruling party, and even the government, remarked the legislator.

Hu declined to respond to legislators' questions about how the decision was made. "The next step is to see 'where the beef is,' and all the things should be done at least within three to five years," he said.
As to the issue of whether the aid for Kosovo will crowd out other important government spending programs, Hu noted that "it will hinge on our wisdom."
Despite opposition at home, the plan has been welcomed by the international community judging from international news coverage of the aid package.

The aid project has increased Taiwan's international visibility, stressed Hu, adding that it should be followed up by winning the international community's goodwill through "near distance" cooperative experiences and by establishing more bilateral and multilateral cooperative channels. This will "not be necessarily an establishment of diplomatic relations; however, the distance between the two sides will surely be narrowed," he said.
The foreign minister expressed his hope that a "most transparent aid program" would be built so that taxpayers' money will be spent wisely.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KILLS FMD-INFECTED CATTLE HERDS

TEXT.P: More than 200 head of cattle from two breeding farms in Shanhua, Tainan County, were ordered to be slaughtered Saturday after it was confirmed that members of the herd had been infected with foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD).

In a hastily called press conference Saturday afternoon, Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), said that the virus found in the two ranches in Shanhua, Tainan County, was the same strain of FMD found in cattle in Kinmen County last week.

Peng said the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) has instructed the Tainan County Government to wipe out the cattle herds of dairy farmers Liu San-ho and Huang Wen-hsiang after FMD antibodies were found in saliva and blood samples of the livestock.
The confirmation of FMD in the cattle in Shanhua proved true health officials' fears that the O-strain that had affected bulls in Kinmen would make its way across the strait, said Peng.
Not leaving anything to chance, Peng said his council has ordered the extermination of all cattle suspected of being infected.
A campaign to immunize all cattle at ranches within a 6-kilometer radius of the two cattle farms whose livestock are infected with FMD will be carried out soon, COA officials said.

FMD, a contagious disease that plagues cloven-hoofed animals, hit Taiwan's hog population in 1997. The outbreak crippled Taiwan's hog farming industry and resulted in the slaughter of more than 4 million pigs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-TAIPEI LOSES TO VENEZUELA 2-0 IN WOMEN'S SOFTBALL

TEXT.P: Venezuela defeated host Chinese-Taipei 2-0 at Hsinchuang Stadium near Taipei on Saturday, the third day of the sixth World Women's Youth Softball Championship.
This was the first loss for Chinese-Taipei. In the past two days, Chinese-Taipei upset Italy 10-0 and beat the Czech Republic 4-1.
In other games on Saturday, the Czech Republic defeated Argentina 8-2; the United States blanked Canada 11-0; Russia edged South Korea 2-1; and mainland China beat Australia 2-0.

Several games were postponed because of heavy rains, including matches between the Netherlands and South Korea, Russia and mainland China, Italy and Argentina, New Zealand and Canada, and the Czech Republic and Venezuela.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER RETURNS FROM PARIS AIR SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 18 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhic and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien left Paris on Friday for Taipei after a six-day stay here for the 43rd Paris Air Show.

In addition to presiding over the opening ceremony of an ROC exhibition booth at the show on June 13, Yang also successfully persuaded several leading international aviation groups to take part in the 1999 Taipei Aviation Fair, which will kick off on Aug. 14.

Ranking officials from Dassault, Boeing, Airbus, SNECMA, Eurocopter, Allied Signal, and Thomson-CSF have all promised to take part in the Taipei aviation show, according to David R.C. Chu, office director of the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development under the ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs.

At the same time, Thomson-CSF has agreed to step up bilateral cooperation with the committee, while Allied Signal, the world's largest aircraft maintenance and repair group, has also showed a strong interest in cooperating with the ROC Aerospace Industrial Development Cooperation in the field of aircraft electronic engineering maintenance, Chu noted.

Besides an exhibition on the ground, the 1999 Taipei aviation show will also feature an aerobatics performance by a special squadron from the ROC Air Force composed of US-made F-16s, French-made Mirage 2000-5s and locally built Indigenous Defense Fighters, according to Chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 20, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1597: Dutch navigator and Arctic explorer William Barents dies at sea at the age of 47. He led several expeditions in search of the Northeast Passage.
1837: Victoria accedes to the British throne at the age of 18 on the death of her uncle, William IV.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1900: Baron von Ketteler, the German envoy in Beijing, is killed in the street by Boxer rebels.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railroad between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation between Vietnam and China.
1940: The French government requests an armistice with Italy.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out the Swede Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia were formally formed on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position. But if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ZOO BACK TO NORMAL AFTER SATURDAY'S FLOOD

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Zoo on Sunday resumed operations one day after visitors had to be evacuated by rubber boats and a Taiwan black bear escaped from its compound.
Despite Saturday's chaos, the Mucha zoo was opened to the public on Sunday after the facility's staff cleaned up sludge and sterilized the area.
Zoo manager Yang Sheng-hsiung said except for the butterfly exhibition hall, which suffered the greatest damage during the flood, all areas on Sunday were operating as usual.

Yang said the zoo's drainage system was unable to handle Saturday's sudden heavy rainfall, resulting in serious flooding in many areas. Visitors had to be evacuated by rubber boats for the first time in the zoo's history.

While firefighters and zoo personnel were busy evacuating stranded visitors, a Taiwan black bear swam out of his flooded compound into the neighboring goat's exhibition area, causing further panic among the tourists.

Yang said the flooding in the bear's exhibition area was due to a closed water gate behind the compound. Yang explained the water gate is normally closed intentionally in order to prevent stray dogs and cats from entering.
Amid Saturday's sudden downpour, Yang said zoo personnel forgot to open the water gate, forcing the bear to flee his flooded compound.
Yang admitted the zoo was caught unprepared by Saturday's events, however, after this experience, he said the zoo is now ready for future emergencies.
Yang said the butterfly exhibition hall will be rebuilt into a new insect hall, and a complete overhaul of the drainage system will improve the zoo's drainage capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY TRANSCENDENCE IS 'ILLUSORY': OPINION POLL

TEXT.P: A newly published opinion poll Sunday revealed none of the presidential hopefuls has a support rating of more than 30 percent, moreover, over half of those polled said party transcendence is "illusory."
The new survey titled, "2000 Presidential Election Trend Investigation" was conducted by the China Statistics Association (CSA) June 10-11 and polled 1,846 legal voters over the age of twenty.

According to the survey, if the presidential election were to be held the following day, former Taiwan Governor James Soong would gather 29.4 percent of all votes, followed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) presidential candidate, Chen Shui-bien at 20.2 percent.
Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan, who was believed to be the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate, received support of 19.7 percent, while 30 percent said they were undecided.

The result was vastly different from previous surveys in which Soong received 40 percent of all tallies, and is the first poll to reveal that none of the presidential hopefuls has more than 30 percent voter support.

However, the opinion poll discovered that while Soong's support rate was the highest, 43.4 percent of those polled believed that Lien stood the greatest chance of winning the race, followed by Soong, at 21.4 percent. Only 9.6 percent thought Chen would win.
In addition, 76.6 percent believed if Soong quit the KMT to run in next year's presidential election, the DPP's Chen would win.

One notable aspect of the poll was the five questions concerning political parties; results show that 60 percent of people acknowledge political parties play a positive role in the development of democracy. Only 25 percent disagreed with the statement.
Another 60 percent believe a multi-party government will cause more confusion in the political scene, with 33.1 percent disagreeing.

Party politics is generally thought of in a positive light as 51.2 percent thought that party-elected candidates are better-suited to guide Taiwan's future political development, with 27.5 percent saying candidates with no party-affiliation are better.
CSA official Hsieh Pang-chang concluded at the press conference that "party politics are now the mainstream," and that "party transcendence is illusory."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNSTABLE WEATHER TO REMAIN

TEXT.P: Unstable wet weather will continue to hammer Taiwan during the next few days, the Central Weather Bureau announced on Sunday.

The current front effecting weather is still lingering over the island and is not likely to leave until Monday, the weather bureau predicted. It added that showers, accompanied with thunder and lightening, will continue in some areas of the island for the near future.
The Central Weather Bureau continued its heavy rain warning on Sunday. It warned people living near or in mountainous areas to be on the alert for possible landslides.

Statistics show that northern Taiwan has absorbed more rain than the south from the current front. For example, from Saturday night until early Sunday morning, Mucha, a suburb of Taipei, received 200 millimeters of rain.

Tropical thundershowers, which mostly occur during the afternoon, are regarded as natural disaster on Taiwan. On Thursday a 50-year-old hiker was struck and killed by lightening in suburban Taipei. Floods caused by heavy rain have caused extensive property demage since the rainy season began this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA HEAD CALLS ON MAINLAND TO HELP STOP FMD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top agriculture official on Sunday called on mainland Chinese authorities to join efforts by officials here to curb the spread of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), urged mainland China to fulfill its responsibility as a member of the international animal quarantine body, the International Office of Epizootics, to help arrest FMD on its side of the Taiwan Strait as the disease has now made its way onto Taiwan.

Peng hoped that mainland Chinese authorities will face the reality that the FMD epidemic has spread across the mainland, and will send virus samples to the FMD Laboratory in Britain for a thorough examination so as to allow other countries to be informed of the infection and contribute to eradicating it.

Citing that no quarantine system is good enough to meet the threat derived from any single smuggling, Peng called for the Taiwan public to treasure the country's agriculture economy by helping the government crack down on smuggling so as to help the government protect the safety of Taiwan's ecological environment.

Quarantine officials on Sunday slaughtered 194 head of cattle on four ranches in southern Taiwan in an emergency measure to check a possible FMD outbreak among the country's cattle population. FMD last affected Taiwan cattle in 1929.

An across-the-board quarantine began on the four ranches Sunday after the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine confirmed Saturday that the virus found on the ranches in Shanhua, Tainan County, was the same strain of FMD found in cattle on Kinmen island last week.

FMD antibodies were found in saliva and blood samples of the cattle from the four ranches. The confirmation of FMD in southern Taiwan cattle confirmed health officials' worst fears that the O-strain of the disease, found in cattle in Kinmen, located close to mainland China's Fujian Province, had made its way across the strait, Peng said.

To stop FMD's spread, the remaining 121 head of cattle on the four ranches suspected of being infected will be exterminated. In addition, 60,000 doses of FMD vaccine is being sent to southern Taiwan for use on all healthy cloven-hoofed livestock animals. Currently, a campaign to immunize all cattle on ranches within a 6-kilometer radius of the four Tainan ranches is being carried out.
Tainan County is Taiwan's largest cattle-raising region, with the cattle population totaling 28,000, about one-fifth of all cattle on Taiwan.
If all healthy cloven-hoofed livestock animals in the Tainan region are injected with the preventive medicine, 120,000 doses will have to be administered, quarantine officials said.

Meanwhile, Lee Chin-lung, director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said the meat market in Tainan County should be suspended immediately if the County government and the ranchers are determined to terminate the deadly disease once and for all.
If the iron-grip measures are not taken immediately, the cattle infection may expand to again damage Taiwan's hog population, a dreadful prospect for the country's economy, Lee added.

FMD, a contagious disease that plagues cloven-hoofed animals, ravaged Taiwan's hog population in 1997, crippling the country's hog farming industry, the staple source of meat in Taiwan and a major foreign exchange earner. The outbreak resulted in the slaughter of more than 4 million pigs.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAINAN COURT GIVES LIFE SENTENCE TO TAIWAN RESIDENT FOR SPYING
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 20 (CNA) (By M.N. Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan resident recently was convicted of spying and given a life sentence by a court in the southern mainland Chinese province of Hainan, the Hong Kong-based Apple daily reported on Sunday.

The daily quoted the Hainan Daily, the only official newspaper on the island province, as saying that Hsiung Tien-chun was given a life sentence by the Hainan Secondary People's Court after he was found guilty of spying for the Taiwan military.

According to the Hainan newspaper report, Hsiung, also known as Pu Fan, was discovered to be connected with Taiwan's Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) after he continuously collected classified military, political and economic information for Taiwan authorities under the guise of travel, private visits and business trips to and from mainland China between 1990 and 1997.

The report said in June 1995, Hsiung bribed Xi Shihguo, an official with the Hainan provincial government, into joining a Taiwan-based US company, owned by Hsiung's uncle. Xi was hired to be a consultant to the firm.

Under the financial lure, the report said, Xi allowed Hsiung into his office many times between July 1996 and March 1997 to Xerox and photograph official and classified documents on mainland China's political, economic and social situation.
Hsiung also arranged for Xi to travel to Bangkok in October 1996 to meet with MIB agents to exchange information. Xi was awarded an unknown amount of money for his treason, the report continued.
The Hainan report, however, did not mention when and where Hsiung was arrested on the espionage charges. It also did not state whether Hsiung was given an open trial for his alleged activities.
The report said that Xi was also given a life sentence for espionage activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK-TANK WARNS OF POSSIBLE MAINLAND BOYCOTT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's business and industrial sectors would suffer grave losses if mainland China launched a boycott of exported commodities from Taiwan, sources from the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) reported on Sunday.

Taiwan will face a loss equivalent to 7.64 percent of its total annual export trade if mainland China imposes a boycott on imports from Taiwan, said the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), which was contracted by IDB to do research on product competition and inter-reliance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The loss of 7.64 percent was valued at around US$7.7 billion if based on 1998 export figures, said TIER researchers.

In addition to Taiwan's exported goods, related up-stream industries would be afflicted with estimated losses worth about 3.2 percent of the country's entire annual exports, once a mainland trade boycott begins, the researchers warned.
Taiwan's labor-intensive industries, including chemicals, leather and hide processing, and basic metal processing, would suffer the greatest impact from the boycott, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENTS DETAINED IN HANGZHOU SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Police detained Saturday five members of the outlawed "China Democracy Party" in Hangzhou, capital of Zejiang province in eastern mainland China.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that the five dissidents are Zhu Yufu, Han Shen, Wang Rongqing, Mao Qingxian, and Li Bagen, and that their whereabouts are unknown.
The information center said the mainland Chinese government is expected to detain more members of the would-be opposition party in other cities soon.

More than 180 mainland Chinese dissidents have been detained by police in recent weeks. The information center added that 31 of them are still being kept in detention, and that they might be sentenced to prison terms.
The center urged the Western countries to condemn Beijing for relentlessly suppressing political dissidents in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON-BEIJING RIFT AFFECTS US-ROC ARMS ISSUES: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Recent rifts in Washington-Beijing relations make the United States more cautious in dealing with sensitive Taiwan issues such as the theater missile defense (TMD) system, Taiwan scholars said Sunday.
The Sino-American Cultural and Economic Association (SACEA) held a symposium Sunday morning to discuss Taiwan's contingency measures after the Washington-Beijing rift.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) international affairs department head Hsiao Mei-chin pointed out that while US-PRC relations are strained for the time being, their long-term strategic partnership still exists.

Academia Sinica fellow Chiu Chao-lin said judging from the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing and Taipei over the past twenty years, whenever a Washington-Beijing strain was caused by a Taiwan issue, the United States tended to concede to pressure from the PRC.
On the other hand, if the Washington-Beijing rift was caused by the PRC the US also cooled its relations with Taiwan, Chiu said.
The recent US bombing of the mainland Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia and the alleged mainland Chinese espionage activities in the US has plunged Washington-Beijing relations to a new low, she said.

In addition, anti-PRC sentiment has risen in the US, and President Bill Clinton's China policy is under attack as well. Under present conditions, she predicted such sensitive issues as the TMD system will become a pawn in US-China negotiations and that Washington will also shirk from its Taiwan policies.

Hsiao said that the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing and Taipei could never be "parallel;" whether US-PRC relations improve or regress, Taiwan, which is caught in the middle, will never wield any influence.
Especially when the US deliberately ignores that sovereignty is the main issue of disagreement across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan will always be caught in a dilemma, she said.

Hsiao pointed out the sovereignty issue is the "zero-sum" game across the Taiwan Strait, with no possibility of concession from either side. She suggested the Republic of China (ROC) government consider which issues can be freely discussed by both sides.

For example, she said, peace, economy and the direct trade, postal and transportation links are mutually beneficial issues, and therefore Taiwan should be prepared to raise these issues when negotiating.

Chang Wu-yueh, the director of Tamkang University's school of mainland affairs, said Taiwan is in no position to reject negotiations with mainland China, and that once at the negotiatiig table, Taiwan should emphasize the unreasonable restrictions the mainland has placed on negotiations over the political difference of both sides.

Mainland Association for Relations Across the Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan's fall visit to Taiwan is a crucial international moment, Chang said. He suggested the ROC government use Wang's visit to open up cross-strait dialogue.

Whether during Wang's visit the negotiations are "constructive dialogue" insisted by Taiwan, or the mainland's so-called "political dialogue," and no matter how polarized the two sides' standpoints would be, Chang said that as long as there is dialogue with mainland China, Taiwan will have the chance to present its stance to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA DECIDES TO OPEN VISA ISSUING OFFICE IN KAOHSIUNG CITY
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, June 20 (CNA) (By Chen Yu-ping and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Malaysian immigration authorities announced the country will open a visa issuing office in Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung in order to facilitate businessmen there in applying for Malaysian visas.
Malaysian immigration officials made the revelation Sunday at a dialogue with representatives of the association of Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia.
At present, the Malaysian representative office in Taipei handles an average of 2,000 visa cases per day.

Malaysia decided to open a visa issuing office in Kaohsiung in view of the fact that Kaohsiung and Kota Kinabalu, the capital city of Malaysian state of Sabah, have direct air links, as well as the fact that more and more businessmen in southern Taiwan do business in Malaysia.

During their talks, Chen Huang-kun, president of the association of Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia, suggested that Malaysian immigration authorities extend the effective period of a landing visa to one week from the current 72 hours and solve some technical problems in the issuing of visas.

Chen also urged Malaysian immigration authorities to give Taiwan school principals and teachers in Malaysia one-year visas, instead of issuing renewable visas every two weeks, as is the practice at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHIEF CALLS FOR IMMEDIATE "THREE LINKS"

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman Hsu Hsin-liang on Sunday said that Taiwan should immediately rescind its ban on the cross-strait "three links" and boldly make an inroad into the mainland market.

Hsu quit Taiwan's main opposition party in May in preparation for his run as an independent in Taiwan's next presidential election in 2000 after the DPP was sure to nominate former Taiwan mayor Chen Shui-bian as its candidate.

In his "Taiwan's 21st Century Economic Policy Guidelines", Hsu said mainland China is emerging as one of the biggest markets in the world and that only by taking a greater share of the mainland market can Taiwan become an economic power.
Otherwise, he warned, the island will turn out to be a mere "factory" that only produces goods for others, a prospect that is sure to lose the mainland market and its future as well.
The "three links" refers to direct trade, postal and transportation connections between Taiwan and the mainland. Taiwan currently bans the three links for national security reasons.

Hsu said that compared to other major economic powers now aggressively exploring the mainland markets, Taiwan owns advantages due to the short geographic distance between the mainland and Taiwan as well as the common cultural and historical backgrounds.

Hsu criticized the government's current "no hurry, be patient" mainland investment policy, which he said has restricted the development of cross-strait economic and trade relations and will further undermine Taiwan's competitive edge in the mainland market.

He suggested a restructuring of the government to upgrade its efficiency and a full opening of the country's capital and services markets in order to effectively face the challenges of the next century.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN JOURNALIST PRAISES ROC, LEE IN MONTREAL NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: A free and democratic Taiwan has outraged communist and totalitarian China, creating all sorts of headaches for tranquility in Asia, a senior Canadian journalist said.

Norman Webster had once been barred from visiting Taiwan because he was previously based in Beijing. "Thirty years on, I'm finally here," he said in an Taipei-datelined article appearing on the Saturday edition of The Gazette of Montreal.

Things change. Trade and culture now link the mainland and Taiwan. "The problem is that Beijing still considers the island to be an integral part of China and will not stand for talk of Taiwanese independence.

"It is, trust me, the only issue besides Tibet that rouses Chinese officials into red-faced fury. It makes them go ballistic -- literally -- as happened in 1996, when an outraged Beijing lobbed missiles into the Taiwan Strait," he noted.
If Taiwanese sometimes seem paranoid about their large cousin, there's a reason: China really is out to get them, he observed.

Most leaders in Taiwan play things cautiously, hoping not to provoke the dragon more than necessary, said Webster. "Taiwanese independence?" says President Lee Teng-hui. "That will get everybody into trouble."

"Tall, trim, 76 years young, Lee is a standing provocation to Beijing because of his popular election in 1996. This made him the first democratically elected head of state in China's 5,000 or so years of history," he wrote.
He said the days of Chiang Kai-shek's dictatorship are long gone; today's Taiwan throbs with political activity and a free press.
"China is a stagnated society," Lee told a group of us, journalists attending the annual assembly of the International Press Institute, he added.
He went on quoting Lee, "Taiwan is the breakthrough in long-run Chinese history. China has to learn from us. Taiwan now is the good example."

Lee's formula: reunification with the mainland can be contemplated when China itself becomes democratic. How long might that take? "Maybe 20 years, 25 years, one generation. In China, we take our time to make our changes," Lee was quoted again.

Another helpful suggestion from the president, who will retire from office next year, is that China be divided into seven fully autonomous regions: Taiwan, Tibet, Mongolia, Xinjiang, Manchuria, northern China and southern China. "Beijing has received the idea with gritted teeth," said Webster, a former editor of The Gazette.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IN MAY EXPERIENCED RARE CLIMATE CHANGE: CWB

TEXT.P: The temperature around Taiwan in May as measured by 22 weather stations island-wide was found to be from 0.6 Celsius degrees to 1.6 degrees below average, according to an official weather report.

The drop in temperature rarely occurs in Taiwan, due to the island's location off the east coast of Asia and in the path of warm ocean currents. Normally Taiwan has an oceanic and subtropical monsoon climate, said the report of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), issued in the Sunday-version of the local United Daily.

The report says since 1990, except for once in April of 1996, monthly temperatures have not fallen below average. Meteorologist Chen Kuei-hung of the CWB's weather forecasting department doubted the climate change is a result of the La Nina effect.

Since 1990, the seas around the island have been detected to be increasingly warming due to a global warming affect, Chen said. He noted, however, the global climate pattern has been disturbed since last July by El Nino's accompanying cold currents.

Chen said his department discovered the water around Taiwan began cooling in May. Temperature readings from seas on the eastern coast of Taiwan in May averaged 26 Celsius degrees, one degree below normal.
However, Chen would not forecast this summer will be cooler than past years. He said, the CWB foresees Taiwan's temperatures in both June and July to be the same temperature as past years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE MORE MEMBER OF CONGRESS PRAISES ROC KOSOVO PLEDGE

TEXT.P: US Rep. Shelley Berkley (D-NV) commended Friday the Republic of China (ROC) as "a member of the world community for their continued commitment to protecting and promoting human rights," and submitted the text of President Lee Teng-hui's June 7 pledge of a US$300 million aid package to help Kosovar refugees to the US Congressional Record for publication.

The congresswoman told the House of Representatives that the ROC aid package includes emergency supplies for Kosovar refugees and contributions to long-term reconstruction efforts by the international community in Kosovo now that a peace plan has been accepted. Moreover, she said, the ROC also offers to arrange for Kosovar refugees to receive short-term technical training in Taiwan.
President Lee's announcement was "both timely and insightful, fully demonstrating the ROC's concern for peace in the world," Rep. Berkley noted.
Twelve other members of both houses of the US Congress over the past two weeks have spoken highly of the ROC pledge to help the Kosovar refugees. (by Nelson Chung)
