DOC.HEADLINE: ROC JOINS WORLD SMALL BUSINESS COUNCIL
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 20 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan formally joined the International Council for Small Business (ICSB) on Sunday, becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.

The Taiwan delegation will be using its official designation, the "ICSB-ROC," in future ICSB-sponsored meetings and activities to share Taiwan's expertise and experience in the small business arena, said John Ni, director-general of Taiwan's Medium and Small Business Administration.
Ni is currently leading a 14-member Taiwan delegation to the ICSB's 44th annual conference, now being held in the central Italian city of Naples. The four-day conference opened Sunday.

Ni said the Republic of China's becoming a formal branch of the ICSB is of major significance to Taiwan's medium and small businesses. In the future, Taiwan will not only contribute to all ICSB activities, but also seek to play host to the ICSB's annual meeting in 2001, he noted.

During a meeting of ICSB board directors and supervisors on Sunday, the Australian executive board director proposed that Taiwan be permitted to join the group with the official designation of "ICSB-ROC." The proposal was passed overwhelmingly, according to Ni.
Although the ICSB has only 11 chapters so far, it has some 2,000 members from over 80 countries and areas around the world.
During this year's meeting, which is being attended by over 500 delegates, the ROC delegation will present three research papers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT HONG KONG LATER THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 21 (CNA) (By Belle Chou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will visit Hong Kong later this year to speak at a forum, a major Hong Kong newspaper reported on Monday.

Sing Tao Daily quoted sources as saying that when Paul Yip, special adviser to Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, visited Taiwan earlier this year, he and Ma agreed that private exchanges between Taipei and Hong Kong should be increased and suggested setting up a twin-city forum to promote economic and cultural exchanges between the two places.
The report said that Yip invited Ma to visit Hong Kong to speak at the forum, and Ma accepted the invitation gladly. The twin-city forum will probably be held in September or October.
Yip assured Ma that if he visits Hong Kong as a private citizen, there would be no visa problems.

Ma visited Hong Kong in early March this year. During his brief stay there, Ma attracted great media attention. Though his visit was private, the former chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council met with several prominent political leaders and inspected the infrastructure of the former British colony.

Ma, who was born in Hong Kong and moved to Taiwan at the age of 1, visited Hong Kong in early 1997 to trace his roots. He also tried to visit in June 1997 prior to Hong Kong's return to mainland Chinese rule, but he was denied a visa, even though he held no official position at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER DEPARTING FOR WEST AFRICA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee is departing Taipei Monday for West Africa to visit Burkina Faso and Sao Tome and Principe, according to sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Lee will lead a Republic of China delegation to attend a meeting of the Mixed Commission of Cooperation between the ROC and Burkina Faso slated for June 23-24 in the Burkina Faso capital of Ouagadougou.
Members of Lee's delegation include officials from MOFA, the China External Trade Development Council and the International Cooperation Development Fund.

During his stay in Burkina Faso, Lee will meet with President Blaise Compaore, Prime Minister Kadre Ouedraogo, Foreign Minister Youssouf Ouedraogo and other ranking officials of the West African country.
He will also meet with ROC agricultural and medical missions stationed there.

The ROC-Burkina Faso Mixed Commission of Cooperation was created in 1995 for promoting closer ties between the two countries, which resumed in February 1992 formal diplomatic relations that had been severed since 1973. President Compaore paid a state visit to the Republic of China in July 1992.
The Mixed Commission of Cooperation meeting is held alternately in the two countries every two years, with the first meeting being held in Ouagadougou in 1995.

After leaving Burkina Faso on June 25, Lee and his group will then proceed to Sao Tome and Principe to meet with Presdient Miguel Trovoada and other ranking officials to exchange views on bilateral cooperation. He will also meet with ROC agricultural and medical missions stationed in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 21, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1527: Niccolo Machiavelli, Italian political theorist, dies at the age of 58. His book "The Prince" describes the achievement and maintenance of power by a determined ruler indifferent to moral considerations.
1788: The US Constitution comes into force.
1791: An escape plan for Louis XVI of France and his family is foiled as members of the National Guard catch the fugitive king at Varennes and bring him back to Paris.
1852: Friedrich W.A. Froebel, German educator who established the first kindergarten in 1837 at Blankenburg, dies at the age of 70.
1900: Battles rage in both Peking and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: A suffragette demonstration in London attracts 20,000 supporters.
1908: Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov, Russian composer, dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in the Orkneys are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's Gen. Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk, on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He accepted on June 6 Gen. Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1970: Brazil carries off its third World Cup after a thrilling game in Mexico in which it beat Italy 4-1. Brazil's third triumph meant the Jules Rimet Trophy had found a permanent home.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1984: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1988: The Burmese government imposes a curfew as the regime totters in the face of student protests.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to the Chinese mainland on June 30.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FOREIGN MINISTER FAILS TO WIN RELEASE OF AID WORKERS

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has failed to secure the release of two Australian aid workers being detained in Yugoslavia, The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Monday.

In a dispatch from Zagreb, Croatia, the newspaper reported Downer was told in Belgrade last Saturday that the two Australian aid workers were spying for NATO, and that, therefore, they had to remain in jail.

CARE Australia, the largest relief organization in the county, told Australian media on Sunday that it would ask that any aid program involved in the rebuilding of Yugoslavia be linked to the release of its three imprisoned aid workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA COULD ALLOW FOREIGN STUDENTS TO WORK

TEXT.P: The Australian government is planning to change its migration rules by allowing foreign students to take up jobs as an incentive to lure full-fee-paying students from Asia and other regions, according to a leading population expert.

Bob Birrell, director of the Center for Population and Urban Research at Monash University in Melbourne, said in a report that the proposed changes to the way skilled migrants are selected could have a direct impact on graduates majoring in accounting, computing, engineering, law, nursing and public relations.
He said past experience in Australia, the United States and Canada indicated that most of these graduates from Third World countries will take up opportunities for permanent residence if they arise.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BUYS RUSSIAN SUKHOI-30 AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: Moscow has decided to sell 72 of its front-line Sukhoi-30 jet fighter-bombers to Beijing, which will certainly strengthen the mainland's air combat capacity and boost its ties with Russia.

According to a report appearing Monday in The Hong Kong Standard, following years of negotiations, Russian President Boris Yeltsin has given the green light to sell three squadrons of the state-of-art combat aircraft to the mainland.

The report quoted Russian-based diplomats as saying that Moscow and Beijing had agreed in principle to negotiations on the sale during mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's visit to Russia early this year.
It is understood that negotiations for Moscow to grant a license for the production of another 250 Sukhoi-30 fighters in mainland China have begun as well.
Last week a high-ranking military delegation, led by the vice chairman of the Central Military Commission, Zhang Wan-nian, visited the jet's manufacturer.
The multi-billion US-dollar sale will send a strong message to the international community that Beijing and Moscow are forging closer military ties, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BABY BOY SUFFERING FROM RARE DISEASE PASSES INITIAL CRUCIAL PERIOD

TEXT.P: A 1-year-old boy suffering from a rare hereditary disease has passed though an initial, crucial period, a doctor from National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) said Monday.

Dr. Lu Meng-yow, the NTUH pediatrician in charge of caring for the boy, said that the boy underwent a transplant involving umbilical cord blood on June 3 in an operation that was the first of its kind in Taiwan.

The boy has grown since the transplant, and on Monday he was allowed to leave an isolation room and enter the general ward for the first time. The boy, Lin Po-chih, suffers from Type II "mucopolysacchoridosis," also known as MPS.

With a stable white-blood-cell count of more than 10,000 and after having undergone a successful blood transplant -- more properly known as a "cord blood stem cell" procedure -- the boy is thought to have passed through the first, crucial period, Lu said.
Lu said that if Lin's condition continues to improve, he will be discharged from the hospital within one month.

Lin's mother said she was grateful to see that her son has become healthy and stronger, and that he has developed an appetite. She said she was sad, though, that the same procedure administered to Lin could not be administered to two older sons, who also suffer from MPS. They are considered too old to qualify for the procedure.

MPS is a hereditary genetic disorder caused by a lack of a special enzyme, or body protein. The particular enzyme deficient in someone with MPS is responsible for helping to break down "mucopolysacharide," a kind of sugar found in cells and tissues.
When sugar is not broken down properly, it accumulates in the body and can affect appearance, bodily functions, and both mental and physical development.

Depending on what parts of the body are affected by the sugar buildup, MPS can eventually result in death. The normal life expectancy for someone with the condition is 10 to 20 years, as there is no cure for the condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIKING CONTRAST SEEN IN PARLIAMENTS OF TAIWAN, CHINA

TEXT.P: There is a striking contrast in the parliaments of Greater China, with people in Taiwan able to enjoy the fun of the chamber while their brothers in both Hong Kong and mainland China do not have the same fun, according to The Australian Financial Review.

In a dispatch from Taipei, correspondent Rowan Callick reported the contrasts are stark. In Hong Kong, most members of parliament are selected by pro-Beijing bodies, so the legislature can always be counted on ultimately to back the administration.
In Beijing, the parliament meets annually in the Great Hall of the People, but the people are kept out by a ring of soldiers, the daily reported.
Callick reported that despite last week's fist fights in Taiwan's parliament, people in Taiwan are no longer fond of brawling in the parliamentary chamber.

He quoted an unnamed parliamentary clerk as saying that much of the infamous violence was originally intended to ensure that TV viewers took note of their new representative and the extent of his or her passion. "But today, TV viewers don't like to see that sort of thing, and the members have learned to control themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: MEW ZEALAND GIVES UP SEARCH FOR MAINLAND CHINESE BOAT PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The New Zealand Air Force has given up its search for a boat thought to be carrying 102 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, according to New Zealand Press Associates (NZPA).
The NZPA reported that a nine-hour search by the New Zealand Air Force on Saturday failed to find any sign of the Alexandra II, which was thought to be heading for New Zealand.
The NZPA on Sunday quoted a Defense Force spokesman as saying that Wing Commander John Seward said Saturday's search had been "comprehensive." The whereabouts of the suspected boat is not known now.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL STOCK PRICES REACH NEW HIGH FOR THE YEAR

TEXT.P: Strong buying in the plastic and chemical sectors provided the momentum to boost the Taiwan stock market 1.7 percent Monday as the local bourse reached its highest level of the year.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index soared 139.12 points to close at 8,413.48 points.
A total of 3.88 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$223.64 billion (US$6.91 billion), down from the previous session's NT$226.74 billion.
All eight major stock categories posted gains for the day, with plastic and chemical stocks leading the surge at 4 percent, paper and pulp issues followed which 3.6 percent gains.
Financial stocks advanced 2.6 percent, textile shares gained 2.1 percent, and cement issues went up 1.4 percent.
Foodstuff shares saw a gain of 1.1 percent, followed by electronics stocks, which increased 0.9 percent. The construction sector also posted a 0.5 percent rise.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market registered a slight gain of 1.33 points, ending the day at 179.16 points, with a turnover of NT$10.20 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July jumped 90 points to close at 8,439 points, with 3,935 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August also gained 90 points, closing at 8,440 points, while those for September climbed 89 points to 8,445. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 126 and 85, respectively.
December futures surged 99 points, ending the day at 8,419 points, with 11 contract transactions. No transactions were registered for next March.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 8,349 points for July, 8,350 points for August, 8,356 points for September, 8,320 points for December, and 8,405 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANHUA CATTLE MARKET CLOSES FOR 10 DAYS OVER FMD INFECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 21 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Tainan County Government on Monday ordered the closure of the decades-old cattle market in Shanhua for 10 days after the discovery of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) infection at two cattle ranches in the township.
The county government said in an administrative decree that all cloven-hoofed animals are subject to the trading ban on the Shanhua cattle mart from June 21 through June 30.

During the period, the county government said, vehicles and personnel are banned from entering the marketplace. Moreover, no ailing or deceased animals can be placed there, and no assemblies or social activities can be staged during the 10-day period.

Shanhua is now Tainan county's only animal trade mart. Nevertheless, cattle trade on the mart has declined steadily in recent years. Trade in non-cattle products and other activities have replaced cattle trade as major events seen on the Shanhua mart.
County government officials said those who violate the ban will be given a prison term of less than a year plus a fine ranging between NT$30,000 (US$923) and NT$150,000.

Meanwhile, the ROC Dairy Industry Association held an emergency meeting at the Liuying dairy industry zone in Tainan County Monday morning to discuss measures to prevent the FMD infection from spreading to Liuying from Shanhua.
The Liuying special zone accommodates a total of 82 ranches which raise more than 12,000 head of dairy cows. The Shanhua FMD outbreak has caused concern among dairy farmers in the Liuying area.

Wu Ming-hsuan, president of the ROC Dairy Industry Association, said the association will send a letter to the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) urging it to inoculate all dairy cows in Tainan County against FMD virus as soon as possible.

Wu said dairy farmers in the Liuying area are worrying about a further spread of the FMD infection because the county government's animal disease control department is giving top priority to inoculating cattle raised in ranches located within 6 kilometers around Shanhua.

Noting that locally produced beef and dairy products are mainly for domestic consumption, Wu said dairy cows have high economic value. "Each cow is worth more than NT$100,000 in market value," he said, adding that he hopes the COA will provide the Tainan County Government with additional FMD vaccines soon to help curb further spread of the epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose to a fourth-month high in the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, rising NT$0.03 against the greenback to close at 32.349.
The New Taiwan dollar has risen for ten consecutive sessions against the US dollar since June 7 for a total of NT$0.393, and a total of US$6.71 billion has changed hands.
The local currency opened at 32.347 and was traded between 32.333 and 32.385.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$633.50 million during Monday's session.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T, FAMILY RESPONSIBLE FOR STUDENT GANG-PARTICIPATION: MOE

TEXT.P: The government, schools and families should all play a role in stopping students from joining gangs, Education Minister Yang Chaur-shin said at the Legislative Yuan on Monday.

The newly-appointed minister was invited to speak on his educational policies by the Legislative Yuan's Education Committee. It was Yang's first report at the Legislative Yuan since he assumed office last week.

The recent funeral of a former gang leader in which nearly one hundred teenagers attended dressed in black or white was the main topic of Monday's legislative session. During the session, legislators wanted an explanation for the infiltration of gangs into local schools.

Yang replied that he is distressed over student participation in gangs. He said students should be receiving an education at school; instead, due to various factors, they are now unable to learn contendly at school.
Yang said the government, schools and families are all responsible for the growing influence of gangs.
He said that the Ministry of Education (MOF) has arranged "practical skills" classes for students unable to concentrate on their studies in a normal school environment.

But he also pointed out that practical skills classes alone cannot lead students back to school. A complete set of measures is required to allow young people to study contentedly once they return to school.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS WILL EMBARGO KAOHSIUNG LOTTERY TICKETS: FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City lottery tickets, if printed abroad and imported into Taiwan, will be seized as instruments of gambling, said a ranking official at the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Monday.
It was reported that the six million lottery tickets for use by Kaohsiung City, a metropolis in southern Taiwan, might be printed overseas and then imported into Taiwan.
Yen Ching-chang, a vice minister at the MOF, said that all tickets printed abroad will be detained by the customs as instruments of gambling according to the 45th article of the Tariff Statute.

Yen told the press at the Legislative Yuan that the proposed action is absolutely in accordance with the law. According to the current law, the issuance of lottery tickets must have the approval of the MOF; therefore, lottery tickets not approved by the MOF are deemed as instruments of gambling, the vice minister added.

Yen went a step further pointing out that according to the law, contraband items are not allowed to be imported; hence, MOF's accusation of gambling by the Kaohsiung City government under article 269 of the criminal law earlier this month was completely in accordance with the law.

As to whether MOF has already ordered customs authorities to seize the lottery tickets, Yen remarked that a seizure does not have to be ordered. Since the tickets are contraband items, customs authorities will carry out their duties and seize all illegal imports.
The ongoing skirmish over the Kaohsiung lottery represents the latest battle of a long-term turf war between the central and local governments for control of various aspects of administration.
It also seen as a political struggle between the island's two main parties in light of the fact that the mayorship of Kaohsiung is held by a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PREVENTION LAW TO BE IMPLEMENTED THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: Two short films were aired during a press conference on Monday to raise public awareness that domestic violence should no longer be endured in silence.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta, a women's rights advocate, attended the press conference co-sponsored by Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation and Taipei City Government's Bureau of Social Affairs
Both Ma and Hsieh wore a purple ribbon to symbolize their support of domestic violence victims and their determination to eradicate domestic violence.

Law enforcement and medical representatives at the press conference also wore purple ribbons to indicate support for human rights and their opposition to violence. The representatives vowed to establish a protective net for abused women.
The showing of the two films marked the start of a series of activities prior to the official implementation of the domestic violence prevention law on Thursday.

Ma, who narrated the film produced by the foundation, said that according to the domestic violence prevention law, the abuser will be required to keep a distance from the residence and working place of the victim, as well as be banned from communicating or meeting with the victim to safeguard their safety.

Ma said Taiwan's divorce rate is the highest in Asia, and domestic violence is part of the reason. He reiterated that domestic violence is no longer a matter within a family and the new law provides a just manner to punish abusers.
Participants also announced that two telephone numbers 080-024-995 and 2700-9595 can be used to report cases of domestic violence.

Statistics showed that in Taiwan, on the average 20 women daily suffer from domestic violence. Most of the cases involve physical abuse. From June 1998 to June 1999, 126 people died due to domestic violence.

An investigation into the causes of domestic violence showed that 38.3 percent of the abused blamed their spouses for having an inclination toward violence, while 32.1 percent attributed their case to poor communication with their spouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEAT TRADE CONTINUES IN TAINAN COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 21 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Tainan County Government on Monday decided not to suspend meat trade in the county, despite the discovery of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in three cattle ranches in Shanhua township.

Lee Kuo-tang, chief secretary of the county government, made the announcement after calling a meeting of relevant officials. Lee chaired the meeting on behalf of Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, who is now on an overseas trip.
The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has suggested that the county close its meat market for a short period of time to protect local hog ranches from being infected with the FMD virus.

Nevertheless, Lee said agricultural and animal disease control officials in the county thought that it's not necessary at least at the moment to ban meat trade in the local market because the FMD outbreak has been effectively controlled.

Wu Wu-chiou, director of the county government's agriculture department, said the "type O Kinmen" FMD virus that infected cattle raised in Shanhua area has not spread because of effective control measures taken by the county government. "The virus is not expected to affect pigs raised in our county."

Moreover, Wu said as Tainan County ranks third in Taiwan in terms of hog production, its hogs have been sold to other areas around the island. "It's meaningless to solely suspend pork trade in Tainan County," he noted.

Chen Ching-wen, head of the county's meat market management department, said all meat marts in the county have intensified sterilization and stepped up inspection of pig ranches in order to minimize the risks of a further spread of the disease.
Meanwhile, the COA has asked major FMD vaccine importers to import additional 400,000 doses to meet the demand.
The COA has also decided to subsidize the Kinmen and Tainan county governments in slaughtering all FMD-infected cattle or dairy cows.

Under current law, the county or city government must compensate farmers whose hogs or cattle are slaughtered to curb the spread of contagious diseases. Farmers can get full cash compensation for their healthy animals and three-fifths of the market value for ailing animals.

A total of 158 head of cattle raised in the offshore frontline island of Kinmen were already slaughtered last week and the number of dairy cows and cattle to be slaughtered in Tainan County over the FMD scare is estimated at 315.

The compensation for all these animals will reach several tens of millions of New Taiwan dollars. As both Tainan and Kinmen county governments have been troubled by cash shortage, the COA has agreed to offer up to 50 percent of the needed funds to help resolve the compensation issue. The current market price for a beef cattle ranges between NT$50,000 and NT$60,000, while that for a milk cow is about NT$100,000.
The spread of "type O Kinmen" FMD virus to Tainan has triggered a panic among cattle and hog ranch operators in the neighboring Kaohsiung county.
Kaohsiung county animal disease control officials have stepped up FMD tests on livestock, including dairy cows, milk goats and hogs, raised in the county.

Kaohsiung health officials have so far collected more than 260 serum samples of dairy cows and milk goats raised in Luchu, Tashe, Yenchao, Chiaotou and several other villages or townships neighboring Tainan County for FMD tests.
County officials have also urged hog farmers to stay high alert on possible FMD attack on their animals.
Kaohsiung County has 85 dairy goat ranches, which raise a total of 20,000 goats, and 42 milk cow farms, which raise 8,000 cows.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RESIDENT SENT TO "EDUCATION THROUGH LABOR CAMP" IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Zhou Yongjun, a permanent US resident and former student leader of the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement, is serving a three-year term in an education-through-labor camp in mainland China.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Monday that Zhou disappeared in late December after he tried to slip into mainland China from Hong Kong to see his parents, and that he recently sent a letter to his wife, saying that he was sick in the labor camp. But he did not say in the letter why and when he was sent to the camp.

Zhou, who was imprisoned for two years after the 1989 Tiananmen incident, fled to the United States through Hong Kong in 1993. He and his family were living in New York as permanent US residents before he was found missing in late December, the information center said.

The information center also said that several dissidents were rounded up by police in the eastern city of Hangzhou Saturday when they were talking at a tea house. Among them were two members of the outlawed "China Democracy Party", whose whereabouts are unknown.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING CALLED TO DISCUSS GOVERNMENT MARITIME POLICY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) will call a meeting on Tuesday to overhaul the government's maritime policy.

More than 120 scholars, experts, government officials, and opinion leaders are expected to take part in the two-day event, and conclusions reached in the meeting will be used as references for the RDEC to modify a draft of the ROC government's first-ever white paper on maritime policy.

The RDEC move comes one year after Premier Vincent Siew issued instructions at a national seminar on maritime policy that relevant government agencies should work out a comprehensive policy in an area considered especially important, given Taiwan's position as an island nation.

After a year of research, the RDEC has recently completed a preliminary draft of the ROC's first official white paper on maritime policy, focusing on marine environmental protection and development, national defense, and assistance in the event of maritime catastrophes.

However, the issue of whether the government should set up a specific agency in charge of maritime affairs remains undecided because it is a vast area currently covered by 15 government agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Finance, the National Science Council, and the Mainland Affairs Council.

RDEC Chairman Wei Chi-lin said that before any such maritime affairs agency is set up, it is vitally important that the 15 government agencies should continue to make concerted efforts to carry out their respective missions relating to maritime affairs.

Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan has already decided to establish a coastal patrol agency with an aim of cracking down on smuggling and illegal immigrants and protecting Taiwan fishermen, starting early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKFORCE AGAIN RANKED FIFTH BEST WORLDWIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workforce was rated the fifth best in the world for the fourth year in a row by a Swiss rating agency, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Monday.

Among the 49 countries assessed by the Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) in its annual "Labor Force Evaluation Measure", Taiwan ranks behind only Singapore, Switzerland, Belgium and Japan, said the MOEA.
The other two Asian states listed among the 49 states were South Korea, at the 13th spot, and mainland China, at the 40th position.

The BERI rated a country's workforce according to "legal framework", "relative productivity", "worker attitude" and "technical skills." These areas accounted for 30 percent, 30 percent, 25 percent and 15 percent respectively in the survey.
Taiwan's legal framework scored the third highest after Singapore and Belgium.

Relative productivity was based mainly on a country's productivity per day and daily working wage. In this category, Taiwan moved up four spots into sixth position, after Singapore, the United States, Belgium, France, and Switzerland.
In the worker attitude and technical skills categories, Taiwan ranked fourth and 11th, respectively, among the 49 states, said the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSCRIPTS TO BE DISCHARGED AHEAD OF SCHEDULE FROM 2000

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is working on a program under which conscripted men will be discharged from their mandatory military service one or two months ahead of the schedule.
Vice Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen made the statement Monday during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's interior affairs committee.
If all goes smoothly, Wu said, the program can be finalized by the end of this year and implemented from early next year.
To cope with the excess number of male adults available for conscription, Wu said, the MND has decided to allow some enlisted men to be discharged one or two months ahead of the schedule.
Nevertheless, Wu said, the ministry would not consider shortening military service at the moment.

"Wu must conduct a comprehensive review of military manpower demand before we mull whether to shorten the current two-year mandatory military service," Wu said, adding that the current law must also be revised to pave the way for shortening compulsory military service.
In view of the complexity involved in the military service reduction, Wu said the MND would not consider the proposal at the moment.
According to an MND estimate, about 20,000 conscripts can be discharged from the military ahead of the schedule in the initial stage.

Speaking on the same occasion, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said his ministry and the MND have jointly worked out a program for implementing an "alternative military service" system under which about 10,000 conscripts will be able to serve in non-military units to replace their compulsory military service.
Huang told lawmakers that the long-talked-about "alternative military service system" will be put into practice from July 1, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE PRESENTS REPORT ON NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) President Lee Teng-hui on Monday presented his views on the nation's foreign policy while presenting a five-point guide on national development to the National Assembly.

Lee described "facing reality" as the first principle for handling Taiwan's foreign relations. Under this principle the fact that two separate administrations exist on the mainland and Taiwan is recognized. The principle states that both sides should be treated as equal political entities.
The four other guiding principles are:

-- "Doing whatever the country should do," under which the ROC will strive for its own interests based on the consensus of its citizens, and will not impose self-restrictions due to oppression from mainland China;
-- "Parallelism," under which Taiwan will not challenge mainland China, but will jointly take part in international organizations and activities; and

-- "Unchanged stance," under which Taiwan will try to enlarge its international space, to create a favorable environment, and to attain reunification under the concepts of freedom, democracy and equitable wealth.
Lee said that the government will promote "all people's diplomacy" and "comprehensive diplomacy" by using the ROC's democratic accomplishments and economic power.

Lee's report to the National Assembly, the last one before the expiration of his tenure of office in May of next year, contained nine major themes: constitutional reform, government reorganization, improvement of defense power, stable economic development, strengthening of social security, development of education, culture, science and technology, utilization of natural resources, exploration of external affairs, and promotion of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

In spite of some natural disasters and company failures caused by the Asian financial crisis during the past one year, Lee said the situation has recovered due to the efforts of related government units.

He went on to say that US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's trips to Japan and the United States posed new tests for Taiwan, but the government has effectively responded to the developments.

Lee also took credit for the troubl-free elections last December of legislators and mayors in both Taipei and Kaohsiung, last October's mainland trip by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, and Taipei's US$300 million pledge to Kosovar refugees.
In general, he stated, the country's development in all fields during the past year has displayed a new face, producing confidence for the country as it marches into the 21st century.
On the development of cross-strait relations, Lee said that Koo's visit to the mainland last year revived the channel of systematic communications after a three-year suspension.
He said the forthcoming Taiwan visit by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will be helpful for cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU STOCKMEN URGED TO REMAIN ON ALERT FOR FMD

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tso-kwei on Monday urged Hsinchu animal disease prevention authorities to raise vaccination rates in local ranches to prevent any outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in this northern county.

Peng also called on owners of animal ranches to stay on high alert and vaccinate their herds, as the "0 Kinmen" type of FMD virus recently found in cows on three ranches in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan had been transmitted from the outlying island of Kinmen.
The COA head, however, stressed that the cases on Taiwan proper do not constitute an epidemic, as the infected Tainan cattle have all been slaughtered.
Peng made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Hsinchu County Disease Prevention Center.
Peng lamented the latest FMD outbreak, a little over two years since an FMD epidemic wiped out a large percentage of Taiwan's hog population.

Although Hsinchu animal disease prevention officials briefed Peng that the percentage of the county's pig population which has received "O type" Taiwan pig FMD vaccine has increased from 60 percent in May to 79 percent in June, Peng urged local stockmen to vaccinate their entire herds in order to help prevent a fresh epidemic on the island.
He pointed out that the COA has approved the distribution of more than 1.7 million vaccines for Hsinchu County alone.
He also expressed the hope that the establishment of a coastal patrol force early next year will help the Hsinchu authorities carry out their disease control mission more efficiently.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANK TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 21 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Union Commercial Bank has received approval from the Hong Kong authorities to set up a representative office in the former British colony, a bank official said on Monday.

Tai Huo-shan, general manager of Union Finance International (HK) Ltd., said his company was set up by Union Commercial Bank in 1997 as the bank's foothold in Hong Kong, mainly to provide loans for Taiwan businessmen there.
He added that he is hoping that the representative office can be set up within one month.

Tai pointed out that in the wake of the Asian financial crisis which began ravaging the region in mid-1997, Hong Kong banks have tightened their restrictions on corporate credit, providing an opportunity for Taiwan banks.
He said that after the representative office is upgraded to a branch, it will serve local customers and Taiwan businessmen doing businesses in Taiwan and mainland China.
To date, six Taiwan banks have now set up branches in Hong Kong, eight have set up representative offices, while four have set up finance companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL HOPING TO DISCUSS `PRAGMATIC MATTERS' WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: A Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) delegation will visit Beijing on Saturday to discuss matters relating to a visit to Taiwan later this year of Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, an SEF official said on Monday.

SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Hsu Hwei-yow said that the delegation, to be led by SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, are also prepared to discuss pragmatic matters such as fishery disputes and the repatriation of hijackers with their counterparts in the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

He stressed that the riot last week in a northern Taiwan detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants showed that the illegal mainland immigrants want to go home, and he urged Beijing to show more concern about their plight.

The detainees in Ilan County took two police officers hostage last Tuesday to vent their anger over their long period of detention and their fear of a disease in the center caused by malnutrition which led to three deaths and 13 hospitalizations. The two police officers were released unharned on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS OF TAIPEI MAYOR'S VISIT TO HONG KONG PREMATURE: AIDES

TEXT.P: Aides to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Monday that there are no plans as yet for the mayor to visit Hong Kong later this year.
The aides made the remarks after Hong Kong's Sing Tao Daily reported that Ma will visit Hong Kong in September or October to speak at a twin city forum.
Ma, who was born in Hong Kong and moved to Taiwan at the age of 1, last visited the former British territory in early March, attracting a great deal of media attention.

During that visit, Ma and Paul Yip, special adviser to Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, agreed that a twin city forum sponsored by private academic groups should be set up to promote economic and cultural exchanges between the two cities.

Taipei City government officials will travel to Hong Kong at the end of the month to discuss details of the forum such as the timing and agenda, but the aides pointed out that while Ma is scheduled to go to Europe in July to observe city development in Paris and Italy, a visit to Hong Kong is currently not in his schedule.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
NO OPINION POLLS TO BE PUBLISHED DURING PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) of the Republic of China passed a draft amendment on Monday stipulating that no opinion polls can be published during the 28 days of the official presidential election campaign period.

The draft amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law was made to prevent a flood of polls from swaying public opinion before the 2000 presidential election, the CEC said.

The amendment stipulates that no political parties, private citizens or corporations are allowed to publish opinion polls on candidates' popularity ratings or result predictions during the 28-day presidential campaign period and before the voting deadline.
The draft also stipulates that voters must have resided in their constituencies for a minimum of six months, up from the previous four months, to be eligible to vote for their area's candidate.

To clean up Taiwan's election environment, the draft amendment further stipulates that convicted gangsters, and those with criminal records relating to illegal drugs or firearms are not allowed to run for office within ten years of their pardon or the end of their sentence.

In addition to meting out even more stringent punishments for election bribery, a collateral punishment clause has been added to the draft amendment for political parties whose elected candidates have been charged with election bribery.
The draft amendments are slated to be included on the agenda of next week's Legislative Yuan session.

Meanwhile, CEC member Peng Huai-en (New Party) made a motion to expand the amount of the presidential election deposit, and the CEC settled on two alternatives to be put before the Ministry of the Interior: a set amount of NT$15 million, or one-thirtieth of the total campaign funds.

However, the CEC agreed in principle that the election deposit should not exceed the amount of the last election, for fear of critics slamming the staggeringly high election deposit restriction a "rich man's clause."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AID TO KOSOVO `CHANCE OF 1,000 YEARS': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday described the US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urged the public to have empathy, as well as a broader mindset.

Lee made the remarks at a National Assembly meeting during which he gave his last State of the Nation address, listened to the suggestions of the assembly deputies, and explained his decision earlier this month to pledge the aid to refugees from the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo. Lee's term expires in May next year.

On accusations from the public that the decision was too rash, Lee said that since the start of NATO airstrikes on Yugoslavia on March 24, the Kosovo refugee problem had worsened, to the concern of the ROC government.

He said the National Security Council had therefore asked the Ministry of the Interior and the agencies under the Executive Yuan to form a task force to study various assistance proposals over a two-month period.

Lee said that the amount of US$300 was decided at that time, and that as Premier Vincent Siew was visiting Central American and Caribbean countries at the time, it was decided on June 7 that he himself would make the announcement.
Lee said that since the ROC is determined to help the Kosovar refugees, a delayed announcement would have compromised the effect of such assistance.

Lee said that the task force studied various assistance proposals and took "several factors" into consideration. In view of Taiwan's limited land area, he said, allowing refugees to live here was unfeasible, especially since the number of refugees was increasing daily.

The president said that the ROC government therefore decided instead to provide vocational training for refugees who would come here only temporarily, so that they could start businesses upon return to their homelands.

Faced with criticism from certain quarters, Lee said only that it is normal for people in a democratic country to express their opinions, and added that in any case, the assistance offered by the ROC in the past has been less than that offered by some other countries. In addition, the aid plan will be spread over a three-year period, which he said will not place any extra burden on the nation's finances.
He stressed that to move forward, Taiwan needs to have the attitude of a big country, and that there would have been "no second chance" if his plan had not been announced immediately.

The president also urged the leaders of mainland China to identify with the ROC's approach, saying that both sides should "join hands to help others," because extending a hand to such countries will display the dignity of a nation with a broad "international mindset."
He further defended his aid plan by noting that the Vatican has praised it.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION DISAPPOINTED BY PRESIDENT'S STATE OF NATION ADDRESS

TEXT.P: The two opposition parties in the Republic of China's National Assembly on Monday expressed disappointment over President Lee Teng-hui's State of the Nation address, describing it as "overcautious."

Liu Yi-teh, whip of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Caucus in the National Assembly, said the report, the last of its kind before Lee's four-year term ends next May, was short on constitutional reform, and long on routine affairs of the government.
The DPP was especially frustrated by Lee's apparent satisfaction with the progress of the constitutional reforms, which Liu said is in complete contrast to the DPP's view.

Characterizing Lee's report as more like a premier's boring report to the Legislative Yuan on the day-to-day affairs of government than a president's farewell speech to the National Assembly, Chen Chin-teh, another DPP heavyweight in the National Assembly, said it focused too much on trivialities, and lacked vision for the country's future.

The other opposition party represented in the National Assembly, the New Party, shared the DPP's view, with its caucus whip Ching Chi-hua saying that the president's report neither reviewed the work of constitutional reform over the last 11 years, nor mapped a path for his successor.

The New Party Caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Cheng Lung-shui, said Lee has demeaned himself by presenting to the National Assembly a report which "dodges the real issues and has nothing new."

Branding it an exercise in bells-and-whistles about democracy which totally avoided addressing the problems of the dominance of gangsters and billionaires in the nation's politics and the deterioration of "financial discipline," Cheng said Lee's report should have emphasized the problems which arose during his presidency.
Although he presents his report to the National Assembly and is supposed to listen to suggestions made by its members, the president is under no legal obligation to act upon those suggestions.

DOC.HEADLINE: US INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN GREW SHARPLY IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relative stability during the Asian financial upheaval has made it a magnet for foreign capital, with investment from the United States surging by 128 percent in the first quarter of this year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Monday.

Compared with the corresponding period of last year, overall foreign investment in Taiwan has increased by 41.57 percent, with the lion's share, or 38.2 percent, going to the electronic and electrical appliance industries, said the MOEA.

Besides the United States, other foreign states have also funneled more capital into the island, with investment from The Netherlands up 51 percent, and Singapore investment showing a 31 percent increase.

The only state to buck the trend is Japan, which saw its investment in the island decline by 30 percent in dollar terms, despite a 22 percent growth in the number of projects with Japanese investment.

A survey conducted by the MOEA of Taiwan's principal foreign investors shows that they are generally satisfied with the island's business environment, with many of the foreign investors who also do business in Southeast Asia or South Korea saying that they consider Taiwan a more favorable place for investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES BEIJING TO RESOLVE PRACTICAL CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Monday urged Beijing to resolve pressing practical cross-Taiwan Strait issues through systematic negotiations.

The premier said the negotiations should be resumed as soon as possible so that practical issues such as the transmission of foot-and-mouth disease from the mainland to Taiwan through smuggled cattle, and the repatriation of hijackers and illegal immigrants, could be resolved.
Siew made the remarks in a speech delivered at a dinner party organized by Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) for over 100 Taiwan businessmen doing business in mainland China.
He expressed the hope that Beijing will resume systematic dialogue to resolve practical problems so that mutual trust and a mechanism for cross-strait peace and stability can be established.

Referring to a Beijing proposal that the two sides hold political talks to terminate hostilities, Siew stated that all issues relevant to democratic reunification can be raised at this autumn's meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties between the two sides.

Turning to the island's economic development, Siew declared that Taiwan has emerged safely from the Asian financial crisis, evident in the fact that this year's real economic growth rate has been revised upward to over 5 percent.

He told the participants that the government will speed up reforms in the political, economic and social fields, and added that the results of these reforms will serve as powerful support for people from Taiwan who conduct business on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 22, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, British explorer after whom Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates for the second and last time after his defeat at the battle of Waterloo.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, German bacteriologist and immunologist who won with Elie Metchnikov the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or the Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1936: Chen Chi-tang rebels in Canton.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The American powerful fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 times.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when General Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which General Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the USSR, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes with Soviet insignias, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1956: ROC Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter signs the "Taiwan Relations Act" into law in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over thirty thousand people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tienanmen Square protests in Beijing are shot after televised show trials.
1991: The Republic of China gains admission into the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservatives to conduct a party leadership election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter the public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a family, how is it right to ignore the duties a man owes to his sovereign and country."
