DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES REACH 14-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 2.3 percent Tuesday to their highest level in 14 months on heavy investment by foreign institutional investors and strong buying in the electronics sector.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index surged 195.43 points to close at 8,608.91 points, the highest level since April 24, 1998.
A total of 3.78 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$216.12 billion (US$6.68 billion), down from the previous session's NT$223.64 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics stocks posted the largest gain of the day, rising 3.9 percent. They were followed by plastics and chemical shares, which climbed 2.4 percent.
Textile issues gained 2.1 percent, construction shares advanced 0.8 percent, financial stocks rose 0.7 percent and foodstuff shares went up 0.1 percent.
Cement issues registered the only loss of the day, dropping 0.5 percent, while the paper and pulp sector remained static.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market saw a 1.75-point gain, ending the day at 180.91 points, with a turnover of NT$11.14 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July soared 260 points to close at 8,699 points, with 4,146 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August jumped 210 points, closing at 8,650, while those for September surged 255 points to close at 8,700 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 162 and 72, respectively.
December futures gained 210 points, ending the day at 8,630, with 6 contract transactions. Futures for next March increased 94 points to close at 8,589, with 1 contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 8,439 points for July, 8,440 points for August, 8,445 points for September, 8,420 points for December and 8,495 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MOST LIKES TO SEE SOONG ELECTED PRESIDENT: POLL

TEXT.P: A number of local people believe that communist China most likes to see former Taiwan Governor James Soong elected the Republic of China's next president, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The telephone poll of 1,070 adults, conducted by the ROC College Professors Association, found that 21.62 percent of the respondents believe that Soong is Beijing's favorite choice for the ROC's next presidency.
Slightly more than 16 percent said they think that mainland China prefers to see Vice President Lien Chan's capture of the ROC's top leadership post next year.
Only 3 percent of those interviewed said they believe Beijing would be happiest to see former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian become Taiwan's next president.

Survey results also show that 61 percent believe communist China would use every possible means and opportunity to influence the ROC's coming presidential election scheduled for March 2000, roughly three times the number of those who said they don't think so.

As high as 70 percent said they are convinced that relations across the Taiwan Strait will affect Taiwan's overall national security and development, and more than 50 percent said they believe the outcome of Taiwan's next presidential election will have a significant impact on the cross-strait relationship.
Meanwhile, 71 percent said they think that all presidential hopefuls are obligated to present a clear, comprehensive policy on relations with mainland China.

Asked which party's mainland policy will most benefit Taiwan people, about 30 percent chose the ruling Kuomintang; 6.45 percent opted for the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); 1.78 percent cited the pro-unification New Party; and 0.19 percent chose the Taiwan Independence Party. Nevertheless, nearly 40 percent said they do not know which party's mainland policy will benefit ROC nationals most.
Among the four possible presidential hopefuls, Lien wins most trust in formulating a mainland policy that can best serve Taiwan people's interests and rights, with 22 percent choosing him.

In comparison, 17.6 percent said they think that Soong, who is widely believed to break ranks with the KMT to run as an independent in next year's presidential election, is most capable of presenting an effective mainland policy to protect Taiwan's interests.

Chen, who will represent the main opposition DPP in the coming presidential election, came in third, with 13.8 percent recognizing his ability to present a mainland policy conducive to Taiwan's interests; while Hsu Hsin-liang, a former DPP chairman who renounced his DPP membership in May to run for the presidency on his own, won the trust of a mere 2.34 percent of the respondents in this regard.

Asked who will be most capable of handling cross-strait issues, 22.14 percent throw their support behind Lien; 20.46 percent opt for Soong; 13.64 percent choose Chen; and only 1.87 percent support Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EXPORT ORDERS EXPECTED TO GROW 4 PERCENT IN 1999: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders in 1999 are expected to register growth of 4 percent, according to an estimate made by the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Figures released by the Statistics Department on Tuesday revealed that a total of US$10.36 billion worth of export orders were received by manufacturers in Taiwan in May, up 3.14 percent from the same period last year. The growth was attributed to stronger competitiveness in sectors such as electronics and telecommunications.
Year-to-May export orders totaled US$49.94 billion, an increase of US$1.61 billion, or 3.34 percent, over the same 1998 period.

Among manufacturers polled by the department, 42.46 percent said they expected June's export performance to be similar to May's, while 26.46 percent said they expected an improvement and 31.08 percent said they expected a decline.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANIMAL HEALTH OFFICIAL WARNS RECENT FMD OUTBREAK A THREAT TO PIGS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Research Institute for Animal Health (TRIAH) warned on Tuesday that the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreak that recently hit the offshore island of Kinmen and southern Tainan County could pose an even greater risk to hogs than to cattle or goats.

The institute conducted a test last week to determine whether Taiwan's pig population would be susceptible to the "type O Kinmen" FMD strain that recently hit in Tainan County, said TRIAH Director Lin Shih-yu. All seven pigs exposed to the virus became infected, which means Taiwan's pig population is at risk, he said.

Noting that the Tainan County Government has decided against closing its meat market, Lin said he worries that the decision may result in FMD spreading from cattle to hogs, noting that pigs at meat markets are often kept in the same pens as cattle.

The FMD outbreak, which was first spotted at three ranches on offshore Kinmen Island, has resulted in the slaughter of 158 head of cattle on the island, while it is expected that more than 300 cattle in Tainan County will be slaughtered as a result of the outbreak.

Lin said TRIAH, the only institute in Taiwan that is capable of conducting FMD tests, is closely monitoring the situation, adding that it will soon complete tests on serum samples sent by 63 ranches from seven cities and counties.

Tainan County Government and meat market officials met Tuesday again to discuss the situation amid a warning by the Council of Agriculture (COA) that the Tainan County Government and meat market officials should be held responsible for the further spread of the disease since they are against closing the market.

Lee Kuo-tang, chief secretary of the county government, said that if the COA wants it to close the market for a short period, it should specify which days it wants the market closed. Lee said another problem is the business losses that meat market shop owners would face, adding that the market was already closed for three days because of the long weekend last week.
Lee said pigs raised in Tainan County have been sent to meat markets all over the island, adding that it is pointless to ask Tainan County to suspend pork trading alone.
COA officials went to Tainan County Tuesday afternoon to discuss the matter with local officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION RECEIVED BY MALAWI PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, June 21 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation led by Control Yuan President Frederick Chien was received by Malawian President-elect Bakili Muluzi on Sunday in the southern city of Blantyre.

Chien, head of the seven-member delegation, arrived in Malawi over the weekend to attend the Monday inauguration of Muluzi, the incumbent Malawian president who scored a sound victory in the country's June 15 presidential election.
Muluzi thanked Chien for traveling so far from home, and expressed his hope that bilateral ties between the two countries will be further strengthened.
Currently, two-way cooperative ventures are being carried out smoothly, and both the Malawian government and its people greatly appreciate the assistance the ROC has extended, he added.

Turning to his successful re-election bid, Muluzi said he believes that he will be able to continue promoting democracy, improving the people's lives, and facing up to new challenges during his next five-year term.

For his part, Chien conveyed President Lee Teng-hui's congratulations to Muluzi, and pointed out that Malawi has made noticeable progress, particularly in the fields of education and medical care, since Muluzi assumed the presidency in 1994.

At the same time, construction of a hospital funded by the ROC is scheduled to be completed by the end of this year, while an ROC medical assistance mission will be stationed soon in Malawi to help run the hospital, he said.
On Sunday night, Vice Malawian President Justin C. Malewezi held a banquet in honor of Chien and other ROC delegates. More than 20 ranking Malawian government officials were present.
Douglas Hsu, Malawi's honorary consul in Taipei and chairman of the Far Eastern Group, offered a briefing during the banquet on recent ROC developments.

The ROC has been affected less than other countries by the Asian financial crisis, and it sits on one of the world's largest foreign exchange reserves, he said, adding that Taiwan's flexible small business sector is the major reason the country has been able to ride out the storm so well.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT STAGE OF DEMOCRATIC REFORMS HINGE ON DPP: CHEN SHUI-BIAN

TEXT.P: Presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday that the next stage of democratic reforms in Taiwan must be conducted by the DPP.
In an interview with a local radio station, Chen also said that there was nothing new in President Lee Teng-hui's last report on the state of the nation to the National Assembly Monday.

Chen said that Lee has contributed to Taiwan's democratic reforms, adding that he has laid the groundwork. But one cannot expect Lee or his heir apparent to continue such reforms, and only another party can be expected to continue the mission, he said.
He also criticized the US$300 million aid package for Kosovar refugees announced recently by Lee, saying that the president did not clearly specify where the money would come from.

Chen also questioned whether the aid might be an attempt to solidify relations with Macedonia, the newest ally of the ROC. He also questioned whether the aid was based on humanitarian or strategic concerns.

Chen repeated the DPP's vow to either abolish the National Assembly or merge the legislature and National Assembly into a unicameral parliament. He noted that there are 535 congressmen and senators in the United States, which has a population of 260 million, while there are 559 legislators and National Assembly deputies in Taiwan, which has a population of 21 million.
Next year's presidential election will result in a resurgence of political party rivalry, he said, adding that people running as independents have no chance of winning.
Chen said he does not rule out the possibility of Vice President Lien Chan forming a ticket with former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong.

Soong's current popularity would drop as a result of his running with Lien, though, he said, adding that by running with the current vice president, Soong's image as a reformer could be seriously compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR INVESTMENT PROJECTS EXPECTED TO HIT RECORD HIGH IN 1999

TEXT.P: If the location of Taiwan's eighth naphtha cracking plant is determined by the end of this year, the total amount of investment in major projects around the nation should exceed last year's record of NT$470 billion, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Tuesday.
Major investment projects are defined as those over NT$200 million.
A total of NT$250 billion was poured into major investment projects from 1995 to 1997. In 1998, NT$470 billion was invested, sources said.
Since January through May of this year, investment capital has totaled NT$170 billion, a decline of 29 percent compared to the same period last year.

However, besides the naphtha cracking plant, another 15 projects worth approximately NT$100 billion, are slated to begin construction in the fall. When the naphtha cracking plant finally begins construction, total investment in major projects in Taiwan should hit a record high.
The location for the eighth naphtha cracking plant is still under evaluation, with southern Taiwan's Pingtung the most likely choice. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GDP EXPECTED TO BE REVISED UPWARD: MOEA

TEXT.P: The gross domestic product (GDP) of the Republic of China is expected to be revised upward, said the head of the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Tuesday.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department, pointed out that in light of a much brighter showing by Taiwan's industrial product index than previously anticipated, Taiwan's GDP is expected to be adjusted upward.
Taiwan's total industrial value increased 10.76 percent in May over the same period last year, the first double-digit growth since last year, noted Chang.
The growth was attributed to a robust performance by various sectors, including manufacturing, which grew 12.03 percent, and housing construction, which was up 7.14 percent.

The electric and electronics sector grew 24.28 percent as a result of the Y2K effect, said the director-general, adding that the 17.54-percent growth registered in the petrochemicals industry was mainly due to the sixth naphtha cracker plant of Formosa Plastics Corp. entering production.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC TECHNOLOGY CONFERENCE OPENS

TEXT.P: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference sponsored by Merrill Lynch Taiwan Limited opened on Tuesday, with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
The three-day conference, which is being held in the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel, is the first of its kind in Taiwan. The first conference took place in Hong Kong a year and a half ago.
Fifty representatives from leading regional information and electronics companies have been invited to deliver addresses on the industry's overall development.

Tuesday's conference was presided over by Adam Quintom, president of Merrill Lynch's Asia-Pacific regional research, and was attended by representatives of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., D-Link, Winbond Electronics, Delta Electronics and other companies.

During the conference, an official from Fidelity Investment's Hong Kong branch said foreign capital is usually concentrated in areas that are globally competitive, adding that the electronics industry and Taiwan Petrochemicals giant Formosa Plastics Corp. are seen as particularly attractive.
Local institutional buyers attending the conference said this kind of gathering will help foreign investors to better understand Taiwan-listed companies.
After the conference, attendees are expected to visit local companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAN BECOME TAIWAN'S RULING PARTY IN NEAR FUTURE: ING

TEXT.P: Nita Ing, chairwoman of Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC), said on Tuesday she believes that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be able to win the mandate to rule Taiwan in the near future.
The outspoken business executive made the statement during a seminar with a group of DPP party workers and public office holders.
Ing said she has consistently held a special affection for the DPP because she has grown up with the DPP since she returned to Taiwan 22 years ago.

"History will record the DPP's brilliant contributions to Taiwan's democratization, liberalization, openness and progress over the past decade," Ing said, adding that she knows many people in all walks of life support the DPP in private and expect the party to work out a comprehensive national development plan to pave the way for its capture of the ruling power.

Ing said she feels that Taiwan is still overshadowed by authoritarian rule. "My observation is that there are still many legal restrictions obstructing our national development and that collaboration of ruling party officials and government administrators has adversely affected Taiwan's overall development," she added.

Noting that the government controlled many key industries in the past, Ing said such practice has left many drawbacks, including kickbacks, irregularities in bidding for public construction projects and mixed use of government and party resources.

To further promote Taiwan's democratic development, Ing said Taiwan must endeavor to establish a sound civil service system and devote even more energy to teaching the younger generation the tenets of true democracy.

Ing went on to say that the ruling Kuomintang's behind-the-scenes maneuvering, particularly some actions taken by KMT chief financier Liu Tai-ying, has affected the THSRC's fund-raising for the high-speed railway project.

Stressing that Taiwan's high-speed railway is now the world's largest BOT (build-operate-transfer) project, Ing said the THSRC is most concerned about price and technological know-how in selecting its electric engineering system, either a German-French hybrid system or a Japanese system.

Ing further said the THSRC, a private industrial consortium which won the US$13 billion contract to build the island's first high-speed rail system last year, will do its utmost to make the new railway meet the public demand and expectations.
According to the contract signed by the THSRC and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), the 345-kilometer high-speed railway must be completed by 2003.
Nevertheless, Ing said the premise for that deadline is that construction on the new railway got started in 1997. "Completion in 2003 is just a goal," she noted.
The THSRC already began construction on the high-speed railway's southern Taiwan depot and several other minor construction work, but many core tasks have yet to get underway.

Ing said she hopes the government will resolve several controversial issues, including that the proposed construction of a depot in Hsichi, Taipei County, would violate the existing hillside conservation law and that the new railway would divide the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park now under construction into two parts.

According to a THSRC-MOTC agreement, the MOTC must resolve the six remaining technical issues, including the above-mentioned two, before the end of June to enable the THSRC to start its civil construction in the second half of this year.

Ing said she hopes the government will honor its promise to fulfill its duties in time. As for fund-raising, Ing said she is confident that the THSRC will be able to raise enough funds for the project.
Noting that the high-speed railway is Taiwan's first BOT project, Ing said it requires concerted efforts from the government, the THSRC and bank consortium to ensure its success.
Under the BOT formula, private companies will carry out the construction and operate the public service system for a set period of time, after which the system will be turned over to the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SCORE MAJOR POINTS IN LARGE-SCALE GANG BUST

TEXT.P: Taiwan police scored major points Tuesday in an islandwide gang bust, arresting nine suspected gang members thought to have infiltrated Taipei schools, including some of the city's most prestigious high schools.

Amid a recently increased gang presence in area schools, the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior ordered a nationwide bust, targeting gangs suspected of infiltrating schools and teen-age gangs.
The operation began at daybreak, and by 10 a.m. police had arrested nine suspects, including four suspected leaders of northern Taiwan's largest teen gang, the "Eastern Union."

Police said that gang has been the most active in trying to establish itself in city schools, adding that the gang has even set up a special branch to recruit students from Taipei City's most prestigious high schools.
The gang has 500 members, of whom 300 are students, according to police statistics. Student members range from the junior-high-school to the university level.
An initial police investigation revealed that over 30 junior- and senior-high schools and universities have been infiltrated by the Eastern Union, including nearly 10 prestigious institutions.

In addition, police discovered that many of the student gang members belong to prominent families in Taiwan's political and financial circles, and some are the children of high-ranking police and judicial officials.

An NPA spokesman announced that police are confident they can completely wipe out the gangs' presence from city schools. He also urged parents to pay more attention to their children, and urged schools to cooperate with police in resisting school-infiltration attempts by gangs.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASTE DISPOSAL AMENDMENTS FORM LEGAL BASIS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL POLICE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China legislature Tuesday passed several amendments to the Solid Waste Disposal Act that serve as the legal basis for an environmental protection agency police force that will go into effect July 1.

To establish a legal basis for the environmental police to conduct solid waste inspections and issue penalties by July 1, the Legislative Yuan raced to pass amendment drafts to the Solid Waste Disposal Act during the final session of the current legislature on Tuesday.

The amendments stipulate that environmental investigative officials will have the right to inspect any area where they suspect waste is being illegally disposed of, provided they have proper identification. They may also demand relevant documents from manufacturers suspected of illegal waste disposal.

If necessary, investigators can confiscate machinery and equipment that produce serious pollution, as well as place limits of the use of property and real estate, and cut off a building's supply of water and electricity.

In addition, the amendments call for even more stringent penalties for illegal solid waste disposal. Those who dump hazardous waste that results in a loss of life may be sentenced to life imprisonment.
The amendments also stipulate that if waste disposal agencies violate the law, the companies whose waste they have disposed of must shoulder collateral penalties as well.

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Tsai Hsung-hsiung encouraged the public to actively inform authorities of illegal waste disposals to help protect the environment. He also warned manufacturers not to take chances with improper waste disposal.

The EPA also announced on Tuesday that two illegal dumping sites in southern Taiwan contain cancer-causing agents. One site is in Chiayi's Hsinkang township, while the other is under an old iron bridge near the Kaoping River.

DOC.HEADLINE: TERRACOTTA SOLDIERS FROM IMPERIAL CHINA TO BE SHOWN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A large-scale exhibition of the fabulous ancient terracotta soldiers from mainland China is expected to be held at the National Museum of History (NMH) in Taipei next year, the United Evening News reported on Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the paper said that the Museum of History in Xian in northwestern China has tentatively agreed to lend the treasures to the Taipei museum for public display as part of its efforts to promote cultural and academic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

According to the paper, the loan promise was made during a visit to the Xian museum on Monday by a delegation of officials from various Taiwan cultural institutions headed by NMH Director Huang Kung-nan.

The vast army of terracotta soldiers were first unearthed in the early 1970s from the Chin Dynasty (221-207 B.C.) burial site of China's first imperial emperor, Chin Shih Huang, who commissioned the sculptures to guard his final resting place.

Huang said Taiwan has previously requested to exhibit the soldiers, but the Xian museum turned down all the earlier requests apart from loaning just a few of the sculptures for a Taipei exhibition in December 1992. This time, he said, the museum agreed to the proposal for a much larger undertaking. According to Huang, mainland China's Ministry of Cultural Affairs and the State Council are also expected to approve the proposal.
The evening paper said the Xian museum may also agree to lend some newly unearthed colored terracotta soldiers to the Taiwan museum.

The Taiwan delegation visited major museums, libraries and related cultural institutions in Nanjing, Shanghai, Xian and Beijing during its 11-day tour, and managed to reach several agreements with mainland Chinese cultural institutions, including an NMH exhibition beginning on July 2 of ancient paintings and calligraphic works belonging to the Nanjing Museum of History.

The delegation was composed of senior executives of the NMH, the provincial library in Taichung, the Changhua Cultural Center and the Keelung Cultural Center, as well as officials from the Council of Cultural Affairs, the Ministry of Education, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 WOULD-BE ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS DETAINED AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Seven mainland Chinese nationals who intended to make way into the United States with forged travel papers were intercepted at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-Shek International Airport late Monday night.
The Airport Police Bureau announced the breaking of the case on Tuesday.

Airport police said the seven mainland people, headed by a Hong Kong man who held a forged Republic of China passport, arrived at CKS Airport from Hong Kong via EVA Air flight No. 858 on Monday night.

They were intercepted by police during a transit stay at the airport. Their final destination was Los Angeles. After questioning, airport police repatriated the seven mainland nationals to Hong Kong where they started their journey.
Airport police said they checked the mainlanders' travel documents at the request of American authorities.

US immigration officers said they have found that an increasing number of illegal mainland immigrants have made way into the United States via Taiwan. They asked Taiwan to help intercept would-be illegal mainland immigrants.

Airport police said they have since intensified checks of suspicious transit visitors' travel papers. In the past, mainland Chinese human smuggling rings sent mainland people to the United States from Bangkok via CKS Airport. Due to tight Thai airport police monitoring, mainland rings have recently changed their route, with Hong Kong as the starting point. to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUST. OBSERVER SEES MILITARY BACKING MEGAWATI

TEXT.P: Indonesia's military led by Defense Minister General Wiranto is likely to support Megawati Sukarnoputri to become president later this year, a leading Australian observer of the June 7 elections predicted.

In his article published by the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, Kevin Rudd, a federal member of Parliament from the Labor Party, and one of the Australian Parliamentary Observers' Team during the Indonesian elections, predicted Megawati's party PDI-P will win between 210 and 220 seats of the 462 available seats in the House of Representatives or DPR.

He projected the ruling Golkar and its Islamic allies will end up with between 200 and 210 seats from the elections. The remaining 30-40 seats will go to the Islamic Modernist Party -- PAN -- led by Amien Rais, together with the 38 seats still appointed by the military, Rudd said.
He gave his reasons why the ABRI or Indonesian armed forces would support Megawati instead of other presidential alternatives, including B.J. Habibie.
First, the army has real concerns about Golkar's abandonment of the religious pluralism of the Pancasila period and its all too rapid embrace of Islam as a sort of formal state orthodoxy, he said.

Second, the army genuinely fears the political reaction of urban Java, particularly the prospect of violence on the streets if Golkar just manages a victory -- having to rely in the end on the army's seats in the MPR or the People's Consultative Assembly for the win.
"Siding with Mega, from General Wiranto's perspective, may be the lesser of the two evils," he added.
He believed the three greatest problems -- corruption, collusion and nepotism -- would be more tackled under Megawati than under other political alternatives.
"Megawati is only likely to become president with ABRI's support. This will affect the pace and depth of any program fully to civilianize the role of the Indonesian military," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: A THIRD OF NEW ZEALANDERS WANT TO BECOME PART OF AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: One in three people in New Zealand want to become part of Australia and Kiwis are acting more like Australians, according to a new study by the CM Research/Porter Novelli.
In a dispatch from Auckland, the Australian on Tuesday reported that the finding was shocking but true because it paints a portrait of modern Kiwis as an optimistic bunch of practical doers.

The study shows Kiwis are becoming more laid-back, friendly, practical and less class conscious. It also finds New Zealanders see themselves as a "very masculine" culture that doesn't rate itself as either highly sophisticated or academic.

The study shows 40 percent of New Zealanders own a chainsaw and have milked a cow. Yet only one in five has shorn a sheep. More than half want New Zealand to become a republic and although 36 percent think it would be a good idea to join Australia, they don't want to admit it, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND'S ECONOMY RECOVERING STEADILY

TEXT.P: New Zealand's 0.9 percent growth in the first quarter of this year puts the country on track for a annual economic growth rate of 1.4 percent, according to a report by the Macquarie Bank in Sydney.

The report shows the country's economy is improving due to stronger household demand. Consumer confidence is at the highest level in two years as households benefit from increasing employment and low interest rates.
While exports remain weak, New Zealand's services were buoyed by a 22 percent jump in travel exports in the first three months of this year, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING EXTENDS GRIP ON ACTIVISTS, SAYS REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing's security alert against dissidents and "anti-government elements" will be enforced at least until the Oct. 1 National Day celebrations have completed, the South China Morning Post reported today.
The report quoted a security source as saying that while Beijing was relieved that relative quiet surrounded June 4, it feared underground elements might redouble efforts to make mischief later on.
The source reportedly said scores of dissidents detained in the past two months had not been released and some might soon face prison terms.
A Western diplomat was quoted as saying that the Communist Party's Central Committee had set up a group to review preparations for the Oct. 1 festivities, which include a huge military parade.
"The group reports directly to President Jiang Zemin," the source said.
According to the report, the same tough tactics will be applied to the growing numbers of affiliates of underground churches and sects currently under surveillance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM JOHN HOWARD ACCUSED OF IGNORING APEC

TEXT.P: The regional trade organization -- Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) -- has "fallen into a hole" during the stewardship of Prime Minister John Howard and requires an urgent injection of policy substance and political horsepower to revive its previous strength.

In presenting his policy paper, Opposition Shadow Minister Peter Cook said that APEC's focus on sectoral liberalization in recent years had been a mistake with little progress on issues of interest to Australia, including agriculture, according to the Australian Financial Review.
He said that despite its controversial nature, APEC could not afford to ignore the debate over the linkage between labor standards and trade agreements.
Cook was quoted by the daily as saying that these issues would not be solved by "shunting them off to one side," but only by dealing with them in a sensible and constructive framework."

DOC.HEADLINE: MINING EXPLORATION SPENDING PLUNGES IN AUST.

TEXT.P: Mining exploration spending plunged 17 percent to only A$193 (US$129) million in the first three months of this year from a year ago due mainly to the falling commodity prices worldwide, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show that exploration spending was 40 percent lower than two years ago. The plunge of commodity prices was led by gold, diamonds, uranium and iron ore.

"Companies have to cut expenditure where they can and one area of discretionary spending is exploration. But in the long term, they need to explore to survive. (The actions) are understandable but if it continues for much longer, it will harm the viability of the industry," said Dick Wells, chief executive of the Minerals Council of Australia.

ABS officials attribute the falling spending to the drop in demand for Australian commodities from Asia due to the financial crisis since the middle of 1997. They said the long-term outlook remains optimistic because of the current recovery in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE PAPER STRESSES ROC SOVEREIGNTY OVER DISPUTED ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) released on Tuesday a draft of the Republic of China's first white paper on maritime policy.

The white paper, which stresses the ROC's jurisdiction over the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, also points out that the ROC is willing to jointly develop the region's natural resources with neighboring countries based on a peaceful and rational framework, and will seek a solution through diplomatic channels to determine the jurisdiction of the overlapping areas of the territory.
The RDEC also emphasized that the Tiaoyutai Islands, which lie to the northeast of Taiwan, are also ROC territory, and detailed historical links between the ROC and the islands to prove its case.

The major purpose of the white paper, RDEC Chairman Wei Chi-lin said, is to remind ROC nationals of their forgotten territory, and to set a course for the country's maritime policy in light of Taiwan's strategic position in the Asia-Pacific region.

Meanwhile on Tuesday, the RDEC also called a meeting of more than 120 scholars, experts, government officials, and opinion leaders to discuss the draft's contents. Conclusions reached at the two-day event will be referred to the Executive Yuan for use as guidelines in setting the final content of the white paper in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AMONG 12 NATIONS ALLEGEDLY DUMPING STEEL PRODUCTS IN US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: US Commerce Secretary William Daley said on Monday that the US government has begun an investigation into alleged dumping of iron and steel products by 12 nations, including mainland China and Taiwan.
Daley made the statement on the eve of a US Senate vote on an act filed by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV (D-W.Va.) to set quotas for imported iron and steel products.

Since last September, the US iron and steel industry has spent at least US$10 million on lobbying in Washington, D.C. to urge lawmakers to pass a bill to restrict the import of foreign iron and steel.
The US House of Representatives adopted the bill to this effect on March 17.
The US Senate was scheduled to vote on Tuesday on a similar act filed by Rockefeller, and the Clinton administration has expressed concern about the outcome of the vote.

Daley reiterated in a news conference held at the Congress that the passing of the bill would have a harmful effect on the US economy. The unilateral setting of import quotas also violates the norms of the World Trade Organization and would probably ignite a trade retaliation war between the US and its trade partners, said Daley.
The US Iron and Steel Union was scheduled to stage a mass demonstration at Capitol Hill on Tuesday to pressure Congress to pass Senate Bill No. 395, filed by Rockefeller.

Senator Arlen Specter (R-Pa.), the co-signatory of the Rockefeller act, said it is very possible that the act will pass the Senate vote. However, he added, whether the act will win a two-thirds majority vote that President Clinton cannot veto is still uncertain.
The Clinton administration has previously hinted that the president will use his veto right if both the Senate and the House of Representatives pass the bill.

The main purpose of the bill, which would remain in effect for three years, is to ensure that the volume of US imported iron and steel returns to the average monthly import level of three years before the Asian financial crisis which began in July 1997.
In order to achieve the goal, Clinton will have take measures such as unilaterally setting import quotas, raising import tariffs, and negotiating on bilateral import quotas.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA WELCOMES TAINAN COUNTY'S DECISION TO SUSPEND MEAT MARKET

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) welcomed a decision by the Tainan County Government on Tuesday afternoon to suspend cattle and meat markets in the southern Taiwan county in an effort to prevent any further spread of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level COA, expressed relief upon learning of the decision, describing it as wise, although difficult for cattle raisers, slaughterhouses and meat dealers, at a time that eradication of FMD is more important than financial gain.

Tainan County government officials and representatives of the Tainan County Meat Dealers Association reached consensus on a suspension of the regional meat market for 10 days from Wednesday until June 29.
The COA suggested last Saturday that Tainan County temporarily suspend meat trading after an FMD alarm was raised upon the confirmation of FMD infection among cattle on four ranches in the county.

However, it took county officials and meat traders the subsequent four days to agree with the suggestion, with officials saying a trade closure will not help arrest the FMD virus, and meat traders saying the market suspension will only benefit unlicensed or black-market butchers and meat traders.

Quarantine officials began to monitor 58 cattle ranches in seven southern counties and cities after FMD was reported on a ranch in Shanhua, Tainan County last week. As of Tuesday, no FMD antibodies had been found in cattle on the surveyed ranches except for the four in Tainan County.

FMD, a contagious disease that plagues cloven-hoofed animals, ravaged Taiwan's hog population in 1997, crippling the country's hog farming industry, the staple source of meat in Taiwan and a major foreign exchange earner. The outbreak resulted in the slaughter of more than 4 million pigs and a ban on exports of pork products.

DOC.HEADLINE: INNER MONGOLIAN PUBLISHERS HOLD BOOK EXHIBITION IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first book exhibition in Taiwan by Inner Mongolian publishing companies opened at the National Central Library in Taipei on Tuesday.
On exhibit are about 300 types of book from seven publishing companies, with their contents ranging from Mongolian folklore, customs, and history, to science and literature.
The exhibition was organized by Wu Kuei-yu, president of the Republic of China Book Publishers Association, to promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Inner Mongolia.

A symposium was held on Tuesday afternoon for local and Inner Mongolian publishers to exchange views on bilateral cooperation, the selection of book themes, as well as how to respond to the influx into Taiwan of Japanese publications.
According to the visiting exhibitors, Inner Mongolia now has seven publishing companies and 149 magazines, with about 2,000 new books published annually.
Last year, a delegation of representatives of Taiwan's book companies visited Inner Mongolia and concluded deals for copyrights on 14 books.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK DIPS TO FOUR-MONTH LOW ON TAIWAN FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped by NT$0.001 on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday to a four-month low of NT$32.348.

In line with its weakening position against major Asian currencies, the greenback maintained its declining trend in the last few trading sessions in Taiwan, opening at NT$32.345 on Tuesday, and being traded between NT$32.329 and NT$32.36.
The US dollar has lost NT$0.0394 in the last eleven business days.
A total of US$516 million changed hands during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES TO PROTEST MALAYSIAN STRUCTURES ON SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Philippine defense department has recommended the filing of a diplomatic protest against Malaysia after confirming the existence of Malaysian-built structures in the disputed Spratly Islands.

Defense Secretary Orlando Mercado said the structures are 253 nautical miles from the Philippine island of Palawan and within Malaysia's 200 mile exclusive economic zone, but also inside an area claimed by the Philippines.
The Philippines had earlier protested a mainland Chinese military build-up on Mischief Reef, which is also within the Spratly Island group.
Aside from mainland China, Malaysia and the Philippines, the Spratlys are also partly or wholly claimed by Taiwan, Brunei and Vietnam.

In a report to President Joseph Estrada, the Western Command of the Armed Forces said the structures are a 20 by 50 meter rectangular platform with a helipad, a two-story rectangular building, and a radar tower.
Several barges with cranes and construction materials and navy vessels without flags have also been sighted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB SUPPORTS APEC RECOVERY INITIATIVES

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank said on Tuesday it has approved a US$2.15 million technical assistance grant to help developing Asia Pacific Economic Corporation (APEC) countries.

The grant will help them facilitate speedy and sustainable economic recovery, ensure greater efficiency in resources, and develop immunity against adverse economic shocks through well-coordinated policy reforms and action.

The assistance will support APEC collaborative initiatives to formulate sound macroeconomic policies and strengthen domestic financial markets by enhancing regulation and supervision systems and restructuring banks and corporations.

The assistance, which will be completed by June 2001, will involve studies, surveys and workshops, and will support the technical work and consultation process related to the policy agenda prescribed by APEC finance ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE OFFERS `GOLF SUMMIT' FOR CROSS-STRAIT LEADERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday offered to meet mainland Chinese leaders for a "golf summit," to help ease tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Lee said he hoped that his offer will be conveyed to the mainland Chinese authorities by Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.
The president made the remarks during a ceremony to mark the teeing-off of the First Taishang (Taiwan businessmen) Cup Golf Tournament in Linkuo, Taipei County.

In his speech to some 160 businessmen and government officials taking part in the tourney, Lee reiterated the government's "no haste, be patient" and "tread gingerly to attain long-lasting stability" policies toward mainland China.
He said the policies have been devised in the hope that Taiwan businesses which are poised to make inroads into mainland China will further assess business and risk prospects before acting.

Lee pointed out that the "no haste, be patient" policy is aimed at slowing down Taiwan businessmen who are planning to embark on investment projects worth over NT$50 million on the mainland, while the "tread gingerly to attain long-lasting stability" strategy he described as having an ultimate goal of seeing Taiwan businesses enjoy sustainable operations and development, both at home and in mainland China.

He called for an immediate resumption of high-level dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China, saying that Taiwan would demonstrate great patience and sincerity during the dialogue process in a bid to seek solutions to problems arising from increased exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, including investment problems that Taiwan businessmen commonly encounter on the mainland.

Meanwhile, he stressed his wish that by engaging in closer exchanges with the mainland, Taiwan will help accelerate structural changes there, consequently improving the investment climate and environment for Taiwan businesses.

Lee, a talented golfer who is close to professional standard, did not have an opportunity to play in Tuesday's tournament because he had been tied up with the activities in the National Assembly earlier in the day.
However, he told the competitors that he will definitely compete in next year's Taishang Cup tourney, by which time he will have retired.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA HAS `NO UNDERSTANDING' OF TAIWAN: SEF CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland China has absolutely no understanding of Taiwan, and the Republic of China resents Beijing's oppression of Taiwan's international space, the chief of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Tuesday.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the quasi-official SEF, made the remarks in an interview during a golf tournament he hosted on Tuesday afternoon in response to ROC President Lee Teng-hui's State of the Nation address which he delivered on Monday.
Lee emphasized that Taiwan should acknowledge that two separate administrations exist on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and that both sides should have their own international space.

Koo pointed out that mainland China announced in January that it will "do its job" for the Taiwan people, but on the other hand the mainland boycotts Taiwan incessantly in the international community, and does everything in its power to subvert the ROC government.

In addition, mainland China maintains its view that "unification would be better than the present situation," Koo said, adding that this reveals that the mainland does not understand Taiwan at all, as the people of Taiwan will never believe that unification under Beijing's terms would be better.
In Lee's report, he said that the ROC will not challenge mainland China, and will jointly take part in international organizations and activities and enlarge its international space.

Koo agreed with Lee, and said that while it is difficult to fathom the mainland, the ROC government wishes that Association for Relations Across the Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan's autumn visit will enable him to understand Taiwan a little better.
Taiwan has already positioned Wang's visit as "a journey to understand Taiwan," and Lee has also offered on numerous occasions that he would be glad to personally lead Wang on a tour of the island.

In response to SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng's forthcoming visit to Beijing to conduct talks with his mainland counterpart, Koo said that cross-strait administrative issues are very important. Not only are they related to the people's rights, he said, they are also a starting point for both sides to "accumulate mutual trust."
He said that since mainland China calls itself the "People's" Republic of China, it should respect its people's rights even more.
He also pointed out that if the mainland authorities cannot even abide by the four agreements signed during the 1993 Koo-Wang talks in Singapore, it is doubtful that both sides can build trust.

Koo urged both sides to resume an institutional negotiation mechanism, and to handle practical issues such as the repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal immigrants and fishing disputes, which are directly pertinent to the people's rights on both sides of the strait.
The "middle-range agreements" between both sides should be accomplished one by one like building a pyramid, in order to gradually build trust, Koo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPLAINANT DISAPPOINTED WITH VERDICT ON NORTHWEST AIRLINES SUIT

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court on Tuesday ruled that Northwest Airlines must pay NT$61,396 (US$1,895) to former Taiwan passenger Wu Pei-min and his family as compensation for their suffering from "a certain degree of disturbance" during a flight from Taipei to San Francisco last year.
Interest accumulated from the date of Wu's filing of the suit will be included in the payment, the judgment ruled.
The court, however, rejected Wu's demand for compensation of NT$11.72 million (US$362,000) from the US-based airline on charges of damage caused by second-hand smoke, maltreatment and discrimination.
The judges said it is hard to define the damage caused by second-hand smoke, particularly during a short period of time.
Upon hearing the judgment, Wu expressed disappointment, and said he will consider filing an appeal.
Wu stressed that the goal of his suit against Northwest was not for money, but rather to highlight the harm caused by smoking.

On a flight from Taiwan to San Francisco via Tokyo on April 2, 1998, Wu, his wife and three daughters were seated in non-smoking seats in business class. As the seats directly behind them were smoking seats, Wu asked the flight attendants if he could move his daughters to empty seats in the front of the non-smoking section, as one daughter suffers from asthma and another has a weak respiratory system.
After denying Wu's request, a flight attendant taped off the empty seats to discourage him from moving his daughters there on his own, he stated.

Wu said that because of the smoke during the 10-hour flight, his youngest daughter suffered from incessant coughing, diarrhea and vomiting, and was diagnosed with bronchitis, which is linked to second-hand smoke, upon landing in San Francisco. The family was then forced to cancel their vacation.

Wu said he tried to negotiate with Northwest authorities but after failing to receive a response, contacted the John Tung Foundation, a local anti-smoking crusader group, and filed a lawsuit on July 28 last year.
Upon learning of the ruling on Tuesday, Northwest Airlines' Taipei office expressed regret over the result, without making any further comment.
It was learned that following the Wu incident, Northwest banned smoking altogether on all of its flights beginning on Aug. 1, 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETTER ADDRESS DIFFICULTIES ON PATH TO DEMOCRACY: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that it is better to press ahead with democracy and address the difficulties along the way than to balk at pursuing democracy for fear of the problems it might entail.

At a luncheon for National Assembly delegates, Lee addressed public concerns that the local legislature is awash with gangsters, saying that closing loopholes in the electoral system is not enough to block the mobsters from infiltrating politics. Instead, Lee advocated education as a cure for the problem.
Noting that Taiwan has followed its democratic path for only about ten years, Lee said it natural that problems will crop up along the way.

Responding to some National Assembly delegates' complaints about Taiwan's worsening social order, Lee blamed Taiwan's flawed education system which, he said, puts too much emphasis on academic achievements and discriminates against those who perform less well in examinations.
The unhealthy education system has forced many students who cannot adapt to it out of the nation's schools, and has set them against society, said Lee.
The president urged an overhaul of the education system to allow schools to embrace students with lower academic achievements, and to give them their due.

In response to questions from delegates during the luncheon, Lee displayed flexibility toward the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's demands for constitutional reforms, and urged the DPP to keep on negotiating with the ruling Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BASED AIRLINES DENY VIOLATION OF AVIATION PACT WITH MANILA

TEXT.P: The two Taiwan-based airlines operating between Manila and Taipei denied on Tuesday that they have violated an aviation pact between the two countries by extending its Taipei-bound flights to the United States.

Both China Airlines and EVA Airways, which provide flight services between Taiwan and the Philippines, said all US-bound passengers from Manila are deplaned in Taipei and transferred to different planes with different flight numbers, as required by the aviation pact, before continuing on to their final destinations.

Arguing that they operate the Taipei-Manila route with medium-sized Boeing 737s, but routinely use Boeing 747 jumbo jets on the Taiwan-US route, the two carriers said it is impossible for those passengers originating from Manila to fly aboard the same plane to the United States via Taipei as the Manila authorities have charged.
The Manila civil aviation administration threatened on Tuesday to impose sanctions on the two carriers if they do not answer the charges within five days.
The aviation administration claimed that EVA took 181 US-bound passengers from Manila in May, and that China Airlines carried 29 passengers in the first week of June.

Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of Taipei's Civil Aeronautics Administration weighed in on Tuesday to support the two airlines, and blamed their Philippine rival, Philippine Airlines, for making false complaints to the Philippine government because of its poor business in the face of the Taiwan carriers' competition.
Chang said the dispute will be discussed in July when the bilateral aviation pact is up for renewal.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATRIATES, MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES TO BE INCLUDED IN NHI PROGRAM

TEXT.P: More people living in Taiwan who are not Republic of China nationals will be allowed under the umbrella of the National Health Insurance (NHI) program, following the passing of an amendment to the NHI law by the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday.

The passage of the amendment will immediately benefit contracted military personnel, expatriates, mainland Chinese spouses, and other foreign nationals who have lived in Taiwan for more than four months and own residence permits, Legislative Yuan sources said.

The amendment also lowers fines on delayed payment of NHI premiums by 0.3 percent while lowering the ceiling on the number of dependents in a family who must pay the premium from the current five to three.
The amendment was passed with the aim of reducing the financial burden on the NHI carriers, according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S YOUTH SOFTBALL TOURNEY MOVES INTO FINAL ROUNDS

TEXT.P: Chinese-Taipei defeated New Zealand 1-0 and beat Argentina 10-0 at Hsinchuang Stadium on Tuesday to rank second in Division A of the sixth World Women's Youth Softball Championship.
After the preliminary rounds of the tournament, the top four teams of Divisions A and B will advance to the final rounds starting on Wednesday.
The top four teams in Division A are the United States, Chinese-Taipei, Canada and Venezuela. In Division B, the top four teams are Japan, mainland China, Australia and Russia.
Chinese-Taipei will play against Japan on Wednesday afternoon, and the championship final will take place on June 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER JUVENILE DELINQUENCY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday expressed concern over the worsening problem of juvenile delinquency on Taiwan, and said he has asked related authorities to take effective steps to deal with the issue.
Addressing the National Assembly, Lee said that juvenile delinquency has become a source of worry for society, and is likely to become an obstacle for the nation's development in the future.
In order to help resolve this problem, he said that it is important to create an educational environment imbued with the spirit of "happiness, learning, growth."
The president said he has asked educational authorities to carry out reforms in all aspects of the education system, including curricula, teaching materials and teaching methods.
Besides prohibiting youngsters from entering "unsuitable places," Lee also pointed out the need to provide more leisure establishments and suitable activities for the nation's youth.

He also urged parents and teachers to help youngsters to understand and nurture their abilities and interests, rather than continually pressing them to study for examinations to enter high schools and colleges.
Lee said that many juvenile problems are connected with dysfunctional families, and expressed the hope that the people of the island will attach greater importance to "spiritual reform."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Legislative Yuan passed widely anticipated revisions to the business tax law on Tuesday, paving the way for reduction of the added-value business tax for financial institutions to 2 percent from the current 5 percent.

The Liberty Times:
The legislature passed 24 bills on the last day of its current session.
The Commons Daily:

The China Post:
Business tax provisions pass through the legislature.
The Taiwan News:
Tax cut for financial institutions passes.
The Taipei Times:
The disposal act gets new life.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS EYEING MILITARY COMPOUND FOR NEW HOME

TEXT.P: Legislators on Tuesday night passed a resolution to relocate their headquarters to a military compound located in downtown Taipei, sources from the Legislative Yuan said on Wednesday.

After examining eight possible relocation sites, the legislators selected the Air Force General Headquarters on high-priced Jenai Road. The site received 54 votes, more than half the number of votes cast during the legislature's Tuesday night session.
The legislature's selection does not mean the facilities will automatically become available to them, however, as air force authorities have expressed opposition to giving up the compound right now.

The air force will not be able to relocate its headquarters until its own relocation plans are settled, air force authorities said. It has been proposed that the air force relocate to a tri-military compound located in Tahchih by the Keelung River.
The Legislative Yuan has talked about relocating its headquarters for years, as the current building is old and too small to accommodate the increased numbers of legislators and their aides.
Recently, the Legislative Yuan selected eight possible relocation sites.

The seven other options -- the Huashan Railway Station, the Sungshan Tobacco Plant, Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the Grand Hotel, the Taiwan Railway Bureau, the Chung Hsing New Village and an overhaul of the existing Yuan tract -- all received less than 10 votes.
Meanwhile, the opposition New Party still opposes the relocation, saying it is immoral for the legislature to spend taxpayers' money for the benefit of lawmakers themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION CONGRATULATES MALAWIAN PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, June 22 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and Malawi will be further strengthened based on the current basis, said Control Yuan President Frederick Chien on Tuesday here. Chien, head of a seven-member ROC delegation, arrived in Malawi over the weekend to take part in the Monday inauguration of President-elect Bakili Muluzi in Blantyre, a major commercial city in southern Malawi.
Muluzi, beating four other rivals, scored a victory in his re-election bid in the country's June 15 presidential race.
Chien said the ROC delegation has been received by the Malawian government with the highest honor, and expressed the belief that two-way ROC-Malawi ties will be further stepped up.

In Monday's presidential inauguration of Muluzi, Chien, alone with heads of state from Zambia, Botswana, Mozambique and Tanzania, as well as with the prime minister of Namibia and Malawi's first and second presidents, sat in the first row of the audience.

In Muluzi's inaugural speech, the ROC was the third country, after Britain and the United States, to be named as one that has extended significant assistance to Malawi. Other countries included Germany, Norway, Holland and Japan.

During a state banquet held in Monday evening, Chien and his wife also sat together with Muluzi and his wife at the same table, an indication that the ROC envoy was warmly received by the Malawian newly elected president.

In a Sunday gathering with the ROC delegation, Muluzi voiced appreciation for President Lee Teng-hui's reception last time when he visited Taiwan in 1996, and offered an invitation to Lee, welcoming him to visit Malawi.
While in Malawi, the ROC mission also met with ROC nationals and technical assistance personnel residing here. The delegation is scheduled to leave here for Taiwan on Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HU TO VISIT CHICAGO, SAN FRANCISCO

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu will leave for the United States on Friday for a two-city speech tour, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.
MOFA acting spokesman Chen Ming-cheng said Hu will first attend the 11th annual meeting of the North America Taiwan General Chamber of Commerce scheduled to open in Chicago on Saturday.

As Vice President Lien Chan holds a doctoral degree from the University of Chicago, some people speculate that Hu's Chicago visit may be aimed at arranging for Lien to visit his alma mater later this year. Chen would not make any comment on such speculation.

Following his Chicago visit, Hu will travel to San Francisco where he will deliver a speech on Taiwan's role in peace, democracy and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific area on June 29 at the invitation of the World Affairs Council in North California.

During his stay in Chicago and San Francisco, Chen said Hu will inspect the Republic of china's representative offices in the two cities and meet with Chinese community leaders. Hu is scheduled to return to Taipei on June 30.
