DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PATENT APPLICATIONS INCREASING IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: More and more Taiwan applications for patent rights are being filed in mainland China, which benefits cross-strait trade, a mainland official involved in intellectual property rights protection said Wednesday in Taipei.

Wu Buoming, deputy director of the Intellectual Property Rights Bureau, made the remarks at a conference in which representatives from Taiwan and the mainland exchanged views on patent theory and practices.

Wu said 73 percent of Taiwanese patent applications in the mainland were filed for innovative products that are practical for daily life, such as household appliances, furniture and sporting equipment. Meanwhile, 17 percent of patent applications are related to designs, and 10 percent are related to inventions.
Most invention-related patent applications filed by Taiwanese are concerned with electronics, including telecommunications equipment and computers, Wu said.
The two-day cross-strait conference opened Wednesday in Taipei, and more than 30 mainland Chinese officials and experts in the area of patent rights have been invited to take part.
Mainland China is a signatory to the Patent Cooperation Treaty, an international cooperation agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE IN MAY HIGHEST FOR THAT MONTH SINCE 1978

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to 2.84 percent in May, the highest jobless level for that month since 1978, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Wednesday.
DGBAS officials put the blame for the high jobless rate in May on an increased number of job seekers and fewer openings.
The officials warned that if the unemployment is not arrested effectively in following months, the jobless rate for this year may break the alarming and intolerable 3-percent mark.

Taiwan posted a cumulative 2.78-percent unemployment rate for the first five months of this year, a relatively high level compared with the same period last year. Joblessness is typically low in April and May, when seasonal factors are at a minimum, DGBAS officials noted. But this has not been the case this year, they said.
They said the 1999 jobless rate is very likely to exceed 3 percent, as the unemployment rate is expected to average over 3 percent in the "peak months" of June, July and August.

According to DGBAS tallies, the number of jobless people in Taiwan increased by 10,000 from April to 273,000 in May. That number is the largest ever for the month of May and the largest as a percentage of the total workforce since 1978.
The statistics showed that Taiwan's workforce totaled 9.35 million people at the end of May, up 72,000 over the year-earlier level, and 45,000 people more than were recorded in April.
Although Taiwan's economy picked up steam in May, the number of job openings in the business and industrial sectors did not rise correspondingly to meet employment demands, the officials pointed out.

Taiwan's jobless rate in May was still lower than those of other major economies in Asia, they said. South Korea's unemployment rate was 6.5 percent in May, compared with 6.3 percent in Hong Kong, 4.8 percent in Japan and 3.9 percent in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN SET TO POSTPONE EAST TIMOR'S AUGUST REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The United Nations, angered by pro-integration militia violence and intimidation in East Timor, is preparing to postpone the scheduled Aug. 8 referendum on the fate of the territory, Australian media reported on Wednesday.

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has indicated that the referendum could be postponed by at least two weeks so that the territory's 400,000 East Timorese will be able to choose independence or autonomy within the Indonesian republic freely and without harassment.

He also indicated that security problems and the unlawful participation of local government officials in pro-autonomy political campaigning remain, despite Indonesian claims that violence and political tension have significantly subsided.
The UN mission in East Timor is understood to have recommended a postponement that could push the vote back to Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE-CHINESE SCIENTIST LEADING EFFORTS TO DEVELOP BETTER TV SCREENS

TEXT.P: A young Australian scientist of Chinese origin has taken the lead in advancing nanotube technology, paving the way for a completely new type of television and flat-panel computer display, according to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) on Wednesday.

In a statement faxed to CNA, the CSIRO said Liming Dai -- aided by Shaoming Huang, a contracted scientist from Nanking University -- has improved the technology, discovered by a Japanese scientist in 1991. Both Dai and Huang are working for the CSIRO in Melbourne as researchers.
In screens, carbon nanotubes work as an intermediary, focusing electrons onto a surface where they react with a fluorescent material to produce light for picture displays.

"It has been a major challenge for researchers to get control of the way they form. In order to use nanotubes for panel displays it is important that the tubes are either aligned or formed into patterns," Dai said in the same statement. Dai went to Australia in 1986 to study and obtained a Ph.D. from Australian National University in Canberra.
"We have been able to take a lead in this research, as we found ways to control the arrangement of the nanotubes," he added.
Flat-screen technology is expected to result in a multi-billion dollar market worldwide over the next few years, the statement said.

"CSIRO's carbon nanotube work is world class, and could well lead to exciting developments in flat screen technology," said Ernst Hammel of the top scientific body in Australia. "This technology is the subject of intensive R&D, especially in the USA, but we believe the Australian research is at the very forefront," he added.
Commercial production is expected to take place in a few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TIPPED TO PLAY HOST TO WORLD CUP

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to become a strong contender in the competition to serve as host to the 2003 World Soccer Cup, and it is expected to compete with other bidding countries, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

In a dispatch from New York, correspondent Michael Cockerill on Wednesday reported that the Australian bid committee for the 2003 tournament is due to meet executives of the world body, FIFA, in Los Angeles on July 6 to formally present its submission.

The committee, comprising officials of Soccer Australia and the Australian Women's Soccer Association, said Australia is now the only country to have officially expressed an interest in playing host to the World Cup. But the officials said they thought both Brazil and the United States would enter the race later.

FIFA will select a host country in December, and Australia remains the firm favorite, the daily reported. FIFA President Sepp Blatter has shown genuine enthusiasm for Australia's bid to play host to the World Cup, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAYS FURTHER SALE OF TELSTRA SHARES EXPECTED

TEXT.P: The Australian government under Prime Minister John Howard has won Senate approval to sell 16.6 percent of government-owned telecommunications giant Telstra to help reduce the government reduce its public foreign debt.
The Senate approval of the Telstra sale is a follow-up to a privatization move by the government in which it sold one-third of its shares in the company in 1997.

The second tranche of Telstra sales will result in the government maintaining control of 50.1 percent of company, as politicians have insisted that the telecommunications giant remain in government hands.

But Howard vowed on Tuesday to achieve the full privatization of Telstra, while assuring that partial proceeds from the second sale would be used to reduce the government's external debt to A$20.5 billion (US$13.7 billion) in fiscal 1999-2000 from its current level of A$51 billion (US$34 billion). The government intends to eliminate the debt entirely by 2002-2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 23, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Pedro de Mendoza, Spanish explorer, dies at sea on his way back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia, in a bid to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent for the saxophone, a woodwind instrument with a single-reed mouthpiece and a usually curved conical metal tube, including soprano, alto, tenor and baritone sizes.
1894: Edward VIII, British monarch, is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title the Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, American zoologist and sociologist best known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1911: Thousands turn out to celebrate the coronation of Britain's King George V in London. The coronation ceremony is attended by 8,000 people, including representatives from all over the world.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chung-hua ke-ming tang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected director-general.
1922: Foreign Minister Wu Ting-fang, who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of an illness in Canton at the age of 81. He was reportedly angered by Chen Chiung-ming, who revolted against Dr. Sun Yat-sen on June 16.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan in Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching to be governor of Taiwan.
1971: The European Economic Community (EEC) concludes negotiations in Luxembourg for Britain's entry into the EEC.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The US Supreme Court rules that the US Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Eemergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: Jonas Edward Salk, American microbiologist, dies in California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive, is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

DOC.HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PREVENTION CENTER OPENS

TEXT.P: In line with the implementation of the new domestic violence prevention law, a municipal domestic violence and sexual offense prevention center will formally open on Thursday, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the ceremony.

The center is located in a police station of Taipei City's Hsinyi district, and will offer round-the-clock assistance, protection, accommodation, medical care, and law consulting services to all victims of domestic violence.
All citizens who have suffered domestic or sexual violence will be able to receive assistance and protection with just a phone call.

Currently, reported domestic violence cases total more than 36,000 in Taipei, with an increase rate of 1,300 new cases each year, Taipei City Government statistics show. In addition, a total of 575 cases of sexual assault were reported last year.
The domestic violence protection law will fully take effect from Thursday, after a one-year grace period since the law was promulgated on June 24, 1998.

From now on, all victims of domestic violence can apply for civil affairs protection warrants from prosecution authorities on a case-by-case basis, Yen Da-ho, director of the Department of Prosecution Affairs under the Ministry of Justice, said at a news conference.

Any offender who violates the ruling of a protection warrant, such as failing to move out of the victim's residence within a certain period, will be sentenced to a jail term of up to three years or a fine of up to NT$100,000, according to Yen.
Although the victim may be unwilling to take court action against his or her offender, prosecutors are entitled to take adequate measures to help ensure the victim's personal safety, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON ISLANDS TURMOIL WILL NOT AFFECT TIES WITH ROC: MOFA

TEXT.P: The current turmoil in the Solomon Islands will not affect the South Pacific island nation's relations with the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

Acting MOFA spokesman Chen Ming-cheng made the remarks in response to foreign wire service reports that the unrest in the South Pacific island nation is related to a power struggle between its pro-Taiwan and pro-mainland China factions.
Chen dismissed the reports as sheer speculation, and stressed that the conflict is a result of ethnic tension.

"The turmoil should not be used as an excuse to influence ROC-Solomon Islands relations," Chen said, adding that the government of the Solomon Islands has reaffirmed its friendship with and firm support for the ROC.
Chen went on to say that the ROC Embassy in the Solomon Islands has been closely monitoring related developments there, and has reinforced its security measures.
"To date, all ROC expatriates, embassy staff, members of our agricultural mission and their families are safe," Chen said.

Tensions have been growing in the Solomon Islands since last September when an informal group known as the Guadalcanal Liberation Army began pressing for the removal of Malaita islanders from the main island of the Solomon group, and compensation for their presence there since the country gained independence.
The nation is now under a state of emergency following a series of guerrilla attacks on oil palm plantations in Mbalisuna, a township east of the capital, Honiara.

According to foreign wire service reports, former Fiji Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka has arrived in the Solomon Islands to help mediate peace in the scenic island country, which maintains close diplomatic ties with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNE EXPORTS ESTIMATED TO SOAR 2.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in June are expected to soar 2.5 percent to 3 percent over the year-earlier level, while imports are estimated to remain at the same level, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Wednesday.
MOF officials estimated that June exports will top between US$9.3 billion and US$9.4 billion, while imports will amount to US$8.6 billion.

The MOF statistics show that Taiwan's exports totaled US$5.86 billion in the first half of June, up 2.3 percent over the year-earlier level, while imports amounted to US$5.49 billion, down 0.1 percent.
As a result, Taiwan was left with a surplus of US$1.33 billion in the two-week period, a whopping increase of 56 percent over the corresponding period of last year.

Cumulatively, Taiwan posted a surplus of US$4.85 billion in foreign trade in the period between Jan. 1 and June 15 this year, a figure about five times that posted in the same period of 1998, according to the MOF tallies.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Statistics Department, attributed the soar in exports in June to brisk trade in electronics, telecommunications and information technology products as the result of a worldwide economic recovery, particularly in Asia.

Hsu said Taiwan's military hardware imports declined sharply in the first half of June, but imports of capital equipment and industrial as well as agricultural raw materials increased, resulting in an import level about the same as the year-earlier level.

He forecast that both the export and import trade will further gather steam in the third quarter, on the grounds that the economies in the Asia-Pacific region have become brisker, which means their imports from Taiwan will increase; Taiwan's first high-speed railway project is kicking off soon; the Y2K effect; and the ever-increasing expansion of the cellular phone industry in the country.

In addition, Hsu noted, the recent worldwide dioxin scare triggered by Belgian dairy and meat exports has not adversely affected Taiwan's economy, as local imports of Belgian food products are minuscule in proportion to the island's overall foreign trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO MEET PRESS AND REVIEW FIRST 6 MONTHS IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet the press on Friday and will lead his working team in a review of their work as the city's administration six months after Ma's inauguration.

The mayor is said to be attaching great importance to the upcoming press conference, with a rehearsal scheduled for Thursday, and even a strict dress code for city government officials attending -- dark suits for the men, pink for the ladies.

During an administrative meeting a month ago, Ma requested officials at each administrative level to list their five most successful accomplishments and their five least successful accomplishments of the past half-year, and these findings were compiled into a report which Ma will use as a base to explain to Taipei's citizens what his team has done for the people.

In view of the fact that Ma's working team got a lower rating in polls regarding their performance as compared with its predecessor -- the team headed by former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian -- Ma expressed his hope that he can show the citizens of Taipei his team's achievements.
Some of Ma's team have been criticized as "bureaucratic" and poorly chosen for their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL TOURNEY TO BEGIN IN JULY

TEXT.P: The 22nd William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament is scheduled to kick off on July 27 at Taipei's Municipal Gymnasium, the ROC Basketball Association reported on Wednesday.
The invitational tournament, which will run through Aug. 7, will bring together eight men's and five women's teams from around the world to compete, an association spokesman said.

Between July 27 and July 31, women's teams from Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the host Taiwan will compete against each other, while men's teams from Costa Rica, Iran, the Philippines, South Korea, New Zealand, South Africa and Taiwan will meet in a round robin scheduled for Aug. 2-7, the spokesman noted.
This year's William Jones Cup men's section is being widely tipped as a litmus test for the Asian Cup Men's Basketball Championship to be held in Fukuoka, Japan later this year.
The tournament is named after Dr. William Jones, a British man who established the Federation of International Basketball Associations (FIBA) more than four decades ago.
As FIBA founder and secretary-general, Jones visited Taiwan in 1977 to personally deliver a silver cup to mark the inception of the William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSIAL TAX BUSINESS AMENDMENT PASSES THROUGH LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan acted true to form on the last day of the current legislative session late on Tuesday evening, scurrying to pass as many bills as possible.

The most controversial among 21 bills passed in the session which did not end until 9:40 p.m. was an amendment to cut business tax on financial and insurance institutions to 2 percent from the current 5 percent, a move which brought fierce protests from some legislators.
The bill, which was adopted by a vote of 93 to 84, did not pass until the third and final reading, as the first two readings were invalidated due to the lack of a quorum.

The tax cut, which will go into effect on July 1, will reduce annual government revenue by NT$41.3 billion. However, the savings stemming from the tax cut will be used to offset up to NT$300 billion-worth of bad loans in banking institutions in four years, therefore lowering the ratio of overdue loans to below 2.5 percent, said officials from the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
Nevertheless, legislators from both the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition New Party blasted the MOF, saying it has failed to come up with replacement measures to make up for the revenue losses.

The fairness of the bill also invited arguments, legislators said, saying it will mostly benefit some poorly performing banks with higher-than-average bad debt ratios, leaving the public to suffer the consequences.
Under the amendment, banks, insurance companies, trust investment companies, securities and futures brokers and pawnbrokers will now be subject to 2 percent business tax.

The amendment also rules that banks and insurance companies should allocate 3 percent of their profits to offset overdue loans or fund a bad debt reserve within four years of the bill's implementation.
If these targets are not reached, an additional 1 percent will be added to the business tax.

Meanwhile, it was reported that the MOF is working with the banks to establish a schedule as well as measures to offset bad loans, and that the legislature has requested the MOF to report to and obtain permission from the legislature before implementing such measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES SHED 1.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices shed 1.4 percent on Wednesday as a wave of profit-taking swept through the local bourse.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dropped 116.59 points to close at 8,492.32.
A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$229.88 (US$7.11 billion), the highest level this year.
Boosted by the passage of a tax cut bill for financial institutions, the financial sector opened high but ended 1.2 percent lower as selling pressure surged in end-of-session trading.

The electronics sector suffered the largest setback among the eight major stock categories, falling 1.9 percent, while construction shares, with a 1.3 percent rise, enjoyed the session's largest gain.
Paper-making issues rose 0.7 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares declined 1.7 percent and foodstuff issues went down 1.2 percent, followed by the textile sector, which lost 0.8 percent and the cement sector, which shed 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market suffered a 1.93-point drop, ending the day at 178.98 points, with a turnover of NT$9.98 billion.
Depressed by the big decline in the stock market, all futures also registered heavy losses.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July declined 163 points to 8,527 points, with 5,303 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August moved down 118 points to 8,532 points, with 185 contract transactions, those for September fell 145 points to 8,555 points, with 69 contract transactions, while December futures went down 99 points to 8,551 points, with five contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March registered a drop of 87 points to finish at 8,564, with only one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 8,690 for July, 8,650 for August, 8,700 for September, 8,650 for December and 8,651 for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY MAYOR REPORTS ON ADMINISTRATIVE ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh, who will have been in office for six months on Friday, on Wednesday emphasized the importance of "continuously surpassing his ideals."
Hsieh made the remarks during a press conference held at city hall, where a multi-functional trade park blueprint is on exhibition.

The rezoning application for the park was approved by the Ministry of the Interior's (MOI) city planning committee in early June, which has given a boost to the city administration, Hsieh said while describing the positive prospects for the park.

Hsieh also reported on the Kaohsiung city government's administrative achievements over the past six months, including the promotion of the trade park, inclusion of the Pratas Islands into the city domain, and the controversial issuance of a charity lottery.

In addition, he said, the city government will continue construction of mass rapid transit systems, begin enrollment of the Kaohsiung University next year, strive for the establishment of a new southern international airport, readjust administrative districts, and begin construction of a "giant egg" domed stadium.

Hsieh, who said he won the mayoral election "by a miracle," said he has now adjusted to his office. He also stressed that the achievements were realized through the concerted efforts of all members of the present and past city governments and mayors.
He added that he has simply continued with "the basis established by his predecessors" and has done his best to "move the city along."

In response to questions on his opinion of his administrative efforts, Hsieh replied that he has continuously strived to be "better and better," is not satisfied with his present achievements, and will leave the grading of his administration to the citizens.

Kaohsiung City might not be "no. 1," Hsieh said, but it must be the "only one." He pledged to exert his utmost efforts to guide the city's administration, and build Kaohsiung City into an "international oceanic capital."

DOC.HEADLINE: HU DENIES US TOUR IS TO PAVE WAY FOR VP'S CHICAGO VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Wednesday denied allegations that his forthcoming visit to the United States is aimed at paving the way for a later visit by Vice President Lien Chan to his alma mater, the University of Chicago.

Hu is slated to leave for the United States on Friday for a five-day visit to Chicago and San Francisco, where he will speak at the North America Taiwan General Chamber of Commerce (NATGCC) annual meeting and the World Affairs Council in Northern California.

In response to questions from the press, Hu said that both are long-standing engagements, and added that the NATGCC chairman even came to Taiwan to personally extend the invitation, which made him decide on the visit.
Hu said he also plans to meet with American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush during his visit, but denied media reports that they are scheduled to discuss specific issues.

On the subject of Nauru, one of Taiwan's 28 diplomatic allies, deferring on Tuesday its application to join the United Nations (UN) because of opposition from mainland China, Hu said the ROC is paying close attention to the issue, and called the mainland's actions a display of "naked hegemony."
Hu said that mainland China's continued objection to Nauru's admission into the UN is unacceptable to the ROC, and that naturally the ROC government will be closely monitoring the situation.

The UN Security Council committee on the admission of new members reviewed the application of Kiribati and Nauru on Tuesday. While Kiribati's request was quickly endorsed, Nauru's application was deferred due to mainland China's opposition on the grounds that the tiny Pacific island nation acknowledges the ROC's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RULES OUT IMPORTS OF MAINLAND CHINA-MADE FMD VACCINE

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) of the Republic of China on Wednesday rejected a proposal to import mainland China-produced foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) vaccine.
BOFT Deputy Director-General Wei Ke-ming said the board would not hastily open Taiwan's doors to mainland Chinese FMD vaccine because few data are available concerning its safety and efficacy.
Wei made the announcement after presiding over a meeting of officials from relevant government agencies to discuss whether an import ban on mainland China-produced FMD vaccine should be lifted.

Mainland China indicated earlier this month that it is willing to provide Taiwan with FMD vaccine to help contain the spread of the contagious disease which affects cloven-hoofed animals such as pigs, sheep, cattle and goats.
Beijing's offer came after several cattle raised in the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen and the southern Taiwan county of Tainan were found to have been infected with the FMD virus.

Laboratory tests show that the FMD virus that infected the Kinmen and Tainan cattle is similar to a strain found in mainland China's southeastern coastal areas. Local animal disease control officials suspect that the virus in Kinmen and Tainan might have been transmitted through smuggled animals from mainland China.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said mainland China has long been recognized as an FMD-infected area, and serious FMD outbreaks have been reported in several mainland provinces in recent months. Beijing, however, has never reported details of its FMD infections to the Paris-based international organization dedicated to the control of contagious animal diseases.

Noting that three types of the virus have been discovered in mainland China -- "type O," "Asia-1," and "type A, COA officials said mainland China should send its FMD vaccine to a global FMD virus testing laboratory in Britain to certify its safety and efficacy.

Lee Chin-lung, director of the COA's Plants and Animals Quarantine Bureau, said the ROC government would consider lifting the import ban only after mainland China's animal disease control measures and its vaccine production process have become more transparent.

About 10 countries around the world, including Germany, France and Argentina, produce FMD vaccine. Although Taiwan has the technology to produce the vaccine, it still relies on imports, choosing not to produce its own out of concern over risk and cost effectiveness.

Lee said Taiwan still has 2 million doses of vaccine against various types of FMD virus, and warned: "Local dairy farmers should not use smuggled mainland Chinese-made FMD vaccine, because this increases the risk of spreading unknown viruses from the mainland."
All the 500-plus cattle raised in the FMD-infected ranches in Kinmen and Tainan have been slaughtered over the past week to prevent further spread of the virus.

FMD is an acute, contagious disease that can be spread via air and infects mainly cloven-hoofed livestock and wild animals. Its mortality rate is 5 percent, but can rise to 50 percent in young animals.
Taiwan's hog farms were hit by an FMD outbreak in 1997, resulting in the death of 3.85 million pigs and an estimated financial loss of NT$160 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar remained unchanged against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 32.348.
The local currency opened at 32.341 and was traded between 32.339 and 32.354.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$211 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS' PERFORMANCES GET LOW CREDIT RATINGS

TEXT.P: Legislators received low credit ratings for their performances during the first session of the Fourth Legislative Yuan, according to the results of an opinion survey released on Wednesday.

The survey of local reporters covering the legislative beat was conducted by the office of ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chen Hung-chi from June 8-17. The office sent out 104 questionnaires and received 79 valid replies.
The survey results show that local journalists gave a low score of just 51.42 points on a 100-point scale to lawmakers' performances in the legislative session which ended on Tuesday evening.
According to the poll, 47 percent of the respondents evaluated lawmakers' general performances as "average," while 32 percent said they feel the lawmakers' performances were "bad."

An overwhelming 89 percent of the reporters said they found that the legislators performed either "badly" or "very badly" in the category of "disregarding personal interests while mulling legislative bills."
Meanwhile, 83 percent said they feel that the legislators have failed to fulfill their duties of screening the government's budget plan and supervising its use of the budget.
Seventy-two percent said they think that the overall quality and performances of the incumbent legislators are worse than those of their predecessors.

Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said he would "humbly accept" the reporters' criticism of the legislature, but noted that members of the current legislature come from diverse, "complex" backgrounds, and that several subgroups and factions have dominated legislative process and operations during the just-concluded session.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT KAOHSIUNG OFFICE THROWS RECEPTION FOR OUTGOING AND NEW HEADS

TEXT.P: Darrell Jenks, outgoing head of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), Kaohsiung Office, bid farewell to his local friends on Wednesday at a reception held in the southern Taiwan city.

After a three-year stint in Kaohsiung, Jenks has been transferred to the US Embassy in Sao Paulo, Brazil. Speaking in fluent southern Fukienese dialect, he thanked more than a hundred local politicians, business leaders and well-wishers for their assistance over the last three years, and said that hopefully, he will have the chance to serve in Taiwan again in the future.
He then introduced his successor, Stephen Dunn, to those attending the reception.
Dunn, who has served at the AIT Taipei Office for the last five years, vowed in Mandarin Chinese to enter his new job with fully charged confidence.

A graduate of the University of Arizona, with a masters degree in Asian Studies, Dunn studied Chinese at National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei before entering the US State Department in 1986, and has previously served in Mexico and mainland China besides Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL EXPLAINS ROC POLICY TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Beijing's "big-country" diplomatic strategy will not succeed in preventing the Republic of China (ROC) from the participating in the international community because most countries support democracy and freedom.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC, made the remarks on Tuesday in a speech to more than 30 representatives of Chinese-language newspapers and Taiwan university alumni association leaders currently living in Thailand.
Wu said Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan have failed in the wake of Macedonia's decision to establish diplomatic relations with the ROC.
Although at present only 28 countries maintain diplomatic links with Taiwan, the ROC has substantial trade and economic relations with more than 100 countries, Wu said.

The 56-year-old executive of Taiwan's mainland policy warned that a conflict between the ROC and mainland China would result in a great loss of life and would likely become a testing ground for each country's modern weapons.
Wise leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said, should take steps to avoid the gloomy scenario by stopping the purchase of increasingly powerful modern weapons.

Wu, who paid eight visits to the mainland before asssuming his MAC post, said that it would be impossible for Taipei to stop purchasiong modern weapons before Beijing abandons its military threat against Taiwan.

Some academicians and cross-strait affairs experts in Taiwan support the idea that Taipei should change its "defensive" national defense policy into a "deterrent" one in order to safeguard the lives of 20 million Taiwan people, he said.

Citing the confrontation between South and North Korea, Wu said that he beleived even if a summit meeting between the leaders of Taiwan and mainland China would not necessarily be able to stop the cross-strait arms race immediately.

The best way to resolve cross-strait disputes, according to MAC's strategy, is to launch a series of peaceful negotiations and exchanges over a variety of issues, with the aim of promoting mutual understanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 800 ARRESTED IN NATION-WIDE GANG BUST

TEXT.P: Taiwan police ended the fifth wave of a nation-wide gang bust on Wednesday by arresting over 800 criminal suspects.

The island-wide gang bust began on Tuesday at 5:30 AM, with police targeting suspected perpetrators of gang violence, gun trafficking and environmental destruction. The operation ended Wednesday morning.

In addition to Tuesday's capture of five high-ranking leaders of the "Eastern Union" gang, northern Taiwan's largest teen gang, Taiwan police arrested leaders of the island's most notorious gangs, including the infamous "Hsinchu Union" gang and the "Four Seas" gang.

In addition, police rounded up suspected arms and drug traffickers, as well as those believed to be involved in illegal loan-sharks, professional gambling, and morality offenses, arresting a total of 839 criminal suspects. (By Wendy Chung) EDITEM ZCZC CEP028 06-23-99 TAIWAN BOURSE ON BULLISH LONG-TERM TREND

Taipei, June 23 (CNA) While the recent rally of the Taiwan Stock Exchange will lead to profit-taking by investors and despite the local bourse's need to make a downward correction, the local stock market is still on a bullish long-term trend, a securities industry expert said on Wednesday.

Ku Yueh-han, general manager of Merrill Lynch Investment Consultative Corp. (Taiwan), made the remark during the second day of the second Asia-Pacific Technology Conference held at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel.

While electronics stocks dominated the local bourse in 1997, banking and electronics stocks, especially those semiconductor stocks that are rumored to be corporate merger targets, can be the investment targets for local investors during the next three years, Ku suggested.
Because the world economy has started to recover, stocks that are related to the rise and fall of economic cycles can also be investment targets, Ku added.

Joe Osha, a semiconductor industry analyst with Merrill Lynch Securities, indicated the semiconductor industry, from the American point of view, can maintain its prosperity for at least two more years. He added that Taiwan's wafer foundry industry is expected to perform well during this period due to the industry's competitiveness in the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS COOPERATIVE MEMO WITH ATSC ON DIGITAL TV DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Digital Television Committee (TDTC) Wednesday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Advanced Television System Committee (ATSC) of the United States on digital TV cooperation.
Under the terms of the pact, ATSC, which dominates US digital TV standards, will help Taiwan to dominate the drawing of Chinese digital TV standards.

The Taiwan Digital Television Committee is comprised of several local companies that are leaders in television, broadcasting and information technology. It was formed under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
ATSC Chairman Robert K. Graves Wednesday signed the cooperative MOU memo with TDTC Chairman Chen Sheng-tien, who is also president of the Sampo group.

Republic of China Ministry of Transportation (MOT) statistics estimated that the development of local digital TV systems will create NT$20 million worth of business. Four Taiwan cable companies have already invested heavily in this field and have established a trail television station. Commercial electronics companies are also eyeing the huge market potential.
The TDTC will be sending members abroad to observe and study the US and Japan's latest digital TV technologies in addition to seeking cooperative opportunities.
Digital TV is already broadcasting in the US, Sweden and England, while Taiwan, Korea, Japan, Singapore, Australia, Germany and Spain are scheduled to air Digital TV programs in two to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC AIRLINES WARNED BY PHILIPPINE AVIATION BOARD

TEXT.P: Following a crackdown by the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) on foreign airlines that violated a bilateral air agreement with the Philippines, the Air Transpiration Office (ATO) Wednesday said most of the 26 airlines that operate in the country violate the agreement.
"Most of them are eating up the market of Philippine Airlines, the country's flag carrier. Most of them have violated the agreement" ATO chief Capt. Jacinto Ortega said.

According to Ortega, apart from the two airlines registered in the Republic of China (ROC), Eva Air and China Airlines, the CAB is also monitoring the passenger loading done by Korean Airlines and Asiana Airlines, South Korea's national air carriers, as well as airlines from Hong Kong to see if they are violating the bilateral air agreement.
Ortega, the vice-chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) said the board will not allow the violations by foreign airlines to go on.
"They are eating up our flag carrier's market, nobody can help us except us Filipinos," Ortega said.
Earlier, the CAB sent a "show cause order" (warning) to both Eva Air and China Airlines explaining that they have violated the "Six Freedom Rights".
The Six Freedom Rights is an agreement between two countries authorizing the two countries' airlines to fly into the other.
According to Ortega, the CAB will see to it that all air agreements signed with other countries are followed to the letter.
"We have an air agreement with these countries, they have to abide by these agreements, in the same token that our country's flag carrier is abiding by the agreement", Ortega added. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: PAI PING-PING WANTS TO HAVE A CHILD FATHERED BY A NOBEL WINNER

TEXT.P: Well-known Taiwan TV actress Pai Ping-ping said on Wednesday she intends to have a child with a Nobel Prize winner using in vitro fertilization process.
If a Nobel Prize laureate is not available, Pai said, a medical school student will do.
The Republic of China's only Nobel Prize winner is Yuan T. Lee, the current president of Academia Sinica. Lee won the 1986 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

In a press conference promoting her new TV series, Pai, a widow whose only daughter Pai Hsiao-yen was murdered after being kidnapped in a high profile case in 1997, said that although she has adopted several children, she wants to give birth to a child fathered by a Nobel Prize laureate or a medical school student.
Wednesday would be the 20th birthday of Pai Hsiao-yen, said Pai.

Pai's another desire is to continue her schooling at a senior high school. She dropped out of high school because of her family couldn't afford to provide her an education. By receiving a senior high school diploma, Pai said she would fulfill her teen dream.
Pai said she hoped to pursue the two goals after completing the TV series.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PANAMA SIGN PRESS COOPERATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) and the Republic of Panama signed a press cooperation agreement in Taipei on Wednesday to step up bilateral relations.
The agreement was signed by ROC Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Chen Chien-jen and Panamanian Interior and Justice Minister Mariela Sagel.

Chen said at the signing ceremony that Taipei and Panama have maintained close political and economic relations, and the new agreement is certain to further strengthen the friendship of the two countries.

With the signing, Panama became the seventh diplomatic ally to sign a press cooperation pact with the ROC since August 1997. The six others are Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Paraguay, El Salvador, Dominica, and Malawi.
Meanwhile, ROC Premier Vincent Siew met with Sagel on Wednesday and expressed his satisfaction over smooth exchanges and the level of cooperation between the ROC and Panama.
Sagel said that since her arrival in Taipei, she has held talks with Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng and Justice Minister Yeh Chin-fong.
She said that she received several constructive ideas on prison management from her talks with Yeh Chin-fong.
Sagel praised Taipei's National Palace Museum for sending duplicated collection items to Panama for exhibition, saying that the collection will be helpful in promoting ROC-Panama cultural exchanges.
Sagel arrived in Taipei on June 21 for an eight-day visit at the invitation of the GIO. In addition to holding talks with Taipei officials, she will visit major economic and cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD FORGING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: A credit card forging ring was busted in Sanchung City, Taipei County on Wednesday, with three suspects arrested, said police.
In addition to computers and other machines used to make the fake credit cards, police seized 48 phony credit cards, and 350 blank cards when they raided a room used by the ring.
Three suspects, Chen Yung-chuan, 34; Ching An-ping, 29; and Lin Wen-chih, 24 were arrested at the scene. All of them have various criminal records.
The police took action after shadowing Chen, who was wanted for past forgery violations. Law enforcement authorities had been staking out the building for nearly three months.
A preliminary investigation found that the suspects bought the forgery equipment and blank cards from a Hong Kong man, identified only as Peter.
The police estimated the ring has raked in more than NT$20 million (US$619,195) in illegal profits by selling the false cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE US LAWMAKERS WELCOME TAIWAN'S PLAN TO AID KOSOVO

TEXT.P: Another two members of the US Congress have commended the Republic of China's (ROC) US$300 million aid package to help Kosovar refugees, saying Taiwan is most praiseworthy in its willingness to assist other nations.

Rep. Donald M. Payne (D-NJ) spoke on the House floor Tuesday that the US Department of State announced on June 7 that it welcomed Taiwan's plan to offer $300 million to help Kosovar refugees and for reconstruction of Kosovo.

As a major economic power in the Far East, the congressman noted, Taiwan feels that it must not shirk its responsibilities to help other countries in need and "hopes to set a good example for other wealthy nations in the world to extend a helping hand to all those displaced Kosovar refugees."

As a matter of fact, even though Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, Taiwan has always committed itself to help other countries in the Far East and Africa. "Taiwan's willingness to be a donor nation deeply reflects its people's firm commitment to protect and promote human rights and their humanitarian concern for the Kosovar refugees living in exile as well as for the war-torn areas in dire need of reconstruction," added Rep. Payne.

Rep. Shelley Berkley (D-NV) also applauded last Friday the ROC as "a member of the world community for its continued commitment to protecting and promoting human rights." And she submitted the text of President Lee Teng-hui's June 7 statement on the aid package to be printed in the US Congressional Record.
President Lee's announcement of the contribution was "both timely and insightful, fully demonstrating the ROC's concern for peace in the world," said the congresswoman.
Twelve other members of both houses of the US Congress have spoken highly of Taiwan's generous offer to help the Kosovar refugees over the past two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCUSERS OF TAIWANESE CREW REUNITED WITH FAMILY IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Three of the four Filipino sailors who accused Taiwanese officers of throwing three Romanian stowaways overboard in 1996 have been reunited with their families in Halifax, the Canadian Press (CP) reported Wednesday.
The CP quoted Rev. Flemming Holm, who speaks for a group formed to defend the Maersk Dubai seamen, as saying the family of the fourth is expected to arrive within weeks.

All four sailors were granted landed immigrant status after a long fight to stay in Canada. They claimed their lives were at risk back home because they had told authorities that three stowaways had been forced from the Maersk Dubai at sea.
Holm said the first three families actually came to Canada in February but it wasn't made public for fear of too much publicity.
The children are attending schools in the Halifax area and all four men are employed, according to the report.
The captain of the Maersk Dubai has been indicted for negligence by a Taiwanese court but it's unclear when he will go on trial, the CP noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AMERICAN HERITAGE WEEK RECOGNIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An American congressman speaking on the floor of the House of Representative Wednesday applauded the contributions that the Taiwanese-Americans have made to the United States.

Bob Schaffer (R-Co.) in Wednesday's House speech, which has been included in the Congressional Record, also affirmed Taiwan's democratic development and its efforts to protect human rights over the past 10-odd years.

Schaffer said the 500,000 Taiwanese-Americans have made countless and influential contributions to the United States, and their achievements can be easily seen in all areas of American life. The group includes artists, Nobel Prize winners, human rights campaigners and business leaders.

He said the Taiwan American Heritage Week also provides a good opportunity for Americans to recognize Taiwan's democratic development. Since 1987, he said, Republic of China residents have been able to select their own president and enjoy freedom of religion and speech.
Most important, Schaffer noted, the Taiwan American Heritage Week underlines the long-lasting friendship between Taiwan and the United States.
May has been dedicated in the United States as American Asia-Pacific Tradition Month, during which various activities introducing Asian-Pacific cultures were staged.
Beginning this year, one week in May was dedicated as the Taiwan American Heritage Week to exclusively introduce Taiwan to America.

President Bill Clinton sent a congratulatory message to the opening of the Taiwan American Heritage Week, and David Wu (D-Org.) and other congressmen recognized the weeks' special meaning for immigrants from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN COURT DISQUALIFIES ONE NATION'S SENATOR

TEXT.P: The Australian High Court has for the first time declared Britain a foreign country and thus disqualified One Nation party's only candidate elected to the Senate in last October.

The court's landmark declaration automatically annulled the qualification of Heather Hill, a senior One Nation official in Queensland, to become the party's senator on July 1 because she failed to renounce her British citizenship when she was nominated by her party to take part in the October 3 election. She was the only One Nation candidate to win a Senate seat.

The decision came after a Chinese businessman in Sydney challenged Hill's qualification to become a senator. Under Australian law, a considerable number of Australians have dual citizenship, but they must renounce the citizenship of their mother country once they take part in elections.

The High Court will reconvene in Brisbane on Thursday to consider how a recount of the Queensland Senate votes should be carried out. It is believed the recount would give another One Nation candidate -- Len Harris, Hill's Senate seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO DEREGULATE PETROL INDUSTRY

First, to benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country; secondly, to encourage labor without giving cause for complaint; thirdly, to desire for the enjoyments of life without being covetous; fourthly, to be dignified without being supercilious; fifthly, to inspire awe without being severe."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WANTS TO 'PARTICIPATE' IN WORLD PLAN TO ASSIST KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday that the Republic of China wants to "participate" in international efforts to assist Kosovar refugees in Yugoslavia.
Hu made the remark when he was interviewed by a local radio station about the ROC's US$300 million assistance plan for Kosovar refugees, announced by President Lee Teng-hui earlier this month.

Hu said the world has estimated that Kosovo's reconstruction will require US$30 billion over a period of between five and 10 years, adding that it is hoped that the ROC's aid plan can be coordinated with that of the international community.
Taiwan businessmen will also be involved in the US$30 billion plan to solicit business opportunity, he said.

He said that the West is now studying the aid plan for Kosovo's reconstruction and ways to share the responsibility for it. In the future, humanitarian assistance will be provided by private organizations or related agencies under the United Nations.

The reconstruction work will be conducted by the European Union, while the World Bank will be in charge of financing, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) will be responsible for some minor projects, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
