DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES RECLAIM 8,500-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 1.1 percent Thursday to reclaim the psychological 8,500-point level on strong buying of plastics and chemical shares and electronics stocks.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index climbed 96.99 points to close at 8,589.31 points.
A total of 3.72 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$217.07 billion (US$6.71 billion), down from the previous session's NT$229.88 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, plastics and chemical shares posted the largest gains of the day, rising 2.9 percent, followed by electronics issues, which climbed 2 percent. Textile stocks advanced 0.8 percent.

Cement shares and foodstuff issues both fell 0.1 percent, while the financial sector and paper and pulp stocks both suffered a 0.4-percent drop. Construction shares suffered the largest setback of the day, losing 1.4 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market gained 2.02 points to close at 181 points, with a turnover of NT$8.53 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July soared 170 points, ending the day at 8,697 points, with 4,819 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August jumped 138 points to close at 8,670, while those for September rose 125 points, ending the day at 8,680 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 176 and 36, respectively.
December futures surged 150 points to close at 8,680, with 6 contract transactions. Futures for next March went up 106 points and closed at 8,670 points, with 1 contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 8,527 points for July, 8,532 points for August, 8,555 points for September, 8,530 points for December and 8,564 points for next March.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange announced Thursday that it will cease business for one day on July 1, when financial institutions will settle their accounts for the year. The over-the-counter market and futures trading will be suspended for one day as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DOESN'T LIKE TO SEE WORSENING OF BEIJING-WASHINGTON TIES: LIEN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China does not like to see relations between mainland China and the United States worsen and thus lead to regional tension and affect other countries in the Asia-Pacific region, Vice President Lien Chan said on Thursday.
Lien made the statement in an exclusive interview with a four-member delegation from the Dow Jones press group, led by Karen Elliott House, head of the US-based group's international department.
This is the first time in recent months that Lien has been interviewed by a renowned American news organization.

During the one-hour interview, House focused on issues related to the feasibility of Taiwan's participation in the US-initiated Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, top mainland negotiator Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan this autumn and Lien's candidacy for the ROC's next presidency.

House, who oversees all of Dow Jones' overseas publications, including the Asian Wall Street Journal and the CNBC cable service, first asked Lien about recent developments in relations between mainland China and the United States, which have remained at a low ebb since NATO mistakenly bombed mainland China's embassy in Belgrade last month.

Lien said he hopes Washington and Beijing will resolve their disputes or issues through consultations and that neither of them would take any actions to aggravate the situation and increase obstacles to addressing their problems.

"Both the ROC government and people hope to see mainland China and the United States resolve their current disputes in various field in a rational, pragmatic manner," Lien told House, adding that he believes that such an attitude will be conducive to world peace and stability.
Lien went on to say that the ROC appreciates the US concern about mainland China's missile threat to Taiwan and its repeated reaffirmation of no change in its policy toward Taiwan.
"We hope the United States will continue providing us with adequate defensive weapons in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act to maintain military balance in the Taiwan Strait," Lien said.
Noting that mainland China has not renounced its attempts to use force against Taiwan, Lien said Taiwan "reserves" its rights to take part in the TMD project.

Asked about his views on top mainland envoy Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan later this year, Lien said Wang will be the highest-ranking mainland representative to visit the island over the past five decades.

"Wang's visit will mark progress in cross-strait relations," Lien said, adding that the much-anticipated visit will enable Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, to see for himself various aspects of the everyday life here.

Stressing that Wang's Taiwan visit is of great significance to the development of cross-strait relations, Lien said he hopes Wang's visit will help pave the way for resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue to facilitate bilateral exchanges and better protect the rights and interests of the people on both sides of the strait.

Turning to ROC-US relations, Lien said the two countries share many common ideals and interests. "We hope to furtehr reinforce exchanges and cooperation with the United States in various fields on the current basis," he added.

Touching on Taiwan's next presidential election, House asked Lien when he will formally announce his candidacy, and the possibilities of his teaming up with former Taiwan Governor James Soong in next year's presidential election and the possible impact on Lien's presidential bid of Soong's participation in the race as an independent candidate.

Lien said he is not in a position to answer all those questions at the moment because the ruling Kuomintang will not select its presidential candidate until August. Lien, a KMT vice chairman, is widely believed to represent the ruling party in next year's presidential election.

House, a senior, influential American journalist who once received a Pulitzer prize, arrived in Taipei earlier this week to attend a seminar sponsored by the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS SET TO HOST CROSS-STRAIT MEETING IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 24 (CNA) (By Chang Lung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing is set to play host to a meeting between the intermediary body Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), ARATS sources reported on Thursday.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng is scheduled to lead a Taiwan delegation to Beijing Sunday to meet his Beijing counterpart, Li Yafei, to primarily discuss matters regarding the trip to Taiwan this fall of the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan.
ARATS sources said Jan will first meet with Li Sunday evening for a preparatory meeting to work out the agendas for the two rounds of talks scheduled for Monday.
Jan's SEF delegates will meet with the ARATS group led by Li Monday morning and afternoon for the two rounds of talks, which will mainly focus on the details of Wang's Taiwan visit, the sources said.
Jan will then meet with ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei or Secretary-General Zhang Jincheng Monday night or Tuesday morning, according to the sources.
Jan and his party are scheduled to leave Beijing for home Tuesday.

It is unclear whether ARATS will agree to talk about other pragmatic matters, such as fishery disputes and the repatriation of hijackers and illegal mainland Chinese immigrants -- issues Taiwan is eager to discuss with mainland authorities.
The SEF and ARATS are two quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by governments in the two sides to deal with exchanges across the strait in the absence of formal contacts.

The much-talked visit to Taiwan by Wang Dao-han was originally scheduled for last October. It was postponed to this spring, and then again to later in the year, probably October. It will be Wang's first visit to Taiwan.
Wang's Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, visited Beijing last October for a landmark meeting with Beijing authorities.

Koo and Wang first met in Singapore in 1993, marking the one and only high-level meeting between Taiwan and mainland China in 50 years. During the meeting, the two sides established a formula for regular SEF-ARATS gatherings.

The Koo-Wang talks have since been unilaterally suspended by Beijing after the regime there accused President Lee Teng-hui of using his visit to the United States in May 1995 to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST SUSPECTED VIAGRA DEATH REPORTED IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: A man in his 50s in Hsinchu may have died as a result of Viagra-related heart problems, said sources from Chang Kung Memorial Hospital on Thursday.
The man's death is the first suspected of being connected to the "magic pill," which was formally introduced in the country in March this year.

The man was rushed from a Hsinchu hospital to Chang Kung hospital in Linko, Taipei County, in mid-April after he was stricken by an acute myocardial infarction during sex, and about one hour after taking a Viagra pill.
He died of ventricular fibrillation at Chang Kung five days after he was checked into the hospital. He never regained consciousness.
Chang Kung physicians discovered that the man had chronic cardiovascular disease and had been taking heart medicine regularly.

Dr. Chiang Cheng-wen with Chang Kung's Cardiology and General Medicine Department said the cause of death is not yet known, pointing out that sex alone could be dangerous for a man with a heart condition.
Chiang urged people taking heart medicine not to take Viagra rashly or to disregard doctors' instructions.
Basically, the "small blue pill" should not be mixed with heart medicine, he added.
Meanwhile, a Pfizer Taiwan spokesman said the company has not been informed by Chang Kung about the incident.
Pfizer, the manufacturer of the anti-impotence drug, also has no idea where the man obtained the pills, which must be prescribed by hospital doctors, the spokesman noted.

Although a prescription medicine, Viagra so far is not included in the national health insurance plan, which means people taking the drug must pay for it themselves. A single 50-mg Viagra tablet costs an average of NT$500 (US$15).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES PANAMANIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui Thursday received Panamanian Interior and Justice Minister Mariela Sagel, and during the meeting he said the ROC is willing to share its experience to help Panama develop its economy.
Lee exchanged views on a broad range of subjects with Sagel, who is involved in interior, judicial, transportation and communication affairs in Panama.

Lee pointed out that Panama is the bridge between North and South America, and is situated at an ideal geographical position. Consequently the central American country should make use of its advantages to develop itself.

The Panama Canal is especially meaningful to the country, Lee said, adding that the Chinese people have a saying: "Water is wealth." He suggested Panama look at ways to develop its agricultural sector with the aid of canal water.

Sagel expressed gratitude for the warm welcome she has received during her visit, and said she was most impressed with the ROC's development. She said this trip will be a valuable reference to her in the future, and agreed to continue to promote further bilateral exchanges.
Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Chen Chien-jen, Panamanian Ambassador to the ROC Carlos Mendoza and Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih were also present at the meeting.
Sagel arrived in Taipei on Monday for an eight-day visit at the invitation of the GIO. In addition to holding talks with Taiwan officials, she will visit major economic and cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG TO MEET WITH JAMES SOONG BEFORE AUGUST

TEXT.P: John Chang, the ruling Kuomintang's secretary-general said on Thursday he is prepared to meet with former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong before August to discuss Soong's views on the upcoming presidential election.

But Chang told a group of grassroots KMT cadres, among whom Soong is extremely popular, to brace themselves for the failure of attempts to make Soong the running mate of Lien Chan, the incumbent vice president and expected presidential candidate of the ruling party in next year's election.
Chang met with grassroots KMT members in Chiayi County Thursday morning during which the question of whether and when Chang would meet Soong was raised.
Chang said the perfect time for him to meet with Soong would be chosen and that the talks must result in a certain outcome.
As KMT secretary-general, Chang said, it is his duty to meet with Soong.

But Chang said it makes no sense to urge "somebody" to be the KMT's vice presidential candidate if that "somebody" is determined to run for president, Chang said in reference to Soong, who has not publicly declared his candidacy but who has traveled extensively in Taiwan and abroad in what is seen as a pre-campaign tour to drum up support.

Considering that Soong is not only a member of the KMT but also of its Central Standing Committee, it is regretful that he regularly slams his own party, Chang said, urging Soong to communicate his views without criticizing the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT AGRICULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China should proceed according to organizational measures, and relevant formal channels should be established, said a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official Thursday.
Fu Don-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs under MAC, made the remark at a seminar sponsored by MAC and attended by agricultural officials and scholars.
Fu pointed out to reporters that there were differences between Taipei and Beijing over the issue of cross-strait agricultural exchanges.

The mainland authorities have an eye toward acquiring capital and techniques from Taiwan, while the Taiwan side focuses on assisting mainland farmers to improve their living standards and to increase their incomes, instead of increasing productivity, which might result in price plunges that would not improve mainland farmers' living standards, Fu said.

The consensus reached by Taiwan agricultural officials and scholars is that mainland farmers should be offered management and distribution techniques based on Taiwan's agricultural experiences, said the MAC official. The two sides should also establish a cross-strait agricultural exchange mechanism through institutionalized dialogue, and work to prevent the smuggling of agricultural products, he added.

As to whether Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) would touch on agricultural topics in meetings with mainland officials during an upcoming visit to mainland China, Fu responded by pointing out that cross-strait agricultural exchanges were one of eight points of consensus reached during previous cross-strait talks.

Those talks were held in preparation for a meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan. What should be done at the present stage is to prepare well for that meeting, he said.
A delegation of eight or nine members, led by Jan, is expected to head to Beijing Sunday to begin preparations for a meeting between Koo and Wang later this year.
Regarding the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in the southern county of Tainan, Fu said it was caused by the smuggling of cattle into Taiwan from the mainland.

Taipei will not accept vaccines offered by the Chinese mainland, Fu said. Since smuggling was the root of the problem, it would be better to focus on preventing smuggling through joint efforts across the Taiwan Strait, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WITHOUT BEIJING'S MISSILE THREAT, TAIWAN NEED NOT JOIN TMD: LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday there will be no need for the Republic of China to take part in the US-initiated Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system so long as communist China stops missile deployment against Taiwan.
Lee made the remarks while meeting with a four-member delegation from the US-based Dow Jones Group, led by Karen Elliott House, head of the group's international department.
House, a senior, influential American journalist who once received a Pulitzer prize, asked Lee whether Taiwan would participate in the costly TMD project.

In response, Lee said it is unreasonable to demand Taiwan refrain from taking any self-defense measures in the face of mainland China's intensified missile deployment along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan in recent years.

"So long as communist China stops using missiles to threaten us, the ROC need not join the TMD system," Lee noted, adding that if the ROC really takes part in the purely defensive system, it would only help enhance the TMD's strategic values and contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
Lee went on to say that the ROC has finalized bilateral consultations with nearly all of its major trading partners concerning terms for its entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

"Therefore, we earnestly hope that the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body will consider our membership application completely based on our own economic terms," Lee said, adding that the ROC's WTO accession should not hinge on Beijing's membership application.

For her part, House, who interviewed President Lee two years ago, told Lee that she has been impressed by the ROC's progress, particularly in the establishment of a democratic political system, over the past decade.
House arrived in Taipei earlier this week to attend a seminar sponsored by the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University.

House, who oversees Dow Jones' overseas operations, including the Asian Wall Street Journal and CNBC cable service, and her delegation also conducted a one-hour interview with Vice President Lien Chan on Thursday.
The delegation members included Nancy Smith, editorial page editor of the Asian Wall Street Journal, and Russell Flannery, the paper's Taiwan correspondent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.005 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Thursday, closing at 32.353.
The local currency opened at 32.355 and was traded between 32.351 and 32.373.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$273.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTIRE MAINLAND CHINA MAY BE 'TAIWANIZED': LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday that the Republic of China's existence is critical to developments in mainland China, Asia and the entire world.
Lee made the statement while meeting with a delegation from the American Assembly, a public policy research think tank founded by Columbia University in 1950.
The ROC president told his American guests that if Taiwan can establish a peaceful, liberal and prosperous democracy, mainland China is unlikely to maintain its status quo forever.

"Inspired by the Taiwan experience, the whole of mainland China is likely to be 'Taiwanized,'" Lee said, adding that should Taiwan cease to exist, mainland China's hegemony would expand further and pose a serious threat to Asia and the entire world.
Lee went on to say the ROC fully understands that the Clinton administration's "engagement" policy is mainly aimed at pushing mainland China to accept international norms and regulations.
Nevertheless, Lee said, the ROC hopes that the United States will maintain parallel relations with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lee further said the "three wins" concept unveiled by US President Bill Clinton when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited Washington, D.C. in 1997 is same as the ROC's goal.
The "three wins" refer to balanced developments in three sets of bilateral relations -- Taipei-Washington, Washington-Beijing and Taipei-Beijing ties.

Lee said he is hopeful that the US government will fully implement provisions and spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act, further enhance bilateral cooperation for mutual benefits, and help safeguard peace, stability and prosperity in the Taiwan Strait area.

For years, Lee said, the United States has been one of the ROC's most important allies. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Lee said the two countries share the same ideal of upholding democracy, enjoy longstanding friendship and maintain close exchanges and cooperation in economic, cultural, academic and technological fields.
In 1998, ROC-US trade amounted to US$49 billion. Taiwan is now America's seventh largest trading partner, seventh largest import source and export outlet.

The American Assembly has set up a China Factor forum and has sponsored many seminars in the United States and on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, respectively, in recent years to discuss issues related to Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.
The assembly is co-sponsoring in Taipei a seminar on cross-strait ties with the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University.
The assembly delegation to the seminar was led by David Michael Lampton. And its members included Daniel A. Sharp, Ezra F. Vogel, William Clark, Karen Elliott House, and William P. Fuller.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD PRIMARY TO PICK PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, June 24 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will hold primary on Aug. 21 to determine its candidate for the 2000 presidential election, party Secretary-General John Chang said Thursday.
Before the vote, the KMT will stage an endorsement activity among party representatives on Aug. 7 to pick party members eligible for vying in the primary.
Those who intends to vie in the primary must gain at least 218 of the 2,181 party representatives' endorsement.

The endorsement activity will last for five days. The presidential candidate-elect must choose his running mate before Aug. 25 and send the ticket to the party's caucus, slated to meet Aug. 28-29, for confirmation.
Chang went to Chiayi County to meet with grassroots KMT members. He also went to the county's Hua Chi Hospital to visit Yunlin Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung, who is currently a patient.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA OPENS TAIWAN'S FIRST DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PREVENTION CENTER

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday pressed a button to symbolize the start of operations at the Taipei Domestic Violence and Sexual Offense Prevention Center.

Noting the center's motto of offering an entire team's worth of assistance with a single telephone call, Ma announced the beginning of the municipal government's fight against domestic violence, which comes in the wake of the implementation of the new Domestic Violence Prevention Law.

Anyone who suffers from domestic or sexual violence can obtain protection, assistance, medical care, housing and legal advice with just one phone call, Ma said during an address at the center's opening ceremony.

Ma said the center's establishment challenges the traditional Chinese belief that "no laws can run in the family," meaning laws cannot settle domestic disputes. He added that Taiwan is the first Asian country to have written laws concerning domestic affairs.
The Domestic Violence Protection Law took full effect Thursday, after the expiration of a one-year grace period initiated when it was promulgated on June 24, 1998.
The law helps victims of sexual or violent abuse at the hands of spouses or relatives to obtain help, Ma said, noting that the center's next task is to devise efficient assistance measures.

The Taipei domestic violence and sexual offense Prevention Center includes sections that provide a round-the-clock hotline, investigate claims of abuse, provide protection to juveniles and adults, provide medical care and manage administrative affairs. More than 30 social workers will be employed at the center.
All police stations and offices, along with 28 teaching hospitals around the city, have joined in efforts to crack down on domestic violence.

Also on Tuesday, representatives of several women's associations, led by Legislator Pan Wei-kang, who is also chairwoman of the Modern Women's Foundation, jointly applied for a court protection order for a woman whose husband poured sulfuric acid on her.

The woman -- who now goes under the pseudonym Jentung -- married last year into a loveless marriage, Pan said, adding that before the domestic violence law went into effect, police could not become involved in her situation, even after her husband poured sulfuric acid on her, resulting in third-degree burns on more than 25 percent of her body.

In addition to seeking the court order, the groups also released a joint statement in which they said they would invite scholars and experts, as well as public representatives, to review official operations islandwide aimed at preventing domestic violence next month.
The statement said the upcoming review will be focused on the efficiency of the court's protection order, an indispensable means of safeguarding the lives of domestic violence victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE PANEL PASSES PRO-TAIWAN RESOLUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A US House of Representatives subcommittee on Wednesday passed a resolution demanding the secretary of state submit a report to Congress before Jan. 1, 2000 detailing US efforts to help Taiwan join major world organizations.
The Asia-Pacific Subcommittee under the House International Relations Committee unanimously passed the resolution with a voice vote.
The resolution, introduced by Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), will be referred to the House International Relations Committee for approval next week.

According to the resolution, the US secretary of state is required to report to Congress the executive branch's efforts to help Taiwan join major international organizations, particularly the World Health Organization (WHO), as promised in a 1994 Taiwan policy review.
Once the resolution clears the House floor in the future, the executive branch will be obligated to implement it.
The resolution listed major reasons for Taiwan's participation in the WHO. It stressed that Taiwan should have proper and meaningful participation in the WHO.
Several influential House members, including International Relations Committee Chairman Benjamin A. Gilman (R-N.Y.), spoke in support of the resolution during Wednesday's discussion.

On Tuesday, the US Senate passed an authorization bill for the Department of State which requires the secretary of state to submit a report to Congress every six months detailing the executive branch's efforts or measures to help Taiwan join major world organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT IN ARMED FORCES MUSEUM MURDER NABBED

TEXT.P: A soldier of the Republic of China Armed Forces has confessed that he raped and killed a high school girl in the director's office of the Armed Forces Museum last week, police said on Thursday.

Police said the suspect, private first class Kuo Ching-ho, 21, was one of a four-man team of three enlisted men and one officer asked to guard the museum during the Dragon Boat Festival holiday stretching from Friday through Sunday last week.

Kuo told the police that on Saturday afternoon, when there were few visitors in the museum, he followed the victim, Chang Fu-chen, a student at Chingmei Girls' Junior High School who had come to the museum to prepare a school report, to the third floor.

He then offered to give her extra assistance in the director's office, but when he tried to rape her, she put up a fight. Kuo strangled his victim, wrapped her body in black plastic bags, and hid it in the museum. He then rented a car in Shanchung, Taipei County, and fled with a colleague to southern Taiwan before returning to Taipei at around 4 a.m. on Sunday morning.
He then returned to the museum, collected the body, and dumped it in some bushes near a parking lot in Wuchuan Park in Panchiao, Taipei County.
The family of the victim had appealed to the public to help find their daughter since her disappearance.

Police said that Colonel Lee Ming-teh, the museum's director, filed a police report after finding his office in disarray on Monday when he returned from the long weekend holiday. However, to the dismay of the police, he was unaware that it could be a crime scene, and asked his orderly to clean up the mess, thereby destroying any possible evidence.

Chang's family also asked the museum to examine the video tapes taken from the museum's 16 close-circuit security TVs, but it was discovered that Kuo, who was placed in charge of the tapes during the holiday period, could not account for the fact that the tape for Saturday was missing, and that tapes marked June 18 and June 19 were actually recorded on May 19 and May 31, respectively.
The military turned Kuo over to the Panchiao District Court on Thursday morning.
Police said that Kuo, who lived with his mother and stepfather, has no previous convictions. Because he is on active duty, he faces an automatic death sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, N. CAROLINA SIGN BIOTECHNOLOGY COOPERATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chen Xin Technology Development Corp. recently signed an investment agreement with Eno River, a company from the US state of North Carolina, to establish a biotechnology cooperative institute, sources said Wednesday.

According to the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Atlanta, after Chen Xin General Manager Lee Cheng-ming met with US biotechnology company officials on Wednesday, he announced that the company will invest at least US$2.5 million in cooperation with Eno River.
The cooperative agreement includes setting up a joint-investment company, technology transfers, strategic alliances and training exchanges, Lee said.

He said the two companies will sign a contract before December this year to establish the Taiwan-North Carolina Collaboration Institute, which will aim to develop biotechnology cooperation and joint-investment plans.

Lee is among a 28-member biotechnology delegation, led by Republic of China Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-Chien, that is in the United States for a four-day visit. They have come at the invitation of North Carolina Gov. James R. Hunt, Jr.
The delegation arrived in Raleigh, the capital of North Carolina, on Tuesday and was received by business officials from the state government.
The Taiwan visitors met with noted local biotechnology companies, visited the biotechnology research park established by Hunt, and held a seminar with the US companies.

TECO officials pointed out that Taiwan's biotechnology industry is still in its infancy, adding that the delegation's visit to North Carolina marks a new era of biotechnology cooperation between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BULLISH MARKETS FUELING TOURISM BONANZA

TEXT.P: Recent bullish performances by Taiwan's stock market have not only resulted in an upbeat economic mood but also fueled outbound tourism as well, the Taipei Association of Travel Agents said on Thursday.
Recently there have been more than 5,400 applications for passports filed daily -- nearly double the number of daily applications filed in previous months -- said an association spokesman.

According to the association, almost all travel agents around Taiwan are enjoying a bonanza of bookings for overseas tours during the upcoming summer months by Taiwan residents. Trips to Japan, the United States and Southeast Asia are particularly popular, it said.

Sources from the Foreign Ministry's Bureau of Consular Affairs also noted that in recent days, the bureau has received an average of 5,400 applications for new passports daily, compared with an average of 3,000 per day early this year. The increase in applications for passports for children is particularly sharp, bureau officials said.
The travel agents' association said mainland China was the only place where fewer people are seeking to travel to these days.
The association spokesman attributed the decline to hot weather, poor sanitary conditions, and social and economic instability on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU MODEL A REFERENCE FOR CHINA'S UNIFICATION
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 24 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The European Union, which unites 18 countries, could serve as a model for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait of how to proceed with unification, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Wu An-chia said in Bangkok on Wednesday.
Wu made the statement in an English-language speech delivered to an audience of China affairs experts and members of the Thai media.

Before moving toward an united Europe, the 18 countries were first combined under the European Common Market, then gradually introduced into the EU, Wu said. He added that the unification of East and West Germany can also be a reference for Republic of China and mainland China.
However, mainland China has voiced opposition to both examples, Wu noted.

Wu, who is in charge of setting Taiwan's mainland affairs policies, said he expects the political atmosphere between Taipei and Beijing to be eased with the visit to Taiwan this autumn by Wang Daohan, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, although he added that he doubts that the time for political dialogue between the two parties has come.

Wu also pointed out that a summit between ROC President Lee Teng-hui and his mainland Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin during September's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting in New Zealand is out of the question, given Beijing's strategy of opposing the ROC's place in the world community.
Wu and other MAC officials are scheduled to complete their three-day visit to Thailand on Thursday. Their next stop will be the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT EXPRESS SORROW OVER GIRL'S MURDER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan expressed shock and sorrow on Thursday over the murder of a high school girl.

A Presidential Office spokesman said the suspect has done "irreparable damage by murdering the girl," and expressed the hope that he is brought to justice as soon as possible for his "inexcusable" crime.

Meanwhile, a spokeman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said that Defense Minister Tang Fei had extended his sincere apologies to the family of victim Chang Fu-chen and the nation over the public unease created by the incident.
The spokesman said that Tang had reported the matter to Premier Vincent Siew, who asked the MND to handle the case responsibly, pursue it relentlessly, and discipline any personnel found negligent.
Tang was also asked to review thoroughly discipline in the armed forces and take effective measures for its improvment.
The spokesman added that contrary to a local TV report, Tang made no mention of resigning over the incident.
Vice National Defense Minister Sung Li-chuan on Thursday visited the victim's family to express his condolences and extend an apology.

Private First Class Kuo Ching-ho confessed on Thursday to the rape and murder of Chang while she was visiting the Armed Forces Museum on Saturday to collect research material for a paper she was writing.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA TOUTS CREDIT CARDS FOR NEW GRADUATES

TEXT.P: VISA International on Thursday suggested that graduates entering the workforce should accumulate good credit through careful use of credit cards, in order to make future loan applications easier.

Many new graduates are presently entering the workforce for the first time, and with their new-found financial independence, these graduates need to learn how to manage their financial affairs, according to VISA International Taiwan General Manager Chen Chun-jen.
Chen gave the new graduates various suggestions for personal finance management:
-- Select a credit card that suits personal consumption needs, such as a department store or airline credit card;
-- Separate personal and work-related credit card use to make filing expense accounts more convenient;
-- Ask for a temporary raise in credit limit during an emergency;
-- Analyze spending habits by studying the monthly credit statements;
In addition, he pointed out, those who already own credit cards and have maintained good credit records can ask for a higher credit limit once they start working.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATOR LASHES OUT AT `FOREIGN LABOR DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chien Hsi-kai on Thursday lashed out at the government for what he described as the use of foreign laborers to promote relations with other countries.
Chien claimed at a press conference that the approach has exacerbated the jobless problem in Taiwan, which saw its unemployment rate in May reach a 21-year high.
Saying that "foreign labor diplomacy" has had a deep impact on society, the legislator added that advanced countries rarely adopt such measures.
He said the ratio of foreign laborers in Taiwan is already the second-highest in Asia, behind only Singapore, but accused the government of continuing to play its "foreign laborer" card.

In addition to the Filipino, Thai, Malaysian and Indonesian laborers which are already here, Chien said the government is considering the introduction of more foreign laborers from Central and Southern America, North Korea, Vietnam and Macedonia (in the form of Kosovar refugees).

Chien said the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan has already hit 300,000. Claiming that there are 270,000 unemployed laborers in Taiwan, Chien said that there is no more room for any more foreign laborers.
Chien asked the government to review the policy of introducing foreign laborers from Vietnam and Macedonia immediately.

However, Su Hsiu-yi, deputy director of the Employment & Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said that while the CLA has indeed had discussions with Vietnam about introducing foreign laborers, no mention has ever been made about introducing 40,000 Vietnamese workers, as claimed by Chien, and the discussions have since been suspended.

Su also stressed that the introduction of foreign laborers follows strict quotas, and that the decision to employ foreign laborers lies with domestic employers, and not the CLA. He backed his assertion with the example that the government has wanted to introduce foreign laborers from Nicaragua, but discussions in this regard got nowhere because of a lukewarm response from local employers.

Su also dismissed Chien's claims about the Kosovar refugees, pointing out that the government in fact plans to train 2,000 Kosovar refugees in Taiwan, after which they will return to help rebuild Kosovo rather than staying in Taiwan to work.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES DEMANDS MALAYSIA DISMANTLE STRUCTURES IN SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government on Thursday sought the dismantling of Malaysian structures on Pawikan Shoal in the Kalayaan (freedom) Island Group.
A Philippine presidential spokesman said Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon relayed the demand during a call to Malaysian Charge d' Affairs Rahman Badruddin.

The Western Command of the Armed Forces of the Philippines confirmed that Malaysia had constructed a helipad, a two story building, and a radar tower at the southern tip of the disputed Spratly islands.

The Philippine government considers the structures a violation of several agreements, including the ASEAN declaration on the South China Sea signed in Manila on July 22, 1992, the Joint Statement of the Heads of State and Government of ASEAN and China issued in Kuala Lumpur on December 17, 1997 and the Hanoi Declaration of December 1998.

The spokesman said the documents emphasize the need for all claimants to the disputed territory to "exercise self-restraint to create a positive climate for eventual peaceful and mutually satisfactory resolution of all disputes, and to promote peace and stability in the area."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AID PLEDGE TO KOSOVAR REFUGEES RECEIVES WIDE ATTENTION
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 24 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's recent pledge to provide US$300 million in aid for Kosovar refugees received wide attention at a symposium sponsored by the Forum of the Future in Paris on Thursday.

At the symposium, organized to discuss the Kosovo crisis and the region's rehabilitation, Wang Chen-tai, Taipei's representative to Paris, raised ROC President Lee Teng-hui's June 7 announcement of the huge aid pledge.
In response, French Cooperation Minister Charles Josselin described it as an impressive move, and said he believes the international community will be encouraged by Taiwan's move.

Ahigail Friedman, first secretary of the US Embassy in Paris, said that reconstruction and development of the Balkan Peninsula requires international participation, adding that Taiwan's aid will be a great help to the region's stability and development.

Taiwan's aid package for the Kosovar refugees consists of emergency support in the form of food, shelter, medical care and education, short-term accommodation for some refugees in Taiwan with opportunities for job training, and support for Kosovar rehabilitation in coordination with international recovery programs.
The Forum of the Future has been described as "France's think tank," with its members coming from the elite of the nation's political, economic, military, industrial, news media and academic fields.
The symposium was presided over by forum president Jacques Baumel, a parliamentarian.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S THREATS PROMPT CALLS FOR TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: MAC

TEXT.P: Wu An-chai, vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned Beijing on Thursday the stronger the military threat from mainland China, the more popular the call for Taiwan independence will be.

"Prior to Beijing's missile threat in March 1996, only 9 percent of Taiwan's people preferred an overt breaking of relations with the mainland. After that incident, this group of people increased to 21 percent," he said.

Wu, who left Bangkok for Manila after a three-day visit, made the remarks to high-ranking Thai government officials, academicians, journalists and ethnic Chinese community leaders as well as Taiwan investors in the kingdom.

Wu said that surveys show that more than 80 percent of Taiwan people prefer the maintaining of the status quo in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and oppose immediate unification or immediate independence.
However, the surveys also show that the popularity of Taiwan independence is closely related to Mainland China's military threat toward Taiwan, he said.
A bigger space for Taiwan in the international community would also help to alleviate pressure for Taiwan Independence, he pointed out.

According to Wu, many Taiwan people believe that if the name "Republic of China" is not feasible for participating in international organizations, the name "Republic of Taiwan" might be an alternative to gain a role in these organizations.

Analyzing cross-strait relations, Wu said "co-existence, mutual prosperity and cooperation" will contribute to peaceful democratic unification of the two sides and to the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific Region.
In terms of cross-strait interaction, the ROC government has followed two major tracks -- exchanges and negotiations -- to strive for better relations, he said.
Wu said a gradual process of negotiations will contribute to stability in relations, and will also benefit the people's interests.

Wu urged "Thai friends" to help the ROC fully enjoy the right to take part in international organizations prior to unification, since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are under separate jurisdictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES TWO PATROL BOATS TO PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Wednesday donated two patrol boats to the Paraguayan Navy.
In a ceremony to mark the donation, ROC Ambassador Liu Tin-tsu presented two models of the patrol boats to Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Mecchi.
Speaking at the ceremony, Liu said the donation of the boats, as well as two other patrol boats presented to Paraguay two years ago, underlines the ROC's friendship with Paraguay.
He reiterated Taipei's commitment to cooperating with Asuncion on different fronts, especially in harnessing Paraguay's abundant hydro power resources to boost the country's economic development.
Gonzalez for his part said he admires the contributions made by the two previously donated boats to his country's efforts to beef up defense, crack down on smuggling, and aid in rescue operations.
The two Taiwan-made fiberglass boats, measuring 16.5 meters long by 4.5 meters wide, require a 12-man crew and have a maximum speed of 40 knots.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC FORECASTS 1999 ECONOMIC GROWTH OF 5.15%

TEXT.P: Boosted by improving economic prospects, the Central Bank of China (CBC) estimates that Taiwan's economy will grow by 5.15 percent this year, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said on Thursday.

The figure underlines the CBC's new confidence in the island's economy compared to its March forecast of 4.8 percent, and the 5.07 percent growth predicted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.
The CBC revised its forecast following an upward trend in Taiwan's exports, coupled with a more rapid than expected stock market recovery, and a rise in industrial indexes, said Perng.

Taiwan's exports, measured in US dollars, have grown by 5 percent in the first five months of this year, while public projects financed by the government are pushing ahead as scheduled, which points to brighter economic prospects, said Perng.
Although the labor market is still slack, with the unemployment rate standing at 2.78 percent in the five-month period, this has helped minimize salary inflation pressure.

Perng said that this. combined with declining import and wholesale prices (with an average drop of 8.67 percent and 7.13 percent, respectively, in the January-May period), will speed up economic expansion.

With the declining unit labor cost and the slow climb of average rents, which influences consumer prices heavily, the CBC predicted a moderate 1.06 percent rise in consumer prices for this year, compared to 0.48 percent for the first five months of the year, said Perng.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.2 MILLION SURF INTERNET IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: The number of Internet users in Taiwan has hit 4.2 million, and they are more optimistic, more willing to air their opinions on public issues, and can recognize more public figures, according to a recent survey.

The telephone poll, conducted by newly launched business magazine "Business Next" among 1,076 persons between June 4-8, found that 68 percent of "digital citizens" -- those who use computers, electronic pagers, or mobile phones and who communicate via e-mail -- believe that they are better off now than before, and 50 percent of them believe they will be even more better off in five years.
Among the "unwired" people -- those who do not use any of the above digital gadgets -- only 33 percent said they think they will be better off in five years.
About 75 percent of the "digital citizens" said they have already chosen their presidential candidate for the 2000 election, compared to 60 percent among the "unwired," according to the poll.

The three favorite presidential hopefuls -- James Soong, Chen Shui-bian and Lien Chan -- garnered 40 percent, 24 percent and 10 percent, respectively, of the support of the "digital people," and 30 percent, 21 percent, and 9 percent, respectively, of the "unwired."
The poll also found that more than 40 percent of the "digital people" think longer work hours do not necessarily drive up productivity.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS TOP BUSINESS GROUP IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group has taken over Lin Yuan Group as the most profitable business group in Taiwan last year, according to a survey of the top 100 business groups in Taiwan published by Business Weekly on Thursday.
Pre-tax profits of Formosa Plastics totaled NT$24.6 billion last year, followed by Lin Yuan with NT$20.7 billion and KMT Management Business Group with NT$19.2 billion.

The China Steel Corp. Yulon Motors, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), United World Chinese Commercial Bank Group, President Group, Kimpo Electronics, and Koo's Group rounded out the top 10 business groups.

Analyzing last year's profits, the survey found that those who focused on their core businesses, such as FPG, China Steel, Yulon Motor, TSMC, United World Chinese Commercial Bank Group, and Kimpo Electronics, made steady gains.

In comparison, the Far Eastern Croup, which has operations spanning textiles, retail, telecommunication services, hotels, and banking businesses, had an overall performance ranked only 71st among the top 100, while its ranking according to pre-tax profit ratio ranked only 52nd.
The same applied to Koo's group, which has also diversified into other areas. Koo's had a ranking in pre-tax profits and ratio of 59th and 49th, respectively.
In terms of business turnover, Lin Yuan Group topped with NT$343.2 billion in 1998, far surpassing that of FPG's NT$240 billion and Shin Kong Group's NT$226.5 billion.
Rounding out the top 10 in terms of business turnover were Acer, Koo's Group, President Group, Yulon Motors, Philips Electronics, China Steel, and KMT Management Business Group.
Including the Far Eastern Group and Evergreen Group, which were ranked 11th and 12th, respectively, 12 local groups had business turnover of over NT$100 billion (US$3.0769 billion) last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE CASE OF "PLASTER CAST BABY' REPORTED

TEXT.P: A hospital in central Taiwan on Thursday reported a rare case of what it described as "plaster cast baby."

The baby boy, who is now four months old, was diagnosed as suffering from cytoplastmic body myopathy, a rare disorder which makes the patients' limbs and back so stiff that they are as immobile as if they have been cast in plaster, said Chen Chao-huei, neonatal division chief of the pediatrics department of the Veterans General Hospital in Taichung.
Compared with average infants, the baby displays fewer facial expressions, and can only move his toes.
The boy, who must rely on an artificial ventilator around the clock, also has to be fed through a nasal gastric tube because of his condition.
Chen said that as far as she knows, there are only around 30 cases worldwide, in various age groups. She added that it is particularly unusual to find the condition in such a young patient.
The doctor said that she is researching literature on similar previous cases to try to find the best form of treatment for the baby, the second child of a mother in her early 30s.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Senior military officers were disciplined over soldier's murder-rape of high school girl at the Armed Forces Museum.
The China Times:
Soldier admits to murder-rape of high school student at the Armed Forces Museum.
The United Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said Taiwan's participation in the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system hinges on mainland China's military deployment.
The Liberty Times:
Defense Minister Tang Fei personally visited the murdered high school student's family to express his deep regret.
The Commons Daily:
President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan urged mainland China to remove missiles deployed along its southeastern coastline opposite Taiwan.
The China Post:
Soldier admits to schoolgirl's murder; Army museum crime sends shockwaves; death penalty seen.
The Taiwan News:
High-speed rail deadline cleared; progress evident but tough obstacles remain.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 25, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th US state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Company turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia in World War II, last viceroy of India, then commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende and other minerals, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration.
1942: Major General Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of US forces in Europe, and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the UN Charter. The ROC, the US, the USSR, France and Britain are made members of the UN Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, a match which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1975: Mozambique becomes independent, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos, and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as US secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: Britain refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist who supports and promotes democracy, to leave mainland China to study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for newsgathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1991: Yugoslavia plunges deeper into political crisis as Slovenia and Croatia declare their independence.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqualung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S DOMINANCE OF PANAMA CANAL SEEN AS A THREAT TO US

TEXT.P: A US congressional delegation that toured Central America in anticipation of the handover of the Panama Canal at the end of this year concluded that mainland China's dominance of the canal represents a threat to US security, according to the delegation's report.

The partly blacked-out report notes that "US and Panamanian security officials stated that Panama has become the central base of operations for Communist China in Latin America. Panama (City) is a Pacific Ocean port, and the canal is vital to commerce between the Asia-Pacific region and the Americas. It is also a vital component to emerging Chinese Communist strategy to dominate the Pacific and to undermine and isolate the United States."
The number two user of the canal after the United States is Japan, with mainland China and Taiwan competing for the third position, said the congressional report.

It pointed out that the unofficial representative of mainland China in Panama is believed to be a senior intelligence officer who operates out of an office on the top floor of a bank building in Panama City, with a staff of 14 assistants.

"Worldwide, China appears to be progressively positioning itself commercially and militarily along the key naval choke points between the Indian Ocean (its bases in Burma), the South China Sea (Hong Kong), the Straits of Malacca (the Spratly Islands and a growing role in Cambodia), the Central Pacific (a major satellite tracking station on Tarawa), the coast of Hawaii (a major ocean mining tract), and the Caribbean (Cuba and the Bahamas); and now the Panama Canal," said the report.

Mainland China's flagship commercial shipping fleet, China Ocean Shipping Co. (COSCO), is directly connected to the mainland Chinese government and People's Liberation Army, and COSCO ships have served as carriers for the massive smuggling of weapons, drugs and illegal aliens to destinations throughout the world.

In addition, COSCO has been used by the mainland Chinese government to ship missiles and components of weapons of mass destruction to such nations as Pakistan and Iran, according to the congressional delegation.

Colombian insurgents have reportedly been conducting raids deep inside Panama, taking advantage of US troop withdrawals, and they are backed and supplied by Cuba, Russia and mainland China, according to the report.

"The growing anti-US/NATO 'strategic partnership' of China and Russia poses an increasing threat. There is a well-documented history of both Russian and Chinese organized crime organizations working as tools of their governments. In Panama, where government corruption is rampant, there is a dangerous convergence of well-financed Chinese and Russian mobs with Cuban government operatives and Latin American drug lords, leftists and narco-terrorist militants," said the congressional delegation.
"This dark partnership is a threat to democracy in Panama and in neighboring countries, and is a direct long-term threat to Mexico and the United States," the report concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXILED E. TIMOR LEADERS ALLOWED TO ATTEND MEETING IN JAKARTA

TEXT.P: The Indonesian government will permit exiled East Timorese independence leader Jose Ramos Horta to set foot in Jakarta for the first time in 23 years to join reconciliation talks between rival factions in the contested territory.

In a dispatch from Dili, capital of East Timor, The Australian reported that Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas announced that three independent activists, including Nobel Peace Prize winner Ramos Horta, would be granted visas to attend talks in Jakarta, reversing his earlier stand of refusing to issue visas for them.

The daily however reported that it is unclear whether Ramos Horta, a Portuguese passport holder and resident of Australia, would be allowed to travel to East Timor after he attends the reconciliation talks in Jakarta, to be chaired by East Timor Catholic bishops Carlos Belo and Basilio do Nascimento.

In another dispatch from Dili, The Sydney Morning Herald reported the United Nations has supported Ramos Horta's decision to fly to Jakarta in an attempt to stem violence in East Timor during the referendum vote.

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan this week indicated that the vote on the future of East Timor would be delayed for at least two weeks from the scheduled date of Aug. 8 because of harassment and intimidation by pro-Indonesian militiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1.6 MILLION AUSTRALIANS FEELING LONELY

TEXT.P: More than 1.6 million Australians aged 15 years and over feel lonely, as they are living alone as a result of changing social conditions, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show almost one-third of Australia's elderly spend an average of 12 hours and 26 minutes of their waking hours alone every day.
Australia has a population of less than 19 million.
Aged Care Western Australia President Vaughan Harding said more and more older people were seeking out home care services, not due to physical need, but because of social dislocation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED UK COP HOLDS HIGH-PAY JOB IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A retired senior British police officer has received an unprecedented pay raise of about A$110,000 (US$73,333) a year, bringing his annual salary to A$425,000 (US$283,333), making him Australia's highest-paid public servant.

Australian media on Friday reported New South Wales Police (NSW) Commissioner Peter Ryan, who retired from the UK police force and was hired by NSW Premier Bob Carr in 1996, was the highest paid official in Australia. His pay is higher than Prime Minister John Howard, who receives an annual salary of more than A$200,000 (US$133,333), according to The Australian newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO LEAVE FOR AUCKLAND FOR APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will head for Auckland, New Zealand on Saturday to attend an annual trade ministers meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Wang will head a 19-member delegation, composed of officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other relevant government agencies, to attend the APEC trade ministers meeting.

The meeting agenda will include APEC's contribution to the World Trade Organization (WTO), progress in trade liberalization, strengthening of market mechanism, promotion of e-commerce, and response to recommendations presented by the APEC Business Advisory Commission.

The participants will also discuss APEC strategy and stance on a new round of WTO trade talks scheduled to open after the third WTO ministerial-level meeting to be held in November aimed at setting the direction for global trade in the new century.
The upcoming APEC trade ministers meeting will be chaired by New Zealand's International Trade Minister Lockwood Smith.

In addition to attending multilateral discussions, Wang will also hold bilateral talks with his counterparts from the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Chile, Thailand, Japan, Vietnam and Russia to discuss issues of mutual concern.

APEC, a regional economic cooperation forum, groups 21 economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, mainland China, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS SUFFER 3.8-PERCENT SETBACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices plunged 3.8 percent Friday as institutional investors locked away profits after recent heavy gains amid cautious sentiment after the total value of margin loans exceeded NT$500 billion (US$15.45 billion).
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index plummeted 323.35 points to 8,265.96, posting the largest index drop this year.
A total of 3.24 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$195.37 billion (US$6.04 billion), down from the previous session's NT$ 217.07 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, losers outnumbered gainers, with both the electronics and financial sectors suffering the largest falls, dropping 4.7 and 4.5 percent, respectively.
Plastics and chemical shares posted a 3-percent loss, textile stocks went down 2.4 percent and cement shares declined 0.3 percent.
Foodstuff issues and construction stocks both gained 0.3 percent, while the paper and pulp sector remained static.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market suffered a 6.24-point drop, ending the day at 174.76 points, with a turnover of NT$8.28 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July dropped 263 points to close at 8,434 points, with 5,512 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August fell 270 points and closed at 8,400 points, while those for September plunged 284 points, closing at 8,395. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 230 and 53, respectively.

December futures suffered a 270-point setback, closing at 8,400 points with 5 contract transactions. Futures for next March plummeted 300 points, ending the day at 8,434 points, with 3 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 8,697 points for July, 8,670 points for August, 8,679 points for September, 8,670 points for December and 8,734 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE EXHIBITORS DENIED VISA TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Organizers of a textile show in Melbourne have accused the Department of Immigration of denying visas to exhibitors from Taiwan, mainland China, India, Pakistan, Egypt and Nepal in the wake of a rising influx of boat people into Australia recently.

The Australian Financial Review on Friday reported that the refusal to grant visas to businessmen from these countries would jeopardize the Textile Clothing Footwear International Exhibition, scheduled to open next Tuesday.

The daily quoted Graeme Selby, managing director of Australian Exhibition Services, as saying that the denial of visas to the exhibitors may be evidence of an immigration crackdown in response to the recent spate of highly publicized arrivals of boat people from mainland China and other places.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS JAPANESE WOMEN DRINK MORE BEER

TEXT.P: Two in three Japanese women are drinking more beer, according to a report by The Australian on Friday.
A survey of 600 Tokyo residents by Kirin reveals women drink alcohol 3.1 times a week.

The survey shows half of the women say they like to drink beer after a bath, while one-third like drinking on planes or trains. Many Japanese women say their favorite thing about drinking a beer is the moment it goes down their throats.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TYPHOONS EXPECTED TO HIT TAIWAN THIS SUMMER

TEXT.P: With the approach of typhoon season, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) warned on Friday that more typhoons are expected to hit Taiwan this summer.

CWB data show that an increasing number of tropical cyclones are being spawned in the northwestern Pacific Ocean, while temperatures in the northern Pacific have risen to 1.13 degrees Celsius above average, the second-highest reading in 30 years.

The bureau predicted that 17 to 19 tropical typhoons are expected to generated in the northwestern Pacific, three to five more than the average number, which indicates that more typhoons might hit Taiwan this summer.
An average of 27 typhoons are generated annually in the northwestern Pacific and South China Sea, three or four of which can be expected to hit Taiwan in July, August and September.
Annual direct losses caused by typhoons average NT$13 billion, accounting for 75 percent of all losses caused by natural disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST JOINT MEETING OF TAIWAN BRITAIN-BUSINESS COUNCIL OPENS

TEXT.P: The first joint meeting of the Taiwan- Britain Business Council (TBBC) opened Friday, with both parties proposing to jointly invest in the vast markets of mainland China and India.

Leslie Koo, co-chairman of the TBBC, said that with the political ties and close commercial relationship between Britain and mainland China and with Taiwan's manufacturing, research and development technology, Taiwan can best enter the mainland market by closely cooperating with Britain.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, Finance Minister Paul Chiu and Ambassador-at-large and Euro-Asia Trade Organization Chairman Jeffery Koo attended the conference, as did British Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) Director Mike Cohen, Confederation of British Industry Director-General Adari Turner and Rolls-Royce Plc. President Colin H. Green.

During his welcoming remarks, Jeffery Koo said Taiwan's overall investment in Britain amounts to only US$20 million, while British businessmen have poured US$90 million into Taiwan. He urged ministerial-level officials from Britain to visit Taiwan and discuss with their Taiwan counterparts ways to boost two-way trade.
In response, Turner of the Confederation of British Industry promised to work toward achieving this goal.

It is believed that ministerial-level exchanges are increasing, said Leslie Koo, noting that British Trade Minister Brian Wilson visited Taiwan for an economic and trade conference last March, while ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang is slated to lead a delegation to Britain next month.
Technological collaboration in the fields of bio-chemistry and aeronautics as well as financial cooperation were also discussed during the conference.
A TBBC Taiwan branch in Taipei was established on June 3, and Friday's conference was the first joint meeting of British and Taiwan TBBC members.
The council will be convened annually and meet alternately in Taiwan and Britain.
Nineteen Taiwanese companies and 16 British companies have been incorporated as TBBC members.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER LEAVES FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu left on Friday for a two-city speech tour in the United States, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Hu will first attend the 11th annual meeting of the North America Taiwan General Chamber of Commerce which is slated to open in Chicago on Saturday. He will then proceed to San Francisco on June 29 where he will give a speech at the World Affairs Council in North California.
Commenting on speculation that his Chicago visit might be aimed at making arrangements for Vice President Lien Chan to visit his alma mater, the University of Chicago, Hu replied "absolutely not."

Because Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, often attends various activities organized by Taiwan businessmen in the United States, it is also expected that Hu will meet Bush during his trip.
The foreign minister is scheduled to return to Taipei on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Friday, closing at 32.352.
The local currency opened at 32.358, and was traded between 32.350 and 32.368.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$361 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC RESURGENCE TO BE STRONGER IN 3RD QUARTER: TIER

TEXT.P: The volume of Taiwan's exports has increased heavily since the first quarter of this year, and is expected to improve further after July, the chief of a local economic institute said on Friday

Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), said the overall recovery in Taiwan's domestic economic recovery started between the end of the first quarter and the beginning of the second quarter, and that it will become even stronger during and after the third quarter.
To date, continued Wu, the resurgence trend is very clear, and the economic growth in 1999 may well achieve the 5.28 percent estimated by TIER in April.

The Central Bank of China (CBC) on Thursday announced an upward revision of its own economic annual growth estimate for the island to 5.15 percent, which is a little higher than the 5.07 percent estimated by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

A survey report for May released by TIER on Friday shows that 39.9 percent of manufacturers expect better economic prospects in the next six months (from June to November), a slight decline from April's survey report of 41.4 percent. However, those expecting worse economic performance declined to 13.5 percent from April's 13.8 percent, and those expecting the situation to remain the same rose to 46.6 percent from April's 44.8 percent.
The TIER official indicated that taken overall, the figures reveal manufacturers hold an optimistic attitude toward domestic economic prospects for the near future.
Since most East Asian countries have now recovered from the Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan's exports to the region are sure to be boosted, Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN GROUP OFFERS TO PROVIDE SHELTER FOR TAIWAN STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: A German animal rights protection group has offered to provide shelter for Taiwan's stray dogs, a local animal rights activist said on Friday.

Shen Rong-chen, president of the ROC Animal Protection Association, said the Germany Animal Protection Association now plans to launch a fund-raising campaign aimed at transporting Taiwan strays to Germany for settlement.
Noting that it takes about NT$10,000 (US$307.7) to send a stray dog to Germany from Taiwan, Shen said the German association has a 1,000-ping shelter for strays. One ping is about 36 square feet.
According to Shen, the German association will first provide shelter to crippled or abused strays.

In May, two German animal rights activists brought to Taiwan 300,000-plus letters written by pet lovers and ordinary people in Germany, Switzerland, Britain and Austria expressing their concern about the Republic of China government's policy toward stray dogs and the situation of Taiwan strays.

At that time, the two German activists -- Dirk Stegen, director of Germany's Karlscuhe animal health research institute, and Christa Schechtl, a wildlife conservation journalist, noted that Taiwan has made some progress in treatment of stray animals.
Nevertheless, they said Taiwan must make further improvement in providing better shelter for healthy stray animals and administering euthanasia for terminally ill strays.

Commenting on the German association's drive to transport Taiwan strays to Germany, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said it hopes animal rights activists at home and abroad can give it more time to handle the stray dog issues.

Taiwan currently has about 1 million stray dogs. "It's no easy task to perfectly resolve problems related to such a large number of strays in a short period of time," said Lee Chin-lung, director of the COA's Animals and Plants Quarantine Bureau.

Lee said the COA has earmarked a budget of NT$80 million in the current fiscal year for handling strays. Moreover, the Cabinet has agreed to subsidize many local city and county governments in building new shelters for stray animals.

Lee said the ROC government has stepped up efforts to improve treatment of strays. "This year, we have given the top priority to personnel training and improving facilities at government-run stray animal shelters."

Lee further said the COA is cooperating with the Ministry of Education and the Environmental Protection Administration to improve treatment of strays and educate the public how to treat stray animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REVIEWS FIRST SIX MONTHS IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou celebrated six months in office on Friday, and in a review of his administrative team's work, said he will build the city's administration from a "show house into a real home."
Deputy mayors Ou Chin-der and Pai Hsiu-hsiung, and all heads of the municipal government departments joined Ma for a press conference to deliver his review.

Ma said he believed that the administration has done a pretty good job over the last 180 days, but pledged to do even better in the future. He also said he has now adjusted to his office, as have all his staff.
On the other hand, Ma did not rule out the possibility of making some changes in his administrative team, but added that the "appropriate time" has not arrived yet.

Ma opened the press conference by thanking the 82,000 members of the municipal government for their hard work over the last six months, but stressed that if the first six months of his four years' term in office represents the first kilometer of a race, Ma said he and his team of "long-distance runners" will continue to exert themselves over the remaining seven kilometers.
He then went on to report on the six major administrative achievements of his administration, and listed six main objectives for the future.

Ma pointed out that between January and May this year, violent crime has declined by 37.58 percent compared to the same period of last year, while burglaries have fallen by 12.99 percent. In the same period, a safe telephone ordering system for taxis, and a Domestic Violence and Sexual Offense Prevention Center have begun operation, he noted.
Traffic control measures implemented by his administration include the elimination of illegal roadway obstructions and strict enforcement of new laws on drunken driving.
Attempts to promote a "digital municipal government," he said, twelve Internet connections have been set up to make data searching for citizens more convenient.

Turning to environmental protection measures, he cited the resolution of the problem of pollution of the Tamsui River by wholesale poultry farms, together with a concrete plan to reduce the number of stray dogs in the city.

In cultural and artistic promotions, the city government is not only preparing for the establishment of a new cultural department, but has also held several large-scale public events such as the Taipei Lantern Festival, he said.

Finally, Ma said, in the care of underprivileged groups, the city government not only held the first religious funeral ceremony for laborers, but also resolved the contentious "diver's symptom" incidents involving workers on the city's underground mass rapid transit lines. In addition, the administration also raised the proportion of aborigines hired as non-public servant employees.

Ma's six major objectives included forward-looking city development plans, living environment safety, sustainable development of the city environment, impartial city society, diversified city culture and participatory city politics.

Important items for future development include completing the mass rapid transit system's Hsintien line, overall monitoring of hillside land use, garbage disposal fee collection, and establishment of the cultural bureau and a citizen's social welfare forum.

In response to the much-discussed issue of transfer of government heads, Ma said that since the Taipei Municipal Council is still in the process of budget examination, the timing is not yet right for personnel transfers.
Ma declined requests to grade his achievements, saying: "I never grade myself, since I cannot be objective while being both player and referee."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SET DATES FOR WANG DAOHAN'S TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China on Friday urged Beijing to present definite dates for its envoy's planned visit to this island in autumn.
Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the appeal during a SEF board meeting.

Koo said Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), accepted his invitation to visit Taiwan this year when he made an ice-melting visit to the mainland last October.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
