Koo said although mainland China tentatively proposed in March that Wang visit Taiwan this autumn, it has so far not come up with a definite itinerary for Wang's trip.
Koo said he hopes that the two sides will be able to finalize an itinerary for Wang's visit during SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng's upcoming trip to Beijing.

Jan will head a SEF delegation to visit Beijing from June 27-29. In addition to working out Wang's itinerary, Koo said he is hopeful that Jan will discuss with ARATS officials several pressing issues related to rights and interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"Those practical issues include repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal immigrants as well as prevention of the spread of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) among cloven-hoofed animals and protection of safety of Taiwan investors in mainland China," Koo said, adding that Beijing should respond to Taiwan's call for resumption of regular SEF-ARATS dialogue as soon as possible.
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and oversees SEF operation, also reiterated its welcome to Wang's planned Taiwan visit.

"We hope Wang can visit Taiwan as early as possible to continue constructive dialogue across the Taiwan Strait," MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said, adding that Taiwan will do its utmost to ensure that Wang's "get to know Taiwan" journey will proceed in a safe, comfortable, sincere and constructive atmosphere.

Sheu said the MAC will be pleased to see SEF-ARATS exchanges increase steadily to forge mutual trust and pave the way for resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue and create an environment conducive to higher-level cross-strait contact and cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SAYS `NO COMMENT' ON LIEN-SOONG TICKET

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Friday declined to comment on the idea of a ruling Kuomintang presidential ticket of Vice President Lien Chan with former Taiwan Governor James Soong as his running-mate in next year's presidential election.

Ma, who held a press conference on Friday to mark six months in office and review his administration's achievements during the period, said he had been too busy running the city and working toward unity and reform of his party, the KMT, to pay attention to media speculation on the presidential candidates.

He expressed the belief that as long as the KMT can unite and reform itself, the party will win the 2000 presidential election. This is how the Taipei mayoral election was won last year, he pointed out.

Responding to public opinion which holds that he is "too honest and sincere," and thus lacks the boldness for a firm administrative hand, Ma replied that he does not "wear dominance on his face," but would rather "apply force with his hands."

He also stressed that he is a man of long-term commitments rather than a "sprinter," and pledged to continue to serve the city. He emphasized that his administration has already done a great deal, not all of which has been explained and broadcast to the public.
Now that his administrative team has finished warming up and had adjusted its pace, he said it is ready to increase its speed in the race toward the next millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-PHILIPPINES TO RESUME MILITARY EXERCISES

TEXT.P: The Republic of the Philippines (RP) and the United States (US) agreed on Friday to resume large scale military war exercises in January or February of next year.

The war exercises between the two countries were suspended in 1994. The agreement to resume them occurred at the opening of the 41st RP-US Mutual Defense Board (MDB) meeting at the AFP Headquarters in Camp Aguinaldo.

In a joint press statement, Armed Forces of the Philippines chief of staff Gen. Joselin B. Nazareno and Admiral Dennis C. Blair, commander in chief, US Pacific Command (CINCPAC), MDB co-chairman, announced that preparations for the war exercise are now in a final draft stage.

Topics discussed during the meeting between the two countries' military officials were regional security assessment, reports of the MDB standing committees, status of the RP-US combined rules of engagement, an update on the review of the MDB concept plan and the result of the RP-US seminar war game "Handa (ready) 99."

Also discussed were the results of the first RP-US-Australia trilateral seminar on humanitarian assistance and disaster relief "Sagip 99", and the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) ratification implementation.
Nazareno who read the joint statement, said the "meeting has been fruitful and rewarding for both treaty allies.
The Philippines and the US signed a Mutual Defense Treaty (MDT) in 1951. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET MAY RISE IN THIRD QUARTER: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market should rise further in the third quarter of this year, said a researcher with the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research on Friday.

Tung Jui-pin, chief of the institute's sixth department, told reporters that judging from Taiwan's current economic fundamentals and the trend of its economic performance, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) is expected to go up during the July-September period.

He said that the TSE weighted price index's registered steady gains the past few months are mainly due to the influx of foreign capital. Tung also pointed out that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are sound.
He predicted that Taiwan's economic performance in the third quarter will be even stronger than it is currently, causing a rise in the local stock market.
The TSE weighted price index plummeted 323.35 points to 8,265.96 on Friday, the largest single-day drop this year.

Tung predicted that the Taiwan stock market will perform even better in 2000, if the presidential election here goes smoothly, the US stock market keeps up a steady performance and the Japanese and mainland Chinese economies do not suffer setbacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAURU WON'T DUMP ROC TO JOIN UN

TEXT.P: The Republic of Nauru will not join the United Nations (UN) at the expense of abandoning its friendly ties with the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
MOFA made the remark after Nauru was not admitted into the UN on June 22 due to opposition from mainland China.
A membership screening committee organized by 15 member countries of the UN Security Council (UNSC) screened the applications of Nauru and Kiribati, two Pacific island nations on June 22.
Beijing, a standing UNSC member, vetoed Nauru's UN membership because of the island country's diplomatic relations with the ROC.
T.J. Shih, director of MOFA's Department of Asia-Pacific Affairs, said Nauru became a member country of the British Commonwealth of Nations on May 1.

Nauru's seeking to join the UN was welcomed by the international community and was totally in accordance with the UN principle of universality, Shih said. He slammed Beijing for blocking Nauru's UN membership, saying international support for the island-country would not change.
Nauru President Rene Harris said in an interview with Canada's Globe and Mail on May 1 that Beijing's move would not prevent his country from maintaining official relations with the ROC.
"We will not abandon our friend and if joining the UN means we must abandon our friendly ties with the ROC, we will not join (the UN)," he added.
Nauru is very satisfied with ROC-Nauru agricultural and fishery cooperative relations and considers the ROC a partner in its development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACT-FINDING MISSION TO VISIT KOSOVO IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private sector has decided to form a fact-finding mission to visit Kosovo to gain a better understanding of the needs of the ethnic Albanian refugees after they returned to their home in the Serb-controlled Yugoslavian province from neighboring regions.

At a meeting held Friday at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), representatives of a dozen social welfare organizations, including World Vision of Taiwan, the ROC Red Cross Society, Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, and Chinese Association for Human Rights, agreed to form a seven-member delegation to visit Kosovo in early July.

It was also decided that all participating charity groups should continue to gather information on refugees' needs through their own channels, while the MOFA will help in financing and helping carry out relief programs, Andrew L. Y. Hsia, head of the MOFA's International Organizations Department, said.

So far, World Vision of Taiwan, which has sent personnel to Kosovo, has raised NT$11.75 million (about US$370,000) in fund, and the MOFA is willing to offer an equal or double amount to jointly realize the varied aid projects, he noted.
According to Hsia, the private sector will play a major role in the first-stage operations of a Republic of China's US$300 million aid package to Kosovo.

Civil charity organizations are in a good position to offer immediate assistance to the refugees, while government organizations will focus on much heavier restructuring plans such as building roads and bridges, and restoring electricity supply, Hsia said.

The ROC embassy in neighboring Macedonia, which has taken a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees following NATO's bombings of Kosovo, will also provide concrete proposals to Taiwan's charity groups to help them proceed with their aid programs, Hsia added. It is understood that winter clothes, blankets, medicine, and wheel chairs are the most wanted items among refugees.
World Vision of Taiwan Chairman C. M. Shao said the Taiwan fact-finding mission, accompanied by officials of an international humanitarian organization, will stay in Kosovo for four or five days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN'S SPEECH ENTERED INTO US CONGRESSIONAL RECORD

TEXT.P: A recent speech by Chairman Koo Chen-fu of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on building a peaceful and stable cross-Taiwan Strait relationship has been recorded in the US congressional record.

In his English-language speech at a panel discussion of the 48th General Assembly of the International Press Institute in Taipei on May 18, Koo echoed the proposal of US Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth that Beijing and Taipei sign "interim agreements" on some practical issues with a view to improving bilateral relations.

The decision to put Koo's speech into the congressional record indicates the US legislative branch's support for Beijing and Taipei signing several "interim agreements" and continuing in constructive dialogues.
Koo remarked that Roth's proposal for signing "interim agreements" does not necessarily call for the signing of an agreement on establishing a "big framework" for cross-strait engagement or talks.
Instead, he said he thinks Roth's suggestion refers to the signing of multiple agreements on issues concerning the rights of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"All these pacts are interim agreements, which are expected to help improve cross-strait relations gradually and steadily," he noted.

On the "one China" issue, Koo said, "It is my view that China is now divided, and both Taiwan and the mainland are parts of China and the two sides are ruled by two distinct political entities, with neither side subordinate to the other."

In his speech, the SEF chairman also mentioned Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's 1995 six-point proposal on normalizing cross-strait relations, and reviewed the results of his talks last October with Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DING BECOMES INT'L CRISIS GROUP TRUSTEE

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Senior Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih recently became a trustee of the International Crisis Group (ICG) under the recommendation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the ministry said on Friday.
The ICG is a non-governmental, non-profit private organization founded in July 1995 with the aim of strengthening the international society's awareness of danger zones that might disrupt world peace.

When the ICG was first established, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-foo served as the ROC trustee. He later passed his position to Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.
Jeffry Koo recently resigned from his post, and Ding took over under MOFA's recommendation.

MOFA Deputy Director of International Organizations Tung Kuo-yu in response to reporter's questions said that the ICG is presently monitoring eight regions in the world, and will later send analysis reports to each nation's president, foreign ministers and press.
The eight regions are Bosnia, Albania, Macedonia, Algeria, the Republic of Burundi, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Cambodia and Yugoslavia.

ROC President Lee Teng-hui on June 7 pledged a US$300 million aid package for the reconstruction of Kosovo, whether the ROC will extend its aid through Ding's position in the ICG is the center of much attention.
Tung said that the ROC has attempted to contact the ICG, but does not know at present how or what role the organization will play in the reconstruction of Kosovo.

He said that ICG is one of Taiwan's choices for channeling the assistance to Kosovo. But he added that since the organization is specialized in crisis prevention rather than relief operations and resconstructrion, whether it is a suitable channel remained to be weighed.

The ICG has 47 trustees on its board, most of whom are renowned international political leaders. They include former presidents, premiers and ministers. Member countries include Belgium, Norway, the US, Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark, Canada and Austria.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY OFF TO CZECH REPUBLIC FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: The first lady of the Republic of China, (ROC), Tseng Wen-fui, left for a private visit to Prague, the Czech Republic Friday night.
The first lady was accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason Hu's wife Shirley Shaw and Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang's wife Helen Huang.

Government sources said that Tseng will take part in various cultural activities while in the Czech Republic. As the visit is a private trip, the Presidential Office and the Foreign Ministry declined to comment.
Although the ROC and the Czech Republic currently do not maintain diplomatic relations, they have a substantive relationship in several areas.
ROC Vice President Lien Chan has visited Prague, and Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel's wife has made a visit to Taipei.

Last month, the ROC Government Information Office's Director-General, Chen Chien-jen, was invited to attend an international book exhibition in Prague. The Czech culture minister also visited Taipei recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASKS ARATS TO HELP PROTECT TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has asked its mainland Chinese counterpart to help protect Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China following a recent murder of a Taiwan businessman there.

SEF Vice Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said on Friday that SEF had already sent a letter on Wednesday to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), demanding it help investigate the murder and pay heed to personal safety and business interest of Taiwan investors in mainland China.
SEF made the request after learning of the death of Tsai Cheng-hsiung, a Taiwan businessman, at his residence in Dalian of the mainland's northeastern province of Liaoning on Sunday, according to Wu.
Meanwhile, Tsai's wife, three children and other relatives are scheduled to leave for Dalian on next Tuesday to take care of his aftermath, he revealed.

According to Wu, SEF was informed of Tsai's death by his brother, Tsai Ching-shan, secretary of Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's Fengshan office in southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung. Tsai Ching-shan was quoted as saying that his younger brother was killed because of trade disputes.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH PRIVATE ENTERPRISES SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: British private enterprises support the Republic of China joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) and support Taiwan's goal of becoming an Asia-Pacific operations center, a British industrialist said Friday.

Adair Turner, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, made the remark while calling on Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu. Turner also said he hopes the ROC will further open its financial market to allow foreign investment.
Turner came to Taiwan to attend the first joint meeting of the Taiwan-Britain Business Council (TBBC).

The TBBC is a regular communication and exchange channel for ranking Taiwan and British business executives. Its main purpose is to promote bilateral technology cooperation, strategy alliance as well as to increase trade opportunities.
Turner, on behalf of British private enterprises, supports the ROC's entry into the WTO as soon as possible in order to further liberalize its market.
He said that British private enterprises were very impressed by the stability of the Taiwan economy during last year's Asian financial turmoil.

Customs house statistics show that Taiwan's trade with Britain in the first five months of this year totaled US$2.13 billion, up 1.5 percent from the same period last year. Of the total, exports to Britain were valued at US$1.42 billion and import reached US$714.70 million, with a trade surplus of US$709.20 million in Taiwan's favor.

The United Kingdom is the ROC's third largest export market in Europe as well as its third largest source of imports. Because Britain encourages foreign investment, Taiwan enterprises have gradually become more and more important to English entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party reached a two-point consensus on constitutional amendments.
The China Times:
Police officers will be held responsible for gravel truck-related accidents in traffic control areas.
The United Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui condemned lax discipline in the military.
The Liberty Times:
The United States offered a US$5 million award for arresting Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.
The Commons Daily:
Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County will cooperate in creating an integrated living environment.
The China Post:
The Taiwan Stock Index (TAIEX) slumps 3.76 percent in biggest one-day loss.
The Taiwan News:
Lien ticket not for me, says Soong.
The Taipei Times:
The World Bank approves controversial loan to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 26, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the fabled Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain, and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, is bestowed with an honorary doctorate by Oxford University. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The US Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students to study in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the UN founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter became effective on Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into the National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to US President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Ghandi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: Strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang, and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Students leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the ROC.
1992: A peoples court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: US forces hit targets in Iraq following a threat to the life of former President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: US RESOLUTION INTRODUCED ON PANAMA CANAL

TEXT.P: US Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-CA) has introduced a House resolution prohibiting US assistance to Panama if a defense site or military installation built or formerly operated by the United States is provided by the Panamanian government to any foreign government-owned entity.

A US congressional delegation that recently toured Central America in anticipation of the handover of the Panama Canal at the end of this year concluded in its report that mainland Chinese dominance of the Panama Canal zone represents a threat to US security.

The US-Panama Security act of 1999, introduced by Hunter on June 16, was referred for consideration to the House Committees on International Relations, Banking and Financial Services, Armed Forces, and Intelligence.

Hunter noted that a recent grant to Hutchison Whampoa, a Hong Kong firm with ties to the Beijing government, of management control of the Panamanian ports at either end of the Panama Canal has raised the specter of the expansion of mainland Chinese political influence in Panama, a situation aggravated by unanswered questions concerning the methods used by the Hong Kong firm to win its bid.

The resolution requires the US president to submit to the Congress a report explaining how Hutchison Whampoa was selected to receive a grant for management control of the Panamanian ports at either end of the Panama Canal, and whether or not the US government had any knowledge of ties between the Hong Kong firm and the Beijing regime.

The bill also requires the secretary of defense to report to the Congress on the extent to which such control by Hutchison Whampoa poses a threat to the security of the United States, and how the US strategic interests with respect to the Panama Canal will continue to be protected after its handover to Panama.

In addition, the resolution requires the director of the Central Intelligence Agency to submit an annual report by March 31 on mainland Chinese intelligence activities against or affecting US interests in Panama.

The resolution also authorizes and directs the US president to confer with the Panamanian government to renegotiate the Panama Canal Treaty and the Treaty Concerning the Permanent Neutrality and Operation of the Panama Canal, or negotiate a new agreement for the purpose of providing the security of the canal into the next century. Any negotiations should include the right to control or prohibit the use of the Panama Canal by hostile powers, terrorist states or criminal groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN EX-OFFICIAL GUILTY OF FRAUD, THEFT

TEXT.P: A former cabinet minister of British Columbia's New Democratic Party government on Friday pleaded guilty to charges of fraud, theft, forgery and breach of trust.
Dave Stupich had been at the center of the so-called "Bingogate" scandal, in which the NDP was accused of funneling lottery money into party coffers.
The scandal helped bring about the resignation of Premier Mike Harcourt even though he wasn't directly involved. It has dogged the current NDP leader and Premier Glen Clark.
Stupich, 77, faced 64 charges, which were dated between 1976 and 1995. He was agriculture minister and briefly finance minister in the NDP government of 1972-1975.
Earlier this month, the NDP announced it would repay part of the money. A total of C$117,948, including interest, has since been repaid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTREAL TO HOST INTERNATIONAL FOOD AND BEVERAGE SHOW

TEXT.P: Canada's Agriculture and Agri-Food Minister Lyle Vanclief announced on Friday that Montreal has been made a permanent host of a prestigious food and beverage show.

Every two years, food and beverage companies from around the globe compete and exhibit at Salon International de l'Alimentation food shows in Paris, Asia and Latin America. The show has opted to add a North American stop to the tour and Montreal has won the honor.

The Quebec Agri-Food Export Club and the Quebec Food Retailers Association, which will host the Montreal show, are associations of Quebec food processors focused on developing trade partnerships worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT RULING SEEN PUSHING AUSTRALIA TOWARD A REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: An Australian High Court ruling disqualifying a One Nation candidate this week of her eligibility to become senator will have a far-reaching impact on Australia's push to become a republic, according to political analysts.

The court made a landmark decision to disqualify Heather Hill, chief adviser to One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, of taking a seat in the Senate on July 1 because she did not renounce her British citizenship when she was nominated as candidate to take part in the October 3 federal election.

Analysts said the Hill case will bolster the argument that the time has arrived for Australians to make their last symbolic break with Britain, which four out of the seven judges at the High Court described as a foreign power.
Other experts said the Hill case will serve as a striking example to many Australians who support their country becoming a republic.
Australia will hold a national referendum in November to decide whether to sever the remaining ties with Britain.
Recent public polls show more than 50 percent of Australian people want a republic. But the monarchist movement in Australia is also quite strong, with support of about 40 percent of the population.

Analysts believe there are still many Australians who have dual nationality, with the number ranging from four to five million. They have no problem so long as they do not run for any elections, but they must renounce their original nationality if they want to become politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCILWOMAN'S FATHER ATTENDS MAINLAND CHINA MURDER TRIAL OPENING

TEXT.P: Eleven months after Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan was murdered in mainland China, her father departed Saturday on the sad journey to the mainland to attend the opening of the trial of his daughter's murderers.
The trial is scheduled to open at a Liaoning provincial court on Monday, and Lin's father is seeking compensation of 44 million renminbi (about NT$170 million) from the perpetrators of the crime.

Four men involved in the case have been turned over to Anshan Intermediate People's Court on various charges of intentional assault, robbery, and unlawful restraining the freedom of movement, but the group's mastermind, Lee Guangzhi, is still at large.

The request for compensation, the highest amount in any previous case filed across the Taiwan Strait, is not expected to be fully met, but it is hoped that it will set a precedent for Taiwan crime victims in the mainland seeking compensation in the future.

Lin Ping-huei, accompanied by his lawyer and an official of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said at the airport before his departure that main priority is to seek justice for the death of his daughter.

Councilwoman Lin, a rising political star in the DPP, traveled with her boyfriend Wei Tien-kang to Dalian in northern mainland China in late July, where they were abducted by armed men and repeatedly given shots of unknown drugs. Wei managed to escape to alert the police, but was too late to save Lin, who died of a drug overdose at a hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT CLOSER TO TAX REFORM

TEXT.P: The Australian government succeeded in pushing the bulk of its tax reform through the Senate committee on Friday night, effectively paving the way for a final "yes" vote on the complete package on Monday.

The Senate committee voted in support of an amended 10 percent goods and services tax (GST), bringing Prime Minister John Howard just one step from completing a 25-year-old odyssey to fundamentally change the tax system in Australia.

Howard said: "This is a major step towards a new tax system for Australia. I can't think of a week where the government has done more solid policy and more gains for the long-term benefit of the country."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER HEADS FOR APEC MEETING IN NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang left for Auckland, New Zealand on Saturday to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Accompanying him to the June 29-30 meeting will be Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Director-General of the Board of Foreign Trade Chen Ruey-long, and 16 other officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other government agencies.

Before boarding an Auckland-bound flight on Saturday afternoon, Wang said he will hold bilateral meetings with ministers of other APEC member states to deepen economic cooperation and seek their support for Taiwan's access to the World Trade Organization.

The meeting agenda will include APEC's contribution to the World Trade Organization (WTO), progress in the early voluntary sectional liberalization program, the strengthening of market mechanisms, promotion of e-commerce, and response to recommendations presented by the APEC Business Advisory Commission.
During the meeting, business leaders will also be invited to attend a round table meeting with the APEC ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY FINDS COCA-COLA WORLD'S MOST VALUABLE BRAND

TEXT.P: Coca-Cola is now the world's most valuable single brand, despite its recent product recall problems in Belgium, with a valuation of US$83.8 billion, according to the first "US$1 billion brands" league table.

The Australian Financial Review on Saturday quoted a survey of the value of 60 global brands worth more than US$1 billion as showing that Microsoft ranks second, with a brand valuation of US$56.7 billion.
The findings also show that Coca-Cola, Gillette and Louis Vuitton are the most effective companies at translating their brand muscle into revenue and profits.
The purpose of the study was to enable companies and investors to assess the contribution of brands to business and their role in delivering long-term shareholder value, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO OFFER HUMANITARIAN AID TO NORTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Australia has hinted that it will provide humanitarian aid to North Korea following landmark talks between senior officials of the two countries in Bangkok on Friday, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.

In a dispatch from Bangkok, the daily reported that the six-hour talks, the first high-level contact since Pyongyang broke diplomatic ties with Canberra in 1975, came amid a renewed round of international efforts to ease tension on the Korean peninsula following recent skirmishes between naval ships of South and North Korea.
The Australian aid is understood to include food and other forms of humanitarian assistance to help North Korea overcome its crippling economic problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND'S ECONOMY GROWS 0.7 PERCENT IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: New Zealand registered an economic growth of 0.7 percent in the first quarter of 1999 compared with the same period of last year, the Australian Financial Review reported on Saturday.
The daily attributed the growth to a rise in internal demand from investment by business on fixed assets and infrastructure. But investment in non-residential buildings dropped.
New Zealand's manufactured exports were still lagging, rising just 0.4 percent from the year-earlier level, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO SET UP MILITARY ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has promised to set up a special committee to investigate various tragic accidents in the military in recent years.
Defense Minister Tang Fei made the promise after the families of several conscripts who died in military accidents staged a demonstration in front of the ministry on Saturday.
The families, who have formed an association to promote human rights in the military, demanded that the MND investigate and unveil the true causes of their sons' death in a more transparent way.

In response, Tang agreed to form a special committee to investigate such incidents. In addition to MND officials, the committee will also include elected representatives, various key opinion leaders, and representatives of the victims' families, in order to enhance transparency and ensure impartiality in the investigative process.

The demonstration took place coincidentally with the convening of a meeting of senior military officers on the streamlining of military discipline after a soldier raped and murdered a high school student inside the Armed Forces Museum in downtown Taipei last Saturday.

The demonstrators wore headbands and carried posters demanding the MND unveil the truth about their sons' accidental deaths while fulfilling their mandatory military service. They blasted the military for failing to keep its investigative processes transparent. As a result, they said, many military-related accidents have remained shrouded in mystery.

Minor clashes erupted between demonstrators and military police when some protesters tried to force their way into the MND building. The Chungcheng branch of the Taipei City Police Headquarters sent dozens of police officers to help maintain law and order at the site.

The clashes ended after Tang assigned several senior military officers to receive representatives of the victims' families and assure them of the MND's determination to streamline military discipline and improve handling of accidents in the military.
Vice Admiral Fang Shou-lu, a senior naval officer, also told the representatives that the MND has already set up a military human rights protection commission, which went into operation in March.

"In response to your request, Minister Tang has also agreed to form a special military accident investigation committee to ensure impartiality and transparency in investigating the true causes of all such accidents," Fang told the representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINES ECONOMIC MEETING POSTPONED
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 26 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The 1999 ROC-Philippines economic cooperation conference, originally slated to be held on July 5 in Taipei, has been postponed, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines said on Friday.
The major reason behind the postponement is that Philippine Trade and Industry Minister Jose Pardo will be attending a meeting in New Zealand at that time, the office said.
It is understood that the two countries are poised to negotiate the renewal of their aviation agreement at the meeting, as the current accord will expire soon.
Manila had expected to hold the aviation talks by the end of this month, but Taipei wanted to discuss the issue at the annual ROC-Philippines economic cooperation conference.
The Philippine side is reportedly hoping to conduct the aviation talks as soon as possible as part of its efforts to help Philippine Airlines grab a larger market share.

Conflict broke out recently between the Philippines and two Taiwan-based airlines, with the Philippine aviation authorities accusing China Airlines and EVA Airways on June 22 of violating the current bilateral agreement by carrying passengers from Manila to Taipei, and onward to the United States.
The Philippine government has demanded an explanation within five days from the two Taiwan-based carriers, warning that if no explanation is offered, they will face sanctions.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HOPES TO SOON WORK OUT DATE FOR ARATS CHIEF'S VISIT

TEXT.P: An official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Saturday that it is now time to work out the date for a much-hyped visit to Taiwan by mainland China's top negotiator with the Republic of China.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng made the remarks as he prepared to depart for the mainland on Sunday for a three-day visit.

Jan and an accompanying SEF delegation is expected to have discussions with the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on the exact date for the visit to Taiwan later this year by ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, as well as the technical issues concerning the repatriation of hijackers, illegal mainland immigrants, and fishery disputes.

Jan said that Wang's visit is crucial to the future of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, and added that SEF hopes that the date can be set as soon as possible so as to facilitate the arrangement of Wang's itinerary and give a clearer picture of his trip to "learn about Taiwan."
Noting that although cross-strait exchanges have been going on for the past 11-and-a-half years, Jan said that proper procedures have yet to be genuinely established for these exchanges.

He said that SEF has set up a provisional itinerary for Wang, covering areas such as culture, religion, agriculture, science, economics, academia and democracy in Taiwan, and that Wang can select the areas in which he is interested, in order to enjoy a "comfortable and constructive" visit.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY HAVE LAME-DUCK PRESIDENT AFTER 2000 ELECTION

TEXT.P: An independent presidential hopeful said on Saturday that Taiwan's next presidential election may produce a lame-duck president.

Hsu Hsin-liang, a former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who broke ranks with Taiwan's largest opposition party last month with an aim to run in next year's presidential election on his own right, made the forecast while attending an event at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex.

Hsu said that if former Taiwan Governor James Soong breaks ranks with the ruling Kuomintang and joins the 2000 presidential race as an independent, none of the candidates in the election will be able to win more than 40 percent of the vote.
Against this backdrop, Hsu predicted that no matter who wins the election, he or she will almost certainly be a lame-duck president.
Moreover, Hsu said Soong's departure from the KMT would result in the splitting of the ruling party and the consequent restructuring of all major Taiwan political parties.
Should that be the case, Hsu further forecast that Taiwan's government after 2000 will be one that transcends party politics, the ethnic divide and the independence/unification controversy.

The outspoken politician went on to say that Soong's stern criticism of the KMT leadership indicates that a "Lien-Soong" ticket is unlikely to become a reality. Lien refers to Vice President Lien Chan who is almost certain to be the KMT's standard bearer in the 2000 presidential election.
Meanwhile, Hsu said he does not believe that incumbent Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, a DPP heavyweight, would team up with Soong in the coming presidential election.
"If a Soong-Chen ticket really appears, it would signify a gradual meltdown of party divide and would eventually lead to party restructuring here," Hsu noted.

Hsu originally planned to accompany a group of child cancer patients on a voyage aboard a naval ship. However, he was forced to drop the plan because of opposition from the Ministry of National Defense, according to a local press report.
Hsu instead showed up at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex to see the child cancer patients off on the specially designed voyage, organized by the private Chou Ta-kuan Cancer Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RAISE INVESTMENT IN PANAMA'S FORT DAVIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considering raising its investment in Panama's Fort Davis Industrial Zone from the current level of US$17 billion to US$20 billion, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Friday.
The CEPD made the announcement after a meeting with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Central and South American Investment Corp.

According to the CEPD, Taiwan's top economic planning government agency, it will also suggest the Panamanian government ease regulations on visa extensions and permanent residency, simplify its procedures and provide greater access to loans for Taiwan businessmen and technical personnel.

It was also decided in the Friday meeting that relevant government agencies will join forces in sponsoring investment seminars in North America, Central America and South America to attract investors to the Fort Davis Industrial Zone.

The Republic of China and Panama signed an memorandum of understanding in 1995, with the two sides agreeing to jointly develop the 100-hectare Fort Davis Industrial Zone, a former US military base. Currently, less than 50 hectares in the compound have been developed by investors with shops there.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS PREDICTS RISING DOMESTIC INVESTMENT IN SECOND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Domestic fixed investment is expected to increase in the second quarter of this year, boosted by a bullish stock market and expanding exports, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) said on Friday.

According to DGBAS data, fixed domestic investment in the first quarter dropped 12.5 percent compared to the same period of last year, but the import of capital equipment has increased 12.8 percent since April, while the index for investment goods production has grown 18.4 percent.
This data, together with booming foreign trade, shows that domestic investment in the second quarter is reviving as the country meets the rising export demand.

The DGBAS predicted in May that the domestic investment growth rate for the second quarter would be 1.1 percent, but this figure will further increase, as fixed investment is expected to surpass the originally estimated NT$242.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO LEAD DELEGATION ON MACEDONIA VISIT

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is slated to head a delegation on an official visit to Taiwan's new political ally, Macedonia, with the hope of further cementing ties with the Balkan state.
The delegation, which is scheduled to leave Taiwan on Saturday night, will also travel to Italy, Austria and the Czech Republic to visit those countries' parliaments.

Macedonia has already sent high-level officials, including the premier and the speaker, to Taiwan since the establishment of diplomatic relations on Jan. 27, and Wang has long planned a reciprocal visit. However, the trip has assumed a much higher profile since President Lee Teng-hui's announcement of a US$300 million package to help rebuild the neighboring Yuglosav province of Kosovo and assist the thousands of Kosovar refugees who fled to Macedonia.

This is also Wang's first official visit since he became of Taiwan's legislature, and his delegation will include various legislative officials, including Chang Chun-hsiung and Fong Ting-kuo, the legislative caucus conveners of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and New Party, respectively.
The delegation's first stop will be in Italy, and it is slated to arrive in the Macedonian capital of Skopje on July 3. It will return to Taiwan on July 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAPE AND MURDER SCANDAL SHAMES ARMED FORCES: DEFENSE HEAD

TEXT.P: The rape and murder of a Taipei schoolgirl by an army private has tarnished the image of the armed forces, making the military ashamed to face their fellow countrymen, said Tang Fei, minister of national defense, on Saturday.

In an urgent meeting organized to discuss ways to tighten military discipline, Tang said that the scandal has undone the military's efforts to earn the respect of the public by protecting the county and its people.
The meeting was called after a girl was raped and murdered by a soldier at the Military Historical Museum in Taipei on June 19.
The soldier, a private assigned to the museum as a handyman, lured the girl into the office of the curator when no one was around and strangled her to death during an attempted sexual assault.
The incident has caused a public uproar, as the museum is within a maximum-security complex that includes the Ministry of National Defense and the Presidential Office.
Since the murder the military has been strongly criticized by the media for its lax discipline.

Tang told a group of top military officials at the meeting that although he personally conveyed his apologies and sympathies to the girl's family on Friday, there is no way to compensate them for their loss.
The minister has also extended his apologies and sympathies to the girl's classmates and the principal of the school she attended.

Noting that the military is supposed to protect the people, and that military barracks are supposed to be a safe place, Tang said he regretted that a man in uniform did the opposite by assaulting a civilian in the office of a military agency, adding that the man's actions have made barracks a dangerous place in the eyes of the people.

It is an axiom beyond dispute that the military's combat capability depends much on its discipline, Tang said, noting that the scandal has exposed a lapse of morals and a type of mismanagement that will undoubtedly undermine the troop's combat effectiveness. He urged military leaders to search for and close all loopholes in regard to military discipline.
Echoing Tang's remarks that the scandal has tarnished the military's image, Gen. Tang Yiau-min, chief of general staff, outlined at the meeting a plan to improve discipline.

In addition to bringing those responsible for the murder to justice, Gen. Tang Yiau-min ordered a stepping up of legal education in the armed forces. He asked that the girl's murder be used as an example to teach military personnel ways of preventing such an event from happening in the future.
The campaign should be targeted at those who are assigned as handymen to non-combat units, said Gen. Tang Yiau-min.
The units that provide such men should vouch for their good conduct and be held responsible for their wrongdoings, he said.
The main jobs of soldiers are combat and training. Any non-combat assignments to soldiers should conform to their skill and talents, he said.
He also ordered the establishment of a strict conduct code between male and female military personnel to protect the many women in Taiwan's armed forces.

To mete out administrative punishment more quickly, he called for revisions of military rules to allow authorities to take quick disciplinary action without becoming bogged down in time-consuming legal procedures.
He urged military commanders of various levels to take responsibility for the wrongdoings of their subordinates.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND-QUARTER TRADE SURPLUS ESTIMATED AT US$3.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second-quarter trade surplus has been estimated at US$3.6 billion, largely up from the US$1.3 billion posted in the same period of 1998, the Ministry of Finance reported on Saturday.

Taiwan's exports are expected to total US$29.2 billion for the second quarter of this year, up 6 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, which represents the largest increase rate over the past six quarters, ranking ministry officials said.
At the same time, the island's imports will hit around US$25.6 billion for the same three-month period, a drop of 2.4 percent on a year-to-year basis, the smallest drop in recent five quarters.
Fueled by an apparent economic recovery in Asia and at home, both Taiwan's export and import sectors are expected to further grow in the third quarter, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINI COUNTRY SCHOOL HAS UNIQUE COMMENCEMENT CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Twelve students celebrated their graduation from a suburban primary school in Taipei in a unique manner on Saturday.

The Pingteng Primary School in Yangmingshan area is a true-to-form mini country school. The school is said to be very attentive to the distinctive needs of each of the dozen students in the graduating class.

For their graduation, the students were presented with seedlings and flower seeds by the school. The school made a deal with them that they would bring back the grown-up trees and flowers for transplant to the school campus in two or there years, signifying that their links with their school will never be cut.

The Pingteng school community's mood was one of joy and happiness on Saturday. The sound of gongs and drums spread across the community of Pingteng borough in the morning. The graduation celebrations included a mock wedding, with two second-grade students posing as the bride and bridegroom in a traditional Chinese wedding.

The 12 graduates followed the bridal sedan chair. They distributed candies and sweets along the way as a way of sharing their joy with the neighborhood. They were greeted by well-wishers as they walked along.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST PATROLLING ADMINISTRATION TO BE INAUGURATED AHEAD OF SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: The proposed national coastal patrolling administration might be inaugurated ahead of its original Jan. 1 schedule if its organizational statute cruises through the legislature soon, said officials.

Given the increasingly rampant smuggling between Taiwan and mainland China, the officials said the Executive Yuan has instructed the Ministry of National Defense to come up with a bill on the new administration's organization.

The proposed coastal patrolling administration will integrate the existing Coastal Guard Command under the Ministry of National Defense, the anti-smuggling arms of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, and the Marine Police under the National Police Administration, with a force of some 20,000.
The new administration will report directly to the Executive Yuan with its head having a rank equivalent to that of a Cabinet minister, said the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HAILS KAOHSIUNG'S DECISION TO SUSPEND LOTTERY LAUNCH

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Saturday hailed Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh's decision to suspend the planned July 1 launch of the second issue of the Kaohsiung City Government's welfare lottery.

"It's a right and wise decision," government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said, adding that the Cabinet fully supports Hsieh's decision and is willing to communicate with the city government over the lottery issue.

If necessary, Chen said, the Cabinet will assist the Kaohsiung City Government in resolving issues resulting from the suspension of the planned lottery launch, such as compensation for losses incurred by lottery distributors.

Noting that both central and local-level governments are obligated to serve the people, Chen said the Cabinet hopes to join forces with all city and county governments to help underprivileged groups improve their living conditions.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu also expressed welcome to Hsieh's decision, saying it is good news and a good policy.

Chiu said he understands that Hsieh's decision to issue the welfare lottery was aimed at helping disabled people earn a living. "If the welfare lottery is issued by the central government and sold around the island, more handicapped persons and members of other underprivileged groups will benefit from the lottery and our society will also become more harmonious," he noted.

Asked whether the Ministry of Finance will withdraw its complaint against the Kaohsiung City Government over the lottery issue, Chiu said it's up to judicial authorities to decide how to handle the issue.
The ministry filed a complaint with the Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office after the city government issued its first welfare lottery on an experimental basis on June 14.

Hsieh, a heavyweight from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, announced on Saturday that the Kaohsiung City Government will postpone the launch of the formal version of its welfare lottery because there are no channels for the lottery tickets, printed overseas, to enter Taiwan.
The mayor of the southern Taiwan port city originally planned to formally launch the lottery on July 1.
Hsieh reiterated the city government's determination to hold the lottery, saying the lottery will be launched "as soon as the tickets arrive."

The resourceful lawyer-turned-politician said he is willing to further discuss the lottery issue with the central government. Nevertheless, Hsieh said he does not rule out the possibility of printing lottery tickets in Taiwan to facilitate its launch if the Ministry of Finance fails to make a positive response to his goodwill gesture.
The Kaohsiung City Government's kept secret the location where the lottery tickets are being printed but has admitted that it is outside Taiwan.
The Finance Ministry alerted customs offices at Kaohsiung's airport and harbor to prevent the tickets from reaching the city government's building.

Hsieh said the city government originally planned to issue 5 million lottery tickets on July 1. "As a government agency, the city government cannot smuggle the tickets into Taiwan. Therefore, we have to suspend holding of the lottery," he explained.

Hsieh said he will discuss with Finance Ministry officials issues related to the welfare lottery. "I hope the central government will raise the ratio of lottery earnings to local-level governments and that the central government-run nationwide lottery can be formally launched either in august or September," he added.

Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said on Saturday that the ministry will invite officials from the Ministry of the Interior and other relevant government agencies, as well as lottery distributors, and representatives of aboriginal groups and disabled people to a meeting on June 29 to discuss the ministry's upcoming lottery program.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAUDS FORMOSA PLASTICS GROUP'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew praised Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) for completing 80 percent of its difficult and complicated sixth naphtha cracker in the central Taiwan town of Mailiao within six years, sources reported on Saturday.
FPC's construction has not only fueled Taiwan's economic growth, but the company's entrepreneurial and business management has also created an excellent example for Taiwan, Siew said.
Siew made the remarks when he visited the plants with other Cabinet members.

Siew promoted the project to build the industrial complex nine years ago, at which time he was economic affairs minister, he said, adding that it is hard to believe the construction has proceeded so smoothly, considering that it is the first such plant to be built locally and that there were few government regulations related to the plant's construction for FPG to turn to for guidance.

Siew said the petrochemical complex is significant not just for its size but for how FPG strove to accomplish its construction, adding that it illustrates the abundant vigor and determination of Taiwan's private sector.
Siew later toured the complex's facilities and an adjoining harbor with Wang Yung-ching and his brother Wang Yung-tsai, chairman and general manager, respectively, of FPG.

The sixth naphtha cracking plant, whose construction was the largest investment project ever undertaken by the private sector, cost NT$400 billion (US$12.3 billion) to build and occupies 2,600 hectares of land, including 2,134 hectares of reclaimed land.

In addition to 47 refineries and naphtha cracking plants, buildings, dormitories, a hospital and recreation centers, the plant also includes an industrial harbor 24 kilometers deep. The deepest such harbor in Taiwan, it can accommodate ships of up to 260,000 tons.

The complex is expected to produce 21 million tons of crude oil, 3.84 million tons of light oil and 1.5 million tons of ethylene. An estimated business of NT$1 trillion will be generated for middle and downstream industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TERMINALLY ILL CHILDREN TOUR NAVAL SHIPS
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, June 26 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 300 terminally ill children and their parents managed to make a rare tour of two naval ships at the Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan on Saturday.
The tour was organized by the private Chou Ta-kuan Cancer Foundation with the assistance of the country's naval authorities.

The tour was a "dream come true" for many of the terminally ill children. Some of them were moved into tears when they viewed the Navy's marching band and honor guard performances at the Keelung Harbor's No. 5 wharf.
The child patients also boarded two second-generation naval ships to view their weaponry systems and other related facilities.
Naval officers and enlisted men serving on the two ships warmly greeted the child visitors and their families.

The wives of Premier Vincent Siew and Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and several ruling Kuomintang legislators as well as Chou Chin-hua, chairman of the Chou Ta-kuan foundation, accompanied the terminally ill children on their memorable tour of the warships at the Keelung Harbor.
The Chou Ta-kuan foundation was founded by Chou Chin-hua two years ago in memory of his son Ta-kuan who died after a courageous long fight with cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: US BILL ON CONTROL OF HIGH-TECH EXPORTS TO HK CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Wen Wei Po, Beijing's organ newspaper in Hong Kong, Saturday criticized the recent approval by the US Senate of a bill sponsored by Sen. John Ashcroft to restrict exports of strategic US goods to Hong Kong and Macau as a "hegemonic move."

The newspaper said in a signed article that the legislation is clearly biased against Hong Kong, and that it will be harmful to US-Hong Kong trade and exchanges, and to the development of mutual relations.
The legislation came after a US Congressional report said in May that mainland China has used Hong Kong as a conduit for illegally obtaining strategic US goods and technology.

The report by Rep. Christopher Cox also pointed out that military vehicles of the People's Liberation Army carrying strategic materials frequently cross the border between Hong Kong and mainland China.
If enacted, the legislation will impose on Hong Kong and Macau the same export controls that govern sales to mainland China, according to a statement issued by Ashcroft.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST PRIVATE NATURAL GAS POWER PLANT INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power was inaugurated in northern Taiwan on Saturday.
President Lee Teng-hui and Yang Tien-sheng, chairman of the Ever Fortune Group, presided over the inauguration ceremony of Ever Power IPP in Taoyuan County's Luchu township.

The plant, which sits on a plot of about 10 hectares, is a joint venture by Ever Fortune Industries, Japan's Marubeni, Chiao Tung Bank and others. It is estimated that the total amount spent on the plant's construction was NT$20 billion (US$615 million).
When the president pushed a button to signal the inauguration of the plant, a resulting spark set fire to a floral decoration near the stage. The fire was quickly put out.

President Lee noted that the plant's inauguration marks a milestone in the liberalization of Taiwan's power industry, adding that he hoped that the government and the private sector can work together to boost the nation's power supply.

Lee said that with rising demands for electricity and a growing trend of power industry liberalization, the government will continue to push for the private sector to participate in the construction of power plants.
Since the Ministry of Economic Affairs allowed the private sector to become power suppliers, Ever Power has been the first power plant to use natural gas to generate power.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, speaking on the same occasion, said that power needs in Taoyuan County total 2.5 billion watts, but there are only two power plants in the county. Together they can supply only 7 percent of the county's power needs, which means plants outside the county must provide the rest.
He said that Ever Power, which can generate 900 million watts of power, will help relieve the power shortage.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu expressed her appreciation for the Ever Fortune Group's decision to build the facility in Luchu, saying that the construction of the plant will help develop the surrounding area.

Ever Power officials also announced plans to work with the Taoyuan County government to promote local prosperity and to help improve the living quality of the local community through leisure, cultural and other activities.
Also attending the inauguration ceremony were Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng and other government and business leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS REPATRIATED
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, June 26 (CNA) (By Soifa Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of 101 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants were repatriated on Satuday from a detention center in the northeastern coastal county of Ilan.

As eight illegal mainland immigrants allegedly held hostage two police officers at the Ilan detention center last week, the detention center exercised extreme caution in handling the repatriation work.

All illegal mainland immigrants were subject to body searches and their luggages were also carefully inspected. Some dangerous contraband items were uncovered through extensive searches and inspections.
Following Saturday's repatriation, the Ilan center still has more than 200 illegal mainland immigrants waiting for repatriation.
The eight illegal mainland immigrants allegedly involved in the "hostage drama" have been taken into custody by the Ilan District Prosecutor's Office for further questioning.
Meanwhile, the Hsinchu detention center in northern Taiwan also repatriated a batch of about 100 illegal mainland immigrants on Saturday.
Last week, a group of illegal mainland immigrants held on Taiwan's offshore frontline island of Matsu were also repatriated.

Because of mainland China's reluctance to take back illegal mainland immigrants, seized mainland stowaways usually have to wait for several months or even several years before they can be repatriated.
Taiwan has spent a large amount of money taking care of seized illegal mainland immigrants since it opened doors to civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the late 1980s.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 27, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: Jame Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1871: A new system of currency based on the yen is introduced in Japan.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who is born deaf and blind, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads went out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle in aid of South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of the China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hit Hong Kong, whose closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government Spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HEADS DELEGATION TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jing-pyng left Taipei Saturday evening for a visit to Macedonia.
The delegation will also proceed to Italy, Austria and the Czech Republic to visit those countries' parliaments.

The delegation, comprised of 14 lawmakers from the ruling Kuomintang, main opposition Democratic Progressive party (DPP) and New Party (NP) as well as independents, is the largest ever legislative mission to visit Macedonia since Taiwan forged diplomatic ties with the Balkan state n January of this year.
ROC President Lee Teng-hui earlier this month announced a US$300 million aid package to help rebuild Macedonia's neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
Sources revealed that Wang's visit aims to better understand the situation in Macedonia and Kosovo so as to best utilize the aid as required by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PEACE ANGELS' TO VISIT MAINLAND IN MID-JULY

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) presented a flag to the 44 children from all over Taiwan, known as "the angels of peace", prior to their departure for mainland China on July 10.

The unique cross-strait exchange visit is in its eighth year. The children will be in mainland China from July 10-18 under the lead of former Ministry of Education (MOE) Elementary Education Director San Hsiao-lin.
The "angels of peace" will meet local children from Yunnan and Beijing. Their mission is to introduce popular Taiwan dances, songs and native children's games to their hosts.

MAC Cultural and Educational Affairs Director Chao Chieh-fu presented the delegation's honorary leader San with a flag. Chao lauded the visits as helpful to the promotion of goodwill between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Since mainland China and Taiwan have been separated for 50 years, Chao said, a sense of estrangement has arisen between the people. Through private exchanges and reciprocal visits, misunderstandings and estrangement can be mended. Cultural folk-craft visits set a good example for cross-strait exchanges, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABORATORY ABLE TO READ BLACK BOX TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The first laboratory in the Republic of China that can read the data contained in an air craft's black box will be officially inaugurated next month, the Aviation Safety Council (ASC) under the Executive Yuan said on Sunday.
The reading of data in black boxes containing flight data information and voice recordings of the cockpit crew is considered essential in determining the cause of an aircraft crash.

In the past, the ROC has sent black boxes overseas for reading, resulting in a delay of the investigative work into the flight's crash. Language barriers also compromised accurate readings of cockpit voice recorders.

The ASC has tried to step up its ability to determine the cause of flight incidents since it opened in May of last year. It solicited the assistance of plane crash investigative organizations in the United States, Canada, and Australia to set up a laboratory that meets international standards.

Jung Kai, managing director of the Aviation Safety Council, said the laboratory will be completed at the end of this month. Testing of the facility will occur in July with the formal inauguration by the end of July.
Jung said that in the future, except for aged flight recorders or flight recorders from Russian-made planes, around 90 percent of the black boxes on ROC aircraft can be read in the laboratory.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SAYS KMT NEEDS REFORM

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong Saturday said during film director Lee Hsing's birthday celebration that while he is presently a member of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), he hopes that he won't be without a party in the future.
Soong made the remarks during his congratulatory speech at Lee's 70th birthday celebration at the Grand Hotel Saturday evening.
Soong established good relations with members of the entertainment community during his term as the director general of the Government Information Office.

Soong said during his recent contact with the public he realized that "the KMT needs to be reformed, the political situation needs to be reformed and people's lives need to be reformed." He added that the present condition requires a "good man," and he is ready to "fight for the public" in the near future.

In response to proposals that he form a "Soong-Lee" ticket for the upcoming presidential election, Soong happily embraced the director. He lauded Lee for 50 years of accomplishments in the Chinese film industry, adding that he himself has also dedicated his life to politics.
Amid chants of "President Soong," Soong thanked the crowd for their support, and pointed out that the word he hopes to spell out for next year is "This is fair."

DOC.HEADLINE: DETERIORATED US-PRC TIES HARMFUL TO TAIWAN: AIT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Washington-Beijing engagement is not a zero-sum game, and Taiwan's own position becomes more tenuous when US-PRC relations deteriorate, according to the top American liaison official with the Republic of China on Saturday.

Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said in a speech on Saturday that the ROC should be realistic concerning the triangular relationship between Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.

In his speech delivered at the annual conference of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce of North America, Bush said Taiwan does not live in a completely peaceful neighborhood and cannot afford not to be prepared for the worst. He promised, though, the United States will help the ROC prepare.
"Taiwan need not act in a way that excites the worst fears and misperceptions of the other side. Instead it should strive for the best and work to bring it about," he noted.
Indeed, Taiwan has already contributed to economic growth and social welfare on the Chinese mainland, and it serves as a good example of democracy in action, Bush added.
"With creativity and political will, it can foster a more peaceful neighborhood, assuming that the other side is equally creative and forthcoming," Bush continued.

Bush used the speech to give a detailed explanation of the American stance on the so-called "interim agreements" offered by US Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth in March to Taiwan and mainland China.
Roth's plan has the two sides signing agreements on some difficult topics in order to maintain momentum to the long pursuit of peace through dialogue.

Bush said some people fear that maybe Roth had a specific type of agreement in mind; that the United States in effect was imposing such an agreement, and that such an agreement would be bad for Taiwan. Bush stated he thinks these people are over-reacting.
Bush said Roth's "interim agreements" referred to agreements that offer less than an ultimate resolution, are less than comprehensive, not total.
But he (Roth) also had in mind agreements that are objectively achievable, that are meaningful, and that lead to a significant reduction in tensions, Bush noted.

"We agree that a total solution to the Taiwan Strait issue won't occur overnight. But even without a full agreement, would not the people of Taiwan be served by agreements that are possible and which reduce tensions, expand cooperation, and build mutual trust?" Bush said.

He emphasized that it is not for the United States to suggest or dictate a substantive solution to the Taiwan Strait issue. "And indeed, Mr. Roth made clear that it was the two sides themselves, and not the United States, that should reach these agreements, because the sides are the ones who can craft specific solutions which balance their interests while addressing their most pressing concerns," he added.
The key word in Roth's statement, and the word that should have received the most attention, was "creativity," Bush said.
The situation in the Taiwan Strait is more stable than it was three years ago, but it is still not stable -- and that is not in anyone's interest, Bush continued.
"We hope that both sides will demonstrate the creativity to find ways to foster more stability and less tension and to take advantage of the opportunities for cooperation," he stressed.
Bush encouraged Taiwan to approach that effort with a sense of confidence. "In part because it knows that the United States shares those objectives," he said.
Bush said some may ask, "How can Taiwan show confidence and creativity when the PRC is deploying ballistic missiles targeted on Taiwan?" That is a very good question, he said.

"The first answer I would offer is the statement that Secretary of State Albright made in Beijing in March, when she urged the PRC to consider the reactions to its missile deployments and to exercise restraint in these deployments.

"Secretary Albright said, "instead of worrying about a decision that has not been made to deploy defensive technologies that do not yet exist, China should focus its energies on the real source of the problem -- the proliferation of missiles...Nothing would better serve China's interest than using its developing dialogue with Taiwan to build mutual confidence and reduce the perceived need for missiles or missile defense."

"My second answer is that future US decisions on whether to provide Taiwan with TMD, which does not yet exist, will be guided by the Taiwan Relations Act and considerations related to Taiwan's security. The US government has certainly not precluded Taiwan from receiving TMD," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETERIORATED US-PRC TIES (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: So people on Taiwan should not only be confident about their achievements but also be confident about the role and long-standing policy of the United States, Bush said, adding that Washington believes that Taipei and Beijing possess the creativity to resolve the problems between themselves, and will continue to encourage them to do so. But America will not impose a solution of its own.

Moreover, Bush said he believes that people on Taiwan have nothing to fear from United States' approach to cross-strait relations, which is part of Washington's one-China policy. That approach, he said, consists of five principles:
* The United States insists that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved peacefully.
* The (US) Administration believes that constructive and meaningful dialogue and cross-Strait exchanges are the best way to resolve cross-Strait differences.
* Differences should be resolved by the two sides themselves.
* The United States will remain even-handed in its approach to cross-Strait dialogue, and will not apply pressure to either side.

* The Administration believes that any arrangements concluded between Beijing and Taipei should be on a mutually acceptable basis. And because Taiwan is a democratic system, it is the Taiwan public that ultimately must approve any such arrangements.

Bush said there is no doubt that those who speculate that perhaps the crisis in US-PRC relations, triggered by the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on May 7 by US planes, represents an opportunity for the PRC to press for concessions from the United States on issues such as Taiwan, WTO, human rights, Tibet, and non-proliferation.

"These speculations are mistaken," Bush said. "US policy in these areas is determined by clear and long-standing assessments of US national interests and fundamental values.
