Our fundamental interests will not change in reaction to either the bombing error in Belgrade or the Chinese reaction to it," he stressed.

Over the long term, he said, the United States' long-term strategy toward the PRC must be, as President Clinton said in April, "to encourage the right kind of development in China -- to help China grow at home into a strong, prosperous and open society, coming together, not falling apart; to integrate China into institutions that promote global norms on proliferation, trade, the environment, and human rights."

"We of course do not know how the PRC will evolve in the next century. We can neither assume that it will be a constructive player nor that it will be a disruptive spoiler. So we need realism and balance. As President Clinton has stressed, "I believe we have to work for the best, but do it in a way that will never leave us unprepared in the event that our efforts do not succeed."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAINLAND PING-PONG CHAMPION PASSES ON TECHNIQUE IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Former mainland Chinese table tennis champion Di Chianghwa Saturday visited Kinmen island to impart her winning techniques to more than two hundred coaches and players.

Di, along with her two star pupils Zhou Dungyu and Chen Kaichi, who are newly crowned teenage champions on the mainland, went to Kinmen at the invitation of the county's table tennis promotion committee.

Ti won the national women's singles championship in 1964 and is a former coach of mainland's national table tennis team. In her analysis of the techniques, she emphasized spirit, stamina and technique are the three keys to winning.
Most people think that long and tedious practices lead to success, she said. However, she emphasized that brains are needed as well, and "practicing with skill" is the key to championship.

Committee official Yang Shih-ta pointed out that table tennis is the second most popular sport in Kinmen. While the young players are all eager to learn, he said, they lack proper training information.
By inviting renowned coaches to impart lessons, local players greatly benefit, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF'S JAN HOPES TO SET WANG AGENDA DURING BEIJING VISIT

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation from Taiwan arrived in Beijing on Sunday for talks concerning Wang Daohan's fall visit to Taipei.

Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), the head of the delegation, said in Taipei prior to his departure that he was given full authority to discuss with mainland officials all aspects of Wang's itinerary. Wang is mainland China's top negotiator to Taiwan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Jan said following his arrival that he will take a working dinner with his mainland counterpart, ARATS Deputy Secretary-General Li Yafei, to discuss the agenda of their formal talks on Monday.
He and the mission will fly back to Taipei on Tuesday, Jan said.

Jan noted that his Monday talks with Li will also focus on issues concerning rights and interests of the peoples on the two sides, such as the repatriation of hijackers, and illegal mainland immigrants who are often kept at stowaway detention centers for four to five months due to Beijing's reluctance to take them back.

The SEF official said he hopes his Beijing visit will produce fruitful results that not only decide Wang's Taiwan agenda, but also prompt the mainland to follow a cross-strait agreement in 1993 that the two sides conduct dialogue every three months.
The mainland side has never carried out the agreement, Jan said.
Both SEF and ARATS show strong desires to confirm the exact date of Wang's Taiwan trip as the approach of the upcoming Jan-Li meeting, local observers disclosed.

Jan's delegation is made up of senior executives who have been involved in past cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations in the repatriation of hijackers and illegal immigrants, including SEF Director of Legal Services Hsieh Fu-yuan.
Li's team is said to be comprised of Zhou Ning who is in charge of ARATS negotiations with Taiwan, as well as Ma Xiaoguang and Xu Shangding, two ARATS deputy directors from the Research Department.

Jan and Li have not carried out via-s-via talks since March 18, when the two met in Taipei in the hope of drawing out a concrete itinerary of Wang's visit to Taiwan. That meeting only resulted in an idea that autumn is a proper time for Wang and his wife to tour the island for five or six days.
The two sides have been failed continually since to confirm an exact schedule or visit itinerary.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies established by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG'S PLAN TO MEET WITH SOONG CALLED 'EMPTY TALK'

TEXT.P: Former spokesman for the Taiwan Provincial Government Chin Chin-sheng Sunday said Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary General John Chang's recent announcement that he will meet former Taiwan Governor James Soong is "empty talk."

After Soong's recent attack on high-ranking KMT officials, Chang said on Thursday that he will arrange a meeting with Soong as soon as possible to discuss his views on the upcoming presidential election.
Chang has said the meeting will force the KMT to have "important contact" with Soong, and that the ruling party will assume a low-key attitude in its dialogue with Soong in order to avoid conflict.
Chin said that Chang since March has stated his intention to meet with the former governor, but has never followed through.

Chang's recent announcement was simply "empty words" that have no meaning, he said. As for whether Soong will be willing to meet with Chang, Chin replied that he will not answer any "hypothetical questions."

In addition, a legislator who is close to Soong revealed that Soong has began contacting his supporters in the legislature to discuss matters related to his presidential bid. Chin neither affirmed nor denied the legislator's remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY-RUN INSTITUTE UNVEILS UNMANNED AVIATION VEHICLE

TEXT.P: The Chung-shan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) unveiled an unmanned strategic aircraft during its 30th anniversary celebration on Sunday.

Vice President Lien Chan, speaking at the CIST celebration, said that the development of the unmanned aviation vehicle (UAV) was made possible through the institute's past experience in designing high-performance trainer and fighter planes.

Lien noted that the unmanned aircraft will be able to conduct reconnaissance operations round the clock, monitor war zones and locate targets. He added the UAV will help reduce unnecessary deaths and cut costs.
The information collected by the plane could be sent back to ground control stations and command posts enhancing combat capability, said Lien.
The aircraft could also be used for research by the fishing industry and to collect information on ocean pollution and weather trends.
In light of lax coastal control due to a shortage of manpower, the aircraft could also be used to patrol coastal lines, monitor smuggling activities, illegal immigration and drug trafficking.

Lien hailed the CIST's performance over the past three decades, saying that because of its research and development of indigenous weaponry systems, the military has been able to upgrade its capabilities in anti-air, anti-sea, anti-landing and electronic warfare.

The CIST also developed the Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF), land-to-air and air-to-air missiles. Lien encouraged the CIST to continue to develop products that can be used by both the military and civilian sectors of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL- AND MEDIUM-SIZED ENTERPRISES FAVOR DOWNSIZED NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Most small- and medium-sized enterprises want a downsized National Assembly and are opposed to an expansion of its powers, a survey showed on Sunday.

The survey, conducted by Legislator Lai Shih-pao of the opposition New Party, found that small- and medium-sized enterprises responded negatively to the possible expansion of the National Assembly's power.

Up to 75 percent of the polled also said that they feel uneasy about the prospect of constitutional reforms, and that they are against the National Assembly being integrated into a bicameral parliament with the legislature as its lower chamber.
About 40 percent of the enterprises expressed steep opposition to the expansion of the National Assembly's powers.

Half of the survey said that they wanted the National Assembly to be abolished. Half also said that they want to keep it under certain conditions. Among them, 22 percent said that the National Assembly should be marginalized and devoted entirely to the constitutional reforms. Currently, the National Assembly performs ceremonial functions such as the confirmation of president's appointment of grand justices.

Lai noted that the National Assembly in the 1990's revised the constitutional four times. Most significantly, in 1994, when it stripped itself of the right to elect the president, laying the groundwork for the first popular presidential election two years later.
But Lai said that after four constitutional reforms and repeated attempts to reform itself, the National Assembly has actually turned away from the will of the people.
Lai said while it would be difficult to abolish the National Assembly in one stroke, it should be downsized to a body of between 100 and 200 deputies from the current 334 deputies.
A downsized National Assembly should exclusively handle constitutional reforms so as to be closer to the will of the people and political reality, Lai said.
Lai's survey was conducted between June 14 and June 20. Some 350 questionnaires were returned out of 513 distributed.
Meanwhile, KMT and DPP officials are due to meet again on Monday to discuses the way National Assembly deputies will be elected in the future.

The KMT will propose that the number of National Assembly deputies be reduced from the current 334 to 300, with one third of all seats filled through a proportional system. The DPP has demanded a switch to a full proportional system.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN FOR THE FIRST TIME LEADS CHEN IN POLL

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Vice President Lien Chan in a recent poll for the first time gained more support than opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian.

In its most recent poll, the National Will Survey and Research Center found that 28.9 percent of eligible voters will cast their votes for former Taiwan Governor James Soong in the event Soong, Lien, Chen and former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang all enter the presidential race.
Lien gathered 20.4 percent of the respondents' vote, while 17.6 percent selected Chen. However, 29.3 percent either refused to answer the question or said they are still undecided.

If only Lien and Chen are vying for the presidency, 28.8 percent of the respondents said they will vote for Lien, while 24.3 percent said they will elect Chen. A stunning 37.4 percent refused to answer or said they were decided.

When the race involves four candidates, 41 percent said they believe Lien will be elected president, while 19.3 percent predicted Soong will win the election. Only 7.9 percent believed that Chen will win the bid. A total of 30.7 percent were undecided.
The poll found that 80 percent of voters want the candidates to state their platforms on issues, in contrast to only 9 percent who want the candidates to highlight their personal charisma.
Nearly 60 percent do not understand the "supra-party, all-people's government," espoused by Soong, the poll found. Only 38 percent said they understand the concept.
About 69 percent said they have only a vague idea about what Chen Shui-bian's "new middle-of-road" concept means. A smaller 28 percent said they have a firm grasp of the concept, the poll found.
The poll of 2,400 eligible voters around the island was conducted by telephone recently, with an error margin of 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF COMMUNIST PARTY MEMBERS IN CHINA EXCEEDS 60 MILLION

TEXT.P: The number of Communist Party members in mainland China totaled 61 million at the end of last year, accounting for 5.1 percent of the total population, the Xinhua News Agency of Beijing reported Sunday.
The news agency said in a Chinese-language report that the party has 3.5 million local organizations under the supervision of 160,000 local party committees.
Of the party members, 10.29 million are female, accounting for 16.6 percent of the total, the report said, adding that 14.28 million, or 23.1 percent, are under the age of 35.
Some 11.02 million party members, or 17.8 percent of the total, have college or higher educational degrees, the report said.

The total number of party members increased approximately two million between December, 1998 and September, 1997 when the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China was convened, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU APPLAUDS TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN AROUND THE WORLD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 26 (CNA) (By David Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Saturday applauded the contributions Taiwan businessmen have made to the country.

Addressing the opening of the annual conference of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce of North America in Chicago, Hu said he hopes the "customer-oriented and cost-efficient" enterprising spirit espoused by Taiwan business people would someday also be applied to the ROC government's political administration.
A number of ROC officials were guests at the opening dinner of the annual conference, attended by more than 600 Taiwan business people who maintain business or industrial operations in North America.
Chiao Jen-ho, minister of the ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, also saluted the Taiwan businessmen in North America for their commendable contributions to Taiwan.

Chiao said in the past, many people had little confidence in the Republic of China on Taiwan. Nevertheless, Taiwan has managed to weather one crises after another, and now stands tall, thanks in part to the contributions of Taiwan businessmen, he noted.
Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, also delivered a speech at the conference.

Bush clarified the US position toward the ROC in his speech. Bush said that Washington has no intention of forcing Taiwan and mainland China to reach "interim agreements", the term US Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth proposed in March as the way to solve difficult areas in the process of seeking peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Bush reiterated the United States' five principles concerning cross-Strait relations: the US insists that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved peacefully; the US believes that constructive and meaningful dialogue and cross-strait exchanges are the best way to resolve cross-strait differences; the differences should be resolved by the two sides themselves; the US will remain even-handed and will not apply pressure to either side; and any arrangements concluded between Beijing and Taipei should be on a mutually acceptable basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER SUGGESTS TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN EXPAND INTO SE ASIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government should assist domestic manufacturers in expanding into the Southeast Asian market, Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) said Sunday.

CIER made the suggestion in its latest research report on the Southeast Asian industrial restructuring effort following the Asian financial turmoil's harmful effect on Taiwan investment in the region.

CIER said after the Asian financial turmoil, Southeast Asia governments proposed various measures to cope with problems facing them. As a result, the investment climates in Thailand and the Philippines have turned optimistic, while the investment climate in Malaysia has soured. The Indonesian situation depends on the result of its political situation.
Now the best investment destinations for Taiwan businessmen are the Philippines and Vietnam, CIER said.
At present, most Taiwan investments in Southeast Asia are in export-oriented industries. With the expansion of the region's market, local sales in the region have increased gradually.
In the face of increasing competition from mainland Chinese businessmen in the region, the ROC government should assist Taiwan businessmen expand into Southeast Asian markets, CIER suggested.

CIER thought the best strategy currently is for the government to lower trade barriers between the ROC and Southeast Asian nations in order to promote exchanges of commodities, information and personnel.
It suggested the government use the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as a channel to lower regional trade barriers and to further promote regional industrial divisions of labor.

The private academic research institution stressed that the biggest problem for Taiwan businessmen in Southeast Asia is the difficulty in obtaining loans due to the shortage of funds, the increase in bank bankruptcies and the general lowering of banks' lending abilities after the Asian financial turmoil.

CIER thought the government should eliminate investment barriers facing local banks in Southeast Asia. It suggested that the government urge local banks to merge to increase their competitive edge and to streamline their overseas operations, especially in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- SEF and ARATS -- begin a new round of talks on top mainland envoy's Taiwan visit.
The China Times:
The Department of Health said four types of domestic violence violators must be subject to medical treatment.

The Taiwan News:

The Taipei Times:
Envoys meet in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 28, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1491: Henry VIII, king of England famous for having six wives and his rebellion against the Roman Catholic Church, is born.
1776: British are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, the fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1844: Joseph Smith, founder of the Mormon Church, and his brother Hyrum are shot dead by a mob who burst into the prison where they are being held in Illinois.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: The peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Versailles Treaty because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against Chinese communists.
1935: US President Franklin Roosevelt orders a federal gold vault to be built at Fort Knox, Kentucky.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1945: The Ford Motor Company announces that it has accomplished its target number of military vehicles and other supplies for US government use in World War II. The company produced 8,600 bombers, 278,000 jeeps, and 57,000 aircraft engines.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from COMINFORM at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the American government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the navy and air force.
1950: General Douglas McArthur, commander of Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1950: The novice US soccer team beats Britain 1-0 in the first round of the World Cup in Brazil.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of a 17-year-old soccer player Pele, real name Edson Arantes do Nascimento. Pele leads his national team to three World Cup championships (1958, 1962 and 1970).
1970: US troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 Lion members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: Russian troops begin their withdrawal from Chechnya.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention: that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious.

DOC.HEADLINE: FESTIVAL OF AUSTRONESIAN CULTURES OPENS IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: The Festival of Austronesian Cultures in Taitung 1999, the first of its kind, opened Sunday in this eastern Taiwan city with colorful dances and artistic performances by aborigines from eight countries in the Pacific region.

Foreign delegates came from Fiji, Guam, Hawaii, Malaysia, New Zealand, Palau and the Solomon Islands, and were happy to be in Taitung -- home to six of Taiwan's nine major aboriginal tribes. Delegates said they were surprised to find that the music, dances, people and weather here are so similar to those of their own countries.
Many of them said they felt like they are returning to their ancestral homeland.

Speaking at the opening of the eight-day festival on Sunday, Taitung County Chief Chen Chien-nien said he is not 100-percent sure that Taiwan is where New Zealand's Maori originated from, but he is thrilled to see so many anthropologists, scientists and indigenous people from the Pacific region gathering here to celebrate the similarity of indigenous cultures in the region.

Professor Geoffrey Chambers from Victoria University in Wellington declared in a research report last year that the ancestors of New Zealand's Maori and of other Polynesian peoples of the Pacific region came from mainland China. Taiwan would have been the first stop in the emigrants' island-hopping -- a process that occurred centuries or millenniums ago.

Chambers believes the Maori traveled from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia. From there they traveled to the islands of East Polynesia and, then, southwest, eventually settling in New Zealand.

He said in the report that there is an exact living record of these voyages of colonization preserved in the DNA of the travelers' modern-day descendants, who are still living in these places along the route.

During the opening ceremony, Chen and Lin Chen-chih, Taiwan's top cultural official and the chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, donned traditional Taiwan tribal outfits to perform a heaven-and-earth worship ritual under the instruction of a wizard from the Puyuma tribe.

Sunday afternoon, renowned Australian archaeologist and anthropologist Peter Bellwood delivered a keynote speech titled "5,000 Years of Austronesian History and Cultures," while M. Kedite of Australia's Queensland University delivered one titled "Retention of Culture: Isban and Austronesian."
Monday morning Nancy Pollock from Victoria University said in a speech that the foods of the Austronesian people are important evidence of their cultural legacy.
Food bridges cultures among the Austronesia people, she said.

Pollock said that in the Austronesian-speaking regions, food is a symbol of generosity, and the phrase "come to eat" is a universal greeting throughout the Austronesian-speaking population, which inhabits the largest geographic area on earth.

Starchy foods, including rice, taro, tubers and yams, are staple foods of the Austronesian-speaking population, but they are not considered "complete meals" unless coupled with fish, meat or coconut flesh, Pollock said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING-JAPAN TO FORGE TIES THROUGH PERSONNEL EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: A massive personnel exchange program involving 15,000 young professionals will be one of 33 proposals to be presented to mainland Chinese leaders by Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi next month, The Hong Kong Standard reported Monday.
The package intends to lay the foundation for friendly relations between the two Asian neighbors, the report quoted diplomats as saying.
Tokyo will offer to provide most of the funds for the program, the largest ever to be proposed between the two countries.

Tokyo diplomats reportedly said that because of friction concerning Japan's invasion of China during World War II, President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan earlier this year failed to achieve its goal of building a strategic partnership and stable relations for the next century. As a result, many programs scheduled to boost relations were sidelined.
Therefore, Obuchi will put forward a 33-item program to improve relations with Beijing. The highlight is the exchange of young professionals over a five-year period.

According to the report, outstanding young professionals from various government agencies; educational and academic institutes; social and cultural institutions; and the industrial, commercial, banking and financial sectors will join the program to promote better understanding and cooperation between the two countries.
"The exchange program would include short-term and long-term training courses, academic and research cooperation projects among young professionals," it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL INSURANCE CONFERENCE OPENS

TEXT.P: Executives from insurance companies in the Asia-Pacific region gathered in Taipei Monday for the two-day 1999 Strategic Issues Conference.
The Life Insurance Association of the Republic of China, and LOMA and LIMRA of the United States are sponsoring the conference.
Premier Vincent Siew, speaking at the opening of the conference, noted the steady growth of Taiwan's insurance industry, thanks to Taiwan's economic development over the past decades.

Siew said 99.3 percent of Taiwan's population has taken part in an insurance program, and as of last year insurance companies in Taiwan had aggregate disposable capital of NT$1.5 trillion (US$46.6 billion), making the island the world's 14th-largest insurance market.

Siew said that to build up a social security network, Taiwan began a national health insurance program four years ago. As of the end of April this year, 20,870,000 people have taken part in the program. Unemployment insurance program was put into effect in January this year, while a national annuity program is scheduled to begin in 2000.

Tasks facing the industry include the regulation of financial exchanges among insurance and banking groups, the nurturing of insurance professionals, and ensuring insurance operators' resources are well used and effectively coordinated with other social security programs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CANADA SIGN WTO ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has finally signed an agreement with Canada on terms for its entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO), marking a step forward in its bid to join the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

The agreement was signed in Auckland, New Zealand on Monday by ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Bob Speller, secretary of state in charge of parliamentary affairs at Canada's Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade, on behalf of their respective governments, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said.
Taiwan began bilateral consultations with Canada on its WTO membership bid in May 1994, and the two sides finally came to terms after 13 rounds of difficult talks over the past five years.
MOEA officials said Taiwan already finalized bilateral trade consultations with all the 26 WTO contracting parties which had expressed intention to hold such talks.

To date, only Hong Kong has not inked a formal accord with Taiwan on the island's WTO accession terms, even though the two sides have completed all related negotiations for some time. Observers attributed Hong Kong's reluctance to formally sign a WTO pact with Taiwan to the so-called "Beijing factor."
Minister Wang is currently in Auckland to attend the annual trade ministers meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Highlights of the newly signed ROC-Canada WTO agreement are as follows:

-- The ROC agreed to the Canadian demand that tariff rates on 314 agricultural and fishery products, including beef and Corona oil, be lowered; on non-tariff trade barriers, the ROC promised to either allow imports of selected Canadian products under a tariff-quota system, lift the import ban immediately after its WTO entry or fully liberalize its market by the sixth year of its WTO accession.
-- The ROC also agreed to cut tariffs on 764 industrial items, including optical fibers, environmental protection machinery and equipment, plywood, sporting goods and cellular phone systems.

-- As for the service industry, the ROC promised to open its markets for financial, insurance, professional, telecommunications and transportation services based on the results reached in its consultations with WTO contracting parties.
Taiwan applied for WTO membership as an independent customs territory in January 1990. Economics Minister Wang has said Taiwan stands a good chance to join the WTO this year.

However, Beijing has insisted that it should be admitted to the WTO ahead of Taiwan. In consideration of Beijing's such hegemonic attitude, Hong Kong, now mainland China's special administrative region, has been reluctant to ink a formal WTO accord with Taiwan.

Beijing applied to join the WTO in 1986. But it lags far behind Taiwan in its accession terms-related talks. It remains uncertain whether both sides of the Taiwan Strait can be simultaneously admitted to the world trade regulatory body by the turn of the century.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF, ARATS REACH AGREEMENT ON WANG DAOHAN'S TAIWAN VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 28 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China on Monday reached a preliminary agreement on the details of a forthcoming visit to Taiwan by mainland China's top Taiwan negotiator.

According to Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), he and his Beijing counterpart, Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), have agreed that ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan will accept a Taiwan invitation to visit Taiwan either between Sept. 12 and 19 or between Oct. 12 and 19.
The exact date of the visit will be up to Beijing to decide, said Jan.

During Wang's visit, SEF will arrange for Wang to tour the whole of the island -- from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south -- in a bid to help the mainland's top negotiator gain a better understanding of Taiwan in his first, landmark visit, Jan said.
Wang is expected to meet with his Taiwan counterpart, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, for at least two rounds of dialogue, he added.

Jan, who is currently leading a five-member SEF delegation to Beijing for negotiations on Wang's forthcoming visit to Taiwan, said SEF will formally invite ARATS Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Zhang Jincheng to visit Taiwan in either late August or early September, for talks with his SEF counterpart, Shi Hwei-yow. The two will put the finishing touches on plans for Wang's visit.

Jan said SEF will continue to push for cross-strait talks on pragmatic issues including fishery disputes and the repatriation of hijackers and illegal mainland Chinese immigrants. SEF hopes that during the upcoming meeting between Shi and Zhang, these pressing issues will be added to the agenda of the Koo-Wang talks.

Meanwhile, Jan, Li and their respective parties also agreed on Monday that prior to Wang's Taiwan visit, SEF and ARATS will accelerate personnel exchanges between the two intermediary bodies, beginning with a SEF-sponsored visit by a legal group to the mainland, and an ARATS-sponsored agricultural group visit from the mainland to Taiwan.

Since last October SEF has made strenuous efforts to bring Wang to Taiwan, as Taiwan attaches great importance to this visit. But the visit is expected to be mainly symbolic, as cross-Taiwan Strait relations have been at an impasse for over 50 years, Jan noted.
Wang's Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, visited mainland China last October for an ice-breaking meeting with Beijing authorities.

Koo and Wang first met in Singapore in 1993 in the first and only high-level meeting between Taiwan and mainland China in 50 years. During the meeting, the two sides established a formula for regular SEF-ARATS gatherings.

The Koo-Wang talks, however, have since been unilaterally suspended by Beijing after the regime there accused President Lee Teng-hui of using his visit to the United States in May 1995 to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU RULES OUT VICE PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Sunday ruled out the possibility of teaming up with Vice President Lien Chan in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.
Hu reportedly made the statement while being questioned by reporters at the airport.

Hu arrived in San Francisco from Chicago on Sunday afternoon and is slated to deliver speeches on Taiwan's role in the periphery of the Pacific Ocean at a luncheon co-sponsored by two mainstream political organizations in California.
According to Taiwan newspapers, Lien has been in contact with several prospective running mates, including Hu, Premier Vincent Siew and Wu Poh-hsiung, a senior adviser to the president.
Hu said that his running with the current vice president was "out of the question."
Speaking on Taiwan's US$30 million humanitarian aid package to Kosovo, Hu said Taiwan's move is highly valued by the international community.

Since a concrete plan for helping Kosovo to rehabilitate is still under evaluation by politically important countries, it is inappropriate to speculate on whether Taiwan will be permitted to take part in relief efforts directly, Hu said. He added, however, that Taiwan would nevertheless cooperate closely with the international community in the relief mission.

Taiwan will provide US$10 million during the first year of the relief program, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will be responsible for financing the rest of the package with the assistance of other ministries, Hu added.

Before heading for San Francisco, Hu attended the annual conference of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce of North America in Chicago. During the meeting, Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institution in Taiwan delivered a speech on the triangular relationship between Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.
Hu told reporters that Bush made it clear that the United States' stance toward Taiwan will not be affected by any changes in ties between mainland China and the United States.

Bush also said Taiwan need not act in a way that excites to the worst fears and misperceptions of the other side. Hu said he would not speculate on the meaning of the remark and said it was up to the United States to explain its meaning.
"There is no need for Taiwan to change or adjust the direction of foreign policies," Hu said.
Bush and Hu exchanged views after Bush's speech, but Hu declined to name any specific subjects of discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SHARE PRICES, FUTURES UP SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened high but managed to close 0.2 percent higher Monday amid wait-and-see sentiment brimming in the market.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted price index edged up 15.49 points to 8,281.45 on a turnover of NT$123.88 billion (US$3.83 billion).
The financial sector, the textile sector and plastic shares all enjoyed large gains.
Decliners led advancers 257 to 179, with 78 issues unchanged.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market suffered a 0.3-point drop, ending the day at 174.46, with a turnover of NT$5.82 billion.
Trading in the TAIEX International Weighted Price Index futures (TAIEX Index Futures) was mild as investors maintained a wait-and-see attitude towards future developments.

TAIEX Index Futures for July advanced 13 points to close at 8,447, with 2,883 contract transactions, those for August finished at 8,453 points after earlier fluctuations between the 8,480 and 8,384 marks. 113 contract transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for September moved up 55 points to finish at 8,450 with 28 contract transactions, while those for December went down 19 points to 8,410, with 4 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March closed up 13 points to 8,484 with 2 contract transactions. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO WANTED MEN REPATRIATED BACK FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Two men wanted in Taiwan were returned to the island from mainland China on Sunday under an agreement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to jointly crack down on crime.

The two had a long history of criminal activities. You Ming-huei, 31, had a criminal file listing more than 30 cases of robbery since 1988, while Lee Ming-tsai, 41, was wanted for possession of narcotics.

You and Lee, under arrangements made by Red Cross Socities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, were brought from mainland China to face justice in Taiwan via Matsu, according to the Criminal Investigation Bureau.

Matsu, an offshore island opposite mainand's Fujian province, also served as the stop Sunday or the 169 mainland illegal immigrants being repatriated from Taiwan to mainland China, officials of the Matsu detention center said.
The officials said that the repatriated illegal immigrants did not include any who were involved in the disturbance at an Ilan detention center in northeastern Taiwan earlier in the month.
Another 91 mainland stowaways are stilling waiting at the Matsu center for the next round of repatriation operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS CONCERNED ABOUT FIRE INCIDENTS IN HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: Legislators visited the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park on Monday to express their concern about a series of recent industrial incidents in the park.

Approximately 12 incidents involving fires and gas explosions in the park's plants occurred over the past four years. The resulting property losses due to the incidents is estimated at NT$20 billion (US$615 million).

A 10-member delegation, comprised of Legislators Tsai Chia-fu and Chiu Ching-chun and officials from the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), toured the park to review the facility's industrial safety operations.
The delegation noted that the National Fire Administration has nine chemical fire trucks and suggested that one be assigned permanently to the park.
A fire fighting squad using aircraft was also recommended to be established because the park has a large number of tall structures.

The delegation also asked that fire squads in Hsinchu county and city cooperate closely with their counterparts in the park. The three units were recommended to hold joint fire fighting exercises in the near future.

The administration of the Hsinchu Science-based industrial park is also planning to inspect temporary constructions in the park to ward off future fire incidents involving makeshift warehouses like the one that occurred last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-HK TIES IMPROVING BUT NO MAJOR BREAKTHROUGH SEEN YET: MAC

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong have seen positive progress over the past year, but no major breakthroughs have been achieved yet, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

The Cabinet-level council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks in an analytical report marking the second anniversary of Hong Kong's handover from Britain to Beijing on July 1, 1997.

Generally speaking, the report said, Hong Kong's situation has remained stable in the past year. Nevertheless, the report said, Hong Kong faces fundamental changes and challenges in political, economic and social fields due to lingering economic recession caused by a regional financial crisis.

The report cited several of Hong Kong's current woes, including a continued economic slowdown, rising unemployment rate, a Legislative Council-initiated no-confidence vote against senior Hong Kong government officials and challenges to its judicial system.

On Taiwan-Hong Kong ties, the report said the Hong Kong government is still reluctant to forge official contact or engagements with Taiwan apparently because of its consideration of Beijing's attitude.

For instance, the report said although Hong Kong has finalized bilateral consultations with Taiwan on terms for the island's entry to the World Trade Organization, it is unwilling to sign a formal agreement on the issue.

Moreover, the report said, no Hong Kong officials have ever visited Taiwan over the past two years. The Hong Kong government is too conservative in handling relations with Taiwan now that many senior mainland Chinese officials have made visits to Taiwan in recent years, the report said.

As for mainland China's jurisdiction over Hong Kong, the report said Beijing has not explicitly interfered with Hong Kong's internal affairs in order not to cause apprehension among Hong Kong people nor to affect the international community's confidence in Hong Kong.

However, the report said senior Hong Kong officials' habits to speculate on Beijing's attitude and hinge their policy or measures on such speculations have undermined the Hong Kong government's ability to cope with emergencies and may eventually hinder substantiation of Beijing's promise: "Hong Kong people rule Hong Kong and Hong Kong maintains high degree of autonomy."

The report pointed out that the existence of a democratic Taiwan is conducive to the substantiation of Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula in Hong Kong and Macau, a Portuguese colony which will revert to Beijing's rule in December this year.

Noting that Beijing has let the "one country, two systems" formula implement in Hong Kong mainly because it wants to set a model to lure Taiwan to accept the scheme, the report said without Taiwan's existence, Beijing may not bother to initiate the formula.

Nevertheless, the report said Taiwan is not Hong Kong. "Hong Kong used to be colony, while the Republic of China has been an independent sovereign state from the very beginning," the report stressed, adding that the ROC has diplomatic and self-defense capabilities which Hong Kong never has.
Stressing that the ROC's future can only be determined by its people, the report said there is no timetable for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The report went on to say that the ROC government hopes to see Hong Kong maintain stability. "We'll also continue promoting normalization of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations," the report said, adding that the two sides need an institutionalized framework for regular consultations and a more convenient mechanism for bilateral engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC PROSPECT INDICATORS IN MAY HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan's leading composite economic indicator and its coincident composite economic indicator in May hit new highs, according to the latest government figures.

Figures released Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan showed that the leading composite economic indicator in May surged to 100.1 points, a new high since May of last year; meanwhile, the coincident composite economic indicator rebounded to 103.6 points, breaking January 1998's previous record.

In addition, May's leading composite indicator showed the third consecutive month of resurgence, growing 1.3 percent, while the coincident indicator showed a rise of 1.2 percent, turning the CEPD-designed five-color composite economic measurement light to yellow-blue. Yellow-blue represents medium growth.
The CEPD pointed out in view of the fact that various parts of the government-designed economic monitoring system generally showed improvement, the domestic economy is recovering step by step.
Among the nine indicators used by the CEPD to gauge domestic economic health, three measurements showed record-high annual growth for the first time since the outbreak of the Asian financial turmoil.
The first indicator to have a record high was the M1B money supply, with 9.2 percent annual growth in May.
The second indicator is the stock price index which shed its blue-light indicator for the first time since the Asian financial meltdown. A blue light represents a low ebb.
The third indicator is export growth which regained red-light status for the second time since January, showing Taiwan exports had attained a very robust performance.
By and large, observed CEPD officials, in light of improvements in both economic and financial indicators, the domestic economy has clearly been in the midst of a recovery since May.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: A dramatic day of trading on the Taipei currency market Monday saw the New Taiwan dollar sustain drops against the US dollar at the market's opening, only to end with a slight appreciation.
The NT dollar opened at the day's high of 32.35 to the greenback. It had a low of 32.363 before closing at 32.351, a gain of NT$0.001 against the greenback.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$273 million.

Predictions that the US Federal Reserve Board will tune up interests rates on Tuesday has recently rocked confidence on Wall Street, thus dragging down the US unit on the international currency market.
Local dealers said the greenback's weakness, however, encouraged the buying of major Asian currencies including the NT dollar.

In order to maintain stable export growth, which is grounded on a stable currency fluctuation, the central bank once intervened in the NT dollar trading to prevent transactions from becoming overheated during the session, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG-CHEN TICKET NOT LIKELY: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tan-shun has expressed his support for the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) presidential candidate, making it unlikely that he would agree to be the running mate of former Taiwan Governor James Soong, DPP chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said on Monday during a radio interview.
The Taiwan media recently reported that Soong wants Chen to be his vice presidential running mate in next year's presidential election.

Lin replied that the possibility of a "Soong-Chen" ticket is not "as likely as the public has been conjecturing," since Chen expressed his full support for the DPP candidate, Chen Shui-bian, on Sunday.
In addition, Lin said that Chen Tan-shun has never mentioned his desire to become a vice presidential candidate.

When answering whether he would meet with Chen personally to discuss the matter, Lin said that Chen is a seasoned and respected politician who will not easily change his mind no matter who goes to see him.

Chen does not need "a pat on his head," he said. Besides, he added, the DPP's vice presidential candidate will not be decided until after the party holds its National Congress on July 10 to officially nominate its presidential candidate.
The party's presidential candidate will then appoint his vice presidential candidate, Lin explained, adding that it is too early to discuss who the vice presidential candidate might be.
Lin refused to discuss the split among ruling-Kuomingtang (KMT) candidates, saying it is not his place to comment on KMT domestic problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESCHOOLERS PETITION FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF CHILD AFFAIRS BUREAU

TEXT.P: More than 10 pre-school children petitioned for the establishment of a children's affairs bureau on Monday in the company of dozens of senior executives of human rights promotional groups.

The petition, organized by major women's and children's rights promotional groups, including the Awakening Foundation and the Children's rights Promotion Association, was staged in front of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

The child demonstrators sang songs and played games during the petition to signify their cause, while the adult demonstrators urged the interior ministry to set up a children's affairs bureau before September when local schools will re-open for a new semester.

The demonstrators asked the ministry to clearly define the role and functions of the children's affairs bureau and launch a publicity campaign to educate the public the importance of protecting children's safety and rights.

They also asked the ministry to open special channels for rescuing abused children and hold nationwide children's rights meetings regularly to discuss plights and problems faced by local children's and their families.
In addition, the ministry demanded that the ministry draw up a comprehensive blueprint for protecting children's basic human rights and improving welfare services for them.
Children's rights activists said although the country enacted a children's welfare law in 1973, it has not taken effective measures to protect local kids safety and rights.

An amendment to the welfare law adopted in 1993 provided a legal basis for the interior ministry to set up a children's affairs bureau, but the Legislative Yuan failed to enact an organic law to pave the way for the bureau's inauguration until last week.
"We hope the interior ministry will speed up preparations for the opening of the children's affairs bureau as soon as possible," said an Awakening Foundation executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF HIV CARRIERS INCREASES BY 120 IN THREE-MONTH PERIOD

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) reported on Monday that it has detected an additional 120 HIV carriers in Taiwan between April and June.
Among the newly discovered HIV carriers, 117 are Republic of China nationals and three are foreigners. In terms of gender, 107 are male and 13 female.
DOH tallies show that two of the three foreign HIV carriers are laborers and the third one is an ethnic Chinese restaurateur.

Two of the newly found local carriers were discovered during police spot checks of "special commercial places" which are often linked to the sex trade. One of them formerly served as a male transvestite in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, and the other was an unlicensed prostitute in the Tainan area.
DOH officials urged anyone who has engaged in dangerous sexual activities in the two areas to receive an HIV test at one of the 25 hospitals around the island equipped to provide screening.

During the three-month period, the DOH also detected seven married people who have contracted HIV from their spouses. One of these was a pregnant woman who underwent an abortion after learning that she had been infected, DOH officials said.
So far, the DOH has detected a total of 2,379 HIV carriers here, including 2,139 ROC nationals. DOH tallies also show that 767 of them have since developed full-blown AIDS.

Most noteworthy is that of 38 foreign spouses infected with HIV, 37 were foreign brides from places such as mainland China and Southeast Asia, indicating that the influx of women from these areas poses a threat to public health and causes social problems, the DOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE POLITICAL DISSIDENTS DETAINED IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese police continued to round up members of the outlawed "China Democracy Party" last week, a dissident group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that Li Xian and Xu Guang were picked up by police in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province last Friday, and that Zhang Jian and Liu Jin were missing from their home in Zhangjiakou, Hebei province, last week. The whereabouts of the four dissidents are unknown, it added.

Since early May, nearly 200 dissidents have been rounded up by police. Of them, 27 are still in detention, 30 have been placed under house arrest, and four have been sentenced to prison terms, the information center said.
The would-be opposition party is growing despite relentless government suppression, it said, adding that the party has established branches in 27 provinces.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON CLEAN COASTS HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 1999 International Seminar on Protection of Clean Coasts was held on Monday at the National Sun Yat-sen University in this southern Taiwan port city.
The seminar, presided over by Chiu Wen-yen, a maritime environment and engineering professor at the university, was attended by more than 100 experts from home and abroad.

Addressing the seminar, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said that he places great emphasis on the importance of cleaning up and protecting Kaohsiung's coasts and maritime ecology, given the city's position as a major international port and Taiwan's largest harbor.

Echoing Hsieh's view, Chiu said the protection of marine ecology and the coastline has become a pressing and critical issue for the Taiwan authorities, as ecology and natural resources in the island's coastal areas have undergone major changes as a result of over-development, leading to deteriorating living environments for the people of Taiwan in general.

The Taiwan Maritime Cultural Foundation, which sponsored the seminar, has launched a campaign to promote maritime education among the public, and has already started coast-cleanup operations around the island, said Chiu.
However, he noted that the building of a truly comprehensive marine ecology protection network requires joint efforts from experts, social groups, and the government sector.

Meanwhile, W.C. Chan, secretary of Keelung City's Environmental Protection Bureau, said his northern Taiwan city has made some progress in marine ecology and coastal protection in recent years, ever since the bureau and the private sector started working together on the problem.

Nevertheless, he stressed that it is still necessary to increase public awareness on the issue. He illustrated his point by citing the problems caused to the Keelung Port authorities by the large amount of garbage discarded by the public inside the port area, the island's second-largest harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSENSUS ON PRACTICAL ISSUES WILL HELP IMPROVE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: If Taiwan and mainland China can reach consensus on problems arising from bilateral exchanges before a visit by the mainland's top envoy to Taiwan, it will help improve the relationship between the two sides, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said on Monday.

Sheu called on Beijing to face up to the reality that the problems arising from bilateral exchanges, such as the repatriation of illegal immigrants and smuggling controls, are of major concern to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He also expressed the hope that a delegation from Taipei currently visiting Beijing will be able to help resume two-way talks on these technical issues, in addition to arranging for a visit to Taiwan later this year by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Jan Jyh-horng, vice secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and leader of an SEF delegation, departed for Beijing on Sunday for the second round of talks this year with ARATS to set a date for Wang's visit, provisionally slated for this autumn.

Besides pushing for Wang's visit, Taipei also hopes to rekindle bilateral systematic talks on technical issues which were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in protest against an unofficial visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui in the summer of 1995.

But prior to Jan's talks on Monday with his ARATS counterpart Li Yafei, Beijing stressed that it will continue seeking to hold political talks with Taipei rather than limiting the discussions to technical issues.

Later on Monday, it was reported following the first round of talks that the SEF and ARATS have decided to exchange visits to boost cross-Taiwan Strait activities, with the SEF promising to organize a visit to the mainland in August of a delegation of legal representatives, in exchange for a visit to Taiwan by an ARATS agricultural mission.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO ACQUIRE 50 SU-30 JET FIGHTER-BOMBERS FROM RUSSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 28 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Beijing has concluded negotiations for a purchase of 50 Sukhoi-30 jet fighter-bombers from Russia, with delivery beginning in 2002, according to Monday's edition of the US-based Defense News weekly.

Gen. Zhang Wannian, vice chairman of the Central Military Committee of the Communist Party of China, visited Russia in June and signed a letter of intent with Russia at that time, the magazine reported.

The weekly said that the 50 fighter-bombers, or two squadrons, with a price of US$37 million apiece, will considerably beef up the People's Liberation Army's attack capabilities on the ground and at sea.

Beijing has already purchased 250 Su-27s, but the newly ordered Su-30s will be made entirely in Russia instead of being made in mainland China in a joint venture project, as was the case for 200 of the 250 Su-27s, said the weekly.
A military analyst from the Washington-based think tank the Heritage Foundation described the Su-30 is the Russian equivalent of the US F-15E jet fighter.

He predicted that Beijing will equip the planes with airborne early warning and control systems, an electronic information gathering system, and anti-radar missiles, as well as advanced air-to-surface missiles and anti-ship missiles.

The acquisition of the state-of-art fighter-bombers underlies Beijing's determination to set up an all-weather attack force which will have an impact on the security of Taiwan, Japan, and all states which are in dispute with Beijing over overlapping claims to islands in the South China Sea.

A former military attache at the US Embassy in Beijing pointed out in the weekly that Beijing's procurement of Su-30s is more significant than its purchase of the Su-27s, in view of the new plane's accurate attack capabilities against warships, and its edge over Beijing's indigenous J-7 fighter.
The weekly said Beijing holds the option to order more Su-30s in the deal, and will also probably cooperate with Russia to produce the fighter-bomber in mainland China.
Also included in the deal was an agreement to produce the KR-1 anti-radar missile, an updated version of the Kh-31p missile, in mainland China, the weekly quoted a Russian official as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND HOTEL PRESIDENT QUITS FOLLOWING UNION COMPLAINTS

TEXT.P: Stanley Yen looks set to resign as general manager of the Grand Hotel in the wake of complaints from the hotel's labor union, his aides said on Monday.

Yen is insistent on carrying through his resignation, saying that his mission at the hotel is finished, and adding that he hopes his departure will put an end to the dispute that is poised to further disgrace the once famous and historic hotel, the aides said.

Yen chose to leave the hotel, after 16 months spent helping it regain some of its former glory, when members of the employee union denounced him openly in local newspapers for "emptying the hotel's assets and conducting waves of personnel cleaning."

Yen was defended by the manager of the Grand Hotel's Human Resources Department Fan Hsi-ping, who said the charges were groundless, as the hotel's bank account stood at NT$198 million as of June 30, an amount much higher than 16 months ago.

Fan said the Grand Hotel staff should in fact "be grateful" to Yen for the reforms that have won back some of the hotel's former glory, enticed back prestigious guests, and enabled the Taipei landmark to show a profit.

S.L. Chang, director-general of the Tourism Bureau, and a member of the hotel's board of directors, asked Yen to remain in his post, pointing out that is not up to the labor union to decide whether Yen should stay or go.
"Apparently, the labor union has usurped Chairman Koo Chen-fu's rights on personnel decision-making and has staged political infighting, in which Yen has served as a scapegoat," he said.

The Grand Hotel, the brainchild of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, widow of the late president of the Republic of China, witnessed its darkest hour in 1995 when a fire gutted its famed "dragon roof" and upper stories.

The hotel, founded in 1952 as a state banquet venue, reached its business peak in the 1960s when it entertained many government leaders and celebrities. It was renovated to its present 14-floor Chinese palatial style in 1970.

The hotel, renowned as a "modern architectural delight in a classical Chinese palace style," is now in the hands of a management team chaired by business tycoon Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO SPEED UP REPATRIATION OF ILLEGALS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 28 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China had a second round of talks on Monday afternoon, following which Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) issued a statement urging the mainland to speed up its repatriation process for illegal immigrants.

Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of Taiwan's quasi-official SEF is currently leading a five-member SEF delegation in Beijing for negotiations on a forthcoming visit to Taiwan by Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan.

In the talks with his ARATS counterpart Li Yafei, Jan urged the mainland authorities to abide by the Kinmen Agreement, signed between the two sides in 1990, which stipulated that mainland China should take back illegal immigrants to Taiwan within 20 days of their apprehension.
The SEF also issued a position paper on the issue, the highlights of which are as follows:

-- Mainland China has used all kinds of excuses to delay the 20-day extradition limit, and each illegal currently spends an average of 155 days in Taiwan detention centers before returning home. While over 37,000, have been repatriated, more than 800 remain in detention, some of whom have waited for between two and six years to return home;

-- To alleviate their homesickness, the Mainland Affairs Council arranges phone calls and family visits for the detainees during certain national holidays. However, it is the mainland's failure to keep their side of the Kinmen Agreement which has resulted in the detainees' misfortune;

-- People on the mainland use every means to sneak into other countries, which causes considerable harm to those countries' social security, and has become an international concern. As a member of the global community, mainland China is responsible for restricting its own people's illegal immigration and stepping up border controls; and

-- The illegal immigrant repatriation issue has been discussed repeatedly by both sides, but mainland China unilaterally suspended cross-strait dialogue in June 1995. The SEF hopes to resume negotiations, but before new agreements are signed, the SEF urges the mainland to abide by the Kinmen Agreement and let the remaining illegals return home as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: LESS HONG KONG PEOPLE HAVE CONFIDENCE IN FUTURE: SURVEYS

TEXT.P: The numbers of Hong Kong people having confidence in the future of Hong Kong and in Beijing's "one country two systems" formula are reducing, according to a report released on the eve of the second anniversary of the territory's reversion to Beijing.

The Social Science Study Center of the University of Hong Kong said in the report that, according to its various surveys made during the two years after the territory was handed over to mainland China on July 1, 1997, nearly 72 percent of Hongkongers said in the first year that they were confident about Hong Kong's future, but the average dropped to 61 percent in the second year.

The surveys also showed that, in the first one and a half years after the reversion, 65 percent of Hong Kong people had confidence in Beijing's "one country two systems" formula; the average dropped to 58 percent in the past six months.
Beijing said before the reversion that it would allow Hong Kong to govern itself for 50 years according to the so-called "one country and two systems" formula.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ANNOUNCES NEW AGRICULTURAL IMPORT QUOTAS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) on Monday announced a series of new management methods for the import of agricultural products, to be implemented once the island enters the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The new system will allow the import of 43 types of agricultural products, some of which will have no restrictions on quantity, while others will have a tariff rate quota (TRQ) system which levies low tariffs, mostly at half of the current rates, COA officials said.

All 43 of the items, one of which is rice, are currently banned from being imported into Taiwan, or are subject to import restrictions depending on their origin, in order to protect local agricultural development. The island's WTO accession obliges it to open its market under the WTO's free trade principle.
Rice, the most sensitive item on the list, will still be imported on a strict quota system after Taiwan joins in the WTO, according to new system.
Just 140,000 metric tons of foreign rice, or 8 percent of Taiwan's total rice consumption between 1990 and 1992, will be allowed into the country by 2000.

Twenty-two other products will be imported based on the TRQ system, including sugar, peanuts, red beans, dried garlic, dried mushrooms, dried lilies, betel nuts, coconuts, oriental pears, shaddocks, dried longans, bananas, pineapples, mangoes, persimmons, fish, pork bellies, chicken meat, and offal.
The rest, mostly fruit or goods that Taiwan does not produce itself, will be freed from import restrictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SUMMONS SALVADORAN AMBASSADOR ON VEHICLE OFFENSES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday summoned Ambassador David Panama of El Salvador to explain a serious violation of traffic regulations by an embassy limousine driven by a local miscreant with a long criminal record.

MOFA issued the summons in response to news reports that a Taiwan citizen with 14 criminal convictions drove a BMW limousine bearing foreign diplomatic license plates on June 24 against the traffic and ran a red light in central Taiwan's Nantou County.
Witnesses reported the incident to the police, who in turn informed MOFA when it was found that the limousine belongs to the El Salvador embassy.
MOFA then sent a diplomatic note to the Salvadoran embassy to ask for an explanation, which it failed to receive, prompting MOFA officials to summon Panama on Monday to demand a personal explanation.

Panama apologized and promised to cooperate fully with MOFA. He explained that the limousine was originally parked in the embassy's garage but was driven away by a local driver hired by the embassy. He pledged that the driver would not be hired again, and that he would not allow any repeat of such an incident.
However, MOFA was "very unsatisfied" with Panama's story and asked him to provide a more detailed explanation.

MOFA said that in addition to asking the Salvadoran embassy to provide a more detailed explanation, it will also seek police assistance in obtaining explanation from both the local driver hired by the embassy and the convicted felon to whom the embassy driver apparently lent the car.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY VISITING PRAGUE

TEXT.P: The first lady of the Republic of China Tseng Wen-fui on Monday visited "Vision 97" a charity organization based in the Czech Republic, the Foreign Affairs Ministry said in a press release.
She also met with her Czech counterpart, the wife of President Vaclav Havel, for discussions on the promotion of charity operations.
Tseng later visited a local theater to watch a performance by a Beijing opera troupe from Taiwan.
The wife of President Lee Teng-hui left for Prague on Friday for a private visit, accompanied by Shirley Shaw, wife of ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
Although Taiwan and the Czech Republic maintain no diplomatic relations, they have long enjoyed close and substantial unofficial bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK UNLIKELY TO BE STUMBLING BLOCK IN TAIWAN'S WTO ACCESSION: MOEA

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has promised not to hinder Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) pointed out on Monday.

With the Republic of China finally inking an agreement with Canada on Monday on terms for its entry into the WTO, Hong Kong remains the only member which requested accession negotiations yet to have signed a formal accord with Taiwan on the island's WTO accession terms.

The ROC-Canada bilateral accord was signed in Auckland, New Zealand during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's annual trade ministers' meeting, making Canada the 25th WTO member country to have signed a formal agreement with the ROC.

Although there has been concern that Hong Kong will become an obstacle in Taiwan's WTO accession due to the so-called "Beijing factor," the BOFT pointed out that the former British colony has agreed not to obstruct approval of the ROC working party report which must be submitted during the WTO's 11th working party meeting at the end of July, a BOFT spokesman said.

According to WTO entry regulations, the applicant country must summarize the results of all bilateral and multilateral consultations into a working party report and protocol of accession, for approval through general consensus of the WTO Working Party.
The WTO General Council will then review the package of accession documents through a second stage of general consensus. Once the documents are fully approved, Taiwan's entry will be finalized.
However, if a member country were to cast an opposing vote, Taiwan's accession would then have to pass a two-thirds majority vote of the General Council.

The MOEA has assessed that the third WTO Ministerial Conference, which will be held in Seattle at the end of November, would be the best timing for the ROC's entry, which means that the working party report and protocol of accession must be approved in the near future.

Since the ROC applied for WTO accession, it has signed bilateral accords with South Africa, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Turkey, El Salvador, Columbia, Uruguay, Chile, South Korea, Australia, Iceland, Norway, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, New Zealand, Singapore, the United States, Switzerland, Mexico, Hungary, Argentina, the European Union, Thailand and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER HOLDS TALKS WITH COUNTERPARTS FROM 7 NATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang has held separate talks with his counterparts from seven countries since he arrived in Auckland, New Zealand, on Sunday to attend an Asia-Pacific Economic (APEC) forum ministerial meeting.

In an interview with the CNA late on Monday, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said Wang and his 25-strong delegation requested their counterparts from New Zealand, Australia, Canada, Japan, Mexico and Thailand to support Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
In addition, Wang and his counterparts also discussed trade liberalization among the APEC countries, and the facilitation of tariffs and other issues of common interest, Lin said.

Wang also signed a formal agreement on bilateral market negotiation with his Canadian counterpart, the most important task since his arrival in Auckland, and had a discussion with his Vietnamese counterpart on the issue of bilateral trade agreements and preferential tariff treatment, Lin said.
Wang and his delegates will attend the opening of the APEC ministerial conference on Tuesday morning, and will also hold separate talks with their counterparts from the United States and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING AGREES ITS FRONTMAN WILL VISIT TAIWAN IN SEPTEMBER OR OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Beijing agreed on Monday to Taipei's suggestion of a visit to Taiwan in September or October by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator to the island.

In a meeting between Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his Beijing counterpart, Li Yafei of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Beijing agreed to choose between September 12-19 and October 12-19 for ARATS Chairman Wang's visit, although the exact date might still be moved ahead or postponed a couple of days.
They also agreed that Wang's seven-day journey will start in Taipei and end in Kaohsiung.

Further progress in the one-day meeting was achieved when the two sides agreed on an exchange of visits by delegations before Wang's trip, with a delegation for legal affairs from Taiwan visiting the mainland and an agricultural delegation from the mainland coming to Taiwan sometime between July and August.

During the meeting, however, Beijing stonewalled on Taipei's request to negotiate on issues without political overtones, such as the repatriation of illegal immigrants and hijackers, and the settling of fishing disputes, in parallel with talks on Wang's trip.

Both sides reiterated invitations to the leaders of the two organizations, with ARATS extending an invitation to SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, and the SEF responding with an invitation to ARATS Secretary-General Zhang Jincheng. Both invites were dismissed by the other side.

At a press conference for Taiwan-based mass media after his meeting with Li, Jan said he regretted Beijing's reluctance to restore institutionalized dialogue with Taipei and put the SEF-ARATS work back on track.

Beijing's foot-dragging in this field has seriously obstructed the deportation of illegal mainland immigrants by Taiwan, and has reduced the impact of the Kinmen accord signed between the two parties on this issue in 1990, said Jan.

For his own part, Jan said he rejected a request from Beijing to co-sponsor a non-governmental forum and make it a platform for both parties to air their views on bilateral economic, political, or any other issue.

He restated Taipei's stance that the SEF and ARATS are non-government organizations with a special government mandate, and should focus on bilateral negotiations rather than engage in hosting a forum with no specific purpose which would have to compete with the many private organizations already pursuing the same ends.
SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow earlier this year branded Beijing's advocacy of the forum as a plot to throw a "hand grenade" into Taiwan.

Shi said ARATS is trying to make the forum a "second channel" for dialogue, with the ultimate purpose of replacing the contacts between SEF and ARATS, or at least making it a platform for Beijing supporters in Taiwan to float their pro-Beijing opinions.
Jan and his entourage arrived in Beijing on June 27, and will leave for Taiwan on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25 MILITARY PERSONNEL DISCIPLINED IN RAPE-MURDER SCANDAL

TEXT.P: In addition to a soldier who confessed to raping and murdering a schoolgirl at a military museum, 24 other personnel have been punished for negligence which led to the scandal, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Monday.

Lt. Gen. Soong Li-chuan, administrative vice minister of national defense was reprimanded, and Lt. Gen. Chang Ching-lai, director for the History, Editing and Translation Bureau which supervises the Military History Museum was censured twice and removed from the directorship, said the MND.
Col. Lee Min-teh, curator of the museum, was censured and discharged for dereliction of duty and lack of leadership which gave rise to the irregularity, according to the MND.
Two lieutenant colonels who had abandoned their posts at the museum, and should have been on duty when the case took place on July 19, were court-martialed.

Another four privates, one of whom failed to conduct his guard patrol around the museum, one of whom was absent from his post at the museum during the time of the crime and two others who cleared up the rape scene, thereby destroying the evidence, were also sent for court martial, said the MND.
Another 16 officers, including two major generals, were either censured or reprimanded for negligence in duty, but were spared court-martial, said the MND.
The case occurred on June 19, when a schoolgirl was raped and killed by private Kuo Ching-he while she was visiting the Military History Museum during a quiet period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION VISITS VATICAN
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 28 (CNA) (By Fang Pye-ching and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Vatican secretary for relations with the states on Monday reiterated the Holy See's solid and close relations with the Republic of China, but expressed hope that the Holy See can build a direct communication channel with Beijing for the sake of the millions of Catholics in mainland China.
Jean Rouis Tauvan made the remarks while meeting with a visiting parliamentary delegation from Taiwan led by Wang Jin-pyng, president of the ROC Legislative Yuan.

After the meeting, Wang said Tauvan stressed that the Vatican's biggest concerns are that Beijing should allow mainland Catholic followers to join in Vatican affairs, and that it should allow the Holy See to nominate bishops for mainland dioceses.
Tauvan also extended his thanks for the ROC's US$300 million aid pledge to the refugees of Kosovo, and expressed his hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can reunite peacefully, Wang said.
Tauvan revealed that the Holy See will hold a meeting of bishops in Asia next year, but said the Pope has no plans to visit the region in that year, according to Wang.
The 20-member ROC delegation arrived in Italy on Sunday, the first stop of a four-nation European tour, which will also include Macedonia, Austria and the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Top mainland Chinese negotiator Wang Daohan will visit Taiwan either in mid-September or mid-October.
The China Times:
The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party reached a consensus on the one-month recess of the current National Assembly session.
The United Daily News:

The Liberty Times:

The Commons Daily:
