Senior military officers will be punished following the murder-rape of a high school student at the Armed Forces Museum.
The Taipei Times:
Talks edge toward date for ARATS President Wang Daohan's Taiwan trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSION ACCOMPLISHED, CANADIAN F-18S RETURN HOME

TEXT.P: Four of Canada's 18 CF-18 fighters returned home Monday from the Balkans, having completed their missions in the NATO air campaign against Yugoslavia.
The four F-18s arrived in Bagotville, Quebec. Four more should arrive back in Canada later Monday. Six will remain behind at a base in Italy to continue patrols over Kosovo.
Fewer NATO jets are needed now that the air assault on Yugoslavia has ended. Canadians flew 10 percent of all NATO missions, dropping more than 530 bombs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA A MODEL FOR THE WORLD: PM CHRETIEN

TEXT.P: Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien said Monday Canada is a much more egalitarian country than the United States and should serve as a model for the world.
In an interview with the Cable Public Affairs Channel, Chretien said Canada has done a better job than the United States in balancing administrative responsibilities with social justice.
"We're very different from the Americans in many ways. We have a duty to, and a notion of, unity in diversity," Chretien said.

He added, "The United States tried to envisage that everybody had the same language and the same skin color, but that didn't happen ... We're also a country much more egalitarian than the United States."
After attending a recent meeting of G-8 leaders in Europe, Chretien said he had time to reflect on how fortunate Canadians are to lead a generally peaceful existence.

"When I go to any international meeting and I listen to my colleagues and I discuss with them ... when I get back in the plane, I say 'I'm going back to probably the easiest nation in the world to run,'" Chretien said. "That does not mean that it's easy, but in relative terms, it is."

Chretien said his wish for Canadians this Canada Day would be that they feel proud of their citizenship. "As a Canadian, when I compare myself I feel very good. I want Canadians to feel very good on the first of July 1999."

DOC.HEADLINE: KANGAROO HEARTS CAN BE USED IN HUMANS

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have discovered that aortic valves from kangaroo hearts last much longer in humans than those from pigs, the present mainstay of valve replacement.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday reported that researchers from Fremantle Hospital of Western Australia said when transplanted into sheep, the kangaroo valves do not calcify nearly as quickly as pig valves.
The kangaroo hearts are abundant, energetic, lean and may become the epitome of cardiovascular fitness to repair diseased human hearts, the daily reported.

The daily quoted Dr. Andrew Hodge as saying that, "The kangaroo heart valve is almost identical to the shape of its human equivalent. We also expect it to be more robust than tissue from pigs because of the kangaroo's more active lifestyle and upright posture."
He said the results of the initial 10 valve replacements using kangaroos parts implanted into young sheep two years ago, show almost no calcification. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBLING PROFITS IN AUSTRALIA GREW LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Gambling revenue in Australia increased significantly with profits exceeding A$11 (US$7.3) billion in fiscal 1997-98, led by earnings from poker and gaming machines, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show the 143,000 poker and gaming machines in clubs and pubs netted A$5.7 (US$3.8) billion in the 1997-98.

Bookmakers provided the best payout ratio at around 96 percent while lotteries and the pools had the worst at around 60 percent. For TAB punters (mainly horse racing), the ratio was around 84 percent, according to the ABS figures. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SENATE APPROVES SWEEPING TAX REFORM BILL

TEXT.P: The Australian Senate has passed a sweeping tax reform bill that introduces a 10 percent goods and services tax (GST) for the first time effective July 1, 2000.
Under the GST, the Australian government will impose the 10 percent tax on many products, including textile goods, services, manufactured products and imported products.
But the 10 percent tax, passed on Monday night, will not be levied on any food products except cooked chicken.
The government will use the proceeds to finance major projects, including infrastructure and defense spending.
Under the tax reform package, the government will drop the current wholesale tax and small businesses will be given a handout to cope with the GST.
Businesses welcomed the Senate passage of the GST, saying the tax reform move will sharpen Australia's competition edge in the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEN. ASHCROFT BLAMES CLINTON ADM. FOR CHINESE SPYING

TEXT.P: US Sen. John Ashcroft (R-MO) said Monday that President Bill Clinton and his administration bear major responsibility for grave American intelligence losses to the People's Republic of China, thus jeopardizing the national security of the US.

According to a report in The New York Times on Sunday, former White House Chief of Staff Leon Panetta was briefed on intelligence losses to the PRC in July 1995. He then instructed the Central Intelligence Agency to work with the National Security Council in conducting its investigation.

A member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Ashcroft said, "Even if the White House was first briefed on Chinese espionage in April 1996, senior administration officials took no substantive steps to stop the loss of critical nuclear secrets until February 1998, almost two years later."

"The fact that the White House was briefed on these intelligence losses almost a year earlier than originally disclosed demonstrates near-complete incompetence within the National Security Council," noted the senator.

Although the Clinton administration has sought to portray such intelligence losses as endemic over the last two decades, Rep. Chris Cox (R-CA), chairman of the select committee which reviewed Chinese espionage activities, has stated that "Some of the most significant thefts occurred during the last four years."

Ashcroft continued that "Passing the buck to earlier presidents is unacceptable behavior from an administration that has much to explain in this espionage scandal. The simple truth is that the (Clinton) administration has jeopardized US national security through bureaucratic delay, blatant mismanagement, and a desire to engage Beijing at any cost."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 ANNUAL IT CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) won the right to host the annual global Information Technology (IT) conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Monday.
Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming and Mitac Computers Group Chairman Matthew Miau jointly presided over a preparatory meeting to discuss who will be invited for the conference.
According to Yin, MOEA will provide US$2 million to fund the high-tech conference. Any additional funds needed to host the event will be provided by the private sector.

Previous speakers at the IT conference include former Britain Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and former USSR leader Mikhail Gorbachev. MOFA announced yesterday that invitations to speak at the Taipei conference will be sent to Microsoft CEO Bill Gates and Virginia Governor James Gilmore. (Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT MAINLAND INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: Some 64.8 percent of Taiwanese businessmen with investments in the mainland said a visit by Wang Daohan, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, will help cross-strait trade relations, a survey showed on Tuesday.

The survey, conducted by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), also found that 77.5 percent said that trade issues -- particularly the signing of an investment guarantee agreement -- should be the top priority in cross-strait talks.

The survey found general optimism among local investors in the mainland, as up to 40 percent said they expect to increase their capital investment during the next year, and nearly 76 percent predicted they will turn a profit next year.
Between May 15 and 31 CNFI sent 1,500 questionnaires to Taiwan businessmen with mainland investments. The CNFI collected 152 effective samples.
The survey found that 54.2 percent of those polled said that they made a profit in the mainland this year, while 26.4 percent said they broke even, and 19.1 percent said they lost money.
Compared with a similar survey two years ago, more businessmen reported earning a profit in the new survey and fewer reported losses.
The survey showed that local businessmen have confidence in their investments, as 75.5 percent expect to make a profit next year, an increase from a similar survey last year.
Some 17.1 percent of Taiwan businessmen predicted that they would break even, while only 6.8 percent said that they will have a modest loss.

The major problems encountered by Taiwan businessmen include difficulties in obtaining loans from mainland banks, the extra expenses required for social activities, the frustration of trying to pry open mainland markets, and the adjustment problems that newly arrived executives face.

Taiwan businessmen also said the type of assistance they most hope to get from the government is legal counseling, followed by information on trade in the mainland, and help in obtaining loans from mainland banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF REGRETS BEIJING'S RELUCTANCE TO SET DATES FOR WANG'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Tuesday expressed regret over Beijing's reluctance to set definite dates for top mainland Chinese negotiator Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan later this year.

The quasi-official intermediary body made the remarks after its deputy secretary-general, Jan Jyh-horng, ended a day of intensive talks in Beijing on Monday aimed at setting the stage for Wang's landmark visit to this island.
SEF offered its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- a choice of dates for the trip, Sept. 12-19 or Oct,. 12-19.
ARATS officials, however, did not make an immediate choice, saying they would "report back to their leaders" before giving Taiwan an answer.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Wang's visit would reciprocate a trip to mainland China by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu last October which helped thaw bilateral relations.

SEF said even though it is not satisfied with Jan's inconclusive talks with his ARATS counterpart Li Yafei during his June 27-29 Beijing visit, it will still continue active preparations for Wang's "get to know Taiwan journey" in line with the principles of "safety, comfort, sincerity and constructiveness."

SEF pointed out that Wang's Taiwan visit is of great significance as Beijing has unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue since mid-1995. The suspension has hampered substantiation of the agreements signed during the first Koo-Wang meeting held in Singapore in April 1993.
"We look forward to seeing gradual re-opening of institutionalized SEF-ARATS communications channels through continued dialogue," SEF said in a press statement.

SEF stressed an urgent need to resume systematic consultations between the two intermediary bodies to resolve some practical issues related to the rights and interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, including fishing disputes, repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal mainland immigrants, cross-strait smuggling, protection of Taiwan business people's physical safety and prevention of the spread of animal diseases.
During the just-concluded Jan-Li talks, the two sides agreed to organize professional groups to exchange visits before Wang's reciprocal trip to Taiwan.

SEF said it hopes such exchanges can help boost mutual understanding and resolve some problems arising from bilateral exchanges. For instance, mainland visitors have often deliberately dodged calling at SEF office and relevant Taiwan government agencies. "We hope increased bilateral exchanges will help normalize SEF-ARATS and overall cross-strait interchanges," it added.

As for the ARATS proposal that the two intermediary bodies co-sponsor a seminar on the development of cross-strait relations before Wang's Taiwan visit, SEF said private sectors on both sides have been active in organizing similar activities. In 1998 alone, Taiwan's private groups sponsored more than 100 similar seminars. Against this background, SEF said it does not think that the two organizations need to bother to organize such kinds of events.

SEF went on to say that since the two intermediary bodies are set up to serve the people, they should work together to resolve all practical problems arising from ever growing cross-strait civilian exchanges. "We earnestly hope that ARATS will return to the negotiation table as early as possible to fulfill its obligations under the agreements signed during the first Koo-Wang meeting," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.033 against the greenback on the Taipei market Tuesday, closing at 32.318.
The local currency opened at 32.347, and was traded between 32.28 and 32.353.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$604.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIAL OF COUNCILWOMAN'S ALLEGED MURDERERS TO FINISH IN 45 DAYS

TEXT.P: The trial of four men being charged in connection with the murder of a Taiwan councilwoman in mainland China is expected to be completed in 45 days, sources in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, said on Tuesday.

The trial began at Anshan Intermediate People's Court in northern mainland China at 8 a.m. Monday. The four are being tried in connection with the murder of Lin Ti-chuan, a Kaohsiung City councilwoman and a rising star in the DPP.
Two coroners have been called in to provide testimony, as has Lin's boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang.

Lin and Wei went to the mainland in late July last year. Shortly after they arrived, they were abducted by armed men and repeatedly injected with an unknown substance. Wei escaped and alerted police, while Lin died of a drug overdose at a Haicheng area hospital.

Lin's father Lin Ping-huei, accompanied by a lawyer and a DPP official, went to the mainland on Saturday to attend the trial. He has asked the court to determine the truth behind his daughter's death.
Noting that Li Guangzhi, the alleged mastermind of the abduction, was still at large, Lin has also asked the court to impound the property of Li and his family.
Lin is also seeking compensation of 44 million renminbi (about NT$170 million) from the alleged perpetrators of the crime, the highest amount sought in any case filed across the Taiwan Strait.

Although it is unlikely that Lin will receive the full amount he is seeking, it is hoped that this case will set a precedent for Taiwan crime victims in the mainland seeking compensation in the future.
Lin commemorated his daughter and called on Haicheng City's mayor after the second day of the trial on Tuesday. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC-PROPOSED HASTENING OF MARKET LIBERALIZATION WOULD HURT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's food industry will suffer a serious hit as member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Tuesday proposed fully opening markets by 2004, with regional tariffs on foods being lowered to less than 5 percent.
APEC's previous timetable called for open markets among its developed members by 2010 and completely free markets among all members by 2020.

Trade and commerce ministers and other officials from APEC's 21 member economies gathered on Tuesday in New Zealand for an annual meeting. During the meeting, a proposal to free up trade in oilseed, food, rubber, fertilizer, civilian aircraft and automobiles was high on the agenda.

The proposal, brought up by Australia and endorsed by the United States, suggested all member economies establish by 2004 food markets that are completely free. The liberalization measures would affect vegetables, fruits, alcohol, beverages and raw materials for food products.

In the oilseed sector, APEC proposed total liberalization by 2002 with zero tariffs and all member economies should allow free import of raw materials for food oil, such as sesame and soybeans, together with edible oils.

The average tariffs in Taiwan's food sector is 40 percent, while many kinds of vegetables are import-restricted items. If the liberalization were to take place ahead of its original schedule, it would have a tremendous impact on Taiwan's foodstuff-producing companies.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Council of Agriculture (COA) both expressed opposition to the proposal.
Domestic oil-producing firms would not be able to survive, while the oil-processing industry would lose its competitiveness once Taiwan agrees to the proposal, said the COA.

The proposal to advance free trade in the food and oilseed sectors goes beyond regulations set by the World Trade Organization (WTO), and Japan, mainland China and South Korea are not likely to support it, the COA noted. Taiwan will urge APEC members to pass the issue to the WTO for further discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE REITERATES IMPORTANCE OF KOSOVO AID

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said the ROC will play an increasingly important role in the world community in the 21st century, and aiding Kosovar refugees is a concrete display of Taiwan's participation in global affairs.
Lee made the remarks during a Monday morning reception for high-ranking officials from the Taipei Junior Chamber (TJC).
As Taiwan has developed into a free, democratic and prosperous country, it will play an even more important role in the international community in the next century, Lee said.
Thus, he said, aside from committing itself to domestic developments, the ROC must actively devote itself to participation in international affairs and the fulfillment of its international duties.

He further pointed out that out of humanitarian concerns, Taiwan is willing to offer US$300 million to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes, and this act is demonstrative of the ROC's active participation in world affairs.

Since the Kosovo peace program has received much support and attention from most countries in the world, he stressed, the ROC's participation in the rehabilitation of the Kosovo region is a good chance for the ROC to join in the global community.

In regard to national development, Lee raised three issues that need to be considered: the purpose of national development; the advantages Taiwan possesses; and the methods to be used to achieve national development goals.

Aside from urging the people of Taiwan to reach a general consensus, Lee also encouraged everyone to observe each problem with a broad perspective and to work toward the country's long-term stability and peace.
The TJC members were accompanied by Deputy Secretary-General to the President Hwang Jeng-shyong at the presidential tea reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 29, or the 16th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1620: The UK government bans the growing of tobacco in Britain and a tobacco-growing monopoly is granted to the colony of Virginia, at a tax of one shilling per pound.
1801: The first census is carried out in Britain.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thai revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland, write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law or Eugenics Bill after a third reading.

1994: Japan's Parliament chooses Tomiichi Murayama as prime minister.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ADJUST UPWARD TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH ESTIMATE

TEXT.P: The National Income Statistics Assessment Committee (NISAC) will adjust upward Taiwan's economic growth in August, noted the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Tuesday.
The remark, made by the DGBAS under the Executive Yuan, was a reflection of the fact that most of the island's important economic indicators have shown an improved performance for May.

Figures released Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan showed that the leading composite economic indicator in May surged to its highest point in a year; meanwhile, the coincident composite economic indicator in May also rebounded and hit its highest level since January 1998.

Chou Chi, head of a branch office of the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, observed that the recovery of the domestic economy has been stronger than expected. The Chung-Hua Institute will revise its domestic economic growth estimate upward to over 5 percent from the previous 4.97 percent, he added.

Chen Chang-hsiung, head of DGBAS's Third Bureau, said that in light of the fact that the island's economic resurgence is increasingly clear, it is expected that the NISAC, a lower branch of the DGBAS, in its third meeting in August will adjust Taiwan's annual economic growth to a higher level.
K.C. Lee, vice chairman of the CEPD, noted that the island's annual economic growth will likely reach 5.5 percent, which is the goal set by the government.

As to whether the monetary policy of the Central Bank of China should be kept loose and easy or be tightened, Chou said the current policy should be maintained and that the bank should not adopt a tighter monetary policy, at least for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES RECLAIM 8,500-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 2.8 percent Tuesday to reclaim the psychological 8,500-point level as technology shares led the index upward.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted price index surged 232.82 points to 8,514.27 on a turnover of NT$182.53 billion.
Despite an expected interest rate hike to cool an overheated US economy, Wall Street rallied overnight, resulting in most Asian markets reporting gains on Tuesday.
The local bourse shrugged off last Friday's 300-point drop and closed high on strong buying in electronics shares by institutional investors, dealer said.
Sentiment was also boosted by the index of leading economic indicators, which pointed to a stable economic recovery.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics shares enjoyed the largest gains, rising 4.91 percent, while financial issues climbed 2.24 percent.
Cement issues and chemical issues suffered the largest losses, dropping 0.67 percent and 0.64 percent, respectively.
Gainers outnumbered decliners 253 to 196, with 65 stocks unchanged.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market enjoyed a 5.49-point rise to close at 179.95 on a turnover of NT$8.34 billion.
Boosted by the stock market, the futures market also performed well with all futures closing higher.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July advanced 171 points to close at 8,618 points with 3,720 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August moved up 172 points to finish at 8,625 with 179 contract transactions, while those for September went up 172 points to 8,621 with 26 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December closed at 8,552 after fluctuating between 8,610 and 8,528 points, with 4 contract transactions, and those for next March posted a gain of 171 points to 8,655, with 3 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN DIPLOMAT H.K. YANG IN CRITICAL CONDITION

TEXT.P: Veteran diplomat H.K. Yang was in critical condition Tuesday after developing a breathing problem, doctors at the Tri-Service General Hospital said on Tuesday.
He checked into the hospital June 17 because of a stomach ulcer. During his stay in the hospital, he has developed difficulty breathing and pulmonary edema.
Doctors said that they are doing everything possible to save Yang, who is currently in an intensive-care ward.
Yang, 87, has been dubbed "Mr. Africa" because of his familiarity with African affairs. He has served as vice foreign affairs minister and was ambassador to South Africa between 1979 and 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SOONG TICKET IS STILL LIKELY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has not ruled out the possibility of Vice President Lien Chan teaming up with former Taiwan Governor James Soong in the next presidential election, Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan said on Tuesday.
Chen, a heavyweight in the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who met with President Lee on Monday, made the revelation in an interview in a popular radio talk show.

The physicist-turned-politician said his meeting with Lee was set on June 12 when Lee gave a dinner in honor of Chimei Group Chairman Hsu Wen-lung, a respected tycoon who has constantly called for a cut in government work force and upgrading of administrative efficiency. Chen was also present at the dinner.
During their Monday meeting, Chen, now in his early 60s, said he had asked Lee about the possibility of a Lien-Soong ticket.
"It's possible," Lee was quoted as having told Chen. "After a brief pause, the president further said that anything is possible," Chen recalled.

Chen said he also took advantage of the occasion to clarify speculation that he may serve as Soong's running mate if Soong really breaks ranks with the ruling Kuomintang to run in the 2000 presidential race as an independent.
"I told the president that I has no intention to run for the vice presidency," Chen said, adding that neither Soong nor his aides has ever contacted him over the teaming-up issue.

Asked if he is likely to team up with DPP presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian, Chen said if the former Taipei mayor approached him for the issue, he will carefully consider the offer. "Nevertheless, my answer is very likely to be negative," he added.
Chen said if the ruling Kuomintang manages to field a Lien-Soong ticket, the DPP will face a "very, very tough uphill battle" in the coming presidential election, scheduled for March 2000.

Soong, whose relationship with the KMT leadership has worsened since the central government decided to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government two years ago, has consistently led in public opinion polls as the most favorite choice for the next presidency. Soong has on many occasions hinted that he may run on his own if the KMT nominates Vice President Lien as its standard bearer in the next presidential election.

During their 40-minute talks, Chen said they had exchanged views on the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park now under construction, development projects in Tainan County and domestic political reforms.

Chen said he has suggested that President Lee take the initiative to revise the current election and recall law to prevent criminal ring members or those with criminal records from taking part in parliamentary or local-level elections. "Even Japan has imposed strict restrictions on criminal ring leaders' participation in political elections," Chen stressed.

Chen is now serving his second term as Tainan County magistrate. His diligent, devoted working style and moderate manner have won him much praise and respect. Many of his fans are concerned about his political career after his current tenure.

Chen said he has no intention to serve as the running mate of any presidential candidate. Nevertheless, he said if the next premier invites him to join the new Cabinet following next year's presidential election, he may not turn down the offer so long as his health permits.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORIAN DIPLOMAT CALLED IN TO ANSWER FOR LIMOUSINE'S JOY RIDING

TEXT.P: The Salvadoran ambassador to the Republic of China Tuesday arrived at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in a BMW limousine that last week was spotted running a red light and going the wrong way on a one-way street in central Taiwan.

Local media recently reported that a Republic of China national with 14 criminal convictions on June 24 drove a BMW limousine bearing foreign diplomatic license plates recklessly, swerving into the oncoming lane and running a red light in central Taiwan's Nantou County.
Witnesses reported the incident to the police, who in turn informed MOFA when it was discovered that the limousine belonged to the Salvadoran Embassy.
MOFA summoned Ambassador David Panama on Monday for a personal explanation after an earlier diplomatic note went unanswered.

MOFA Director of Protocol John Feng on Tuesday requested a second meeting with Panama since the ministry was "very unsatisfied" with the ambassador's statement the day before, and asked him to provide a more detailed explanation.
A crowd of press members awaited Panama's arrival Tuesday afternoon at the Foreign Ministry's front entrance. To avoid the reporters, the Salvadoran ambassador entered by the west entrance instead.
Reporters noted that Panama arrived in the same black BMW limousine that had been spotted in Nantou.

Panama declined to answer reporters' questions. While offering no explanation to reporters, Panama said, "This is a big mistake," adding, "There are misunderstandings." He promised that "all will be cleared soon."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 30, or the 17th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were formerly locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1918: Susan Hayward, the American actress who won an Oscar for "I Want to Live," is born.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: American general Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: US President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian astronauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.

1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the Deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The US government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands back Hong Kong to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL GROUPS TO STAGE PARADE TO CALL FOR ABOLISHMENT OF NA

TEXT.P: A number of local social groups formed an action alliance on Wednesday to promote the abolishment of the National Assembly (NA) and the elimination of gang- and money-linked politics.

The alliance's convener and spokesman, Chu Hai-yuan, said the group will organize a massive parade in Taipei on July 24 to push major domestic political parties to heed the public demand for abolishing the National Assembly and suspending elections for NA deputies.
Alliance representatives will call at headquarters of major political parties and meet with the four presidential hopefuls to solicit their support for the cause, Chu said.
"We demand the passage of a constitutional amendment within a month to legalize NA's abolishment and suspension of NA deputy elections," Chu said.
Noting that the NA's existence does not meet the fundamental spirit of democracy, Chu said the expansion of NA's powers in recent years has seriously distorted Taiwan's democratic system.

Worse yet, Chu said, many NA deputies have abused their perks. In addition to a monthly allowance of NT$170,000, each NA deputy can also receive hundreds of thousands of NT dollars in extra income during the annual NA plenary session.
Chu said a large number of public opinion polls here have consistently found that more than 60 percent of local people support the NA's abolishment.
"We hope all those who oppose the continued existence of the NA to stand out and join the July 24 parade to express their common aspiration and opinion," Chu said.

Another convener of the alliance, Shi Ming-teh, a legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said many people have expected President Lee Teng-hui to complete sweeping parliamentary reforms during his tenure. "Much to their disappointment, President Lee seems to lack the willpower or sincerity to do so," Shih said, adding that now is the time for members of the general public to stand up to push for the NA's phaseout and other parliamentary reforms.
Shih said if the NA cannot be abolished this year, it will be even more difficult to realize that goal once the Fourth National Assembly is elected next year.
The alliance said it will launch an islandwide signature campaign to enlist public support for its cause.

The alliance is composed of the Awakening Foundation, the Labor Front, the Taiwan Human Rights Promotion Association, the Taiwan Medical Doctors Association, the Taiwan Professors Association, the National Federation of Lawyers Associations, the Social Legislation Promotion Alliance and several students groups.
