DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT ON MAINLAND DIMINISHES ABRUPTLY

TEXT.P: Investments made by Taiwan businesses in mainland China showed an abrupt decline of over 69 percent in the first five months of this year, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday.
The sharp decline indicates that Taiwan businessmen have turned more cautious than before toward expanding operations on the mainland, MOEA officials said.

Officially approved investments indirectly made by Taiwan businesses on the mainland totaled US$331.55 million in the January-May period for 158 projects, down 68.59 percent in value and 46 percent in the number of investment projects, compared with year-ago totals, according to MOEA statistics.

Taiwan businesses channeled US$1.42 billion abroad for 331 investment projects overseas during the first five months of this year, up 14.6 percent, or US$181.86 million, over the year-earlier level in value, the officials cited MOEA tallies as indicating.
The number of investment projects, however, declined by two from the previous year's 333, they noted.

Meanwhile, according to the MOEA tallies, fresh investments made in Taiwan by foreign nationals and overseas Chinese during the January-May period amounted to US$1.21 billion for 412 projects. It showed a decline of US$44.11 million in value and an increase of 44 in the number of investment projects over year-earlier levels.
In May alone, officially approved investments in Taiwan made by foreign nationals or overseas Chinese totaled 84 in number and US$183.45 million in value.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND HOTEL PRESIDENT INSISTS ON RESIGNING

TEXT.P: Stanley Yen is sticking firmly to his decision to resign as general manager of the Grand Hotel after being attacked by the hotel's labor union for his "work ethics."

Yen announced his determination to give up his post as general manager of the problem-plagued Taipei landmark on Wednesday as he bade farewell to the hotel's core management. He apologized for turning down a request from the hotel's board of directors to stay.
Yen noted, however, that he will relinquish his seat on the board of directors.

He submitted his resignation to the board Chairman Koo Chen-fu a month ago amid complaints from the employee union that he was draining the hotel's assets and conducting waves of "personnel cleansing."
He told Koo that his job of restoring the 47-year-old hotel to some of its original glory is now finished.
Yen was defended by Human Resources manager Fan Hsi-ping, who said that as of Wednesday, the hotel's account stood at NT$198 million, far higher than when Yen joined the staff 16 months ago.
Fan said Yen's reforms have also enticed back prestigious guests and have enabled the hotel to show a profit.

The 14-florr hotel, renowned as a "modern architectural delight in a classical Chinese palatial style," was the brainchild of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, widow of the late president of the Republic of China. It was built in 1952 as a state banquet venue.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUST SHOW THE TRUE FACE OF TAIWAN, SAYS FORMER DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: While Taiwan is hoping to help mainland China's top Taiwan negotiator get better acquainted with the island during a visit here later this year, what he should be shown is a question that requires careful consideration, said former mainland Chinese democracy activist Wu'er Kaixi.

In a letter to the United Daily News' "Reader's Forum" Wednesday, Wu'er, who now lives in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, said the long-expected, much-talked-about visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will finally take place in either September or October of this year.

Taiwan had envisioned the visit as a "get to know Taiwan trip," but this idea has been rejected by mainland authorities, who have said the visit should only be a high-level talk between the two sides, Wu'er said.

The mainland Chinese response caught the Taiwan people and officials of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) by surprise. They cannot understand why the mainland is so insistent, and they are once again experiencing the conservative and rigid style of the Beijing regime, Wu'er said.

Wu'er, a prominent student leader in the Tiananmen Square incident of 1989, said he personally believes that the visit here will allow Wang, a person who has definite influence on Beijing's policymaking toward Taiwan, to get to know Taiwan.

If Wang were to get to know Taiwan, it would be of great significance to cross-strait relations, which have been at an impasse over the last five decades, Wu'er noted. In addition to decades-old historical and political rifts, Wu'er said misunderstandings and a lack of communication have also contributed to the cross-strait stalemate.
Whether Beijing agrees to Taiwan's suggestion that Wang's visit be a "get to know Taiwan trip," it is up to Taiwan to allow Wang to really get to know it, Wu'er said.
Arranging for Wang to gain a better understanding of the island is a highly demanding and challenging task, Wu'er said.
He said it would be a bad idea for Taiwan to seek to show off its economic prowess.

As a long-term rival to Taiwan, mainland China knows about Taiwan's economic wealth only too well, Wu'er said, adding that he believes that any attempt by Taiwan to show off its wealth will backfire. It will only trigger a larger degree of defiance by the mainland, he said.

Wu'er said it would be a good but impractical idea for Taiwan to seek to show off its democratic achievements. It will be impossible to provide Wang with an in-depth understanding of Taiwan's democratization in only seven days, he said.
A mainlander who personally witnessed major changes and human rights retrogression on the mainland, Wu'er said he sincerely hopes Wang will be allowed to see for himself the true face of Taiwan.

Let Wang see ordinary Taiwan people, he said. Let him see the daily life that an ordinary government employee leads; let him see how a young man in Taiwan has made his dream come true by starting his own business.
Let Wang feel for himself that Taiwan is full of concealed energy, and let him feel that living in Taiwan is not something to be soiled, Wu'er said.
Let him experience all the things that, while taken for granted by the people of Taiwan, are sought after and wished for by the people of the mainland, Wu'er said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices dropped 0.6 percent on Wednesday as investors locked in profits from the previous session's gains.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index dipped 46.90, ending the day at 8,467.37 points on a turnover of NT$194.92 billion (US$6.03 billion), up from the previous session's NT$182.53 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, only the paper and pulp sector and electronics shares registered gains, rising 0.56 and 0.32 percent, respectively.
Plastic and chemical issues and financial stocks suffered the session's heaviest losses, losing 2 and 1.68 percent, respectively.
Losers outnumbered gainers 266 to 196, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market posted a 1.33-point decrease to close at 178.62 points, with a turnover of NT$8.31 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for July fell 59 points to close at 8,555, with 2,884 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for August went down 60 points, ending at 8,565, while those for September declined 66 points to close at 8,555. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 172 and 26, respectively.

December futures enjoyed the only gains of the day climbing 17 points to close at 8,569 points, with five contract transactions. Futures for next March suffered a 59-point drop to end at 8,596, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL TO MEET FORMER GOVERNOR OVER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang said on Wednesday that he will meet with former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong before mid-July for talks on the ruling party's plans for the 2000 presidential elections.
Chang has apparently altered the schedule of the meeting with Soong from mid-August to mid-July, a move widely believed to be a turnabout in the KMT's presidential election strategy.

Following up on reports from a day earlier that President Lee Teng-hui, the incumbent KMT chairman, has hinted at the possibility of fielding a "Lien-Soong" ticket, Lee was asked again by reporters on Wednesday about the probability of naming Soong as Vice President Lien Chan's running mate, but he evaded the question, saying only "take a wild guess."
Soong has been at loggerheads with the KMT policymakers since late last year after the central government moved to downsize the provincial government.

Confident that the people will always be with him, Soong has made no secret of his intention to run for president in next year's election. However, he emphasized recently that he will be running as a KMT candidate rather than an independent.
Meanwhile on Wednesday, a group of KMT members from central Taiwan traveled to KMT headquarters in Taipei to appeal to the party leader to consider a "Lien-Soong" ticket.

They said only a "Lien-Soong" ticket can win a triumph for the ruling party in the elections. If the central hierarchy of the party do not listen to the people and take action soon, they will risk triggering the indignation of all party members and the general Taiwan public, they warned.
KMT spokesman Huang Hui-cheng said that while it has been agreed that Lien will represent the KMT as the presidential candidate, no party decision has yet been made on his running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST SQUADRON OF MRT POLICE SET UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first squadron of mass rapid transit police will be formally set up in Taipei on Thursday, at a ceremony presided over by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

The 100-man task force, the first-ever of its kind in Taiwan, will be in charge of maintaining order and safety along the 41.16 kilometers of Taipei's current four-line mass rapid transit system, as well as in its three generator houses and 39 stations.
As the system expands in the coming years, the manpower of the squadron will also be gradually increased, Taipei Police Headquarters said on Wednesday.

Captain M.C. Chen, chief of the new squadron, said that in addition to setting a good example of "horizontal cooperation," he also wishes to enhance the image and integrity of the police force, as well as its ability to maintain public order and strengthen its services to Taipei citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CUSTOMS TO EXAMINE TAIWAN'S TEXTILE MANUFACTURERS

TEXT.P: The US Department of Customs is to send a mission to Taiwan from August 2-20 to examine textile manufacturers on the island, following a previous investigation in September last year, officials of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday.
The department stressed to the Taipei authorities that the main job of the mission will be to investigate the illegal transshipment of textiles, BOFT officials disclosed.

The manufacturers under investigation will not be notified in advance that they are to be investigated by the US team. According to the current textile trade agreement between Taipei and Washington, both sides are supposed to prevent illegal transshipments.

In the investigation which took place last year, several local manufacturers made mistakes in questionnaires they were required to answer, while others were discovered to have given false information regarding manufacturer's names in the quota certificate for textile exports to the United States.

It was also discovered that some manufacturers failed to keep records of production data, arousing doubts in US customs which resulted in textile products from many Taiwan manufacturers being refused entry to the United States.
The BOFT called on local textile manufacturers to cooperate with the US mission, and to keep abreast of the situation, so as to avoid any misunderstanding.
US customs noted that it is estimated that over 90 percent of illegal textile transshipments to the United States are connected to people of Chinese ancestry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER BETWEEN MOTOROLA AND ASE APPROVED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission (FTC) on Wednesday approved a merger between Motorola Electronics Taiwan Ltd. and Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc. (ASE).
FTC Vice Chairman Liu Chung-jung said the commission's evaluation shows the merger will benefit Taiwan's economic development more than it will harm market competition.

Liu said the merger will integrate the two companies' production lines in designing, manufacturing, packing, and testing integrated circuit (IC) products, a move which will create commercial opportunities for silicon wafer manufacturers.

The deal will also help the island's efforts to improve its IC and IC-related manufacturing, Liu said, adding that ASE's takeover of a semiconductor operation division of Motorola will also help maintain stability in the local labor market.

Under the terms of the merger, ASE will buy out Motorola's semiconductor operation division, which employs 1,500 people. After selling the business Motorola will no longer be involved in IC packing and testing in Taiwan.
ASE will increase its current 26 percent market share in the IC packing and testing sector to 33 percent as a result of the merger, according to the FTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: 44 NEW FISH SPECIES REPORTED IN TAIWAN SINCE 1981

TEXT.P: Researchers have found 44 new fish species in the waters around Taiwan in the last 18 years, Director Shao Kwang-tsao of the Institute of Zoology of Academia Sinica said on Wednesday.

Shao reported that using funding provided by the Cabinet-level National Science Council, Taiwan researchers have since 1981 published the discovery of 60 new fish species, although they later found that only 44 of the recorded species are indigenous to Taiwan waters alone.
Shao noted that of the approximately 25,000 fish species found around the world, those indigenous only to Taiwan total 2,450, or about one-tenth of the world's total.
Compared with the size of Taiwan, at less than 0.3 percent of the world's landmass, the figure illustrates the richness and diversity of Taiwan fish species, Shao said.

This diversity, he said, is largely a result of Taiwan's geographical location -- at the northern rim of the East Indian islands, as well as on the rim of the world's biggest continental shelf, and at the confluence of the East China Sea, the South China Sea, and the Philippine Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN HAILS ROC AID TO KOSOVO
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 29 (CNA) (By P.C. Fang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's US$300 million aid pledge to Kosovo has aroused positive international resonance, according to Vatican Foreign Minister Jean-Louis Tauran.

During a meeting with a visiting parliamentary delegation from Taiwan on Monday, Tauran expressed appreciation on behalf of the international community for the aid extended by the ROC to the Yugoslavian province, stressing that the move has added to Taiwan's international integrity.

Tauran also told the delegation leader, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, that formal diplomatic ties between the ROC and Vatican remain stable, and dismissed the pressing question of whether the Holy Sea will soon set up official relations with Beijing.

In addition to attending a luncheon banquet hosted by a pro-Taiwan group in the Italian parliament, the ROC legislative mission, accompanied by ROC Representative to Italy Hung Chien-chao, also paid a visit to Italy's lower house on Monday afternoon and had dinner with a dozen local opinion leaders that evening.

During the dinner party, Wang voiced the hope that the Italian parliament will support the ROC's bid to join the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization, and invited Italian parliamentary members to visit Taiwan.

Such parliamentary visits can help reduce the gap among Taiwan's various political parties, thus helping build a new culture in Taiwan's parliament and improve its image among the public, according to Wang.

The delegation arrived in Rome on Sunday for a three-day visit. It left on Tuesday for Vienna en route to Macedonia, the ROC's new diplomatic ally in Europe and the major stop on the mission's European tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 OUT OF EVERY 100 CONSCRIPTS HAVE CRIMINAL RECORD

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Wednesday that 14 out of every 100 new military conscripts have a criminal record, which inflicts heavy pressure on the management of the armed forces.

Tang made the statement while attending an end-of-semester ceremony at Chingmei Girls High School in suburban Taipei to offer his apology again for the rape and murder of a Chingmei student by a conscript at the Armed Forces Museum in downtown Taipei earlier this month.

Tang said he appreciates the school authorities offering him another opportunity to express his heartfelt apology to the school's 3,000-plus faculty members and students for the rape-murder of Chang Fu-chen at the museum on June 19.

Tang said private Kuo Ching-ho's cold-blooded crime has left a scar on the minds of all Chingmei teachers and students, adding that the crime has also made them lose trust in the military and confidence in the safety of local society.

"I myself and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) must assume full responsibility for this tragedy," Tang said, adding that the military will streamline discipline and improve its management techniques so that Chang's death will not have been entirely in vain.

In addition to extending an apology to Chang's parents, Tang said, the MND has punished 24 military officers and enlisted men for their negligence which led to the tragedy. The military will also mete out a harsh penalty on the murderer in accordance with the law as soon as possible, he added.
This was Tang's second visit to the school since the incident. He paid his first condolence visit last Friday.
Chen Fu-kuei, the school's president, said all faculty members, students and their parents applauded the MND's responsible attitude toward handling the situation.
Nevertheless, he still handed three letters to Tang to express the teachers' and students' heartfelt sorrow over Chang's death.
Chingmei students said in their joint letter that they used to consider the Armed Forces Museum "a sacred place." Now, however, "the museum has come to represent only pain in our hearts and minds."
The letter also expressed the hope that military and civilian agencies will work together to create a safer and more secure living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S YOUNGEST SENATOR OF CHINESE ORIGIN BECOMES PENSIONER

TEXT.P: Bill O'Chee, the youngest senator in Australian history, is leaving politics on Wednesday to become the country's youngest political pensioner.
The 34-year-old National Party senator will walk away under the Australian pension law with benefits worth almost A$1.4 million (about US$933,000) after nine years and one month of service.
O'Chee was elected to the federal Senate at the age 24, becoming the youngest politician in Australia. He failed to get re-elected in the Oct. 3 election. His tenure ended June 30.
The outgoing senator was not available for comment on whether he would return to his previous job as a merchant banker.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEGAWATI OPPOSES EAST TIMOR INDEPENDENCE, FEARS FLOOD OF REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Megawati Sukarnoputri, the presidential front-runner in Indonesia, has made it clear that she opposes independence for East Timor because she fears an influx of East Timorese into Indonesia if the territory were to choose independence, according to Australian media.

Rival factions in East Timor have agreed to lay down their arms ahead of a UN-supervised ballot in late August to decide the future of the territory as a mob of about 100 pro-Indonesia militia members armed with clubs and rocks attacked the UN outpost in East Timor on Tuesday, injuring at least seven people, including a South African electoral officer, according to The Australian.

The Sydney Morning Herald quoted Kwik Kian Gie, a key adviser to Megawati, as saying that the leader of the PDI-P believes East Timor could not be separated from Indonesia easily after 24 years of being under Jakarta's rule.
Megawati, a staunch nationalist, said she was worried that many pro-independence Timorese would be forced to flee East Timor if they chose independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU TOLD TO EXPLAIN DEBATE OVER US

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji has come under pressure from a group of conservative deputies who want him to appear before the NPC's Foreign Affairs Committee to explain the downturn in relations with the United States, The South China Morning Port reported Wednesday.
According to the report, Zhu has also been criticized for policies ranging from enterprise reform to mainland China's efforts to join the World Trade Organization.

Since former Premier Li Peng became NPC chairman last year, the legislature has been more aggressive in asking ministers to account for policies, particularly those deemed unsatisfactory, the report said.
"Conservative NPC members want an explanation on why the US should 'target' China and what the government has done to prevent the country from being bullied," the report quoted sources as saying.
The sources said that while hardliners had Li's support, they were in the minority and that it was unlikely Zhu would be forced to comply.
"Though Zhu is head of government, it is president Jiang Zemin who is in charge of foreign policy," the sources said.
"However, while the premier can probably be spared a date at NPC, attempts to get him to appear have already proved an embarrassment," the same sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSERVATIVE WEEKLY SAYS US MUST STAND UP TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Now that Slobodan Milosevic has lost the war in Kosovo, it is time for the United States to start paying serious attention to a far more dangerous dictatorship in Beijing, checking mainland China's ambition of intimidating US allies and someday forcing the United States out of Asia, according to the latest issue of The Weekly Standard.

The Washington-based conservative magazine wrote in its editorial titled "From Belgrade to Beijing" that most Americans learned the right lesson in the Kosovo conflict: Appeasement of dictators is a disastrous error. Even former US Balkans envoy Richard Holbrooke now admits that the Clinton administration "made numerous mistakes" in dealing with Milosevic.

The evidence of the mainland Chinese government's hostile intentions, both with regard to its own people and to US interests worldwide, is overwhelming. Anyone who knows the mainland Chinese dictators understands that they want to increase their military capabilities in order to achieve their ambition of intimidating US allies and someday forcing the United States itself out of Asia, said the editorial.
The weekly magazine said that what is shocking about this is that the truth has so far barely dented the comfortable bipartisan consensus supporting the continued appeasement of Beijing.

In early June, President Bill Clinton announced his intention to renew "most-favored-nation" (MFN) status for mainland China. When Congress votes on MFN in the next few weeks, will Republicans stand up and send at least a symbolic message that they will not accept business as usual with the Butchers of Beijing, any more than with the Butchers of Belgrade? asked the editorial.

It said that the big American corporations will also try to block the tightened export controls recommended by the House's Cox committee. Will Republicans have the nerve to place national security and national principle above trade?

It happens that the American people would support such an effort, wrote The Weekly Standard. A new poll by the Pew Research Center shows only 29 percent of Americans agreeing that the United States should grant MFN status to mainland China, with 57 percent opposed.

Even though advocates of engagement have succeeded in changing the term MFN to the supposedly more salable "normal trade relations," it turns out that 32 percent of Americans say the United States should grant "normal trade relations" status to Beijing, with 54 percent saying no, added the editorial.

The weekly continued that the US victory in Kosovo came after many years of inattention to and appeasement of Milosevic's tyranny. Thankfully, the United States and NATO were so strong and Milosevic so weak that the allies could prevail even after what Holbrooke acknowledges to be the Clinton (and Bush) administrations' many mistakes.

But the editorial stressed that "Our margin for error in the case of China is smaller. The longer we appease Beijing and pretend it is some kind of 'strategic partner,' refusing to acknowledge the reality that China is in fact a serious strategic competitor, the greater chance that someday -- maybe soon, maybe a decade from now -- we will pay the price for our fecklessness."

Holbrooke said last week in the Senate hearings for his nomination as US ambassador to the United Nations, "Had the United States responded vigorously and appropriately early in the (Balkan) crisis, we might have avoided three of the four wars that the Belgrade dictatorship has caused."

The Weekly Standard concluded that the best way to avoid a future crisis with mainland China is not to appease it, "but to respond 'vigorously and appropriately' while there is still time to check Beijing's ambitions, preserve peace, and strengthen the forces of reform in China."

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU CALLS FOR CLOSER LOOK AT TAIWAN'S VALUE AND FUNCTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 29 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday called on the Pacific rim countries to faithfully recognize the Republic of China's role and functions in the region as a "preserver of peace, vanguard of democracy, promoter of prosperity."
Hu made the call in his speech delivered at a meeting of the North California World Affairs Association.
Hu also urged his American audience not to view everything about Taiwan from Beijing perspective, nor to drag Taiwan into issues between mainland China and the United States.
Noting that the ROC looks forward to developing cordial relations with the United States, Hu said Taipei-Washington ties should never be affected by rifts between Beijing and Washington, D.C.

Hu pointed out in his speech, titled "Take a Closer Look at Taiwan," that the ROC can offer valuable contributions to future regional peace, democratic development, economic prosperity in the Asia-Pacific as well as to international disaster and humanitarian relief efforts.

The minister went on to say that Taiwan should be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) as early as possible. Given its economic strength, Hu said, Taiwan should even be admitted to the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other major global financial organizations to facilitate its fulfillment of international obligations, sharing of international responsibility and contribution to overall global economic development.

Hu said Taiwan's WTO membership application should be considered purely in terms of its own economic strength and system and should not be affected by political considerations. "We hope to enter the body by the end of this year," he added.

Hu further said Taiwan has found the right path toward modernization. "Our experience can provide inspiration for mainland China and other developing countries," he noted, adding that for developed countries, Taiwan can serve as a valuable partner in the pursuit of regional and global advancement.
Touching on recent rifts between Beijing and Washington, Hu said the ROC has no intention to get involved in mainland China-US relations.

Stressing that Taiwan-US and US-mainland China relations are two parallel sets of bilateral relations, Hu said Taiwan hopes its interests and rights will never be hurt by any developments or incidents in Beijing-Washington engagements.
Hu also said as long as the Taiwan Strait can maintain peace over the next 10 to 15 years, mainland China's social and political systems will inevitably undergo significant changes.
Emphasizing the ROC's aspiration for peace, Hu said the Asia-Pacific region should establish a comprehensive security mechanism to minimize regional tension and facilitate relevant security dialogue.

This was the first time that Hu managed to deliver a public speech to a major US group since he assumed his current post. More than 250 politicians, academics, journalists and Chinese community leaders in the Bay area attended the meeting.
Hu also attended a North American Taiwan Chamber of Commerce meeting in Chicago before coming to San Francisco. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Friday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES TO FOUR-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar moved up NT$0.014 in value against the greenback on Wednesday, closing at 32.304, the highest level for the past 10 weeks.
Continuing weakness of the US dollar on the international market attributed to the NT dollar's appreciation, as well as that of the Japanese yen and other major Asian currencies.
In addition, active inflow of foreign funds into the local stock market also benefited the NT's rise in value, dealers said.
The local currency opened at 32.302 and was traded between 32.259 and 32.304.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$422 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR CRITICIZES PARTY POLITICS

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Wednesday derided party politics in Taiwan, saying the problem is that "no party is willing to shoulder its responsibilities."
Continuing an islandwide series of visits to his grassroots supporters, Soong received his by-now usual warm welcome from followers in the Taipei County townships of Linkou and Taishan.
He reiterated the importance of the will and the needs of society at the grassroots level, and slammed the increasing discrepancy between the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the people's sentiments.
Politicians should not "write empty checks" to the people during election campaigns, Soong stressed, referring to KMT promises during last year's county magistrate and city mayoral elections.

Noting that during the last election campaign every candidate promised to build an international airport within their jurisdiction, Soong joked that it was lucky not all of them won the elections, otherwise the skies would be full of colliding planes.
He stressed that "sincerity is the only ticket" to persuade the public and make them believe that the government will serve the people and solve their problems.

He was also at pains to point out that the "party transcendence" he advocates does not negate the value of political parties, but places the emphasis on the appointment of officials according to their abilities, regardless of party affiliation or ethnic background.

Soong said that his goal for the future is to uphold national security, ensure the safety of women, children and students, revive the domestic economy, and wipe out inequality, so that everyone, and not only a small group of privileged elite, will enjoy the country's benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED FOUNDATION TO SET UP HOSPICE FOR AIDS PATIENTS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan charity has proposed founding a sister organization which will in turn set up a hospice for the homeless and for terminally ill AIDS patients, a spokesman for the Garden of Hope Foundation said on Wednesday.

Garden of Hope, which has long been concerned about the plight of the island's AIDS victims, said that it will hold a fund-raising dinner on July 2. This will be followed with a charity auction of works by famed photographer Chen Shen, as well as works produced by AIDS patients and their nurses. The money raised will be used to found the Garden of Mercy Foundation.
The initial target for the fund is NT$5 million (US$154,321), the foundation spokesman said.

At a press conference to announce the setting up of the Garden of Mercy Foundation, officials of the Department of Health, as well as those from the government and private sectors, appealed to the public to demonstrate their compassion by donating funds to the foundation which will be dedicated to helping AIDS sufferers.
The DOH estimated that as of the end of June, 2,379 people in Taiwan have tested HIV positive, the precursor of full-blown AIDS.

Actor-turned-social volunteer Sun Yueh said at the press conference that although Taiwan people are generally warm and caring, people diagnosed with AIDS are destined for a miserable life, shunned by their families and society.
The plan of the Garden of Mercy Foundation to set up a hospice for AIDS victims will enable these people to end their days in tranquility and with dignity, Sun said.

Chang Li-yu, a social worker at National Taiwan University Hospital, also spoke about her experience of caring for AIDS patients, the problems faced by the families of AIDS patients, and those faced by the nurses who take care of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUPS DEMANDS ARMY TO STEP UP SEXUAL EQUALITY EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Women's rights groups from across Taiwan on Wednesday demanded that the military step up its sexual equality education in view of the armed forces' long-term "paternalism" as displayed in the recent rape-murder scandal at a military compound.

A Taipei high schoolgirl was raped and murdered by an army private at the Military History Museum on June 19. The incident has caused a public uproar, with the military being strongly criticized by the media for lax discipline.
Chou Hui-ying, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday called for a public hearing to fully investigate the incident.

Chou blasted the Ministry of National Defense (MND) for having "bureaucratic" and "male chauvinistic" sentiments, after a ministry official allegedly asked, "What problems can a public hearing into the case solve?" in response to Chou's call for an investigation.

As a representative of females in Taiwan, Chou said, she must uphold an even stricter standard in supervising government agencies. She also demanded that the government take effective measures, and not let the tragedy repeat itself.

Wang Ju-hsuan, chairman of the Awakening Foundation, a local women's rights group, pointed out that while Defense Minister Tang Fei has issued a public apology and held an emergency meeting to tighten military discipline, women's groups do not need an apology for individual cases.

Rather, they want a military that respects women's safety, Wang said, adding that she hopes the armed forces and the public learn a lesson from the incident so that the victim will not have died in vain.

The foundation's secretary-general Chen Mei-hua said that the rape-murder incident at the Military History Museum revealed a lack of safe learning environment and the military's long-term disrespect towards women.
She urged the military to learn from the tragedy and reconsider how its men are taught to have greater respect for the female gender and sexual equality.

Lee Yu-kun, assistant deputy chiefof MND's Human Resources office admitted that in the past, the military lacked comprehensive rules on women's issues. But with the increase of females in the armed forces, the MND has established strict codes of conduct for both sexes in army barracks, he said.

After nearly a year of implementation, he said, the MND is still worried that the norms might not be thorough enough, and has set up a special committee to interview female military personnel from all over the island for suggestions on improvements.
Lee also stressed that the military already has stringent standards on sexual harassment offenses; violators are court-martialed, while less serious offenders are censured or removed from the post.
The military will mete out speedy and clear-cut administrative punishments, he said, adding that a 24-hour hotline number has been posted in each military unit to answer reports of misconduct.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO BID SHOULD BE CONSIDERED SEPARATELY : US OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The bids by Taiwan and mainland China for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) should be considered separately and on their own merits, said US Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Pacific Affairs Stanley Roth on Tuesday.

Speaking at a luncheon hosted by the Washington-based think tank Institute for International Economics, Roth said that it is Washington's long-standing stance that Taiwan should be granted WTO membership once it meets WTO requirements.
However, the WTO reaches decisions through consensus and Taiwan should understand that there are factors other than the Taiwan-United States relationship which affect its WTO application.
The United States will not block Taiwan's entry into the WTO, and before mainland China does, it should take into account obstruction's impact on Taiwan-mainland China relations.
Although Taiwan has finished all bilateral negotiations with WTO members on the terms of its entry, Taiwan's access is still in doubt due to Beijing's opposition.
Beijing, whose application has been blocked by Washington due to trade and diplomatic disputes, insists that Taiwan not be admitted into the WTO until it's own membership is granted.
Roth also explained his usage of the term "interim agreements" in a speech in March.

Noting that technical agreements on minor aspects would not do a whole lot to improve cross-strait relations and that the time is not yet appropriate to resolve the entire range of Taipei-Beijing issues, Roth said in his speech , "it seems to me...it is in the interest...to look for something in between which would have the advantage of being able to address significant issues, more than technical issues and less than a comprehensive resolution."

He reiterated that the current US policy -- that the US not act as a mediator, negotiator, intermediary on cross-strait issues and that all issues should be solved by the two parties themselves -- dates back to the Reagan administration.

Roth said he hopes the two parties use the visit in the fall of Wang Daohan -- Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan -- to attempt to make significant progress that brings some momentum to cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO WILL CERTIFY TAIWAN HAS ERADICATED POLIO NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) next year is expected to announce that the Republic of China (ROC) has eradicated polio from the island, an official from the Department of Health (DOH) said on Wednesday.

Tu Hsing-tze, DOH director of the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said that one of the conditions to meet WTO confirmation is a vaccination rate of over 80 percent. The ROC currently maintains a vaccination rate for polio, tetanus, and German measles of 90 percent.

Tu said that there has been no confirmed cases of polio since 1982, and that no suspected cases have occurred since 1991. Taiwan has also established a notification system to report any outbreak of the communicable disease.

He said that the ROC has sent related documents to a WHO committee for screening. Barring any political impediments, Taiwan is expected to be listed in the ranks of nations that have eradicated polio starting next year.
Tu said his department's next efforts will be aimed at eradicating tetanus and improving the standard of public health to that of an advanced nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL PROMOTE PEACE AND PROSPERITY IN ASIA-PACIFIC REGION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 29 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) will continue to play a constructive role in promoting peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region, the ROC representative to the United States Stephen Chen said Tuesday.
Chen made the remark at a seminar during the World Forum conference held June 25-27 in Colorado. The conference was organized by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research.

Chen introduced a seminar on the current situation in Asia during the third day of the conference. Other seminars were introduced by US Secretary of Defense William Cohen, US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, and US Representative Christopher Cox.

Cohen analyzed the security situations of major Asia-Pacific nations. He said the US would continue to maintain a military presence in the Asia-Pacific region in a bid to ensure regional stability and shore up US interests.
Cohen also explained the importance of the theater missile defense (TMD) plan at a panel discussion on the topic. He stressed that the TMD will be conducive to security in the region.

At the panel discussion on the theft of US nuclear technology and other secrets by Beijing, all participants agreed that Beijing's intensified development of its nuclear weapons posed a threat to global security. The theft of other secrets also has harmed US interests, the panel concluded.

Christopher Cox, the author of a recent report on mainland China's stealing of US nuclear technology, stressed that the US should help the ROC maintain its security according to the Taiwan Relations Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLOW 'GLOBAL QUOTA' SYSTEM FOR WTO MEMBERS EXCEPT US

TEXT.P: Taiwan will begin a "global quota" system starting Thursday, allowing the import of livestock products from World Trade Organization (WTO) member countries except the United States, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday.

Under the system, Taiwan will allow the importation of 9.163 tons of chicken, 1,160 tons of pork belly, 2,500 tons of pork offal and 5,000 tons of beef offal from WTO members excluding the United States.

Taiwan last year agreed to allow the import of 10,000 tons of chicken, 5,000 tons of pork belly, and 7,500 tons each of pork and beef offal from the United States annually prior to WTO entry under the "down payment' system.
To further facilitate its entry into the WTO, Taiwan implemented the global quota this year.
BOFT officials said that any Taiwan importer interested in receiving part of the quota goods should submit an application between July 12 and July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MIN. HOLDS TALKS WITH US, RUSSIAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday held separate talks with his US and Russian counterparts at the conclusion of the two-day APEC forum ministerial conference in Auckland, New Zealand.

In an interview with CNA, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said Wang, the leader of the 25-member Chinese Taipei delegation, discussed the agenda for the upcoming Sino-US sub-cabinet economic dialogue with Deputy US Trade Representative Richard Fischer.
That meeting will be held in Taipei on July 16.

In another meeting, Wang and his Russian counterpart discussed the possibility of cooperation in the bio-technical and aviation fields between the two countries. The Russian minister showed interest in a ROC proposal, Lin said. Russia is strong in both areas and the ROC would benefit from any cooperation, he added. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA FEARS PROTECTIONIST US CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Canada's top trade official said Tuesday that a protectionist Congress and a shift of economic power to the south and west of the United States are among the greatest cross-border challenges faced by Canada.
International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi made the remarks upon emerging from a Cabinet meeting in which discussions focused on Canadian-US relations.
The United States absorbs a whopping 85 percent of Canadian exports, as almost C$1 billion worth of goods crosses the longest undefended border in the world between the two countries.

Marchi said Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and US President Bill Clinton continue to enjoy a warm relationship. But Congress is another matter, he said, citing recurring disputes over Canadian softwood lumber and agricultural exports.
"You have a very protectionist, inward-looking Congress, where surprisingly too many congressmen don't even own a passport.
"It gives you a sense that they are happy with America and that they don't concern themselves with anything exterior to America," he told reporters.
Marchi termed that a "very dangerous attitude for congressmen to take ... a very harmful position for the international community."

He also noted that economic power has been shifting within the United States from the north and northeast to the south and southwest -- away from the Canadian border and long-standing Canadian commercial ties.

"What that means is we've got to get to know a whole part of the United States. ... We have to take a look at a whole new north-south axis from the one that we've been traditionally used to," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATORS MEET WITH ITALIAN PARLIAMENTARIANS IN ROME
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 29 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China (ROC) parliamentarian delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, met with Italian parliamentarians in Rome on Monday.
According to the ROC delegation, both sides agreed to strengthen exchanges of parliamentarians in the future.
The visitors from Taipei called on the Holy See's foreign minister on Monday morning before visiting the Italian House of Representatives.
A House member told the delegation that Rome-Taipei relations have been strengthened thanks to the efforts of the ROC Representative to Rome, Joe Hung.

The ROC side expressed appreciation to the Italian Parliament for adopting a resolution calling for a peaceful solution to the conflict in the Taiwan Strait after mainland China test-fired missiles near Taiwan in 1996.
In addition to Wang, other members of the ROC delegation were Chang Chun-hsiung, Tseng Yung-chuan, Lai Shih-pao and Tsai Chung-han.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATED AA+ BY STANDARD AND POOR'S

TEXT.P: The US ratings agency Standard and Poor's rated the Republic of China's (ROC) long-term foreign currency credit "AA+" on Wednesday, indicating its belief that the country has a high capability to fulfill its financial commitments.

The ratings were released by Standard and Poor's joint venture on the island, Taiwan Rating Corp., which also gave the ROC an "A-1+" for short-term foreign currency credit; an "AA+" for Taiwan's long-term local currency credit; and an "A-1+" for the country's short-term currency credit.
The series of evaluations produced a stable outlook for Taiwan's debt repayment, according to Standard and Poor's.

The rating report praised the ROC's public sector for only carrying small amounts of external debt. It also indicated that the total amount of external assets in the Taiwan banking system and its central bank's international reserves surpasses the country's foreign debt.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves reached US$95 billion in mid-1999, the world's third largest, following that of Japan and mainland China. The figure also outnumbered the total amount of Taiwan's short-term foreign debt by 240 percent, marking that the island is supported by a solid financial foundation, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG'S TAIWAN VISIT WARMLY WELCOMED BY FM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday said Taiwan most gladly welcomes the mainland Chinese top negotiator to Taiwan, Wang Daohan, for an autumn visit, and that the ROC will make the "most proper" arrangements for his Taiwan tour.
Hu extended his welcome in his speech delivered at a meeting of the North California World Affairs Association in San Francisco on Tuesday.
Hu said in his speech titled "Take a Closer Look at Taiwan" that some people in the United States have suggested both sides of the Taiwan Strait sign so-called "interim arrangements."

However, he said, the ROC maintains that certain issues pertinent to the rights of people on both sides of the strait, such as fishing disputes, joint crime-prevention efforts and the repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants, should be dealt with first.

The ROC hopes to resolve these issues and sign agreements with mainland China as soon as possible since the signing of these agreements can be a basis for future negotiations on more important issues.

Like building a pyramid, Hu said, one must begin from the bottom and add one block at a time. After the foundation has been consolidated, it will add to mutual trust and lead to a more stable relationship, he said.
Hu also said that as the Asia-Pacific region develops, major challenges emerge. Hu listed the three most profound and influential elements facing the Pacific rim as follows:
- The economic crisis incited by the Asian financial storm has not yet passed, and the problems remaining in each countries' economic system are still in need of fundamental solutions.

On the subject of regional peace and stability, Hu said that tensions on the Korean Peninsula, disputes over the sovereignty of the Spratly Islands and the instability across the Taiwan Strait could all explode at any moment.

Aside from a few existing bilateral security cooperative structures, he said, the Asia-Pacific region still needs a "truly effective" comprehensive and multilateral security dialogue mechanism that enables each side to establish a consensus for peace and to prevent conflict through regular dialogues.

Hu said the mechanism does not need to exclude any specific regional member, nor does it need to view any regional member as an hypothetical target; its aim should be to provide a channel for complete expression and exchanges of worries and suggestions concerning regional peace and stability.
Even if a consensus cannot be reached through this dialogue mechanism, at least the mechanism will offer a means of communication ,he said.
Hu pointed out that the ROC can offer valuable contributions to future regional peace, democratic development, economic prosperity and international aid efforts.
The speech was Hu's first to a major US group since he assumed his current post. More than 250 politicians, academics, journalists and Chinese community leaders in the Bay area attended the meeting.
Hu also attended a North America Taiwan Chamber of Commerce meeting in Chicago before coming to San Francisco. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Friday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET AGENCIES OPEN OFFICES IN NANTOU

TEXT.P: The office compound of former Taiwan Governor James Soong will officially reopen Thursday as the central Taiwan offices of the 16 Cabinet ministries and agencies.
The offices in Chunghsing New Village, Nantou County will be manned by the staff of the former provincial government. The ceremony will be presided over by Premier Vincent Siew.
The opening of the central government's office will also mark the execution of the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Chang Che-shen, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration under the Executive Yuan, said that the downsized Taiwan Provincial Government will initially keep 905 former workers, although the staff will gradually be reduced to 285.

In addition to the 1,327 workers who have either voluntarily retired or quit with favorable severance pay, another 124,041 Taiwan Provincial Government workers will be assigned to staff the Cabinet's new central Taiwan offices, said Chang.
Chang said the downsizing will not affect the public's benefit in any way as reduced levels of bureaucracy boost government efficiency.
The Examination Yuan will also open its central Taiwan office in the same office compound in a separate ceremony Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MINISTERIAL MEETING BENEFICIAL TO ROC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China scored fruitful results from its participation at the two-day APEC ministerial meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, the spokesman for the Chinese Taipei delegation said.

In an interview with CNA, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said the first achievement was that ROC delegates held separate talks with their counterparts from nine countries, including the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and Thailand. They all fully supported the ROC's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), he said.
The second achievement was that both Vietnam and Russia agreed to upgrade their economic cooperation with the ROC.
Lin said Russia was particularly willing to share its advances in biotechnology and aviation with Taiwan.

In addition to the liberalization of trade in industry and agriculture through e-commerce, the benefit the ROC received from the APEC meeting was that all ministers agreed to urge the WTO to take into account APEC work to liberalize trade in six sectors, including food, fertilizer, oilseed, aviation and automobile.
"This will give some breathing space to our local industries because it will allow three years to liberalize all six sectors, instead of requiring immediate liberalization," Lin said.
Wang and his delegation were entertained by more than 300 overseas Chinese in New Zealand, including many migrants from Taiwan on Wednesday night, Lin said.
Wang and Lin will meet with New Zealand parliamentarians on Thursday morning before heading back to Taipei. PETER CHEN

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS LAUD DEFENSE MINISTER AS RESPONSIBLE

TEXT.P: Lawmakers on Wednesday praised National Defense Minister Tang Fei for being responsible and straightforward in handling the scandal surrounding the recent rape and murder of a schoolgirl in a military museum.

At a press conference, legislators Tsai Ming-hsien and Lee Wen-chung, both of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Kuomintang lawmaker Chi Tzeng Li-chen criticized the lax discipline in the military and demanded that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) rectify the situation.
However, all three applauded Tang for acting responsibly and courageously in handling the incident.

Tsai noted that during the time he served as convenor of the legislature committee on national defense over the past three years, he has received at least 10 petitions per year relating to serious injuries, accidental deaths or sexual harassment in the armed forces, which he said illustrates the problem of lax discipline.
He further pointed out other discipline problems which have long existed in the armed forces, such as excessive drinking.
The problem is so serious that even legislative assistants have been subject to harassment, Tsai claimed.
Tsai urged the MND to set up and implement discipline reform measures, and in the meantime set up a channel for dealing with sexual harassment.

Chi Tzeng threatened to review the MND's budget to prompt the ministry to find out how the incident could have been allowed to occur, while Lee urged the arm forces to change its methods of dealing with such problems and set up a panel to deal with similar cases.

Lee added that there is also a need to greatly shorten the period of compulsory military service, to implement professional psychological counseling in the army, and to make the system of courts martial more transparent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH INSURANCE GROUP TAKES OVER HUNG FU LIFE INSURANCE

TEXT.P: Department of Insurance director Cheng Chi-shih under the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Wednesday that the financially strapped Hung Fu Life Insurance has been taken over by British conglomerate the Prudential Corporation.

Prudential is a well-known global insurance group and the biggest in Britain. It has assets of US$190 billion, with US$18 billion-worth of annual premiums collected from its customers, a figure larger than Taiwan's overall insurance premiums.
Cheng said he expects that Prudential's takeover will benefit the local insurance market.

With the takeover, Hung Fu's original insurance contracts will remain effective, and the employees will keep their jobs, Cheng said, adding that apart from a new owner, basically there will be no other changes for the company.
The first general manager of the new company will be Lian Chia-chu, a high-ranking Prudential official.
Hung Fu's problems created panic among hundreds of thousands of its customers when news of the company's financial difficulties broke at the beginning of this year.
